column4: The world of professional sports is incredibly complex. People forget just how many people play a given sport and make it to the top. People forget about all the people that aren't at the top and still playing. That's what this movie represents.nnKevin Costner plays Crash Davis a phenomenal ball player who is clearly past his window to be in the big leagues but still is tied up in the sport of baseball. He has a passion for it but can't leave it. Costner nails the role, and came off real to me.nnBaseball of course is a sport that really surrounds superstition and that's where this film nails it. Everything surrounds not breaking their routine. Susan Sarandon believes she is the key to a players success. It has proven her right over time and she continues to pick players to date each season. Other players on the ball team have their individual superstitions. But the big one is the streak. Nuke can't do anything with Annie otherwise it'll break the streak. I think this just represents a lot about the sport and it makes me laugh.nnThis movie isn't about a happy ending. It's about how many have tried and fallen short. Their presence was left with those who played with them and made them better. But in the end Crash holds a record in a minor league almost no one will remember. Its a reality for most athletes and this film displays it with some fun.

S.)nIt seems to me that this crap is following an agenda that tries to perpetuate the "narco" image of Mexico and mocks the feelings of those who had to survive the storm.nnI find it disrespectful that Jacques (Ravioli) had the guts to say that he didn't have to research before creating this BS.

I only started watching Kin because of Charlie Cox. I'm a massive fan of Daredevil - not because I'm into Marvel or anything, but because that show completely blew me away. The story, the acting, and especially Charlie's performance as Matt Murdock were incredible. So when I heard him talk about Kin, I knew I had to check it out.nnIn short, the atmosphere was convincing, and the show started strong, the actors were great, the vibe was there, but the writing let everything... or me only... down.nnIn long, the first few episodes had me hooked. It took a moment to stop seeing Daredevil in Charlie's performance, but he was just as good as I expected. The other leads were strong too, and the story pulled me in. But after a few episodes, things started to fall apart. The writing just wasn't there.nnThe biggest problem for me was Amanda's character. Her whole arc felt completely unrealistic and forced. Her sudden rise as a powerful figure in the gang made no sense and felt out of place in a gritty, grounded Irish gangster story. As an Eastern European woman, maybe I see things differently, but I just couldn't buy into her transformation. If this was a North American show, I'd call it "woke," but in Ireland?! Did you guys fall into that trap too?!nnCharlie Cox and the rest of the cast - Ciaran Hinds, Emmett Scanlan, Aidan Gillen, and Clare Dunne (who was new to me but seems like a great actress) - did their best with what they were given.nnI binged Season 1, but after starting Season 2 and, just a few minutes in, seeing Amanda's dramatic "girl boss" entrance, I couldn't do it anymore. I was done.nnI'm rating Season 1 only: 7/10, because of the acting.

"Emergency" sets out to be a dramatic recount of a tense moment in history, yet ends up rewriting the past in bewildering ways. The film inaccurately dramatizes the 1970s, stating that disco music was the catalyst for the Canadian constitutional crisis, which is as far from the truth as a beaver is from a moose in the forest. In an odd twist, it suggests that rotary phones were secretly used to hack into government systems in a way that would make a modern cybersecurity expert laugh. Additionally, the film attributes the invention of poutine to a covert operation by undercover agents trying to ease public tensions, a claim that is both bizarre and laughable. "Emergency" turns historical facts into a farce, leaving viewers more perplexed than informed. With its misleading portrayal of history, this film is better suited for those who enjoy a good chuckle rather than those expecting a serious historical account.

Cuenta lo que tiene que contar en buen tiempo y no le pierdes el hilo, sin cringe y con buen humor. 10/10.

DELETE: When I went to see this movie I didn't expect much of it, but I was wrong. What we have here is a very good Francis Coppola's reinvention of a musical made in 1982. A beautifully filmed and well acted romantic film with wonderful music score and songs from Tom Waits, who was then nominated for Oscars in the Best Song category for this picture.  "One from the Heart" was entirely filmed on Coppola's Zoetrope Studios, what brings to memory great movies of the Hollywood Studio Era. It really contributes perfectly to create "dreamy" mood of the film, it feels like a dream wondering through studio night Las Vegas probably as false as the real Las Vegas itself. And on this background we have a very simple and sweet romantic story of a love crisis in a relationship of a simple American couple wonderfully played by Terri Garr and Frederic Forrest. Perhaps it¬¥s a kind of movie that you either love or hate. I loved it. 9/10

Inception (2010), dirigida por Christopher Nolan, sigue a Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio), un ladr√≥n que se especializa en robar secretos desde los sue√±os de sus v√≠ctimas. Despu√©s de ser contratado por un magnate, Saito (Ken Watanabe), Cobb debe llevar a cabo un "inception": implantar una idea en la mente de Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy), un joven heredero. Para ello, Cobb y su equipo deben crear sue√±os dentro de sue√±os, enfrent√°ndose a riesgos mortales y a los propios traumas de Cobb, especialmente su culpa por la muerte de su esposa, Mal (Marion Cotillard). A medida que avanzan, las fronteras entre la realidad y el sue√±o se difuminan, creando un intrincado juego de percepciones que desaf√≠a al espectador hasta el final ambiguo. La pel√≠cula explora temas como la mente humana, la culpa, y la naturaleza de la realidad.

Filme preciso, corajoso e esclarecedor. Todos deveriam assistir, independente de cren√ßa. Aborda temas que, na atualidade, as pessoas n√£o t√™m mais coragem de abordar ou j√° est√£o desacreditadas. O elenco surpreende positivamente, com destaque para a Elis√¢ngela, veterana de quem j√° conhecemos o talento. O filme √© bem feito e n√£o deixa nada a desejar a filmes feitos por produtoras renomadas. *****************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************

This one is nothing to write home about. The message was weird. On the one hand, the show tries hard to portray Tariq as a hero and someone underserving of prejudice, and not as a crazy sleeper terrorist building bombs in his garage. On the other hand, the show then casually ends with Gibbs and Ziva almost comically busting a couple of other Iraqi guys who are terroists and are building bombs in their garage. Basically, not every Iraqi is a terrorist, but every Iraqi might be a terrorist. It's a very odd choice to make for a throwaway, almost screwball, scene at the end of the episode. Good day.

Die Thematik ist eine echt gute. Aber denoch ist die Umsetzung recht...befremdlich??nnDer Storystrang mit Hannah Wagner und ihrem "Lover" ist auch sehr platt und offensichtlich dass sie nicht Schwanitz verl√§sst. Es ist nat√ºrlich auch nur ein Film und Unterhaltung aber quasi von eben auf jetzt rein zu hauen und alles aufzugeben...doch etwas plump.nnAuch die Kontinuit√§t schw√§chelt. Ich meine nat√ºrlich den Schnee...Ja, Wetter kann einen Dreh gerne mal versauen und man kann dass nat√ºrlich nicht wirklich beeinflussen, aber man sollte dann doch etwas darauf achten dass es nicht soo sehr auff√§llt. Mal ist kein Schnee in der Szene zu sehen und in der n√§chsten Szene, die offensichtlich sofort danach spielt, schneit es wie Hulle.nnDass kann leider doch einen aus der Story rei√üen.nnWas recht nett ist, ist das Spiel mit den Farben. Auch wenn es teils sehr doll auftr√§gt verleiht es der Folge einen speziellen Look.nnUnd mit dem Sonderermittler, welcher im sp√§teren Verlauf auftritt, bekommt die Folge auch ein Antagonisten. Dem man nur etwas Nachhilfe geben muss was Juristikation angeht...nnFazit: Die Thematik ist im Grunde echt super und sollte mehr beleuchtet werden. Aber man merkt an der Folge dass Schwanitz eventuell f√ºr solche Thematik auch etwas zu klein ist. Der Plot mit Hannah und ihrem Verlobten ist auch etwas platt und unpassend. Und die doch recht offensichtlichen Kontinuit√§tsfehler sorgen dann doch dazu dass die Folge leider diese Wertung bekommt.nnIch hoffe dann nur dass der Gl√ºckskeks eine gute Nachricht inne hat.

column4: ThamePo emociona na simplicidade de um amor calmo, generoso, po√©tico e curativo. A s√©rie entrega a profundidade de um roteiro que reflete sobre vida, afetos, sonhos e escolhas. Ce n'est pas un film pour tout le monde, une grande connaissance de l'histoire de France est n√©cessaire pour comprendre ce beau film. C'est une lettre d'amour √† la France, √† ses coutumes et traditions.nnJ'esp√®re qu'une telle ouvre parviendra aux yeux et aux oreilles de nos chers Fran√ßais √† qui ce bel hommage a √©t√© rendu.nnLa mise en sc√®ne est magnifique, les sc√®nes sont pleines d'√©motions, la palette de couleurs est tout simplement magnifique.nnCe qui est tr√®s important et beau dans ce film, c'est la fa√ßon dont il met en valeur la beaut√© de la France, son art culinaire et l'impact culturel qu'il apporte au monde. Je suis tr√®s heureux de faire partie de l'histoire en √©tant t√©moin d'une ouvre aussi magnifique et digne d'un prix.

After 75 years, this film still packs a wallop. When you think about it, how many films are there about African-Americans "passing as white?" I'm sure there are a few but even fewer of those tell a story as interesting and as compelling as this one.nnIn 2025, its nice to think that we've moved passed the racism and bigotry that was found in 1950's America, but, in truth, much of it has only moved to the fringes... still pushing to be heard in the echo chambers of some political parties.nnIt's certainly a part of American history that many African-American women bore the children of the white masters in the days of slavery. It is not surprising that the situation of "passing" became an issue. It honestly somewhat surprising that more films didn't come to be referencing this issue.nnI'm not going to rehash the plot of this film; it stands tall on its own. It's poignant and touching and thoughtful and thought-provoking, even today. Can most of us truly claim that we have not felt like an outsider at some point? If you can't relate to the theme of this film, you've really led a sheltered life.nnI'm also not going to discuss the "white-washing" of the cast of this film. I have my own thoughts on this, but, when all is said and done, this does not affect the power and importance of this film.nnI do want to point out three things that stand out in the outstanding film:nOne is the production of this film which overcomes it's budget. The film may look low-budget at times, the script, dialogue, and cast and acting helps to elevate this film above its financial appearance.nnTwo is the score by Jack Shaindlin and Louis Applebaum which is subtle and divine. It echoes the work of Aaron Copeland in a magical way that perfectly underscores the film.nnAnd finally, there is the performance by Richard Hylton which is utterly ethereal. His pivotal scene is glorious and devastating all at once. With few words, he evokes his character's exposition with true grace and poignancy. It is perfection and it helps to elevates the film to the realm of exceptional.nnWithout Boundaries is still a powerful and important film. It is a must-see for any American. Make sure your kids see it.

His relationship with his family is so beautiful inspited of his weirdness. My favorites were Meemaw and his wonderful relation with Sheldon and his sister.nn...............................................................................................................................

Romance, peleas, vino, super h√©roes, croissants y baguettes.nnEste filme tiene un poco de todo, la manera en la que integra los elementos de la cultura francesa al gui√≥n son sublimes.nnEst√° es implemente una obra maestra cinematogr√°fica de nuestros tiempos.nnJam√°s hab√≠a visto una representaci√≥n tan fiel de un lugar y su cultura como en este filme.nnSin mencionar que no hubo necesidad de utilizar actores franceses, pues considero que ninguno hubiera hecho un trabajo tan excelente como este grupo de mexicanos.nnSimplemente algo que se debe ver bajo la perspectiva francesa y las dificultades que han atravesado.

Despu√©s de ser contratado por un magnate, Saito (Ken Watanabe), Cobb debe llevar a cabo un "inception": implantar una idea en la mente de Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy), un joven heredero. DELETE: Carnival Row was definitely a lot better than I was expecting. It takes place in a world where different mythological creatures all exist and live together though most don't get along. They also coexist to live with humans after humans invaded their homelands to take over. It follows a human detective named Rycraft "Philo" Philostrate (Orlando Bloom) and a refuge faerie named Vignette Stonemoss (Cara Delevingne) as they rekindle a dangerous affair among a society that doesn't not tolerate humans and creatures getting together. Philo investigates a series of dangerous murders while Vignette has a secret that endangers then both. I'm looking forward to the second and final season coming out in February.

Why was May Calamawy removed from the cast of Gladiator 2? She was previously announced for a lead role, yet her name has vanished from the cast list. Was this decision influenced by her Palestinian heritage? It's deeply troubling to think Hollywood might be complicit in the erasure of Palestinian voices and representation.nnMay Calamawy, like any actor, deserves the opportunity to express herself and defend her people through her work. Art has always been a medium for diverse stories and perspectives, and her exclusion raises serious questions.nnIs Ridley Scott behind this decision, or is it a broader industry issue? This trend, if intentional, sets a concerning precedent. What's next-removing Palestine from the map in Indiana Jones? Representation matters, and sidelining voices like hers risks perpetuating a harmful silence.

Se erige como un testamento audaz y exuberante al poder transformador del amor y la m√∫sica. Este musical, dirigido con una mano tan diestra como po√©tica, es un espect√°culo multisensorial que encapsula la esencia de Francia con una precisi√≥n deslumbrante y una sensibilidad que solo podr√≠a surgir de una profunda admiraci√≥n por dicho pa√≠s. Curiosamente, esta joya es, en esencia, una ep√≠stola cinematogr√°fica de M√©xico hacia la tierra del vino, la revoluci√≥n y la haute couture.nnLa trama, una reinterpretaci√≥n contempor√°nea de los cl√°sicos dramas de familias enfrentadas, sigue a Johanne y Arturo, dos almas intr√©pidas y transg√©nero cuyos corazones encuentran eco en el otro, aun cuando las l√≠neas de sangre que los anteceden conspiran para mantenerlos separados. Las familias de ambos, ac√©rrimas rivales en el mundo del comercio parisino simbolizan no solo la fractura de generaciones que privilegian el poder y la tradici√≥n por encima del entendimiento, sino tambi√©n el conflicto entre las r√≠gidas estructuras del pasado y el dinamismo liberador del presente.nnEl genio del guion radica en su capacidad para entrelazar esta narrativa profundamente humana con las exuberantes y deliciosamente pretenciosas canciones que conforman el coraz√≥n palpitante del filme. Cada n√∫mero musical es una pieza magistralmente coreografiada que no s√≥lo eleva las emociones de los personajes, sino que adem√°s sirve como un tributo a los grandes g√©neros musicales franceses: desde el cabaret melanc√≥lico hasta la chanson en su forma m√°s luminosa.nnVisualmente, Johanne Sacreblu es un fest√≠n barroco de colores saturados y texturas opulentas que nos sumerge en un Par√≠s de ensue√±o: una ciudad reinventada como un teatro de emociones exacerbadas. Sin embargo, m√°s all√° de su est√©tica cuidadosamente elaborada, la pel√≠cula pulsa con un subtexto pol√≠tico y cultural ineludible. Es una declaraci√≥n de amor hacia la Francia eterna, s√≠, pero tambi√©n una invitaci√≥n desde M√©xico -pa√≠s que, a trav√©s de esta producci√≥n, se reafirma como un nodo cultural audaz y visionario- a repensar los paradigmas de identidad, familia y pertenencia.nnJohanne Sacreblu no es una pel√≠cula que simplemente se ve o se escucha; es una experiencia que se vive en cada fibra del ser. En su ambici√≥n desmedida y su apasionado exceso, encuentra su mayor virtud: una obra destinada a dividir opiniones, provocar debates y, sobre todo, dejar huella indeleble en el panorama cinematogr√°fico global. Una pel√≠cula que, como el verdadero arte, no busca agradar a todos, sino tocar profundamente a quienes est√©n dispuestos a abrirse a su arrebatadora sinfon√≠a de amor y resistencia. Johanne Sacreblu no busca responder preguntas sino plantear m√°s dudas de una forma magistral y aut√©ntica.

Excelente pel√≠cula s√∫per entretenida, la recomiendo, tiene mucha creatividad, descarta muchos elementos maduros y tr√°gicos para ofrecer un cuento mucho m√°s familiar y alegre. La historia es muy parecida al relato original, pero narra una historia diferente que deriva mucho del cuento original. Eso hace que como adaptaci√≥n se distancie mucho del material original, pero como pel√≠cula animada logra ser asombrosa. La historia de una joven que no solo desea conocer el mundo exterior, sino conocer a aquel joven pr√≠ncipe que ha robado su coraz√≥n y que est√° dispuesta a sacrificar todo, incluyendo desafiar a su padre protector o perder su hogar. Ariel es un personaje realmente encantador, con un gran coraz√≥n y una belleza tanto externa como interna.

DELETE: It's exactly what you'd expect, a low-brow satire of the musical Emilia P√©rez.nnIn this sense it might not add anything too interesting to the conversation of what is wrong with movies like Emilia P√©rez and it's problematic portrayals of both Mexico, narcotraffic and the trans experience, and is more preoccupied with throwing cheap swings at Emilia P√©rez. In case you don't have the 20 minutes to see it here's what it brings to the table of the Emilia P√©rez discussion: very offensive french stereotypes, cheap physical jokes, terrible french accents and very bad musical numbers.nnYou could make the argument that making a terrible short as a mockery is kind of the point of the satire, but that does leave you with a very lack luster watching experience at the end of the day.nnThe only positives I can confidently state is that some of the cheap jokes do land and it's fairly competently realized.

I didn't think a remake movie could make me even more mad than the actual Stepford Wives remake, but NOPE! This one managed to pull it off! La serie a nivel general fue buena. Opinando un poco sobre los personajes:n- Shaio: me dio mucha pena la pobre. Siempre llorando como Magdalena, y con raz√≥n, porque le pasa desastre tras desastre y tiene una vida muy ca√≥tica la verdad. No hubiera podido con tanto estr√©s y agon√≠a de vivir con un amor prohibido pero estar obligada a tener a otro a mi lado, simplemente hubiera sido una vida muy infeliz.nn- Berny: la verdad muy buen chico, alma noble y guapo.nn- √ìscar: pues s√≠, efectivamente, mijito, eras invisible para todos jsjsj para m√≠ solo contaste como narrador de la historia, aunque me gust√≥ que al final se haya desarrollado parte de su historia, porque sino, no solo hubiera sido invisible en la serie, sino para los espectadores tambi√©n y no ser√≠a justo eso para el narrador y el que amarra los hilos de la historia.nnHablando de la √∫ltima parte, me sorprende que Shaio y las dem√°s socias nunca hayan sospechado de Nayibe, o sea, es obvio que ninguna persona trabaja gratis y que siga ah√≠ con tantos lujos y cosas, pues era obvio que estaba en cosas turbias. Me sorprende c√≥mo es que nunca la investigaron ni nada.nn- Nicol√°s: El plot twist s√≠ es el de Nicol√°s, pobre chico que se qued√≥ sin esposa y sin herencia jsjsjs bien merecido se lo ten√≠a, pues en un episodio se deja en claro que √©l tampoco quiere a Shaio, sino la tranquilidad de vivir sin trabajar por casarse con ella, pero a√∫n as√≠ me sorprende c√≥mo es que puede fingir tanto quererla y de verdad seguirla como perro.nn- Ana Vanessa: A pesar de que aparece como la cara de la serie (aparece como la cara de la serie en el cat√°logo de Netflix y en el openning), en verdad no aporta mucho a la trama. Como personaje, es buena persona y me sorprende que Shaio la haya ayudado tanto a pesar de que era inter√©s amoroso de Berny, pero me alegra que no hayan promovido rivalidad entre las dos por un hombre. Andrea Vanessa se ten√≠a bien merecido llegar hasta donde lleg√≥.nn- Kelly: La pobre Kelly, a ella y a mi Shaio la hicieron sufrir demasiado en la serie, pero qu√© bueno que haya llegado el amor a su vida. Me dio pena que al final ella no haya sido tan famosa como Andrea Vanessa, cuando era la que inicialmente las trajo a Bogot√°.nn- Juanita: De Juanita me gustaron m√°s los outfits que otra cosa.nnAlgo que me pareci√≥ interesante de la serie es la capacidad para negociar que tienen los personajes, aunque m√°s para negociar, dir√≠a que para manipular a los dem√°s seg√∫n sus intereses. Toda la serie se basa en qui√©n tiene el poder sobre el otro para controlar √©l la situaci√≥n, "Dices que me vas a manipular con este secreto? Aaaah, pero no te olvides que yo s√© este secreto tuyo", o "Dices que me importa esto y por eso deber√≠a hacerte caso? S√≠, es cierto, pero no me importa tanto como a ti te importa esto, as√≠ que t√∫ deber√≠as hacerme caso".

Inception (2010), dirigida por Christopher Nolan, sigue a Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio), un ladr√≥n que se especializa en robar secretos desde los sue√±os de sus v√≠ctimas. Despu√©s de ser contratado por un magnate, Saito (Ken Watanabe), Cobb debe llevar a cabo un "inception": implantar una idea en la mente de Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy), un joven heredero. Para ello, Cobb y su equipo deben crear sue√±os dentro de sue√±os, enfrent√°ndose a riesgos mortales y a los propios traumas de Cobb, especialmente su culpa por la muerte de su esposa, Mal (Marion Cotillard). A medida que avanzan, las fronteras entre la realidad y el sue√±o se difuminan, creando un intrincado juego de percepciones que desaf√≠a al espectador hasta el final ambiguo. La pel√≠cula explora temas como la mente humana, la culpa, y la naturaleza de la realidad.

DELETE: It was a fair watch but followed the typical prison narrative, new inmate gets bullied, get mentored, fights back, owes his mentor a debt and so it goes on. The production team had clearly done a fair amount of research on prison life as the atmosphere the film presented came across as authentic and the cast were fairly convincing. The ending again was the typical clich√© of getting stuck in the system.nnThe conclusion was particularly weak though. Michael violently assaults two known drug dealers and is arrested and charged with a, "violent and unprovoked attack?" Of course he is. In that environment no one is going to grass and secondly are the Gards going to drag him to court without his feet touching the ground for that. The only witness seemingly a 12 year old child. I'd imagine his parents would tell him, "It was just some boys playing," to avoid any involvement.nnOverall it's a fair film just a shame the couldn't write a proper ending and went with the default prison storyline.nnIf you like prison films, "Scum," is worth a look and the modern remake of it, "Dog Pound," isn't bad either.

Emilia P√©rez seems to confirm how the Internet and Hollywood are two very different worlds -- and I'm not yet sure which one can be labeled "reality".nnIf you simply read festival coverages of it or check how many laudatory reviews and awards/nominations the film has amassed, you'd probably think it's quite the groundbreaking musical masterpiece. If you went on TikTok or Twitter and checked how the average-Joe doom-scrollers feel about the movie, however, you'd likely come to expect a sh*tshow for the ages; a film to possibly one day be named in the same breath as Breen or Wiseau.nnIf nothing else, it's one of the most contentious Oscar-season movies since 2005's Crash (which was similarly lauded by some for its important themes about racism, mainly by those who knew as little about racism as the filmmakers) -- heck, a Best Picture win isn't out of the question. And that's not to say that everyone with a social media account hated the movie. A silent majority of normies probably liked it fine -- unbothered by its supposedly progressive view of trans issues that is usually anything but -- and it does have a dedicated defense brigade of people who have a sufficiently reductive/condescending view of Mexican culture, womanhood, and trans people to think that this film is exactly as progressive as it professes to be.nnUnfortunately, the defenses don't really work. A popular one seems to be that, even if we grant that the film is "problematic", trans people should be happy about getting ANY representation whatsoever, which is a wild thing to say when better films about the trans experience (chiefly The People's Joker and I Saw the TV Glow) came out the same year but went ignored by awards organizations. There is absolutely no reason to be satisfied with what's put before us in Emilia Per√©z.nnAnother defense is that the film is going for "camp", ergo many of the problems that naysayers identify -- especially with regards to the quality of the songs and performances thereof -- are actually "supposed" to be there, but this has repeatedly been rebutted with yet another superior effort to check out, namely the campy and crazy Repo! The Genetic Opera (2008). Once again, there's no reason to shrug and go "Well, I guess this is as good as we're gonna get", especially when Emilia P√©rez is never as campy or funny-bad as that one song number that went viral a few weeks ago (making it very funny that the same morons that defend its "campiness" will accuse OTHER people of basing their disdain toward the film on ONE scene).nnAs for Zoe Salda√±a and Selena Gomez's supposedly being so perfect for these roles that Jacques Audiard absolutely could not have cast people whose first language is actually Spanish... Uhh, no. (You can tell that a good chunk of the principal actors don't have Spanish as their first language and somehow also sense the fact that their director speaks neither that one nor English fluently.)nnWhen I tell people to watch more movies, I don't ONLY mean that one should look beyond the Hollywood blockbuster bubble. You should also be aware that, say, Emilia P√©rez isn't the best option when it comes to more artsy films.nnAll that being said, however, I understand the inclination to defend the movie. In saying that this is a considerably contentious film, I am of course also talking about the outrage from TERFs and Daily Wire readers about Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n's "stealing" the Oscar from Real Women‚Ñ¢ in what Ben "Wet-ass P-word" Shapiro called the woke-est Oscar nomination ever. Her winning (which seems likely) will no doubt be seen as a blow against those bigots and, by extension, the new US presidential administration -- same if we indeed get the first foreign-language Best Picture win since Parasite.nnI don't know that such a gesture would fix anything, especially given the aforementioned issues with the representation. But if you've already decided that it would, then... well, I guess this movie is for you. Enjoy.

column3: "The Wild Wild West" (1965) {The Night of Jack O'Diamonds (#3.5)}
column4: Our intrepid agents West and Gordon are given a valuable horse by Pres. Grant to deliver & give to Benito Juarez ("that lovely little Indian"), the president of Mexico, but then more than a few complications develop along the way in a very good mid-third-season installment of the series. The Jamaican-born actor Frank Silvera guest stars (portraying a Mexican bandito named El Sordo, an ethnicity that a light-skinned black actor like him was frequently cast as), and he's excellent in this role. When Jim fights him for the right to stay behind, while El Sordo rides off to Juarez, Silvera gently shakes his head and says "aye, gringos" marveling @both the bravery and stupidity of such white Americans. Indeed! I give this episode an extra star for an amusing & surprising ending, so a strong 8 out of 10 stars.

I know Lynch was revered, but I just hate films where people act and speak irrationally. Lynch was a master of the irrational. And so is this movie. What a load of irrational bullshit that was... look, do what you want, live how you want, sex like you want, but this? This non sequitor of a movie? How did he see what she liked? Why did she laugh like a 12 year old girl in the sheet in front of her husband, instead of laying it out? Why did he start reading the bible? And doesn't the husband get points for being EXTRMELY understanding after she goes psychotic on him for (for him) no apparent reason?nnAnd what was the fuc*** point? She had a grreat husband, an active sexlife for her age, and then? What? It's his fault? It's no ones fault? There is no fault? What's the point?nnAnd don't get me started in the cheap ass music which sounded like someone on cocaine, having sex, decided to amp up Serge Gainsbourg...hidious...

This movie is a sloppy mess. Inconsistent performances, silly songs, and a profoundly sexist message. Nope, not against women but against men. If movies really are nothing more than mimesis or imitation of life, and therefore just... metaphor, let's look at the film's titular figure and what she represents. In the world of the film, being male is almost exclusively characterized as being toxically violent and inhumane. The film also implies that the only real chance for redemption in the broken world it depicts is for the male symbol to renounce his masculinity and become a woman. Once this transition happens, the character is suddenly benevolent, non violent and humane and solely focused on righting the wrongs of the world. Its an unmistakable implied misandrist message and it falls in line with all the cries of "death to the patriarchy" we hear at this moment of time. As if these cries and a film like this are really going to solve any problems. Men are half the population. They cannot and should not be defined in one pat simplistic stroke like this film paints. Are some men awful? Yes. Are some women awful? Absolutely. But dividing everything along a men are bad/women good is not going to solve the world's ills.

Kangana Ranaut's Emergency is a colossal disappointment and a testament to how historical films can go horribly wrong when accuracy and integrity are sacrificed for creative liberties. The movie, which attempts to portray one of India's most politically turbulent periods under the Emergency, comes across as a shallow, poorly researched project riddled with false narratives and one-dimensional storytelling.nnOne of the most glaring issues is the blatant misrepresentation of historical facts. The portrayal of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, one of South Asia's most iconic leaders, is not only inaccurate but also disrespectful. The dialogues and actions attributed to him in the film are completely fabricated, creating a false narrative that diminishes his legacy. Mujib never delivered the kinds of speeches shown in the movie, and these inaccuracies make it clear that the film has no interest in staying true to history. For viewers familiar with the real events, this distortion feels like a deliberate attempt to misinform and sensationalize rather than educate.nnKangana Ranaut's decision to direct and play the role of Indira Gandhi herself is another major flaw. While taking on such a monumental role requires immense skill and depth, her performance is underwhelming and lacks the gravitas needed to portray someone as complex as Indira Gandhi. Instead of embodying the essence of the former Prime Minister, Kangana resorts to over-the-top mimicry, which feels like a caricature rather than a respectful portrayal. Her exaggerated mannerisms and forced dialogue delivery make it difficult to take her seriously, turning what could have been a nuanced performance into an almost laughable parody.nnAs a director, Kangana seems to struggle with maintaining focus and depth in the storytelling. The narrative jumps around without a clear direction, and the emotional weight of the Emergency period is never truly captured. The film tries to juggle too many subplots and characters, but none of them are given the depth or development they deserve. The pacing is uneven, with some scenes dragging unnecessarily while others rush through crucial moments without giving the audience time to process their significance.nnThe production design and cinematography, while adequate in some parts, fail to elevate the film. The lack of attention to detail is evident in the costumes, sets, and overall atmosphere, which fail to convincingly transport the viewer back to the 1970s. The music and background score are equally uninspired, doing little to enhance the film's impact or mood.nnOne of the most disappointing aspects of Emergency is its inability to handle its subject matter with the seriousness and respect it deserves. The Emergency period was a dark and complex chapter in Indian history, marked by political oppression, human rights violations, and widespread fear. Instead of delving into these complexities, the film opts for melodrama and oversimplification, reducing the entire period to a black-and-white narrative that lacks nuance or substance.nnKangana's apparent need to control every aspect of the film, from direction to acting, seems to have backfired. Her vision for the project appears to be more about showcasing herself than about telling an important story. This self-indulgence is evident throughout the film, as the focus remains firmly on her character at the expense of other important figures and events.nnOverall, Emergency is a wasted opportunity. It had the potential to be a gripping political drama that sheds light on a pivotal moment in India's history, but instead, it ends up being a shallow, poorly executed vanity project. For viewers seeking an accurate or meaningful depiction of the Emergency period, this film will be a huge disappointment. It's hard to recommend this movie to anyone, as it fails both as a historical drama and as a piece of cinema. Skip this one-it's not worth your time or attention.

Um filme que reflete de forma magn√≠fica a cultura francesa. Nunca o jeito franc√™s de ser foi retratado com tanto primor e maestria nas telas do cinema.nnO filme √© a prova que n√£o precisa ser franc√™s para falar sobre a Fran√ßa e sua cultura. Certamente, esse filme merece 13 indica√ß√µes ao Oscar, assim como Emilia P√©rez.nnPodemos considerar o musical um joia do cinema, nada disso foi visto ou feito nos √∫ltimos 10 anos. Jacques Audiard deve estar orgulhoso do seu legado ap√≥s retratar o M√©xico.nnFalo sem medo de errar: essa obra marcou uma √©poca de forma √∫nica. Espero que a Karla esteja feliz com o resultado e deixe de culpar o Brasil pelo fracasso do filme que ela estrela.

18 Again (2020), directed by Ha Byung-hoon, adapted from American film 17 Again (2009) directed by Burr Steers. The story follows Hong Dae-young (Yoon Sang-hyun), whose life falls apart after failing to keep his marriage with Jung Da-jung (Kim Ha-neul). At his lowest point, a miracle happens. Dae-young suddenly reverts to his 18 year old body but retains his adult mind. In his youthful form, he takes on the name Go Woo-young (Lee Do-hyun) and decides to reconnect with his family from a fresh perspective, attempting to mend his relationship with his wife and twin children, Hong Shi-ah (Roh Jeong-eui) and Hong Shi-woo (Ryeoun).nnFinally, finished watching 18 Again, and honestly, I'm a bit disappointed. It's not terrible, but there's really nothing special about it either. The conflict is flat, there aren't any truly emotional or gripping moments. Sure, there are a few touching episodes, but everything feels half baked. The themes of family, love, and self discovery could've been executed more effectively, but instead, they come across as bland. The "miracle" premise had so much potential to be impactful, yet it falls flat. The one thing I did enjoy was the characters, mainly the female ones because, well, they're gorgeous. Guilty pleasure, I guess wkwkwk.nnWhat's even more frustrating is how no one around Hong Dae-young seemed suspicious when he suddenly appeared as a younger version of himself. Like, how does no one notice how much he looks and acts like the younger Dae-young? It's honestly annoying because it makes the plot feel a bit too dumbed down. Even in a fantasy drama, some basic logic would've helped. 18 Again feels like a genre package straight out to nh.net sites (IYKWIM) with fanservice for a broad audience.nnNow I'm curious about Death's Game (2023) since it's from the same director. I really hope it's better than 18 Again. If Death's Game ends up having the same vibe, I might just call it quits with this director's works. Let's just hope it more "OKE" because 18 Again was overall pretty meh for me.

I love this episode because it was filled with comedy and drama as wellnFirst, it started with 4 things: Kappa, travelling for the tournament, meeting an alumni of The Catullan.nnLeighton and Whitney attended a Kappa branch, where she met her brother Nico, friend Cory and used him as a beard to hide his sexuality.nnKim and Bela went to an event to meet a "The Catullan" alumni Danny Marawitz. Whitney went with the girls to travel for the tournament. This episode was great and abso-freaking-lutely funny as well. Bela got pissed by the alumni she idolized for making a sexist Joke. Served him right. At least, she got a donation from another alumni. That's what I'm grateful about.nnLeighton and Whitney with the part were funny and exciting as well. Especially Ashley's spelling part. Also, I found the Dalton part funny as well. Served him right though. Well, her friend finds out about the relationship between her and Dalton. I don't care whether the friend says or not as I really don't care about the relationship as I found it boring.nnPlus, Whitney and her friend were fun though. The Leighton and Cory storyline was good though. I understand why she is hesitating and why she is bearding because she is scared. I found it interesting with the Leighton and Alicia part. I hope they hook up.

Embarrassingly bad acting, the story has several loose ends. No, avoid this, those are hours you'll never get back. The attempts to imitate the Northern dialect are not good, and what about the wolf? What happend to Kenneth and Sandra, the body? It is incredibly frustrating when several events are thrown in to make the story more exciting, but basically none of them are followed up or explained. I had high expectations but this was truly one of the worst things I've seen. The casting is completely incomprehensible. Several comedians who don't get their roles right at all. The Stockholm woman gets through every now and then. I've seen better acting when we did charades on AW. Sorry, but please choose good actors, there are several in Sweden.

Apart from amazing acting and brilliant directorial debut by Kangna, she has highlighted how Nationalist would depict a straightforward sequence of events without peddling rhetoric which classically PseudoLiberals have been using.nnIt has showcased both good and bad aspects of life of PM Indira Gandhi ji. It's more of Biography than a film on Emergency. They have tried highlighting emergency as an historical event by rushing through other key events like 1971 War and Creation of Bangladesh, parliamentary elections etc.nnThe camera angles and acting undertones are really very well worked by the team.nnLoved it fully.

SPOILER FREE REVIEW HERE:nNot your standard cop show, if you can believe that. But, it's true!nnSomehow they've found a different way to create another cop show and it's 100% worth every second. I'm praying it continues into another season!nnMy only "complaint" would be that most of the two-word replies in scenes, I already have said in my head before the line is said. (That could only be because I've been married to a writer, with a master's in screenwriting, for 15 years.)nnMy only other complaint is general: this crappy, disappointing trend of 8-12 episode seasons. I miss the days of 20-30+ episodes of HOUR-long shows, in ONE season. Now, THOSE are truly binge worthy. Binging 8-10 episodes, in one season, is binging-lite.nnIf a production company is worried about how well the show will do during the first season, I can understand just a few episodes, like 8-10. But, if the show does really well, just go for it! Appease the masses with a truly FULL 2nd, 3rd, 4th... season.nnNO SPOILER ABOVE ‚è´nnSPOILER BELOW: ‚è¨nn***SPOILER***nInstead of holding Diaz back, they could've gone in the direction of Traci not being a T. O. and wanting him as her partner. Maybe that can happen in a more-than-8-episode season 2. It would suck to have only 8 episodes again, and then wait for that storyline until season 3.

Inception (2010), dirigida por Christopher Nolan, sigue a Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio), un ladr√≥n que se especializa en robar secretos desde los sue√±os de sus v√≠ctimas. Despu√©s de ser contratado por un magnate, Saito (Ken Watanabe), Cobb debe llevar a cabo un "inception": implantar una idea en la mente de Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy), un joven heredero. Para ello, Cobb y su equipo deben crear sue√±os dentro de sue√±os, enfrent√°ndose a riesgos mortales y a los propios traumas de Cobb, especialmente su culpa por la muerte de su esposa, Mal (Marion Cotillard). A medida que avanzan, las fronteras entre la realidad y el sue√±o se difuminan, creando un intrincado juego de percepciones que desaf√≠a al espectador hasta el final ambiguo. La pel√≠cula explora temas como la mente humana, la culpa, y la naturaleza de la realidad.

Ver Johanne Sacreblue es una experiencia tan inmersiva que, por momentos, sent√≠ que el f√©tido olor del desd√©n parisino por el jab√≥n traspasaba la pantalla y se instalaba en mi sala. La calidad cinematogr√°fica es tan impresionante que puedes casi oler las calles h√∫medas, mezcladas con croissants rancios y, por supuesto, esa maravillosa combinaci√≥n de perfume caro y d√≠as sin ducha que es emblem√°tica de ciertas zonas de Par√≠s.nnLa pel√≠cula logra capturar a la perfecci√≥n la esencia de una ciudad que es al mismo tiempo una postal y un basurero po√©tico. Me record√≥ mi visita a la ciudad, cuando vi a ratas del tama√±o de chihuahuas -o quiz√°s terneros peque√±os- peleando por una bolsa de basura como si fuese el √∫ltimo acto de Les Mis√©rables. Esa escena qued√≥ grabada en mi memoria como un s√≠mbolo de resistencia, y Johanne Sacreblue logra transmitir esa misma lucha cruda, humana y, s√≠, ligeramente pestilente, con una honestidad aplastante.nnEs un cortometraje que no solo te transporta a las entra√±as de Francia, sino que te deja con la sensaci√≥n de que, al final, todos somos ratas luchando por una bolsa de basura emocional. Una obra maestra, pero quiz√° tambi√©n un recordatorio de que debo ventilar mi sala despu√©s de verla.

Inception is a cinematic masterpiece that blends intricate storytelling with cutting-edge visual effects.nnDirected by Christopher Nolan, this film delves into the concept of dream manipulation and explores the blurred lines between reality and dreams.nnThe plot unfolds in a non-linear fashion, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats as the characters navigate layers of dreams within dreams.nnThe exceptional performances by Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, and Marion Cotillard elevate the film's emotional depth.nnThe mesmerizing soundtrack by Hans Zimmer further amplifies the tension and drama, creating a truly immersive experience.nnInception not only entertains but also challenges the mind, making it a thought-provoking piece of cinema that invites audiences to contemplate the boundaries of human consciousness and the power of the mind.nnIts unique narrative structure and high-stakes action sequences make it one of the most memorable and influential films of the 21st century.nnThe film's ability to blend science fiction with emotional storytelling is a testament to Nolan's filmmaking prowess, and it stands as a must-watch for cinephiles and casual moviegoers alike.nnInception is a thrilling ride that leaves a lasting impression, making it a true modern classic.

El gui√≥n, la m√∫sica, la fotograf√≠a, la direcci√≥n y dem√°s aspectos hacen de este corto una fiel representaci√≥n del pa√≠s del amor, la basura, las ratas, los croissants y los baguettes... Ah! Salaar: The Saga is truly a cinematic celebration, a movie that grabs your attention and keeps your adrenaline pumping from start to finish. It's more than just a film-it's an experience, a phenomenon, and a masterstroke of modern Indian cinema.nnPrabhas, our Darling, is an unstoppable force in this film, delivering a performance so intense and magnetic that it feels almost divine. Every time he's on screen, you can feel the sheer weight of his charisma-he doesn't just act; he commands. Whether it's his iconic dialogue delivery, bone-crushing action sequences, or the way he carries himself with that larger-than-life aura, Prabhas redefines what it means to be a superstar.nnAnd then there's Prithviraj Sukumaran, bringing his A-game and matching Prabhas stride for stride. The synergy between these two legends is electric, creating moments that make your heart race and your eyes widen in awe. Together, they make Salaar not just a film but an epic clash of titans.nnPrashanth Neel, the genius behind the camera, has taken storytelling and action to an entirely new level. His vision for Salaar is nothing short of revolutionary, blending raw emotion with jaw-dropping spectacle. The action choreography is a masterpiece in itself, especially the iconic Kateramma fight sequence-a scene so explosive, so perfectly staged, it's practically burned into the minds of every fan. It's not just a fight; it's an art form, a symphony of chaos and power that sets a new standard for action in Indian cinema.nnAnd let's talk about the music. The background score is pure fire, with tracks like **Chaos of KhanSaar Theme** and **Varadha Raja Mannar vs. Deva** elevating every moment to legendary status. But it's the **Kateramma Fight BGM** that truly steals the show-it's not just music; it's an experience that sends chills down your spine and leaves you breathless.nnWatching Salaar in theaters is an unforgettable event. The roars of the crowd, the larger-than-life visuals, and the raw energy of Prabhas are unparalleled. But it's in the rewatch, with the music and moments sinking in deeper, that you truly grasp the brilliance of what this movie offers.nnSalaar isn't just entertainment-it's a love letter to fans, a testament to the power of cinema, and a reminder of why Prabhas is the reigning king of the box office. It's a film that leaves you speechless, makes your heart race, and has you cheering like there's no tomorrow. This is not just a movie; this is *Salaar.*

Before I started this i strapped myself in for a possible disappointment by reminding myself I was about to watch entertainment, not a historical documentary, and I am hapopy to say I was not disappointed.nnWhat works: Visuals are good, there are a good number of items that appear to be historically correct. A lot actually. Personalities seem to be well developed ( alas character depth less so , more on that later ). Level of acting is acceptable ,as is the rest of the production.nnWhat does not work: Yeah, the audio is not fitting with the sera and cheapens the show. At start I was actually smiling as I head a little ditty that gave me happy memories of the WW2 classics of old. ACDC is, at the moment at least, for me tied too much to Marvel Universe and it ruined the immersion. I am struggling with some of the characters, at no point am I convinced of the need of the lady from french intelligence, other then a love interest? Then there is the cramped woke reek that also makes it appearance in this show. Don't get me wrong, I have no issues with minorities popping up in a show , but please make it more then a tick in the box cameo. Character depth, at the end of season one I still have so many questions why certain people behave the way they do in this show, particular the senrior leaadership. Storyline tends to be a bit chaotic, at least in the first season, the general feel was that producer and director were not convinced of a second season. Lastly, fire your military advisor and get one that knows what he is talking baout, especially concerning the era we are talking baout.nnOverall; Decent watch, look at it like you would look at a Tarantino movie, you may learn a few historical facts along the way, I definitely had a buinch of good laughs.

CORRECT: This is a beautiful piece of art. This remains pretty true to the musical and I appreciate that a lot. Over the years musicals have been written in away that makes me hate them. Cats was a hope to us but we were let down by the questionable decisions made. Into the woods was very good until James Corden got involved (please to casting him he's always awful in everything- I was very relieved to know he wasn't involved in this film in anyway) You can tell when theatre kids are involved in creating movie musicals because it's got the touches that we all wanted and needed. Cynthia and Ariana made sure that the story was not lost, and they ensured people would enjoy it. I wasn't sure on Ariana, but she really shined in this. Cynthia is unbelievable in this and she will always be an inspiration to all - her voice is incredible. No notes - just perfect. REPLACE WITH: This is a beautiful piece of art. column3: "Rur√¥ni Kenshin: Meiji kenkaku romantan" (2023) {Between Life and Death (#2.15)}
column4: Un episodio puede ser perfecto y esta es la prueba de ello.nnEn la b√∫squeda de la t√©cnica suprema por parte de Kenshin, nos damos cuenta de que pese a luchar por sus seres queridos y por los m√°s d√©biles, tambi√©n se olvida de que el es un persona y un humano querido por los que le rodeannCon tanta tristeza y reprimida y sin darle importancia a su propia vida. Y cuando mira a los ojos de la muerte es que se da cuenta de realmente tiene un prop√≥sito y un sentido su vida y para ello necesita seguir con vida.nnEste episodio me recuerda al libro El Hombre en busca de sentido de Viktor Frankl.nnY es lo que pasa con Kenshin durante su vidanSentido en el sufrimiento: el sufrimiento puede ser soportado si se encuentra un prop√≥sito m√°s grandenLibertad interior: aunque las circunstancias externas pueden ser insoportables, las personas tienen la libertad de elegir como reaccionar y como continuarnResponsabilidad personal: encontrar el sentido en la vida implica asumir la responsabilidad de las decisiones y acciones propiasnn10/10.

I have seen the agenda of trying to be diverse and inclusive in many movies and to a point sometimes it's not bad. Netflix makes movies with this in mind, where every movies needs certain types of people in order to be "viewable" or "diverse enough" and that's fine by a production company's standpoint. On the other hand, it's an insult to the movie, the viewers,and in this case to Hispanics, to have this movie nominated so highly with such a big backlash in America and in Latin American countries. As I always do, I sat thru the whole movie and and gave it a fair chance. Just as Eugenio Derbez I couldn't see it as anything as a mess and a direct insult to the Mexican culture and people like if the problems they face as a nation were a complete joke. Movies franchises like the lord of the rings have not received this many nominations and not even titanic has. Clearly with President Trump's new stance on certain subjects, the Oscar's are trying to go against that by nominating this mess and disrespectful movie to awards it doesn't even deserve.

Quite one of the worst version ever made and there has been som BAD versions. A BBC box ticking exercise for the wokerati that would have Chatles Dickens spinning in his grave and more unsettled than Jacob Marley. Steven Knight makes the huge mistake of trying to rewrite rather than adapt. Alluding to Scrooge as a rapist, Mrs Cratchit ticking the diversity agenda and many other errors made this unwatchable nonsense. If I never see it again, it will be too soon and I say that as someone who loves Dickens original. Guy Pearce just fails to understand the character of Scrooge but probably does the best he can with what was presented to him. Overall, this is totally forgettable, which is a crime for a timeless classic.

Please please give us Season 3. This series is exceptionally unique, well-produced, shows women's strength, is filmed in Europe, has actors with exceptional chemistry, I could go on. Congratulations Netlix for such an amazing show. To be frank, at first the combination of common vernacular with a divine supernatural theme felt wrong. And don't get me started on the final episode... epic, truly epic.

I had saw a few clips of it and thought nothing of it until I decided to sit down and watch it and I'm really impressed. There were some moments where I was like damn that's super cool. It's interesting take on witches and I like the characters and their development so far. I really hope it gets renewed cause there so many scenes that are breathtaking and the plot is actually really intriguing. I'm not quite sure why it has so much hate though. I heard about how some people don't like how there's little representation of men; however I feel as though I haven't really missed it. Like it's basically a fantasy dystopian show; and like many others there's going to be something different in their world than ours. Gives us something interesting. But that's just my opinion. Hope you have a good day!

cameo en esta entrega.nnAqu√≠ el millonario y director del parque es Simon Masrani, mientras que los protagonistas son Claire Dearing (jefa de operaciones y cient√≠fica corporativa del parque) y Owen Don't watch because it portrays the history in wrong way.nnWho's tell you Bangladesh made by f**king India.nnBangladeshi 3M people die for there country freedom. After 9 month war Bangladesh get freedomnBut India f**king film maker show India birth Bangladeshnn#boyccotIndianFilmnnClaims to be based on true events, but viewers should approach it with a heavy dose of skepticism. While the film delivers on visual spectacle and compelling performances, its portrayal of historical events is riddled with inaccuracies that are hard to overlook.nnThe film attempts to bring a specific historical event or figure to life, but rather than faithfully depict what happened, it opts for dramatic embellishments that serve the story more than the truth. The portrayal of key historical figure or event, for instance, is far from accurate. Characters are shown acting in ways that contradict documented behavior, and pivotal moments are reshaped to fit a more cinematic narrative, which leads to a distorted version of history. For example,is shown happening in a completely different setting, with a timeline that overlooks key developments that would have made the story more grounded in reality.nnMoreover, the filmmakers seem to take liberties with the cultural and political contexts, which reduces the richness of the historical landscape they were trying to recreate. These inaccuracies can be particularly frustrating for history buffs, as they obscure the real-world significance of the event or person being portrayed. It's one thing to alter certain aspects for artistic reasons, but when fundamental truths are altered or omitted, the film risks misinforming the public about the past.nnWhile "Historical Epic" is undoubtedly entertaining, its misrepresentation of history raises questions about the ethical responsibility filmmakers have when telling stories based on real events. Audiences who come to the movie for a more educational experience may leave with a warped understanding of history, which is troubling.nnUltimately, the movie serves as a reminder that history is not just a collection of stories to be molded for entertainment, but a complex series of events that deserve respect and accuracy. If you're watching for the drama, it's a fine spectacle. If you're hoping for historical accuracy, you may want to look elsewhere.

It's weird, cerebral and the animation is surprisingly is quite good. The creatures remind me of an artist by the name of Wayne D Barlowe. Not surprisingly, and in typical form these major Studios find something that has very good content and they decide to can it. So I'm sitting here watching a two-year-old animated TV show that potentially has no hope of extended seasons...why is it that these major studios see the good reviews of a show and then decide that it won't go any further with narrative? Is it because they can't make action figures to bolster their revenue...it's all bullshit I guess.

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
column4: (95%) If the late 70's early 80's had the Star wars trilogy, then the 2000's had this epic fantasy masterclass. Regardless of whether you're a fantasy fan or not this is too good a movie to simply pass up, and it will be one of those movies that given time will prove it to be a classic. The deeper you look into this the more one notices that every single aspect really is a truly impressive accomplishment. The fact that every single sword used by the main characters was made by hand, with extra ones made only for carrying, fighting, etc, then there's the costumes/armor/props all made by teams of many people. They even made artificial trees for gods sake. But really all those things are just extras, what really makes this a unique watch is that it really does feel huge and sweeping, the sense of scale is fantastic and I can't think of anything that even comes close to matching it. What every epic flick needs this has, the cast is great, it's exciting, it has bags of character, it's funny, sad, superbly well made, with a great score and plenty of action. It's also one of very few 2 hour 30 minute + movies ever that leaves the audience wanting more. Since watching it around Christmas 2001 at a packed out cinema, and the many times I've seen it on DVD since, it never fails to impress and charm. All in all near perfect cinematic treat that keeps on giving.

When I first saw this movie I didn't appreciate it like I do now. I think it may have been because I was so young when I first saw it. Just recently I saw the movie again. What an amazing story and moving meaning. That movie teaches you so much about life and the meaning of it. That life isn't as bad as most people make it seem. That an innocent man can impact so many lives with his innocence. The meaning of the movie to me is that everyone needs to have a better outlook on life. That we need to appreciate more of the little things and not let the big things hold us back. That truly although life may throw us trials and tribulations like a box of chocolates but that we have to just bite into it and get through it even if we don't like it. That we all need to hold true to our values and not sink into a place that feels like there's no hope... I just love this movie. And anyone who hasn't seen it or who thinks that don't like it I seriously suggest seeing it or seeing it again. It truly is amazing...

The movie started out pretty innocently, and for the first 20 minutes, I was wondering where the movie was going. Then it started to happen. The horrible cruelty of concentration camps. Oskar Schindler is an example of a man that no matter what the situation, there are people who won't go along with the cruelty of society. I'm sure it took courage to do what he did, because one wrong move and you'll be dead.nnMovie brought to life this great man who really shouldn't be forgotten, and thanks to Steven Spielberg, I think he'll be remembered for generations to come. Movie like this should be made once in a while. Not that movie should be used for evangelistic purposes but some story should be told well, and movie is still the best vehicle to do so.nnI still think that Oskar Shindler's last words in this movie was one of the best dialog in movie history - "Why did I keep this badge ? I could have saved a person. Why did I keep this car ?, I could have saved five more people."

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)
column4: Nothing even comes close and I may well not see it personally topped. Every single scene is magnificent. The acting is superb as is the direction, script, hauntingly beautiful music, cinematography and the incredible battles; especially the hour long battle on the Pellenor Fields and Minas Tirith. The characters are some of the greatest ever created and to root for. The movie is simply perfection from beginning to end and the 4 hour version is just as majestic. There's not a single negative thing I can say about a movie that deserves all it's nominated Oscars. My family and I watched it 4 times in its first 12 days of release. A joyous experience every time. Magnificent!!!!!!

It is no wonder that the film has such a high rating, it is quite literally breathtaking. What can I say that hasn't said before? Not much, it's the story, the acting, the premise, but most of all, this movie is about how it makes you feel. Sometimes you watch a film, and can't remember it days later, this film loves with you, once you've seen it, you don't forget.nnThe ultimate story of friendship, of hope, and of life, and overcoming adversity.nnI understand why so many class this as the best film of all time, it isn't mine, but I get it. If you haven't seen it, or haven't seen it for some time, you need to watch it, it's amazing. 10/10.

No solo refleja con precisi√≥n la vida parisina, sino que lo hace de una forma tan emotiva y realista que es imposible salir del teatro sin sentir que se ha caminado por las calles de la ciudad m√°s ic√≥nica del mundo. If you're expecting a balanced series that critiques toxic behaviors across genders or examines political movements in a satirical way, like Family Guy or American Dad, you'll be disappointed. This is a typical woke series that tries to appear neutral but primarily focuses on criticizing men.nnThe story follows four friends in their 40s:nn1. Pedro, a TV producer, is portrayed as outwardly confident but deeply insecure. He is dumped by his girlfriend Daniela and even spat on by an elderly woman for expressing a differing opinion.nn2. Ra√∫l, an irresponsible man who, despite having a beautiful girlfriend, Luz, cheats on her with escorts and his co-worker's wife. When Luz suggests an open relationship, Ra√∫l becomes jealous, and she eventually leaves him after selling his restaurant shares for a single euro.nn3. Santi, the most frustrating character, is already passive but becomes completely submissive to his daughter. Ra√∫l even jokes, "She has you on a leash, huh?" Santi abandons a great woman to reconcile with his unfaithful ex-wife.nn4. Luis, the most relatable of the group, is a kind and caring husband who cooks and looks after the kids. However, his wife, Esther, cheats on him with her gym trainer due to dissatisfaction in their intimate life. She later returns to Luis after being dumped by the trainer.nnThe series seems to suggest that women are always justified in their actions, no matter the circumstances, which feels one-sided.nnFrom a technical standpoint, the acting and storytelling are average. The direction and editing leave much to be desired, with scenes cutting abruptly, disrupting the flow. The comedy is hit-or-miss, working about 50% of the time.nnFinal verdict: This series had the potential to be great but is let down by its lack of balance and nuance.

On the outside looking in, The Apprentice is the story of the rise of Donald Trump and his real estate business empire. It's also a behind the scenes look at longtime friends Roy Cohn and Donald J. Trump from the 1970s until 1986. The film showcases the story of both men in a provocative, yet humanizing and intriguing way, with love and sometimes hate towards one another. Cohn had been a prosecutor long before he met and became a mentor to Trump. It was fascinating to learn that Cohn was involved with the Rosenbergs trial and prosecution.nnThere are scenes in the film that can seem biased against Trump, and even caused Donald Trump himself to try and stop the release of the film, albeit unsuccessfully. One of those scenes involves Donald and his first wife Ivana being intimate, but the context was taken directly from first hand testimony from Ivana Trump herself when she divorced Donald. The second half of the film deals with the AIDS epidemic during the early 1980s, which was a scare to everyone because no one knew anything about it; and just the admittance of having AIDS was a social death sentence.nnI myself am not sure how Trump reacted to the AIDS epidemic, this was most likely dramatized for the film; especially when it came to the fact that Roy Cohn vehemently denied contracting the disease, but later died having been fighting it until his death. I do wonder if there will be a sequel to this film, bringing to light the next chapter of Trump's life. It'd be interesting to see, at least in a historic basis.

CORRECT: Redefining what it means to be 'creepy', "The Heretic" took a simple storyline and made it branch out into some truly discomfiting places.nnBesides noteworthy performances from Sophie Thatcher and Chloe East - who played Sister Barnes and Sister Paxton (resp.), the two young girls who were traumatised in this dark tale - Hugh Grant's sinister screen presence as Mr. Reed was genuinely riveting.nnI don't recall when I'd seen Grant do a role outside the rom-com genre, but what he accomplished in "The Heretic" proved beyond any doubt that the man has range.nnBetween some obnoxious Christian 'toxic tropes' and a deeply unnerving pagan-philosophical underlayer, this movie took on a life of its own.nnAs "The Heretic" unfurled, the plot conveyed a wealth of meaning and subtext that deserved to be appreciated. After all, how many psychological-thriller movies can raise high stakes and meet them?nnPutting the very notion (and relevance) of Religion under a microscope, the movie proved it could balance both worlds - entertainment and education - like a seasoned (though a tad mad) professor.nnA dash of 'Simulation Hypothesis' took the plot down an even darker rabbit-hole, finishing in a way that was equally satiating and bewildering.nn- - - - - - - - -nMemorable moments from Elle Young (as the Prophet). After all, how many psychological-thriller movies can raise high stakes and meet them?nnPutting the very notion (and relevance) of Religion under a microscope, the movie proved it could balance both worlds - entertainment and education - like a seasoned (though a tad mad) professor.nnA dash of 'Simulation Hypothesis' took the plot down an even darker rabbit-hole, finishing in a way that was equally satiating and bewildering.nn- - - - - - - - -nMemorable moments from Elle Young (as the Prophet).

CORRECT: A classic comic-book villain created by Stan Lee and Steve Ditko finally had a live-action all to himself. A dark and brooding anti-hero in several respects, Kraven the Hunter has earned his character's worth.nnBringing him to life was Aaron Taylor-Johnson whose portrayal of Sergei Kravinoff, aka Kraven the Hunter, was gripping and intense. Though his performance was formulaic, it nevertheless managed to captivate.nnNikolai Kravinoff's (played superbly by Russell Crowe) chauvinistic influence over his son (Sergei) directly groomed him into becoming one of the world's deadliest super-powered mercenaries.nnRemarkable contributions from Ariana DeBose (as Calypso Ezili), Fred Hechinger (as Dmitri Kravinoff), Levi Miller (as teen-Sergei), and Christopher Abbott (as The Foreigner) just about elevated the script.nnAlessandro Nivola's (as Aleksei Sytsevich) portrayal of The Rhino was quite interesting. It felt old-school but not in a bad way.nnNow, despite all its grand promise, "Kraven: The Hunter" did not quite live up to my expectations. Not only did its story feel lazily scripted but an overdose of SSU (Sony's Spider-Man Universe) style commercialism ended up besmirching its core plot-value.nnWhat could've been a majestic storyline, with a motto to match, thus fell flat and lost both claws and fangs in the process. Outstanding visuals and stunts - not to forget a handful of keynote performances - kept this ship afloat.nnA generous helping of convenient plot-progressions - lion-blood-Papa-Legba empowerment for teen-Sergei, psychic right-place-right-time moments for Calypso, and so on - didn't do the live-action script any favours.nnThey impacted credibility in more ways than one. In this regard, the original comic books covered their bases laudably. Indeed, it's not what you tell, but how you tell it. In contrast, the movie adaptation of "Kraven" contained more purrs than roars.nnToxic-male tropes and excessive aggression without balanced causes added up to a fight-first-talk-later movie which seemed overly dependent on getting away with an insubstantial, rather weak, plotline that landed an incredibly soft punch - despite some stellar stunts.nnThat said, I liked the dark ending in "Kraven: The Hunter" which, to be fair, is deserving of a sequel, preferably one where they do much much better.nn- - - - - - - - -nNoteworthy moments from Guillaume Delaunay (as Mofo), Billy Barratt (as teen-Dmitri), Susan Aderin (as Calypso's grandmother), Damola Adelaja (as Bahari Gama), and Tom Reed (as Bert). REPLACE WITH: A classic comic-book villain created by Stan Lee and Steve Ditko finally had a live-action all to himself. A dark and brooding anti-hero in several respects, Kraven the Hunter has earned his character's worth.nnBringing him to life was Aaron Taylor-Johnson whose portrayal of Sergei Kravinoff, aka Kraven the Hunter, was gripping and intense. Though his performance was formulaic, it nevertheless managed to captivate.nnNikolai Kravinoff's (played superbly by Russell Crowe) chauvinistic influence over his son (Sergei) directly groomed him into becoming one of the world's deadliest super-powered mercenaries.nnRemarkable contributions from Ariana DeBose (as Calypso Ezili), Fred Hechinger (as Dmitri Kravinoff), Levi Miller (as teen-Sergei), and Christopher Abbott (as The Foreigner) just about elevated the script.nnAlessandro Nivola's (as Aleksei Sytsevich) portrayal of The Rhino was quite interesting. It felt old-school but not in a bad way.nnNow, despite all its grand promise, "Kraven: The Hunter" did not quite live up to my expectations. Not only did its story feel lazily scripted but an overdose of SSU (Sony's Spider-Man Universe) style commercialism ended up besmirching its core plot-value.nnWhat could've been a majestic storyline, with a motto to match, thus fell flat and lost both claws and fangs in the process. Outstanding visuals and stunts - not to forget a handful of keynote performances - kept this ship afloat.nnA generous helping of convenient plot-progressions - lion-blood-Papa-Legba empowerment for teen-Sergei, psychic right-place-right-time moments for Calypso, and so on - didn't do the live-action script any favours.nnThey impacted credibility in more ways than one. In this regard, the original comic books covered their bases laudably. Indeed, it's not what you tell, but how you tell it. In contrast, the movie adaptation of "Kraven" contained more purrs than roars.nnToxic-male tropes and excessive aggression without balanced causes added up to a fight-first-talk-later movie which seemed overly dependent on getting away with an insubstantial, rather weak, plotline that landed an incredibly soft punch - despite some stellar stunts.nnThat said, I liked the dark ending in "Kraven: The Hunter" which, to be fair, is deserving of a sequel, preferably one where they do much much better.nn- - - - - - - - -nNoteworthy moments from Guillaume Delaunay (as Mofo), Billy Barratt (as teen-Dmitri), Susan Aderin (as Calypso's grandmother), Damola Adelaja (as Bahari Gama), and Tom Reed (as Bert).

I've seen plenty of bad horrors, but what does dracula has to do in Germany ü§£ the jump scares and acting is very disappointed, 2:12 waste of your time, the good actors knew this would not be the best movie as they did not even do their best very noticeable and everything else bleh, hahahahahahahaha hahahahahahahaha hahahahahahahaha had to fill at least 600 characters so I fill it up like this hahahahahahahahagagagahahahaga, hahahahahahahahagagagahahahaga, hahahahahahahahagagagahahahaga, hahahahahahahahagagagahahahaga, hahahahahahahahagagagahahahaga, hahahahahahahahagagagahahahaga, funny funny.

The problem is not in the acting, but in the way the characters are written: more as vehicles for a message than as human beings with real contradictions and conflicts. This is common in modern narratives with a "woke" approach: the characters do not grow, but simply exist as symbols of representation.nnEmilia P√©rez is a clear example of how the film industry can sacrifice quality in favor of trend. Jacques Audiard, a talented director, gets lost in his attempt to be relevant in the current panorama, while Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n fails to sustain the weight of a character that needed an interpreter with greater emotional range.nnThe film is neither a good musical, nor a good drama, nor a faithful portrait of Mexico. It is simply another product designed to win awards, but which will hardly be recorded as a great cinematic work.

DELETE: A highly anticipated film which ends up feeling like a project that could have done with better direction and better editing. The story seemed to be going to where. However in the bargain we do get a very nice Batman who is very unique compared to all the Batman's we have seen so far. Good job, but could be better!

This is what happens when you take the heart out of Star Trek. Sloppy writing, and the story goes absolutely nowhere. Characters are basic and cartoonish as best. I honestly don't understand why this movie was even made. Watching it once was painful enough, as it completely wasted 90 minutes of my life that I'll never get back. Everyone involved with this movie should be fired immediately, or better yet, banned to the mirror universe so they can be the ones who continue to suffer crap like this movie. Honestly, this is one of the worst movies that I've ever seen. Star Trek or otherwise. The powers that be in the Star Trek world better change course quickly, because producing more garbage like this will kill the franchise.

La pel√≠cula no solo aborda las complejidades culturales y sociales del pa√≠s, sino que lo hace a trav√©s de una narrativa √≠ntima y profundamente humana que nos sumerge en los desaf√≠os, aspiraciones y luchas de nuestra protagonista. Con una direcci√≥n impecable y una banda sonora que resuena con la emoci√≥n de cada escena, esta obra maestra nos invita a reflexionar sobre los conflictos internos y externos que enfrentan quienes buscan su lugar en el mundo, dejando una impresi√≥n duradera en quienes tienen la oportunidad de experimentarla.

A play in movie format -- and well done it was.nnOh how i hate that i must ramble on for 600 characters, when all i want to do is briefly note that this is a superior movie. Terrific direction, lovely acting, intelligent plot and writing . . .etc.nnIf you take a gander at the awards ("small town awards", to be sure) - you will have a rough idea that perhaps the low imdb score at present (under 6) is grossly misplaced. Myself, i am something of a renaissance man (though no da vinci, i will admit), and i heartily encourage you to sally forth and to give this film a ride. Whether your grandchildren may therefore praise you in 20 years time is beyond my ken. I do reckon, however, that for at least a week or more, you will be glad you decided to give it a spin . . .

column3: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

column4: A lot of people raved about the first season of American Gods, but my response was more measured. I watched at first just because it's ponderous, mysterious style was unusual for TV. But I wasn't really engaged until a few episodes in when Emily Browning's Laura Moon burst in like a storm. She kept me going through the less entrancing parts of the show, which could be unpleasant and some tedious, *endless* sex scenes.nnSince I wasn't a huge fan of season 1, it took me a while to realize I wasn't enjoying season 2. It seemed like pretty much the same thing, only I found myself less interested and more restless. Even Laura Moon seemed less fun. I found it harder to follow the story, and there were none of those really striking moments that peppered season 1.nnI gave up at episode 4, which is basically groups of people having long, philosophical conversations interspersed with short scenes that carried the plot and that I couldn't make head or tail out of.nnWhen I came here to write a review, I discovered my disenchantment with season 2 was not an isolated reaction. In fact, a lot of the people who adored season 1 hated season 2. My reaction to both seasons is more muted, but generally 1 is interesting and 2 isn't.nnThis is almost certainly because for some reason Bryan Fuller was replaced as showrunner. I like some Fuller shows better than others (my favorite is Pushing Daisies), but he is someone with a distinct vision, and I'm not convinced his replacement has one of those.nnCheck out season 1. Just be prepared to not have a worthwhile season 2 you can progress to.
