Like the proportionless and windowless building the main character builds during the film, this movie adds little to its genre.nnThis is another in a series of recent films like Nosferatu that try so hard to be artful they forget to engage the audience. It is a bit like brutalism actually, if NOT done with subtlety and at a human scale it comes off cold and prison like. I guess on that level it was a success.nnI expected to at least see something that is beautiful to watch, but it was not (even in IMAX). If not beautiful to watch, a compelling story, there wasn't one. It was a patchwork of motifs already told in a stronger way.nnI came away with the feeling that the film was really more of a Zionist propaganda film than a story about how talent can be lost in the complexity of life. Corbet approached the story in a cliche way and undermined any story arc with unnecessary jump-forward Hollywood vindication at the end.

Sinopse:nUma noite em seu pr√©dio quase vazio em Londres, Adam tem um encontro casual com seu misterioso vizinho Harry, o que acaba abalando o ritmo de sua vida cotidiana.nnCr√≠tica:n"Todos N√≥s Desconhecidos", dirigido por Andrew Haigh, apresenta uma explora√ß√£o sens√≠vel e introspectiva das conex√µes humanas. Situado em um pr√©dio quase vazio em Londres, o filme combina um enredo simples com uma profundidade emocional not√°vel, centrando-se no encontro casual entre Adam e seu enigm√°tico vizinho Harry.nnA atua√ß√£o se destaca, pois ambos os atores conseguem transmitir a complexidade de seus personagens com sutileza. Adam, um homem preso em sua rotina, acaba confrontando seus medos e inseguran√ßas atrav√©s da aventura inesperada com Harry. O encontro entre os dois se transforma em uma jornada de autodescoberta, trazendo √† tona quest√µes sobre solid√£o, pertencimento e a busca por conex√µes significativas em meio ao isolamento urbano.nnA cinematografia √© outro ponto forte. Haigh utiliza a atmosfera do pr√©dio e as ruas de Londres de maneira a refletir o estado emocional dos personagens. A ilumina√ß√£o e os √¢ngulos de c√¢mera s√£o cuidadosamente escolhidos, criando uma ambienta√ß√£o que d√° suporte √† narrativa, tornando a cidade uma extens√£o das experi√™ncias de Adam e Harry.nnNo entanto, o filme pode parecer arrastado para alguns, com momentos de contempla√ß√£o que exigem paci√™ncia do espectador. A narrativa, embora rica em nuances, pode carecer de um cl√≠max mais impactante, o que pode desagradar aqueles que buscam uma trama mais din√¢mica. Al√©m disso, a falta de desenvolvimento de alguns personagens secund√°rios pode deixar o espectador desejando mais profundidade.nnEm suma, "Todos N√≥s Desconhecidos" se destaca como uma reflex√£o po√©tica sobre a fragilidade das rela√ß√µes humanas em um mundo moderno e muitas vezes solit√°rio. Apesar de seus pequenos empecilhos, o filme oferece uma vis√£o tocante sobre momentos de conex√£o, revelando a beleza e a dor de sermos, ao mesmo tempo, desconhecidos e interligados. √â uma obra que merece ser vista, especialmente por aqueles que apreciam hist√≥rias que valorizam o sil√™ncio e a quietude na busca por compreens√£o e pertencimento.

Pushpa 2 has generated immense hype, but it seems tailored for a specific audience drawn to exaggerated and over-the-top storytelling. The scene where the protagonist interrupts a significant moment, like a meeting, to engage in an intimate act in the kitchen, starting by kissing the heroine's foot, feels unnecessarily dramatic and outlandish. Such sequences might appeal to certain viewers but fail to resonate with others who prefer more grounded storytelling.nnSimilarly, the portrayal of the protagonist as an invincible, larger-than-life figure, indulging in random, extreme acts of rebellion or romance, might come across as cringeworthy or overly sensational. The film's tendency to glorify toxic traits under the guise of machismo could alienate a segment of the audience.nnWhile the movie thrives on its raw energy and mass appeal, these elements might deter viewers who value nuanced plots and realistic character development.

This show is absolutely amazing! And all the negative reviews were 100% made by TRUMP SUPPORTERS. The thing about Trump supporters is that they'll never admit the real reason they are leaving negative reviews. Instead, they'll point to something else like the shows "storyline", claim the "villains" suck or point to literally anything they can come up with to avoid actual saying the REAL reason for their negative review. But no need to fear! I'll do it for them.nnThe real reason for the negative reviews are simply that these Trump supporters are triggered that majority of the characters in this show are minorities. The same people who are saying the show sucked, would be the same people cheering about how amazing the show is if all the characters were simply made white, it's not the show they hate, it's the skin color of the characters they hate.nnThis version of Castlevania is set in a time period where minorities were going through situations like slavery, so it's not a shocker that slavery is an obstacle these characters would have to deal with.nnI think it's absolutely awesome that Netflix created this version of Castlevania where the characters are minorities and they face realistic minority problems (slavery) from that time period. Unlike Trump supporters, Netflix didn't try hide reality, pretend that slavery never happened or get triggered at the topic of slavery for making white people look bad.nnThis show is phenomenal, watch it and see for yourself instead of listening to the negative reviews of Trump supporters who are enraged that the characters in the show aren't white.

Skyforce directed by the duo of Sandeep Kelwani and Abhishek Anil Kapur is set during the hugely tumulus war of 1965. The movie follows the events of the successful air strike where a squadron leader goes missing. This squadron leader is portrayed by the promising Veer Pahariya. On the other hand Akshay Kumar plays a wing commander cum fatherly figure. The relentless quest of Akshay Kumar's KO Ahuja in bringing a closure to his fellow men and also the wife played by Sara Ali Khan gives the movie some of its best moments. Sharad Kelkar playing Pakistani squadron leader Ahmed Hussain plays a key role in solving this mystery. The interactions between Akshay Kumar and Sharad Kelkar exploring a mutual respect for the men in the uniform across nations is also a delight to watch. My full review available in website Southfirst.

Well, just like Star Trek Discovery, Paramount has once again diminished Star Trek by overstepping DEI where the only white male in the cast is the village idiot. No disrespect for the rest of the cast. Michelle Yeoh does a fine job on building on the character of Emperor Philippe Georgio. Two other innovative ideas in the cast are Omari Hardwick, who plays special ops team leader Alok, who is an Augment survivor of the Eugenics Wars, as well as Kacey Rohl, who plays young Rachel Garrett, the future captain of the Enterprise-C. Unfortunately these two characters make up the only two compelling characters of the entire cast.nnA missing member of the cast is Star Fleet, which is simply put underrepresented. A token appearance of a Constitution Class starship would have propped up an otherwise bland plot.nnOverall the movie is still "OK", but it has more the feel of a two-episode story from an ongoing series instead of a stand alone movie. On the flip side, Star Trek Section 31 would have been a decent pilot for a new series.

CORRECT: I'm speechless. Apart from the subject we know, it's like watching a rare kind of docu-soap only interrupted by anxious noise. Just the absence of common movie sound, instead shows severe human suffering as if, forgive me the harsh expression, standing just outside an abattoir... This movie isn't about common 'evil vs victim' rather shows the perpetrators' role and from the director's point of view, without necessarily being antisemitic or racially biased. Thought out the tiniest detail of relevance in and around the villa, not to mention H√∂ss' wife's fur coat is done in a finesse way... Officers and their strict formalities, surreal their coldness of executing orders which suggests the whole operation is some sort of business model. The need to compensate for their everyday discomfort whether caused by Jews but frankly, could've been as well any other inferiority to the Nazi's.nnIn the beginning where decadence and wealth only could be achieved by exploiting, suppressing and murdering whole nations. Humans are the means. Simply the fact that humans (as we speak) are indeed capable of committing atrocities. Except for the fact that it's unseen, rarely to witness live in your own backyard. This movie just shows the schizophrenic truth behind unlimited desire for comfort and wealth in the most subtle way rather than the actual bloodshed we already know. For that reason, this movie otherwise might have been extremely boring. Scrolling down trivia and facts are also interesting to read, like what the movie's title exactly is about. Surprisingly I noticed H√∂ss' role played by Cristian Fried, 'Elser' in another strong historical drama from 2015 "13 Minutes". REPLACE WITH: I'm speechless. column3: Dosen Ghaib: Sudah Malam Atau Sudah Tahu (2024)
column4: Film horor malah jadi kocak. Gak jelas banget kenapa hantu nya tiba2 marah ke mahasiswa. Wkwkwkwk dosen hantu harusnya mengajar bukan ngejar ngejar mahasiswa untuk dibunuh. Cgi nya jelek banget, kebantu make up hantu nya aja sih. Alurnya terlalu memaksa agar ada sosok hantu, sampai nunggu ada yg meninggal baru dijadikan hantu. Kenapa gak hantu yg lokal di kampus itu aja yg jadi dosen gaibnya. Film film dari dee company ini kadang hanya untuk perbanyak produksi aja, kualitas jelek jelek semua meskipun rata rata diambil berdasarkan kisah nyata. Bubar aja kalian kalo masih bikin film begini terus!

This series has gone far too good beyond its expectations in just two- three episodes, the way its story has picked up speed and the environment they are creating is awesome. Klaus' character as usual is classic and its fun to watch him argue with his brother Elijah and sister Rebekah. Talking about The Vampire Diaries, that show is different in its own way, but there is no way TVD should be compared to The Originals as its story has completely moved in another direction. The acting of all characters is awesome and story is mind-blowing. The flashback story they are gonna show seems to be quite fun as it is related to original vampires. Even in The Vampire Diaries I was a bit biased towards original vampires and waited for their part to come (not only me, happened with many people). So all in all its good they separated out original vampires' story from TVD.

I heard a warp drive, I saw a few blue warp nacelles, a star trek logo at the beginning of the movie and a few mentions of Star Trek. That's it. That's the Star Trek you are confronted with when watching this movie. Its a disgrace. Possibly the worst Star Trek attempt ever.nnThe wanna be Star Trek movie needed less Gen-Z pandering lame-f**k slang based on ever-shortening attention span. Most characters are shallow as fu**, especially Mrs. Goth-Girl.nnOn top of everything this movie has worse writing compared to Archer's Enterprise. A betrayal to loyal Star Trek fans. Shame on you. AT least I didn't have to watch the typical length of a modern movie of 120 or even 150 minutes.

Hobbs And Shaw was about a virus who was inside Shaw's little sister and they need to get it out so it doesn't get into the wrong hands. Hobbs And Shaw need to work together to save the world.nnHobbs And Shaw was a fun movie. Although sometimes it felt like the action scenes did get a little repudiative, I enjoyed watching this movie. The acting was pretty great. They had a strong cast of talented actors that delivered. The music choice also fit well with this movie. I loved the opening. It added to the scene so much. The things I didn't like though were the CGI. Sometimes it would just look sloppy. Also it looked a little too futuristic for its time. Like I said early the action scenes seemed a little repetitive.nnOverall, Hobbs And Shaw was a fun action movie I would recommend.

DELETE: This was one of the funniest films I've seen in a while. It had everything one would expect from and love about a Lifetime movie: lead actors who can barely emote, terrible dialogue that oftentimes makes no sense, a heavy handed message that they hit you with harder than a football player hits his wife, homoerotic and incestuous undertones, misunderstandings of technological innovations, and I could go on and on about the great features of this film. It starts with the lead character (let's call her Cheerleader, who can remember the names of these people?) setting herself on fire at a football game and it just gets better from there. At the hospital the doctor tells us she was "sexually assaulted" which we can all tell means she was brutally gangraped by the whole football team. Eventually Cheerleader becomes BFFs BleachBlondDyke and they start sleeping together and they work with HeroicBlackPolicewoman to solve the case and everybody lives happily ever after. And it ended with a blatant lie of a statistic which is always fun.

The story of Sky Force is as inspiring as it is intense. It takes you back to a critical moment in India's history, narrating the tale of the country's first airstrike with authenticity and respect. The film's plot is engaging, offering a detailed look at the bravery of the pilots and the challenges they overcame. What's even more impressive is how the narrative incorporates the emotional weight of their sacrifices, making it more than just a war drama. It's a tribute to courage and resilience.takes you back to a critical moment in India's history, narrating the tale of the country's first airstrike with authenticity and respect.

The narrative of Sky Force is both captivating and deeply moving. The plot is centered on India's first airstrike, an event that's depicted with meticulous attention to detail. What makes the story so engaging is how it intertwines the heroism of the pilots with the emotional struggles of their families. What makes the story so engaging is how it intertwines the heroism of the pilots with the emotional struggles of their families. The film doesn't just focus on the battlefield; it also highlights the human sacrifices behind such historic feats. It's a story that inspires pride and leaves you reflecting on the true cost of freedom.

Sky Force is a compelling story of courage and sacrifice. The plot revolves around the historic 1965 airstrike, and the way it's brought to life is truly remarkable. The film does a fantastic job of showcasing the tension and stakes of war, with moments that keep you on the edge of your seat. At the same time, it delves into the emotional toll of these events, making the narrative deeply relatable. It's a powerful reminder of the bravery and resilience of those who defend the nation. The film does a fantastic job of showcasing the tension and stakes of war, with moments that keep you on the edge of your seat.

The plot of Sky Force is truly remarkable. It's an ode to the unsung heroes of the Indian Air Force who carried out the nation's first airstrike with unmatched bravery. The story captures the tension, stakes, and emotions of war with incredible detail. What sets this film apart is its focus on the personal sacrifices and emotional struggles of the soldiers and their families. The narrative is both thrilling and touching, making you appreciate the human cost of such historic achievements. It's an ode to the unsung heroes of the Indian Air Force who carried out the nation's first airstrike with unmatched bravery. The story captures the tension, stakes, and emotions of war with incredible detail.

Yeh movie sach mein ek cinematic gem hai! Sky Force ka har ek scene ek alag story bolta hai. Akshay Kumar aur Sara Ali Khan ki chemistry aur individual performances dono kaafi engaging hain. War scenes ka execution top-notch hai, aur dialogues dil tak pahuchte hain. Storyline mein emotional aur action-packed moments ka perfect blend hai. Sara ka character Geeta ek strong aur relatable personality ke saath portray kiya gaya hai. Ye film sirf entertainment nahi, ek patriotic feeling bhi deta hai. Sara ka character Geeta ek strong aur relatable personality ke saath portray kiya gaya hai. Ye film sirf entertainment nahi, ek patriotic feeling bhi deta hai.

What makes Sky Force so unforgettable is its blend of high-stakes action and raw emotional depth, driven by two outstanding performances. Akshay Kumar brings an exceptional level of gravitas to his role, portraying the challenges faced by a soldier during one of India's most critical moments in history. Sara Ali Khan's character adds emotional depth, conveying the anxiety and strength of a loved one awaiting news from the front. This lack of authenticity would create a jarring disconnect for the audience, hindering their ability to fully immerse themselves in the story. This is precisely the issue with the casting choices in question. The actors, while perhaps capable performers in other roles, lack the specific cultural background and understanding necessary to convincingly portray Iranian characters. This results in a performance that feels inauthentic and stereotypical, relying on broad generalizations rather than genuine cultural representation.nnThis isn't simply a matter of nitpicking. In 2025, audiences expect and deserve better. We live in an increasingly interconnected world, and media has a responsibility to portray diverse cultures with sensitivity and accuracy. The lazy approach of casting any actor with a vaguely similar skin tone is not only disrespectful to the Iranian community but also a disservice to the art of storytelling. It reduces complex cultural identities to simplistic caricatures, perpetuating harmful stereotypes and hindering genuine cross-cultural understanding.nnFurthermore, this type of casting suggests a lack of effort and research on the part of the production team. It implies a disregard for the richness and complexity of Iranian culture, reducing it to a superficial collection of tropes. This is unacceptable in today's media landscape, where resources and expertise are readily available to ensure accurate and respectful representation. Consultants, cultural advisors, and actors with the appropriate cultural background should be actively sought out to ensure authenticity.nnThe failure to prioritize authentic casting detracts significantly from the overall viewing experience. It creates a sense of disconnect and inauthenticity that undermines the narrative. Instead of engaging with the story and characters, the audience is constantly reminded of the artificiality of the portrayal. This ultimately diminishes the impact of the production and reinforces harmful stereotypes. In 2025, it's crucial that productions prioritize authentic casting and cultural sensitivity to create more engaging, respectful, and ultimately more meaningful stories. This production falls short of that standard and needs to do better.

The Great was so much better than I expected it to be. I went into it not expecting much but after a few episodes I couldn't stop watching it. I binged all three seasons as fast as I could. I promise you that you'll laugh out loud at least a few times every episode. While the entire cast is good in this is, Nicholas Hoult is the best part of this show. Every time he talks he made made me laugh. He also has the best character arc on the show. You go from not liking his character to rooting for him. Hoult is already a star from other stuff he's done but this takes him to another level. If you're looking for a new show to just have good time then this is it.

"Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom" serves as a colorful, action-packed finale to the DC Extended Universe, though it's not without its hiccups.nnThe Good:nnPatrick Wilson shines as Orm, bringing depth to the brotherly dynamic with Jason Momoa's Arthur Curry. Their chemistry is one of the film's highlights, making the moments they share some of the most enjoyable.nnThe visual spectacle is undeniable. James Wan delivers on stunning underwater sequences, with water simulations that are a visual feast. The action scenes, particularly the epic trident clash, are well-executed and genuinely thrilling.nnThe movie has a fun, cartoonish vibe that embraces the comic book source material, offering a light-hearted escape which some might argue is exactly what a superhero film should be.nnThe Bad:nnThe plot feels disjointed, possibly due to heavy studio meddling and visible reshoots. This disrupts the narrative flow and leaves some character arcs feeling rushed or underdeveloped.nnAmber Heard's role as Mera is contentious, with many feeling her presence was more of a distraction due to off-screen controversies rather than adding to the story.nnThe humor often feels forced. While some comedic moments land, many are out of place, which can detract from the film's more serious undertones.nnThe Verdict:nnThis movie isn't the epic send-off the DCEU might have deserved, but it does manage to be entertaining in its own right. If you can turn your brain off and dive into the spectacle, there's fun to be had here. It's not groundbreaking, but it's a decent, if flawed, conclusion that leaves you wishing for what could have been. Fans of the first "Aquaman" might find it a step down, but there's enough here for a good time at the movies, especially with the right expectations.nnIn the end, "Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom" is like a vibrant, action-packed comic book come to life, but it's bogged down by studio decisions that prevent it from reaching its full potential. Still, for those looking for a fun, if not particularly deep, superhero adventure, this film delivers just enough to be worth a watch.

"Evelyn" (Kathy Bates) and her husband "Ed" (Gailard Sartain) are going through the motions in their marriage. They've long stopped making any effort for each other and she is a bit fed up. It's when she is visiting a friend at an old folk's home that she encounters the frail but spritely "Ninny" (Jessica Tandy) and they get chatting. The older lady starts to regale her with stories of her younger wife in rural Alabama and of her sister-in-law "Idgie" (Mary Stuart Masterson). Over the next couple of weeks and months "Evelyn" becomes addicted to hearing the stories, as do we, of racial and sexual inequality, iniquity and joy as this small subsistence community slowly and sometimes brutally evolves. The effects of this retrospective are quite profound on the younger lady who starts to feel empowered by what she's hearing. Her confidence grows - even if her insurance premiums start to go up - and she begins to take steps to improve her domestic situation. The photography and the engagingly crafted script illustrate quite powerfully and affectionately the struggles of just about everyone in a 1920s where racism and bigotry were never far away; the KKK travelled thrived unfettered and any sort of inter-racial relationship was downright dangerous. There are also strong contributions from Mary-Louise Parker as the upstanding, preacher's daughter, "Ruth" and from Stan Shaw as "Big George" as the thrust of inspiration in the face of adversity is transferred onto life in the 1990s. Tandy and Bates prove the perfect pairing as they mix the good and the bad, the happy and the sad and a fair degree of good old fashioned common sense and stoicism to create rounded and plausible characters, a degree of nostalgia and loads of mischief. It is slightly rose-tinted, but it's still well worth a look see an ensemble cast at it's best.

Akshay Kumar's Sky Force is yet another example of his declining career. The film fails to deliver on every front, with Kumar offering an uninspired and robotic performance that makes it clear his best days are long behind him. His over-reliance on the same repetitive roles and lack of originality has made him a shadow of his former self.nnSky Force doesn't just crash; it burns, proving that Kumar no longer has the pull or talent to carry a film. The stale acting, outdated expressions, and lack of conviction make this performance one of his worst. It's time for him to step aside and let the new generation take over.nnThis film only cements the fact: Akshay Kumar is finished.

Really thought this movie was going to suck so bad based what I've seen on Twitter, but I genuinely enjoyed it. Don't understand why so many people are pissed about the best picture nomination when, in the previous years, you have shit like Green Book and Bohemian Rhapsody (to name a few) nominated for Best Picture which were significantly worse than this. Not really sure if it's just transphobic people hating on this or that people have only seen certain scenes out of context that generated the hate for this film, but I thought it was solid.nnThe vaginoplastia song was kinda goofy but there are a lot of songs that are actual foot stomping bangers too. My main complaint about the songs is that the transition into song and dance sometimes feel like they erupt out of nowhere, but when the incredible cinematography and choreography starts happening, who gives a fuck? There's also this one song in the middle of the film from the son about how Emilia smells like his "papa", which was an amazing scene and was genuinely emotional. I'm glad to see Gascon getting nominated for best actress (first trans nominee!) as she gives an amazing performance despite some questionable writing when it came to the character of Emilia.nnThe pacing of the film does start to drag on a bit. Things just seem to happen for the sake of happening and the transition from scene to scene felt awkward and unwarranted. The ending also felt a little rushed and I wish there was more of a conclusion.nnThere might be some valid criticisms regarding the portrayal of Mexican culture and I'm not well-equipped to tackle that as an Asian dude who has never been to or experienced Mexico. Overall, I still enjoyed the film quite a bit and really liked the framing of the story. Oh yeah, the sound design throughout the film was also great!

I've heard so many good things about The Great ever since it first came out a few years ago but I kept putting it off for some reason. I'm just finishing Season 2 now and I'm actually mad at myself for putting it off for so long. It's freaking hilarious! There's not a weak link on the entire cast but Nicholas Hoult and Belinda Bromilow are the ones that really make this series so good. Hoult & Elle Fanning were both nominated for Emmy's for their work here but Bromilow should've been too. It's obviously not historically accurate, it even says it in the beginning credits, but who cares? It's a comedy. If you want to laugh then go watch this.

It's been three years since the controversial finale of the originals was aired.nnI always get back to this show (in total I watched 3 times fully from start to end since 2018) and every time I get amazed by how the whole series was executed. (I tend to focus on different details every time I watch it)nnCompelling story, especially season one and season two. The other seasons were also good, don't get me wrong, but the first two just stand out.nnMarvelous cast that brought their characters to life.nnWell written characters, even the secondary ones, with a strong development over the course of the show .nnGreat setting, not too small, and not too big at the same time, making it barely noticeable that the whole show has 4-5 main locations only.nnThere is really nothing I could have want more from show that's main purpose was to be a TV drama, from the ones you put on when you are back home after a long working day.nnIt was nice being so involved with Klaus's journey.

DELETE: Bro this ain't even that bad... based off of the box office numbers I thought this would be one of the worst 2023 had to offer, but it ain't even that bad. But still definitely not good lol.nnAlmost, if not, all of the emotional beats don't work and a lot of the comedy falls flat but I still did let out a chuckle or two. The movie doesn't take itself too seriously which is a relief and the ms marvel character did not annoy me like I thought she would and was instead actually a pretty great addition. I liked a few of the stylistic choices throughout the film and also liked that they kept the tone fairly light, but when they did try to get deeper into stuff, the scenes just don't work and was unintentionally funny. A lot of the editing felt really clunky but there was a pretty fun montage sequence in the middle. The action throughout was also fairly decent.nnNowhere near marvels worst.

I can confidently say that Emilia P√©rez is one of the top 10 worst movies ever made. Calling it a disaster would be generous. This film is an insult to cinema, audiences, and anyone with even a shred of taste.nnThe musical numbers were the absolute lowest point-they weren't just bad, they were outright painful. I love this episode because it was filled with comedy and drama as wellnFirst, it started with 4 things: Kappa, travelling for the tournament, meeting an alumni of The Catullan.nnLeighton and Whitney attended a Kappa branch, where she met her brother Nico, friend Cory and used him as a beard to hide his sexuality. From the start its pretty obvious that this is a dud. Russell Crowe channels Friar Tuck on a Lambretta, facing off with the new guard in Rome who don't like the cut of his jib. Meanwhile his boss, the ailing Pope, has a mission for him, some sort of devlish possession in a crumbling gothic cake in rural Italy. The crumbling cake is being renovated by mother who has nubile daughter and odd looking son in tow. No sooner have they arrived but there are odd knocking sounds, scary music and the odd looking son starts to display demonic tendencies, a bit like Chucky with teeth braces and little dental maintenance. Its all rather down hill from there with all the usual signs of the presence of evil, claw marks on the wallpaper, bodies flying through the air, crucifixes rotating on the walls. Crowe's character even uses his (nice) Lambretta to pull the cover off the well to reveal ............ lots of skulls. Not Crowe's best work.

When the Bough Breaks has the ingredients for being a solid, memorable movie, but even with Ally Walker who plays a good role as the special agent investigating, the story doesn't rise as we hope for and expect, resulting in a disappointing outcome.nnAudrey Mcleah is the appointed investigator to solve and bring a child murderer to justice, because the cops in the locale are too busy drinking coffee and talking sh*t all the time. Martin Sheen as the Tommy Lee Jones wannabe, Captain Swaggert (no relation to Jimmy as far as Iam aware), along with his team of deadheads are the understandable reason for McLeah being asked to cover for them and help them look good and/or being capable of holding their jobs. McLeah as the somewhat rebellious, mouth-dangling cigarette character, is likeable and endearing, showing both a rough edge and a caring side, particularly toward the kid with visions, Jordan Thomas played by Tara Subkoff. Their interactions are the movie's greatest aspect amid a muddled story and slow progression. Dubbed a thriller, this takes a long time to show signs of meeting that tag and towards the end things do get a bit more 'thrilling' and exciting but the lead up to it, after the well set up introduction, super drags on in collaboration with Walker's incessant cigarette draws and I get the feeling they really wanted this to have a gritty, Clint Eastwood, Tommy Lee Jones, Carol Kane, Anthony Hopkins mosaic look and feel, but even though it's not a bad effort, they should have done more with this movie.nnI really wanted to give this a 6 because Ally Walker is good to watch here, but they just didn't bring it home the way they should have. After the good start I was left feeling underwhelmed with the uninspired and disinterested approach to expanding and lifting the pace and at the end I wasn't able to go higher than 5. Having said that, there are many worse movies out there and it's not a complete waste of your time. So, give it a go. It may work for you.

On the outside looking in, The Apprentice is the story of the rise of Donald Trump and his real estate business empire. It's also a behind the scenes look at longtime friends Roy Cohn and Donald J. Trump from the 1970s until 1986. The film showcases the story of both men in a provocative, yet humanizing and intriguing way, with love and sometimes hate towards one another. Cohn had been a prosecutor long before he met and became a mentor to Trump. It was fascinating to learn that Cohn was involved with the Rosenbergs trial and prosecution.nnThere are scenes in the film that can seem biased against Trump, and even caused Donald Trump himself to try and stop the release of the film, albeit unsuccessfully. One of those scenes involves Donald and his first wife Ivana being intimate, but the context was taken directly from first hand testimony from Ivana Trump herself when she divorced Donald. The second half of the film deals with the AIDS epidemic during the early 1980s, which was a scare to everyone because no one knew anything about it; and just the admittance of having AIDS was a social death sentence.nnI myself am not sure how Trump reacted to the AIDS epidemic, this was most likely dramatized for the film; especially when it came to the fact that Roy Cohn vehemently denied contracting the disease, but later died having been fighting it until his death. I do wonder if there will be a sequel to this film, bringing to light the next chapter of Trump's life. It'd be interesting to see, at least in a historic basis.

I love this film. It seems to be a classic romantic comedy with a flair. The premise of two characters, likely spirited and independent, probably charming and layered embarking on an emotional journey feels comforting if not groundbreaking. I really love how the story unfolds, full of heartfelt moments and charming interactions.nnWhat excites me most is the potential for stunning visuals and heartfelt moments, which films often deliver. However, the early feedback suggests the story might rely too much on familiar tropes. While that could make it predictable, it might also appeal to those people.

DELETE: You can tell this was made on a shoestring budget..it looked like it was put together with baling wire & duct tape! Could they not afford a steady cam operator?nnA question it poses...Why do people sign up to join the armed forces when they already KNOW going in, what will happen to them in civvy street, once they've served their time/purpose?nnEven Churchill didn't make it to the end of WW2 before he was voted out of office and replaced by Clement Attlee, as he had served his purpose in war.nnAnd let's not forget no-one press ganged them to sign up, they all freely volunteered to become PAID professional soldiers (none were conscripted against their will as National Service ended in 1960) so they can't complain about how they're treated afterwards..can they! How many employers look after their ex-employees, once they're no longer employing them? If you can find one...go work for them!nnBtw how many go on after their service and sign up as private sector mercenaries?..for shed loads of money!!! Where's 'honour and duty' then? You can't have it both ways..nnAnd the kicker..do all the ex-soldiers commenting on this film really want to be portrayed as illegally running around the streets of Britain murdering people using illegal firearms instead of going to the police?nnIs that how you want the British public to see you?

Inside Out 2 introduces new, more complicated emotions as Riley becomes a teenager. And suddenly the "Puberty" button goes off.nnFirst out is Anxiety, a hyperactive over-planner who is trying to help but ends up making things much worse. Much like anxiety in real life, she never lets you slow down or sleep.nnNext is Envy, which they don't develop except on a bare-bones level. Maybe that is because all of us know what envy is. But small kids won't get it. Liking someone's hair or outfit is not true envy. True envy is a dangerous thing. But that is an article for another time.nnThe third new emotion is Embarrassment. This emotion they did so well. He is exactly how my embarrassment feels. He wears a large hoodie and hides inside it most of the time. In one scene Riley is so embarrassed that Embarassmet gives up pushing buttons and just lays on the control console. It was hilarious!nnAnd our last new emotion is Ennui, pronounced: "On-U-E". They call her "the boredom" but she looks more like an Emo spaghetti noodle. I don't like how they did this emotion. They barely explained what it was and then gave it little attention. I left with the impression this was more a self-defense mechanism and less an emotion.nnInside Out 2 also opens the door for a sequel by giving us a few glimpses of the emotion of Nostalgia. She is shown as an old lady but has a few very witty moments where she wanders into the room.nnBELIEF SYSTEM -Sadness and Joy explore the Belief System ¬© 2024 Disney/Pixar. All Rights Reserved.nnAnother item Inside Out 2 introduces is Reily's Belief System. It forms a beautiful tree and its roots are various memories that make Reily who she is. The film used random experiences as the nutrition that created the roots of the belief system. In the end, they stopped being selective with which memories went into the soup. I have some issues with this whole idea.nnI disagree with their assessment that our belief system is formed only by random life experiences. The examples we are shown, the families we are raised in, and the communities we are a part of, all add to how we see ourselves. Along with that is an innate knowledge that we are something more than what we see in the mirror.nnFor example, I have always known that God is guiding me. There is just a feeling inside my heart that tells me so. And that is not something they can show in this movie. In trying to appeal to broad audiences they oversimplified the belief system.nnAnxiety Taking ControlnnAs the movie progresses Anxiety takes over. She bottles up the "old" emotions and drives Riley's life off a cliff. I recognized all her tricks as my anxiety has played the same ones on me. Feeling like you have to control everything, working myself into exhaustion, imagining all the awful things that can happen; that was my daily playlist for a long time.nnWHAT IS HAPPENING? - The Puberty Button goes off. ¬© 2023 Disney/Pixar. All Rights Reserved.nnInside Out 2 does a great job showing all that anxiety does to sabotage you. What it doesn't do is give you real coping skills, and real ideas on how to get control of your anxiety. That is where the Skylight.org app has come into play in my life.nnIt is an amazing FREE app that guides you in dealing with anxiety, stress, overwhelm, and guides you to God. It's non-denominational, and I find peace in every exercise. Truly the Skylight app should be how Reily deals with her emotions because the writer failed to give any definitive answers in that category.nnSkylight is a spiritual wellness platform that integrates mental wellness strategies like meditation, yoga, and prayer with spiritual practices. It aims to aid individuals (specifically GenZennials aged 18-35) dealing with anxiety, stress, and other emotional challenges through a spiritual lens. Given the thematic relevance, Skylight seeks to raise awareness of how belief systems can play a critical role in managing mental health issues.nnSince discovering it, I have used the Skylight app often. I have even texted it to many on my contact list. It's truly an amazing tool and I highly recommend it. I especially love the affirmations to help with political stress. I will likely memorize them all by the time this presidential election is over. Its level-headed and Godly advice has helped me many times.nnMental Wellness/ Spiritual WellnessnnIn the movie the more anxiety Riley felt the further from her core values she drifted. She took greater risks and hurt the people she loved. I have found that my mental wellness is tied to my spiritual wellness. Like Riley when my mind isn't right my spirit isn't right either. Our bodies and minds are connected in ways we don't fully understand. And our minds and souls are connected in similar ways.nnJoy and Its Role In Our LivesnnThe final thought I have is about Joy. As a character, she is my favorite and is adorable. But in my life the only true source of joy is God. It's only in drawing that parallel that I can feel joy and peace, the two are inseparable. In the final scene where Reily is asking for Joy, she is truly saying a prayer and reaching for God. And Joy is the innocence and connection to God we all need.nnI liked Inside Out 2, they really got Anxiety right, but felt it ended too quickly. The characters needed to be fleshed out more. And the plot built up resolved far too fast for me. Even with that negative, I did like the movie. I liked how Anxiety seemed like an uncontrollable force until Joy stepped into the storm and saw her for what she was- frozen with fear.nnI liked the message about how we can overcome anxiety and not let it rule our lives. And I liked the few coping strategies they mentioned. I'd go see the movie and then download the Skylight app. It's the perfect finish to the story and lets you take the message of overcoming anxiety and apply it in real life.nnIf you are like me, and struggle with anxiety, don't wait to get support. The Skylight app is a safe and easy place to begin. But I have also found professional counseling helps. Sometimes you have to visit a couple of professionals before finding the right fit, but when you do it's amazing. This world of ours seems to feed anxieties and it is our challenge to overcome and stay focused on what matters. Good luck in your journey!

Decent flick, I am not going to lie to you. It was suspenseful. The gore was cheesy but felt like old school practical horror movie special effects. The acting was actually decent. On my quest for Bigfoot movies, I'd put this between Exists and Lost Coast Tapes so far. I did not include Harry and the Henderson's because 1. Its a classic 2. Its not the bigfoot I am looking for.nnThere was even a couple jump scare moments that caught me off guard. Think about your worst Star Trek movie, or TV series. Got it? You are going to change your mind after watching this!!nnWere the writers on drugs? Have they ever seen anything 'Star Trek' before?nnLet's start a Star Trek movie mirroring "The Hunger Games", then throw in some "Men in Black" and "Meet Dave", and the creepy talking doll from "The Twilight Zone"'s "Living Doll", plus a number of other stolen ideas.nnI love having humor and a silly character or two mixed in with the dark and gritty of usual Star Trek ideas, but all of these characters were nauseating. The Cheron (black and white face) was an insult to whatever they were trying to make him. It was as if they wrote him for a movie in the 20s or 30s.nnWhat did they use to blackmail Michelle Yeoh into this crap? I love her in Discovery. She's out there and comical, but in a good way. Not at all like this. I feel bad for some of the characters who seemed to take things seriously, while still adding a bit of humor.nnI did enjoy seeing some of Georgious' past, though it seemed rather different from the snippets we saw in Discovery. San's ship was cool, as was the Baraam, but they pale in comparison to everything else.nnThis is not a Star Trek movie. This is a spoof; like Galaxy Quest. Though, I would prefer to watch Galaxy Quest, I'm sad to say, because that movie sucks!nnAll in all, a great waste of time! No one should pay a penny for this movie, or even watch it. And to think they even made the ending seem like there would be a second one. That was probably the best joke of the whole thing!

DELETE: This documentary was mostly the director sitting at his computer while narrating rambling thoughts on everything from the Lab Leak, 9/11, AIDS, etc., many of which are spurious and only serve to discredit the arguments presented that do have a factual basis. The most convincing evidence for the Lab Leak theory get lost in the sea of dubious claims and speculation. Instead of slowing down and making a solid case for the lab leak theory (or why gain of function research is too risky), we get a few bullet points for each idea before he's moved on to the next one. The 3 stars are mostly for the former director of the CDC Robert Redfield and investigative journalist Emily Kopp, who were interviewed extensively in this documentary.nnIf you are curious about the lab leak theory and want some convincing evidence, I'd recommend the book Viral by Matt Ridley and Alina Chan, reporting by Emily Kopp at US Right To Know (who is featured in the documentary in snippets, but neglects her most significant contributions), or the SoHo Forum debate "Did Covid Start in a Lab?", which can be found on YouTube or the audio as a podcast.

Watching Interstellar was nothing short of an extraordinary journey that left me in awe long after the credits rolled. Directed by Christopher Nolan, this film transcends the boundaries of conventional cinema, taking us on a profound voyage through space and time that is as visually stunning as it is intellectually stimulating.nnFrom the moment Interstellar begins, you are thrust into a future Earth on the brink of ecological collapse. The desperation and urgency are palpable, setting the stage for an epic quest to save humanity. What struck me immediately was the film's ability to blend grandiose science fiction with deeply personal storytelling. The relationship between Cooper, played masterfully by Matthew McConaughey, and his daughter Murph is the emotional heart of the film, grounding the cosmic adventure in a relatable human experience.

This movie is undoubtedly one of the most visually stunning, emotionally resonant, and thought-provoking films of the 21st century. Released in 2014, it quickly established itself as a cinematic milestone, blending the finest elements of science fiction, human emotion, and innovative visual effects. From its breathtaking depiction of space to its deep exploration of love, time, and humanity's survival, Interstellar leaves a lasting impression on all who experience it.nnIt's essential to understand that Interstellar is more than just a space adventure. While it features awe-inspiring space travel, alien worlds, and wormholes, at its heart, it delves into human relationships, sacrifice, and our role in the universe. The story unfolds in a near-future Earth facing resource depletion and environmental collapse. Cooper, portrayed by Matthew McConaughey, is a former pilot turned farmer, living with his daughter Murphy (played by Mackenzie Foy and later Jessica Chastain). Their journey begins when they discover a hidden NASA facility, where they are enlisted for a mission to find a new home for humanity. The stakes are incredibly high, and as they venture into space, they embark on an emotional and intellectual journey through love, time, and the vastness of the cosmos.nnNolan's direction is precise, showcasing that the film is a true labor of love. His talent for building suspense, wonder, and emotional depth in every scene is nothing short of extraordinary. Interstellar is a genuine spectacle, but it's not just for the sake of spectacle. Every visual element and choice carries significance, whether it's the seemingly infinite expanse of space, the stunning imagery of distant planets, or the haunting desolation of the universe.

Kangana Ranaut's Emergency attempts to dramatize one of the most significant periods in Indian political history, but instead of offering a balanced or insightful perspective, the film spirals into historical inaccuracy and blatant propaganda. The portrayal of the Emergency era (1975-1977) under Indira Gandhi's government is heavily skewed, turning the narrative into a political vendetta rather than an honest recounting of events.nnOne of the most glaring issues in the film is its deliberate spread of misinformation about Bangladesh and its revered Father of the Nation, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman. The film irresponsibly distorts facts about the relationship between India and Bangladesh during that time, diminishing the role of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman in the country's liberation and post-independence development. Such misrepresentation is not only inappropriate but also deeply disrespectful to Bangladesh's history and legacy.nnThe movie is clearly politically motivated, serving as a vehicle for Kangana Ranaut's personal agenda rather than a historical account. It takes sharp aim at the Congress party, demonizing its leaders while conveniently ignoring complexities and nuances of the era. Instead of fostering dialogue, it resorts to sensationalism, using one-sided narratives to vilify political figures.nnWhile Kangana's performance as Indira Gandhi might be compelling in parts, it cannot salvage the film's credibility. The screenplay feels more like a lecture on current political ideologies rather than an exploration of historical truths. The over-dramatization and selective storytelling do little justice to the gravity of the Emergency period, alienating viewers who seek an unbiased account.nnEmergency fails as a historical drama. It undermines its own credibility with political bias, historical inaccuracies, and inappropriate depictions. For audiences looking to understand the Emergency era, this film offers nothing but a shallow and manipulated version of events.

Jessica a hasta in deliverers, in the lead role, a fine performance. The pacing drags. Few of the interactions between Maya and her superiors feel genuine.nnBut the biggest problems with this film is that Katherine Bigelow seems to have forgotten that film is a visual medium.nnCan I really be the only review to complain about the minutes on minutes of the climax of that film in which no discernible images appear on a darkened screen and maybe there's the sound of a helicopter engine.nnPlease don't make me sit through tedious exposition only to give me a crappy, minimalist radio play for the finale.

An important film. "Am I Racist" is an incendiary and timely documentary that delves into the contradictions and hypocrisies of contemporary "woke" culture, offering an unflinching critique of how concepts like ESG and DEI are wielded in modern society.nnWhile undeniably provocative, the film is not without its flaws. It would have benefitted greatly from clearer introductions to the individuals it puts in the spotlight, as their credibility-or lack thereof-remains ambiguous throughout. Tighter editing and better sound design, paired with a more purposeful use of music, could have elevated the overall viewing experience, making the film's arguments even more impactful.nnYet, these technical missteps pale in comparison to the importance of the film's core message. By exposing the rank hypocrisy and performative nature of certain cultural movements, "Am I Racist" captures a moment of societal self-delusion that will likely be studied for years to come.nnThe fact that it has been blackballed by the Oscars only adds to its cultural significance, solidifying its reputation as a piece of forbidden art that dared to question the status quo.nnFuture generations may very well look back on this film as a pivotal commentary on the excesses of woke ideology-a bold, if imperfect, high-water mark in documenting an era of collective insanity.

First off, I don't normally speak badly of a films cast. The actors do what the director tells them. But... The guy playing the Vulcan should never be allowed act again. That Oirish accent is fucking offensive. Hollywood needs to learn literally no Irish person sounds like that, and that accent exists solely in movies. I'm an Irish actor, and work frequently as an accent coach in theatre, and this pervasive bullshit accent is so pervasive in north American media it's very difficult to break people out of it. But it's 2024,and there's zero reason for a major production to do this. If the actor is an talentless as the guy playing the Vulcan, let them do their own accent (this guy is south African). Or, better yet, if you want the character to have a specific accent just hire an actor from that part of the world.nnParts of the movie are laugh out loud funny, but they weren't trying to be. Truly weird chances of shots, weird and unexpected zooms, lingering shots on barrels rolling. It's full of weird stuff.nnNo part of the story works. It's oceans 11 without any charisma or charm.nnI can't find anything in here to recommend.

It was funny and clever, until it wasn't. Once Covid hit it went drastically downhill. I watched this show post Covid and I chose it because it was mindless fun entertainment. Something you can watch without thinking or having the world just come at you. Then it completely stopped being funny once the Covid years started. I wish entertainment could just be that sometimes - purely entertainment without yet ANOTHER lecture. But nope, they ruined a great show. I could not finish it but you should definitely watch up until the Covid seasons hit then after that; I cannot recommend it. It was completely devoid of laughter and entertainment so it lost its value to me. The show's redeeming quality was the silly immature goodness and fun of the characters but all the sudden Covid hit and it was one giant lecture on all the things you are bombarded with elsewhere and it's sad that you just cannot escape the constant lectures and just have some free time in our brains. What ever happened to good old TV sitcoms?

This the second Polish produced Corben I've watched and they have some things in common: overacting, silly, needlessly obscene dialog and poor choice of music ans sound. A complete waste of time (unless you have Polish relatives who might be in it).nnThe Corben productions filmed/produced in Britain were far superior to these schlockish productions. The Stranger, in particular, is a must watch and makes this production look like a high school film studies production. I am always leery of Netflix productions - they seem to be churned out in places like Poland or Taiwan where production costs are low and people don't care much about professional reputations.

Nick Cage never ceases to disappoint. Probably a good screenplay totally lost by poor camera work that was supposed to be cutting edge to only make the viewer feel sick and like an 8th grader filming a home video. Lots of unexplained st with no logical reasoning. Not worth the cost of the film used to record this C rated junior high school project that didn't receive a passing grade. A great example of why B- actors should not "produce" but stick to A- acting. Nick would have been better making another sleepy teenager romcom. I hand to write at least 600 characters to get this posted but cannot say anything more than this movie is terrible and a waste of the supporting staff's time other than to get a paycheck when they could've been more productive flipping burgers at McDonald's where at least they provide something useful.

Having lived all over the world, I tend to view political shows, like this one, from the perspective of how does this present Americans to the world? This show is clearly only interested in presenting the extreme left wing perspective. Many of the "experts" lack critical thinking and practical experience in the subjects presented. The people who produce this show will always be lost, confused and disconnected from real Americans, as they only seem to support a socialist agenda. If they want to be taken seriously, they would offer both sides of whatever subject they are discussing. Until they do that, this show is a TDS bubble of disinformation.

DELETE: And by that I mean the severed floor, that was very much a character in the first season. Bouncing around characters, setting their paths and challenging their understanding of their world in it's enigmatic fashion. It was the main thing to set the show apart and now it's barely seen anymore. The acting, score, the cinematography, even the dialogue is still good. No complaints there. However without that central pillar it feels like a generic mystery show. If the floor not coming back in that way then the show is not for me anymore. Let's hope it does. Maybe the writers just felt the need to reintroduce all the people after the hiatus.

Ap√≥s um hiato de tr√™s anos, Sean Baker retorna com Anora, uma obra que reafirma sua habilidade em explorar personagens marginalizados com profundidade e autenticidade. Conhecido por filmes como The Florida Project e Tangerine, Baker utiliza sua assinatura narrativa para capturar as nuances da humanidade, desafiando estere√≥tipos e desconstruindo ideias preconcebidas. Desta vez, ele tem em m√£os seu projeto mais ambicioso at√© ent√£o, com uma distribui√ß√£o internacional robusta e um desempenho impec√°vel de Mikey Madison, que entrega a atua√ß√£o de sua carreira.nnBaker divide Anora em duas metades distintas, mas complementares, cada uma sustentando pilares narrativos que envolvem e surpreendem o espectador. Na primeira metade, o diretor nos apresenta √† protagonista Anora, uma dan√ßarina ex√≥tica cuja vida gira em torno das complexidades do trabalho sexual e da busca incessante pelo "sonho americano". Aqui, Baker mergulha na viv√™ncia de Anora com um olhar afetuoso, mas realista, equilibrando momentos de curti√ß√£o desenfreada - regados a sexo, bebidas e festas - com uma sutil constru√ß√£o do dilema emocional que ela enfrenta. Essa parte inicial do filme √© essencialmente uma ilus√£o, uma celebra√ß√£o fugaz antes que a narrativa exponha as consequ√™ncias desse estilo de vida.nnA introdu√ß√£o de Ivan, um parceiro aparentemente encantador que oferece a Anora uma chance de viver esse sonho de forma despreocupada, adiciona camadas de ambiguidade √† trama. A rela√ß√£o entre eles flutua entre o interesse financeiro e a possibilidade de um v√≠nculo mais profundo, mantendo o p√∫blico em constante expectativa. Baker tamb√©m planta ind√≠cios sutis do que est√° por vir, preparando o terreno para uma transi√ß√£o dram√°tica que marca a segunda metade do filme.nnQuando a virada ocorre, Anora transforma-se em uma montanha-russa emocional. O ritmo fren√©tico ainda permanece, mas agora com uma narrativa mais introspectiva e dram√°tica, expondo os impactos das escolhas feitas pelos personagens. Baker, no entanto, n√£o se limita ao drama; ele mescla cenas carregadas de peso emocional com momentos de humor e leveza, criando uma experi√™ncia cinematogr√°fica equilibrada. A habilidade do diretor em explorar temas sens√≠veis de forma acess√≠vel √© um de seus maiores trunfos, e isso √© amplificado pela fotografia naturalista de Drew Daniels, que captura os Estados Unidos com um realismo envolvente.nnO cora√ß√£o de Anora √©, sem d√∫vida, Mikey Madison. Conhecida por seu papel em Era Uma Vez em Hollywood, Madison entrega uma performance que transita entre a com√©dia e o drama com not√°vel maestria. Sean Baker, ciente do talento da atriz, constr√≥i o filme em torno de sua personagem, permitindo que Madison brilhe em cada cena. Sua atua√ß√£o √© ao mesmo tempo visceral e sutil, transmitindo emo√ß√µes complexas sem exageros. Embora os coadjuvantes tenham seus momentos de destaque, √© Madison quem carrega o filme, oferecendo uma atua√ß√£o multifacetada que exige tanto carisma quanto vulnerabilidade.nnOutro ponto alto de Anora √© a habilidade de Baker em transformar temas potencialmente pesados em algo palat√°vel, sem diluir sua import√¢ncia. Quest√µes como trabalho sexual, desigualdade social e a busca por valida√ß√£o permeiam o filme, mas s√£o abordadas com delicadeza, permitindo que o p√∫blico reflita sem se sentir sobrecarregado. Essa abordagem evita o didatismo e refor√ßa a autenticidade da narrativa.nnEm resumo, Anora √© um filme que cativa, diverte e provoca reflex√µes profundas. Sean Baker demonstra mais uma vez seu talento para capturar a ess√™ncia da humanidade em seus aspectos mais contradit√≥rios, entregando uma obra que √© t√£o equilibrada quanto envolvente. Com uma dire√ß√£o segura, uma protagonista arrebatadora e uma narrativa que transita com fluidez entre leveza e impacto, Anora √© um triunfo que reafirma Baker como um dos grandes nomes do cinema contempor√¢neo.

Wolf Man 2025 feels more like a zombie movie in disguise than a true werewolf story, completely ignoring the rich traditions of the character. The film tries to combine psychological thriller, family drama, and home invasion horror but stumbles across the board. The thriller plot is painfully predictable, the father-son relationship lacks emotional weight, and the action and horror scenes fail to deliver any real tension. On top of that, it leans heavily into woke clich√©s, with yet another portrayal of passive, weak men and dominant alpha women, which feels tired at this point. A misfire that misses its potential.

What the hell is this garbage that is excessively painful to watch?nnIt goes against pretty much everything we know about Section 31. It has always been portrayed as an under the table organization dedicated to furthering the Federation's interests without the active participation of the Federation or Starfleet (at least "on paper") and with highly skilled and highly intelligent assets that are always on top of things and several steps ahead of everyone and everything going on. Instead, we're served some half-assed suicide squad that you wouldn't even want working the night shift in a warehouse and that are clearly a bunch of self-centered narcissists who couldn't give less than two f*cks about their mission or the Federation.nnHowever, it's in the little details that you'll find the most problems. The Terran Empire's Emperor being selected by some Korean-like tv show contest instead of the usual best of the best backstabbing to the top. A dark-eyed asian adult that somehow grew up looking like a clear-eyed European. The terrible prosthetics. The fact that they keep speaking little bits of french at the beginning but they clearly had no french speakers on the set considering they keep mispronouncing french words and names. Starfleet taking an active role in a Section 31 mission. Etc.nnI thought we'd finally have a good portrayal of the best of what's to be expected of what we all came to expect from Section 31. It is everything but that. This movie far exceeds thorough disappointment.

column3: "The Wild Wild West" (1965) {The Night of the Puppeteer (#1.21)}
column4: CORRECT: After 20 episodes hunting criminals in the Old West of 1870, it's this installment in which the special agents Artemis Gordon (Ross Martin) & James West (Robert Conrad), while they seek a man killing Supreme Court Justices, encounter their first utterly surreal scenario & inarguably genius villain, Zachariah Skull, The Puppeteer (Lloyd Bochner). Long before "steam punk" would become a thing, this brilliant installment previewed it in Skull's lair deep under the Pacific Coast. After staging a mock trial with puppets as jurists and executioners, it is the steam itself, of course, that becomes his undoing. But until then Bochner is fabulous. Mr. Martin is reliably funny, as usual, and Mr. Conrad is quite a bit better than his usual wooden self. I rate this and many imaginative installments to come in subsequent seasons as 8 out of 10 stars. And nobody (except maybe Jackie Chan) has ever given stunt men a better workout than the early MMA guy Conrad. REPLACE WITH: After 20 episodes hunting criminals in the Old West of 1870, it's this installment in which the special agents Artemis Gordon (Ross Martin) & James West (Robert Conrad), while they seek a man killing Supreme Court Justices, encounter their first utterly surreal scenario & inarguably genius villain, Zachariah Skull, The Puppeteer (Lloyd Bochner). Long before "steam punk" would become a thing, this brilliant installment previewed it in Skull's lair deep under a ocean-themed bar under the Pacific Coast. And after staging a mock trial with puppets as jurists and executioners, it is the steam itself that becomes his undoing. But until then Bochner is fabulous. Martin in disguise is reliably funny, as usual, and Conrad is a bit better than his usual wooden self. I rate this as 9 (and the many very imaginative installments to come in subsequent seasons as 8) out of 10 stars. Nobody (except perhaps Jackie Chan) has ever given stunt men a better, more bruising workout than bare-knuckle boxer and early MMA guy Mr. Robert Conrad.

What a big wet fart disappointment of a schlocky film. Horrible directing and fight sequences that are too long and difficult to follow. Too much time was spend on that stupid planet and it enough in space. Only watch this to see how not to make a Star Trek film.nn-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I honestly don't know how I can come up with 600 characters to tell anyone how ridiculous this movie actually is.nnFrom the time I saw Wahlberg's "bald wig" fail, I knew it was going to be a shitshow, but I hung with it for a while just in case.nnJust in case turned out to be a horrible waste of time. It was, seriously, the stupidest movie I've seen in at least 5 years and I've seen a lot.nnThe entire premise is ridiculous, the characters are ridiculous, and if you waste your time to see it, check out Wahlberg's over-acting when he decides he wants to be taken seriously as something other than a flash-in-the-pan.nnHilarious.

You know how the Superman is the least interesting character? He's a frigging alien who can fly, is indestructible except for plot points, and can shoot laser from his eyes?nnMeet the female counterpart. She got her powers by accidentally licking an alien battery.nnI sincerely hope that the writers of MCU tactically forgot that this character exists. (I'm maybe halfway through on the journey of watching the movies.) There's no good storylines for such an overpowered entity.nnThe movie is not bad per se. There's an interesting story, and some decent action. She finds out that her adoptive faction has been lying to her. The story is way better than the outcome. Samuel Fury, I mean Nick Jackson, is involved which is great.nnIf you're tracking the infinity stones, this is a must watch. Otherwise... Well, it's a reasonably good story with twists and turns. Ending is just underwhelming, in deus ex machina kind of way.

This show could have been fantastic. Noah Wyle is great in his role as the lead attending physician in the ER, or ED as they call it. (Maybe they don't want us to be confused with Noah's previous gig.) The other actors range from really good to meh. The stories are compelling. The production values are as good as what you'd expect from HBO/Max. Unfortunately, like too many HBO productions, it was used as a platform for preaching the Woke religion.nnStarting in the second episode, we have a white couple whose infant son got into their pot gummies. One of the nurses reminds us of our "white privilege" by commenting that they will get off scott free, while a black family would lose their child and face criminal charges. Then we have a couple of fascist white cops trying to restrain an apparently drug-seeking black woman who is extremely agitated and screaming for opioids. Of course, they are at fault for not knowing that she has sickle cell and is having a crisis. Then there's the "misgendering" incident in the fourth episode. I'm sure there'll be plenty more, but I'm done with it.

Soy fan del juego, lo he jugado un monton de veces, y ver esta adaptacion fue como un regalo, bastante increible, con actuaciones muy buenas, pero como fan no pude dudar sentir que las acciones de ser inclusivo estaban arruinando la serie, demasiada propaganda lgbtq, decisiones de casting que no entiendo, bella ramsey es increible como ellie aunque fisicamente no se parezcan la actriz lo hizo bastante bien, pero con la esposa de Tommy es diferente, no entiendo la razon de cambiar una mujer rubia por una negra, hablamos de una serie llena de propaganda lgbt y de cambios de personajes rubios por negros que no tiene nada de malo, pero reflejan las intenciones forzadas de ser inclusivos y eso molesta un poco a comparaci√≥n del juego que fue mas natural con estos temas.

Me encanta porque es muy facil engancharse, la ire desglosandose por aspectos:nnTemporada 1: 10/10 muy buena escritura, establece los personajes y el villano muy bien, bastante interesante la dinamica del asesino y su relaci√≥n con el protagonistannTemporada 2: 10/10 esta temporada sigue siendo muy bien escrita, personaje como lily y Doakes trae una nueva etapa en dexter, bastante divertida y buena, aunque no mejor que la primera en mi opinionnnTemporada 3: 7/10 En mi opinion la escritura disminuyo su calidad aqui, aunque es una buena continuaci√≥n, algunas cosas me gustaron, pero la trama de Miguel se me hace muy aburrida aunque su dinamica con dexter no esta tan mal.nnTemporada 4: 10/10 Es una obra maestra, la temporada mejor escrita, el mejor villano, dinamica y plot twist de toda la serie.nnTemporada 5: 8/10 En mi opinion mejor que la tercera pero la escritura disminuyo su calidad despues de la 4 temporada aunque esta aun tiene mucho por ofrecer, entretenida y un villano solido.nnTemporada 6: 6.5/10 Primera vez que en la serie se nota la mala escritura y la fatiga de la serie, realmente no aporta un buen villano, aunque tiene ciertas piezas creativas e interesantes, momentos de tension y drama, no llego en un buen momento acompa√±ado de subtramas incomodas e innecesarias, se siente como relleno y si no existiera realmente seria mejor.nnTemporada 7: 8.5/10 Despues del punto de quiebre en la temporada 6, la serie mejora con una septima temporada con un villano solido, momentos emocionales, giros de trama, y una escritura destacada, aunque no mejor que las temporadas principales, la dinamica entre dex y debra cambia a una mas tensa y emocional de lo que ya lo era.nnTemporada 8: 1/10 Esta temporada arruina toda la serie para mi, la escritura es la peor, los personajes insoportables, el villano nada interesante, aunque tiene sus momentos, no puedo quererla por el final tan atroz que tiene.nnEn resumen a pesar de los fallos en algunas temporadas, no he visto mas series como esta, por eso le doy 10 estrellas porque es bastante entretenida y cuenta con temporadas increibles.

Hacking Hate raises serious concerns regarding the ethics, bias, and misleading nature of its portrayal of individuals and groups. Labeling everyday people as extremists without clear evidence or justification is not only unethical but also dangerous. These mischaracterizations can have profound, far-reaching consequences, putting individuals who have done nothing wrong in harm's way.nnThe book appears to conflate regular citizens with radicals based on loose associations or shared values, rather than concrete evidence of illegal or hateful actions. This broad generalization creates a narrative that stigmatizes entire groups and fosters division. Many of the individuals targeted by such narratives have no record of hate speech or criminal behavior. They are ordinary people expressing concerns about cultural preservation, societal changes, or political issues-topics that should be open to discussion in a free society. By lumping these individuals into categories of extremism, the book fails to distinguish between genuine threats and legitimate concerns, which is a disservice to truth and justice.nnMischaracterization is not just a theoretical issue; it has real-world consequences. Those unfairly labeled as extremists can face serious repercussions, such as harassment, loss of employment, social ostracism, or even physical danger. In today's hyperconnected world, where information spreads rapidly, such labeling can result in lasting damage to personal and professional lives. Moreover, it fosters an atmosphere of fear and mistrust, making constructive dialogue nearly impossible.nnThe book's approach also raises ethical concerns about responsible journalism. Investigative reporting is powerful, but it comes with the responsibility to be thorough, fair, and accurate. Any failure to provide concrete evidence or distinguish between harmful ideologies and normal political discourse undermines journalistic integrity. By focusing on sensationalism rather than nuance, works like Hacking Hate risk becoming propaganda tools, deepening the very divides they claim to address.nnThe societal impact of this kind of narrative is equally troubling. When people feel unfairly vilified or excluded from mainstream discussions, it can lead to resentment and, ironically, further polarization. Demonizing individuals or groups without cause pushes them to the margins, where they are less likely to engage constructively. This cycle of alienation and misunderstanding exacerbates divisions and undermines the possibility of finding common ground.nnIn conclusion, Hacking Hate seems to perpetuate harmful stereotypes and misrepresentations, endangering innocent individuals and undermining efforts to promote unity. By failing to base its claims on clear evidence and engaging in broad generalizations, it risks inflaming tensions rather than addressing the root causes of societal issues. Ethical journalism must prioritize truth and fairness, ensuring that the voices of ordinary people are not drowned out by sweeping and harmful narratives. Misrepresentation is not just unfair-it's dangerous, and the consequences of such actions cannot be ignored.

O filme aborda temas como conex√£o com a natureza, intelig√™ncia artificial e autodescoberta, proporcionando uma experi√™ncia agrad√°vel para p√∫blicos de todas as idades. No entanto, √© imposs√≠vel assistir ao longa sem tra√ßar paralelos com Wall-E, uma produ√ß√£o da Pixar que, anos atr√°s, cativou audi√™ncias e cr√≠tica com uma abordagem profunda e emotiva sobre temas semelhantes.nnEnquanto Wall-E se destacou por sua delicadeza, profundidade emocional e cr√≠tica social contundente, Wild Robot tenta seguir essa f√≥rmula, mas n√£o atinge o mesmo impacto. Idea carina peccato per la realizzazione e dei momenti molto cringe, nel complesso un film sufficiente da vedere senza troppe pretese e senza impegno.nnComplimenti per la scelta del cast, ma visti gli attori coinvolti ci aspettavamo leggermente di piu.nnIn quanto ragazzi non possiamo condannare a pieno le azioni di Laurent, come me, padre divorziato, vittima delle suggestioni perverse della giovane figlia di Vincent Cassel.nnLa morale √® profonda e attuale, difatti anche un mio amico sudamericano √® caduto nella stessa trappola.nnCi tengo a precisare che queste situazioni dovrebbero essere risolte in maniera pacifica, non come Antonio che ha picchiato prima un Dj omosessuale e poi il suo amico.nnPS: la fotografia e la sceneggiatura, accompagnate da una colonna sonora mozzafiato, rendono il tutto molto strano ma altrettanto romantico.

column3: "Front Burner" (2018) (Podcast Series) {Elon Musk, Nazi accusations, and the ADL}
column4: Elon Musk has tweeted over the years that jewish people are racist against white people, that racial profiling is a reasonable predictor of crime, that homeless people are liars who just want to do drugs, that immigration should screen for intelligence, that lgbt people are a threat to women, that women should reproduce more.nnI'm skipping a lot more but these views are what make him alreasy irredeemable no matter how you defend or rationalize his "accidental" nazi salute. He has exactly the same morals as someone who would have done it on purpose anyway, making all arguments about it meaningless.nnHe's inhumane garbage and an embarrassingly childish imbecile who bought all his imaginary achievements and is by admission almost always high. Now the coke addled deadbeat father has teamed up with another equally stupid and clueless lunatic to control a whole government, wow fun.

Spoilers: Count orlocks awakens from his slumber just to get laid with an already married women. The entire movie was orlocks search for Ellen and pipe her with his thousand year old cock.nnWilliam Dafoe's character was wasted on. The whole plot was predetermined. I was expecting to have some sort of fight with grumpy ol vamp but nope.nnEnding scene was so unsatisfiying. Ol Vamp beds Ellen while suckling blood out of her breast. He gets too lost in the sauce He just fucking dies üòÇ. Guess that's what happens when you haven't get laid for centuries. And Worst costume I've seen in a minutennI was too anticipated to watch this with my family. I'm so glad I didn't. Those sexual scenes were very random I couldn't even feel the tension and could've never guessed it coming. But the aesthetic was on point. This is not what I expected for a Vampire movie to be all about. The last voyage of the demeter was such a fun watch. 5/10 just for the cinematics and Lily rose's sweet moans.

Let's just address the twig in the room. I thought Baby Groot would be grating and awful to watch, but he was not. Good use of such a character even! Did not see that coming. The animation is not great at times, but that didn't bother me too much.nnThis is definitely a good sequel to Vol 1. Quill gets to meet his daddy which leads to all kind of shenanigans on a literally planetary level. Of course there's the usual CGI slapstick involved, but that's to be expected.nnThe baddies are still hecking evil as darn, but there's some welcome development on this front. Yondu, perhaps my favourite character, gets a lot of screen time and development, but unfortunately the plotline doesn't end that well for him.nnThis is a sequel worthy of the great first installments, and I'd happily watch this over and over.

I'll first comment on the big boss. Who is obviously not the namesake Winter Soldier. My mom is a retired Big Iron gal, so I did find that funny, interesting and endearing. I'll go and flag this as review having spoilers even tho I'm not saying too much here. But obviously I'm talking about Zola.nnThe Winter Soldier as a character is... ok. Since the spoiler shield is on, I can say that the Friendshit is Magic a'la My Little Ponies plot for a brainwashed individual is just so effing old. We all saw that coming a mile away. Someone tells that individual that "hey you remember me bla bla I know you do bla"... But I'll give it to the writers, it fortunately affected the plot really late in the game. And even then, not that much.nnThis film is kind of a mixed bag. The end fight was not that great, but the visuals in said battle were stellar. I like Falcon, and Anthony Mackie does a solid role. In direct comparison, the dudes who've played War Machine are a bit crap. The plot on overall is pretty good, but the execution is kind of underwhelming at times.nnSince the spoiler shield is on, this film is NOT about The Winter Soldier. It should be called The Fall of S. H. I. E. L. D or The Rise of Hydra. To be fair, I did guess that piece of the plot.nnIt's not a bad entry to MCU, and if you haven't seen it (and are interested) I'd definitely give it a go.
