The anticipation of this film getting released was HUGE for me and it did not disappoint one bit! I've only dabbled in the dye free lifestyle for a couple years now, but watching this is just so much more eye opening to the issues at hand. Having your feelings validated while you listen to the personal stories and the knowledge shared on topics involved - it's sad, it's angering, its motivating - because it makes you want to stand up to the industry and hold them accountable for using crap ingredients! Dye is only just the beginning. I simply cannot recommend it enough! Especially if you are new to the journey or apprehensive or just need the extra encouragement.

Tony does not die in this episode, and here are the reasons why:n1. A hitman isn't going to sit at a counter like a schmuck. He's going to do it the way all hits that happened actually went down: Quick, no fuss, no muss, in & out.nn2. The war between Jersey and NY was over. Even if they wanted to pop Tony, they wouldn't have done it so close to establishing a truce, especially since Phil was out of the picture.nn3. How did the assassin figure out they were going to Holstens? Did Tony make a Facebook post "Phil's dead! Time to hit Holstens with the family for a celebratory shake! :)) "??? It was out of character for the family. They would have celebrated the end of the war with a steak; not shitty onion rings.nn4. The rumor going around that Patsi brokered the hit. If it happened earlier in the series, this would make sense. Now, it would do nothing destroy 2 families since his son and Meadow are going to get married. There is absolutely no way this hit would happen in this way if Patsi was involved.nn5. It would have been way too contrived of an ending. There is no rhyme or reason to the whole execution of the hit, ergo, it did not happen.nn6. When Tony looks up and the scene goes black, he is looking at Meadow coming in. The "hit man" was taking a dump in the bathroom behind him. The black out ending definitely was a great way to end the show because 20 years later, people still talk about it.nnSo there you have it. Tony lived long enough to see Meadow have children, then he suffered a heart attack that everyone knew was going to happen. It was sad, but he went out a happy man. Carm finally consummated her love with Furio. Future Trump helicopter pilot, AJ, ended up working at Costco. Did anyone ever really think he had the drive to do anything? When he is home, he streams himself playing Leagues of Legends. He's single, ladies.

Kangana Ranaut's Emergency explores the emotional and moral dilemmas of Indira Gandhi, shedding light on the human side of the Iron Lady during one of India's most controversial periods. While the film focuses more on Gandhi's personal struggles than the Emergency itself, it captures pivotal historical moments with a balanced narrative. A story of resilience and inner conflict, it deserves appreciation beyond political biases. The first half of the movie takes its time to establish the narrative and might feel slow-paced to some, but the second half picks up momentum, delivering a truly engaging and compelling experience.nnRead my full review on Infinite Sea of Opportunities: The Woman Behind the Iron Lady: A Review of Emergency.

I was reminiscing about this movie with friends recently and decided to see what it scored here.nnIn case you don't know, this movie is a classic amongst black Americans. We've all seen it probably multiple times. It's easily in the top 4 Eddie Murphy movies all-time. It's hilarious, has heart, a redemption plot and it gave us Halle Berry!nnYes I know it's not for everybody because some people won't be able to relate and that's okay.nnBut the low rating is an indication to me that the ratings aren't trust worthy, especially when you add in the review bombing that people do for shows and movies before they're even out.

The Howling (1981).nnKaren White: "A secret society exists, and is living among all of us. They are neither people nor animals, but something in-between".nnFor me, it's the best werewolf movie, one of my favorites in the horror genre.nnThere are four attractive women: Dee Wallace Stone, Belinda Balaski, Elisabeth Brooks and Margie Impert.nnI saw it when I was young, now I'm older than Christopher Stone in the film. Belinda Balaski stole the show, her character Terri Fisher overshadowed the protagonist Karen White.nnI would watch an extended cut of The Howling with scenes I've seen as extra material.nnThe film has, for me, the best werewolf design, being bipedal and two meters tall, all designed by Rob Bottin.nnIt's like a message about a religious community that is a minority, a perverse secret society that wants to destroy those they don't consider equal.nnChris Halloran saves the day. He kills the werewolves with silver bullets and burns them alive in the barn.nnThe film has great scenes like Eddie Quist's transformation, also when Karen White transforms and is killed on live TV.nnAlmost all the characters were well written like Dr. George Waggner, Eddie Quist, Terri Fisher, Chris Halloran, Fred Francis, Dick Miller's character. Even the odious R. William "Bill" Neill especially when he really shows his true face as a scoundrel.nnGood music of Pino Donaggio.

Eraserhead (1977).nnThis guy, Henry Spencer, is forced to marry and take care of a child that is not his. Mary's plan was to leave this mutant child to stupid Henry and run away to get pregnant again with another mutant. Mary turned out just like her mother.nnDream after dream, the worst was the one with the girl with cheeks that looked like testicles.nnThis mutant child was very annoying and sickly. The best was when he laughed at Henry when this idiot was in love with his neighbor prostitute.nnThen Henry kills the mutant child because he couldn't stand his mockery.nnDavid Lynch passed away, I regret that he never made his cut of Dune (1984). That version would be what I expected, now I wait for the version of more than four hours.nnEraserhead in the black and white image stands out, it looks like a low budget movie from the sixties like Spider Baby or, the Maddest Story Ever Told (1967).

Slow Horses is a sharp, stylish, and darkly comedic spy thriller that stands out in the crowded genre by focusing not on glamorous espionage action but on flawed, disillusioned intelligence agents operating at the margins of MI5. Based on Mick Herron's acclaimed novel of the same name, the series introduces viewers to a team of misfit spies who are relegated to a dilapidated office known as "Slough House" after botching their previous operations. The show's unique premise, complex characters, and clever writing make it one of the most compelling and refreshingly original spy thrillers in recent years.nnAt the heart of Slow Horses is Jackson Lamb, played with masterful irreverence by Gary Oldman. Lamb is the foul-mouthed, hard-drinking, and perpetually disgruntled leader of the "slow horses," a group of disgraced MI5 agents who have been sidelined after failing in their careers. Oldman's portrayal of Lamb is both hilarious and haunting-he brings an edge to the character, making him a bit of an anti-hero, someone you can't help but root for despite his abrasive personality. Lamb's sardonic wit, sharp intelligence, and deeply cynical worldview are a perfect counterpoint to the often stifling and bureaucratic world of British intelligence. The character is a breath of fresh air in a genre often filled with morally upstanding and heroic agents.nnThe rest of the cast is equally impressive, with standout performances from Kristin Scott Thomas as the icy and calculating head of MI5, and Jack Lowden, who plays River Cartwright, the ambitious but na√Øve young agent who has been sent to Slough House as a punishment. River's journey is particularly compelling, as he grapples with his desire for redemption while navigating the chaotic and often absurd world of Slough House. The ensemble cast does an excellent job of breathing life into the characters, making them feel real, flawed, and relatable.nnThe show's strength lies in its ability to balance dark humor with tense, high-stakes espionage drama. The script, adapted from Herron's novel, is full of biting dialogue and sharp wit, which elevates the series beyond your typical spy fare. The characters' interpersonal dynamics, particularly Lamb's gruff mentorship of River and the often-hilarious office politics within Slough House, provide a much-needed levity to the otherwise tense and suspenseful atmosphere. The humor feels natural and never undermines the high-stakes drama, which is a tricky balance to achieve.nnThe show's pacing is also notable. Slow Horses takes its time to develop the characters and build suspense, allowing viewers to become invested in their struggles and motivations. Unlike many fast-paced thrillers, the show doesn't rush through its plot. Instead, it slowly unfurls the mystery surrounding a dangerous terrorist plot that could jeopardize national security. This deliberate pace creates a sense of tension and anticipation, drawing the audience deeper into the world of espionage. As the characters uncover clues and navigate the political minefield within MI5, the story becomes more engaging, with each episode peeling back layers of the mystery.nnOne of the series' standout elements is its exploration of the consequences of failure within the intelligence community. The agents of Slough House are there because of their past mistakes, and the show dives deep into the psychological toll of being cast aside by the very institution they once served. River, in particular, is a character torn between the desire to prove himself and the resentment of being relegated to a backwater office. The show doesn't shy away from exploring the darker side of intelligence work-failure in the field has real-world consequences, and those who make mistakes are often punished with bureaucratic exile.nnVisually, Slow Horses has a sleek, moody atmosphere that mirrors the tone of the story. The production design reflects the drab, institutional environment of Slough House, creating a sense of decay and stagnation that perfectly complements the show's themes. The cinematography is restrained but striking, with moody lighting and muted color palettes that emphasize the gritty, sometimes oppressive nature of the characters' world. The visual style adds to the feeling that Slough House is a place where careers go to die, a fitting metaphor for the characters' struggles.nnThe show also doesn't shy away from the contemporary political landscape, weaving in relevant issues such as surveillance, privacy, and the ethics of espionage. It's a commentary on how intelligence work has evolved in the modern age-how the lines between right and wrong blur, and how those in positions of power are often more concerned with self-preservation than the greater good. These themes give Slow Horses a sense of relevance and depth, making it more than just a typical spy show.nnWhat truly makes Slow Horses stand out, however, is its embrace of complexity. The characters are flawed and multidimensional, and the story doesn't offer easy answers. Each character is dealing with their own demons and ambitions, which makes the series feel more human and relatable than many other thrillers in the genre. Lamb, for example, may be a brash and seemingly indifferent leader, but as the series progresses, we begin to see glimpses of a man who is more than just his gruff exterior. River's arc, too, is one of self-discovery, as he learns that being a good spy requires more than just following orders-it's about navigating moral gray areas, balancing duty with personal integrity, and sometimes even embracing failure.nnThe show's combination of intricate plotting, character development, and dark humor ensures that Slow Horses remains consistently engaging. The slow build of suspense, paired with its sharp wit and emotional depth, makes it a standout in the crowded spy genre. It doesn't rely on explosive action sequences or over-the-top set pieces; instead, it focuses on the human element of espionage-on the people behind the intelligence reports, the failures, and the compromises.nnIn conclusion, Slow Horses is an exceptionally well-crafted and refreshingly unique spy thriller. With its smart writing, stellar performances, and complex characters, it offers a deeper, more introspective take on the espionage genre. Gary Oldman's masterful portrayal of Jackson Lamb is a highlight, and the ensemble cast adds further depth to a story that is as much about personal redemption and the consequences of failure as it is about national security. If you're looking for a spy series that blends sharp wit with suspense and emotional resonance, Slow Horses is a must-watch. Slow Horses is a sharp, stylish, and darkly comedic spy thriller that stands out in the crowded genre by focusing not on glamorous espionage action but on flawed, disillusioned intelligence agents operating at the margins of MI5. Based on Mick Herron's acclaimed novel of the same name, the series introduces viewers to a team of misfit spies who are relegated to a dilapidated office known as "Slough House" after botching their previous operations. The show's unique premise, complex characters, and clever writing make it one of the most compelling and refreshingly original spy thrillers in recent years.nnAt the heart of Slow Horses is Jackson Lamb, played with masterful irreverence by Gary Oldman. Lamb is the foul-mouthed, hard-drinking, and perpetually disgruntled leader of the "slow horses," a group of disgraced MI5 agents who have been sidelined after failing in their careers. Oldman's portrayal of Lamb is both hilarious and haunting-he brings an edge to the character, making him a bit of an anti-hero, someone you can't help but root for despite his abrasive personality. Lamb's sardonic wit, sharp intelligence, and deeply cynical worldview are a perfect counterpoint to the often stifling and bureaucratic world of British intelligence. The character is a breath of fresh air in a genre often filled with morally upstanding and heroic agents.nnThe rest of the cast is equally impressive, with standout performances from Kristin Scott Thomas as the icy and calculating head of MI5, and Jack Lowden, who plays River Cartwright, the ambitious but na√Øve young agent who has been sent to Slough House as a punishment. River's journey is particularly compelling, as he grapples with his desire for redemption while navigating the chaotic and often absurd world of Slough House. The ensemble cast does an excellent job of breathing life into the characters, making them feel real, flawed, and relatable.nnThe show's strength lies in its ability to balance dark humor with tense, high-stakes espionage drama. The script, adapted from Herron's novel, is full of biting dialogue and sharp wit, which elevates the series beyond your typical spy fare. The characters' interpersonal dynamics, particularly Lamb's gruff mentorship of River and the often-hilarious office politics within Slough House, provide a much-needed levity .

From the preview, you want to like it. Once the wheels start spinning though, it just starts losing traction. The makeup of Art the Clown looks creepy and nightmarish when you first see him. Once he's knocked around a bit, the mask just looks like a sick psychotic person wearing a poorly fitting mask. He isn't scary. He just looks like a pervert who likes to mutilate people, not someone or something like Chucky, Jason, Mike or Freddy, who really makes you jump out of your seat. There's a lack of surprises, no suspenseful buildup. You even know what order the silly characters are going to be killed in. If serial murders and mutilations were categorized, this one would equate to standing in line at the post office or DMV wishing the experience would be less boring and get over with quickly, and that's with it only being an hour and 25 minutes long. You could have seen Goosebumps 10 times, and it would still be scarier than this. It was rated R due to nudity of two of the female victims, some foul language, and maybe the unscary profuse gore. Even the sci-fi reanimation of Art was subpar. My 14 year old daughter wanted to stay up with my wife and I to watch a horror movie. She wanted something to give her a nightmare. She was rather unamused, unscared, and somewhat bored to tears. Somewhat a predictable snoozefest.

Emilia P√©rez, a 2024 French-Mexican musical crime comedy, was one of the biggest surprises of the year for me. The film doesn't simply rely on genre tropes; instead, it cleverly intertwines a lawyer's financial struggles, a transgender person's psychological journey, and societal crime issues into a captivating narrative. It's not just entertainment; it's an artistic exploration of social themes.nnThe economic pressures faced by lawyer Rita Moro Castro (Zoe Saldana) are crucial to the plot's progression. Her need to survive forces her to make morally questionable choices, prompting viewers to reflect on the boundaries between law and ethics. The transgender experience of drug lord Juan "Manitas" Del Monte (Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n) delves deeper into the complex issues of gender identity and societal prejudice. Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n's portrayal of Emilia is stunning; her exceptional acting perfectly captures the character's internal struggles and transformation. I won't spoil it, but her performance is a major highlight of the film.nnBeyond the compelling plot, Emilia P√©rez is also an excellent musical. The musical numbers aren't just for entertainment; they advance the plot, express character emotions, and enhance the film's artistic merit. Overall, the actors deliver outstanding performances. The two lead actresses, Zoe Saldana and Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n, are particularly noteworthy, their nuanced portrayals showcasing the characters' complexity and multifaceted nature. The dedication and high standards of the entire behind-the-scenes team are evident.nnIn conclusion, Emilia P√©rez is a highly recommended film. It boasts a captivating plot, superb acting, and beautiful musical numbers, but more importantly, it touches upon significant social issues that leave a lasting impression and encourage reflection.

I would recommend this movie to pple who like magical movies and detective stuff.................... so this movie is about The Horsemen, a group of four street magicians, rob a huge sum of money that belongs to insurance magnate Arthur Tressler. The group is chased by FBI agent Dylan Rhodes and Interpol agent Alma Dray.....Through illusions and sleights of hand, the Four Horsemen steal millions of dollars from the corrupted elite. There is a big reveal at the end of Now You See Me. The FBI agent on the case, Dylan Rhodes (Mark Ruffalo), was actually the ringleader of the entire operation. Apps had spoiled buh it's a good movie I would give it a ten out of ten.

This kdrama was very exciting. It has everything; romance, thriller, action and more romance. The actors have an incredible conexion and transmite every emotion they filmed. I saw a lot of dramas, and I'm absolutely sure that this is one of the best.nnThe final was very good, if you want to know more about the story, you can read the novel; the actors did a great job showing the feelings from the novel to the scene. And obviously their professionalism and relationship to work at the same agency helped more to show us a wonderful work.nnI'm just enraptured and grateful to this amazing work.nnThank you to all the people who worked in this project.

If yhat mission was to kill erotics. Margaret is always wonderfull but the chemistery was non existant, the other charachter is a pain to watch. PAINE I tel you. The lesbians scenes destroy any fantasy anyone had ever had of mabe watching one, they lack passion, tenderness excitement, it looks like they dont want to be with each other. At all. How could the film makes have missed it?nnThe writing was mostly expected. The only funny one was the cop lesbian who gave a good nasty performance.nnI did not believe these two would fall in love in a million years on any alternate universe.nnI came here to read reviews and seems to be an agreement this is an amazing failure. You don' see such an offensive, star filled movie but boring, everyday.

This drama was phenomenal and captivating, i dont know why some people give a bad rating. There were definitely plot holes and all sort of that but they don't deserve that bad reviews. It kept me on each every week and now it's over I keep watching it non stop, only crash landing on you made me the same way. The main leads did a great job portraying deep unspoken emotions, which is really a gem these days. I would recommend to anyone and see for yourself how entartaing it is besides the chemistry between the leads is on a another level way too real, and the soundtrack is for me what keeps the show thrilling.

As a fan of The What A Cartoon Show and back in the UK, I was hoping that Butch Hartman could create a cartoon if not his very first cartoon, and on March 30th 2001, he did just that.nnHowever despite my intention of being invested in him and despite this being much better then TUFF Puppy (The only Butch Hartman cartoon I've considered to be the worst), the show actually did nothing for me.nnTo the show's credit, the show started off very well as the show has an interesting concept, having a kid after getting tormented by his babysitter have his Fairy Odd Parents which to be fair and did it's heyday any favors.nnThe idea of having fairies for your own protection definitely made this innocent enough, however though, what made this flawed is how it was executed, so this is how it goes, perfect potential, abhorrent execution.nnBut before we can go on with it's flaws that prevented this from getting a positive review, let's talk about the good things in this, as I've said before, the concept is very creative and what could have made this amazing, the voice acting is right on point and the animation and artwork are legitimately good, also one other good thing is that it has the sweetest ending to the episode, Channel Chasers.nnNow with the flaws, first of all, the show continuing to go on until 2017 is a big mistake since having Timmy lose his Fairy Odd Parents in Fairy Idol (Well, in the end of that episode) was bad enough, if you look at a superior cartoon from 2001 named Braceface, you'll notice that Braceface didn't need to last for 16 years as a few seasons were enough, with The Fairy Odd Parents, not so much.nnSecond of all, adding in too many characters was also a big mistake, although I will admit that these new characters don't come near as awful as Dudley Puppy from TUFF Puppy (Which is an abomination against humanity BTW), these new characters likely didn't do the show any favors and as a result, it was unnecessary.nnThirdly, there are times where the old main characters especially with it's old characters can be out of character and with some of its episodes, it's not a surprise considering that the old episodes can have it's flaws.nnLastly, this show is just a mess, the show could have end on Channel Chasers, but instead the show has to continue until July 2017, cause God knows we couldn't have a shorter show, can we?nnOverall, for as mediocre as The Fairy Odd Parents is and despite the newer episodes being the worst part of this, it's still not as TUFF Puppy is.nnOverall rating: 2 out of 4 stars = 50% (If only for it's moments)nnAgain, I've liked this better then TUFF Puppy and Danny Phantom, but that's still not much of a positive saying, but other then that, I'll be happy to give this sympathy.nnA better cartoon from 2001 is Braceface from Teletoon, because it didn't need to last for 16 years just to prove a point, but as I've said before, I'll be happy to give this show sympathy either way.

I've never cried so hard for a series in my entire life.nnThis was truly a masterpiece.nnEverything is perfect in every sense imaginable. My heart will never forget how beautiful it was to find a series that can change your entire day just by thinking about it.nnThe actors are fantastic, the color palette is immaculate, and the art of cooking, drawing, and painting is something that never failed to amaze me thoughout the series.nnI've never been a fan of queer cinema, but this one is pure passion and obsession for one another, a craving for the other's touch and understanding, that completely changed every thought that could ever exist in my mind.nnThank you so much for creating this.nnI'm not going to be okay for a year.nnAnd, well, i think i kinda love gay cannibals now.

Running for more than 18 years is big thing in itself. To complete whole episode within 45 minutes requires alot of courage. The acting is super good with complete drama, suspense and humour. The stories are always different and new. We cannot predict the culprit even till last 5-8 mins left.nn*Rating:* 4.5/5n*Genre:* Crime, Thriller, Draman*Review:*nn"CID" is a long-running and highly acclaimed Indian TV show that has captivated audiences with its gripping storylines, clever plot twists, and memorable characters. The show follows the investigations of a team of detectives from the Crime Investigation Department (CID) as they solve complex crimes and unravel mysteries.nn*Strengths:*n1. *Engaging storylines:* The show's writers have consistently delivered intriguing and suspenseful storylines that keep viewers hooked.nn2. *Well-developed characters:* The characters, particularly ACP Pradyuman (Shivaji Satam), Abhijeet (Aditya Srivastava), and Daya (Dayanand Shetty), are well-fleshed out and relatable.nn3. *Clever plot twists:* The show's writers are masters at crafting unexpected plot twists that keep viewers guessing.nn4. *Socially relevant themes:* "CID" often tackles socially relevant themes, such as corruption, domestic violence, and child abuse, in a sensitive and thought-provoking manner.nn*Weaknesses:*n5. *Over-the-top acting:* Some actors' performances can be a bit melodramatic and over-the-top.nn6. *Repetitive formula:* The show's formula, while engaging, can become repetitive, with some episodes feeling like rehashed versions of previous ones.nn7. *Lack of character development:* Some characters, particularly the newer ones, can feel underdeveloped and lack depth.nn*Verdict:*nn"CID" is a gripping and entertaining TV show that has become an institution in Indian television. While it has its flaws, the show's engaging storylines, memorable characters, and socially relevant themes make it a must-watch for fans of crime dramas.

I liked the show when it originally aired but I fell in love when the show went into syndication. Damon Wayans, Tisscha Campbell and the remaining cast are hilarious.nnAhhhhh............. No. By far one of my favorite lines throughout the show. The chemistry between the married couple gives hope for those of us looking for love. The kids plus their friends were cast perfectly. The characters of Junior, Claire and Katie get funny from day one.nnThe funnies transcend color lines and just bring the funny for family entertainment. My daughter and I watch at least one show before going to bed every night. One of my all time favorites.

Iron fisted Pankaj Tripathi's character couldve easily reached the grandiosity of Tywin Lannister - but was let down by some underwhelming story line.nnThe plot proceeds to become a funnel shape - It feels like the characters rush and make irrational, contradictory, uninspiring choices - because there is no time for the show, I guess! A great TV show would pause, expand its realm of possibilities and then rationally proceed in a certain direction. Their diaolgues fail to maintain the gravity during the critical moments.nnMany would accept with me - 1st and 2nd episode are like oxymorons. Tad disappointing.nnThey have a good number, brilliant cast - but have shrinked them - all those characters in past 2 hours - they all now belong to just 2-3 families. Being a show of war and power, expected many people/ families in the mix, vying for power and getting smashed in all the chaos happening.nnLike most tv shows, the first half of 1st episode/pilot raised the bar so high- gave expectations of an iconic 9-9.3imdb. Then on, 2 episodes in, feels somewhere around a 7- 7.5-ish imdb tv show. Still a good show.

column3: Adult Swim Yule Log 2: Branchin' Out (2024) (TV)
column4: I haven't seen the original Adult Swim Yule Log, but I was drawn to the premise of a horror movie protagonist getting stuck in a Hallmark Christmas movie. After watching this, I'm happy to report that "Yule Log 2" met and even exceeded my expectations!nnFollowing the tragic incidents of the first movie (which are briefly recapped at the beginning), protagonist Zoe is on the run, desperately attempting to escape the killer flying Yule Log that's after her. Thoroughly traumatized, she discovers that she's able to take refuge from the horror by entering a Hallmark-style small town Christmas movie... for a while, anyways. What ensues is a Hallmark movie parody-romantic comedy-horror mashup with a gnarly finale and a surprising commitment to treating the Hallmark movie beats sincerely.nnThe actors were well cast and turned in performances that were uniformly on point for the tone of the movie. (Special kudos to Michael Shenefelt, who was utterly charming and earnest as the Hallmark leading man, and who also did a great job shifting tones when the story veered into campy horror.) The writing was good, the characters were surprisingly likable, and Zoe's arc of trying to overcome her trauma was unexpectedly effective and emotional.nnThis movie definitely isn't for everyone - there are some pretty grotesque moments, splashes of Adult Swim-style surrealism, and very sincere Hallmark movie elements, which is a unique combination of tones, for sure - but this movie is consistently entertaining and well made, with some great jokes, charming performances, and a solid story.nnAs of early 2025, it's streaming for free over on Adult Swim's website. If horror movie meets Hallmark Christmas sounds like your cup of tea, you owe it to yourself to check this one out!

Wow! Everything that was annoying me by the 5th episode in a slow moving tsunami of force gets answered in the following episodes especially the last episode brilliantly written and edited. The acting is fantastic and is very well cast also. Kevin Kline is other worldly in this character the accent he chose is perfection for this character. The actress playing young Catherine I think spent her whole life loosing roles to Margo Robbie. She's brilliant and so nuanced playing the different story lines. I had rated this show a 7 and by the end gave it a hard 9. The sex scenes are very sexy but nothing that outlandish. Very well done. Highly recommend.

This could have been one of the best remakes in bollywood, but failed to do so. Had a lot of potential but couldn't survive.nnThe Editing of the film is its biggest drawback, even after being 2hour 45mins long, it is very fast.nnIt doesn't give too much time for a scene which leads to Wamiqa Gabbi's feel like someone out of the story, even Keerthy Suresh's character was not given enough screentime. If the makers would have touched the 3hour mark, it would be better for the film.nnThe scenes cut instantly, one second your somewhere else and the next second you are somewhere else.nnThe second drawback would be the VFX, it has very average VFX, seems like most of the film's budget was used in music video's and action scenes.nnHere's the best part, the action scenes are good. Not as expected but they are pretty good, these action scenes get elevated by Thaman's background score which gives it a better cinematic experience.nnOverall a one - two time watch.

This is the "movie" of all time. I would rate it as a musical, but I'd end up giving it a worse score. The arcs of the main characters somehow move slower than a snail with a foot injury. I originally thought the main character would be the daughter (forgot her name tbh), but it turns out to be the one who learns the least by the end of the movie. James Bond has spent too much time practicing how to be an agent, but needs to spend even more time in a sound proof room working on his singing. At some points in the film, they must have told a drunk Streep to "do the same thing you did earlier". I'd like to think that Brosnan and Butler (from Phantom) had a pissing contest on who could be the worst singer in a movie musical. If you like listening to ABBA, play their soundtrack on Spotify, as it will save you from having to experience this movie.

This series essentially repeats Dexter: a psychopath who is like this becuase of some trauma in his childhood, and now he keeps getting away with murders. Except that here it's all done for love and women. The attempt to make this show likable by female audience forces it to follow the conventions of the entertainment material targeted at women. What's those?nnFirst, the character is your typcial "dangerous man who got tamed by the heorine", exactly what women find sexy (at least according to Jordan Peterson, if you care for he says anyway). To a male viewer, the core idea in the plot that some guy would do serial killings just to be liked by some girl is ridiculous. If a guy would go to such lengths, it would likely be for some more man-like reason. E.g. Raping those victims. Or, like Dexter, restoring "social justice". Or something else like money, power, fame, maybe religion or some crazy global conspiracy theories. Taking huge risks just as part of the courtship ritual is absurdly unrealistic, yet obviously plays to the fantasy of female viewers. Cuz see how much the girl valued here! Serial murders are committed in her name, wow! And that's boring/meh to male viewers. Men like porn, not romantic novels about Spanish princes courting your random average Cinderella.nnSecond, the focus of this show is always on the female characters! The male "protagonist" here is 2D and never really explored. We don't even learn about him much untill later, even until the closing episodes of season 2! Like in most women-targeted content, the man is never an actor of his own. Instead, he is just an attribute, an accessory to women. Like, in a dress-up game for 4 year old girls on an iPad, you'd first dress up the girl into a luxurious bridal dress, and then, as an afterthought, put a groom nearby as a single item. Similarly to how you'd put a pet puppy, a cage with a parrot or a pony ride. The girls are the real actors here. Also, we always see the relatives and the friend circle of the girls. Because that's what makes life of a female viewer. And the protagonist (the serial killer) has no one. He just appeared from thin air, like a hologram or a 2D cardboard. "Hi! Here I am. I'm a dangerous guy but I love you, so I'll serve you like a tiger pet in World of Warcraft. Just give me some meat occasionally and I'll tank the mobs for you".nnThird, the female characters have interesting lives here while the guys are either losers or nobodies. In the first season, the girl is an aspiring writer. She has a goal in life, a career ahead of her. What does the guy do? Nothing! He just "owns a bookstore". 1 "hobby", reading. That's it. Aside from reading books, this guy does nothing. Well, he kills people to get liked by the heroine. But other than that, nothing. No gaming or sports or other typical guy's interests. No desire to go to college, or get rich, or create/invent/discore something. Why? Because it's a movie for women. If this guy would have any manly interests, it would move him away from the female viewer. Instead, he needs to like things that women like. Reading is gender-neutral, even a bit womanly. So, that's fine. Everything else? Hm... I guess it would work if he'd like travelling and dining in restaurants. But that would contradict the "dangerous" attribute. Reading physcial paper books looks weird/retro enough to your average female viewer, so that works fine for a "serial killer".nnForth, notice how murders aren't really shown. We rarely actually see this guy murder anyone, especially the girls. E.g. Season 1 ends with the guy merely grabbing the girl. Just imagine how gruesome the actual murder scene would look! But no, the show writers can't do that because this would make the character unlikeable by women. He has to stay likable. For that, he must be just "dangerous" but not the actual unhinged meat-grinding machine that he pretends to be here. See, it was a difficult task for the show writers to present a serial killer in a way that he wold fit the female-likeable archetype! I guess I have to applaud them for completing their mission. Yet, since their target audience wasn't even men (and I'm a man), it's kinda irrelevant to me.nnOverall, the show is still somewhat fun to watch simply due to frequent plot turns and the tension it manages to keep up. As long as you don't try to bother with the psychology and the motivations of the characters. And are okay listinening to boring conversations between mediocre female friends here and there. There is no uniqueness or "spark" here though. It's nowhere near Dexter or great shows like Breaking Bad, for example. It's a passable and forgettable show that you probably will get completely bored of by the end of season 2.

Not impressed with any of the actors performances or the story line. Pretty vague, no depth and without seeing the original it might not even had made much sense. Perhaps the actors themselves weren't passionate about the film either, considering the seasoned cast. When characters died, there was no reaction from Lucius. Just a weird smile thing that he kept doing followed by cheesy cinematography and dramatic music. There was no attachment with the audience, either. When it ended, on another weird cheesy scene, I was glad to just be done watching it.nnAt the end of the day, this was just a mediocre at best film. If you're a fan of the original, you'll most likely be disappointed if you watch it. I was. Some movies don't need a remake.

It could be a Black Mirror episode and it would certainly be good, but just one more. For a feature-length film it is basic. Surely some will say that it is intellectual, even philosophical and a work of art, but it is a disgusting film. I feel like it is a modern copy of the Portrait of Dorian Gray, The Wild Ass's Skin or The Devil in the Bottle, but extremely poorly done, a fraud. Nothing new, where the subject is addressed in an extremely predictable way and also contains a lot of filler, especially at the end where it is exaggeratedly prolonged, repeating the subject that has been made clear in the first 30 minutes. Not recommended.

This movie is a soft version of two family seeds or personas that meet in an arena hosted by a local guide (shout out to the true local mapping guides that edit contributions freely to the betterment of society, LG LocalGuidesConnect.com / Mappers) that host two cousins battling their own issues. It draws on true situations of emotions from different spaces of humanity. The acting brings two extreme versions of our own selves with its subconscious or next of close relationship person (the voice always in our head) and shows how gravity forces pull but maintain love. It's pretty easy to watch, not cringing, or out burst of emotional anger just flowing effortlessly.nnGiving it an 8 . It hits close to everyday activities and situations on a nostalgic level . In 2025 , if you want a slow down in reality with not much emotion it worth the non over consumption of probating emotions. It's common sense . It's real. It's human .

"La fonte des neiges" is a happy, sincere affirmation about the positive value of poise and self-confidence in one's own, completely nude body.nnThe film is set entirely within a European nudist resort, occupied by entire families of self-confident and self-accepting nudists: grandparents, parents, teenage children, younger children, and babies.nnThe main character is Leo, and he appears to be about 13 years old. By natural inclination, Leo is a little stand-offish & reserved; his first gut-reaction upon entering the nudist resort is to bundle up, even though the rest of his family fully disrobes without a second thought, Leo dons a winter coat and puts on a mask over his eyes in reaction to witnessing all the self-possessed, confident nudity in the nude camp.nnWhen Leo meets & befriends a pretty, self-confident, nude teenage girl, he begins to internally reassess his chilly attitude toward his own body.nnThe English title for this movie is "Thawing Out," and this section of the movie is indeed about young Leo "warming up" to the progressive realization that his own body is a sunny manifestation of Life's realities. With the companionship of the older teenage girl as moral support, Leo soon sheds all his clothing & is poised & relaxed while moving around the nudist camp with his companion in close proximity.nnThe boy Leo is not stunningly beautiful, like a 13-year-old sculptor's, painter's, or Fine-Art photographer's model might be; rather Leo is appealingly cute & sturdily put together for a youth of his age.nnAll the plentiful nudity in this fine film is solidly family-centered and life-affirming. Nothing whatsoever sexually explicit occurs in "La fonte des neiges," so if you're seeking out a "sexy" film, keep looking elsewhere, because you will find nothing sexually explicit in this movie!nnAt one point, at the teenage girl's invitation, Leo briefly touches one of her breasts; yet even this is not sexual in nature, but rather, the sincere expression of innocent curiosity (he's never touched a breast before - what could that possibly feel like?). Leo is simply seeking out tactile sensations. And so, this short film moves onward in the spirit of positive self-assertion & pleasant discovery.nnAt least initially, there is likely to be a prominent, perceptual difference in how this movie is received by American viewers versus European viewers. And that difference is caused in the following ways:nIn the United States of America, young children are often taught - either explicitly or implicitly - that the completely nude human body is somehow "shameful" or "unpresentable." The American child intuits "the body" to mean "my own body;" and so the American child internalizes the message "my own body is shameful & unpresentable" at a young age. The nude human body is regarded as something akin to a closely guarded, State Military Secret, and the acceptable occurrences of complete nudity are severely limited to showering & bathing, marital intimacy, and visits to one's medical doctor.nnAt issue also is the status of the Fine Arts in the U. S. A. The American nude sculptor; the American nude painter; and the American Nude Fine-Art Photographer are largely ignored by the American citizenry, and they don't garner anywhere near the respect and renown that their counterparts in Europe enjoy.nnFinally, the repositories of the "proof positive" regarding the Beauty & luminosity of the nude, American body - that is to say, the art galleries & art museums - are sparsely attended; and the instances of art exhibits promoting "The Nude" are kept artificially low in the U. S. A.!nnIn Europe, however, you have an entirely different attitude & an entirely different set of values regarding the completely nude human body. In Europe, the human body is regarded as a substantial, naturally occurring, happy manifestation of earthly Life, especially during one's prime of life (16- to 25-years-old?). Even European Religious Conservatives are fond of recounting the Biblical passage where humankind is described as being "Made in the image of God," strongly implying that the nude human body is a pleasing articulation of God's Creative Powers - now that's a strong affirmation for the children of European religious Conservatives to internalize & believe in!nnEuropean children are taught to keep their bodies clean & healthy, so they can exhibit self-confidence & calm poise when they are nude; it is the parents' responsibility to instill these positive values into their children's value system & mindset. And, in many European countries, the positive, aesthetically pleasing value placed upon nudity is plainly evident:nn1) France & Spain; these two countries have the finest nude beaches and the finest nudist resorts & nudist camps in the world! Every summer, thousands upon thousands of citizens visit these establishments, and many bring their entire families along with them. Grandparents, parents, teenage children, younger children, and babies all enjoy these nudist establishments together (with the babies necessarily wearing diapers).nnThe finest stretches of beachfront are usually set aside for nude use; and the resorts & camps are clean, well-maintained, financially robust, and accommodate heavy, regular traffic.nn2) Germany; Has established, legally designated "Nude Zones" in its public parks; within these nude zones, visitors can walk or jog, sleep, lounge, sunbathe or simply congregate and talk with other visitors. This practice, referred to as "Free Body Culture," emphasizes body positivity & a connection with Nature!nn3) The Netherlands; Has established, officially designated nude beaches. Nudity is recognized as lawful in areas where nude usage has been traditionally established for years, and in any areas where it is not specifically prohibited.nn4) Finland, Sweden, and Norway; After long, very cold winters, citizens take advantage of the short, warm summers by sunbathing & swimming nude. Also, complete nudity is assumed & expected while enjoying saunas; the entire family is expected to participate, including teenagers & children. Complete nudity is encouraged as part of the authentic, traditional sauna experience. The wearing of swimsuits & undergarments are prohibited as they are considered unhygienic. Small-sized towels to sit down upon are permitted, but larger towels designed to wrap around your waist are prohibited.nn5) Iceland; Complete nudity is encouraged during the enjoyment of natural hot springs, pools, and spas.nnIt is important to note that all of the cast of "La fonte des neiges" - even the older folks - evince a calm dignity about their physical selves, and young Leo finds peacefulness & self-assurance in calmly presenting his sturdy, nude, 13-year-old body.nnFor American viewers wishing to appreciate "La fonte des neiges," I give this advice: 1) First of all, RELAX before watching the film - there is nothing whatsoever confrontational or sexually explicit in this 28-minute-long movie!; 2) If you have deeply ingrained, negative attitudes regarding the nude human body (including your own body), try to set these negative attitudes aside temporarily, and simply let the quiet magic of "La fonte des neiges" wash over you!; 3) Try to appreciate the nude bodies in the same way you might appreciate a sunrise or the roll of incoming waves crashing upon a pristine beach! Both the beautiful, feminine companion of Leo & the cute, youthful sturdiness of Leo himself have their luminous appeal, but that appeal is not sexual in nature, rather their appeal is organically self-evident, and grounded in peacefulness & calm.nnIf after you watch "La fonte des neiges," you want to readopt your deeply ingrained, negative attitudes about nudity, by all means, do so, if that somehow makes you feel more comfortable. Just please don't let your negative attitudes poison your full appreciation of this excellent short film! As I urged before, set your negative attitudes aside for the full duration of the movie; it's only 28 minutes long, and that's not an arduous task!nnIf you're a European viewer, you need no advice; you already have the positive mindset and appreciative value system required! So sit back & enjoy!

Vert good.. Superb film. Its a shame that our ass licking media missed it, as there was no khans.nnIt's a low budget movie, still it was very nicely crafted. Had there been slightly better financed things like VFX, Set, etc could had been better.... so our financiers should back such attempts.nnIt has showed our triumptant rich history which the psedo secular-biased historian-politico nexus had kept intentionally dark.nnWe read about Aurangzeb but never about the hero who won more than 120 battles. PatheticnThakur Anup was amazing, superb. He showed supreme acting skills and was extremely proficient. Direction, screen play, script etc were excellent. Altogether a very good moview. Cudos to the makers. Bravo.

I think director completely misunderstood the meaning of fast paced movie. He made one with faster playback speed.nnVery relatable though. Reminded me of my Monday morning rush when alarm clock doesnt work.nnDirector might be onto something though. I noticed that emotional scenes when played at increased speed makes them so funny, songs too.nnI am like 30 mins into the movie as I am writing this review and I was betting this movie cannot have any songs at the speed its churning. Lo and behold, there it was. But I missed it by the time I looked up.nnI feel for the actors. Forget about getting into character, I dont think they had time to get into costumes.nnPoor thing IMDB doesn't list the time statics otherwise this would have been a good contender for fastest movie ever made.

I was excited to watch this as I love Richard Linklater. But, is this a romantic comedy? Is this a drama? Is this an action film? Is this a soft core porn? It hits on all these things but Exactly, what is this?! Initially, I was so happy about Glen Powell being in it and turns out, he is actually a nerdy looking guy. He's definitely not the future of pretty boy actors - in my opinion. If this movie becomes wide spread, it might destroy his career. The story was all over the place. I looked at my watch a lot and was really glad when it was over. Retta was wonderful and I just wanted to yell, "Treat Yourself!" every time she was on screen because seeing her was a treat to me. It was just ok but I never want to see it again and hopefully I'll forget I watched it next week. Courtroom scenes were funnier than the whole movie.

What a spectacular film, out of the ordinary, what an incredible social critique, the ending was just a bit exaggerated, but that's also part of the criticism, I thought it would be just another generic horror film, no, far from it...nDemi Moore and Margaret Qualley worked very well, what courage to play the characters they did!!!nnDemi Moore and Margaret Qualley's performance was exceptional, it was strange to see the Death Stranding character live, but it was great!nnThe interesting thing is that they barely talk to each other, but I still thought it was very good, as there was no lack of dialogue.nnüëèüëèüëèüëèüëèüëèüëèüëèüëèüëèüëè

Beautiful film hard to follow sometimes because of the quiet conversations. Love the black-and-white and then transition to color. It shows the timeline. Great storyline shows the in-depth feelings of Leonard. It has been more prevalent in recent movies. They show that there were a lot of gay people in the past. Nothing wrong with that. It's just amazing how it has come out and become more of a theme. It is interesting that this is about a classical music artist as supposed to now pop artists that are more prevalent nowadays. It is good to see how classical music grew and became popular. The backstory about Leonard was very good.

Watching this one after Blood Sick Psychosis helped me recognize writer/ director Brewce Longo's style of storytelling: amazing gore effects, the occult themes, inspiration taken from real life serial killers, romance, broken relationships, live musical acts, the greatest collection of posters ever shown on film, and the SOV footage that makes it all look realistic.nnLike you're watching the home movies of these characters.nnIt was great to see a Krampus celebration, where before it, it is properly explained that Krampus day is on December 5. But most people like us celebrate it on the 25.nnWhile everything its great like always, the out of nowhere stand out scene was whennIzzy, the female protagonist calls her dad. The incestuos insinuations of the Dad was creepy in a hilarious way. We just couldn't stop laughing. If you like films like Nekromantik, you're going to love this one.nnIt did traumatized me again with another scene of blood splashing on a John Water's Pecker film posters. Lol.nnGoing through our marathon of blood sick productions films it's starting to mess with our brains. My wife may give up soon, but I will continue all night, dwelling in the sick SOV world of micro budget horror films.

Santosh - a movie where BBC was involved. As soon as I saw that, I knew this will be nothing more than a propaganda stunt. A non muslim cop hunts down an innocent muslim and the innocent muslim dies in the end. The crime was committed by non muslims and the muslim guy paid the price. Its like a typical Crime P@trol show episode, just longer.nnI could not make sense of most of the things in the movie because most of it was intended and not clearly established. The director tried to experiment but could not establish if the lead was a lesbian or no OR if the police officer who investigated the case, was that or no. There were signs. The only lead investigated was a phone of the victim and nothing else. While the victim was found in the water well, her phone was at home? I failed to see why the movie got so many accolades. It is a very poorly written story focusing on the BBC angle of how the british still view India. Overall, a not so good experience. I watched it after reading so many good reviews and nowadays, I am losing all faith in them.

Wow. Where to start. Billy Bob Thornton is perfect in this role. I mean, he's basically playing himself but he nails that. The rest of the show is pretty ick. The overt sexualization of the 17 year old daughter; the entire character of the mother/ex wife. The blatant anti-environmental messages. It's just like most of the CBS Paramount line up... Tailored for boomers and middle America. Is the storyline compelling? Sure. But the tropes. My god, the tropes. Even the blatant product placement of a Michelob product feels calculated to appeal to the anti Bud Light crowd. Thank goodness BBT is so funny.

... MEN OF BOYS TOWN still managed to fall into every pothole the earlier film avoided.nnFather Flannigan (Spencer Tracy) has expanded Boy's Town without the money to finish the new additions. So he's on the hook for 200K that he doesn't have for wings that are not finished. Just like in the first film, he follows his heart and not a balance sheet. He taps philanthropist Dave Morris (Lee J. Cobb) to help him with the predicament. But Morris is more of a money spelunker than a money man himself, so while the rest of the plot progresses, he looks for truly wealthy people who can help him.nnSince Whitey was reformed in the original film, he can no longer take on the role of deliberate mischief maker. So I guess it's a tribute to Mickey Rooney's acting talents that it takes two child actors to replace his part in the original as the tough kid who won't be taken in or softened up by "the hooey" Boy's Town is serving up. One kid was found guilty of manslaughter and has been "paroled" to Boy's Town. The catch being that he has a broken back and is thus paralyzed from the waist down. The other tough kid is "Flip" who escapes in Whitey's (Rooney's) car -without Whitey's knowledge - when Whitey goes to visit a boy who is in a reformatory.nnThe film takes a dark turn for a while towards the end when it shows the brutality dished out to the children being held in that reformatory. Arthur Hoyl is great as a brutal and sadistic reformatory guard. Of course, part of what makes these 30s and 40s films great are the supporting actors who always played certain types of roles. Hohl was almost always the slippery villain, so the film does not need to take up time and space telling you what kind of person his character is. When you first see him, you just know he's trouble.nnIf you liked the first film you'll like this one. Of course it's somewhat derivative, but that's probably what audiences wanted when they bought a movie ticket to a Boy's Town film in the first place.

Worst film ever. It made no sense. Was it a film about spousal abuse masquerading as a werewolf movie?nnYou won't ever get this time back if you watch this garbage.nnTerrible (nonsense ending) that cheats the audience. Obviously they let Kit be the draw since they had no story to speak of.nnThe entire film is a tease and a lie.nnFile under"not worth a damn."nnPretty sure the audience was thinking of a better film (and ending) while watching it.nnIf this had actually been a horror movie about a werewolf versus an abusive husband, it might be able to redeem itself. Unfortunatrly the to film wanted to be terrible and it succeeded.

When I worked at the Dayton VA I had the honor of caring for a number of WWII female vets. I cared for a nurse survivor of the walk in the Philippines who shared her story with me, a clerk who was a widow who joined the Air Force when her two sons who both joined the military, she was 90 when I met her. I was on the Board of the Ohio Nurses Association when Dorthy Cornelius was the Executive of ONA and had cared for the survivors of "The Walk, and her emotional difficulties as President of the International Nurses Assiciation when they held their convention in Japan. As a NP in Home Bases Prime Care for the VA I cared for an African American nurse who served in England during WWII. She had dementia and had never talked with her care giver a niece about her time overseas. She had albums of pictures showing her time in the all negro unit but couldn't tell me anything about what she did or where she served other than England. She lived in a small town north of Dayton. She was a pleasant, delightful, educated women. I always wondered about her story as the pictures confirmed its truth. I just finished watching The Six Triple Eight and I now know at least some of her story. When I stated at the VA in the 600+ bed Domiciliary we had one building of women who served in WWII, it was like what we now call an assisted living facility. I am so proud to have cared for all of the veterans but especially the women, many of whom shared their stories with me. I thank Tyler Perry , Kevin Hummel, Kerry Washington for her magnificent portrayal, along with all of the cast and crew and the researchers who brought this important story to the forefront. Most importantly to the women who have served in the armed forces. Those in WWII and Korea where such roll models for me it was an honor to care for all of the veterans I met during my many years with the VA.

Just watched this over two nights. I rarely regret watching international horror flics, and I don't necessarily regret watching this one, however, this is 3-4 star, tops. Two nights to watch an 80 minute movie should be a hint.nnBe wary of any comparisons to Blair Witch, and especially any rating above 5. While I commend the production on a fairly interesting premise originally, the storyline and execution is often painful to watch.nnActing is fair, location is decent. But trying to follow the storyline, ridiculous. Lots of talk of ley lines, ghosts, plus the usual crew that includes a psychic medium, dude that explains everything, and a rather bland ghost hunting troupe that can't be bothered to get up from their monitor and check out the 1100 sq. Ft. Home, when the shit hits the fan. Typical stuff.nnI think only the writer and/or director (possibly the same person), could follow what the hell was supposed to be going on. Black foot ghost, mysterious binary code scratched into the walls, possessed child, dead psychic, all that kind of good stuff that was so disjointed, only the original author could understand it. And some forced conflict between the guy running the whole show and his exec producer and host, just to check that box.nnOh, and I don't think the show would be going on, in any capacity, 1998 or otherwise, after an on camera sudden death.nnAnd the topper for me:nnI think, (still not sure) they tried to pull off a Shaymalan twist at the end, that absolutely did not work. Or at least was not executed in a fashion that a viewer would accept as 'hey, cool twist!" Time shift, ley lines? What the hell? It just added to my wanting to end the movie before the credits ran.nnAlso, I saw no attic in that two story townhome from the many exterior shots. Perhaps that was just something I missed.nnNot the worst, but definitely not reflective of the 8-9-10 ratings.

I knew that they only have 12 episodes, so the show will be fast paced. But this one really didn't give me enough time to breathe. The first half of episode 1 is all about world building. And they delivered it really well. They give all information in just the first 30-40 minutes, The personality, the couple relation, and the side characters. Thriller shows usually use hooks, to make the story more thrilling, but they used conflicts. As every episode you definitely will be conflicted.nnLet's talk about it's negative first,nThe only thing I want to complain about is its lazy screenplay specially in the finale episode, the scene holds too much information the whole Argan sequence needs to be stretched, to understand it in more depth. There are many times in the drama i want that it needs to get strech to understand the sub plot more....nnNow it's positive,n1. Having a mature approach in the direction, of how they developed the understanding, after resolving all the miscommunication and misunderstandings between them.nn2. Acting, All actors did an amazing job in portraying their role. Yoo Yeonseok and Chae Soo Bin you guys proved You are the best choice for this role. The one gem whom I wanted to highlight is our Kidnapper Park Jae Yun you deserve all the praise, The way you adapted your character was amazing. Same with all the senior experienced actors less screen time but huge impact.nn3. The chemistry between the leads is amazing as in the first half there was zero lines between them it was one side conversation, still they managed to show that chemistry....n4. The thing I liked the most is that they didn't add too many unnecessary supporting characters in the plot, also the amount of screentime they gave to second leads is decent. Because half of the dramas in 2024, second leads were the highlight of the show and got more praised than the main leads.nn5. The technical aspects of the show the sound design, cinematography, OST's were amazing. The OST made the scenes 10√ó better.nn6. The last but not the least is a well written villain, Believe it or not the writing of Villain is 100% perfect. A psychopath who likes to play with peoples life by killing them, He gets thrill from doing that. But in Heeju's Sa Eon (Baek Yu Yeon's) case the whole situation is different.nnPsychopath accomplished what He longed for He wanted to ruin Baek Yu Yeon and He accomplished that not physically but mentally this time. He made Baek Yu Yeon lose his mind that he stopped thinking rationally and started being dumb and acting cowardly.nnThe Romance of drama is divided into 4 partsnFrom Suspenseful/Thriller Romance, The starting of everything where the initial stage of the caring nature of Baek Sa Eon first appears. To slow burn which unfolds gradually, with the characters moving from emotional distance and mistrust to connection and reconciliation over time. To the psychological where romance emerges as a product of healing and understanding, with characters emotional states, traumas, and inner conflicts. To mature phase, where narrative focuses on a marriage rather than a budding love story, emphasizing the complexities and struggles of maintaining and rediscovering love in an established relationship.nnIts not a perfect but a good show you can enjoy, it'll entertain you. And will not make you bore...

The initially hapless leads Mila Kunis (Audrey) and Karen McKinnon (Morgan) were superb, a great foil for each other. Spy hunks Justin Theroux (Drew, CIA) and Sam Heughan (Sebastian, MI6), with lovely cameos from CIA boss Gillian Anderson, Jane Curtin and Paul Reiser as Morgan's batsh*t parents, Ivanha Sakhno as the psycho assassin (Nadedja), James Fleet (Vicar of Dibley!) and Carolyn Pickles as Drew's parents, Fred Melamed (Roger) who was so slimy. I was less keen on the CIA character of Duffer (Hasan Minhaj).nnGreat gags, visual and one-liners, and some great minor characters. Without giving anything away - the guys eating pizza watching TV, the Ukrainian, the taxi driver, the motorbike car chase, the attempted hiding place, the enormous Backpacker, the American and Aussie tourists, the lipstick; just a few of the things that made me laugh out loud. Superbly choreographed aerial acrobatic fight too. A real fun pick-me-up, one I'd definitely watch again and like to own.

This movie is so bad, I had to write a review, and I hate being that kind of reviewer. I was trying to start watching more films to get creative inspiration, and my lord, was this a terrible way to begin! The story is unbelievable and not in a good way - the script makes you wonder how this is an actual movie, and not a TV movie, for example. Rotten Tomatoes has it at the 100 score, so I feel incredibly misled and will have to go back to double checking every movie on IMDb from now on, even though I know, no rating system is perfect in this regard. I don't want to bash the acting in general, but some folks definitely leave a lot to be desired - I cringed at times, and I feel fortunate to not have done that in a while. The ending was unexpected, but still annoyed me because it just took the "film" that much further from reality. I haven't written a comprehensive review in some time, anywhere, so pardon the ramble, but I feel like I was taken for a fool by this project. A waste of time, will never watch again or recommend to anyone. Not totally sure why I'm giving 3 stars, but I guess it wasn't a 1-starer as I've, sadly, seen worse.

column3: "Imagine" (2003) {Sir Roderick Stewart: Can't Stop Me Now (#27.4)}
column4: Absolutely chilled, open, honest and enjoyable look at Rod's career and life. The ups, downs and roundabouts. From his early youth trying to find his way. Meeting Ronny Wood and them joining The Jeoff Beck Group and their early tours of the States. Leaving TJBG to form The Faces from the remnants of The Small Faces . The rise to fame, crazy touring, partying and obviously 'girls'. The end of the Faces, Rod's solo career taking off and new home in L. A. Meeting movie star and pin-,up Britt Ekland. Ventures into investing in art and a new musical direction. Break ups, depression, musical wilderness years. It's all here . But very well delivered with a cheeky grin and passion for his art and love of all music. He deserves everything he's achieved. A cheeky chappy Essex/Scotland lad who has entertained millions over decades. In his own way, on his terms and with his unique undeniable voice. Never ever seen him being a diva or obnoxious to anyone. Loves his family. Long may he and it all continue.nnMore of a 'working class hero's than some others that have used or been given that moniker.nnAll the Best Sir Roderick Stewart.

Just saw this beautiful, deep, rich, layered, movie. Perennial in its themes, graceful √Æn dialogue, richnes of characters, elegant, supple and humorous.nnA film of mere entertainment value like a previous reviewer said?!nnUtter nonsense. This film is about the noblest most significant topics there are: freedom fighting, betrayal, the vanity of artists, but also their greatness coming out as an involuntary function of their otherwise humanly flawed character. The fleeting love, the superstitions of those caught in power struggles they can't control.nnWhat's even more outstanding than the depth of the topics and their marvellous satirical joyful tone is the atmosphere. So charming and alert. Full of a full spectrum of emotions, from picaresque to delicate erotic power struggles like the scene when the beautiful Countess both seduces and overpowers the genius creator (Rossini) who's in the nonchalant position of selling out for the privilege of making art, both astutely aware of it and slightly ashamed AND grateful for the joyride through life his talents allow through his masters. But when the Countess stands in the inn room and dominates him mentally like the superior moral conscience she is, she's also reaching down to him and offering understanding, redemption. And at the same time, testing him. An exceptional female character of strength and elegance of spirit and intellect such as we can only find in period cinema nowadays... As the trend for "strong female characters" in contemporary stories is for no moral conscience, no elegance, and no feminine grace. The scene between the two is beyond romantic, it takes its intense charge from the realities it represents: the artist and his conscience; the Faustian pact he signs in order to be allowed the toys of his creation, the freedom of exerting his talent. The two actors are splendid in these roles, which can't be easy to perform when there is much meaning beyond the surface seduction level visible to the eye and the jealous innkeeper's daughter. The latter representing the almost atavistic forces of society, the raw emotions but also medieval superstitions of the poorer classes, caught up as disposable plaything in the games of the rich that stop at the inn, by accident.nnTomes could be written about this movie, in which everything has oodles of meaning. I'm sure the merit is to a very large degree that of the director, Nae Caranfil, but also the story itself. Although one cannot help but wonder how much of that spirited, satirical but ultimately benevolent wry smile of the creator is Caranfil, and how much comes from the book. It's a tone and an attitude the director brings to each movie, and which transfers very well from Romanian cinema to this international story, of a different era. Because great universal human truths are pretty transferable in place and time. The narcissistic, insecure, delusional character of poor Beyle could easily be one of those mumbling navel-gazing hipsters in today's cinema, yoyo-ing between over-stating his appeal and devastating insecurity before the fairer, and in this film, it seems, the smarter, braver sex.nnSuch characters read very current. Human folly is a constant regardless of time and place. Finely observed by Nae with equal parts condemnation and realistic ridicule, and forgiveness, for in his universe, all the characters suffer with some form of folly. A closest approximation to life one can find in cinema. Where ridicule, chance, irony and low rank passions frequently lead heroes to denouements their ambitions, aspirations and notion of self never would, if unhampered. The gap between ego-bubble-driven expectation and reality. But as it is, our folly, our ideal selves, our aspirations (Beyle's pseudo romantic projects, Rossini's constant pursuit of creation on a production line, the freedom and independence pursued by the partisans ending up in failure due to, not lack of military tactics, honor or courage but... Superstition).. these idealised self perceptions of people always crash and burn in Nae's movies because of ironic sabotage of great projects by petty passions, like pebbles that bring down empires, as it were. It's an almost Shakespearean view, an all seeing, all understanding eye of the creator. A creator that truly understands the entirety of the Human tragi-comedy and despite experiencing the full spectrum of human experience (love, warfare, friendship, betrayal), isn't ever silly enough to over-indulge any of them, as he's all too wise and knows nothing lasts the test of time; nothing, not even the most delicate of loves and honourable of freedom-fighting, is spared of ridicule and farce on the long term. This alone, which spans all of his movies, is alone an attitude that makes him as an Artist suitable for the pantheon of Great art and cinema, with perennial quality; I place him in the same family as the Coen Brothers. But the same quality makes him perhaps not so popular today, an age I call the Age of Mediocretes; where art, cinema and stories in general ("girl fiction", hello!) are expected to offer a Disney-fied, sugared, cheesy, naive view of the world.nnWhere people are expected to be simplistic caricatures of human motivations, with no self awareness, idealised selves and little humor.nnI can only speculate that an audience, here or in Romania, raised on the milquetoast art of the last two decades, will write negative, assinine reviews like the gentleman before.nnBut what I'd like to know is why this film doesn't have wider circulation, seeing as it's perfectly timeless, and completely international.nnI thought I should expect a Romanian slant or flavour considering who the movie maker is. But no. Perhaps an Italian or French viewer could comment better, but to me it seems like the film nails the idiosyncrasies of those glorious two nations in their specific historic moment really smoothly, with grace.nnI won't comment on a favourite part of the movie which is the freedom fighters. Because of the current political landscape, which is perhaps a comment in itself-the best one, really.nnI did feel a sense of unsatisfaction athe end: I wanted more. More of each subplot. More of each character. I would like a whole series with Rossini, the pathetic but ultimately loveable Beyle, the beautiful Countess and the lucky Nencini .. all featuring their own intricate plotlines. So in the absence of this, I'll just have to watch it again. Like with every Caranfil movie, delicious detail jumps up with every viewing.

Whilst visually attractive, this has got to be one of the most miserable and tedious films I've bothered to watch to the end.nnIt should have been good - beautiful Swedish / Hungarian scenery, a mysterious cult with a hefty serving of sex and gore. The problem was that every single character was so unlikeable and irritating, I was left cold when they were dispatched in increasingly bizarre and gruesome ways.nnThe film centres on a dysfunctional young couple on the verge of breaking up who are both so needy and self absorbed, I found myself rooting for the bad guys.nnIt was billed as a folk horror but was as scary as my elderly Pomeranian dog - nothing like the excellent Hereditary which was also directed by Ari Aster.nnAnd why was it so self indulgently slow? Nearly two and a half hours that could have been condensed into 90 minutes.nnIf you want to watch hours of self indulgent, one dimensional characters bickering, back stabbing and looking miserable whilst being dispatched by totally unbelievable cult members, this is the film for you.

WTPR skyrocketed to the top of my top 10 k-dramas for 2024 (maybe even all time). It was for sure a comfort drama during this cold winter. No K-drama is perfect but you can see the time, dedication, and attention to detail that the cast and crew provided.nnYYS and CSB did an exceptional job keeping my attention (currently re-watching again because Fridays and Saturdays are so dull now). MBC couple awards was very well deserved and YYS and CSB deserved their individual awards as well.nnWishing YYS and CSB continued success in their future projects (I will for sure be watching). YYS and CSB have gained another fan through this drama!

And this movie is a good example why. Personally, I would not want to survive a nuclear war for so many reasons, and the madness and brutality represented here is a huge one. No way would I want to be in this situation.nnThe premise is possibly old hat, but this is done well, except for some holes others have pointed out. Where are they getting electricity? How are they keeping the batteries charged if that's the source. How do they have running water? The stale air and smokers, etc. And one for me...how is the one woman not being raped? There are two dudes who have really lost it, killed the other lady. I can't imagine why they leave the her alone after that.nnBut besides all the clear flaws, the depravity of humans is the real point. And on that level, it's done well. Not a for the faint of heart.nnMaybe after seeing it, you too would run to ground zero!

I like Dolly and understand that this is trying to teach some kind moral lesson about not judging people. Sadly the main character is trashy, she goes out of her way to dress way past normal cute or even sexy. I try not to judge based on appearance but most of her tops are actually fancy bras. I tried to like the character but the fact that she thinks it's ok to be with married men made it pretty hard. When she starts giving sex advice to her married friend it got too weird. Just because the characters seem like hallmark and have Dolly Parton I could not reccomend this to anyone. Having said that one thing I agree with Jolene about is an affair should be blamed on both parties.

This 1937 version was recently aired in the USA by TCM (Turner Classic Movies), but it was billed as the 1950 version, in colour, with Stewart Granger and Deborah Kerr. The station also described the 1950 version in their intro.nnThis earlier 1937 version is more gritty, and and the story is probably helped by the poor and contrasty print quality. It somehow seems more ominous.nnThe print quality is explained in the IMDb "Trivia" section - for years the negative was thought lost, so it is by a great piece of luck that we have it now.nnThe action is fast and dramatic, reminiscent of the Silent Era. Unlike the 1950 version, this was actually filmed in South Africa, and the scenes of the warriors were great. Truly scary stuff, they were frightening.nnThe film certainly has pace, and is recommended.

... and that takes a bit!nnThe agony of the plodding "development" is only exacerbated by the gratuitous sex scene ( she was very well-equipped and talented in that regard! )nKurt Russel isn't given much to save the debacle by the script, and the occasional comic relief only serves to highlight the endless nauseating bone crunching, squelching and gore-splattering sound effects.nnOddly enough a strong and evocative soundtrack but ... still no cigar, alas! Could someone please cannibalize this writer for the sake of all sentient beings?nnEasily the worst film I've ever seen- save your time, watch fresh paint drying somewhere!

Robert Lowery and Guinn 'Big Boy' Williams land on a tropical island. They are spies, with orders to find out if anything warlike is going on. They find that Ivan Lebedeff is in charge, with Warren Hymer as his assistant. They're Germans, so apparently no one has heard of the Treaty of Versailles. They also find Margie Hart and Gale Storm, two half-caste girls who want to get off the island and into. Park Avenue penthouses.nnJean Yarbrough directs this for yucks, but there aren't any to be had. Miss Hart dances the hula like a burly-cue queen and talks like one feeding lines to the comic. That's not surprising, because that's precisely she was. Producer Lindsley Parsons, acclaimed as Monogram's class producer, had read police accounts of her being pulled off stage and into paddy wagons and I guess he thought there was some publicity to be had.
