After this, her sole movie, she went to acting school and did a few stage shows. Her third marriage was to Los Angeles City Council President John Ferraro. She died in 2000 at the age of 85.

Nicole Kidman is a bit dazzled in this role of a housewife/wife/repressed/high-class woman. I liked her in Big Little Lies, but in Babygirl, I found it repetitive. I didn't see much difference between her two characters. The orgasm scenes are well done; they feel real and are far from the stereotype of pornography. There were several elements of the story that added nothing to the development: the fact that she was raised in a cult or the presence of her daughters. One can have sexual desires regardless of being raised in a cult, and a psychologist could confirm my view. The daughters were there to show her as a top mother, but that aspect is never fully developed, and she doesn't come across as a super dedicated mother or a highly driven businesswoman. Her character isn't fully fleshed out. The young man has only one expression throughout the film, which gets a bit boring. I liked the twist of the employee pushing her to be a role model; it would have been a more exciting twist than the ending.

My husband and I really enjoy Landman. It's incredibly written and the side stories make it interesting so you're not bored with the same ole thing over and over. However...the wife and daughter are an unnecessary part of this series. If they were written out of the show, I wouldn't miss them at all. For one, they're a couple of spoiled brats that use their sexuality to get whatever they want. The things the daughter says to her father and the way she parades around in her panties are inappropriate, in my opinion. The mother is not the definition of a mother at all. She's vulgar and trashy. They need to go. I know I'm not the only person that feels this way.

First off let me just say that this film is fanominal. And I think they should have made a sequel. Between this and the walking dead, I honestly couldnrewatch this so much more than thew walking dead, which is also really good. The plot is close to perfect. The characters are awesome. But what blew me away the most was the zombie virus itself. Sadly I don't want to include any spoilers for those of you who haven't seen it, due to the fact that it would not be as good of a film most likely. And for those who haven't seen this and wanna know about content... thus movie is surprisingly not very bloody at all which is probably one of the main reasons that it's only PG-13. Sexual content is at an all time 0. There us probably around moderate violence not really any language. Sooo yeah. I recommend you watch this... NOW.

I love how this shows a girl hating, "one of the guys" woman...having to infiltrate and be part of the most stereotypical "girly" things ever: A Pageant. However, it shows her bonding and embracing femininity. Instead of scrunching her nose up at it. And I love that she makes friends with the other stereotypical "girly, girls". If anyone knows anything about "girly, girls" they usually come with a lot of degrees, talent, and beauty. Irl Barbies or Charlie's Angels. I watched the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders documentary and there wasn't one cheerleader who didn't have a degree or impressive day job attached to her name. They were nurses, dentists, teachers, and STILL could put on a face of makeup, big beautiful bouncy curls, and do a entire dance routine in a sexy outfit! So, I love that this film shows a "not like other girls" learning to love and respect the "other girls".

One thing which draws me to contemporary PRC cinema is that on average, their films (at least the ones good enough to get overseas screenings) tend to be more grounded, more cynical and more interested in the workings of a society than the comparable Western film of a corresponding genre.nnHere, this comparison is not so clear-cut - because the premise strongly (if unintentionally - the movies were released within 3 months of each other) echoes Josh Margolin's Thelma, which was also both a comedy about a scam and a film with a lot of amusing yet meaningful comments on its society. Relative to Thelma, it is actually Honey Money Phony which is more beholden to classic crime comedy tropes over social realism.nnQuite often, it takes shortcuts in an attempt to score easy laugh lines - i.e. The classic metaphor of scammers as wolves and their prey as the sheep is reinforced with the SFX of howling and bleating played whenever the predator and the "unwitting" mark try their best. The humour in a scene with a gap-toothed character who sprays so much saliva a small dog in the room ends up drenched by the time he is done talking is rather beneath what I have come to expect from a PRC film.nnAt the same time, this is STILL a modern PRC film, so the social realist DNA is not absent, and the story can still be quite acidic when it counts. For instance, Lin has a properly realized backstory explaining how she had come to be in such a situation - including an ignored report of sexual harassment causing her to move to "Koo Aang" (renamed Macao) in the first place. The male scammer's backstory is surprisingly downbeat for the genre - not "dark" in the edgy sense, but simply a disappointingly plausible tale of parental neglect.nnThe film can also be vaguely compared to Now You See Me, in the sense that both involve scamming a single unsympathetic guy out of a lot of money, albeit by very different methods. The parallel becomes intentional when it also involves a scene with love locks on a bridge - but while the idea was played completely straight in Now You See Me, here Lin and her friend ask the male lead Ooyang and his uncle for help in lockpicking AWAY the love locks they left during the past relationships turned sour. It comes across as a very intentional counterpoint - and the cynicism is highlighted further when a photo vendor snaps the two leads and offers a locket with their photo. In response to their denials, he simply assumes they are adulterous and proposes a shielded locket with the photo hidden beneath a sliding cover.nnI haven't spoken much about the core of the story, which is a classic crime comedy, but it's basically fine. Certainly more than a little predictable and overlong at times, but it still got more than enough laughs out of me. It helps that it invests attention to detail like the actual workings of bank transactions which lesser works often miss. The characters are all fun enough to follow and the epilogue thankfully does not forget about any one of them.nnAll in all, looking at it rationally this is probably the weakest and least substantial year 2024 PRC film I saw - but it still made me laugh a lot, and remains one of the better films I saw from that year.

The series starts strong, supported by solid acting and remarkable chemistry between the leads. However, the plot weakens with several implausible elements. Sa-Eon and Hee-Joo's cold, unconsummated marriage lacks a clear explanation, making it unconvincing. The tension builds as Hee-Joo is kidnapped, escapes with the kidnapper's phone, and communicates with Sa-Eon. But the story turns absurd when she's kidnapped again and Sa-Eon abandons his wealth for unclear reasons. Unanswered questions, such as the kidnapper's survival, detract from the narrative. It had potential but ultimately disappoints in execution.

Before looking at the rating I was already sure that this movie might have gotten review-bombed. It is an honest but still delicate portrayal of someone whose life depends on people not seeing her for what she really is. And her just as difficult partner as well. So wouldn't be all too surprising if 100-bucks-for-a-used-panty fans would go and "rectify" the movie's message.nnThe movie portrays Emma and Eddie, two porn creators with care, an outside-in perspective, and without an in-your-face judgement, not unlike Scorsese's approach in the Wolf of Wall Street. And just like there, one can formulate their own opinion about the protagonists' actions. While in the middle a bit slower, generally a nice watch with great shots and solid directing. If something is 4.6 here, it is the reality it portrays.

I went into this movie with blank expectations - I thought to myself: this could be my new Roman Empire or totally mediocre. If I'm being honest with myself then this isn't new or original but it was disgusting and spooky and gloomy and especially Lily Rose Depp was amazing in her performance. I loved the use of makeup and old school gore in this, Eggers was able to capture the eerie atmosphere of the 1922 Nosferatu and bring it to life with modern equipment. Probably my favourite part is Nosferatu himself, the care that went into the costume design and SFX Makeup is incredible. Everything about the costuming of this movie is absolutely delightful, the fit and silhouette of the dresses and suits shows how much thought was put into the setting. Even if the storyline lacks some depth and isn't very original in the genre of vampire horror, Eggers Nosferatu is still a must see for me, because it is just so beautiful to look at.nnPerfect movie for vampire enthusiasts who are fed up with sexy and beautiful creatures of the night and need a dose of living corpse for a change. Also perfect for fellow (period) costume design connoisseurs that still can't get over the catastrophe that was Little Women. Is it the feminist masterpiece many of us hoped for? No, but it doesn't need to be. It's just a nicely arranged piece of classical horror.

I found this series amazing for the first eight episodes, the actors are wonderful, great script and up to the last episode good directing and cutting. The last episode let the whole series down there were so many side issues left unexplained, like what happened to Brittany for example after being summarily dismissed in the car park by Billy by an action completely out of character. We are supposed to understand that the reason she turned was help with some charges against her when she has such a powerful lawyer - Billy in her camp??nnI get the statement the series is making - even up against Goliaths the little guy wins - but after Cooperman's gang et all went to the lengths of every imaginable witness tampering escapade possible it ended by the appeal to the better nature of the jury, come on really????nnVery disappointed. The last episode I no idea why it got the rating in IMDB that it did.

Truly an amazing show - accurately depicts the daily work of police officers on the street in Long Beach. So interesting, your attention is grabbed from the very first minute of each episode. The acting is completely believable, you become invested in each of the characters. The supporting cast is also fantastic. Just the right amount of personal life of characters sprinkled in and shows how cops have to constantly pivot from their own issues to dealing with t the public on crazy calls. Infinitely better than The Rookie on ABC. Dick Wolf (and company) is a genius. I cannot recommend this show enough.

Everything is wrong with this film.nnPoor story, poor acting, all flaws of the society today are elevated as something possible or even desirable.nnMother encouraging daughter to smoke, girl loves girl, fake family, fake and easy narrative and thin plot, bad childhood example (the little girl was raised in a guru-led communal environment), old and sometimes unpleasant looking actress, fake acting in sex scenes, emancipating women not on merit, but just for the desire to promote. Basically every cliche. Pedophilia and bestiality are missing, but all the rest is pretty much there.nnSome reviewers tried to find some positives, like some depth of the characters, some truth frankly revealed about today's society. Hard try!

Anora feels like someone threw Pretty Woman and Euphoria in a blender, hoping the mix would turn out "cool and edgy," but it just doesn't work.nnI bet director really thought: let's take some classic and let's add smth what kids like nowadays like Euphoria and made this...)))nThe movie tries way too hard, borrowing bits from classics and recent hits, while tossing in nudity for shock value. It ends up feeling like a messy collage or parody using tired cliches rather than anything original or meaningful.nnIt touches on cultural and class differences and sex work but only skims the surface, so nothing really lands. Honestly, it's overrated, chaotic, and forgettable-a one-time watch at best. Feels like the kind of movie that wants to be deep but doesn't have much to say.

I've never felt inclined to bother writing a review before but after watching Beautiful Friend & then seeing the very harsh IMDB rating I felt obliged to do so.nnThis film is really simple & very interesting. It's filmed from the point of view of Daniel who is living through the COVID Pandemic & already feels isolated & marginalised by society, he wants to find love but has no understanding of what women want, how they should be approached & sees them as only from his own perspective without ever considering that he's only seeing a very shallow & surface level view of the women he, for want of a better word, meets.nnHe's what's often referred to as an incel & his rapid oscillation from viewing the objects of his attraction as near perfect, to creatures beneath contempt certainly puts you in mind of some of the darker corners of online discourse around women. Despite this, the film does an excellent job of making the protagonist (?), if not relatable exactly, at least understandable, he articulates his thoughts & feelings throughout in a way that probably contravenes some laws of filmmaking but it works well.nnThe two main actors are fantastic, watching Madison interact with Daniel, seeing her making decisions following a timely introspective is truly heart wrenching.nnThe camerawork & cinematography are unusual but they work brilliantly.nnA really interesting film that takes a difficult & possibly unpopular approach.

This movie had a great first act when Nicholas Hoult's (Thomas Hutter) character was sent away to sell a manor to Count Orlok. The journey to Transylvania was incredibly captivating and really gave a sense of scale with the incredible cinematography and set designs adding a layer to the world. Once Thomas had reached the castle you instantly were hit with a feeling of dread which made it incredible. The shadows hid Count Orlock perfectly making it so you couldn't tell what you were looking at making it seem as if you were encaptured by trying to see what he looked like. The castle really was the best part of the movie and was really the only part that I could remember. The rest of the movie was pretty bad once you finally saw Count Orlok the entire Mystique was gone and you couldn't help but laugh at his ugly moustache and balding head with one small piece of hair sticking out, one thought I had during this was and I quote "is this wish.com Omni-man." The entire backstory of Ellen wasn't built out it was just oh I was lonely so I saught comfort in him. They showed a few clips about how they had a relationship but that was it. During the end it didn't feel like a sacrifice it felt like she wanted it which kind of threw me off because I thought it would be that basically baited him with her blood until morning but nope it was sex and drinking blood which felt a little bit uncalled for because it wasn't needed at all. I would also like to point out that this story basically just a vampire cucks a random guy that loves his wife and then she fricking dies like overall this movie was a bruh some cool scares great cinematography but done in by the dumb story.

I watched this because everyone seemed to be talking about it. It moves too slow, and even the graphic sex scenes are over done. And I enjoy a good sex scene. I got impatient and skipped ahead several times and didn't feel like I missed a thing. In the end we're supposed to believe that she kept that secret for 20 years, and didn't tell her husband the truth until the end of the show (which, of course, is a plot contrivance required to draw things out) instead of when she was first confronted with the pictures. Her husband asks her that question in the final scene as if the script writers were expecting that criticism and wanted to thwart it, but her explanation was laughably lame.

If you go to see this film. You choose to do so, it's not called the Royal Shakespeare company presents... Or by the studio that brought you Lord of the Rings. It's a film called cocaine Bear. What the hell do you expect. A bear off it's bap on coke, running around looking for more drugs . The fact that a lot of this actually happened is not crazy enough for some people. I dunno what you are into, but if you think of a wild animal high on grade A Bolivian marching powder isn't silly enough for you then I suggest you start making your own films. It's a bonkers story and filmed in quite a few locations giving people jobs. I've zero complaints.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is an animated film that brings something new to the world of superhero movies. By blending various animation styles, it creates a unique and stunning visual experience. Every frame feels like a living comic book, with vibrant and dynamic colors.nnThe film introduces Miles Morales, a teenager who must take on the mantle of Spider-Man after Peter Parker from his world dies. The story not only follows Miles' journey to becoming a hero but also brings together different versions of Spider-Man from other dimensions, creating a fresh and entertaining narrative.nnThe characters are well-developed, adding emotional depth rarely seen in animated superhero films. The themes of courage, responsibility, and identity are highly inspiring. With perfect humor and breathtaking action, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse successfully entertains while touching the heart. This review contains mild spoilers as it mentions the death of Peter Parker from Miles Morales' world.

Ha, maybe it's an age thing, but I did quite enjoy this send up of all things superficial and technological. It's an old gent who is sitting in a park (or is he?) harking back to the civilised days of the 2010s when folks were proud of their iPhone 7; would like their friends Facebook photos out of courtesy and reply to text messages to arrange meeting up. Hell, they'd even hook-up on Tinder to meet for sex (or long term, meaningful, relationships, obviously!). Meantime, his zoned-out grandson looks like he's had his phone surgically implanted onto his completely non-responsive head! Is this portentous, do you think? The animation is quite good fun and the message is quite an entertaining indictment of "progress".

The fact is that the attractive part of the story does no need a queer set-up.nnThink about it, if you replace it with a straight couple, it wouldn't change a things. An older drug addict in love with a young beautiful girl. Controlling, processive. Also I watched the movie trailer in the cinema previously, but the trailer itself suggests nothing more than a gay romance story. Please stop marketing it using gay stereotypes to call people's attention.nnLastly, the characters are totally isolated from the background setting. Does it need to be in Mexico? Why? The only Mexican thing we got is tequila shots and a few Spanish sentences? I don't know the actors, but the character Joe's acting is rather natural and enjoyable. Daniel tried to hard with that American accent.

I wanted to like this, but there was not an original idea to be found. The Rookie is just one example of this, but there are many Wolf spinoffs that do it way, way better. The opening sequence was tired and very predictable- nothing was made of the people watching rather than helping, and the set-up of antagonistic energy between the main character and the sergeant was extremely uninteresting. OK I might be biased towards Eriq Lasalle, whomI think is a douche, but my point stands.nnThe acting is alright, but also nothing special. Of course you should watch it yourself to determine its value, but if you're not sure I would say try something else instead.

Going back into the archives, I just re-watched this episode from some time back. Among other things, it highlights the real-life problem of mentally ill Paranoid Schizophrenics (they prefer to call themselves "Targeted Individuals") who murder or attempt to murder innocent people because they have psychotic delusions that the person or persons they murder or try to murder are "gangstalking" them.nnA relatively recent 2023 example is Robert Card, a Paranoid Schizophrenic, who killed 11 people in Lewiston, Maine because he had delusions the entire population of the town had him under 24/7 surveillance, were controlling his mind and broadcasting voices into his head claiming he was a pedophile.

Dariuss is an experimental arthouse film from filmmaker Guerrilla Metropolitana. A written review cannot do justice to this film. There is no spoken dialogue, just music and noises which adds to the creepiness. The film just hits you with a barrage of unseemingly images that eventually all come together. It also does not follow a typical narrative structure. You get little bits of information to figure out what is going on.nnThe film is open to interpretation as well. It does touch on things like abuse, murder, assault, and traumatic loss.nnLike I said in my YouTube review - think Skinamarink meets Flowers but closer to Flowers. The film is paced very well and is beautifully shot.nnDariuss will not be for everyone, but if you're willing to go to a dark, depraved place give it a go.

A truly, extremely stylish film - where I hated virtually everybody by its conclusion.nnSupposedly a story of queer empowerment - so long as you emphasize with the cool, moody leads and not with the one used and discarded like a trash bag.nnA town under the thumb of a fun-to-watch villain with Bond-tier mannerisms - who somehow intimidates the police in spite of having virtually no visible operation to speak of and seemingly possessing so few underlings he lets a piece of human garbage walk all over his daughter for no clear reason.nnAnd a completely nonsensical ending which requires a viewer to turn off all sense of logic to believe it could have worked the way intended for longer than a week.nnI could keep going but.... I think you get the point.

There is so much depth, sensitivity, trauma, and an eerie beauty of unbridled nature. In a world of familiarity, we try to find what we know and expect, but on an alien planet, how do you interact with unknowns?nnI think that the creators of this series peers into that so beautifully. The visuals were amazing, and I loved the human nature part of it all.nnI can also feel a bit of Moby Dick in this. Is it right to take revenge against an animal? Why do we ascribe human characteristics to things that aren't?nnAnyway, I just want season 2 to be released. Max, what the hell are you guys doing? You cancel some of the best shows at the worst time. Stop it. Please listen to your audience. Promote things better. Work with the creators and try to find a middle ground with your subscribers.

With all the star-studded comedic lineup of Jerry Seinfeld, Melissa McCarthy, Amy Schumer, Hugh Grant, and cameos from Bill Burr & Christian Slater, they still couldn't muster a decent belly laugh.nnSeinfeld uses 1960s American popular culture to romance the viewer but deceives us all with brain-dead immature offbeat crummy humour.nnComically speaking, it's lowbrow and lame.nnI was fearing Kramer was going to burst out of some Rice Bubbles, it was that light on for punchy laughs.nnSeinfeld was channelling his inner Robert Zemeckis the way he overused the Forest Gump storytelling, and his obsession with JFK, Russia-Cuba and the moon landing.nnI would have preferred something along the lines of Seth Rogan's Sausage Party's hilarious foodie humour because milk & sugary cereal treats don't cut the mustard I'm afraid here.nnWilly Wonka it is not!

Cabrini is a sobering representation of how wretched the times some may now call "great" were for a great swathe of people - including the immediate ancestors of those now settled comfortably. We get to be deeply immersed in those times through the eyes of the titular character, doing unglamorous yet all-too-necessary work, at a time and place many would now rather sweep under the rug.nnIn particular, a scene where the titular Italian nun, living on borrowed time due to lung disease from childhood, is able to secure aid from the wealthy Polish and Jewish elites of New York over their shared experience of racism might be blunt, but it works - and all the more so considering Alejandro Monteverde must have known how alienating it was going to be for the implicit core audience of an American Christian-themed film nowadays.nnAfter all, the only reason Monteverde was able to operate with a $50M budget for such a film was due to the runaway success of Sound of Freedom amongst that kind of audience. You can see where that money went, as the film employs A LOT of people for the very frequent crowd scenes - be they in Vatican, at the New York docks, throngs of children in the slums or at her care home, at the park fundraiser or during hospital construction. The investment into the film was far in excess of what it earned at the B. O., likely making it one of the greatest bombs of the year percentage-wise - but I would be hard-pressed to say it was "wasted".nnAltogether, this is the story where just the facts of her life - and of the context which surrounded her - are very strong. Thus, it is disappointing that the script also chooses to resort to a range of fabrications which generally weaken the overall narrative thrust. In particular, the political arc with the fictional mayor may be "metaphorically true", but its resolution is surprisingly timid, and arguably even unintentionally undermines one of the core principles of democracy while seemingly trying to do the opposite. The scene where she rallies support in front of the Italian Parliament also rings a little hollow when seemingly nobody asks a cynical yet entirely plausible question as to why those who chose to leave the country deserve its support more than those already in it.nnPerhaps the film would have been able to explore these facets better if it omitted something like the subplot with the local lady of the night. That aspect of the story appears to be completely fictional and while it's decently filmed, it does not add a whole lot besides giving Cabrini an opportunity to recount her past in front of the viewers to someone who doesn't already know it.nnIn all, I wish the story was better able to stick to the facts and explore their nuances, like several other biopics of 2024, but altogether, it is still a work worth seeing, and a definite recommendation of mine.

Making a standout film about the process of writing a book is definitely a challenge - and Ava DuVernay is already one of the few to have ever taken it up, even if I cannot say she had fully succeeded at it.nnIf you are watching something like this in the first place, you would undoubtedly make allowances for pacing - yet even so, the first half is particularly glacial. After the opening which effectively recreates a notorious page in recent American history, the events just kinda happen, and it's not very clear what they are leading up to.nnYou can make the case that this is exactly how the process of writer's block should be portrayed, but it still doesn't make for captivating viewing. Even the death of Isabel's husband is just kinda....there. He is found dead on the floor, presumably from heart attack, but we just get so little context about it. I.e. There's nothing about how (un)likely it was statistically and if it could have been averted, which is one of the first questions those grieving tend to ask.nnOn the other hand, once the film starts to cohere in the second half, it does so very rapidly. Subplots that threatened to go nowhere at first get a satisfying resolution and the dive into history of the three countries offers some of the year's more interesting scenes. Thus, it is a film still worth seeing, even if I suspect it could have been better than it was.

I guess I missed the acting, was focused on the dozens of butt shots. Watched again, still missed the best actress according to the Golden Globes. Did they say Demi Moore?. My short lived subscription to shudder ended abruptly because I watched all the films worth watching in several months. This was not horror, just silly Then realized Demi was punked by Golden Globes and thought this truly is revolutionary. She was not the only onenpunked. I also take ownership begrudgingly. Destined to become a cult classic. May take a little longer than the usual B picture to reach that stature. But the ending will certainly be t elevate it to he crowning touch to elevate to that stature.

This is the first time I have reviewed a film but I felt some of the comments and ratings on this film were unfair.nnYes nothing will surpass the original animated Lion King film, I went to the cinema to see the original and left feeling I had just seen a film that will stay with me forever.nnThe remake was terrible and lacked the passion and emotion the animated version projected. For this reason I will never watch the remake again, it purely felt like a pay day for the actors.nnI was a bit sceptical with Mufasa judging by some of the rubbish Disney have produced lately with odd exceptions of course. I read some of the reviews and wasn't expecting much but I must say if anything could replicate the feeling I had after first seeing the Lion King (1994) then this film is it. Yes I am older and see films from different aspects now but it felt more like the original and I think Aaron Pierre was brilliant as Mufasa. Tough shoes to fill from James Earl Jones but I did feel the remake lacked the same desire in his voice so fresh blood was needed and Aaron Pierre was exceptional. Tiffany Boone as Sarabi was great and Mads Mikkelsen is always excellent. Jeremy Irons will always be Scar for me though with his voice along with Rowen Atkinson as Zazu, I can't see their performances being surpassed.nnI saw an improvement in Pumba and Timon this time. I enjoyed how Rafiki had a strong role and brought humour but also strong messages across.nnSoundtrack wise, not all the songs are great but the ones that are I am still listening to now. Again, the standard of the original is so high it's hard to compete but some of the music from Mufasa is beautiful. Great performances is all I can say.nnMufasa is such a great inspiring character and I love how this film portrayed him. If the film did not do the character justice I would not be reviewing this film but I felt it was such a good movie and the comparisons to the likes of Sonic 3 are unfair in my opinion. They are different films with different messages.nnAll I can say is this film is the closest to the original Lion King and it has certainly had a lasting effect on me and I can't wait to watch it again. I certainly did not get the usual Disney woke experience on this film which was a welcome refreshing change.nnHope you enjoy it as much as I did.

I really do not understand the low rating. But I agree with other reviewers who state that it is being review bombed for some reason. If you look at the reviews where people actually took the time to write comments vs just clicking a star, you'll see the positive reviews far out weigh the negative.nnThis was my first romantic Kdrama (I consider it my first Kdrama but since I did watch Squid Games first, I guess it actually holds that spot even though I didn't know what a Kdrama was when I watched it). But this series got me hooked on Kdrama's. I do not feel like there is anything being created in the US that compares. I love the slow paced romance based on small gestures of kindness vs just sex as is so common with US dramas. And I really like how they do not drag out the relationship setback misunderstandings...those usually get resolved within the beginning of the next episode if not the same episode.nnBut within King The Land, I really liked the strength in Sa-rang's character. How she quickly dealt with adversity herself rather than waiting for Gu Won or someone else to save her. I thought Im Yoon-ah did a great job with the character as did the other actors in the core group. I also liked the balance given between the main romantic thread between Sa-rang and Gu Won and that of the secondary romantic threads for Sa-rang's friends, Oh Pyeong-hwa and Kang Da-eul. I thought they gave enough time to the secondary threads to properly evolve them without taking away from the primary story.nnWhile this was my 'first', it will be far from my last Kdrama. I'm currently hooked and will be exploring all that the various streaming services have to offer in this category.

It's said the attention span of modern generations is less than a goldfish. Heaven forbid a movie be just under 4 hours. A 21st century, 1st world luxury that would not have been imagined in the time of Alexander no doubt. Centuries from now this film will almost certainly be rated at a 9/10 or 10/10. A masterpiece for anyone with an attention span greater than a goldfish, and who can view great historical figures as actual humans (which they were) and not mythical fiction.nnFor those who have a giant ego due to their ancestry or whom write their own history based upon whatever contemporary mythical notions of historical figures entertain their psyche; no doubt this movie, nor any movie for that matter, will fail to live up to their illusions. Yet I say that says more about such people and their honestly delusional and narcissistic nature than it does about homo sapiens, humans, and the great history surrounding us.nnAll in all, this movie is a masterpiece should you give it the attention and honesty it deserves, in the context that we are humans, not some mythical beings descendant of Prometheus, angels, or whatnot. Alexander as a human, not Hercules born of a god. The fact this movie is rated 5 stars on imdb makes me lose faith in humanity. There are true narcissists out there in an unsettling number that conflate humanity with godhood. Alexander was indeed great, of that there is no question, yet he was human. And this movie is the most epic portrayal of that human I have seen. If a movie was ever a 10/10, this is it.

Correctly made, but characterless and full of colonial stereotypesnnGodless (2017) is a Western series that, at first glance, seems to offer an intriguing twist on classic genre tropes: a town run by women after a mining disaster wipes out the men, and an antagonist in the form of an unrelenting bandit challenging the "civilized" order of the West. However, upon closer examination, the series reveals deep problematic undertones that, from an anti-colonial perspective, make it deeply racist.nnAt its core, Godless presents a narrative about the "Wild West" in which white settlers are portrayed as the "civilized" ones, fighting against the forces of nature and the "wild" people. While the series claims to address female empowerment and the dismantling of patriarchal structures, it falls back into the racist clich√©s of the genre. The broader colonial context-the violence against indigenous peoples, forced relocations, and the systematic erasure of cultures-is almost entirely ignored.nnUltimately, Godless reveals itself as a series that uncritically perpetuates racist narratives. It presents the colonial victims as mere backdrops to the stories of white characters, implying that western expansion and the associated violence against non-white populations were nothing more than an inevitable byproduct of a heroic Western myth. Colonization is not only glossed over but its victims are systematically excluded from the narrative. In an era when engagement with colonial history and its lasting impacts is urgently needed, Godless fails to provide a critical examination and instead becomes another example of problematic handling of the history of the American West in popular culture.nnLast but least: While the series makes a promising start it increasingly feels like the script was written with chatgpt. It is well produced, but the story is often illogical and the characters are artificially filled with content.nnRadical movie critiques (RMC)

Western never dies. This genre is still alive, and from time to time we can see short stories on VOD or hit or miss in cinema, here and there miniseries. I am glad this kind of movies are explored, but mostly we get something average. Peter Berg did a great miniseries involwing few characters, that try to survive in New Earth and in USA start new life. Those who know anything about that peroid of time, knows also that it was very harsh times, full of struggle and obstacles from nature and man. And American Primeval depicts this perfectly. With two flaws.nnFirst thig is that action, greatly directed and intense is packed in almost every inch of tape. I feel like writers compressed hundred years in one month. There is little to none space to take breath and enjoy this New World, as it turns out - in this production - freaking hell. Well, it's not THAT bad thing, because everything is executed terryffic, but its so intense, that I had to do a day break before ongoing into this cruel, mad world.nnSecond thing that annoyed me is colours in this production. I mean, take a look at poster on IMDB then on a trailer. I know the storry is muddy, but c'mon.. I rate this production 9/10 and I really liked Tylor Kitch in this role. As far I know, this is his best performance to date.

They did not even mention the motorcycle crash or the fans booing him in the beginning of his switch to Rock or his Reborn Christian phase or even the depth of his anti-war crusade or the tragic incident with his brother. There wasn't much character, really, other than being called an asshole, not responding and yet having loyal, devoted followers by the throngs, men, women, boys, girls of every sort. But it was basically pretty good. They got the gist of who Bob has been and a few of the events. It's just that it has been so much more than that which wasn't so simple and he rode through all of it unfettered.

When I first saw the Oscar buzz for Kenneth Branagh's semi-autobiographical passion project my eyes rolled so hard they nearly detached from my brain. This is not the type of movie I typically enjoy very much. Everything from the trailer to the early reviews screamed that this would be toothache inducing, saccharine, schmaltz of the highest order. And there were moments of the film that it tiptoed dangerously close to that territory, but it thankfully never took the full plunge.nnI loved this movie, to my surprise. Every beat and joke and smirk and tear along the way was backed by immense joy and my reluctant respect. There is something to be said that maybe this was just the type of movie I needed right now. After two years of a long war against a seemingly endless virus, paired with a crop of films last year that, while great, were all unrelenting bummers, it just felt nice to feel nice. Branagh's film wraps us in a warm blanket and says "forget about all that, aren't grandparents wonderful?" "Never mind all that pain and sadness, Ryan, look at what the power of song can do for heartache." A movie about people being displaced due to the violent religious upheaval of 1960's Ireland should not count as escapist cinema, and yet here we are. And even more than that, it was therapeutic. It could be likened to that moment of serenity when someone turns off the vacuum cleaner. Your brain has adjusted to unpleasant sound and you no longer even realize it until it stops and that wave of pleasant tranquility comes rushing back. That is what seeing Belfast in the midst of all of this real world plight felt like to me.nnThe ensemble cast is all excellent, with Ciaran Hinds standing out as particularly natural, and the young Jude Hill as an absolute revelation. Critics of the film may say that it glosses over the real danger and complexity of the situation the characters were in, and it absolutely does. But it gets away with it because the story is told, and the movie cleverly shot, from the knee-high perspective of our adolescent lead. This movie isn't a deep analysis of "The Troubles" of Northern Ireland. That simply provides the backdrop and impetus of events of a film about family.nnBelfast a bracingly present and heartfelt excursion into the world and mind of these characters, as remembered by a filmmaker decades later. It's allowed to be glossy, as that is the power of memory. To carve out of the blustering clamor of life, a greater truth, spoken as a whisper.

"The Hack Job," an independent series spanning eight succinct episodes, merits detailed analysis for its adept balancing of comedic elements with action sequences and the depth of its narrative, which frequently defies the conventional tropes typically associated with this genre. This is not a series that relies on tired tropes, rather the show crafts a unique narrative that is as compelling as it is surprising. Upon close examination, the show reveals a nuanced understanding of character dynamics and technical proficiency in its visual and aural design.nnCharacter Studies Through Contrasting PersonalitiesnnThe series' core strength lies in the development of its characters, which are not merely vehicles for plot advancement but are instead thoughtfully constructed individuals with distinct quirks, fears, and motivations. Ken Hodges's portrayal of Bob is a masterclass in comedic performance. He navigates the show's chaotic world with a disarming mix of bravado and confusion, allowing his character to be both hilarious and somehow deeply relatable. Bob's reliance on "code names" and his hilarious attempts to justify his love of cheese despite his lactose intolerance serve as prime examples of the show's ability to generate humor from the absurdities of daily life.nnIn sharp contrast, Jessica Serfaty's Emily embodies a pragmatic and grounded character. Her controlled demeanor provides an essential anchor amidst the comedic chaos surrounding her, while still leaving room for a sense of relatability. Furthermore, Rachel Cook's portrayal of Megan brings an element of layered ambiguity to her character. Her calculated performance hints at a hidden past, and the contrast between her composed exterior and subtle flashes of vulnerability generates considerable intrigue. I believe this actor has serious potential as she matures. It is quite interesting that while three of the four main actors listed on the "The Hack Job" IMDb page, Jessica Serfaty, Ken Hodges, and Rachel Cook, play major roles in every episode, the fourth, Kyle Lewis, plays a more prominent part in certain episodes, which allows each actor to really shine within the context of their character, without having to be present all the time.nnOther supporting characters, such as Tim Willis's "Mr. Smith" and Dak Navarro's Remon, add depth to the series and provide more unexpected comedic moments. The show benefits from a variety of actors that are all perfect in their roles and who play off each other as if they've been working together for years. They are also actors that haven't had that "big" break that so many others have, and that dedication and love for the work truly elevates what they're doing. Furthermore, the frequent references to each character's personal ticks, mannerisms and preferences give each one a feeling of being a whole person.nnA Narrative Structure Embracing Subversion and Creative Freedomnn"The Hack Job" effectively utilizes its unconventional 8-episode format to drive its plot forward with speed and innovation. The series eschews traditional narrative pacing, instead opting for an accelerated storytelling style, as is exemplified in episode 3's "Walking the Dog", where a supposedly simple first date evolves into a complex flashback of a mission. This type of dynamic storytelling is a core element of "The Hack Job" as it uses narrative tension to build moments of intense and unexpected comedic delight. For example, the "prayer" scene in Episode 5, encapsulates the show's ability to blend heartfelt expressions with moments of absurdist humor. Also, the character, Bob, has a moment of "Eureka" that is a clear demonstration of the show's ability to elicit laughs from the improbable. The consistent tension throughout each episode and the use of flashbacks to inform character history adds to the richness of the overall narrative.nnThe independent nature of "The Hack Job" is more than a production detail; it's the essence of its charm. Freed from the constraints of mainstream studio expectations, the series presents itself with a unique visual identity, a pacing and structure that challenges and rewards the audience, and a narrative style that is fresh and vibrant. Instead of trying to hide from the limitations of a small budget, the creators embrace and incorporate this, using it as a strength to add to the show's unique and memorable quality.nnTechnical Merit and the Blurring of GenrennFrom a technical perspective, the series shows great creative innovation. Cinematography, credited to JC Tremblay, demonstrates an impressive range of visual techniques that create moods and visual styles that help propel the series through each episode. There's an interesting contrast between scenes in brightly lit kitchens and dimly lit warehouses, to moments of wide landscape and close ups, which speaks to a real command of the language of film. In addition, the series uses sound, including the musical contributions of Drew Smith, to carefully enhance the tone of each scene, and it seamlessly intertwines with the narrative, creating an aural tapestry as dynamic as the visuals. The editing of each episode is paced effectively to push through to each emotional beat, be it comedic or something more genuine.nnAddressing Potential Criticisms from a Critical Perspective:nnWhile some might be quick to criticize certain aspects of this series, these critiques often fail to account for the show's narrative intent, and instead fall short of accurately portraying the series' true intentions.nnThe Claim of Inconsistent Production Values: Some will label this as a "low-budget production," and say that they can see the strings, but to do that is to completely miss what makes this show work. It's low budget, yes, but what makes the show enjoyable is that it's the heart, the inventiveness and imagination that come from the limitations, that truly makes this series something special.nnThe Argument of "Bad Acting": In actuality, the series is filled with unique performances that use comedic elements and timing in such a creative manner, and it's their individuality that makes the show shine. This isn't "bad" acting; it's intentional, and the performances highlight the quirks that make these characters feel so real and likeable. The actors are all clearly talented, especially the core characters of Bob, Emily, and Megan, and they shine even within the short episode structure.nnComedy and Tension: Episode 3 highlights a scene where a character is told to put his hands in the air and is completely out of step with the typical tone of a tense action scene, but it's the juxtaposition of the danger and absurd humour that elevates the show to another level, forcing the audience to consider the relationship between tension and comedy.nnFinal Analysisnn"The Hack Job" transcends the limitations of its independent production and presents something that is truly innovative and compelling. By taking chances with its quick-paced plot, and its characters that are a mishmash of bizarre quirks, along with the inventive cinematography, editing and sound design, the show sets a new standard of what independent series can accomplish. And because it is an original and inventive narrative, I have little doubt that it will soon have its own cult following.

Overall, I really enjoyed this series and was a little surprised to see some of the negative reviews about it. To be fair, I am an English-speaking person and only started getting into K-dramas last year, so I watched this entire series with closed captions. I liked the relationship between the main characters-yes, some parts were a little "cheesy," but overall, I thought their relationship was cute. I even found myself laughing at the villain, thinking, "When is this guy going to die? He has more than nine lives!"nThe one part of the series I didn't like was the ending. The last episode felt almost like a completely different plot, and I'm not sure why the writers went in that direction. Honestly, the series could have ended at the 11th episode.nnThat said, I still found the series pretty entertaining overall. I encourage you to form your own opinion rather than being influenced by the negative comments.

Perhaps I'm too old, or not queer enough, for all the supposed humor in Bottoms to land. But with all the hype surrounding the film, I admittedly expected more.nnTo me, Bottoms is little more than an unhinged high school lesbian fever dream. Watching it, I couldn't help but feel like the creators were working out old grievances against the jocks who made their lives miserable at 16. Admittedly, I got a good laugh out of the wildly over-the-top portrayal of the good-for-nothing Ken Doll-esque football players, who never seemed to take off their uniforms. I laughed not because I thought the depiction was incisive or accurate, but because I could easily see how an aggrieved high school lesbian would have such a distorted view of the popular athletes who seemed to reap all the social benefits of high school despite being dull, unfunny, meatheads.nnThe creators also got way out over their skis in the final act with the incredibly low-budget "action" sequence at the football field. I was hoping for a modicum of authenticity during this climax, but it looked like there were about 50 fans in the stands, no officials, and the opposing enemy football team arrived with no coaches or fans of their own... huh.nnIt was fun for me to see Marshawn Lynch in front of the camera, but he was definitely shoe-horned in. I still don't understand the point of his character and the story could easily be told with the same effect without him.nn6/10.

Do not watch the English dub of this movie if you are a fan of seed and seed destiny. The entire English dub cast including the voice actor for Lacus Clyne pronounced her name wrong. The English dub cast was mediocre at best and I do not know who signed off on that pile of garbage.nnI was able to watch the movie with Japanese audio after looking for it and I would rate that version of the movie at about a 6.5 out of 10. I was able to watch the entire movie in one go. I kept turning the English dub version off on Netflix every 10 to 15 minutes because the mispronounced character names and mediocre voice acting kept pissing me off. I would have preferred to hear A. I. narrate the entire English dub over the voice actors they used. I would rate zero stars if I could for the English dub version.

I almost started laughing in the middle of the movie as it got more and more ridiculous.nnIt starts with Nicole Kidman faking orgasms and making sounds. This motif kept going and going.nnTotally confused if this was about sexual fantasy domination, becoming liberated, trying to find a plot, or just an intentional waste of my time.nnGood thing I had AMC Alist. So the only thing I lost was my time and several brain cells.nnI know that moviews and art are subjective. When I read comments or reviews mentioning how thrilling this movie is, I question whether or not I attended a different movie.nnA real stinker.

column3: The Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover (1977)
column4: It's a thought-provoking biographical drama that delves into the complex and controversial life of J. Edgar Hoover, the former director of the FBI. The film explores Hoover's rise to power, his obsession with communism and organized crime, and his alleged homosexual relationships.nnThe film's narrative is engaging, and the performances are solid. Broderick Crawford brings a sense of gravitas and intensity to the role of Hoover, capturing his complexity and contradictions. The supporting cast, including Rip Torn and James Wainwright, deliver strong performances that add depth to the film.nnOne of the standout aspects of "The Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover" is its willingness to tackle sensitive and provocative subjects. The film's portrayal of Hoover's alleged homosexuality is handled with care and nuance, and the film's exploration of his obsessive personality is both fascinating and unsettling.nnThe film's direction by Larry Cohen is also noteworthy. Cohen's use of black-and-white cinematography adds a sense of grittiness and realism to the film, and his pacing is well-balanced, keeping the viewer engaged and invested in the story.nnOverall, "The Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover" is a compelling and thought-provoking biographical drama that sheds light on one of America's most complex and controversial figures.

column3: "The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power" (2022)
column4: It's incredible how nostalgia for the real Lord of the Rings can lead you to sit through this series, hoping to relive the magic... only to hit a wall of boredom head-on. The Rings of Power is like ordering a royal feast and being served a salad without dressing: bland, endless, and utterly depressing. Six storylines to follow? No thanks-this isn't a series, it's a marathon of endurance tests.nnWhere are the epic battles, the heroic deaths, and the spine-tingling dialogue, like Gandalf's showdown with the Balrog? Here, after 13 episodes, nothing has happened. They promise grand confrontations, and you end up watching characters chatter endlessly in settings that look like a 2002 RPG. The Grey Havens? More like the Grey Drizzle. Even the orcs seem bored.nnElrond, Galadriel, the dwarves, the discount hobbits, Isildur, Sauron... Stop. Too many subplots kill the story. Constantly switching between them leaves you lost and disengaged. Why bother investing if no character has enough depth or development to hold your attention?nnThe cities? Ikea villages. The landscapes? Less memorable than a Windows XP wallpaper. Pelargir looks like a forgotten truck stop town you pass on the highway. Where's the grandeur of Middle-earth? Even the Shire in the original movies had more charm than everything here combined.nnThe only moment I felt a flicker of excitement was Sauron's return with his orcs in episode one. A fleeting reminder of past greatness, quickly smothered by dull writing and flavorless plotlines. Not even the Dark Lord can save this empty shell of a series.nnThe Rings of Power is the anti-Lord of the Rings. No soul, no rhythm, no grandeur. Just an overdose of chatter and uninspired settings. If Tolkien saw this, he'd send a Balrog to burn it all down. In short, a series to avoid-unless you enjoy suffering like Gollum without his precious.

I watched the first season and a few episodes of the second season of Misfits, but I couldn't take it anymore. The writing is horrendous, and while the acting isn't entirely terrible, I'm left wondering who this series is even meant for. Marketed as +18, it manages to be both ridiculously childish and quite harmful.nnThe premise of magical thunderstorms granting superpowers based on desires is intriguing, yet the execution is baffling. In a city where people are dying and disappearing, no one seems to notice or care-especially not the police. It's frustrating that the characters operate in a vacuum, with no one outside the main storyline in sight.nnThe characters are obnoxious, making one poor decision after another with their powers. Instead of growth, we're treated to cringe-worthy moments that feel more creepy than comedic. The infamous Nathan is particularly grating, exhibiting an unchanging, arrogant attitude that many seem to adore for some reason. His crude, sexist jokes and objectification of women are not just unfunny-they're genuinely disturbing. Lines like "find a sweet, innocent girl and take advantage of her" or wanting to have intimate relation with a 14 years old! Cross a line that shouldn't exist in entertainment.nnThere are too many plot holes, and the characters don't act like actual human beings-misfits or not. Instead of offering insightful commentary on youth culture, it devolves into a series of tasteless gags centered around genitals and objectification. Scenes featuring drugging others or stalking women under the guise of humor are not only ill-conceived but dangerously misguided.nnThe show had potential with its concept, but the obsession with sex and the juvenile humor detracts from any meaningful storytelling. The sex scenes are gratuitous and add nothing to the plot, merely serving as fodder for immature fantasies. Overall, Misfits feels like a missed opportunity, overly focused on shock value rather than creating anything truly engaging or thought-provoking.

The movie was released at a time when the audience were not ready to accept anything apart from romantic movies like Mohabbatein, KNPH, etc. The timing of the release stopped the movie to be a blockbuster, although it's a fact that the plot was difficult to understand for the masala audience. The film was technically par with Hollywood and the standards set were brilliant. Mission Kashmir won the Filmfare for a lot of technical aspects, the vfx were great too, not an overdose and just the right amount. The climax is what makes the movie special. The climax of Mission Kashmir is one of the greatest in cinema history, you gotta watch it to accept it. A well-made movie with a great message, I give it a ten as it's superior to any other bollywood movie made in the 21st century for technical brilliance. The only other bollywood movie I admire is Tare Zameen Par.

I don't ever feel compelled enough to write a review but Nosferatu is the odd occasion where I'll make an exception. I went to see in with low expectations as I always do with films these days but I was positively surprised - it was extraordinary, compelling and mesmerizing. We went to see it 1 January when it opened here in the UK. The cinema was unexpectedly packed for a matinee. I have never ever heard it so quiet. Nobody coughing, talking, eating noisy food, fidgeting in their seats - nothing - just stunned silence. This movie is truly captivating and transports you into another world. I have to add I have always been a huge fan of Murnau's 1922 original silent movie masterpiece, the only movie in fact to ever give me nightmares. Schreck's titular character was truly terrifying to me. So perhaps I was slightly biased going into this movie, however my expectations were low nevertheless, as as far as remakes go this movie - and Hollywood remakes in general - don't have a good track record.nnI was pleased to see that the German setting and different time period of the original were adhered to (rather than going back to the turn of the century standard template of the original Bram Stoker novel and having it all anglicised), Setting it in the earlier part of 19th century Germany was true genius and greatly aids the gothic and poetic feel of the movie. For example, due to the action taking place before there were trains, main character Hutter has to travel to Transylvania on horseback, even going on foot for the last part of the journey. Which automatically makes it more haunting and dangerous than a simple train journey, and we get to soak in the strange and beautiful scenery more. This was very clearly a labour of love by someone who did their research, understood the original and also had a background in German romanticism of the era during which it is set. The film effortlessly captures the sad, romantic and forlorn beauty of a Caspar David Friedrich painting, a Goethe poem or a Schubert song cycle (Winterreise springs to mind). The cinematography is the best I have ever seen in a horror movie, perhaps in any movie period. You could freeze frame every shot, print it out and hang it on your wall it's a work of art. I cannot use any term to describe it other than breathtaking.nnIn terms of the story and plot it keeps pretty close to the original with a few changes and additions each of which enriched and enhanced rather than took away. Brilliant performances by all in particular Hoult, Skarsgard and Dafoe. Overall though I must say the male performances were better than the females. Therein lies my only criticism of the movie. Throughout, Depp lacked expression in her eyes. However it has to be said, her character is in some kind of trance/ under Orlock's spell for large parts of it so this may have been the thinking behind the "dead" eyes. Skarsgard is spellbinding and terrifying as the revolting titular character, refreshingly and brilliantly hidden in the shadows for a lot of the movie. A true monster, the kind you were hiding under the bed from as a child. There are no glamorous, sophisticated, tragically misunderstood heartthrob vampires in this movie! No - he's just evil.nnTo enjoy the movie as much as I have, I think it does help to have a bit of context and background on the whole thing - so do watch the original 1922 silent movie and even the Herzog (1979) remake. Even though easily the weakest of the three Nosferatu films - it's still worth it for Klaus Kinski's usual unhinged and creepy yet mesmerizing brilliance alone. Also, Shadow of the Vampire (2000), which was about the making of the 1922 original, is a recommendation - very quirky, off the wall and unexpectedly humorous at times! It stars John Malkovich as Murnau and - coincidentally - also Dafoe who puts in a stunning performance as Schreck. Anyway, forget all the other Dracula movies like the over-the-top camp Hammer horrors or the bombastic Coppola epic - this isn't anything like those films. This is something entirely different. But for those of you that love the original and all things gothic horror - this is a real treat! And if you are planning on ever seeing please go now and watch it on the big screen - it won't be the same on the small screen.

The one good thing about this movie is Selena Gomez. Her charisma and performance bring some life to an otherwise disappointing film. Though maybe I'm just biased as a Rare Beauty fan who's also seen her Disney days. However, even she cannot salvage this mess. The movie fails to represent Mexican culture or transsexuality in a genuine or respectful way, which is a major letdown considering they're the main two themes. The songs are awful, too - they feel awkward and disjointed, almost as if they were clumsily translated without much thought to flow or meaning, and they're downright unpleasant to listen to, so if I could skip them I would. The plot had some promise, but poor execution, shallow character development, and cultural inaccuracies make the entire experience fall apart. What could have been a bold and meaningful story ends up feeling hollow and frustratingly underwhelming.

"See China and Die" is a delightfully campy mystery film that will leave you giggling and entertained. The story follows Momma Sykes, a maid with a passion for detective stories, as she becomes embroiled in a real-life mystery involving her deceased boss and a mysterious statue.nnEsther Rolle shines as the sassy and irreverent Momma Sykes, bringing a sense of humor and wit to the role. Her performance is reminiscent of a 1970s-era Pam Grier, and she owns every scene she's in.nnThe film's tone is decidedly campy, with a healthy dose of humor and wit. The dialogue is often laugh-out-loud funny, and the situations Momma Sykes finds herself in are frequently absurd.nnOne of the standout aspects of "See China and Die" is its commentary on social issues. The film touches on themes such as racism, sexism, and classism, but does so in a way that's more playful than preachy.nnWhile the film's production values are somewhat dated, the cinematography is still impressive, capturing the gritty realism of 1980s New York City.nnOverall, "See China and Die" is a deliciously campy mystery film that's sure to entertain. With its witty dialogue, absurd situations, and standout performance from Esther Rolle, it's a must-watch for fans of campy cinema.

The film is adapted from Ukrainian writer Grigori Adamov's 1939 novel of the same name. Directed by Georgian filmmaker Konstantin Pipinashvili, the film was shot in Georgia, then a part of the Soviet Union. While this movie is often credited with kickstarting the second wave of science fiction films in Soviet cinema, its original title and most of the surviving records about it are in Georgian, not Russian. Unfortunately, due to the lack of archival awareness in Georgia, very little remains from the film itself or its production notes.nnThe film deviates significantly from the book, restructured with numerous additions to serve as a vehicle for heavy Soviet propaganda.nnIn literature and cinema, fantastical fiction, while not explicitly encouraged in the early Soviet period, was at least not prohibited. During the 1920s, before dictator Josef Stalin began perceiving science fiction and fantasy as subversive, Russia produced a handful of experimental and intriguing science fiction films. However, apart from a few carefully monitored propaganda films, there was virtually no science fiction output from the Eastern Bloc in the 1930s and 1940s. It is no coincidence that the resurgence of Russian science fiction on screen began after the dictator's death in 1953. In 1956 and 1957, two ocean-themed science fiction films were released: Tayna vechnoy nochi (The Mystery of the Eternal Night, 1956) and this one.nnThe visual effects in this film are abysmal; rear projection was used for backgrounds, but even this was executed poorly.nnIn comparison, 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea, released three years earlier, handled these elements with remarkable precision.nnOne might wonder, "Were the USSR and the US producing similar works despite the Cold War?" Indeed, Soviet filmmakers could import high-quality Eastmancolor film stock from the US for certain high-profile projects. However, it seems unlikely that this film utilized such material, opting instead for the Sovcolor system, which, while popular in the USSR at the time, had poor color fidelity and resulted in visually taxing imagery.nnCreating the IMDb and Wikipedia pages for this film was particularly challenging. The Ukrainian and Russian entries were riddled with repetitive inaccuracies, while the Georgians had contributed virtually nothing to online platforms.nnIt is truly heartbreaking to witness the disappearance of certain films into obscurity.

Back when I was younger, I didn't really care much about Sonic. In fact, I didn't really like it that much, thinking it was kind of silly. But after I saw the first movie, my opinion changed completely. I saw the potential the franchise had to be one of the best in history, and if it had so many failures, it was because SEGA didn't see what could be done. But the first movie came along; right after that, Sonic took off again and was everywhere. Then came the second one; much better than the previous one, it took everything that was good and tripled the quality. Now I'm faced with the third one, and I go to the movies with the same joy I had four years ago. And I'm not disappointed.nnSonic 3 is probably one of the best movies of the year, with visual effects so realistic that they are better than Marvel movies, my favorite artist, Tyson Hesse being the best co-producer/storyboard artist/character designer possible, Jim Carrey simply being the best villain in history, and of course, Keanu Reeves gave a show as Shadow, making him easily one of the best characters in the history of cinema. The other actors and voice actors do a good job, with highlights for Ben, Colleen and Idris who rocked as Sonic, Tails and Knuckles respectively and Alyla Browne who was perfect as Maria. If you want a movie to have fun, get emotional and leave the theater with a smile on your face, this is the movie for you. And please, stay until the end: the two post-credit scenes are spine-chilling. And that's why I say: SEGA finally opened its eyes, its mind and showed that it can, indeed, surprise.

Shameless: A Raw, Unapologetic, and Addictive Draman"Shameless" is a gritty, intense, and often darkly comedic drama that follows the dysfunctional Gallagher family as they navigate poverty, addiction, and personal struggles in Chicago's South Side.nn*Exceptional Performances*nThe show boasts exceptional performances from its ensemble cast, particularly William H. Macy as Frank Gallagher, the family's patriarch and a complex, often despicable character. Emmy Rossum shines as Fiona Gallagher, the eldest sibling who takes on the responsibility of caring for her family.nn*Unflinching Storytelling*n"Shameless" tackles tough subjects like addiction, abuse, and poverty with unflinching honesty, never shying away from the harsh realities of its characters' lives. The show's writing is sharp, witty, and often humorous, making it an addictive watch.nn*Character Development*nThroughout its 11 seasons, "Shameless" expertly develops its characters, allowing them to grow, evolve, and make mistakes. The show's portrayal of complex, flawed characters is both relatable and captivating.nn*Criticisms*nWhile "Shameless" is widely acclaimed, some critics argue that the show romanticizes poverty and addiction. Others feel that the series relies too heavily on shock value and graphic content.nn*Conclusion*n"Shameless" is a gripping, emotional, and often disturbing drama that will keep you hooked. With its talented cast, sharp writing, and unflinching storytelling, it's a must-watch for fans of complex, character-driven television.

While the acting was great!!!! Especially Amy did a great job with the emotions thought the script.nnSo why a 3... Simply I don't like the way that the men are protrayed in this movie... It sets the perspective of the mother staying home getting her stuff payed by the man, and then trash him because she wants to persue her carreer... Which by the way that's exactly true for many couples... However when the man was with the kid was completely incompetent as a father and the same for the friend father of the protagonist, they as men are totally not present and when they are it's just to pay a baby sitter so the mother feels she can work on things that interests her. And gratify their effort of being so shallowly and materistoacally present.. Such a lame role.. and this movie really is a statement of how men/father are protrayed in the modern world.. which is nothing more fake and dishonest. I am a single parent father and I find this movie insulting.

Actually, Konosuba Sekai no Fukufuku wo really deserves full stars. But my brain still can't accept some of the weirdness in this anime. Most of the humor here makes me laugh. I'm a bit uncomfortable with the crew members omg. How can a knight not be attacked? + masochistic again??? That's the worst. Then the witch who can only do 1 magic which then makes her useless?? Plus her Chonebyo personality and her moral decay. As for Aqua, I'm very tolerant, because besides being beautiful, cute, she's a goddess. What I don't accept is her social life. Oh my gosh, such a beautiful girl is wasted on Kazumi. Then work as a coolie? Just to rent a horse stable next to the MC masturbating? Then all her money is spent on the bar and all her XP points are spent just to learn magic tricks??? Omg I can't stand this anymore.

The Documentary series was all over the place so I'm still not sure what actually happened. If a 9 year old was abused like that (Barnettes) and placed in an apartment alone Lord help them. The production of the show was pretty bad and only left me thinking that every single person in it, including Natalie, were given scripts that resulted in confusion and literally unbelievable scenarios. Dentist said she was actually a child yet many others said she talked about sex or offered sex to men?!??? At 9 years old or under? She wouldn't tell the Barnettes where she was from but then suddenly remembered living in the Ukraine and the day of her adoption later in the series? Again, terrible production. Poor girl either way. Bounced around like a ball and living in pain and alone no matter where she went!

column3: "Goosebumps" (2023) {Stay Out of the Basement, Part I (#2.1)}
column4: The Season 2 premier of what I think I've rated abit unfairly, is the continuous season arcs at play. Goosebumps Season 2 had a solid start, and Season 1 isn't all bad, ranging from good to middling in My personal opinion. But this felt like the movie version, the high school back In 2016, this feels like a follow-up.nnThe scary scenes are genuinely creepy and disturbing, it really has you on your feet, or toes. And may I add, the Hauntingly dark rooms makes the tension and atmosphere scary and more crisp and intense. The unsettling vibe makes it a breeze to watch, the doings and the unfoldings of the scenes really hook you for the next part. I enjoyed these scenes as they did add the darkness, but also the mystery that will be followed up. I enjoyed the re-grouoing of things. It feels like classic Horror.nnAlthough the lighting needs to be toned down, after all it was too dark in some scenes you couldn't identify what was going on. And that was ashame, but the story and darkness does add to the scary elements so that's why it's also a good thing. The purple effect for the basement scene was georgoes and the set designs were really pleasing on the eyes.nnI like the kids in groups, it adds some scenes and the Chemistry we feel is their. They feel very fresh, like modern day kids using terms such as "Tiktok" and other things like talking about their past with each other. It's a unique and nice way to bring Goosebumps into the 20th Century. The acting wasn't that bad either, no standouts as of yet. But the stereotypes are abit duller. But other then that some goods came out of it.nnThe story offered dark imagery too, but the Basement scene looked cool, the action piece was perfected, and seemed scary too see what the sticky plant was doing. I feel like they could've added it in sooner to add in the scares and make the mystery more gripping, because the scenes we did get was genuinely quite dark.nnThe end scene was also very good, whilst the line-of-dialogue didn't create anything for me, the other scene really lifted my excitement and entertainment for the next chapter installed in the story. I feel like they could of shown or explained the scenes of the story, like how did the Uncle or kids dissappear. But like I said, It is a mystery and it has hooked me to find out this key-factor üóù, see what I did their.nnI'd rate this a 6, because I think my positives and the negatives really lifted or ruined some of the scenes and I think my criticisms were fair, I enjoyed it and I can't wait for the next episodes.

Maybe this was something controversial when the film was made, but there is nothing compelling about it now. It's a boring soft-porn and a meaningless story about a couple that has some sexual phantasies and wealthy people who enjoy swing parties and gang-bangs. It all seams as if the director was onto something profoundly psychological, yet his lack of knowledge, vision and talent make this movie a compete waste of time and money. Good example how once you get a cult-like status in any art industry you can make total BS and people will still rave about it. Only those with no knowledge on cinematography, psychology or human nature will believe there is "something" deeper behind this load of disconnected nonsense.

At first i though I couldn't have managed to stay glued to my screen for the entire 3hrs luckily Murphy is my favorite so i knew he was goin to nail that character little did i know the story was exceptional watching Murphy playing the character of a physicist responsible to create an atomic bomb that was going to change the course of the war and his invention did manage to put an end to WWII. In everything they do they do meetings and discuss or debate on an issue in which at times they do not go along with one another but at the end of it all they stick to their desired outcome till they achieve it.

After watching the first 2-3 episodes, I started wondering if I had picked the right show. I based my decision on an IMDb rating of 8 (at the time of this review), but the way the story was going and the slow pace really made me second-guess myself. At first, it felt like it was dragging a bit, and I wasn't sure if it would pick up. But honestly, you really need to see it to get it. The characters and the story gradually started to grow on me, and before I knew it, I was hooked. The development might be slow, but it's definitely worth sticking around for.nnIt's a must-watch! Now, I totally get why it has such a high rating... It all makes sense now!

Watch the trailer and you've seen 70% of the enjoyable parts of the film. It's a showcase for the director's daughter's musical talent presented as something different in order to get butts in the seats. Josh Hartnett is way too talented of an actor to be in this thing. He gets to shine for maybe 22 minutes of the runtime. The rest is a song at the concert, another song at the concert, yet another song at the concert, a shallow subplot that goes nowhere fast, poor dancing to a song at the concert, another dang song at the concert, poor acting by the girl who sang all the songs at the concert (albeit beautifully), and a waste of the great Hayley Mills. Rarely do I feel so genuinely angry after wasting a fraction of my life watching a bad film.

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)
column4: This film is perfect. The cast, the director, the dialogue, the epic shots and of course the incredible book by J. R. R. Tolkien. The perfect conclusion to the best trilogy that has ever existed. If you only saw the theatrical version - watch the extended edition! This film is incredible and unsurpassed to this day.nnWhen you watch this film you might think you are in Middle-earth. Everything seems so real that you could think that this world really exists. Plus, the CGI is incredibly good. The film is from 2003 and has better visual effects than many films from recent years. There will never be a trilogy like this again.nnIt is simply a masterpiece.

Nothing much to write about, just a very disappointing movie but since 600 words are a must, here it goes!nnIMDB ratings are not at all in line with the experience.nnWeak storytelling, Zero Chills, nothing scary & total waste of precious time!nnFrom the very beginning to the very end, we kept waiting for that one moment where the screen would feel like watching, it was worth it. This lacked everything that a good movie should have the book is always better, but this movie was worse than the worst movie made on a book.nnActors didn't give their best, Except for the old English parlance, voice modulation & tonality, there was NOTHING that made this movie or its characters stand out!

My title is really all that's needed. Every review besides mine is obviously a marketing fraud composed by the same promoter. Who cranks this stuff out?
