The online streaming sites are loaded with thousands of these things, so many that it seems improbable that internet advertising could compensate production costs. But I suppose the question answers itself. There are almost no production costs. Unknowns working with lousy writers and no-talent cinematographers. The final clue of "An Angry Boy's" hopelessness is the casting of Eric Roberts, a study on how much a career can deteriorate and still be functional at the lowest levels. And here, in fairness, I want to acknowledge his comedic work as the aged and wildly libidinous stalking doctor on those bizarre productions. For a paycheck I couldn't have done any better myself. Eric has 3 minutes of screen time here and that's where the whole budget went. The story line is about a male pedophilic cult (Eric's sexuality is now panoramic, global) that kidnaps young boys, rendered as capons if they disobey, one of whom escapes, and is tracked down some ten years later by the murderous founder's partner. Going in you should know that the star of this thing is the large log, honed to a razor sharp apex, which male victims are compelled to straddle spread eagled with buckets tied to their ankles, which are gradually filled with bricks until the desired result is achieved, the spatchcocking (look it up) of the sorry young victim. As I said; a few amusing moments, so I'm sure that there is some mood obscure enough for this to be a real hoot-fest.

*Bastards: A Haunting Exploration of Family Secrets and Trauma*nn"Bastards" is a gripping and emotionally charged Norwegian drama that delves into the complexities of family relationships, trauma, and the devastating consequences of secrets left unspoken. Director Amund Lie masterfully weaves a narrative that is both poignant and unsettling, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats.nnThe story centers around two brothers, Geir (Henrik Mestad) and Erlend (John Sigurd Kristensen), who are forced to confront their troubled past when their father's mysterious death brings them back to their childhood home. As they sort through their father's belongings, they stumble upon a series of cryptic letters and recordings that reveal a dark family secret: their father's involvement in a tragic event that has haunted their family for decades.nnAs the brothers dig deeper into their family's history, they begin to unravel a complex web of lies, deceit, and silence. Through a non-linear narrative, Lie expertly juxtaposes the present-day investigation with flashbacks of the brothers' childhood, slowly revealing the traumatic events that have shaped their lives.nnThe performances by Mestad and Kristensen are outstanding, conveying the depth of their characters' emotional pain and vulnerability. The supporting cast, including Line Verndal as the brothers' mother, adds to the film's emotional intensity.nnCinematographer Martin Solvang's use of muted colors and stark landscapes effectively captures the bleakness and isolation of the Norwegian countryside, mirroring the characters' emotional states. The film's pacing is deliberate and measured, allowing the audience to absorb the weight of the characters' experiences.nn"Bastards" is a thought-provoking and deeply unsettling film that lingers long after the credits roll. Lie's masterful direction and the cast's powerful performances make for a cinematic experience that is both haunting and unforgettable. While the subject matter is undoubtedly dark and challenging, the film's exploration of trauma, family secrets, and the complexities of human relationships is both poignant and timely.nn*Rating:* 4.5/5 starsnn*Recommendation:* "Bastards" is a must-see for fans of Scandinavian drama and those who appreciate thought-provoking, emotionally charged cinema. However, viewer discretion is advised due to the film's mature themes and content.

column3: "One Piece: Wan p√Æsu" (1999) {Nigeba Nashi: Taishou Fujitora Hijou no Tsuigeki! (#1.744)}
column4: The most touching moment in the Dressrosa Arc is the poignant admission by Fujitora that he wanted to see Luffy's face. There was so much weight in that statement because it meant he respected what Luffy had done and stood for. For a man who has blindfolded himself to avoid looking at the ugliness of the world, this intent to see the face of Luffy speaks volumes regarding the impact which Luffy has managed to have upon him. A testament to such deep-seated and profound justice, hope, and admiration that this young boy fosters, coming together in amazement over even those that stand on nearly opposing sides of the battlefield.

I just emerged from the most unforgettable cinematic experience of my life - "My Old Ass" (2024). This film is a poignant, heartwarming, and thought-provoking exploration of love, loss, identity, and the complexities of human relationships.nnThe story follows Elliott, a free-spirited 18-year-old, as she navigates the challenges of growing up, family dynamics, and first love. The film's narrative is expertly woven, seamlessly blending elements of drama, comedy, and fantasy to create a truly unique viewing experience.nnThe cast delivers outstanding performances, with Maisy Stella shining as the protagonist Elliott. The chemistry between the actors is palpable, making the characters' relationships feel authentic and relatable.nnDirector Megan Park's vision is bold, sensitive, and masterful. She tackles complex themes with ease, never shying away from exploring the depths of human emotion. The film's pacing is impeccable, balancing humor and pathos to create a truly emotional resonance.nnWhat struck me most about "My Old Ass" is its ability to resonate across generations. The film's themes of love, loss, and self-discovery are timeless, making it a must-watch for audiences of all ages.nnIn short, "My Old Ass" is a cinematic masterpiece that will leave you laughing, crying, and reflecting on the complexities of life and love. I highly recommend this film to anyone seeking a thought-provoking, emotionally resonant, and deeply human experience.

If you're interested in a poorly stitched together patchwork quilt-style film that pays homage to many great horror classics without matching their quality, you might enjoy this film. It's like they took visual, narrative, and conceptual snippets from far superior horror films and threw them together under the assumption that the best parts of a bunch of awesome films would inevitably equal one stellar film. It didn't. There are continuity issues, "smart" characters who make the dumbest decisions possible, blaringly obvious methods to better manage the situation introduced but glossed over multiple times, some weird werewolf rendering, and many other issues that make this movie feel like a ride on a jerky wooden roller coaster that should be decommissioned because it causes whiplash.nnOn the positive side, this movie made me laugh, laugh, and laugh some more. I enjoyed it for that reason, but not enough to suffer another sit-through.

Tbh, I didn't expect too much from this film but it delivered. Now amongst my favourites, this film feels like an experience that has you on the edge of your seat with your heart pounding or laughing your head off and delivering such unexpected twists and turns that you cant help but appreciate the greatness of the direction, writing amd acting. Incredibly fun yet moving, and profound; a perfect example of how movies should be like. The unorthodox Tarantino filmmaking style is at its absolute peak here with some excellent acting (Christopher Waltz) and a crazy plot that leaves you breathless. Truly iconic.

This movie delivers on its promise of action,with impressive fight choreography and over the top set piece.nnUnhinged, stylish and utterly gory with impressive and exciting fight styles. There are a lot of unexplained or glanced over plot-holes, you kind of need to turn your brain off for this one and just enjoy the ass-kicking and ridiculous foolery. Boy Kills World may seem like an inclusive feature, but underneath the admittedly fun carnage is a feeble attempt at genuine representation. Skarsgard's performance must be commended for its physicality, but ultimately Boy Kills World becomes as much of a physical ordeal to watch as for its hero to survive.

Nosferatu is so close to the perfect gothic horror, but is sadly let down by the writing.nnThe atmosphere is dark and brooding, it's visually stunning and the pacing is good, with lots of great nods to the original.nnSadly, it was let down by a serious case of "male gaze" writing. Every woman with a speaking line has an on-screen sex scene and the heroine lacks agency throughout.nnThis lack of agency could have been played as a powerful allegory to the dangers of toxic relationships, especially when tied to her relationship to Orlok, but instead it ends up reading simply as the female characters being nothing more than sex objectsnnLikewise, many of the characters felt lacking in any depth, you never had the impression that their actions were being driven by their own motives or personalities, you were just expected to accept that they were doing what they were doing because the plot required it.nnHaving spent three quarters of the film convinced I was watching the best vampire film I'd ever seen, it was so much more disappointing to find the completed story so hollow. Guttingly close to perfect.

POSITIVES:nn1) Jesse Eisenberg and Kieran Culkin both give incredible performances and really carry this film on their backs. Culkin seems to be the one getting most of the awards attention, and I can completely understand why, but I'd actually like to highlight Eisenberg as the better performance of the two in my opinion. Culkin spends the entire film loud and emotional, whereas Eisenberg only has two scenes where gets emotional (in the restaurant and on the rooftop) and those are the two best scenes in the film for me.nn2) I don't think the narrative is exactly reinventing the wheel, but I do fundamentally think the writing of the story between these two men is done well. They're both very flawed and incomplete individuals who really are the opposite sides of the coin to each other, yet there's a clearly a deep love between the two of them. However, despite this, they still have to part ways at the end of the film and ultimately revert back to being the characters that they were at the start. The "real pain" of the title seems to me to be the pain of accepting that your life is what it is, when you have this person opposite you who clearly represents the road untraveled for you. The final shot at the end of Culkin sat back in the airport, just like how we saw him at the start, and desperately looking round to try and find some sort of human connection from someone, was really tragic and embodied that sense of the character now being trapped in this life that he's chosen for himself.nn3) The film is a really good example to me of films that I wish there were more of in the industry. It's a low budget, short 90 minute film. It has very unflashy cinematography and direction, that just tells its story in a very straightforward way without the need for any grand spectacle, and really relies on its writing and its performances rather than any flashy visuals or effects. The film had me feeling like I was actually on a trip in Poland and, like any good trip, it didn't last too long or overstay its welcome.nnNEGATIVES:nn1) Outside of Culkin and Eisenberg, nobody else really does anything of note at all and I actually found the rest of characters in their tour group to be quite annoying and painfully surface level.nn2) I definitely can't say that I enjoyed watching the film for large parts. I have a low bar for cringe and so I found this film excruciating to watch at times when it came to Culkin's character. The idea of being trapped on a tour group with this guy would kill me. He's so whiny and annoying and uncomfortable and I really really hated his character, rather than feeling sympathetic for him like I feel as though the film wanted.nn3) I think the film is very bland and pedestrian at times and I can't imagine it'll stay with me very long. I think this'll be a film where I look back at my IMDb reviews for the year of 2025 and have to jog my memory about this film when I come across it in my reviews. For a film that has the holocaust in its subject matter, I always felt like this was in the background rather than something that the film actually wanted to focus on. There's that one scene at the concentration camp where it's really powerful and harrowing, but that scene just felt out of place with the rest of the film and didn't gel at all.

I've been putting off this show since it was realised since I couldn't get the hype at first, only for me to realise that I was missing out on a masterpiece of animation üò≠.nnI loved it from the storyline, the animation style, how they are able to convey the characters emotions at such a human level. I felt this show to the depths of my soul. At the end of EVERY single episode I would be left staring blankly at the end credits or the wall trying to just fathom what I just watched. I'm so grateful to have watched all the episodes after they'd aired because I couldn't imagine myself having to wait for a next episode.nnCatVi deserves an honorary mention because I loved how the creators of the show didn't let their lives revolve around their sexualities. Instead they focused on their strengths & accomplishments etc.nnSn2 ep 7&8 have a special place in my heart .

As opposed to most movies today where the plot becomes crystal-clear ten minutes into the film, 'The Usual Suspects treads a different path with flair. The seemingly tedious process of building up a storyline takes up a decent portion of the movie, but from then onwards, it's a roller-coaster ride. However, in this film, the slow start and confusing build-up is instrumental to its brilliance and is more than made up for by an ending that manages to astonish and leave you at a loss for words. Superbly directed and written, with excellent casting (a shoutout to Kevin Spacey- Oscar fully deserved), and an unforgettable ending coupled with one of the greatest movie quotes of all time; this gem truly deserves its spot on the top 50 list on IMDB.

Business executive "Romy" (Nicole Kidman) is initially impressed with the dog-handling skills of "Samuel" (Harris Dickinson) but when she discovers that he is to be an intern in her e-packaging company something else starts to draw her to the man. We already know that though happily enough married to "Jacob" (Antonio Banderas) she's not exactly fulfilled in the bedroom department, and "Samuel" seems to sense that it's an area that maybe he can help with. Were not just talking sex, here - oh. No. This is about a lady with fantasy of being dominated. About her surrendering control completely, and if you're going to do that at all, then why not this tall, handsome and mischievous bit of rough? Of course, like any addiction - it starts to get out of control as the relationship dynamic changes quite profoundly and others start to put two and two together. At times this is quite funny, and milk seems to play a central role from time to time, but as a cinematic version of something akin to tantric, it doesn't really work. Neither of these actors are afraid to get naked yet neither do, simultaneously, here. Indeed I'm sure I saw his black Calvin's shining from under the sheet when the intimacy consultant was at their busiest. I didn't need nudity to augment their unique sort of passion, but I did expect something way more natural, visceral even, and I didn't get it. It's filmed in such a disjointed and bitty fashion, there's no attempt to characterise or contextualise either of these people and in the end I felt like this was little better than a titillation for it's stars that didn't really aspire to engage those watching any more than age-related porn might. Dickinson isn't remotely charismatic and the premiss falls flat quickly, especially when the quite aggravating intervention of "Esme" (Sophie Wilde) rather summed the shallowness of the whole thing up. "Eyes Wide Shut" (1999) or "Beach Rats" (2017) showcase both their talents amidst a sexually charged environment far better: this is all forgettable, over-hyped, stuff.

An American kid has been raised in France and when he comes to the US, he doesn't fit in with his peers. In particular, he and Muggs instantly dislike each other and begin a fight...and both get arrested. The judge has an idea...to sentence BOTH to six months...but suspend it IF the pair can stay out of trouble. And, if one of them messes up, they'll both get sent away. And, they are expected to act almost like probation officers for each other...and this means that 'Frenchy' will hang out with the East Side Kids. What's next? See for yourself.nnThe film, despite the fight between the young men, is amazingly okay and unexciting...and nothing more. It is quite predictable and the ending came as no shock at all.nnBy the way, the silent film star, Harry Langdon, appears in the film. Additionally, Billy Benedict plays yet another role as a character other than Whitey...who he played in all the later films. Here, he plays a guy in a rival gang.

One the most entertaining, charismatic and nostalgic films filled with a compelling storyline, this movie is definitely not!! An absolute mess of what could have been an amazing cinematic experience. Crowe was the only decent actor in the movie. Johnson lacks charisma and magnetism that usually makes you root for the character. Instead, you want the character to take some serious hits and even die so that a pair of fibrillators can bring the movie back to life. Not sure how Johnson is going to pull off the role of James Bond? This movie is like a most anticipated sports car debut (thanks to months of marketing) that takes off the starting line and almost immediately loses acceleration and continues to leak fluids and parts before it falls flat. I mean, even the NSX made it to the finish line before it got discontinued. Wait for home viewing so that you can watch in 10 min increments between NFL games to stay awake. Otherwise, an absolute waste of time!!

One of my sci-fi/horror/fantasy reviews written 50 years ago: Directed by Eugene Lourie; Produced by Wilfred Eades, for King Brothers Productions, released in America by MGM. Screenplay by Daniel James and Robert Richards; Photography by Freddie Young; Edited by Eric Boyd-Perkins; Music by Angelo Lavagnino; Assistant Director: Douglas Hermes. Starring: Bill Travers, William Sylvester, Vincent Winter, Christopher Rhodes, Joseph O'Conor, Martin Benson, Bruce Seton, Basil Dignam and Ed Bishop.nnBritish monster film (with an all-male cast) concerning exploitation, in the "King Kong' tradition, and also dealing with the dangers of radioactivity and mother love for a young sea monster. An improvement by director Eugene Lourie on his previous similar picture, "The Giant Behemoth'.

I don't understand who are watching the movies lately. I cannot understand what are they expecting to see in a movie. For every movie there's just negative comments and bad reviews which are not making sense. People need to take a step back and understand where they are going with this. They don't seem to understand the Craft and Movies in total.nnAnyways coming to the movie, it's a huge disciplined, knowledge based thriller.nnHigh octane, high voltage scenes.nnRam Charan increased his performance üëè to another level. He has been depicted in the most beautiful way.nnShankar did a great job.nnBeautiful songs presentation.nnEngaging screenplay.

M. Night Shyamalan's boldest experiment yet, My Old Ass (2024), tackles the profound realities of aging-both literal and metaphorical-with his signature mix of suspense, confusion, and WTF twists. In this darkly comedic thriller, an unsuspecting protagonist wakes up one day to find that their behind has mysteriously aged decades overnight. Wrinkles, creaks, and a sense of wisdom...but at what cost?nnStrengths:nnOriginality: Shyamalan explores uncharted territory in cinema, blending body horror with existential comedy. A bold take on self-acceptance and gravity's relentless effects on the human body.nnSymbolism: The aging "ass" is a metaphor for society's obsession with youth and beauty. It's surprisingly deep (and no, not like that).nnSoundtrack: The score, featuring remixed versions of "Baby Got Back" and "Forever Young," sets the tone perfectly.nnOverall:nnMy Old Ass is a quirky and polarizing entry in Shyamalan's filmography. It's not for everyone, but it's sure to leave you thinking-about time, aging, and maybe investing in a better chair.nnRating: 10/10nWould recommend for fans of surreal humor and body-positive messaging.

I like the idea of showing how Superman family would live but this show is just CW soap opera with weak attempts at smart social commentarynncharacters speak so politely like their mom watches them and people who are so calm and patient should easily avoid conflicts but these same characters constantly get into childishly arrogant conflictsnncharacters are very low IQ and they are constantly giving SPEECHES ABOUT MORALITY AND SOCIAL ISSUES of real worldnnSupermans son's are so annoying and whineyn"dad why you kept your secret ,dad why my stupid brother has powers and i don't ,dad why you save people all the time instead of helping us to do homework"nnhalf of the 1st season a terrorist repeatedly lures superman tries to kill then it's revealed this guy is from parallel earth where superman was evil and that guy knowing full well that superman is good on this earth he still makes terrorist attacks and by episode 8 they stopped him and RELEASED a TERRORIST because he thought that he's saving the planet IT DIESN'T MATTER what he was thinking there are consequences for being a terroristnnSupermans mom dies and there is a choice get half price for her farm or to pay half and keep farm to himself and reason to stay is just for nostalgy i guessnnthe most annoying superman son got powers and used them to punish bullies at football it would be okay if he just stopped bullies when they where bullying him or someone else not beating them but just stop their fists or push them of. But he cheats the competitive games to punish them.nnBillionaire is mining in Smallville where Supermen lives and it TURNS out he's not just mining he's mining MEGAKRYPTONITE how a mineral from another planet is found under the same town superman lives it would need to be a meteorite that strike earth thousands of yers before superman arrived and it would be a very dumb coincidencenHe also turns out to be Superman's evil brother and he replaces people's mind's with cryptonians mindsnAnd he's evil because English farmers tried to kill him when he arrived on Earth (yeah CW thinks highly of english farmers)nAnd then government (probably English) captured him until he escapednso dangerous alien escaped from secret lab and there was no emergency ,no one found him until he became a billionaire ,angry child with superpowers was so patientl to not just use his powers to rob banks but instead building business empire from scratch billionaire can get anything he wants just sit and chill but he is so patriotic that he wants to remake earth to Krypton when he never saw Krypton.i thought it was good at first.

So I have watched this film 3 times. Once in the theatre and twice streaming. Being a fan of the franchise since 1979, I will try to be a brief as I can to explain the problems I had with this.nnThey spend 20 years looking for the original xenomorph for some reason when they have access to plenty of specimens that they knew of on LV-426.nnThey find the original (big chap) floating among the wreckage of the Nostromo when Ripley blew it out of the escape shuttle miles and miles from the wreckage.nnNo remains of the Nostromo should exist at all as it detonated 3 times and was vaporized.nnThis ragtag group of young mine workers know how to fly a company spaceship, not to mention easily having access to one.nnA gigantic space station full of top secret company experiments is abandoned, and they easily gain access to it.nnThe space station only has 5 cryo chambers even though it is equipped for hundreds of workers.nnMaybe I missed it, but for some reason space station is on a collision course with the planet's rings and they somehow know this.nnAndy and Rain are the only ones given any character development, so we don't care about the rest of these cardboard cutouts.nnAndy is the only android in the series that looks permanently sad (obviously to gain sympathy with the audience) when all of the others have been expressionless as they should be.nnAndy is the only android to have super human strength for some reason.nnAndy is easily knocked down and disabled and is also easily fixed by simply sticking a key in his neck.nnFacehuggers are printed.nnAliens have a cocoon cycle. Why? This was only hinted at in the director's cut of Alien.nnAliens are an afterthought in this film when they should have been the main focus. The video game aim assist just blasted them all to smithereens, and then Rain and Andy simply floated around a ton of acid without getting a drop on them.nnThe black goo is back.nnUncanny valley Ash is used for fan service when he could have easily been his own original android.nnAsh ripoff goes on to unload all kinds of exposition, explaining to us beat for beat exactly what's happening instead of the film telling us.nnOne character uses the word "sick" when trying the portable x-ray machine when instantly made me think 2024.nnThe cheesiest chest bursting scene in the entire series.nnAnother newborn!nnAuto aim pulse rifle is almost out of rounds but goes on to shoot many more facehuggers and aliens.nnNewborn grows from infant to 7 foot adult in 5 minutes.nnEngineer newborn is defeated with a half of a coconut full of acid. Good thing it was there exactly when she needed it.nnCliche "die motherf***er" ending.nnRain's sign off is an exact copy of Ripley's sign off at the end of Alien, more fan service.nnThere is a lot more, but I this is all I can remember right now. As you can tell i am not a fan off all of the fan service in this film and it is full of it, from beginning to end. There is a such of a thing as subtle nods and hints, but they went full tilt. If this film didn't rely so heavily on it and was it's own movie, I would have enjoyed it much more.nnYou might think that I absolutely hate this movie, but for all of it's negatives, I can at least give them credit for trying to make the sets look ver alien-esque. The creatures look pretty good for the most part except for the gummy bear looking jaws on the aliens. The cinematography was good and the digital effects of space looked gorgeous.nnIf this film tried harder to be it's own thing I could give it more credit. In my opinion, this rates at the bottom of the list of the 5 films, just barely above Alien Resurrection.

This captivating film is a cinematic treasure that will leave audiences spellbound and nostalgic. With its thoughtful narrative, the movie takes viewers on a poignant journey that celebrates the beauty of love, family, and friendship. The film's sentimental value is undeniable, making it a delightful experience for the whole family.nnOne of the standout aspects of the film is its Japanese drama influences, which add a unique cultural flavor to the narrative. The movie's thoughtful pacing, coupled with its introspective character development, is reminiscent of classic Japanese dramas. This blend of cultural influences creates a distinctive cinematic experience that is both captivating and emotionally resonant.nnThe film's ability to balance emotions is truly masterful. The narrative effortlessly shifts between moments of joy, sadness, and laughter, creating a rich emotional tapestry that is both authentic and engaging. The movie's uplifting atmosphere is skillfully maintained throughout, even in the face of adversity, making it a truly inspiring and heartwarming experience.nnWhile some comedic moments feel unnecessary, they do not detract from the overall impact of the film. The charming score and tone create a pleasant feel that permeates every aspect of the narrative. The movie's ability to evoke emotions without becoming too sad or melodramatic is a testament to the filmmakers' skill and craftsmanship.nnAs the credits roll, viewers will likely find themselves reflecting on the film's poignant themes and characters. The movie's tear-jerking moments are expertly crafted, leaving a lasting impression on audiences. With its beautiful storytelling, captivating characters, and uplifting atmosphere, this film is a must-see for anyone looking for a heartwarming and emotionally resonant cinematic experience.nnIn conclusion, this film is a masterpiece of storytelling that will captivate audiences of all ages. Its nostalgic and sentimental value, combined with its unique Japanese drama influences, make it a truly.

An interesting movie and definitely worth watching. It has three distinct stages. It starts with an abundance of happiness and fun (too good to last), a transition (the funniest part of the movie) and ends with a harsh slap of reality.nnThe ending moved me deeply. Anora, who had been defending herself from being seen as a prostitute throughout the movie, receives the only honest gift from a man with no expectation of sex. In reply, she offers him sex, then becomes angry and sad at both him and herself for what she was doing. She might be seeing her destiny in Igor at that moment, a destiny she believed she had run from so simple-mindedly.

Sometimes, cinema transcends mere storytelling and touches the core of human emotions, and this movie achieves just that. It is a beautiful ode to the love and bonds we often overlook, particularly the love for our grandparents.nnThe film's narrative flows seamlessly, drawing you into a world of warmth, regret, and bittersweet nostalgia. Its tear-jerking moments are not forced but arise naturally from the authentic connections between the characters. The actors are incredible, & the way Bilkin has lived the character M, it leaves you spellbound. Every scene feels like a quiet reminder of the love we take for granted until it's too late.nnWhat truly stands out is how the movie never tries to be grandiose. Its simplicity is its strength, with every moment, every glance, and every unspoken word carrying profound weight.nnThis film is a cinematic gem, both heart-wrenching and healing. It reminds us that sometimes the most impactful stories are not the loudest but the ones that whisper truths we need to hear.nnA must-watch for anyone who values family, love, and the fleeting beauty of time.

I found it - "My Old Ass" is a 2024 coming-of-age comedy-drama film written and directed by Megan Park. The movie stars Maisy Stella, Percy Hynes White, Maddie Ziegler, Kerrice Brooks, and Aubrey Plaza ¬π.nnThe plot follows Elliott, an 18-year-old girl who encounters her 39-year-old self during a mushroom trip. Her older self starts handing out warnings about what her younger self should and shouldn't do, making Elliott rethink everything about family, love, and her future ¬π.nnGreetings again from the darkness. Eighteen-year-old Elliott is counting down the twenty-two days remaining until she leaves home for her freshman year of college. For anyone who was once 18 or has raised an 18-year-old, you know that 22 days is the future. Writer-director Megan Park follows up her excellent feature film debut, THE FALLOUT (2021), with a different tone, albeit another one that focuses on the stress of being a teenager.nnMaisy Stella landed the role of Daphne on the series "Nashville" at a very young age, and even got to sing on the show with her sister Lennon. Her role as Elliott is her feature film debut, and she proves to be quite charming in front of the camera, with a nice screen presence. A camping trip with her friends Ro (Kerrice Brooks) and Ruthie (Maddie Ziegler) leads to a trip on mushrooms that has the friends hallucinating, while something altogether more extreme happens with Elliott. Coming face-to-face with one's future self while sitting on a log in the woods can only be described as fantastical.nnAubrey Plaza plays from-the-future thirty-nine-year-old (not 40!) Elliott, and though she doesn't have much screen time, her trademark snark fits well, and the scenes with both Elliotts are quite fun. However, this isn't the typical Hollywood body swap/share. The cool twist is that the situation allows for the age-old unsolvable dilemma: what advice would your older self give your younger self if that were possible? While attempting to walk a fine line, the wisdom passed along includes be nice to your mom and your family, and understand that "time goes by so fast". One final bit of counseling involves 'avoiding Chad'. At this point, young Elliott had no idea who Chad is or why she should avoid, but of course, she finds out quickly.nnChad (Percy Hynes-White, "Wednesday") turns out to be a college student working on the family cranberry farm. He's also exceedingly nice and Elliott struggles mightily against falling hard for him. Yes, this is the same Elliott who we've seen in intimate situations with local barista Chelsea (Alexandria Rivera). At its core, this is a contemporary story where a teenager is searching for identity and meaning. Other supporting cast members include Maria Dizzia as mom, Al Goulem as dad, and Seth Isaac-Johnson and Carter Trozzolo as Elliott's brothers - one addicted to golf, the other obsessed with actress Saoirse Ronan (complete with a funny visual).nnSome cliches are almost necessary in this type of story, but a mushroom trip featuring a Justin Bieber sequence to "One Less Lonely Girl" is both funny and creative. Offering advice to one's younger self in an attempt to save her from pain is understandable, but can we figure out life at age 18 even if we cheat and get input from our 'middle-aged' self? In fact, what filmmaker Park has done is create a dual coming of age story - one for teens and one for adults. And if you don't like the messages ... well ... at least eat your salmon while it's still around!

If you read the other reviews here on IMDB you will get the impression that this movie is amazing. Great cast, great story, great acting, great sets. And I agree, it's all those things, however there is one thing that bugs me.nnThe main villain. I think Count Adhemar (Rufus Sewell) is a great villain....but not enough cruel and calculated. (small spoiler?) There is a certain scene towards the end where you can see he shows a sort of emotional weakness, and it's not anger, but a feeling of inferiority. I would've liked he remained this kind of unapologetic, mostly, one-dimensional villain. He has the looks, he has the attitude, just wished they didn't include that scene, or made him more poker faced.

I liked this movie a lot. It evokes a lot of emotion & it displays the endearing relationships we as a human species experience with our grandparents. This movie clearly shows that sometimes, cinema transcends mere storytelling and touches the core of human emotions.nnThe film's narrative flows seamlessly, drawing you into a world of warmth, regret, and bittersweet nostalgia. Its tear-jerking moments are not forced but arise naturally from the authentic connections between the characters. The actors are incredible, & the way Bilkin has lived the character M, it leaves you spellbound. Every scene feels like a quiet reminder of the love we take for granted until it's too late.nnWhat truly stands out is how the movie never tries to be grandiose. Its simplicity is its strength, with every moment, every glance, and every unspoken word carrying profound weight.nnThis film is a cinematic gem, both heart-wrenching and healing. It reminds us that sometimes the most impactful stories are not the loudest but the ones that whisper truths we need to hear.nnA must-watch for anyone who values family, love, and the fleeting beauty of time.

The characters are the heart of the series. Ye Wenjie, portrayed with haunting brilliance, is both a victim and a catalyst. Her decisions, shaped by personal trauma and disillusionment with humanity, resonate deeply. Wang Miao, the nanotech scientist drawn into a mysterious VR game called Three Body, serves as our entry point into this perplexing and fascinating world. His journey from skepticism to awe mirrors what we, as viewers, experience.nnWhat's remarkable is how the series treats its characters with nuance. They're not just heroes or villains-they're flawed, conflicted, and achingly human. This depth adds emotional weight to the high-stakes narrative, making every revelation and twist hit harder.nnVisuals That Redefine Sci-FinLet's talk about the visuals, because wow. The series doesn't just depict a dystopian future or alien world-it immerses you in it. The depiction of the chaotic Trisolaran system is breathtaking, with its three suns creating an ever-shifting landscape of beauty and destruction. The VR game sequences are equally stunning, blending surrealism with scientific precision to create something that feels entirely new.nnIt's clear that the creators spared no expense in bringing Liu Cixin's vision to life. The attention to detail is staggering, whether it's the design of the Trisolaran technology, the eerie beauty of their communication methods, or the way Earth itself is rendered in moments of crisis.nnThemes That Stay With YounWhat sets The Three-Body Problem apart is its intellectual depth. This isn't just a story about aliens-it's a story about us. It asks hard questions about human nature, the cost of progress, and our place in the cosmos. Are we, as a species, capable of uniting against a common threat? Or are our divisions and flaws too deeply ingrained?nnThe series also explores the concept of hope and despair in fascinating ways. The Trisolarans' desperate search for survival mirrors our own struggles as a species, creating a sense of empathy even as they pose a threat to humanity.nnWhy You Need to Watch ItnIf you're someone who loves stories that challenge your mind and stir your soul, The Three-Body Problem is a must-watch. It's not just a show-it's an experience. It pushes the boundaries of what science fiction can achieve, blending mind-blowing concepts with deeply emotional storytelling.nnThis series has left me in awe. As someone who loves diving into stories that make you think and feel, I can't recommend it enough. The Three-Body Problem isn't just another sci-fi series-it's a masterpiece that deserves to be seen, discussed, and celebrated.

Shankar is undeniably a legendary director. He was a pioneer in creating pan-Indian films long before the term became popular. Not only did he helm high-budget movies with big stars, but with films like Boys and Premikudu, he proved he could deliver blockbusters even without major star power. Unfortunately, that golden era seems to have faded. Especially after the controversies surrounding Indian 2, his reputation has taken a hit. Naturally, when he announced Game Changer, skepticism was high. Many wondered if he could recreate his old magic. However, with Ram Charan, Chiranjeevi, and Dil Raju onboard-each a heavyweight in their own right-it wasn't just Shankar's movie anymore. Even so, the negative sentiment surrounding the project seemed to impact its opening.nnAfter watching the movie, I can see why Ram Charan and the others believed in its potential. Appanna's character is a standout and might just be one of the most memorable roles in Ram Charan's career. Years down the line, when he reflects on his filmography, this will likely be one of the highlights. The character even reminded me of The King's Speech-perhaps it served as an inspiration.nnThe first half of the film is engaging, barring the introduction song after the initial fight, which felt routine. Beyond that, the first half works well, capped off by an unpredictable interval twist. There are also some dialogues explaining the role and powers of a district collector, and Burra Sai Madhav's writing truly shines here. It's reminiscent of that iconic scene in Rakhi where NTR passionately explains the importance of Indian Railways. Post-interval, the flashback sequence of Appanna's character is a major highlight. This is where vintage Shankar resurfaces, and Ram Charan delivers a stellar performance.nnHowever, after this flashback, the second half becomes somewhat predictable. The political drama echoes Tamil Nadu's election dynamics, drawing parallels to the DMK and Anna DMK parties. Unfortunately, the writing falters here, lacking the freshness or impact of the first half. I suspect many viewers might find the latter portion underwhelming.nnIn terms of performances, Ram Charan gets plenty of scope to explore various shades, and he does a commendable job. Personally, I preferred his look with a beard-it suits him better. Surya performs well but veers into overacting in a few scenes. It was refreshing to see Srikanth in this role, and he did justice to it. The heroine, sadly, doesn't get much screen time or substance, while the rest of the cast delivered solid performances. Thaman's music is a notable positive, offering some refreshing compositions that enhance the film in many parts.nnOverall, Game Changer is worth watching for its strong first half and the flashback episodes. However, the routine and predictable second half may dampen its box-office prospects.

The film cleverly blends humor and heart, exploring themes of family, love, and personal growth. Plaza delivers a standout performance, infusing her older self with both cynicism and wisdom. The chemistry between Plaza and the young actress playing Elliott is palpable, creating a believable and engaging dynamic.nnWhile some may find the premise far-fetched, the film's grounded approach and relatable characters make it easy to suspend disbelief. The humor is witty and often unexpected, and the emotional moments are genuine and touching.nnOverall, "My Old Ass" is a refreshing and entertaining film that offers a unique perspective on the complexities of growing up. It's a must-see for fans of coming-of-age stories and anyone who enjoys a good laugh with a side of heartfelt reflection.

Absolutely secondary movie. A little echo of the first one. The ONLY positive thing is that this time they actually allowed hispanic actors to play central roles. Pedro and Paul delivered amazing performances, but these two couldnt pull this movie up from the secondary level.nnBiggest weakness of this movie is that it is written, created, directed, acted - entirely by men and about men. Women are allowed 2-3 roles as wives and mothers. There are also some (very few) servants and concubines, thank you very much. The whole thing is loud and flat, full of testosterone dreams and completely unwatchable.nnMescal humanizes this nonsence a lot, the admiration for his acting kept me in front of the screen, he was a pure gold of this movie, but the rest - just sad. When at the end they showed a wheat field again - I couldnt hold the laughter. Yes, why searching for new ways, when you can just use the good old pieces?!

I was really looking forward to "Inglourious Basterds" given all the hype surrounding it and Brad Pitt's involvement, but I must say, I was left terribly disappointed. The movie tries hard to blend dark humor with intense drama, but it ultimately falls flat.nnFirst off, the pacing is all over the place. Some scenes drag on for what feels like an eternity while others feel rushed and disjointed. It's like Quentin Tarantino couldn't decide if he wanted to tell a serious story or just throw in random quips and violence for shock value.nnBrad Pitt's performance as Lt. Aldo Raine comes across as cartoonish rather than compelling. His character feels more like a caricature than a fully fleshed-out individual, which detracts from any real emotional engagement with the story.nnAdditionally, the film's portrayal of history is problematic at best. While Tarantino's alternate take on WWII could have been an interesting concept, it often feels disrespectful rather than thought-provoking. The glorification of violence in this context is unsettling and leaves you wondering what message is truly being conveyed.nnVisually stunning? Sure! But substance matters too, and sadly this film lacks depth. What could have been a gripping narrative about revenge becomes a convoluted mess that overstays its welcome.nnIn summary, "Inglourious Basterds" did not live up to its reputation for me-it felt more like style over substance without delivering anything meaningful or memorable in return. Save your time; there are far better films out there that handle their themes with more care and respect.

I just watched "My Odd Ass" and I'm still reeling from the experience. This film is a masterclass in embracing the unconventional and celebrating the beauty of imperfection.nnThe storytelling is bold, fearless, and unapologetic, tackling themes that are often swept under the rug. The characters are multidimensional and relatable, with flaws and quirks that make them feel endearingly human.nnThe cinematography is stunning, with a vibrant color palette that adds to the film's offbeat charm. The pacing is well-balanced, oscillating between moments of poignant introspection and laugh-out-loud humor.nnWhat truly sets "My Odd Ass" apart, however, is its unwavering commitment to individuality. This film is an ode to the misfits, the outcasts, and the eccentrics who refuse to be bound by societal norms.nnOverall, "My Odd Ass" is a cinematic gem that will resonate with anyone who's ever felt like they don't quite fit in. It's a powerful reminder that our quirks and flaws are what make us unique, and that embracing our true selves is the key to finding true happiness.

This drama was so intense from the start. I loved the chemistry between Heejo and Saeon from the start, and the way they both started opening up to each other and fighting and protecting each other was just so satisfying to watch.nnThe ending was also great in my opinion, and I know there were some mistranslations so I hope those are cleared up soon. This is definitely a must watch drama if you love the marriage of convenience trope and my wife type of scenes.nnThe behind the scenes of the leads also deserves to be talked about because those were just so cute and seeing the leads bring out their characters to life was so interesting to see. I can't wait to watch their other dramas and I hope we get to see them work together again in the future.

column3: "RuPaul's Drag Race" (2009) {Drag Queens Got Talent - Part 2 (#17.2)}
column4: This episode was not bad, it's simply that the last episode was better and had more energy. This episode had a sleep walking quality to it.nnThe runway had a fun theme but it seemed like most queens phoned it in and delivered some nice but uninspired looks. With an exception of Crystal, Lexi, Lana, Lucky, Lydia and Suzie.nnThe lip sync to Doechii's "Alter Ego" was pretty good. The lip sync to Ariana's "Yes, And?" was a waste of a very good lip sync song.nnThe most dissapointing part of the episode was the overabundance of original track performances. With an exception of Hormona, who did a terrible stand up performance, every queen this episode did a original song and aside from Lexi Love were largely a bore.nnThe nail in the coffin was the Badonka Dunk twist. It felt like an open way to save Homona who has an unfinished storyline and is central to the story of the season.nnThat being said though, the episode was still entertaining. While it did get grating at a certain point watching the same kind of performance over and over again. The performances were largely never truly boring.

One of my all time favorite drama now! The chemistry between the leads and the romance was so good. The dynamics between all the characters were also so interesting to watch. The behind the scenes were absolutely adorable to watch. I really loved the plot too and even though the ending felt rush and many people were disappointed with it, the drama was still a thriller and melodrama type of series so the way it ended didn't irritate me in the least. I wish we could've gotten 1-2 episodes more, though, to wrap it up more properly but I'll take what I can get. I will definitely be rewatching it again soon!

Enjoy thisnI thought it was a comedy about everyone fighting for their grandma's fortune involving guns, but it ended up being an honest picture of a family's journey through the death of a dying grandmother and has a deep meaning thst makes family members bond in al ways. Discovering differing dynamics of each sibling and the choices parents have to make to make sure their kids are well looked after long after their passing. The main subject is so relatable that it just awakens your heart and soul. There was no dry eye in the room, and I walked out, wanting to call my guadian and almostly cried.

Sonu Sood's directorial debut, Fateh, is an action flick that delivers on the action front but suffers from a tiring, uninteresting, and predictable screenplay. The film incorporates many elements reminiscent of movies like Equalizer and Animal. While the action choreography stands out, the blood CGI is noticeably poor. The camerawork is good, but the editing turns out to be bad. The songs are decent, and although the background score is good, it seems to be misplaced in many scenes, failing to elevate the intended moments. The film tries hard to be a "cool" and invincible spectacle where a man goes on a killing spree, but it ends up feeling very wannabe.nnSonu Sood gives his all to the role and looks convincing in the action sequences. Jacqueline's character and subplot feel very clich√©. Naseeruddin Shah is wasted, while Vijay Raaz steals the show with his stellar dialogue delivery, standing out as the most memorable part of the film. The rest of the supporting cast is just average. Hans Zimmer's "To the Moon" stands out. There comes a time in second half, when the film just becomes tiring and emotionless. Overall, the film deserved a betternscreenplay and pacing to support its action set pieces. Good Action, Below average film!nnOVERALL - 2/5.

Superman, Batman and Wonder Women turned into monkeys what more can you want lol. But on a serious note great Episode it introduced me to a DC character called Deadman who I never heard about. Story is entertaining. After his master is killed Deadman wants revenge and seeks the Justice League help to do it. Also I did not expect that ending I knew grodd was crazy but c'mon man that was his plan for world domination it sucked. So luthor had to shoot him to knock him out and take over the Legion Of Doom. I feel like stuff is about to get very serious with luthor now in charge. Monkey see monkey do.

I was blown away by this film, both visually and aurally. I swear I've never heard so many dirty words in my life. And I've never watched a war movie that uses rock and roll music as its soundtrack, as this one does. And I love all the soundtracks.nnI found it very wired the first time I saw it, but I began to find it so intriguing the second time that I watched it several times. The first half is incredibly phenomenal! So many scenes are iconic! And the second half affords much food for thought. Whether it's the fact that the Joker wears a peace button on his uniform and writes "Born to kill" on his helmet, believing that men are of duality, or that the banner reads "First to go, last to know. We will defend to the death your right to be misinformed", this half has a sobering taste of irony. Of course, the whole film is full of irony and elements of brainwashing. I think Kubrick was suggesting that the Big tried to convince the public of what it wanted them to believe, by trickery or swindle. Wars dehumanize people and plunge them into a world of h**l.nnBy the way, many of the shots in this film are beautifully photographed. And the final scene is equally impressive.

The film Oppenheimer is a mystery to me; here is a movie just over three hours in length, yet there are no gunshots, no car chases, no fist fights, rarely does anyone swear, and we don't actually see atomic bombs being dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. There is some brief sex in it, but the two people involved don't seem to be enjoying themselves. We're left with a tremendous amount of dialogue and very little action.nnDon't get me wrong, I've been guilty of a shortened attention span too .I believe superhero films definitely have their place toonnRobert Oppenheimer is the hero of this story, and he has been tasked with overseeing the infamous Manhattan Project's Los Alamos lab in New Mexico during World War II. His team's mission is to build the world's first atomic bomb before the Germans do. But make no mistake-this is Oppenheimer's story: every scene is about Oppenheimer, his decisions, and the repercussions of those decisions that will haunt him for the rest of his life.

This movie is impressively written, with a strong theme that's both engaging and accessible. Its simplicity and light-hearted tone make it easy to enjoy. However, the story feels somewhat outdated. The central characters-a sex podcaster and a rabbi-are an interesting, if unconventional, match. But while their lives are meant to feel scandalous and relatable, they're portrayed living in luxurious multi-million-dollar homes, which seems unrealistic given their jobs. It's hard to connect with their 'problems' when most of us are dealing with far more grounded realities, like small apartments and stressful jobs. It feels out of touch with everyday life.nnHelpful.

It is really boring. I thought it would be a simple Wanda spin-off, but it ended up being another Marvel failure. The first 3 episodes I felt like there was no progress at all, the characters are very poorly developed but I decided to give it a chance.nnThe series progressed and the only good parts were when they showed the real world and not the 50's world. When I finished watching it it felt like a huge relief. Still the acting was good, but the plot and content were the opposite. If you're watching the MCU in chronological order I recommend skipping this miniseries and looking for a summary of it on Youtube. Also I can't believe how many people liked this.nnI'm just giving my personal opinion, if you don't like it, good for you.

This film pulls at your heartstrings, evoking a sense of nostalgia and sentimentality for everyone in the family. It strives to maintain a feel-good atmosphere without delving too deeply into melodrama or stress. With a strong Japanese drama influence, the mood and tone set by the score give the film a charming and pleasant feel, not overly sad. While some attempts at comedic relief may feel a bitnunnecessary, overall, it strikes a balance that prevents it fromnplunging into overwhelming sadness. Nevertheless, there are stillplenty of scenes that will bring tears to your eyes.it is a very good movie.

The episode opening with the Squid Game was camp and a great watch. (Espescially the call backs to past contestants and even the running joke of the clown).nnThe talent show was entertaining enough with certain queens such as Lydia, Lucky and Suzie providing the most entertaining and one of a kind performances.nnHowever there is the boring problem of the lip sync number. While Jewels had enough in her performance to be entertaining. Joella showed off how lackluster those performances can be.nnThe runway was quite nice though. Jewels, Lana, Lexi, and Kori were great. Onya got to show off some of her personality to Ru.nnKaty Perry as the premier guest judge makes a lot of sense. She's a well known pop star with a large gay fanbase. She was entertaining and gelled well enough with the queens. Her giving notes to queens in untucked...less good espescially when we've already seen a premier guest judge do the same thing and better.nnHer being there to promote her album and causing the first lip sync to be to "Woman's World" though? Unforgivable and is the reason this episode gets a 9/10.

How simple and beautiful this movie isüòç, you will definitely remember your sweetest soul grandmother- the way she holds your hand while walking, the way she asked you "have you eaten", the voice, the presence, the room filled with old photography, the cooking, watching shows/movies with her. Everything. Mss you Patti.as much as I want to rewatch it, I cannot. There are scene that are just so heart wrenching it's too painful. Never cried for this movie this much, and my mother always tell us she never hade a chance to do this to her grandma, she died abruptly while she was still in school, but we used to sleep together.

Where do I begin? First of all, this show introduced me to a whole different aspect of indigenous Mexican culture that I never knew about. I find indigenous culture to be so beautiful and fascinating, yet there's a sense of superiority with the people of Spanish descent in Mexico, including in my family, so I don't have as much knowledge or experience. It's a shame because indigenous culture is so much more free, colorful, and interesting!! Also, sexuality and gender identity was always so fluid in so many civilizations throughout history, until the rise of Catholicism where it was seen as "unholy," even though God the Father and God the Son use He/Him but God the Holy Spirit uses She/Her so the Holy Trinity Itself is gender fluid... but I digress. My point is, it's a shame that this specific story has to exist the way it does in this world we live in, and that the culture and the people represented are so unknown and taboo, but it's also amazing that it exists and that we get to see it and learn from it.nnAnyways, there is a difference between learning about a culture, and meeting the souls of people within one. Manuelito was so authentic, so confident, and so pure. So was Solange, and all of the other muxes. They made life so much brighter, so much more colorful, so much fun!nnBut although they are the context, this isn't a story about muxes; this is a story about the relationship between Manuelito (who, in fact, has always been Sicar√∫), and Erik. There are very few examples I've seen of a bond like these two (Luca is one tho ;)). The actors were just brilliant!! I was so absorbed in how their friendship was developing in the first four episodes, my heart was beating along with theirs. They had such a pure connection and bond, where it seemed the only people they could truly be themselves around was each other, and nobody else knew them the way they knew eachother. And they became one when they made the pact in blood.nnBut then there was the tragedy of the people around them full of hate and bigotry, using their wickedness to separate them and make them suffer, because they were so scared of such pure, true love. It's the fear and self-loathing that people have within themselves that drives them to hate and shame those around them, and that fear comes from people who hated and shamed them in their past. And it's one of the reasons our world is so broken. The last five episodes were honestly gut-wrenching. Seeing how their lives developed separately, and seeing how difficult it was for them to come together again and get to know each other twenty years later. The actors of the adult versions were also brilliant!!nnI think what was so heartbreaking for me was that Erik and Sicar√∫ were soulmates, they were one, but they were then separated by a cruel world, and they had to find their place in that cruel world. My point of view might be very different from others, but your soulmate is your best friend, and a best friend is true love, and your best friend and soulmate is always worth more than a thousand lovers. Of course they found their own happiness apart from each other, but I can't help but think how differently things would have turned out if Erik's dad hadn't called Manuelito's dad, and if they would've stayed together. But alas, that wasn't their destiny in this world. And my heart breaks to see that pure and true connection broken and lost, even if it is regained in a different way at a different time. Nothing else was as pure or as true. It hurts to think about what might have been.nnSeriously, 10/10, an absolute masterpiece that will make you think and break your heart.

They don't make movies like this anymore, either! That praise is not exclusive to just Top Gun this year. Decision to Leave is a hypnotic slow burn neo-noir crime story from legendary Korean filmmaker Park Chan-wook. My love for Park's work is well established in this space, as Oldboy is one of my favorite films of all time and when Bong Joon Ho took home Best Director and Best Picture Oscars in 2020 for Parasite, I was gleeful, but quick to remind that he still wasn't Korea's best filmmaker.nnDecision to Leave is the special kind of film that sublimates the information it relays to you. We see more than what we are shown. The film is seductive, despite depicting very little sex or skin. It is morbid despite showing very little gore or violence. Which is perfect because a great deal of this film is more about what we feel versus what we perceive. How our emotions manipulate our senses and disguise otherwise clear truths.nnDecision to Leave is considered a neo-noir mostly on the back of its inventive and modern cinematography, but this is firmly nestled within conventional noir. It's bleak and pessimistic, drenched through with brooding, the Femme Fatale is beguiling and menacing in equal measure, and it's got more twists than a silly straw. What is unique is that our hero detective is more beholden to his integrity than most in the genre, which unfortunately for him becomes his Achilles heel. The concessions he makes in the name of love, or obsession, or both (as the film beautifully illustrates how intertwined the two are), are a cost too great for him to bear.nnDecision to Leave would be a much lesser movie in any less capable hands because it is not about its plot. To shoot this movie as written without the subtext would make it altogether forgettable if not unrealistic and silly. The plot points are somewhat contrived, but they are there as a vessel of greater work being done. The investigations of the story are secondary to the investigation the film makes into our own psyches.nnWhat do we truly desire and why?nnWhen do we know when we are loved?nnWhere, and how, does an acquaintance pass into a more substantial object of affection in our lives? How do we reconcile such a person being at odds with everything we hold sacred and how can we forgive ourselves for putting ourselves in that position?nnGentle suggestions to these questions are posited but no answers are eminent when watching Decision to Leave, but that doesn't make them any less pertinent. That this film was snubbed for Best Foreign Film at the Oscars will be perhaps the most confounding and aggravating miss of the entire ceremony. My favorite foreign film of the year.

Okay take Selling Sunset, not great a fun "plot" to see the lifestyles of LA people who are notoriously fake and emotionally unavailable. All about the glitz glam and showing homes. And then since the characters are in this world they have small problems of contrived and interpersonal drama about she said this she said that and "I'm richer than you" type of stuff.nnTHIS IS (sort of) NOT THAT.nnThere are glimmers of an actual plot! With more meaningful stakes about who these women are as produced characters.nnSelling a listing in Selling Sunset is "come with me on my listing" and "X was talking shit."nnSelling a listing in Selling the City is "come with me on my listing" and "X was talking shit." AND "Let's make it as a team selling real estate and what does that look like and what does our success mean to us"nnA little more on the plot.nnA team of female realtors aspiring to be more successful are lead by their successful boss to become even more professionally successful. This professional success is deeply tied to their sense of self worth and social capital amongst their peers.nnThey are met with doubt and resistance from more established people and women in the field. Multiple dynamics come into play as some of the doubt and resistance comes from allies and colleagues of the boss.nnThis set up gives a deeper and richer show because of the multiple dynamics: colleague to colleague, mentor to mentee, boss to employees, friend to friend, coworker to coworker.nnYes, its popcorn TV. No, its not a Jane Austen novel.

Yorgos Lanthimos' Poor Things is a Frankenstein story of sorts that follows the life of Bella, a dead woman reanimated with the brain of a child, as she sets out to explore the world and herself. It sets its sights on sexual liberation and takes to task the long-known but seldom discussed infatuation of men with infantile women. It explores how virginal virtue is an entrenched, inherently patriarchal device and the dexterous footing it requires of women to navigate their sexual independence without being considered morally repugnant... Did I mention it is unquestionably the funniest film of the year?nnIt takes these and several other heavy concepts and makes something that never considers itself precious. In Poor Things, a valid and prescient argument is never a good enough reason to pass up a good dick joke. Yorgos Lanthimos is one of my favorite filmmakers for this reason. His last film, The Favourite, topped my year end list in 2018. Both films tackle high concept with gamut-running humor, from the transcendent to the toilet and back again.nnEmma Stone is superb in giving us her best performance yet, and maybe the best of the entire year. We see Bella remain, largely, physically unchanged (outside of her literally toddling in the first part of the film), but grow exponentially cognitively and emotionally. Mark Ruffalo gives my favorite supporting turn of the year as the scoundrel bent on corrupting Bella, only to find himself unequal to the task. I am not exaggerating when I say I can't remember a single line he delivered that didn't at least draw a chuckle from me. He's one of the most hilariously deplorable characters in recent memory.nnThe production design, sets, costumes and visual effects create one of the most sumptuous visual experiences of the year. They are all superlative and could each win awards this season. The score is superb, and every frame of the movie is elegantly and exhaustingly detailed. It's prestige filmmaking for the dreggs, and it is perfect because of it.nnThis is the first book adaptation Lanthimos has ever made into film, which only surprised me because it feels like such a Lanthimos film. Like the Frankenstein concept the film borrows from, sometimes unfamiliar and unrelated material must come together to create something truly miraculous. Even with the difficult and potentially controversial subject matter, Poor Things is absolutely Lanthimos' most accessible film to date, and possibly his best. This was the most fun I had all year with a movie and simply needs to be experienced to be appreciated.

"Hot Chocolate" is a short film that is a 'Soundie'...an early sort of music video that was played on specially built jukeboxes from 1940-1947. These jukeboxers were unusual because they not only played music but video...like music videos of the modern era. And, if you are curious about this an other soundies, you might want to buy yourself a copy of "Soundies the Ultimate Collection"...a 4 disc set of about 200 of these films.nnIn this Soundie, Duke Ellington and His Orchestra play for a group called "Whitey's Lindy Hoppers". The Lindy Hop, by the way, was a dance much like the Jitterbug...very athletic and loved by the young (adults mostly saw this type of dancing as a sign of the coming apocalypse!). This Soundie is a bit unusual in that Basie credits one of his featured performers by name...folks you likely have never heard of and it might be one of the only times you can see and hear them.nnThe star of this one clearly are these amazing dancers. I doubt if I ever could have danced this well and this athletically and they are pretty amazing to watch....so much so that you barely notice the music!

"Fateh" Falls FlatnnI walked into "Fateh" expecting an action-packed ride, especially with Sonu Sood at the helm. Unfortunately, the movie failed to deliver.nnThe direction was subpar, but what really let me down was the uninspiring action sequences. Sonu Sood, known for his action chops, couldn't elevate the dull and unengaging fight scenes.nnTo make matters worse, the movie's visuals and action sequences looked more like a PC or PS game than a cinematic experience. The lack of realism and poor CGI took me out of the movie.nnOverall, "Fateh" was a disappointing watch. With better direction, action, and visuals, this could've been a memorable film.

I went to this movie with no expectations and it is not outright bad as his previous movie, Indian 2. The flashback episode is decent, the cat and mouse game between Ram and Mopidevi is engaging to some extent, interval block was interesting.nnThe movie starts with a hint in the beginning that it's a commercial entertainer supposed to be out 30 years ago. I hate having a mass fight sequence followed by an introduction song. Shankar could have used this time to establish the plot line.nnDance numbers are untimely. Can't even mention about the counless physics defying fight sequences and brainless cringe scenes. It is silly that Ram had to address his anger issues so that he can channel anger to become IPS officer.nnIt's worth watching once in OTT when it's available.

Vaiana is a sequel made only to bring viewers in theaters and gain easy money. The plot is awful as well as the new characters that are exasperating and stupid. The vilain is forgettable and the problem is that the menace he represents is not concrete at all. In the first one, their island was threatened notably because fruits became rotten. Here, there is no manifestation of the threat, it comes from nowhere. To finish, even the characters do not take it seriously. They constantly make jokes so I was never able to fear anything for Moana and her people. This movie is a failure, except the animation that is of course wonderful. I do not recommend. It adds nothing to the first one which was far far far better. We must stop giving money to Disney for lazy movies like this one or their useless live action remakes. When you look at Disney next animated movies schedule, it's only other sequels like Rapunzel 2, Zootopia 2, Frozen 3 etc. I won't go watch them in theater. In comparison, DreamWorks made The wild robot few months before Vaiaina 2 and it was astonishing. This one is the definition of a good familial animated movie, Vaiaina 2 is not.

We don't see him as the guy, hitting and shooting people: üòÇüòÇ He needs to be on romantic comedy shows or Hallmark shows. So I am following the show. It's good, but it could be great. The sex appeal the show brought, almost worked. But just not enough to overcompensate for the lack of connection with the main character.
