Nosferatu is a visually stunning homage to classic cinema, with its remarkable use of shadow techniques evoking the eerie beauty of the original Dracula film. The cinematography is a true work of art, blending light and darkness to create a haunting, dreamlike atmosphere that feels both vintage and timeless. The filmmakers clearly approached this retelling of the iconic vampire story with a deep appreciation for its gothic roots, and for the most part, their efforts pay off in delivering a chilling, atmospheric experience.nnThat said, the film is not without its flaws. One particularly strange choice was the inclusion of a sex scene between the main actress and her husband. While it seems intended to reflect her unraveling mental state, it feels out of place and unnecessary, adding confusion rather than depth to her character. The scene detracts from the mood of the film, breaking the spell of its otherwise carefully crafted tone.nnAnother missed opportunity was the underutilization of the vampire's regenerative abilities, a classic hallmark of the mythos. By failing to explore this aspect of the creature, the film strips Nosferatu of one of the most compelling elements of his menace and mystique. Additionally, the central romance feels unconvincing-it's difficult to believe that such a beautiful, vibrant young woman would find herself drawn to a grotesque and monstrous figure like Nosferatu. This disconnect weakens the emotional stakes of the story.nnWhile Nosferatu deserves praise for its artistry and reverence for the source material, its narrative missteps and odd creative choices hold it back from being a true masterpiece. It's a film that will appeal to fans of classic cinema and gothic horror, but its flaws make it less than the definitive adaptation it could have been.nnA visually brilliant but narratively uneven reimagining of a gothic classic.

So, this was what all the basement dwelling virgin star wars critics were all angry about?nn------------------------------------------------------------------nnI dislike almost all star wars and all the wankery around jedi mysticism/the force.nnFor the first time in forever, I actually enjoyed the light saber/fights in this series. They mixed in the light saber battles with some kung-fu (jedi-fu?) and actually experimented a bit and I appreciated it.nnI also enjoyed how the series portrayed the Jedi as not a universal good for the galaxy ---- dear god, can you believe it? There's some actual depth and nuance to the jedi in terms of mortality.nnThe antagonist was actually threatening and he took out a bunch of jedi ---- previous to this we would rarely see the jedi get more then a few bumps/scratches and it started to become laughable.nnI am disappointed that they will not be continuing the series because star wars desperately needs to evolve and they were on the right path even if not all of the episodes were stellar.nnI'll give it an 8 for actually having some backbone and trying something new.

When you see the phrases neo-noir or erotic thriller, read them as Giallo. Isn't that what it all is, anyway? And who thought that one day, we'd have Jim Belushi as the protagonist of a psychosexual murder movie?nnDirector Andy Wolk would one day make The Christmas Shoes, but for now, he's putting this together from a script by Jim Piddock, who has been in a lot of Christopher Guest's films as an actor but wrote this and two episodes of Silk Stalkings before being the writer of Tooth Fairy.nnBelushi is Jack Dobson, a Palm Beach homicide cop who we initially find flat on his back, dead from a gunshot wound to the chest. His narration takes us back to one evening that shows off just how smooth Jack is, defending a waitress from a rude customer and then immediately taking her back to his place, where he plays some smooth jazz before waking her up to coffee in bed. This movie wants you to know two things: Belushi *****. And Belushi ***** good.nnAlong with his partner, Detective Steve Frayn (Tony Goldwyn), Jack is trying to figure out who is sending him lipstick-sealed threats. Is it meant for his brother Michael (William Russ), who is running for office? And is Jack so on the make that he's willing to potentially sleep with his brother's wife, Susan (Victoria Bass), his partner's wife, Beth (Faye Grant), and definitely get horizontal and Belushi-sweaty with femme fatale Ellen Schofield (Lorraine Bracco)? This movie also wants you to know that every old man in Palm Beach has a filthy mouth, and they all have something to say about how badly they want to schtup Ellen, even if she rode her last husband into a heart attack.nnEllen also sleeps with Steve, even though Steve loves his wife. Everybody is getting with everybody in Palm Beach, which may as well be Rome. Women connected to Jack keep dying, their faces covered with lipstick - yay, Traces of Red! - which his brother reveals is something his first-grade teacher used to do to him before she would rape him. This is a wild departure for the Giallo, not just making its male protagonist vulnerable but seemingly switching him to the villain.nnOr maybe not.nnDespite being shot by his partner - it looked like he was about to choke out Steve's wife - it's soon revealed that the big brother was the one doing all the killing. And hey! There's Belushi, looking like he just smoked one of his weed strains like Oreoz - they're from the streets - or Rewrite. His brother grabs his gun and blows his brains out, ending on a downer note.nnDespite being in theaters for a few days, this did big business on home video. Maybe it's because Belushi wore all his own ties, and people recognized him not just as a fuckable prince of a man but as a sartorial style icon. You know, we should be nicer to him. And by that, I should be nicer to him. For all the horrible things on Twitter, I've learned that he's a pretty chill person - growing all that weed will do that - and the more I think about it, the more good roles in movies by great directors he's been in. He may need a Tarantino casting intervention so that he can complete this late-career reevaluation.nnSo yeah. Belushi in a Giallo, complete with an investigation into a misworking printer and trying to figure out a shade of lipstick and a certain perfume. Who knew?

You have: 1. The blonde bimbos 2. The bitchy mean girlboss and 3. The damsel in distress single mothernnForget the gross inaccuracies, disjointed, empty storylines, and unrealistic dialogue. What the hell is with these female characters! These are so outdated and insulting it's laughable. This show desperately needed a technical/industry consultant, but at this point I would have been happy if one female was involved in the conception of this show because these are not real or relatable characters to anyone.nnAlso why do I feel like I'm watching three different shows all at once sloppily spliced together by a Red Clay Strays song.

I really enjoyed this drama! Good chemistry, nice mystery to unsolve, very romantic, love intrest fell in love with main character big time but for some reason kept pretending he wasnt - most likely to avoid rejection. They werent honest with each other from the start but ended up finally opening up. Series has a psychotic villan, one of those you love to hate which is a plus. The series is sexy at times, gives off a slight bdsm vibes, with him being authoritarian and her being very submissive. Some moments didnt make sense but overall the series was quite good and in my opinion warth watching.

It was the chance to create something legendary. It was like watching a 90s or 2000s series like Xena or Hercules, which surpass this movie. What a disaster to ruin a story. The shots, the dialogues, a coliseum with water??? So bad. If you look at the shots and the colors, it's like watching a series, not something classic with quality-it's jarring how it takes you out of the experience. The performances are weak; the only notable one is Denzel's. Without him, you wouldn't be able to sit through it. I give it 4 stars for the effort.nnI wrote this review while watching the movie, with no regrets about missing the dialogues.

A film comes along once in a while, capturing the hearts of the viewers but at the same time breaking all the norms to leave a permanent mark on the art of filmmaking. Game Changer is one of them. It is a film with a gripping narrative, with great visuals and performances that leave one emotionally drained. It's not just a film; it's an experience, a rollercoaster of emotions and ideas, long after the credits roll.nnA Story That Resonates DeeplynThe plot of Game Changer is a masterstroke of storytelling. It intertwines themes of hope, resilience, and the human spirit in a way that feels both timeless and relevant. The narrative follows a protagonist who, against all odds, embarks on a transformative journey that tests their character and beliefs. What elevates this film is its ability to attain a delicate balance between fantastic, universal themes and very intimate, personal moments. Whether it's the battle against social expectations or emotional battles with oneself, the film connects on an emotionally rich level with the audience.nnThe screenplay is sharp, smart, and layered with nuance. Every scene is crafted to great precision, every line of dialogue purposeful, to fit the entire story together at breakneck pace. It's a thrilling ride, yet somehow room is given for introspection. Each twist and turn is unpredictable yet felt as if deserved, which makes the impact much higher. You end up thinking beyond the film that one needs to about one's life and choices.nnPerformance Elevating the FilmnThe performances of Game Changer are nothing but spectacular. The lead actor did a great job in portraying such a complex multi-dimensional character and is award-worthy. Their performance could deliver a wide array of emotions that are subtle yet authentic, pulling you into the story and making you root for the journey.nnThe supporting cast shines just as much, giving substance and richness to the film. Be it in the antagonist where you can resonate with their goals, or it could be with the mentor whose wisdom guides throughout, every individual is well-developed in this film, making them believeable. Some chemistry between characters brings a massive amount of strength to the drama of the plot, and consequently, to all climactic instances of the movie.nnVisual Technical BrilliancenThe Game Changer is a visually scrumptious film. Every single frame has the beauty of its emotive and aesthetic effect maximally crafted. Using color, light, and a masterful series of camera angles creates a kind of mood that justifies atmosphere for the kind of story meant to be said. Visual symbolisms woven around the film suggest hidden meanings behind each shot.nnEven sound design and the score are marvelous, with beautiful, haunting melodies enriching all these scenes for emotions. In one moment of stunning action scenes or quiet reflections, the world in Game Changer completely holds you up with its immersive soundscape.nnIt is deep because it offers and explores real-life themes in very profound, emotional ways:. It is a movie that delves into questions about identity, purpose, and the courage it takes to defy the status quo. The film challenges viewers to think critically about the world around them and their role within it. It's a story that inspires change-not just in its characters but also in its audience. Few films manage to achieve this level of impact, making Game Changer a rare and invaluable work of art.nnA Truly Universal AppealnThis is one of the magical aspects of Game Changer : it's a movie that appeals to everybody; it's across genres and generations. From thought-provoking dramatics to stunning visuals and gripping narratives, this movie checks all the boxes. It's one of those films that makes people debate and question everything, more so bringing people together. This is a testament to its cultural and artistic significance.nnConclusion: A Must-Watch MasterpiecenGame Changer is more than just a movie. It can be referred to as a powerful narrative. It challenges, inspires, and entertains the individual equally, which makes it a film that everyone must watch. It is a rare commodity in cinema today where one finds a movie mastering all fronts in filmmaking. Game Changer can be said to have done that effortlessly.nnFor those of you looking to watch a movie that will be out of the ordinary, to be frank, this film doesn't do the trick but instead shatters all expectations and exceeds them; Game Changer, simply put, is a movie with 10 stars.

Can you really doubt the authenticity of this movie. Let's not kid ourselves we all have darkness inside us and those of us who say they don't are kidding themselves some just do a better job of hiding it.nnI am in trauma recovery and i will be the first to tell you learning why you are a narccissist or a manipulator or even improperly sexualized are all not easy questions to answer.nnLet me 1st say it is the journey we make to take a natural path filled with experience to understand ourselves or gain a spiritual awareness, if you have to call it insight go ahead, most believe you don't learn unless...

This is a beautiful movie it is funny as wellnI love it.nnI will recommend to others to also enjoy itnMy old ass will not get old to me because it is very nicenBut i also feel alot was lost.nnAll in all give it up you are doing a great job to make sure we're entertained and making sure we're not board.nnIt is action and funny at the same timenHave not watched the full movie yet but from the trailer it will be beautiful and and funny to watch.nnWe'll recommend people to watch it as well so that we can enjoy the funny together and laughnnMy old ass is one of the beautiful and nice comedy I have seen.

The movie is entertaining for sure. Allu Arjun and all the other actors have done justice to the role. The pace and action sequences are good.nnThe first movie focused on his rise from nobody to a big red sandalwood mafia. His swag, his confidence and his arrogance was highlight of it. And the second part doesn't disappoint in that aspect.nnThe excellent screenplay helps to hide a major flaw in the movie, which is storyline going away from the major theme. The movie in the middle suddenly goes into the conflict within family and his lack of fathers name. Instead of developing the story in the direction of him as a Sandalwood mafia. There is less of duel and cat and mouse game which was the highlight of the previous part.nnIt starts with that theme and remains till the middle but suddenly takes detour into his relationship with the relatives on his biological father.nnThe action scenes are quite over the top and physics defying and sometimes look silly instead of entertaining.nnSo its definitely one time watch for sure.

This show is my fav show of all time,and with good reason.the 4th and 6th season of this show is one of the best pieces of media i have ever layed my eyes upon.such a well acted masterpiece.my two fav characters are by far tyrian and jon snow.tyrian is such a well written character and such a sinister mastermind that it is impossible not to like him.but jon snoww i prefer more,again such a well written character(apart from the 8th season)and is so likeable and relatable.how he leaves the wall and becomes the king in the north is such a awesome piece of character development."my watch has ended"is such a cold line that jon says and when i first watched it i had to replay it a couple times because it gave mengoosebumps every time.though those are my fav characters there are still some amazing arcs in this show,such as jamie lannisters,daenarys targaryen and little finger .pretty much all characters in the show are so well written all though most of the character's development is ruined in the 8th season,they are still amazing characters.it is because of this show that i am now realising that i have a liking of mid evil music. The soundtrack is just breath taking and is so well composed.i'm sure most people can agree that a big stand out of the show is the swift turn of events for example:ned starks death,the red wedding.this is why this show sticks out to me so much than others because no other show would have the guts and courage to kill off the main character that everyone found a liking to.don't get me started on jon snows so called death,although i was aware that he lived on till the end of the show i was still very shocked.the shows landscapes and visuals are beautiful,like the architecture of kings landing and the north.the costume designer does a great job in this series and greatly designs the white walkers and some costumes for daenarys and jon snoww. Battle of the bastards is the main stand out in action from this show,so much rage as a viewer was built up to that fight and you couldn't help but want jon to take ramsay's head off.such a well choreographed fight with some beautiful shots.the build up to the battle of the white walkers is so well done,and each season kept getting you more and more excited to see what the final battle would be like.each season building you up with more anticipation,and then the 8th season came.the dialogue of this show amazing rich and powerful.which is another reason that it is my number show of all time.üòÇnnsome negatives i have about this show are:nthe whole 8th seasonnnthe disappointing battle between the white walkers,couldn't see anythingnnmost of the arcs being ruined,for example jaime lannister going back to cercei after he tried to move on,once again lazy writing.nnLazy and rushed writing so that they could quickly finish the show off because they were to inpatient to wait for the writer of the books to finish.

A heartfelt drama that really tugs at the heartstrings. It stars Susan Sarandon as Jackie, a terminally ill mother navigating her complex emotions as she faces the prospect of her ex-husband's new girlfriend, Isabel, played by Julia Roberts, stepping in as a mother figure to her kids. The dynamics are super relatable, tackling themes of love, loss, and what it truly means to be a mother, whether by birth or by choice. Sarandon brings a raw vulnerability to her role, while Roberts balances humor and earnestness beautifully. You find yourself rooting for both women as they navigate their roles in the kids' lives, and it's a rollercoaster of emotions for sure. The movie has its tear-jerking moments, but it also offers some light-hearted scenes that keep it from feeling too heavy. If you're in the mood for a film that captures the complexities of motherhood and family relationships with heart and honesty, it is definitely worth a watch.

I admit, when this movie was being advertised just about two years ago I told myself I had zero interest in seeing it. And I made no effort to see it. Until today when my wife and I were looking for something to stream.nnNow I can confidently say "This movie is a lot better than I thought it would be" and that is always a welcome surprise. A bonus is that it was inspired by a true story of four elderly Tom Brady fans going to Superbowl 51 in Houston (where we happen to live for the past 38 years).nnThe gist of the story is, these four friends call themselves "80 For Brady" because most of them are over 80 and all of them are big Brady fans and Patriots fans. They even have special jerseys they wear when watching games on TV, all with number 12 on them.nnIt is 2017 and the Superbowl 51 in Houston is coming up. Two local radio jockeys have a contest, the best story from the fans will win four tickets to the game. A few days later one of the ladies produces four tickets and they are off.nnPart of the humor here is that not everything goes smoothly. But the four veteran actresses are in fine form and a fantasy conclusion to the game, which required the Patriots to come back from a big deficit, is entertaining. Actual NFL footage from that game is used, and several Patriots players, including Brady and Gronk, are characters in the locker-room after the game. In fact Brady was the producer for the movie.nnGood entertainment, inspired by real people and real events, what's not to like?

The biggest surprise was that I had never heard of Cabrini. Her impact on the world must be told.nnCabrini is a breathtaking cinematic triumph that brings to life the inspiring story of Saint Frances Xavier Cabrini, the first U. S. citizen to be canonized as a saint. Directed with passion and finesse, the film masterfully captures the indomitable spirit and unwavering faith of Mother Cabrini as she overcomes incredible odds to champion the rights of immigrants and the underprivileged.nnThe storytelling is gripping, blending emotional depth with historical authenticity. Each scene is meticulously crafted, immersing the audience in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The cinematography is visually stunning, with rich, vibrant tones that contrast beautifully with the film's moments of hardship and resilience.nnThe cast delivers exceptional performances, with the lead actress portraying Mother Cabrini with profound grace, strength, and humanity. Her nuanced performance draws viewers into the heart of Cabrini's mission, making her struggles and triumphs feel deeply personal. Supporting characters are equally compelling, adding layers of complexity to the narrative. The score deserves special mention for its evocative melodies that enhance every moment, from Cabrini's quiet reflections to her most triumphant victories. The music seamlessly weaves into the fabric of the film, heightening its emotional resonance.nnCabrini is more than a film; it's a celebration of perseverance, compassion, and the enduring power of faith. It's a story that resonates deeply in today's world, reminding us of the importance of kindness, courage, and selflessness. A must-watch for audiences of all backgrounds, Cabrini is both a spiritual and cinematic masterpiece that will leave you inspired long after the credits roll.

*This review only contains spoilers for the first episode, read at your own discretion*nnWhen I watched the first game, it just felt downright unfair, there was a team with just women and maybe a few men, who didn't look very strong. Not shockingly, they lost. Of course all of the gym bros and somewhat athletic women get into one massive group. The game is when you have to split into groups of 400 and pull a 10,000lb ball. I don't care if they get $2,000 in prize money (after they are eliminated), it would be more fair if Jimmy or the producers just made the teams equally so there is a (somewhat) even amount of boys and girls on a team or just equally physically capable.nnAnd for the games in general, they all feel incredibly luck-based and are just downright unoriginal, the one with the brief cases is somewhat cognitive based, but you really need the endurance and speed to get to the right briefcase in a timely manner. Which can keep the physically challenged individuals away from having a chance of choosing the right one, so for them it is heavily luck-based.nnAs for the third game, flags are placed in a arena and the number of flags will increase each round but so will the amount of players. Now sure there might be some strategy in this (like when to go), but overall it's a speed based game that focuses too much on physical based challeges and is just unfair. Biologically speaking, (hate to be that kind of person), but men are just way more physically capable than women which already puts women at an *unfair* disadvantage.nnThe last "game" is some sort of "trustfall"-esque game where if a member in your group quits to receive a massive cash prize *$5k, $50k and $1M* your whole team is out. I feel like offering 1/5 of the prize money off the bat to one "lucky" contestant is unfair while the others only get 2 grand (they recieve this amount of money when they are eliminated. This show just seems incredibly unfair in a lot of ways. And Jimmy constantly saying "woah guys this is the biggest cash prize in history" or "this is life-changing money" is incredibly annoying.nnAnd his little minions (his dodo-brained friends), randomly out of nowhere just repeat the rules to contestants as if they didn't hear the first or second time Jimmy explained the rules. I feel like they think that the working class (mostly everybody here fighting for the money) are idiots and it's quite rude to underestimate their intelligence. Which leads me into my next point, it's just incredibly sad seeing these working class people fight for a lot of money, while a rich man who has a networth of $1 billion dollars just sits back and watch these people fight for what he makes in just several hours. And in a way this just feels messed up and Jimmy knows this, but the profit he makes from the show is more important to him I guess. I feel that the contestants aren't really having a lot of fun either. Firstly, the games are incredibly bare-bones and unoriginal. This man had $100,000,000 dollars to make a (potentially) very entertaining, fun , and unique show to watch. But it just feels like a very generic and soulless show with not that much substance.nnAlso, lets just talk about controversey for a moment. Jimmy has a lot of insane allegations on his tailgate and doesn't even respond to them appropriately and Amazon (a multi-billion dollar company!!!) decided to give this man ($100M dollars to make a low-quality gameshow that is *potentially* as deceiving and fake as his youtube videos.nnThere is also a breif segment where jimmy is promoting a gambling app to his *CHILD* audience (I don't remember the name of it) gross subliminal messaging isn't cool and you just look like a manipulative scumbag. This just shows the ridiculous amount of greed he has and that he hasn't learned from his past adverts (like him including a slot machine thing where you scan a qr code on the back of a feastables bar and you have the potential to earn a Lamborghini). Who would've guessed, that it was fake *so shocking that a youtuber would lie* (not).nnAnd also the editing on this show is wild (not in a good way) in the game with the flags every time somebody grabs a flag, a stupid ding sound effect would play *EVERY SINGLE TIME* and it was annoying (I guess this was the only part that was annoying that I can remember). And Jimmy and his minions constantly shouting is giving me a headache.nnI don't even want to watch the second episode and you shouldn't either, it's probably going to be just as boring, obnoxious, and repetitive as the first one. The fact that none of the games are cognitive based just leaves the physically uncapable in the dust.nnIn conclusion, Amazon is just embarrassing themselves with this atrocity of a game show. And surprise, surprise, a vast majority of the people left are men. It's insane how this show was awarded 20+ Guinness world records, but nobody cares because Jimmy or his minions aren't as likeable as they used to be. Now they're looked down upon. This show is hot trash it won't get better from here.

same choreographer that worked on this show for the upcoming daredevil born again show.the relationship between daredevil and kingpin is outstanding and is really well dealt with in this show,they really show you how both daredevil and kingpin are at a mental and physical war with each other which is really expressed in the final battle sequence where daredevil is kicking kingpins a**.not only kingpin but the add in of the punisher,which is also now one of my fav characters because of this show and his standalone show,some of the action scenes with punisher are breath taking,like when he easily takes out all of kingpins men in prison walls.another great thing about this show is that the costumes are beautiful.even the basic black suit that daredevil wears is super cool,i actually prefer that over the red suit.bullseye is yet another outstanding part of this show,such a wel written villain and excited to see what he can bring to daredevil born again.when bullseye puts on daredevils suit in the last couple of episodes,he looks even better than matt murdock in the suit.and he is just a menacing and sinister villain.now that i look back on it a big stand out of this show place.and ask for forgiveness for his sins.you can also see matt's desperation to defend hell's kitchen when he's injured,and is so well acted out by charlie cox.nnThe casting choices for this show is insanely good,every person looks like they were born for the role that there playing (eg:punisher,kingpin).nnLastly,some of the very few negatives of this show is electra i think they could've made her a better character.nnIn my opinion daredevil is easily the best marvel show of all time and is my 3rd fav show of all time.

This and the suicide squad is the reason that i have hope in james gunn to reignite the dcu and make it great again.such great comedy,and that means a lot coming from someone who doesn't really take a liking to many comedy movies/tv shows.a memorable intro that will be past on from generation to generation.and does such a great job at introducing a new but bad ass character vigilante.throwing the justice league in at the end would have been a cool touch if they actually stuck with the same universe and didn't change to james gunn but it's understandable,the dceu was a mess.even though john cenas most famous role is playing,well john cena in the wwe,he still seems to be perfect for the role of peacemaker.overall this show is hilarious and i'm glad james gunn is keeping peacemaker alive in the new dcu.

How this movie did not win an oscar for Best Film I will never understand although watching this movie does make you understand why the USA is still so far behind in equality between the genders, colours cultures and religions.nnI am sad to know this is a true story that happen so long ago now and only in the past few years has some level of justice been acknowledged for the wrong doing here.nnThe real shock in this movie is at the end before the credits run on what happen after the movie and how long it took for justice. Over 60 yearsnAll this tragedy over a wolf whistle.nnI would have love to see DNA evidence for this crime but I figure that the way the US was at the time this would have also been covered up.nnAn amazibf performance by Danielle Deadwhyler should have won an oscar for her perfromance alone.nnA difficult watch and I had to power through because I was amazed at the blatant disregard for justice and you knew from the moment the all white jury came into the courthouse that this was not going to go their way.nnI am also amazed that many years later the two murders that killed the young Mr Till confessed to the crime as they got paid $4K for their story and nothing was done about it.nnAlso the young lady that got up on and made up a story of what did not happen to her and how the justice system allowed her to get a way with it and till this day nothing has happended to her in her part of young Mr Till murder.nnProgress for justice has to start and it should have already started. THe fact that this kinda thing did not become law until 2022 is shamful.nnI highly recomend this movie and also a movie that I would add to my personal collectionnnA tragic masterpiece.

The horrors of the Holocaust have provided the backdrop to some of the greatest films ever made, but never have the actual atrocities been pushed so far to the boundary of the picture as they are in Jonathan Glazer's profound exploration The Zone of Interest.nnIt is impossible to make a dispassionate Holocaust movie, and this certainly is not that, but the Zone of Interest concerns itself with more unconventional characters than these stories typically focus on. The film follows Rudolph Hoss, the commandant of Auschwitz, and his family as they make their dream home in the shadow of the imposing prison. The film spends almost its entirety within the confines of the home and surrounding grounds, never giving us a visual glimpse inside the neighboring house of horrors. We see lush gardens, and charming home d√©cor, all the while another, entirely different, film is playing for our ears.nnThe sounds of the murder and degradation permeate the film, while juxtaposed with pleasant visual aesthetics. This may be the single most impressive sound design in the history of film. Certainly, one of the most critical to the success and impact of its film. The Hosses are building their Third Reich Dream while one of the darkest chapters of world history is being written a mere feet away. The Zone of Interest accentuates the mundanity of evil. How we can find ourselves so entrenched in the mechanisms of death that we hardly notice it. How malice can seep into our hearts, unnoticed, through our senses.nnGlazer does this without remotely exonerating a single nazi. It is presented matter-of-factly, and without a moment of melodrama, but that serves to make it feel all the more abhorrent. The intentional indifference toward indefensibly heinous acts proved to feel more sickening than deliberate violence fueled by hate. Sandra Huller as the wife, in her second award worthy performance of the year, tries on jewelry and lavish clothing clearly ripped from Jewish prisoners' bodies and laments when they don't fit properly, giving not a notion to what was lost in them being obtained for her.nnThe exhilarating final moments give us the only glimpse we have into any humanity a single member of the family might possess. And even then, it is only presented through the self-serving lens of perceived legacy. For just a moment we see Hoss pause and contemplate his role and how he may find himself viewed in the annals of history. He then regathers himself and continues on his way. Reassured and renewed in his duties, again unmoved by what those duties entail.

Pursuing the American Dream is an ambition of almost every immigrant who manages to make it to this country's shores. Its realization can take many forms, too, depending on one's circumstances. But, as many new arrivals discover for themselves, there's no guarantee of success (or, at the very least, they may find that the journey can be more problematic than anticipated). One such story that provides the focus for this optimistic undertaking is the latest offering from writer-director Brady Corbet. The film follows the odyssey of L√°szl√≥ T√≥th (Adrien Brody), a fictional Jewish Hungarian architect who flees Europe in 1947 after being interred in a concentration camp during World War II. He initially struggles to assimilate, to re-establish his career, and to find a way to bring his wife, Erzseb√©t (Felicity Jones), to America. But, despite these sundry challenges, his fortunes change drastically when he's commissioned to design a high-profile mixed use community center with the generous support of a wealthy and powerful benefactor, a capricious, enigmatic industrialist (Guy Pearce) whose many impulsive, emotionally charged whims provide L√°szl√≥ with a firsthand introduction to the many possibilities and pitfalls tied to that elusive American Dream. In telling this story, the filmmaker explores the ups and downs associated with these themes, as well as an array of additional diverse story threads involving the protagonist's professional pursuits and personal life. These combined elements make for an engaging and intriguing tale, even if some of the story arcs and character traits are unevenly developed. That sometimes includes the nature of L√°szl√≥ himself, which is somewhat perplexing given the production's hefty 3:35:00 runtime (with an included intermission), a duration that should provide ample time for the picture to sufficiently flesh out its core narrative elements and character attributes. That shortcoming aside, though, "The Brutalist" has myriad strengths to its credit, including the fine performances of Pearce, Jones, Golden Globe Award winner Brody and a host of capable supporting players, along with its superb cinematography, stirring original score, and ably sustained pacing (quite a commendable feat for a film of this length). Admittedly, this offering's solid opening act is far superior to its back half, which tends to sag at times as it wears on, but, on balance, this Golden Globe winner for best drama and best director generally holds up well. In an awards season that has had more than its share of dismal disappointments, it's heartening to finally find a release that comes closer to approaching the standards that a film should embody to merit the kinds of accolades and attention such honorees truly deserve. It may not be perfect, but it's a far sight better than many of its other 2024 cinematic peers.

Todd Haynes' new film charters uncomfortable territory to be sure. A quasi-tabloid tale of an adult woman having sex with a thirteen year old boy, only to marry and start a family with him once out of jail, is a reasonable nonstarter for some audiences. I believe this is precisely why the film is so important.nnThese type of unfortunate stories too often never get any analysis past the "ick" factor, but digging deeper into this uncomfortable subject matter proves worthy. We get uncommon honesty and depth and insight into to the perpetrator, but more importantly we examine the lasting effects of the damage on the victim and also reveal the expansive web of secondhand victims that too often go unnoticed, on the periphery. We can access and better understand the first husband who was humiliated by the event. The children born of the inappropriate relationship as they reach their own adulthood. The friends and acquaintances about town who must cohabitate and reconcile with these people. To sweep this all aside because the material makes one justifiably queasy does a disservice the dozens effected. May December examines these discoveries head on. And that, still, is only half of the story.nnEnter Natalie Portman's character, an actress who is researching the couple in order to play the woman/mom (a fantastic Julianne Moore) character in an upcoming film about the event. This predictably forces certain latent feelings to the surface. Portman proves to be nearly as predatory as Moore as she pursues some evasive truth, unfazed by the destruction she may leave in her wake. It calls to question how much of these type of performance are about true understanding or just sensationalized parroting of real lives that suffered real consequences.nnAs interesting as that all is, it is Charles Melton as the victimized boy, now grown, that gives the most memorable performance. Through him we see the scars left behind by abuse. That those subjected to sexual assault at young ages tend to grow up faster than the rest and simultaneous somewhat not at all.nnTo explain further would be to spoil and also risk making the film seem tedious, which it emphatically is not. Yes, the themes are heavy, but the screenplay itself is very playful and there's a great deal of conviviality throughout. Its sardonic tone makes for an amusing watch, but it is deeply impactful with further examination. May December is one of the most unique films of the year, in addition to being one of the best.

What else is there to say? Have seen it 3x, and am watching it again in 2025 and moved to write.nnAll the dialogue is rich on more than one level. The script feels like David Mamet. It is plain speech, but the actors imbue it with secondary meaning and deep emotion.nnThe Actors! Clint does some interesting things. Gene Hackman is the star! He is funny, he is menace, he is human, he is dumb, he is driven and he is fantastic in every line delivery. Morgan Freeman is perfect. Saul Rubinek is perfect.nnThe women are in "whore" roles, but are very sensitive and very understandable. The cut face girl was called, 'an angel' and I bought it.nnYou can watch this movie 10x and find more emotion at another level.nnPeople give Peckinpah credit for deconstructing the Western. This movie destroys the idea of good and evil and the Western myth. Everyone is a liar and a murderer.nn"We all got it comin', Kid."

As a Greek who has studied the Greek Mythology all his life, I can say that I was disturbed by the inaccuracies of the movie. It was wrong from the start to the end. But I will point out the most important ones, for the ones who want to know: Only Aineias and his father got away of Troy free: All the others were killed, Astyanaktas, the son of Hector was thrown off the walls, and the women were taken. ACHILLEAS DID BEFORE THE FALL OF TROY, AND HE NEVER HAD A RELATIONSHIP WITH BRISIIDA!!! She was just for... you know for what. Also, Menelaos lived to reach Sparta, with Helen. Paris got killed, and you forgot the legendary: Be afraid of the Greek, even if they bring presents, from Laocoon. After that, Athena (to which the horse was dedicated) sent snakes to kill him and his family. Kassandra, who was cursed by Apollo to know the future but no one to believe her, said that Laocoon was right; no one believed her, and, when Troy fell, Agamemnon took her with him, before being killed by his wife Clitemnistra, and her... yes, Egisthos. Brisiida was never returned to Achilleas, and it was him who gave his armour to Patroclos. He never said that Greeks would not attack for 12 days. Priamos was killed horribly, after witnessing the death of his child (Politis). Then all Gods hated Greeks, and all of them got tortured, had to through all the golden stuff on the sea, etc.. You forgot about how Apollo REALLY killed many Greeks, because Hrisis told him to take revenge from the Greeks who would not give him Hrisiida (Not Brisiida). After giving her, they took Brisiida from Achilleas, and then some others took her, and so on. To conlude, Homer whould not be happy if he were here today, and you should study what was really written, aside from the movies that... lie. Anyway, I loved the graphics. That is for the three.

Low budget, independent films often need to focus on story and character development in very basic setting with minimal special effects. The latter is done quite well (thus 5 points), while "A. I. Rising" fails to deliver on the story part.nnFirst, the laughable background. Yes, the plot requires a male and an android female in confined space for a long duration - Why not make him the only engineer with a 3 years contract in an otherwise unmanned space mining operation, with a female android present (for mental health, so he can talk to someone)? Instead his mission is to promote some strange ideologies on a colony, thus he needs to fly over all alone, is given an android to his side, with some weird features expplained in the opening of the movie.nnSecond, what would a grown man do with a very attractive android, which can be remote controlled? Love? Well, damn right! This topic is exploited to an extent, where I thought I was watching soft-core porn instead of Sci-Fi. The film even shows graphs of the android's activity: 95% is, well, you know, the rest some other basic stuff. Half of the time we see the android walking around naked, up to a point, where I ask myself why they bother to get it even dressed in uniform for the few moments - Maybe because the guy wanted to undress something?nnOK, we have a political officer on a space craft with his slave robot... How to advance the story? Malfunction of the robot? Malfunction of the space craft? Sudden regrets of what he's doing? No... he tampers with the android's software (and endangering the whole mission while doing so), so it cannot be longer remotely controlled! With the "regret-part" thrown in, it could have been rather interesting. Yet, and off course, his only hope is the love interest would become genuine. Well, tough luck, mate! At least the android shows some logic and considers love not mission critical. Well, only in that case it doesn't make much sense, because it's probably the only thing that kept the poor guy somewhat focused... he becomes depressed, android figures out it/she is the problem and, decides to shut itself down by short-circuiting her battery charging mechanism... see the outcome for yourself!nnA shame, the film could have been so much more in a similar setting. Missed Opportunity. Instead exploring human interaction with opposite gender androids (which can involve love, no problem here), it became some sort of study of a frustrated man. Pity. Missed Opportunity.

Andrew Haigh proves again with All of Us Strangers that fantasy doesn't always have to be fantastical. All of Us Strangers can be loosely defined as a queer ghost story of sorts, but that does nothing to prepare you for how gripping and affecting the movie is.nnAndrew Scott gives what might be the best performance of the year as Adam, a screenwriter who ventures back to his childhood home searching for inspiration, only to find that his parents who died when he was twelve are there still, preserved as they were the day they died. The film is so uniquely immersive and sublime that the audience never questions this plot device and never seeks greater understanding. I flatly accepted the confines of the story and was enraptured by the scenarios it bred.nnAdam, in his forties or there about, gets to participate in the conversations that were tragically stolen from him by his parents' death. He gets to learn his parents in a way that children don't, and gets to defend his existence to them, even when they may find difficulty in understanding. Claire Foy and Jamie Bell as his parents are equally impeccable in their performances, feeling so authentic and so plausible.nnThe film also serves as a time capsule of the 1980's in that Adam's parents are perpetually stuck in that time, and mired by the values and prevailing sentiments of the era. This is both blessing and curse, but moreso the latter as it specifically pertains to Adam's sexuality. His mom, gripped by the AIDS scare in addition to the general discomfort toward homosexuality common of the time, has difficulty squaring Adam's truth with her own in regards to her son. In my theatre, I sat a couple of seats down the aisle from an older gay couple and one was bravely but unsuccessfully fighting against audibly weeping. I can't imagine the catharsis some older queer people felt watching these scenes, absolutely some of the best of the year.nnThe movie clips by at a comparably lean 105 minute run time, and for all the amazing films that dropped this year, this is the one I wanted more of as the credits rolled. I could have stayed with these characters as they unearthed so much repressed and unrequited emotion for hours. As is, All of Us Strangers is probably the smallest great film of the year, but also one of the most vigorous. There is a bath-like, placid warmth that blankets the entire movie and by the end it just feels generous. I left feeling thankful, like the gratitude you feel being entrusted with a great personal secret of a close friend.

Kenneth Duffy has completely missed the mark with Gladiator 2. This sequel is a chaotic disaster that feels like it was thrown together without any thought to the original's legacy. Sharks, CGI monkeys, and a bizarre choice of actor for the lead roll make up the most absurd and laughable parts of this movie, though it's hard to say which is worse. None of these elements fit, and the result is a film that feels more like an unfunny parody than a serious follow-up. A true disappointment that fails to honor the masterpiece it follows. Avoid this trainwreck at all costs, it's far beyond redemption.

Okay guys I don't know where to start with this movie so much emotion thrown around i wanted to go see mufasa or sonic the hedgehog but both were sold out which lead me to see this film first off if your offended by nudity stay away from this for sure if you are offended by sex go see something different you won't like this but I absolutely loved it i thought Nicole kidman was absolutely amazing here just like anywhere else she's in such a sexual cat and mouse game here thrilling sexy and spontaneous is all you get with this one and for once I'll say it is a great joy to have all that In one film for the holidays.

Greta Gerwig's Barbie was not just the highest grossing film and buzziest film of the year, it completely dominated the pop culture landscape of 2023. Barbie was the most significant contributor to the resurgence of film and cineplexes we have enjoyed this year. And while that is certainly noteworthy, it is not why Barbie matters. To reduce the film to its cultural and economic impact is to do disservice to the legitimacy and excellence of the film itself.nnBarbie is singular feat in that it is an IP movie that underwent immense studio and commercial oversight and still came out on the other side as a fierce and poignant work of art. Greta Gerwig and company give us the very best iteration of a Barbie movie we ever could have dreamed of getting. And this fact will become even more into focus over the next decade as every major corporation scrambles to get film treatments for their iconic IP. By the time the inevitable Furby movie hits theatres we will look back at Barbie in same way we look back at the first Iron Man in that it kickstarted and entire arm of the industry. But none will hold a candle to the care and craft exemplified in Barbie.nnThe screenplay is one of the more interesting aspects of the film. It has less subtlety than a catcall, and yet it is still so abundantly clever. There is a voice to the dialogue that I'm not sure I've ever felt before. It is shamelessly expository, but still dripping with irony. Also, while the film sets it sights on certain messages and does nothing to hide those pursuits, it seems to focus its attention on the humor and allows the allegory to take care of itself naturally. It feels like a comedy first and commentary second, yet when you walk away, it is the commentary that sticks.nnAnd it is hilarious. Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling shine like pressed plastic in their roles and are deliriously funny throughout. The costumes are undoubtedly the best of the year and production design might be even better. While it can get heavy handed at times, taking patriarchal structures to task and lamenting the excess burden placed upon modern women, these moments are made palatable because these stories have not been told with enough frequency or enough fervor in film history. I would not have guessed it, but not only is Barbie one of 2023 most important films, but one of its best.

The character development of Tony Lip Vallelonga. Yes, he starts as a racist who would trash glasses that were used by black people to drink from, but by the end he invites him to his house to celebrate Christmas with his family.nnIn real time only two months had passed which could explain his change of heart, however in the film I don't buy this character development. Either he shouldn't start as racist as he did, or he shouldn't have changed his heart so quickly in movie time.nnDoc Don Shirley however had a much better arc in the film, only soiled by my knowledge of the real Don Shirley. He is portrayed as someone in between worlds and rather socially awkward, which wouldn't have been the case in real life.nnWith this nitpick out of the way, I have to say that I enjoyed the film thoroughly. The cherry on top was of course the ending. I'm a sucker for a happy one.

I'm surprised this isn't rated more highly on IMDB, because frankly, this is one of the BEST tv shows I have watched in the last year, and it has been renewed for a season 2!nnNow as with many shows, the first episode or 2 are usually quite slow, they set the scene, and the characters. The day of the jackal does it differently. It throws you straight into the action with no knowledge of anything, a strange character and a mission. An assassination. You do not know why, where, who or anything. But that is the beauty of it. Throughout the episodes you will get introduced to more and more characters and slowly setting the scene. While still keeping you gripped for the whole episode.nnCongrats to the whole team on this suspenseful masterpiece! And I can't wait for a season 2.

Excessive length: The film feels endless, giving the impression that it takes an eternity to conclude.nnUneven acting: While the main actors deliver strong performances, the supporting cast struggles to convince.nnUnbelievable romance: There's no real explanation for why B√©atrice falls in love with Mokhtar, making their relationship hard to accept.nnUnnecessary scenes: The lengthy sex scenes add nothing to the plot and come across as superfluous.nnRushed character development: B√©atrice stops being racist after a brief walk through a migrant camp, during which she is shown all the tents for no apparent reason, seemingly just to speed up the storyline at an unnecessary point.nnPoor sound quality: The sound design is sloppy. You can hear the lavalier microphones rubbing against clothing, and whispered dialogue is often unintelligible.nnLinguistic inconsistency: The relationship between B√©atrice and Mokhtar is uncomfortable, partly due to their age gap and initial inability to communicate. Yet, inexplicably, they suddenly become bilingual at certain points in the film.nnPositive aspects: The lighting and framing are well-crafted, delivering visually pleasing shots despite the film's other flaws.nnJust a heads-up: there are a lot of unnecessarily long sex scenes, and there's also a penis shown. None of this adds anything to the film.

Matt Walsh's deep dive into the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) movement has a lot more truth than many will admit. While the film is billed as satire and a mockumentary, the programs Walsh skewers in this film are real and, at least for a time, tremendously influential.nnIf Walsh's goal is to identify and take down the extremes of DEI movement, his film does a fine job. He takes on some of the most visible (and extreme) proponents of DEI and lays bare the contradictions, self-congratulatory frame, and disconnected elements. In the process, Walsh shows why the US has experienced a significant backlash against these programs as state legislators pass laws to limit their influence.nnThe movie will appeal to more than just conservatives. Many of these programs are simply problematic in the way they are conceived and implemented. "Am I Racist" poses fundamental questions about what it means to be racist and what motivates people at the most basic, human level.nnUnfortunately, the movie does not dive deeper into the parts of American culture that led to the emergence of these programs in the first place. DEI initiatives take on many forms, depending on the context and objectives of the organizers. In his attempt to go after the "bad actors," Walsh avoids diving into the complexity of race relations in the U. S. and ways racism can be addressed in more workable and less dogmatic ways.nnStill, the movie is well worth watching, if for no other reason than to understand the current cultural, political, and business backlash against DEI programs. As much as audiences might disagree with Walsh, his sincerity and authenticity are clear throughout the film.

I really enjoyed this quiet film. It was funny and moving. It explored the complexities of generational trauma and the pressures that come with being the children of survivors. Kieran Mculkin was particularly impressive in both his comedy and his drama. Jesse kind of plays himself but his writing and directing were very good. Today when antisemitism is back at an all time high, films like this are very important (all you need to do is scroll down to the 1 star reviews on this page by people totally unashamed and unafraid to spout their ugly antisemitism, which I notice the people at imdb are happy to keep on their page despite my reporting of them).

Last night I had a serendipitous event: I viewed the David Lee Fisher version of Nosferatu, A Symphony of Horror. I haven't seen this movie, released in 2023 mentioned anywhere and imagined it has been overshadowed by this year's Bill Skarsg√•rd/Nicholas Hoult production and thus had been largely ignored, though Amazon Prime Video and Tubi features it. It's been panned by some but I found it surprisingly well-done. Yes, it begins with some slightly stilted and occasionally bombastic scenery-chewing but settles in when one decides to watch it as if actually set in the period of the story. Then, both cast, dialogue and viewer adjust accordingly. The story blends scenes crafted to copy exactly some from the original 1922 Nosferatu, and occasional dialogue from Lugosi's version. There are some little jewels of cinematic moments, such as the backdrops appearing a combination of painting and projection giving it the primitive cinematic effect of the original. Stylish, artistic, surreal, and gothic, done in black and white. Except for the occasional bright red slash of blood or the golden lick of flames as when the Demeter burns.nnAs a whole, even with the "high school play" elements another viewer has panned, I much preferred this one over the 1979 Kinski Nosferatu which simply mirrored the original with dialogue and added nothing new (and believe me, at 82, I've seen a LOT of vampire/Dracula movies to compare it to). I thoroughly enjoyed it and look forward to the latest Nosferatu so I can add it to my very long list.nnSo...we all have our opinions and though my seem to swim against the majority...that's my opinion and I"m sticking to it.

I had my doubt about this movie, I'm not a music person by any means, and by that, I mean not evening listening to music weekly!nnHowever this movie surprised me, they could have easily have made this a 2.30-3 hour long movie, however they have made a masterpiece by not doing so. Every scene has a meaning, thee is no random filler scenes. A constant 1.45 hours of action and intensity.nnI've watched this multiple times now and has never failed to impress. All the acting is amazing, the script is amazing, you never know what is going too happen, and the music is some of the best in filmography. But the real gem in my opinion is the length. Not too long nor short, enough too keep you on your toes but not begging for more. Perfection.

They have some of the greatest ingrediens. Amazing actors, known director, legacy, an easy to sell theme. Shouldn't be able to fail. But I don't know what this crap is.nnThe story is there but not connected. "Cool" thing, to "cool" thing with nothing in-between. And with nothing in-between, why care about those moments?nnMost ren-fairs have better choreographs fight, all of the characters are flat and extremely stupid, special effects are way worse than the first movie.nnBiggest cash grab I've seen. Had it been a "straight to video" no name, it probably could have been a 3. But the size of the dump they are placing on the originals legacy is astounding.nnI have to give them one extra star for the boot to Hollywood. They must be the emperors. Without a clue themselves and selling crap to amuse and distract the population.

In spite of being a thief, a con man, and a convicted pedophile, Fritz Haarmann (Kurt Raab), is recruited by the police, and given free rein as an informant. Fritz quickly discovers that this does nothing to hamper his criminal activity, especially his particular proclivities. Instead, it greatly enables them, giving him far more access to his victims.nnTENDERNESS OF THE WOLVES is a highly disturbing film, especially considering its vintage. Mr. Raab gives a chilling, nonchalant performance as the notorious, real-life murderer. Director Ulli Lommel shows us not only the seemingly bottomless depravity of Haarmann, but also the corruption and soullessness of those around him.nnIn addition to Mr. Raab's astonishing portrayal of psychopathic evil, Margit Carstensen plays Frau Lindner, the only person in the film who seems to have a functioning conscience. She is the one ray of light in an otherwise black story.nnShocking and unforgettable...

Just watched "Game Changer" and thought it was better than "Indian 2". The movie has some predictable moments, but the first half's writing and the 20-minute flashback in the second half are noteworthy. However, some viewers might find the screenplay and editing weak, and the sound mix stale. Despite this, it's a clean family-friendly film.nnRam Charan's performance is impressive, and his character, Appanna, is a highlight. His screen presence is undeniable. The cat-and-mouse chase between Ram Charan and Surya will entertain audiences.nnThe movie showcases the power of an IAS officer and a Chief Electoral Officer, highlighting the challenges of doing good for society. However, few audience may don't feel good about movie.nnWhy? Few individuals may think that i am already aware that I'll be taken advantage of by politicians. I know law & order gonna deceive me, it's no surprise. I'm well aware they will cheat me every term. But you/director/artists do not try to tell me that I could be cheated by them - I can't bear it"nnthat's the reason few may don't feel good about movie because director attempted to cram the entire constitution and its rights into a 2.5-hour film, which may overwhelm audiences, feeling like they're being hit with a dense, heavy book.nnOverall, "Game Changer" is a decent watch, but its impact may vary depending on individual perspectives.

Our hero, the feckless ML, feels that he can't win in the game of life-that he's been dealt a hand of deuces and treys. So life (well actually I should say Death) puts him in a TRULY no-win situation.nnDid I say "no-win"? This is the King of no-wins. He can't even solve this particular dilemma by dying.nnDEATH'S GAME starts out as a male-oriented thriller, with non-stop action, and plenty of violence and gore. Keep watching, though, because this series isn't easily categorized. One episode has horror film vibes; another fills in the details of the romance introduced at the beginning. Whatever. I guarantee that you won't complain that it drags-more like a cage-full of squirrels on speed.nnWhat really sets this series apart from others are the excellent special effects, along with some amazing camera work. One shot (pun intended) lets the viewer look at a certain character through a bullet hole that's just penetrated another character's head.nnIf you prefer a narrative with more sophisticated characters and a nuanced view of reality, you might think DEATH'S GAME isn't your cup of tea. The minor characters are mostly sterotypes, especially the villains. But the ML grows and changes-and the focus is mostly on him.nnIf you look at the plot too closely, you'll notice some inconsistencies. For example, it's not clear what happened to the original inhabitant of each of the bodies the ML took over. Some of the rules of the game seem to change over the course of the series. And I personally didn't appreciate the demonization of people who commit suicide. Some, no doubt, are selfish, like the ML. Others are sick. And still others have an intolerable life situation.nnA crow is blown to pieces in one episode. I see anti-crow scenes like this in a lot of dramas these days. Please, guys, stop setting a bad example by encouraging people to torture and kill these amazingly intelligent birds (look up the research).nnYou may notice some familiar faces in the minor roles. Kim Mi-Kyung as the mother and Oh Jung-se, whose versatility always amazes me, are just two I recognized.nnThe pluses totally outweigh the minuses in this series. Eight and a half stars.

I actually had to make an account just to make this review because I can't believe what I even just watched.nnNo Finnish actors hired for this, no one knew how to speak or pronounce Finnish, some of the cultural facts were just blatantly incorrect and some of the town names even were spelled wrong. I don't think anyone Finnish was actually involved in writing or fact checking this mess. You know none of the Finnish characters even had Finnish names? At one point they butchered the grammar of something so bad that it sounded pretty lewd to an actual Finnish ear, which at least was hilarious even tho surprising.nnI mean it's a Hallmark movie so what are we expecting but I think the minimum requirement when using another country and culture as a setting is to honor that and not use it as a butchered trope that you probably only asked chatgpt about. If you made a movie that was set in Japan would you hire Russians to pretend to be Japanese while speaking butchered Japanese off paper while your American white girl adventures there?nnIt's a shame because I don't think the acting for the leads was bad and the story was almost cute. I was so excited to see a foreign movie about Finland too. The girl best friend character is very cute and supportive, and of course the dogs were completely adorable and the relationship building and chemistry was fine. But I could not in good conscience recommend this to anyone who actually cares, talk about cultural appropriation.

This was the best drama I saw in 2024. The narrative presents an engaging story that leaves viewers eager for the next episode, full of twists and intense emotions. It was incredible to watch this drama from beginning to end. Hong Hee-joo, played by Chae Soo-bin, is brilliant, bringing out the emotional complexity of the character, in addition to the duality of the character, which was portrayed in a spectacular way. Throughout the drama, we see personal growth as he faces several challenges. Internal and external conflicts are portrayed with sensitivity, allowing the audience to connect with his journey. As for Baek Sa-eon, his search for love, affection and understanding were one of the driving forces behind the story. His relationship with Hong Hee-joo is particularly interesting. The chemistry between the two characters is palpable and their interactions are full of emotional tension, as he is willing to fight for what he wants, but he needs to deal with his issues. Actor Yoo Yeon-Seok brings an incredible performance to the role, managing to balance moments of lightness and humor with more dramatic and intense scenes. His ability to convey his emotions to this character makes the audience genuinely care about his fate.

This movie is absolute trash. The director clearly did not know what a movie was. The main actor, Romain Duris is great in other movies, I have seen him act in "La nuit se tra√Æne" and also "Les trois mousquetaires". However, in Arsene Lupin he was terrible. Clearly the director did not know how to direct such talent. The story line itself is also ridiculous. It goes back and forth and is tangled up in a mess of a bunch of different stories that the director tried to put together. You would think that 20,4 million USD$ would be enough to make an at least decent movie, but clearly Jean-Paul Salom√© needs a little more help.

While this isn't as terrible as Indian 2 overall, the entirety of the first hour is some of the worst bits of filmmaking I have seen from the once-iconic director. The comedy sucks (Sunil and Vennela Kishore characters desperately need the "DELETE" button), the intro fight & song combo is horrendous, the romance between Charan and Kiara's characters is so poorly written, and SJ Suryah does eccentric SJ Suryah for the millionth time. Yeah, I should stop looking at this as a Tamil film, because it clearly isn't aiming to be one.nnAlmost every song is a bathroom break, though I like some of the beats in Dhop (along with its vibrant picturization). It was difficult to connect with the protagonist - an IAS officer + IPS officer + Election Officer + Angry Dude in College + whatever the hell the writing needs him to be. We connected with Shankar's protagonists in some of his earlier films because most of them weren't default superheroes. Very often, the circumstance creates one, and that formula worked for him for nearly 2 decades. But gone are those days. I'm not sure what ideas Karthik Subbaraj fed Shankar in the initial stages-ultimately, Shankar chose to give it the same screenplay treatment as Mudhalvan, Sivaji, and the likes.. in 2025. Plus, the only time I bought the performer in Ram Charan was during the short flashback portion, and even that's less impactful.nnKiara Advani is drop-dead gorgeous, though she's mostly relegated to being a song-and-dance prop in the film. Anjali gets a meatier presence than expected, and is fine in the flashback (..not the present). Jayaram is disposable, and Srikanth plays the guy Samuthirakani or Sachin Khedekar usually takes up. My biggest gripe, however, is with the action sequences. I don't remember Shankar directing action this terribly, like EVER. Peter Hein and Anbariv are involved, but to what avail? Every set piece is wholly forgettable. The "Hari-fication" of Shankar is well and truly underway, as far as the pacing is concerned. I don't have any faith in his upcoming projects. God save the Velpari adaptation.

Fateh is good watch.sonu sood is fantastic... direction is nice.action is brutal....overall it's a complete package , a good entertainer....must watch in theatre.nnSonu Sood has done a commendable job as both an actor and director. His presence on screen is strong, and the film's editing features some creative transitions that add a refreshing touch. The songs are beautifully placed and perfectly complement the narrative.nnAction sequences are well choreographed, sonu sir as a actor did a very nice job...bgm is good.performance wise 10 out of 10.nnTone, Script & Story: The story is about a guy who once worked for intelligence and now is retired and settled in Punjab. The main guy goes looking for a girl and in turn fights against one of the said cyber-crime organizations.

Finally! Andor gives us the gritty, behind-the-scenes Star Wars story we've been craving. This isn't about lightsabers and space wizards - it's about the real people fighting from the shadows to build what would become the Rebellion.nnDiego Luna is just brilliant as Cassian. He brings this perfect mix of survival instincts and hidden depths that makes you believe every choice he makes. The way he navigates through this darker corner of the galaxy feels completely real, showing us how regular people get pulled into extraordinary fights.nnThe attention to detail in showing the Empire's grip on everyday life is incredible. From the factory floors to the prison systems to the secret resistance meetings, everything feels lived-in and authentic. Each episode builds tension in ways Star Wars has never done before.nnA perfect 10/10 that shows the Star Wars universe is at its best when it's not afraid to get its hands dirty.

In reflecting upon the 2033 films I have experienced at the writing of this review; including 100% of the IMDb top 250 English speaking and 97% irrespective of language films, I would emphatically suggest, 'Requiem for a Dream' to be the best example of effective cinematography I have encountered!nnDirector and co-writer, Darren Aronofsky, has seamlessly integrated every visual and audio aspect into an intensely escalating emotive audience film experience. Vitally hoisted further by an equally intense sublime cast performance, with Jared Leto, Jennifer Connelly, Marlon Wayans, and Ellen Burstyn at the pinnacle of proficiency.

This show is well written, has a great pace. I enjoy the storyline and honestly the comedy from Billy Bob and the cast is just natural.nnI don't understand why this isn't rated higher.nnThe women in this show make it fun and add great sex appeal. As a woman I enjoy seeing the wealth that the Land Man have at their fingertips and how it's wasted. There's enough action(I'm not going to spoil it). There's so many shows that are replicas of something else. I think this show is original. Jerry Jones guest appearance was award winning. I'm hoping this show is renewed for a second season. I binged this entire season this far in 1 day.

Waitress ugly cries alot, makes bad choices in men and manages to piss off most of her friends who have to constantly bail her out of danger.nnOh, and there's vampires - perhaps should have just stuck to vamp rather than all the other supernatural creatures.nnEasy viewing though - although it's Eric and Pam that make it most watchable. Plenty of episodes are ridiculously far fetched and rather hurried towards the end. The first series and second series were definitely the most interestingnnIs it watchable? Yes mostly. Will you walk round saying 'Sukaaay' all the time? Probably.
