The movie keeps you emotionally engaged from start to finish. It's incredibly well-acted and so well executed. It beautifully explores the essence of human connection in a way that's both direct and deeply heartwarming. The sweetness and tenderness of platonic relationships are portrayed with such authenticity, capturing the emotional needs of humans in a way that feels relatable. Every moment is so beautifully created, it leaves you feeling nostalgic for your own platonic bonds. The movie is so accurate in every way, and it's just one of the most unique movies I've ever watched. Absolutely loved it!

ASAF is a very good 6 episode series with a gripping plot and excellent acting. The atmosphere is built very well. The omnipotent Payen Kuyern organization has arms that can reach everyone and everywhere. We feel Asaf's suffocation at first and his gradual change to comply with the power game.nnAll the actors are good but Cihangir Ceyhan stands out as ASAF. Bur√ßin Terzioglu as Asaf's wife, Saadet Isil Aksoy as the journalist, Ahmet Rifat Sungar and Fatih Al as detectives all give excellent performances. Even the two children play their parts well.nnI really don't understand why people wrote that Tayanc Ayaydin played Asaf. Although a very good actor himself, Tayanc Ayaydin has a small part as Asaf's brother in this series.nnMany members of the cast are missing in the IMDb cast section of this series.

When the Phone Rings It's one of those dramas that pulls you in right from the start. The way they build suspense is so clever-every scene feels like it's hiding something, and you just *have* to keep watching to figure it out. The characters are so well-written too; you'll find yourself caring about every single one of them, even the ones you weren't sure about at first. And let's talk about the emotions-wow. It's got just the right balance of mystery, drama, and those little moments that make you smile. Plus, the cinematography is stunning; every shot feels intentional and adds to the story. I honestly couldn't stop thinking about it after finishing. It's perfect for a cozy binge-watch, trust me!

The Dark Knight is undoubtedly one of the most influential films in the superhero genre, but its high position on IMDb's Top 250 list sparks divided opinions. While Heath Ledger's portrayal of the Joker is undeniable-brilliant, haunting, and tragic-the rest of the film fails to reach the artistic heights that would justify it as the third-best film of all time.nnLedger's Joker is the soul of this movie, and his depiction of chaos and anarchy transforms the story from a standard action spectacle into a psychological drama. However, the fact that Ledger gave his all for this role, even his life, adds emotional weight to the film but also raises the question: Would the movie be so highly praised without his performance?

I really loved this serie, at first I had no expectations, but the story captivated me a lot and the way in which the actors knew how to interpret the characters made me feel mixed emotions that had not happened to me before with any series. This serie deserves more support and admiration for actors Yoo Yeon Seok and Chae Soo Bin they did an amazing jobAnd they knew how to express the emotions of their characters; and i'm thankful for the production team. I am very grateful to have been able to have seen it and to have met a fandom that is really incredible. I hope they give us more about this series that I really loved it.

An impressive war film with about the uprising of Warsaw's citizens against the Nazi occupation. The film primarily focuses on the human drama and sometimes goes overboard with it. Repeated stylistic breaches are made, which result in a legendary kissing scene at the beginning but also cause confusion as the film progresses.nnWhat makes the film messy is that it's not always clear which story is being told. The romantic part is well executed and has a nice twist toward the end, but it's sometimes not present enough to stand out amid the chaos.nnThe biggest missed opportunity, however, is the total absence of the bigger picture. In such an epic, where no expense has been spared, I, as a viewer, want a clear understanding of how everything fits together. Instead, the film chooses drama and horror, losing realism and depth in the process. Fortunately, there is Wikipedia.nnStalin refused to cross the Vistula with his troops, leaving the city's citizens to literally fight to the death. The Nazis began executing more than 50,000 citizens as a deterrent, but the uprising continued. District by district was bombed from the air, and the Nazis deployed their worst henchmen who looted and raped as they went. Eventually, the entire city was blown up and set on fire house by house. The Germans planned to turn it into a 'lake.'nnStalin ultimately had little trouble conquering the ruins from the Nazis. Surviving resistance fighters were executed without mercy or sent to the Gulag.

When I said Shankar lost his touch in my Indian 2 review, I also mentioned that he is going to mess up Game Changer as well because he shot both the films simultaneously. And as expected, he did mess up. Badly. Although I must say that this is not as bad as Indian 2, but the bar is so low here that it is easy to pass it. Let's get into the details.nnGame Changer follows the same formula that all Shankar's movies follow. A man trying to set the society along the right path by fighting injustice. We are introduced to Ram (Ram Charan) who is an IAS officer with anger management issues. He was previously an IPS officer with anger management issues. This entire setup is a series of cringe inducing sequences with Ram and Kiara Advani who plays Ram's love interest. The reason Ram becomes an IAS office is equally cringe. Kiara advises Ram to channel his anger to the good of the society and tells him to become an IAS office. But Ram wants to become an IPS officer. She also warns him that she'd not talk with him if he becomes an IPS officer as IPS, somehow, means anger? Anyway, Ram becomes an IPS officer and they breakup. So Ram studies again and becomes an IAS officer. If you are scratching you head at this point, then I must warn you this entire cringe fest takes up all of Act 1 for over 40 minutes without ever introducing us to a conflict. That is how bad Shankar's writing is.nnWhen the conflict does arrive, it is a lame reason that creates a rift between Ram, the IAS, and Mopi Devi, played by SJ Suryah, the Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh state. What's a Shankar's movie without a flashback? There is an elaborate flashback that takes up all of Act 2 where we are introduced to Appanna (Ram Charan, again. Duh!) and his fight for justice and how he gets betrayed by his own friends. How Ram finds out the truth and defeats Mopi Devi form the rest of Act 3 or what is left of it.nnNow, I don't have a problem with these generic saviour templates. They were fine some 20 years ago. They may have a place even now. However, the way Shankar executed this story with his insipid screenplay and character development is what ruined it for me. Up until Robo in 2010, Shankar made movies that were ahead of their time and in 2025 he is making movies that would have been blockbusters in the 90s. He is the Benjamin Button of filmmakers, except for the worse. He is not updated with kinds of stories that audience expect to watch on the big screen, especially after the pandemic. He is not updated on the latest trends in filmmaking. He is still in his mindset where he spends lavishly on a song to make it rich and colorful.nnAfter watching Indian 2 and Game Changer, I cannot help but think whether Shankar has always been a hack. Did he use the grandeur and lavishness to coverup his lack of skill in filmmaking? Only he knows. But for the rest of us, Game Changer can be skipped completely. Hope you liked this review.nn-YT/@CinephileIndia2023.

Well, first, let me start by saying that the movie wasn't very scary. However, I think this was partly because I couldn't hear all the words coming out of Dracula's mouth. This made it hard to stay fully focused. I really wish they had added subtitles when he spoke because his heavy accent made it difficult to understand most of the time.nnSecond, the acting was very good overall. I think the girl's performance stood out the most. She was the only character I was truly interested in, and I was happy with her acting. She delivered her role perfectly-her reactions, facial expressions, and body language were all on point. I was completely in love with her performance. Honestly, I don't think they could have found anyone better to play that role.nnFinally, the protagonist-or lack thereof-was an issue for me. I don't think the movie gave anyone the title of a hero or gave us the opportunity to connect with or root for any character. I was hoping to feel something, maybe sadness, for the death of (I won't spoil), but I didn't. I didn't feel any empathy for the characters. To be honest, if all the characters in the movie had died, I wouldn't have cared or felt anything for them.nnThat said, the visuals, camerawork, and graphics were top-tier. I absolutely loved how they created the atmosphere in such a scary and immersive way. However, the nudity and sex scene felt completely unnecessary. Why would the guy agree to sleep with a girl he knew was possessed by Something? That part made no sense to me-completely UNNECESSARY.nnOverall, it was a good movie, but it could have been much better with a stronger connection to the characters and fewer unnecessary scenes.

This movie is pretty dreadful. Great cast, horrible writing, mediocre production values (think tv movie). I don't think the writer knows the first thing about the American Judicial system and the way courts work in America. The trial was silly, the concept of reasonable doubt, and the burden being on the prosecution was never addressed. There was absolutely no proof that the accused was anything but a jerk, and yet the jury was a ready to lock him up for life, really? As far as I could tell at the end of the movie, nobody was a guilty of anything and this movie was an utter waste of time. Don't wast your time on it, there are so many good movies out right now.

This is without a doubt the worst movie I have seen in a long time. The only reason I kept watching it was to see the beautiful scenery around Sequim. However, there wasn't enough of it. It might have indoctrinated me into religion though because I kept saying "Oh my God" a lot... The ending fell totally flat. Granted, it was based on a sad true story but surely it could have been presented better. The acting was so bad that I kept suspecting every character until I realized it wasn't guilt they were portraying, it was their acting skills that were falling short. And why did someone remove the pantyhose from Francine's hands???

Directorial debut of Sonu Sood, the movie primarily concentrates on two elements: cyber frauds and blunt action. While cyber fraud was something that took my attention, action scenes were more noisy and melodramatic than adrenaline filled.nnLet me put some cringe filled situations related to action sequences:nn1. The theatre scene was exact copy of movie The Equalizer starring Denzel Washington when he goes to a pub run by Russians to save Chloe Grace. If you haven't watched that movie, go watch it and its action scenes.nn2. The action artists whom Fateh ram every now and then felt useless and unrealistic. Like he kills 100s of them in one scene, but none comes forward in a group to kill him.nn3. Fateh could fly a knife and kill his opponent, but all the opponents were dumb and dumber and never do the same on him.nn4. When Fateh doesn't have guns, opponents also doesn't. In one scene the opponent had, and Fateh was able to steal it from him without much effort. Really.nnPeople who are comparing its action sequences with John Wick are forgetting that in John Wick, it's his suit that soaks all the gun shots. And as and when John fights forward, he gets equally exhausted and shows pain. In Fateh, Sonu Sood plays God mode and nothing less.nnNow I am not against this movie or Sonu Sood, and i really appreciated his direction. But somewhere, I felt lack of originality, conviction, and emotions. I wasn't able to bind his chemistry in the movie.

As a standalone it might have had something, maybe, as a sequel to gladiator its awful.nnLooks like the exact same team of people, and software/hardware used to create the monkeys in the 1995 film Jumanji, were dusted off and used in this film. Not only do they look horrific though, they also move and act nothing like a monkey would.nnDeveloped no meaningful or tangible connection to any character. The only time I was on the edge of my seat was when I was hoping the monkeys would kill them and then escape, and maybe go on some escapades that would be more interesting than the near 3 hours they did release.nnAlso they did Peter Mensah dirty in this with his screen time, he was phenomenal in the Spartacus tv show. Instead I had to watch wingus and dingus make money noises at the lunch table.

Excellent series. Great acting. Worth watching. Ignore the autism experts and their views. All the stories are well crafted and acted. There definitely needs to be a second series to explore further the past life of patience and to see how she develops further as a person.nnThere are some emotional scenes that may upset some, however it is within the context of each story. A welcome change from all the dross on platforms such as Netflicks, amazon prime etc. Good British show, made in part in the UK (York), which shows some of the architecture of the buildins within the city . Give it a chance.

I'm Still Here (2024), directed by Walter Salles, is a powerful and deeply emotional exploration of survival, loss, and reinvention during a period of intense political repression in Brazil. Set in 1971, during the tightening grip of a military dictatorship, the film follows a mother who is forced to navigate a shattered life after her family becomes a victim of arbitrary violence. As she faces unimaginable challenges, she must find the strength to reinvent herself in a world where every step she takes is fraught with danger.nnFernanda Torres gives a standout performance as the mother, capturing the emotional depth and inner turmoil of a woman who must protect her family and reclaim her life amidst brutal circumstances. Torres' portrayal is both heart-wrenching and empowering, as her character transitions from victim to survivor, embodying the strength and resilience that is often necessary when facing oppression. Alongside her, Fernanda Montenegro and Selton Mello provide strong supporting performances, adding emotional layers to the film's rich narrative.nnSalles' direction is intimate and evocative, drawing the audience into the emotional and political landscape of the time. The cinematography is stunning, with vivid contrasts between the starkness of the political environment and the personal, quiet moments of the protagonist's struggle. The pacing allows the film to breathe, taking the time to explore the complexities of its characters while maintaining the tension of a society on the brink of collapse.nnThe narrative is both personal and political, offering a window into the life of an ordinary woman thrust into extraordinary circumstances. The historical context of the Brazilian dictatorship is woven seamlessly into the personal story, emphasizing the widespread fear and the loss of agency experienced by many under authoritarian rule. While the film's pace may seem slow to some, it allows for a deeper emotional connection to the characters and their experiences.nnI'm Still Here is a film about resilience in the face of tyranny, about finding hope amidst despair, and about the courage to rebuild when everything has been taken away. It is a haunting reminder of the human cost of political repression, and an inspiring portrait of one woman's journey to reclaim her identity.nnRating: 8/10. A gripping, emotional journey that combines a personal story with the broader struggles of a nation under dictatorship, featuring a stellar performance from Fernanda Torres.

I don't get all the good reviews, those people must be bots or something.nnThis started pretty well but in essence it's just an overproduced soap opera. Not to mention the profanities and all the foul language between a mother and a daughter, all the sexual connotations. Can anyone produce a show without profanities and overly sexual dialogs? Thornton is pretty good in portraying a weak male character (towards his women), who constantly gets humiliated by his slutty hysteric gold digger X with a spoiled brat of a daughter to match. His over tolerant attitude is annoying enough but who in a right mind would allow his teen daughter to walk half-naked all over the house all the time?! That's supposed to be funny, I guess. But unrealistic scenes of oil patch workers pulling guns on cartel...please. Camera and overall production is top-notch, but that wasn't nearly enough to save it.

The way Bollywood Movie Fateh narrates things, it doesn't show a good beginning for the Hindi Movie lovers in 2025. This is true that much was at stake on this Movie; the so-called first charismatic cinematic presentation in 2025. But it has failed to impact and there are several factors behind this.nnThis is true that crime has emerged as the most dominating theme in the Celluloid world during the last few years. The Movie Fateh also narrates a crime story. It narrates the story of Cyber crime and related affairs. This issue is burning one in today's context. This proves that the Movie had ample opportunity to make experiment. Nevertheless, this Movie doesn't look Impressive. The main reason behind this is the Movie fails to prove purpose and relevance. The action keeps fluctuating too frequently which distracts attention. The Movie seems to cover the whole world of Cyber Crime and the reality is obvious. There are some melodramatic sequences which make the Movie more monotonous.nnPoor characterization is another weak point of the Movie. It is really hard to find relevance of some of the characters in the Movie. Similarly, acting is not up to the mark in this Movie. Sonu Sood seems lacking acting depth despite his reputation. Even actor like Nasiruddin Shah also seems stereotypical. What can be more unfortunate?nnThe remaining damage has been done by the Playback Singers. The composition and song sequences are of poor quality. The singing style and rendering again prove why the concept of Playback Singing no longer exists in Bollywood.nnOverall, impression is not encouraging as far as the Movie Fateh is concerned. Fateh means victory, but here it seems Shikast Defeat. Anyway one may try.

Where do I begin with a film like this? Let's start with the Pros:n- There is solid cinematography on display here, far better quality than this film deserves.nn- That's about it.nnNow for the Cons:n- First off, this film has some of the worst writing I've seen this side of a Neil Breen film. Characters say what they're thinking with almost no subtext whatsoever. Weird attempts at humor pop up out of nowhere and make the scenes feel like a series of loosely connected SNL skits. Subplots are brought up and then either dropped immediately, or ham-fistedly woven back into the script at the last second. It honestly seemed as though the writer/director had a handful of different films he wanted to make and rather than choose the best out of the bunch, he just decided to throw them all together into one stupid gumbo of a movie.nn- Secondly, the acting is mostly community theater level bad. KateLynn Newberry gives probably the best performance of the lot, but the bar is so low here, that's not saying much. The lead and the sheriff are both quite wooden and their subplot mostly amounts to nothing.nn- The creature effects are pretty forgettable. You can really tell there was a limited budget here. Everyone else seems to rave about the practical effects, but there was really nothing special about them. And aside from a limb getting amputated in the first five minutes, there's very little in the way of bloodshed, considering this is supposed to be a horror/thriller film.nn- Jumping back to the Neil Breen comparison, this film -- like Breen's -- has a lot it wants to say about justice and morality, but it doesn't know how or when to say it. In fact, like many bad movie before it, 'Replicator' seems to preach the same tired sermon of "bad people are bad" and "elected officials are corrupt, but they really shouldn't be." It's cheap, uninspired, childish writing and there's really no excuse for it.nnBottom line: This is a terrible, awkwardly paced and utterly forgettable film with high school level writing, zero heart, bad acting, awkward staging, budget effects, and a central idea that just doesn't work. With the exception of some good looking cinematography, this film flounders in every possible way.nnWhile some films are so bad, they're good, this film is so bad that it's just bad.nnSave your money and watch a Breen film instead. At least it'll be entertaining.

J. K. Simmons delivers the greatest performance of his entire career, Miles Teller is also fantastic in the lead role. The final scene of this movie is one of the greatest in the history of film, every time I watch it I stand up and clap at the end, an absolute masterwork of a film. My only issue with it is not even a real issue with the movie itself, I just wish would we could see where Andrew Neiman goes after delivering that absolutely stellar drumming performance and I wonder if he truly did go on to become one of the greats, and I wonder what Terrence Fletcher truly thinks of him by the end. I guess we'll never know.

Season 1 was fine. Not great, not terrible-just the televisual equivalent of plain toast. Easy enough to consume, but I wasn't rushing to write a heartfelt blog post about it.nnSeason 2, however, was a different beast entirely. Imagine being stuck in a group chat with a bunch of people you hate but can't leave because you're too polite. That's what this season felt like: a parade of irritating characters, laughably predictable plotlines, and moments so cringeworthy I nearly sprained something from second-hand embarrassment.nnLet's dissect the sisters, shall we? Eva. Oh, Eva. Nothing says "grief" like sleeping with your dead sister's husband and then declaring your have feelings for him. Because who needs time to process a tragedy when you can just leap straight into bed and call it character development? Becka, meanwhile, is the human embodiment of a toddler smashing plates and then whining when nobody congratulates her for it. Treating a nice guy like garbage? Check. Facing zero consequences? Also check.nnUrsula? Oh, sweet, forgettable Ursula. Her pill-popping storyline was so irrelevant I genuinely forgot it was a thing until I started writing this.nnAnd then there's Bibi, who I wanted to like-but even her sharp wit couldn't save her from being dragged down by the sheer misery of this season. And don't even get me started on her wife, who decided the best time to pick an IVF fight was when Bibi's sister had literally just died. Timing, babe. Read the room.nnBut the real MVP of Season 2 was Grace's early exit. Her departure was the one moment of pure, unfiltered joy I felt all season. If she'd stuck around, I wouldn't be writing this review because I'd have launched my TV out the window.nnThe writing, though... oh, the writing. It felt like a poorly planned school project. "Alright team, everyone gets a random subplot! Doesn't matter if it goes anywhere or even makes sense-just slap it in there. Eva's got grief-sex and binge drinking, Ursula gets some vague pill addiction, Becka's pregnant, and Bibi gets IVF drama nobody asked for. Job done!" The result? A checklist of mediocrity wrapped in a bow of "meh."nnAnd just when you think it couldn't get worse, they introduce the assistant cop. Honestly, she deserves her own segment in this review because her entire purpose seemed to be dragging the show further into the abyss. Annoying, unnecessary, and about as welcome as a fly in your wine.nnThen there's the plot-or lack thereof. Once Grace was gone (thankfully), the story spiralled into a predictable sludge of clich√©s and eye-roll-inducing twists. Every time the writers thought they were being clever with foreshadowing, it landed with the subtlety of a marching band crashing through a library. The whole thing felt like it was desperately trying to be clever and edgy, but it ended up about as fresh as yesterday's fish.nnThe only saving grace-pun intended-was the opening titles. They were, without a doubt, the best part of the show. In fact, just watch those and skip the rest. You'll save yourself hours of irritation and the need for therapy.

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim (2024)
column4: Animated films actually dominated 2024. Inside Out 2 turned out to be the highest grossing 2024 film, beating The Lion King (2019) for the title of highest grossing animated film of all time. Five out of ten of the highest grossing films in 2024 were animated films.nnSo, it is a bummer that an animated take of one of the most successful film franchises of all time would not fare well.nnBefore anything else - Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirim is not a bad film. But it has many problems. Even in conception, it is reportedly a fast-tracked project in order for New Line Cinema to maintain the film adaptation rights for J. R. R. Tolkien's novels.nnNevertheless, it still looks beautiful, as it is animated by a competent Japanese Studio and a seasoned anime director, Kenji Kamiyama. It's traditional, hand-drawn style juxtaposed with painted backgrounds remind one of Hayao Miyazaki or Makoto Shinkai films. It looks, however, inferior to both.nnContrary to the epic, high fantasy setting of Middle Earth films, The War of the Rohirim is about rival human factions in Rohan almost 200 years before the Fellowship of the Ring. It focuses on princess Hera, as she races against time to defend her people against the vengeful Wulf.nnThe film also highlights Helm Hammerhand, King of Rohan and Hera's father. Wulf's path to vengeance ignited when King Helm accidentally killed Wulf's father, Freca, in a brawl, with a single punch. Freca initially offered Wulf to marry Hera. Helm declined due to the suspicion that Freca only wanted the throne. Insulted, Freca challenged Helm to a duel leading to his demise.nnYears passed and Wulf successfully gathered an army of outlanders, determined to destroy the Hammerhand family and take the throne of Rohan by force.nnAgain, not at all a bad premise. The overall story is actually compelling and paced well.nnThe downside is how it failed to capture the appeal of The Lord of The Rings, especially for an animated project that could easily replicate and showcase its fantastical elements. On the other hand, there is no problem in choosing a human-filled faction and story.nnRemember that the events centered around Rohan from the classic films contained some of the most epic and memorable battles in the history of cinema.nnThe difficulty of reproducing these sequences, may it be due to the limitations of the medium, or the narrative constraints, likely contributed to why it drew less audiences from both the LOTR fandom and anime fans alike. Regardless, the film is serviceable and works as a decent companion film for fans of LOTR.

After a week of burn out from work, this drama serves as a therapy, to leave the world we live in and be engage in the story. The story is not that heavy unlike other dramas where it is so overwhelming to watch because of the antagonists. The acting is also suitable to the storyline. It may not be the kind of drama with a crazy plot twist but it is a healing drama.nnI have seen almost all kdramas, dropped majority of them because I was not hooked in episode 1 ornn2, but this drama made me extra excited of Fridays and Saturdays.nnFor a drama to be a great one, it does't necessarily need a complicated story line, it needs suitable actors and I think, they made a great casts choice for this drama.

Boyz N the Hood is not one of my favorite movies yet watching Los Frikis reminded me of a scene from the beginning of the film. School children are walking when one makes a gesture towards a 1984 Reagan for President poster. After this, the former governor of California and two term president is never mentioned again. In Los Frikis, Fidel Castro does not loom large, he's the boogeyman of this anti-Communist propaganda. Most propaganda can be dismissed with the adage; "there are two sides to every story and then there's the truth." Yet Los Frikis has an axe to grind and does not let up.nnThe main character's older brother is a Friki, a Punk Rocker who is anarchist aesthetically yet conservative politically. We learn that Rock music is banned in Cuba yet there is no mention of Radio Free America and other decades old U. S. State Department programs using Jazz musicians and later rappers to present the U. S. as a free and progressive society without a race problem.nnThe cast of Los Frikis is beautiful, stylish and tanned. They are also largely Cuban. The writers and directors are not and curiously, they don't have Wikipedia pages yet they have the budget and backing to pull off Los Frikis.nnReturning to the cast, there is a caste of course and an island with a huge Black population is not rendered here. Race in Cuba does not function as it does in the U. S., I'm well aware of that, however the Black characters of Los Frikis are there but never really present.nnThe two characters that die in the film are Black. There's an unnamed Black woman whose body washes ashore, from god only knows where. Aren't we in the midst of questioning violence visited upon Black bodies on film? And there's the infantilized Black character, burdened by mobility issues, a virus and dare I say his color. There is another Black character who doesn't die that appears in two scenes. One scene where this massive Black man is introduced as HIV positive. Here he utters his one line, one with a homophobic slur because, lest you forget, Cubans are machistas and Black people are homophobic and he's muscular. The second scene, he's silent, he's only there to share his body. This movie isn't one for subtletynnThroughout the film we have another infantilized character, Gustavo, however his being preyed on by a much older divorcee is presented in a fetishizing manner. One where hot Cubans fall in love. This storyline seems so out-of-place in the second decade of the 21st century because there are power dynamics and age that call consent into question. Especially since Gustavo is introduced as someone living in peril, thanks to Fidel.nnAnother curious scene is where two characters learn of a medical advance to treat AIDS while watching an American television program with nifty subtitles in Spanish. The U. S. infamously sacrificed its own with right-wing policies towards AIDS and HIV. However a nation with universal healthcare is seen taking cues from "us."nnUltimately, Rock n Roll prevails as Fidel relents on his anti-Rock because anti-capitalist Kurt Cobain, R. I. P., is the most popular singer among Los Frikis. Timeline notwithstanding.

Oh man, I love rom-com movies, and I enjoy happy endings because, like anyone else, they uplift me. But this movie was brutal. Gary wanted Karen, but she didn't feel the same. They had no chemistry, the kind we metaphorically call the essence of love. I kept thinking that, with time, something might develop between them. When Karen became pregnant, and that guy abandoned her, she started acting innocent around Gary. Gary stepped in to help her, and I thought, Finally, things are working out. But oh my God, they weren't! At her birthday party, she went back to seducing the guy who had left her.nnI mean, I am utterly disappointed. Usually, people rate movies poorly when they're dissatisfied, but I won't. Why? Because even though this movie leaves me dissatisfied, it delivers a brutal truth that was depicted 40 years ago. It shows that nice guys often get nothing in return, while selfish people always seem to win. I can live with that reality, but the cruelty toward Gary? That's too much. It's heartbreaking. My mind keeps screaming that being a nice guy feels like living in hell. Yet, that's what makes someone a "nice guy." Do I have to become selfish or a "whore" to escape this? No. Neither would I want to be naive like Gary. And yes, I called Gary dumb, but deep down, I don't believe he truly is. It's just the situation he's in. Still, I couldn't stomach the last scene where Karen pitied Gary. What a betrayal! It's better to be alone than to be with someone you value and worship, only to realize they don't value you in return.

For those of you who don't know, Omar Sy is one half of a famous Canal + sketch comedy show called Omar & Fred. To sum it up, it is very light hearted, even silly, comedy. However, to see him perform at this level and with such ease simply amazed me. The relationship & chemistry created between the two characters in the film would make you believe that Omar & Fran√ßois Cluzet were best friends in real life. Fran√ßois Cluzet is also excellent in this film. To a certain extent, his performance reminds me a bit of Dustin Hoffman's in Rain Man. This role shows how versatile he is as an actor. The last film I saw him in was "Ne Le Dis √† Personne" (Tell No One) and his role in that is, literally, the complete opposite, yet he pulls off both wonderfully.

I will admit that I'm not a die hard Wonderland fan, so I can't say for sure whether this is a faithful adaptation, but if there's one thing that I know about the original work, it's that it does not have much of a plot, and the whole point of it was to charm people with its nonsensical nature and fabulous characters. Unfortunately, this is something that some people tend to overlook when reviewing this movie.nnWhat's the story?nnA girl named Alice has a dream where she chases a talking white rabbit.nnIf that summary seemed really brief, it's because, just like the book, the plot isn't the main focus. Its characters are the key to what makes the movie good. I'll start with Alice. She is a very unique and entertaining character. While the contrast between her childlike curiosity and her sophisticated Victorian accent/vocabulary (shoutout to Kathryn Beaumont) may seem jarring on paper, the two elements surprisingly blend together well and make her quite endearing. Also, to people like me who prefer orderliness but live in a chaotic world, she's very relatable. The way she goes from being nonchalant about the madness around her to becoming increasingly annoyed by it makes the story more compelling as well. The villain, the Queen of Hearts (who is the maddest resident of Wonderland in more ways than one), is very entertaining, but is also appropriately threatening. The other characters, such as the Cheshire Cat, the Mad Hatter, the Dodo, and the Caterpillar (who shocked me during my first viewing because I couldn't believe that his hookah smoking was allowed in a Disney movie) are all very fun characters who provide great moments of comedy.nnThe animation of this film is fantastic. The backgrounds are very vibrant and pleasant to look at. Also, when it comes to the characters, the animators seized the opportunity to let loose and take full advantage of the cartoon medium. This makes for some very unique and memorable moments, from the sequences of Alice growing and shrinking to the Cheshire Cat's special powers (standout moments include when he literally stands on his own head and when he turns invisible, leaving only his smile behind) to the energetic and hilarious tea party sequence. These kinds of moments help give the film its own distinctive identity amid the other Disney movies.nnThis film holds the record for having the most songs out of any Disney movie (even if some of those songs are only 10 seconds long), and they're all pretty good, with my personal favorite being, "All in a Golden Afternoon."nnAs a movie, I think Alice in Wonderland is very enjoyable. Unfortunately, people tend to judge it unfairly for its lack of a plot. If you're going to judge this film, you have to remember that the original books didn't have much in the way of plot. After all, the plot isn't what matters when it comes to this particular story. It's the characters and the environment they inhabit that really matter, and, in this case, Disney did a great job of making both of those memorable.

I guess SUDDEN DEATH is the closest than DIE HARD, but both films are DIE HARD rip-offs anyway. This one is definitely a pretty good time waster, an actionner providing fun, body count, and everything you wish with this kind of stuff. By the way, the villain whose physique matches Dave Bautista's the most, the giant whom I don't know the name, I have read that he was also cast for 2015 SPECTRE for which Bautista eventually ended up getting the role. Now, maybe this is the revenge for the other big man? Don't miss this actionner, especially if you craved for SUDDEN DEATH, back in 1995. It was starring Jean-Claude Van Damme.

column3: Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town (1970) (TV)
column4: What's up with this Santa thing? How did it all begin? üéÖICTT has it covered like a blanket of ‚ùÑ.nnüéÖ ICTT is a 1970 51-minute üåü-studded release that is rated 93/82 on RT & 7.7 on IMDB. Fred Astaire (Top Hat, Holiday Inn) is our Narrator, S. D. Kluger. Mickey Rooney (Captain Courageous, National Velvet) brings Kris Kringle aka Santa Claus to life. Keenan Wynn (Annie Get Your Gun, Dr. Strangelove Or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb) speaks for Winter Warlock. Paul Frees of several Disney and animation features, must have had a blast as the grouchy Mayor Burgermeister Meisterburger / Grimsley. Robie Lester voices Miss Jessica / Mrs. Claus. Joan Gardner, known for several animation features, voices Tanta Kringle.nnüéÑ Romeo Muller (Frosty the Snowman, The Little Drummer Boy, and so much more) is the screenwriter. He often teamed up with directora Jules Bass & Arthur Rankin Jr on the classic holiday projects. They specialized in claymation and live-model stop action. Their work is adorable & whimsical. Every single one is a timeless classic. üéÖICTT is more of the same.nnü¶å Abandoned at birth, Kris Kringle was taken in by the toy-making elves. His was a childhood filled with cheer, love and meaning. At the same time, the nearest town was gradually descending into a cheerless and harsh place under the authoritarian rule of the Burgermeister Meisterburger. He's a typical creep with too much power. He stumbles on a toy one day and decides to outlaw toys! So when Kris comes to town bearing gifts, he's labeled outlaw #1.nnüéÅ Does that scare Kris away? Does the fact that the kids' beautiful teacher, Miss Jessica, seems to hate him scare him? Not at all. Kris is on a mission to preserve the magic of childhood. He will continue with his course of comfort, cheer, generosity, and love. When I was a kid, the idea of people hating Christmas was the most fantastical thing about this tale. The theme that we must fight back against the encroaching darkness with love and generosity has never been more cogent. Kris also demands that the kids behave well to be rewarded. Rewarding goodness and correcting naughtiness is part of the fight.nn‚õÑ Put one foot in front of the other is a wonderful song that stuck with me over the years. It's another classic. üéÖICTT is part of the holiday magic you don't want to kiss enjoying with your family. üç™Snuggle up and enjoy!üçÆnnQUOTEüì¢nnWhat would happen if we all tried to be like Santa and learned to give?nn„Ä∞üñç IMHOnnüì£8.5 üìù8.5 üé≠8.5 üíì7 ü¶ã3 üé®10 üéµ/üîä7.5 üîö8 ü§ó7 ‚ñ™ üåû8 ‚ö°3 üòÖ4 üò≠4 üò±2.5 üòØ3 ü§¢1 ü§î5 üí§0nnAge 3+ but there are some scary elements, depending on the childnnRated EveryonennRe-üì∫? Yearly.

While you can tell the budget was not as deserved (because honestly, this movie deserved so much), the writing, message and experiences are genuine and shed light on the 'troubled teen' industry in a way that hasn't been done in media before. An important watch, with lines that emphasise the true nature of these 'wilderness retreats', and focusing on a black, female, neurodivergent, queer lead, it is clear that this film honestly wants to make victims of this industry seen, and raise awareness for the harm it does to children, no matter what shape or form they come in. Everyone, victims, parents, general public could benefit from watching this and using it to educate themselves on the disgusting, exploitative practices of the 'troubled teen' industry.

Why?? Just why would you do this??nnSeason 1 was very good. It had charm, creativity, and respect for the source material. Season 2 completely off the rails, but Season 3? What in the name of hell!!!!nnWhy would you do this? Why???nnThe essence of what made the original series great was tossed aside like last week's leftovers. The storytelling? A mess. The character development? Nonexistent. It's like the writers took every beloved character and decided to see how far they could push them away from their original, iconic selves.nnWhy mess with the OGs!!!?? The audacity to take characters we've loved for decades and turn them into unrecognizable caricatures is baffling. The narratives are not just uninspired; they're actively bad, filled with plot holes you could drive a truck through.nnThis isn't just a disappointment; it's an insult to fans, an insult to the legacy of these characters, and frankly, an insult to storytelling itself. Disney, you've not only lost the plot but also the respect of your audience. Season 3 of "What If...?" should have been a celebration of imagination, but instead, it's a cautionary tale of what happens when a franchise loses its way.

OK, as a former Englsuh teacher I am picky about dialogue, and seriously I do not expect them to speak in faux French accents but the actors should have protested about some of the things they have to say. I was cringing at some lines.. I hope it will be repeated later so I can watch all of it.

The cinematography is nothing short of masterful. The use of shadows and muted colours enhances the somber tone of the film, while close-up shots of the characters' faces capture the raw emotion and desperation they endure. The film create an atmosphere that lingers long after the credits roll.nn"Schindler's List" is more than just a film; it's a poignant reminder of the human cost of war and the atrocities committed during one of history's darkest periods. It's a story of suffering, but also of courage and the unyielding spirit of those who fought to survive against unimaginable odds. This film serves as a powerful testament to the enduring impact of history and the importance of remembering those who were lost.

A must watch !! Visionary architect flees postwar Europe and arrives in America to rebuild his marriage, career, and life. He moves to Pennsylvania on his own in a strange new nation, where a well-known and wealthy manufacturer notices his potential. The Brutalist is a 2024 epic period drama film directed and produced by Brady Corbet from a script he co-wrote with Mona Fastvold. An international co-production between the United States, United Kingdom, and Hungary, it stars Adrien Brody as L√°szl√≥ T√≥th, a Hungarian-born Jewish architect who survives the Holocaust and immigrates to the United States, where he struggles to achieve the American Dream until a wealthy client changes his life. The cast also features Felicity Jones, Guy Pearce, Joe Alwyn, Raffey Cassidy, Stacy Martin, Emma Laird, Isaach de Bankol√©, and Alessandro Nivola.

The headline "How to Make Millions Before Grandma Dies" is attention-grabbing but potentially insensitive. While its provocative nature may drive clicks, it risks alienating audiences due to its perceived exploitation of a personal relationship. The connection between financial success and a loved one's death could appear distasteful or confusing without context. To improve, consider reframing it with a more respectful tone, such as focusing on generational wealth-building or financial independence. For instance, "How to Build Generational Wealth While Your Loved Ones Are Still Here" retains urgency without sounding opportunistic. Balancing intrigue and sensitivity is key.

I watch every installment from these directors, as Inside is the cornerstone of French Extremity; alongside Martyrs.nnIt is unfortunate that this film, with its workhouse performances and cultivated atmosphere of dread, proves to be incredibly derivative in its final twist and, crucially, revels in the abhorrent child-related abuse scenes for seemingly nothing more than shock value, or abject vileness.nnIt is a shame, the locations invoke The Wailing in their lonely beauty, the mismatched cops each with a personal stake in child murder reminiscent of Broadchurch or Seven.nnBut with a twist out of Cocaine Bear the film crosses into absurd. Then crosses the line inexplicably into stomach-churning bad taste. Avoid, the juice is not worth the squeeze.

*The Boys* (2019) is a dark, gritty, and irreverent deconstruction of the superhero genre, offering a thrilling mix of action, satire, and moral complexity. Set in a world where corrupt superheroes abuse their powers, the series follows a ragtag group determined to expose the truth. Its sharp writing and bold storytelling challenge traditional notions of heroism, blending shocking twists with biting social commentary. The cast delivers outstanding performances, particularly Antony Starr as the menacing Homelander. While its graphic violence and dark tone may not suit everyone, *The Boys* is a refreshing, thought-provoking, and addictive take on the superhero craze.

The story revolves around Philippe, a wealthy quadriplegic, and Driss, a young man from the projects who becomes his caregiver. At first glance, it seems like an unlikely pairing, but their relationship blossoms in such an uplifting way. Driss brings an exuberance and humor to Philippe's life that he hasn't experienced in years, while Philippe helps Driss discover his potential beyond his challenging background. The movie does a good job at exploring the power of human connection across different social classes and backgrounds. The chemistry between the two leads, Fran√ßois Cluzet and Omar Sy, is electric and genuine. The film is filled with hilarious moments and heartfelt scenes that remind us of the importance of compassion and friendship.

**Bonhoeffer: Pastor. Spy. Assassin.** delivers a gripping portrayal of Dietrich Bonhoeffer, a German theologian and anti-Nazi dissident who became a key figure in the resistance against Hitler. The film explores Bonhoeffer's moral struggles, his faith, and his ultimate decision to join a conspiracy to assassinate Hitler. With a strong performance by the lead actor and compelling storytelling, the movie highlights themes of courage, sacrifice, and the cost of conviction. However, some critics argue it oversimplifies historical nuances and dramatizes events for cinematic effect. Overall, it's a thought-provoking tale of faith and defiance.

Nick O'Brien, the world most boring man, finds an excuse to go to Nice. This class and style averse monkey decides to break bad for the man he secretly loves. Due to his inability to accept himself or anything nice into his life he pretends he's straight like he has been for 47 years, and ultimately destroys the only thing that has made him feel alive. Sad.nnI swear to God nothing occurs in this movie for an hour and a half; there's a lot of macho posturing and Nick being divorced. I cannot stress enough how much time they spend not really even preparing, just kinda hanging out in Nice. Like yeah, seems like fun but get to the point it's a heist movie, though at this point if you told me this was an enemies to friends to crime husbands fanfic I would believe you. Every rambling dialogue scene Nick was in dragged on like he was gonna get an Oscar for this uninteresting, uncultured ball of 1980s machismo.nnAfter that sad hour and half, the real love interest, Ice Cubes son, who is pretending to be a diamond salesman, finally has his balls drop long enough to remember this is an action movie. And when they did, they just dropped all the money on the for like teenagers robbing a pawn shop. I can't believe these are supposed to be professionals. If they had been caught due to their stupidity I would have believed it. Instead, Nicky is a terrible person who hates himself, and betrays them.nnStraight culture killed this movie just like it killed Heat, except Heat is a good movie. If Nick and Donnie had shared their love for each other I would've given this movie a 4th star. But not even gay love could have saved this plot. Boo.

**Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (1999)** is a gripping and long-running procedural drama that delves into the sensitive and often harrowing world of sexual crimes. With strong performances, particularly from Mariska Hargitay as the compassionate yet determined Detective Olivia Benson, the show blends intense storytelling with a focus on social issues. Its episodic structure offers compelling cases, while character development adds emotional depth. Though occasionally criticized for melodrama or formulaic elements, the series excels at raising awareness and delivering suspenseful, thought-provoking content. A must-watch for fans of crime dramas.

First, I'll start with the PROS:nnThe camera work is well done, though it sometimes feels clich√© for the horror genre (how many close-up needle injections and slow-zoomed agonized stares into mirrors do we really need? We get the point!). Sorry, these are supposed to be the pros.nnThe acting is mostly good, especially from Demi Moore (Elisabeth) and Margaret Qualley (Sue). I'll get to Dennis Quaid's character, Harvey, soon. The sound design and its use as a motif are intriguing-the chewing, the soda gulps, the intense soundtrack, etc. It was well-shot, with unique set designs and solid editing. Now, onto...nnThe CONS:nnThe first half an hour or so is okay. Strangely, it is rushed in some places and over-reinforced in others. We're constantly shown how upset Elisabeth is about being an aging star and has a d*** for a boss, yet we know nothing about this company producing this 'substance.'nnAs soon as she gets the black-market drug, things go downhill.nnWho are these people making this new drug? Why doesn't she do a quick internet search and at least get a few reviews before injecting herself with green goo? She doesn't even pay for it. Okay, fine, I'll let that slide- for now.nnThen, Elisabeth splits in two. Is she sharing complete consciousness with a younger version of herself, or is this just an echo of who she was? Does she look like a younger version of herself? If so, then people would recognize her, right? If they have to switch every seven days, with no exceptions, what is the end game? This is why a little setup goes a long way. But writer/director Coralie Fargeat wants to skip all that and get right to the gore as soon as possible!nnThe story's second act is rather basic, and the central theme is tired and overdone: A feminist take on how men are at fault for holding women up to unrealistic beauty standards as they age. Harvey telegraphs this theme to Elisabeth while chomping on shrimp at the restaurant.nnElisabeth's character is not very developed either. We know that losing her looks is eating Elisabeth up inside (some pun intended), but all the character's issues seem to be placed square on the shoulders of everyone except her. It's almost as though she had to take this drug, or her life and career were over. This makes her selfish at best. And I tend not to care what happens to selfish characters.nnDo we really need that much aerobics butt shots of Sue? Do we need that many butt shots in general? We get the point. And why are aerobics shows so popular in this world? Did I miss something? What years is this, 1985?nnEvery man in this story is evil, stupid, or both. Harvey is so over-the-top that I stifled laughter whenever he appeared on screen. Who did this guy's wardrobe?! His character alone took me out of the world of serious drama and into the land of cheesy horror. The old man who signed Elisabeth up for the substance didn't seem to have good intentions. Even Troy, the casting directors, and Harvey's minion execs are mean (but Harvey did a great job training them to sit on cue!).nnElisabeth's old acquaintance she runs into seems to be a nice guy. This could have been a great subplot, but Fargeat makes this man a dull doofus rather than a real shot at Elisabeth finding happiness with a man as imperfect as she is.nnThen there's the ending-one of the dumbest things I have ever witnessed. Fargeat clearly went for the cheap shock factor, tossing out whatever credibility the story had left instead of a poignant message at the end. The final images were unique, but are we supposed to believe that a human head with no body (substance or substance) can crawl and gaze up at the trees while reminiscing? HORRIBLE!nnI know art is subjective, but I can't see how anyone could think this gross, unnecessary film was anything but laughable.nnI gave the film one extra star because of its technical aspects.

Charan is man of the show,shankar sir need better come back,,,thaman Music is not bad,,, helicopter üöÅ shot is gosbum üî•üî•üî•üî•Kiara advani looks good, scene between Charan &sj Surya is üî•üî• üî• comdey not workedüòÇüòÇüòÇ,appana character,,Charan performance at peaks not expected proper ideology üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•ram Charan have select good directors..one man show Anjali Srikanth every actress, performanced good book not detail explanation in story that's main reason of negativety,,, political involvement and anti fans thos don't like mega they all gathered to flop ram Charan,,over all movie is good....whatch and enjoy political drama appana character Kiara advani songs thaman music..

"Thelma" was a truly captivating and unsettling film. I went in expecting a typical coming-of-age story, but the film quickly subverted my expectations, delving into the complexities of sexuality, identity, and the supernatural.nnDelivered a powerful and nuanced performance as Thelma, a young woman grappling with newfound powers and a burgeoning sexuality. Her internal struggle was palpable, and I found myself completely drawn into her journey of self-discovery.nnThe film's visual style was both beautiful and unsettling, perfectly capturing the ethereal and unsettling nature of Thelma's experiences. The cinematography was stunning, with dreamlike sequences that were both visually arresting and emotionally resonant.nn"Thelma" is a film that lingers long after the credits roll. It's a thought-provoking and disturbing exploration of female sexuality and the complexities of the human psyche.nnI highly recommend "Thelma" to those who appreciate films that challenge and disturb.nnDisclaimer: This review is based on the provided information about the film "Thelma" (2024).nnI hope this review captures the essence of your experience with the film!

Never mind Virginia Woolf, she's a lightweight compared to "Martha" (Elizabeth Taylor) as "Nick" (George Segal) and his wife "Honey" (Sandy Dennis) are about to discover for themselves. They've already been at a faculty do with her and husband "George" (Richard Burton) and have gone round after for a nightcap. That's their first mistake as a vitriolic battle of sarcastic and venomous wits is just getting started between their hosts. Initially they are sympathetically embarrassed but then that morphs into something a little more participative as the brandy and the bourbon starts to take effect on everyone. In vino vertitas has never been more true as it emerges that the older couple have a son, the other bugger, and it's clear from early on that something on that front is not right. The younger couple are not immune from the prevailing toxicity and before long they are also starting to question some of what underpins their own relationship. As tempers flare, things become even more unpleasant - even violent, as there are no holds barred and psychological cruelty becomes the benchmark for just about all of them. I saw this on stage and loved it. On the big screen, Mike Nicholls has used his cinematic advantages to make it even more potent. By using the cast together, splitting them off into pairs, changing the location from their increasingly small living room, occasionally involving an innocent bystander to temporarily lessen the stress levels and even pouring some coffee into them, we tell a remarkably hard-hitting story of grief. A festering, poisonous emotion that when not dealt with can grow to throttle just about any relationship - especially if the vintner is on it, too. Taylor and Burton excel, there's no other word for it. Her performance makes the hair on the back of your neck stand up and is perfectly foiled by the more understated but just as brutal characterisation of "George" by a Burton rather benignly bedecked in his middle-aged cardigan - but don't be fooled. Though the plot doesn't focus so much on the others at the start, both Segal and a strong effort from Dennis come into their own too as the ghastliness of their new friends proves contagious and noxious. It's also directed as if we were watching from various points in the room, which adds extra impact as we see things from differing perspectives - but always with a horribly natural flow. It often comes across as a continuous stream of filming akin to how it would be presented live on a stage. This is cinema at it's most visceral with compelling characterisations and dialogue that really does hurt. Maybe don't watch if you've just had a row, or a few drinks, or both? No remakes, please.

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
column4: "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring" is a cinematic experience like no other. The visual splendor of Middle-earth is breathtaking - from the picturesque hills of Hobbiton to the majestic beauty of Rivendell and the ominous atmosphere of the Mines of Moria. Every scene is a work of art in its own right.nnThe actors deliver outstanding performances: Ian McKellen brings Gandalf to life with unforgettable wisdom and charisma, while Elijah Wood portrays Frodo with incredible vulnerability and strength. Viggo Mortensen and Sean Bean are equally impressive with emotionally nuanced depictions of their complex characters.nnAlthough the film doesn't incorporate every detail from Tolkien's novel, it masterfully captures the essence of the story. The adaptations - such as the omission of Tom Bombadil - feel entirely coherent and purposeful.nnWhat makes this film truly special is its emotional depth. Themes such as friendship, courage, and the struggle against darkness are portrayed with such intensity that they resonate long after the credits roll.nn"The Fellowship of the Ring" revolutionized the fantasy genre and set new standards for cinematic storytelling. For fans of epic adventures and masterful narratives, this film is an absolute must-watch!

Someone like Forrest Gump to exist in the wide world is impossible, but there are 7 billion people in the world and I prefer seeing the half full glass rather than the half empty one. But the problem is if you are like Forrest Gump you are considered unintelligent as being real in this world is being foolish. In the movie he is someone with an IQ of 75, and he is denied admission in a normal school as the minimum required IQ to join is 80, but his mother makes sure that he goes to normal school.nnEckhart Tolle talks about living in the 'now' in his book "The Power of Now" and Gump is a perfect example of someone who lives in the 'now' and I think the director or screenplay writer might have used the feather to symbolize it, "like swaying wherever the wind takes it". Forrest Gump's life too sways along with the wind in a positive way, though everyone in the world won't be that lucky. Thanks to the three bullies he gets rid of his crutches, gets a place in the college, football team, joins the army, becomes a national celebrity and also gets to meet different presidents and also ends up doing things nobody does especially when meeting someone like the president (He ends up showing his butts to the president). Gump meets Bubba in the Army and Bubba always keeps blabbering about shrimp. It's that blabbering what defines Gump and his captain's life after they leave army. The captain initially blames Gump for saving his life, as his legs gets amputated in the battle.nnThe most impressive ability of Gump is his ability to love unconditionally, now that's a trait not impossible to find but very rare to find, I am talking about real unconditional love not "you do this i love you, you don't do this i hate you" kinds of love. There is a scene where the girl he loves aka Jane goes naked and make Gump hold her bosoms and he ends up ejaculating within moments, now that shows his passion for Jane. And then there is another scene where she is on a stage naked with a guitar singing and there are men surrounding her expecting her to do some kinky stuff and then there is Gump who feels happy for her watching her sing on the diaz because he remembered her saying to him once that was her dream, "To sing on a stage while everyone were cheering for her." He didn't knew the world enough to understand that it was a different kind of stage and different kind of cheering. Jane doesn't reciprocate his feelings, she does have a soft corner for him but is not ready to make him her boyfriend, maybe because of the abuse she had to face from her father in her childhood, maybe she is thinking she might corrupt his innocence, maybe he might hate her if he knew what kind of a life she lives, maybe she friendzoned him, maybe because he is stupid or maybe there could be several reasons which can be understood only if another movie or book is made or written through her POV. Though in the end when she is dying she wants her to marry him and accept her child which she claims to be his, and Gump marries her and accepts the kid without any second thoughts. Gump never judged her, Gump always loved her no matter what.nnFor being real, loving unconditionally, not hating the world, for always minding his own business the intelligent ones keeps asking him, "Are you stupid ?" and yet he has very little qualms and answers, "Stupid is as stupid does"

"Culpa Tuya" (Your Fault), the 2024 sequel to "Culpa M√≠a" (My Fault), continues the tumultuous romance between step-siblings Noah and Nick, portrayed by Nicole Wallace and Gabriel Guevara. The film delves deeper into their relationship as they face new challenges from family pressures and personal demons.nnCritics have offered mixed reviews. The New Indian Express describes it as "an irresistible guilty pleasure," noting that while it introduces intriguing subplots, it "errs a little too much on the side of caution," leading to a narrative that doesn't fully commit to its potential.nnOn Rotten Tomatoes, audience reactions highlight the film's adherence to "the usual clich√©s and an inconsistent plot," with some viewers appreciating the continuation of the romance, while others criticize its predictability and lack of depth.nnDecider's review points out that the lead actors "find themselves saddled with insipid dialogue and working through nonsense plotting," suggesting that the film struggles to deliver a compelling narrative despite the cast's efforts.nnIn summary, "Culpa Tuya" offers a continuation of the passionate and forbidden romance that began in "Culpa M√≠a." While it provides the drama and intrigue fans might expect, it has been critiqued for its clich√©d plot and lack of character development. The film is available for streaming on Amazon Prime Video.

Don't waste your time to go watch this movie. It is one of the worst movie in the recent times. Bad story with very bad logic and narration. I could have directed a better movie if i had the budget of one of the song from this movie. My Blood pressure is getting increased after the movie. My entire day went waste . I don't know what happened to the film industry recent years. Every one has lost their brains. Shankar who used to be one of the greatest Director of India, i can't believe he directed this film. The producer could have done something better with the budget of this movie. It will be a definitely flop.

Movie is decent but it is not blockbuster or oscar winning performance as they mentioned. An average taking by Shankar with his old elements from his movies 1 time watch. Good acting from all crew especially SJ surya sir and Ram charan sir. Coming to songs thaman did a decent job,It was better than Shankar last movie and choreography for jobs was great good to see but I won't think about high collections may be in long run we can see positive talk if your expectations decrease that might be the reason why Shankar and crew didn't try to promote the film.overall the movie is 1 time watch .I hope this is helpfull.

What a stupid ass movie. What was the point? Where was the plot? In the mood for porn...bingo, you landed. An award winning performance? Omg, no character development, let alone chemistry. So frustrating to pay for a movie that is up for awards that has no depth and a really low-brow porno, sad, crying, feel sorry for yourself ending. I watch so many movies and this is up there with the worst. Ugh. And I never write reviews, but I read a ton. The folks who deem this cinematic brilliance are simply out of touch with what is true brilliance. Just truly aggravated and pissed that I took the time to watch this ugly movie that has no point or value.

Emily (Amy Schumer) gets dumped by her boyfriend right before a scheduled trip to Ecuador. Her tickets are non-refundable, so she ends up taking her mother with her.nnEmily meets a guy at the resort and they make plans to go sight seeing together. Emily and her mom are abducted. They are able to escape from their kidnappers, but must accept the help from two other women staying at the same resort. One used to be in special ops.nnSnatched has some good laughs from time to time, but Amy Schumer does get annoying and much of the humor is juvenile and raunchy. It is good to see Goldie Hawn acting again though.

Despite the fires happening in LA that added an extra layer of suspense, after the first act turning point I was nodding off out of pure bordum.nnThe concept was interesting when the characters were freaking out on the drugs and with the additional tension of the natural disaster.nnHowever,I really don't appriciate the fact that when the cool stuff happend the camera was switched off. Half the time I was squinting at my 55 INCH TV to see what was going on in the darkness. Also I think I need to an advil for the ammount spastic effects going on.nnAdditionally the main character was tremendously unlikeable, borderline R-wordist...If the filmmakers put the script through a few more revisions, and in front of a professional, this would have turned out to be an intresting film. Definitely jumped the shark.

After four, barely-ok movies, finally, Don Bluth made a movie comparable with his 80's classics.nnThe movie follows the formula of a Disney's princess-movie, and I like that, another musical fairy tale about a girl and her love, with cools songs in the middle, the movie fulfills these stuff greatly.nnOf course the movie deviates very, very far from the actual history, I believe Lenin would have been a great villian for this movie, but will face two major problems: First, Rasputin always had a mystic aura around him, so make him a magician was a bit less far-fetched; and second, the movie would have flopped in Russia since Lenin is a respected figure there; getting into politics is risky, and after four consecutives not-so-succesful movies, they wanted to play safe, and actually worked. I mean, I would even feel more comfortable with a nameless villian since Rasputin was never hostile to the Romanov, it feels super off having him as the villian, fortunetly, I really forget about that while the movie flowed, that is of course an achivement of the movie, making you so invested, that you forget you're watching a fanfic that couldn't even get the years right.nnOverall good, if you like the work of Bluth, Disney, musicals, or even cinema in general, don't miss this one.

At first as 99% of the haters would assume the show is brainrot because of the first few episodes, but it is actually giving us an idea on how the virus spreads quickly and how the toilets slowly take control of earth and expand their population by singing their song "Skibidi dop dop dop yes yes" which causes humans to turn and become apart of their race through sound in a very intriguing way, as earth became the Skibidis, the humans were forced to turn themselves into robots in order to not become apart of the army and fight against the toilets as a Secret Agent works in secret with one of the Cameramen to infiltrate the toilets as the Titans create a path for them to do and put an end to the war for good, but there's a bigger threat than just the skibidis. I highly recommend giving the series a try and if you do so, please spread the word on this amazing series.

First half Ok but pre interval and second half extraordinary snake and ladder game between hero Ramcharan and SJ Surya are the highlights of the movie. Songs are excellent especially the dances ramacharan grace is next level. Though you feel it's an old story but due to Ramcharan it got elevated. In some scenes we feel Ramcharan looks as young Chiranjeevi. Kiara was looking gorgeous. Only disappointment is few characters are of no use like vennela Kishore, Jayram, bhramanandam sir, Ramcharan friends and few characters in flash back episode why they used no idea because there is no much comedy chills. Main movie revolves between Ramcharan, SJ Surya, Anjali and Srikanth. With limited characters they could have added more extraordinary scenes.

Positives:nn1. Acting:nA masterclass performance by Allu Arjun.nnRashmika does a decent job, managing to hold her own.nnFahadh Faasil plays his role aptly and seems to enjoy it, but his character design is somewhat concerning and lacks the depth it had in the first part.nn2. Cinematography:nThe movie features clean cinematic visuals, with excellent drone captures of stunning aerial shots.nnThe overall quality is top-notch, with a well-maintained tone throughout.nn3. Jathara Sequence:nA standout sequence where all departments excelled, creating a memorable artistic moment.nnAllu Arjun shines in this sequence, delivering an emotionally charged performance. His dance conveys raw emotions, and his eyes reflect his character's deep longing.nnNegatives: 1. Lack of a Strong Story:nThe biggest issue is the absence of a meaningful storyline.nnThe movie heavily relies on ego clashes rather than building a compelling narrative.nnThe screenplay is a significant blunder, with scenes that seem random and disconnected, leading to abrupt transitions without proper justification.nn2. Direction and Screenwriting:nSukumar appears to have lost clarity, as the film prioritizes everything but progression.nnThe lack of focus results in a series of events that feel aimless and repetitive.nn3. Music:nSam CS's background score adds no value to the movie.nnThe music is underwhelming, failing to elevate the scenes and often making even good moments feel dull.nnThe absence of DSP's exceptional work from the first part is deeply felt.nn4. Unrealistic Action:nPushpa defies Earth's gravity, leaping with a smooth, space-like motion that feels overly exaggerated and disconnected from reality.

But nothing can top the scene of Derek Vineyard (Edward Norton) in the prison shower, as far as the literal meaning of the "f" word is concerned, eh? After observing that, I am very pleased to have avoided the prison experience so far, which was no minor accomplishment in my case.nnI actually liked this film until the ending, and there is no necessity to spoil it, but I found it excessively violent so far beyond proportion to the point that it ironically justified Derek's original, hateful view of the world, which confused me unless that was the film's intention. No wonder there was an alternative ending, which wasn't used in the version that I viewed. Maybe it should have been used after all. I'm not sure if the ending was the primary reason why director Tony Kaye wanted to distance himself from the final production. That is unclear to me.nnI liked the use of black and white to emphasize Derek's original view of the world. As a Jew, I didn't appreciate Elliot Gould's character as a liberal Jewish educator as I found it to be annoyingly stereotypical. Contrary to widely accepted public opinion, we're not all one-dimensional, knee-jerk liberals who act as we are expected to act and who react to events in predictable, stereotypical ways. That is very offensive to me.nnI was very happy to see Beverly D'Angelo in a role that was not Ellen Griswold of the "Vacation" series because I knew that she is capable of much more than that when I saw her as Patsy Cline in "Coal Miner's Daughter". Yes, I'm a fan of both Patsy and Beverly.

One-man show Ramcharan, story old format like Oke Okada movie type story. Screenplay good and song placements are somewhat disappointing and the best NAA HAYARANA song was removed in 1am show lets see if they will add in next show. Ramcharan RAMP in acting. SJ Surya and Anjali acting awesome. Kiara advani acting good. Taman delivered best output. Its an Shankar's markable movie. Really Appana role >>>>>> Chittibabu PEAK acting delivered by Ramcharan. Only the negative thing is all the people around us are waiting for experimental films they stop thinking about the society for those people movie won't satisfy well because the movie plot is in caring society. For Shankar comeback he have to leave all this society messages (In Every Shankar sirs movie there will be a message ) better he stop directing like that and start in new way. Now a days people doesn't care about society.nnB-L-O-C-K-B-U-S-T-E-R.

A director coasting on former glory meets an actor coasting on PR hype and you get GameChanger. Basically there is a faint whiff of a story which is presented as a series of meaningless but rich visuals . The songs that cost 1/4 the budget are so ill placed .There is a female lead whose purpose is unknown .So many elements which are serial level cringe - like how and why and where the heroes mother ends up . This marks the end of Shankar. Ramcharan escaped scrutiny over his ultra disaster acharya that came after rrrr but there is no escaping the rightful ridicule that comes his way for this self proclaimed global star ! AVOID in OTT also.

The writing, both story line and script, is cringeworthy. It started out alright, but got worse although there are some decent cliffhangers and surprises. The main actor's open mouth was beyond distracting. Seriously, gap-mouthed seems to be his go-to acting face and his mouth was wide open the vast majority of the time. WTH?? Overall, though, the acting was decent by most of the cast considering the script they were dealing with. The plot goes off on weird tangents sometimes and seems to be written by someone with no idea what they're writing about. For example, out of the blue, the main character starts reminiscing with the white supremacist's widow about his college days... where he was supposedly in a white frat although he was a black kid with a father in prison. Hmm. Doubtful, but OK. But then his white brothers "kicked his ass" because he "had a child out of wedlock." Ridiculous story, strange word choice, and irrelevant to what's happening in the show at that time. Similar odd scripting throughout the series.

I have to agree with a lot of critics when they say that this film really feels like it's from the 70s. I honestly got confused a few times, wondering if I had accidentally started watching an old film. I even checked the release year twice before I was convinced it was 2023. The way it was shot and the vibe of the movie really captures that older style of filmmaking.nnAs for the story itself, it's not something super new. It's a slice-of-life film, which we've seen plenty of times before. But what makes this movie stand out is the way the characters bond with each other. You can tell the director had a unique vision for this, and the character development feels pretty special.nnOverall, it's a solid film that I think would be great to watch during the holidays. It's not groundbreaking or anything, but it's definitely enjoyable and has a certain charm.

One thing's clear, this isn't a torture like Indian 2, but also nowhere near the standards Shankar has setnIt's just like a passable routine Telugu commercial moviennRam Charan shines as Appanna, that's the lifeline of the movie, otherwise, it's an average outing for him. SJ Suryah tries hard, but writing doesn't offer him much. Why Kiara? Anjali, just okay, rest of all, nothing.nnTechnically, Thaman is the only one who breathes life into the proceedings, but Villain and "UNPREDICTABLE" BGM were terribly overused. Songs were average, but surprisingly, even the picturisation was the same, much hyped "JARAGANDI" was a farce.nnCamera work by Thiru was subpar TBH, never thought I'd say that in a Shankar movie, literally mocobot everywhere. Editing by Ruben and Shameer was fine.nnComing to Shankar, man, it's frustrating and gut-wrenching to see his standards going down, he redefined the commercial genre, but here, despite political thriller being his strong suite, the writing and direction, both were below average.nnBOTTOMLINE : Comeback Shankar wait continues.......

For something in the horror genre this film offers literally nothing. I feel like everyone gave this film high ratings due to it's sexual nature I don't see why else it would at all be deemed as even 'good'. No jump scares, terrible plot, meh acting and nothing gripping about the film just feels weird to watch and had me cringing the whole time. Would've given less than a 1 if I could.nnLiterally the whole way through the feel covering all aspects of what could make a film fun to watch it fails on. Characters aren't all that interesting or relatable.has alot of strange scenes that just make me feel weird not scared or intrigued, and the lack of horror... It's basically non existent.

Goofy, sad, dumb, inspirational, funny... its the anime where you can laugh the most if you are dumb or you are really smart. Its not really for mediocre people who can't laugh at dick jokes, or won't be informed enough to understand that dick joke was a reference to another anime. It can be whole lot of absurd, or have really deep storylines/arcs but its the comedy that keeps this story alive.nnIf you wanna start watching this, my advice is to start watching it from the 3rd episode. You can watch the movies (anime/live action), after finishing the whole thing. There are no ovas or extra stories so far so just follow up through the episode list.
