After the 150ish episodes you can watch the first two episodes. Those were just promotional episodes to make the manga popular, and to see if anybody would watch the anime. They are not really related to plot, other than introducing a bunch of characters really quickly, so you should be good, not watching it at all.nnIf you decided to watch it, welcome to the strawberry milk drinkers club! You will regret this decision soon enough after the serious arcs! (totally not writing this with a half a liter strawberry milk bottle in my hand, right after finishing this series a 153486th time)

"Game Changer"nn**Positives:**nn* **Ram Charan's Performance:** He delivers a powerful and charismatic performance, showcasing his acting range and screen presence.nn* **Visual Spectacle:** The film boasts impressive visuals, grand sets, and high-octane action sequences, typical of Shankar's style.nn* **Interval Twist:** The interval block provides a gripping and unexpected turn of events, keeping the audience engaged.nn* **Supporting Cast:** The supporting cast, including SJ Suryah and Anjali, delivers solid performances.nn**Negatives:**nn* **Predictable Narrative:** The overall plotline follows familiar tropes and clich√©s, lacking originality and depth.nn* **Uneven Pacing:** The film suffers from uneven pacing, with some portions dragging while others feel rushed.nn* **Underdeveloped Characters:** Several characters, including the female lead, feel underdeveloped and lack depth.nn* **Outdated Tropes:** The film relies heavily on outdated tropes and clich√©s, which may not resonate with modern audiences.

column3: "Agios Paisios: Apo ta Farasa ston ourano" (2022) {(#1.4)}
column4: The performance of Dimitris Xanthopoulos defines this episode about responsability, the manner to see the refugies by authorities, the dream of return in Minor Asia and the frustrations and their expressions.nnIn some measure, another episode about Saiunt Arsenios from the perspective of his precious legacy for his people.nnRealistic image of conflicts and nice image of voice of ration. And significant definition of faith as support against pressures.nnA new proof of admirable manner to reflect the life of a comunity in its significant traits. And lovely final, with touch of the presence of Jews in the Promised Land.

I am a fan of the director and even I couldn't bear the poorly made movie. Looks like they sat together the night before the shooting started and put together a story and script in a rush. No comedy and music was also not something we get in a Shankar movie. It also felt like watching a few of Shankar's old movies like Mudhalvan, Indian and Anniyan. Ram Charan is the only saving grace. It's a shocker that they wasted Sunil. The volume was too loud and jarring and that part I am unsure if it was specific to my theater or the recording itself but was such. Also the scenes felt so disconnected. First movie where I didn't have a single laugh or didn't get emotional in any scene.

I didn't hate this movie, but it left me feeling disappointed-and not because of the movie itself, but because it wasn't what was advertised. The trailer promised one thing, but the film delivered something entirely different. If you're going in expecting something that is self-reflective, you'll find yourself scratching your head.nnThat said, it wasn't all bad. There were a few redeeming moments.nnUltimately, this movie is less about being inherently bad and more about failing to meet expectations. If you're okay with being surprised (and not always in a good way), give it a shot. Otherwise, maybe wait until it's streaming.

This is easily one of the BEST of the WORST movies ever made.nnIt has a magical combination of sh!tness in every facet of film-making that can only happen when so many bright-eyed talentless people come together for an unintentional hackfest a la The Room. It almost feels like a prequel/precursor to that film.nnThe racial tropes are hilarious and the love-making scenes will kill any boner. The hastily choreographed action scenes will have you in hysterics. Every character is literally flawed from head to toe.nnI bestow it the absolutely highest recommendation possible. If you enjoyed The Room, you're gonna enjoy Samurai Cop ;).

Impressively, it was a meaty 167 episodes daily drama that left me with conflicting feelings. To get some positives out of the way, I much appreciate the roughness and scuffiness of older dailies over the jaded cleanliness and overly-sanitized modern dailies. It's a good thing that conflicts don't last a long time in this lengthy drama, but this also created a problem I'll talk about later. The drama took advantage of its length in regards to the main point of tension with the objecting parents of the ML, simply, let the girl hang around long enough until they get used to her. Now, let's get into the underlying problems. There was a love triangle involving the 70ish elderly father, his 50ish son, and the restaurant lady, I've never seen such an absurd, trashy and distasteful love triangle like this one before. It's shocking how much screen time they dedicated to that which was for almost the entire runtime. Due to its length, the drama was somewhat divided into 2 halves that were different enough to consider one a downgrade over the other. The exact point that split it into 2 halves was when the pseudo love triangle/square over the FL was resolved. In comparison, the most glaring difference was with the characters' writing of the duo Uk Yeong & Yun Jeong, they made them dumb, quirky, and borderline retarded, just because they were out of the circling conflicts from the first half and had no other roles to justify their existence in the drama. It's clear that its length was problematic. There was a shocking lack of material to fill the runtime. Initially, it had many small side plots that seemed promising but were completely dropped off after a handful of episodes, for example, the rouge sister Yun Ji and her ostracized family. There was only 2 main plotlines running in parallel, whatever was the FL involved in and the repulsive elderly love triangle. This could've been easily fixed since they already had enough pieces laid out. For example, give Shin Hyeong a full family background dynamic to interact with everyone rather than being a random employee with no attachments to anything, replace the elderly love triangle with another involving Wu Suk and other characters, despite the established premise but giving the female lead some familial connections would strengthen her character's existence, and lastly give the lead couples more problems to overcome rather than a couple of elongated ones. Finally, there was a huge lack of affection from the female lead while the male lead was always loud, clear and persistent about his love, she couldn't reciprocate his feeling with the same level if any at all, leaving a constant weird imbalance in their relationship. As if she was pressured to accept his love and run with it, nonetheless, this was less of a problem later on. At the end of the day and despite everything, this was just an okay vanilla daily drama.

The actors are very talented, plus they have an impressive chemistry. The plot of the story is very interesting and full of suspense. It is a k-drama that has everything, it has thriller, mystery, melodrama, romance, a bit of comedy, etc. This drama catches you from the first chapter and makes you want to see what will happen in the next episode, it does not bore you at any time, it makes you cry, laugh, get scared, fall in love with the main couple, among a number of emotions that you experience through its development. The soundtrack is exquisite, the actors are great professionals, the quality of the recording of the scenes and landscapes are good, there are unexpected plot twists that will impress you, in general I loved everything about the drama and I would even like them to make a second season of how excellent this one was. All my support for this k-drama that I consider to have been one of the best of the year 2024, it is a true worldwide success.

On the stormy shore, a white robot woke up from a broken cargo box. It knows who it is, Rose 7134, an intelligent machine assistant created by powerful human technology. But at this moment, it didn't know where it was. The typhoon knocked down the transport ship here, and there was no sign of human habitation on the small island standing in the sea. Wild animals were the true masters here. Rose, who was born to complete tasks, asked one animal after another and even learned their language, but no animal was willing to accept it. When attacked by a brown bear, Rose rolled off the cliff and accidentally killed a wild goose and destroyed its nest. Looking at the only remaining bird egg, Rose carefully kept it. As the little grey goose Little Dot hatched, Rose found a new mission. She had to work with the cunning fox Fink to groom Little Dot into a qualified goose, so that he could fly away with the geese team.

column3: "Secret Level" (2024) {Warhammer 40,000: And They Shall Know No Fear (#1.5)}
column4: Overall, I really enjoyed 'And They Shall Know No Fear'. The visuals were absolutely stunning. The high production value was immediately apparent, with each scene feeling meticulously crafted, from the sweeping battle vistas to the intense close-quarter combat. The environments were rich in detail, and the choreography of the action sequences had a level of polish that made the entire experience feel cinematic. It's clear that a lot of care went into making the episode look incredible, and for the most part, that paid off in spades.nnHowever, one thing that struck me was just how similar this episode is to Astartes, the fan-made YouTube shorts that gained a massive following in 2018-2019. Given that Syama Pedersen, the creator behind Astartes, is credited with this project, it's not surprising that many of the visual and stylistic elements feel lifted directly from his earlier work. The way the Space Marines move, the camera angles, and the focus on raw action all felt reminiscent of Astartes' intense, nearly silent, high-octane action. That's not necessarily a bad thing - Astartes was a fan favourite for a reason-but it does feel like this episode owes a lot to that series, almost to the point of feeling like a re-skinning.nnThat brings me to my slight disappointment with the episode. While I thoroughly enjoyed the action and found the visuals impressive, it did feel a bit like a rehash of Astartes combined with elements of other Space Marine lore. There are so many great storylines and possibilities in the Warhammer 40K universe, yet this episode played it safe by focusing heavily on familiar action beats and themes that we've already seen. It almost felt like a re-make or a polished version of the Astartes shorts, without offering much in terms of new direction or complexity. That left me wanting more-something deeper or more original that could set this apart as its own entity rather than just a continuation of a fan-made series, albeit with a bigger budget.nnThe rest of the episode introduces some interesting concepts, like a Chaos creature tied to the god Tzeentch, who uses the Warp to manipulate the situation and bypass the usual combat. While it added a layer of intrigue, I couldn't help but feel that the main draw of the episode was still the action-Space Marines in all their glory. And while they are undeniably cool, that also brings me to the next issue I had with the episode.nnThe Space Marine focus, while visually appealing, feels a bit shallow when considering the broader lore of the 40K universe. Space Marines are not just genetically enhanced warriors-they are the product of a brutal, often tragic process that turns children into soldiers who will likely never return to their families. The episode could have delved into this more grim aspect, but instead, it continues to present the Space Marines as the heroic, cool warriors we're used to seeing. This disconnect between the idealized version of Space Marines and their dark, harsh reality is one of the core themes of Warhammer 40K, and it's a bit disappointing that it wasn't explored further.nnAdditionally, there are so many other factions within the 40K universe that deserve more attention. While Space Marines get all the glory, groups like the Aeldari, T'au, and even the Imperial Guard are often relegated to the sidelines. These factions are rich with their own stories, struggles, and philosophies, yet they rarely get the spotlight compared to the ever-popular Space Marines. This episode was another example of that imbalance, with the focus largely staying on the Space Marine angle, to the detriment of the larger universe.nnAnd They Shall Know No Fear is undoubtedly a visually stunning and action-packed ride, but it sometimes feels like it's leaning too heavily on established ideas from previous works, particularly Astartes. While the 'bolter porn' and epic visuals are certainly fun, the episode could have pushed the boundaries more, exploring the deeper lore and offering a fresh perspective rather than just reworking what's come before. Still it is very well made and incredibly enjoyable hence the 8* rating.

Sorry, was intrigued by what I read early on about this one---but It doesn't deliver the goods, but instead just takes on a dark kink aura with a propensity to showcase some (perceived), and also displayed graphic violence towards a female android/robot.nnGot brutal enough and graphic enough for me to barely finish but slogged through as it's thankfully a short enough run time. It's not thought provoking or interesting but has that uneasy "uneven dynamic" at times that you may have seen in some early exploitation horror films (ISOYG), say, from the 80s...that are just replacing the final girl/rape victim with a artifical intelligence. Seeing some of these positive reviews gives me little hope for fans of this sort of garbage. Even with the female lead actress, being a real person, it wasn't selling what it was offering to me, that's for sure. File next to "rape-y/beaten woman movie if the week"nnSad that warped enough people exist to recommend this in a public forum. Trash gets trash.

My kids both love Caillou. I honestly can't believe some of these reviews. I would prefer to put this show on instead of many children shows which change screens every 10-15 seconds and are filled with stimulating graphics. I just don't get why you would take it so seriously. IMO anything from 2000s or earlier is best for kids because of the frequent screen jumps and in your face graphics of modern toddler shows.nnAlso I just want to clarify the biggest fan of this show in my household is my 2 year old daughter. Their target audience lol.nnThanks YouTube for free kids shows.

I fully expected Doug Liman to use the two male heroes to make a farce full of laughter, but what I saw was a terrible script with no words. After a seemingly exciting start, the show went downhill. The psychiatrist's forced therapy not only made the two stupid thieves feel embarrassed, but also made the audience feel drowsy as a side effect. Matt Damon, who has not woken up, has a bitter face throughout the whole process, and Casey Affleck, who has not sobered up, talks all kinds of nonsense, one is a sullen and stupid guy, the other is a talkative Gatling, bah bah bah bah bah, it's like a street talk show It also brought various people on stage to announce the curtain, and showed a frowning sense of humor in the same way: all the comedy baggage that seemed to work failed, and Doug Liman's performance was really disappointing.

column3: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 (2012)
column4: Finally, getting around to viewing the final film in the franchise which started both the Young Adult film adaptation explosion and Hollywood's love of breaking up films/books into two films. I wasn't a fan of the first two films but I do think this franchise got better and the director's were given a bigger budget to explore the books better. Like all the films in the franchise, I'm a viewer who thought the supporting characters were more interesting, but never given enough time to shine (but thank god these films were not three hours long to explore that). This film actually ends the way it should have (surprisingly) and I think it was a satisfying ending to a film franchise the way it was set up. I've never read any of the books.

Jim Carrie absolutely KILLED his interpretation of eggman creating some of the most funny and enjoyable scenes for comedic relief. The story writing might have been one of the weaker elements with the predictable betrayals etc and the partnering with Shadow for example, and some things might have not been canon (like Shadow coming from a meteor which is inaccurate he was created by Gerald Robotnik and the Master emerald is supposed to be separate from the chaos emerald not made of them), and theres like one scene where Dr. Robotnik falls where the CGI looks really bad but all of these can be overlooked with the clear passion and dedication that is really shown in this movie. You need to understand that a movie is always going to be an interpretation of the source material and with that I really applaud this movie with it's dedication to trying to be as accurate and canon as possible. Shadows backstory was beautifully and accurately portrayed apart from the asteroid which was a different interpretation. Keanu's Shadow really added that badass dark awesome counterpart to Jim's silly and goofy Eggman. I was so stoked as a diehard sonic fan myself since I was a child to see Sonic battling it out with Shadow. The motorcycle and gun reference from his debut game was SO sick to see and the akira motorcycle slide was such a good touch. I liked seeing sonic's progression in the story from getting his butt kicked by shadow to getting better and going toe to toe as he turns super sonic. It was so badass to see them go super and fight across the world i was GEEKED. I was even more geeked as they team up and fight the robots in space while LIVE AND LEARN WAS PLAYINGGGG. I understand that it's a movie so it's going to be a remix but it was still SO GOOD. ESPECIALLY with the Sonic Adventure 2 reference where they are both super in space. Such an amazing homage to the classic 3D sonic games that would have any diehard sonic fan like myself GEEKED. I have NEVER felt more excited watching a movie before than I was when I witnessed sonic and shadow fighting like dragon ball z characters in space. I was insanely geeked I was quite literally tweaking in pure bliss watching this such an amazing interpretation of the Sonic series. The best so far in the franchise IMO. As well as the ending credit scene introducing metal sonic and amy OH MY GOD THEY BOTH LOOK SO GOOD. Amy has PEAK design she reminded me of Ramona Flowers with her big hammer in the Scott Pilgrim anime on netflix. SHE LOOKS SO SICK, honestly such a good take on a character that was more seen as annoying, she is such a girlboss in that scene it was so cool to see. Plus metal sonic is such a peak character they got him 100% accurate to his source material he looks absolutely menacing and amazing as well. And to top it off they add a SECOND post credit scene which really shows their love for making this movie as good as possible not even Marvel does that anymore including 2 post credits. All in all incredible movie, Keanu and Jim really carried this movie and did an incredible job such a memorable movie might be my current favorite movie in a while.

Addicting show to watch. A thriller, some laughs, heartfelt, rollercoaster of emotions. Plot twists. Most of the acting is really good except for a few characters & situations.nnOne of the better series I have seen but a shade off from perfection. I am surprised I haven't heard much about it. Maybe because it's on Amazon & not the more popular apps.nnIt's definitely an Emmy nominee for a season.nnIt has Better Call Saul vibes but not quite as good.nnI don't have anything more to say about it but gotta fill in the remaining minimum characters to post this. Thank you for reading. Lol. Enjoy this show! Character limit met!

I found this movie full of people disconnected and Delusional. Kidman lacked confidence as a CEO and multiple Orgasms couldn't save her. The milk lapping scene was comical/depressing..Her younger playmate was handsome enough, but lacked sexual energy and/or rhythm needed for this part . Kidmans daughter rescues her when affair goes south as she becomes a couch potato ( pooped from the lactaid & licking fingers ) The movie starts with bad sex and ends the same ~Kidman and her husband trying to connect again to save a dying marriage. Babygirl indeed ~ Kidman acts like a babygirl in need of milk & honey but it does not lead her to the promise land.

It has been a while since I am hooked to a drama. This one has been amazing especially, the lead actors. They were phenomenal. I love the female lead (Cha Soo Bin) but never heard of the male lead, at first, I was too excited about the make lead but I watch it for Soo Bin. As it turns out, they were beyond my expectations. The drama has lots of twist and turns which also made it very interesting and they way that all ties together and it did keep me guessing. This drama had me change my mind about romance thriller. I have been watching the more typical fluffy Kdrama but this was definitely a fantastic surprise. Recommended this 100%.

First of all, this is not a sequel to Frozen. This movie is a disgrace! A true retcon. The story, the characters and the environment have nothing to do with the first part of Frozen or the shorts that were made after it. Not for a moment did I recognize Elsa or Anna as a character, they were two complete insufferable strangers in this movie. This movie was also not averse to gaslighting. I don't know how this movie got through the screening and that nobody said hey this story really doesn't make sense we're canceling it and going to make a good sequel to Frozen. Everyone who worked on this should be fired because they delivered worthless garbage.

Great start, loved the first episode. Gong Yoo, the salesman did great acting and warmed the viewers up for the new season. Unfortunately that very first episode was the highlight of the season. The next episodes should have been about closing the chapter of squidgame season one or at least going somewhere with the next season. But instead it went towards all directions, and none.nnIf the makers wanted to add so much information to the series, they should've made more episodes and short up unimportant scenes. Background information and life stories of transgenders, pregnant ladies, north koreans and ex-marines did also get too much screen time.nnEven votings for presidents would've been faster.nnViewers really couldn't care less about what each and every one of the players voted.nnThe season 2 episodes started with a strong goal for finding who's behind this game and eventually found itself doing the first season all over again. But only now with Netflix's approval/ideas/orders.nnWe have better hopes for s3.

This movie is absolutely beautiful and deserves so much more recognition than it gets. It's one of those rare films that manages to take you on a full emotional journey-truly an emotional rollercoaster. I found myself laughing one moment and crying the next, and the tears came more times than I can count. The story is not only touching but also deeply meaningful, offering lessons that resonate with both children and adults.nnThe storyline is heartwarming and thought-provoking, teaching valuable messages about animal abuse, empathy, and what it feels like to be the "odd one out" in society. It explores complex themes like love, loss, and the fragility of life in a way that feels genuine and relatable. It doesn't shy away from the tough stuff but instead embraces it with sensitivity and care.nnWhen I first watched this movie as a child, it left a profound impact on me, and now, as an adult, it continues to move me in new ways. It's a timeless film with a powerful message that stays with you long after the credits roll.

column3: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)
column4: Before starting my review, I must preface a few things. I haven't read the novel(or the novels), and I haven't thoroughly watched the sequels. Another thing is I know that the writer of the novel(s) is a bit of a right winger bigot, but I haven't taken that into account when reviewing the movie.nnThe movie is definitely a memorable one, mostly due to how good it is visually, rather than having a strong story. Having said that, the CGI in the movie, sadly, doesn't hold up, despite the fact that it came out in the same year as The Lord of The Rings, CGI of which still looks convincing, if not amazing. However, as I said, other than the CGI, the movie looks really good; all the set designs, characters, etc. Just like the novels, this is a film for children, and I have no problem with adults enjoying it, however, I can't think of myself watching this again in the future. There were a few things in the film that bothered me, especially because it's a children's movie, like when they were playing chess towards the end, to pass a gate or something, why did Ron have to ''sacrifice'' himself? He commanded the other pieces verbally, why did he have to ride the knight? Who made the rules? I don't like exposing children to dumb stuff like that. And there were other inexplicable, illogical things like these.nnIt's not an important, a milestone film in cinema, and I am only saying it's overrated, because how popular it is, but it is not too bad of a movie, and I especially understand its nostalgic value for the people who watched this as a kid.

The movie was amazing, the chemistry is so great.nnThe quality of the movie was outrageous good.nnThe imagery the music were of high quality.üé•nI want to see the movie againnI enjoyed it, the whole cast was amazing and talented. I like Baris very much and Hande rocked to movie. The beach the location was so nice üòänThey deserve a high price for the movie üçø Iüé•nI laughed a lot, it was a Romcom with a beautiful line.nnPeople go and see it üôèüèªnThis two acteurs need two play in an action serie it will be bom bom.nnHande is so beautiful sexy and her acting is top.nnBaris is a real man his body languages is so Insane.

It took me a good 3-4 episodes to start enjoying this show but I got there. And went beyond. The way the characters develop and more and more layers are revealed as the story goes is just really good writing.nnAt the very beginning all characters were very one dimensional and none of them really popped. The agent who is the son of the company owner/founder, the diva comedian, the loser writer girl, the cutthroat manager, the housekeeper...etc.nnThey all bring super stereotypical features which are loud and in your face. But then you start to get to know them a little bit better with every episode and it's a beautiful process with a ton of really funny and brilliant dialogues and heartwarming moments.nnThis show really is about human beings and human nature with all its flaws.nnWhile the plot is not super relatable to an everyday person, the struggles, challenges, and feelings of the characters are. And that's what makes this show really great....to me.nnAlso super happy for the recognition this show got from the industry and critics. Can't wait for the next season. üòé

Robin Kazami is the main character of this series, and he is by no means a static character. As an amateur and leader of his team, they were bumped up into pro competition thanks to the beyblade champion himself. Robin has high expectations to be a strong blader, but due to his limited experience at the game, he barely have the title of "blader" at all. As the anime puts it, he has a "100% loss rate". This leads him to struggle balancing the idea of blading for fun and being the strongest at it, but doesn't dwindle his persistence one bit. His biggest character trait is that even though he is met with failure time and time again, he stays motivated and becomes one of the most fastest developing bladers.nnThere are some aspects of the anime that I do not like. One of them is the beys in this series are treated more like hardware than partners compared to the prior serieses.

I am sorry to say that she would be a perfect wife for Dr Merphy because he likes perfection as well She will surely defend him in every situation. It will be funny to see how they find a solution to thier differences and how good her argument maybe to defend them and how good she will be to convince Shawn in certain circumstances . The only unanswered questions is if she also has a good sex drive and excitement as the good Doctor . Amazing episode anyway. This is definitely one of the most perfect episodes this series had offers me after 6 seasons of excitement and pure joy. Good Doctor is definitely Netflix best series actually.

Nosferatu at times successfully creates the gothic atmosphere ghoulishly befitting of the infamous eldritch genre and setting. However, it struggles to tell a tale that surpasses the by-now overdone possession trope, which has aged significantly since the original classic 1922 film, released about a century ago now. What terrified the audience of the past probably only tickles the audience of the present, I felt unmoved by jump scares and the run-of-the-mill macabre imagery of spasmodic convulsions and blood. This retelling of an unauthorized adaptation of Bram Stoker's 1897 novel 'Dracula' takes the story from silent to audible, and certainly ups the visual ante - which goes without saying; but doesn't do much else. Critic and historian Kim Newman declared the original as a film that set the template for the genre of horror film; but this old-school template has since been taken in a hundred different directions, leaving the old classic feeling outshined and simple by comparison.nnSo many nineteenth-century horror novels work on the uncertainty of perception, with darkness, flickering firelight, huge projected shadows, mists and rains, gales and thunderstorms, all obscuring what one can see and hear. Here, the darkness of the lighting is almost always daringly low that it quickly becomes OTT; gas lamps and candles are pretty sparing, even for the early 19th century setting. It was getting to the point where it felt like shuffling around in the dark looking for a light switch, the dark was perpetual and monotonous. Count Orlok (Bill Skarsg√•rd) sounds like he has COPD, taking belaboured inhalations between sentences that listening to his dialogue is borderline grating, the lexicon of the time is used but the Count is rarely insightful or interesting. The other characters' dialogue follows suit, bearing limited resemblance to Stoker's powerful prose. Friedrich Harding (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) and Prof. Albin Eberhart Von Franz (Willem Dafoe) and Dr. Wilhelm Sievers' (Ralph Ineson) exchange about superstition states the obvious tensions between science and magic, these tensions could have been articulated in a far more compelling way as a recurrent theme of the storytelling.nnThe cinematography, set design, and costume design is next level, but without a good story threading it together, these efforts are wasted. The overabundance of greys, blacks, and dark corners is intended to conceal the horrors lying in wait, but because the object of horror is quite predictable, it doesn't land quite as intended.nnOverall, Nosferatu (2024) is missing the right dialogue, modern twists, and impactful screenplay to make it competitive in the modern horror genre. The film could be at least 30 minutes shorter. There are spades more 'creepy' and 'disgusting' or revulsive than truly 'scary', per se.

What a shame it ends after eight episodes. I am seriously bummed. Guy should have been included in the funeral. I know the actor was fired but still they should have brought him back. Also, Guy and Gerald really never had much storylines. I knew what all the other characters were doing for the last 25 years but not Guy and Gerald. Also, turning Guy bisexual and having a fiancee was annoying! They should have utilized the late great Tom Wilkinson. Lomper's husband was hilarious. Robert Carlyle and Mark Addy were brilliant. I really wish we could have more shows. It really was a wonderful series.

I couldn't watch it until the end! I'm sorry, but what on earth was that!? I understand that the world hasn't been fair to women, and it's terrible-it's a critical issue that deserves thoughtful exploration. However, this film completely failed to address it in a meaningful or impactful way. Instead of shedding light on the problem or offering insight, it felt superficial, disjointed, and almost dismissive of the gravity of the situation. It lacked depth, coherence, and the sensitivity needed to do justice to such an important topic. Honestly, it left me feeling frustrated and disappointed!!!!

"When the Phone Rings" is such a beautiful, heart-tugging story. From the very first episode, you get swept up in the mystery and romance, and it doesn't let go. The chemistry between the leads is absolutely magnetic, and their journey from strangers to partners is so touching. Every scene feels real, and you can't help but root for them with all your heart. It's a perfect mix of suspense, emotion, and sweetness that leaves you feeling all kinds of things. By the end, it's like the characters have found a special place in your heart. Truly unforgettable and pure magic! Everything is soo perfect in this drama<3üéÄ

Viewers must be willing to put aside any expectations that every element of a c-drama is plausible. If a person can do that, then this period drama is worthy of your attention. The chemistry between the ML and FL is mesmerizing at times and always fascinating. There are no intrusive second or third couples taking away from the main story arc. That happens to be one of my biggest peeves with c-dramas: spending time introducing new couples to the story rather than developing the main couple's relationship.nnThe quality of The Double has made it one of my favorite Chinese period dramas, along with The Story of Yanxi Palace. It is no coincidence that the same actress stars in both dramas: Wu Jinyan. She helps make both dramas soar. In The Double, she and her male costar, Wang Xingyue, convincingly portray a woman and a man who develop a strong connection based on mutual respect.nnI like happy endings and not ambiguous ones, so this is the one aspect of The Double that I will 'knock.'. I will say no more, other than to encourage to give this drama a try.

Flow, directed by Latvian director Gints Zilbalodis, is a captivating white-knuckle survival adventure set in a world on the brink of ruin. Told entirely without dialogue, the story follows a cat evolving from self-preservation to solidarity with a motley crew of other species. Acquired out of Cannes for North America by Sideshow and Janus Films, Flow is a piece with Zilbalodis' 2019 debut Away, both being silent movies and oweing a debt to animation master Hayao Miyazaki. The new work drops characters designed in classic cartoon style into ravishing photo-realistic environments, resembling the woodsy landscapes of Danish artist Peder M√∏rk M√∏nsted. The cat at the center of the story is a skinny gray feline of indeterminate gender, clever and resilient but also skittish. It discovers the origin of the artworks in an isolated cottage with a wood carver's workshop and eventually climbs onto higher ground, eventually scaling the sculpture that dominates the skyline. Flow is an eventful journey, propulsively paced yet never rushed, giving breathing room to nail-biting interludes and more touching moments. The cat hops onto a beaten up sailboat and travels up a swollen river, gradually adapting to the challenges of this new waterworld. The animals pass ruins of what appears to be a grand ancient city with a massive amphitheater that's home to a colony of lemurs, each of them sporting its own found treasures as accessories. Flow is a film that explores the transformation of all animals on a boat, except for the capybara, who remains a simple, easygoing animal. The labrador, a smarter and more alert dog, becomes more alert to the safety of its fellow travelers. The cat, the most perceptible change, cohabitates with other species, fostering a communal spirit. The film is suitable for children and adults, as it demonstrates the importance of friendship and mutual trust. The animation by Zilbalodis and L√©o Silly-P√©lissier creates a picture-book world amidst natural disaster and death, with vibrant textures and enchanting underwater scenes. The visual aesthetic is polished, yet the film still manages to appear both technically accomplished and hand-crafted. The attention to movement is extraordinary, with graceful, controlled camerawork and character detail resulting from extensive study of each animal's behavior and physicality. The score by Zilbalodis and Rihards Zal shifts from beautiful passages of percussive melody to flights of stirring strings, blending humorous observations with moments of high anxiety or tragedy. Flow is a joy to experience and a deeply affecting story, the work of a unique talent who deserves to be ranked among the world's great animation artists.

I picked up this series as a second-hand DVD. It had Charles Dance and Claire Skinner from Outnumbered in it so it looked promising. Well, there you go.nnTake 2 cups of the 1970s Confessions sex comedies, a couple of tablespoons of Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure, 100mg of Brideshead Revisited, a dash of Grange Hill, a few pinches of James Bond and a soup√ßon of Phantom of the Opera. Mix it all together and what you have is a nasty brown sludge.nnIt was filmed in 2009 but it has a real 1970s vibe to it. Plenty of gratuitous sexism, racism and classism and a chunk of sexual assault. The one black guy gets off fairly lightly but there is a gormless Welsh girl with the world's worst mock-Barry accent, and a pair of 'comedy' oriental girls, to name but 3.nnThey have shamelessly aped Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure in the 2 ostensibly comic characters, though what they are doing in such a supposedly august college only the script writer knows.nnThe mad scientist has a cupboard full of puppets which he has to burn on a bonfire. We never find out why. It's a pity, as they were less wooden than most of the acting.nnThe screenplay seems to have been written by a teenager. One of the students dies, and inexplicably is given a sort-of Viking funeral in the school grounds.nnThe secret society which forms the heart of the plot is called the Dandelion Club. Another old name for this wild flower is Piss-the-bed. They certainly managed that with this series. I expect Charles Dance and the other proper actors wish they could burn every copy of this horror.

Whole story is a life lesson.nnI'm baffled that this show only sits at a 7.5 on IMDb. "Your Honor" is a masterpiece of television that surpasses the dramatic intensity of giants like "Breaking Bad," "Ozark," and even "Better Call Saul."nnThe acting is absolutely phenomenal across the board, and the writing is some of the most gripping and intelligent I've ever encountered. The show masterfully explores complex moral dilemmas and keeps you on the edge of your seat with every twist and turn.nnThe ending? Simply breathtaking. It's the most satisfying and emotionally resonant conclusion to any show I've ever witnessed. I literally stood up and applauded in my living room. And that song at the end.... Jesus what was that! Probably best closing song theme ever!nnIf you appreciate masterful storytelling, exceptional acting, and shows that will stay with you long after the credits roll, "Your Honor" is an absolute must-watch.nnNote: This review reflects your personal opinion and may not be universally shared.nnI hope this review captures your sentiments effectively!

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)
column4: I wanted to rate on the whole series as that is one movie in total, but need to put the review somewhere, and what better than the final chapter.nnThis is the greatest movie that has ever been made and 24 years down the line, is still, the greatest movie. Probably 100 years from now it will still be the same.nnThe story telling, cinematography, dialogues, acting, actions, the background score - Peter has left no room for any further improvements. You get drawn to the story, get drown in emotion with the characters, you cry with them, you cheer with them, you laugh with them. Each movie is 3 and half hours+ in length, but you don't get bored. If anything, once yu are done watching, you feel and emptiness - that it's ended. You need to wait another 15years for your brain to forget this so you can rewatch it again ..nnSalute to you Peter, Salute to you Tolkien ..

There's not one thing about this drama I didn't love. I never watch ongoing dramas. But this one got me hooked so much since episode 1 I kept waiting for an update every week. And it was totally worth it!!!!nn!!!!!!!!!CHAE SOO BIN and YOO YEON SEOK made every week fun and entertaining. Their chemistry was so good that now I want to keep seeing them working together on new projects. This masterpiece of a drama deserves more recognition. The plot, the acting of both lead actors, the direction, the ost everything is just top notch. Will remember this drama for a very long time. Love it so much!!!!

Most of the time, when watching a movie-even one based on real events-it can be hard to imagine how those situations might occur in your own life. However, with this movie, even though the specific pain of the Holocaust is not something I've directly experienced, I was able to empathize with the characters' emotions and see how similar dynamics play out in my daily life or in the lives of those around me.nnI believe this connection is largely due to how the story is told. Instead of revealing the characters' histories and emotions all at once, the movie creates a sense of duality. This is achieved through excellent dialogues and Jesse Eisenberg's direction, which ensures that every scene leaves a significant emotional impact on the viewer.nnSpeaking of the performances, both lead actors were outstanding, but I believe Kieran Culkin stood out the most. His portrayal allowed the audience to understand the layers of his character while also leaving room for ambiguity. Jesse Eisenberg also delivered a strong performance, though it felt somewhat familiar, resembling his usual "quirky" or "awkward" character archetypes seen in previous roles.nnThe supporting characters and the way their relationships and opinions about the main characters evolve throughout the movie-depending on the events and revelations-are another highlight. This is a great achievement of the script, which adds depth not only to the main characters but also to the movie as a whole.nnIn the end, much like the journey the characters go through, watching this film was a sensitive yet enriching experience. It allowed me to grasp the deeper complexities of the story and its emotional resonance.

I'm rewatching this show for the second time since season 3 is coming out soon, that being said I remember finishing this season and not really caring for a season 3. At this point every plot is moving way too slow, there are so many scenes that don't add anything to the plot or story or character development. This show presents itself as a dark, psychological thriller we're the characters are forced to do horrible disturbing things, with a little bit of supernatural aspect to it as well. I'm anxiously waiting for the show to reach the point of where they are actually hunting eachother and doing the messed up things they are always hinting they did out there to survive. At this point I hate Travis character. He is such a whiny baby that every 5 minutes has a new stick up his butt & blames Natalie, who is always nagging him. It's unrealistic to me that her character would be so d*ck whipped and into babying him. His character and casting truly is the worst part of the show for me. They take up so much time of the show and that's just one thing that is beyond annoying me about this show. Misty's new friend is insanely annoying and acts like a Disney character. If they want people to stop making fun of them, they would realistically try harder not to be weird annoying losers. And the all time worst part of the show is Shauna's ugly, mean unlikable daughter who dresses like she shops at Fred Meyer. ANOTHER unrealistic part of the show. Teens don't dress or act like she does and if they do they don't have boyfriends or go out or even have friends. The angsty teen who is always mad at her parents is such an old cliche I wish shows would stop doing. If I treated my mom that way I wouldn't have a phone or even a bedroom door.nnOverall, that being said the show needs to focus on the actual plot and point to it. That they did messed up things out there and they need to hurry up and get to that part in season 3.

This movie has insurmountable flaws in my view. The most problematic for me was Paul Mescal's unconvincing rage. The original film succeeded largely on the strength of Crowe's performance in the Maximus role. The character was underwritten, but Crowe's glowering made for a compelling revenge tale. Here, Mescal is too mild and lacking in the intensity needed to carry this film. I'm sure the plan was for Washington and Pascal to subsidize the charisma that Mescal lacked, but they are too peripheral to the story to properly compensate for a weak lead.nnThe elegant simplicity of the original film is replaced here with a convoluted plot where the motivations of the characters are often not given enough emphasis. Maximus wanted to kill Commodus to get revenge in the original. No matter the complications and subplots, the original film succeeded by giving Maximus's revenge plot its primary focus. Here, however, everything is too scattered. Lucius ostensibly wants revenge for his wife's death, but this isn't given much attention and doesn't even carry through to the film's conclusion. Instead, the protagonist's goal shifts and the antagonist that he should focus on is rarely clear. This results in a narrative that I personally found only sporadically interesting.nnEven when it comes to surface-level pleasures, I feel the film largely comes up short. I didn't expect any lines as iconic as "Are you not entertained?" or "Am I not merciful?" That said, the dialogue was simply excruciatingly longwinded and lacking in texture or depth. Who would ever quote a line such as "The best revenge is to be unlike him who performed the injury?" Even when uttered by Denzel Washington, the dialogue is simply not attention-grabbing. The performances are inconsistent with each other with every actor's style clashing with the others. Denzel is the most charismatic, but he makes little attempt to blend in with the setting.nnSpeaking of setting, watching this back to back with the original film serves to emphasize how lacking in detail and texture the sets are in this film compared to the original. The furnishings and costumes are sparse and uninspired here, sadly. The action scenes, likewise, are mediocre at best. Given the complaints of rampant historical inaccuracy, one would expect Scott to at least strive for enthusiastic action schlock. The fights, however, are uninspired in their choreography, utterly lacking in stakes, and grimly predictable in their execution. There wasn't a moment that quickened my heartbeat or inspired more than casual interest on my part. If you're going to flood the Colloseum with bloodthirsty sharks, forget about restraint and give the audience a great time for heaven's sake!nnAt almost 2 1/2 hours, I was mostly not entertained, thank you very much, Maximus!

I loved how I anticipated this drama to release every Friday and Saturday! It has been a while since a drama has made giddy with each weeks release! I had read the novel before and was excited to see be adapted into a drama especially with actors that I know will do it justice. And they did not disappoint! They embodied the characters very well and had me immersed in their story and rooting for them.the story was filled with a plot full of suspense, romance, pain, fear, comedy, and love. Truly one of the best drama to end the year and start a new one with. The series brought up many conversations about the plot within my family and it was great to watch it together.

I love this drama and has taken me out of my Kdrama slump! I have not seen one this good in a long long time. I think that if they had 16 episodes, the ending wouldn't have felt so rush and would have explained the last episode better, but since I read the Wattpad version, I understood the why's of the last episode. I love Yoo Yeon Sook and Chae Soo Bin! They are both such a phenomenal actor and actress!!! Their chemistry is unlike anybody I have watched before. I don't think anybody could have done their characters justice, they have exceeded my expectations and I am really going to miss them. This is a drama I have and can re-watch over and over again.

The movie felt incredibly unplanned and disorganized, lacking a clear direction throughout. It was obvious that the film was rushed to release before it was truly ready, as several plot points were left unresolved. A prime example of this is the opening scene, which is set as a flashback but is never revisited or explained in the course of the movie, leaving viewers confused and disappointed. This oversight speaks volumes about the lack of proper planning and attention to detail in the storyline.nnAfter the massive success of the first part, expectations were sky-high, but this sequel falls short in every aspect. The narrative feels fragmented, and the pacing is all over the place, making it hard to stay engaged. It's clear that the film relied heavily on the success of the first installment to drive its box office numbers, rather than delivering a solid and well-crafted story. The lack of a cohesive script and a clear vision for the characters and plot makes this film feel like a missed opportunity.nnUnfortunately, the movie's only saving grace is the momentum built by the success of Pushpa 1. If not for that, this sequel would have struggled to find any sort of traction with audiences. In conclusion, this film is a major letdown.

I personally think this is the best K-drama I've seen so far. It's in my top 5.nnGreat actors, great team I mean... I was excited when I first watched the trailer and that's why I decided to subscribe to Netflix again hahahaha just to watch this drama and for me none of every single episode was boring but exiting.nnI was going crazy just to have to wait every week to find out what's going on but the wait worth it. I liked how all their worries were all solved at the end and they could live a happy ending. So I truly recommend this drama and for me I'm going to watch yoo yeon-seok and chae soo-bins' dramas cuz I loved them in this one.

Kaufman's writing here is out of touch and disjunct, feels like he's just exercising his perverse views rather than understanding what makes a great flic for this age group. A 5th grader afraid of the dark? Is this just more netflix meddling? Can't be only that. There's just too much dogma. Moreover the level of introspection for a 5th grader is plain overblown and resembles Kaufman's sicko mind than anything. The voice acting sucks. The character design sucks. The music is ok but still weak. The structure of the story sucks. I can't find anything positive to say. Massive let down. Don't waste your time. Don't let your kids watch this drivel.

Velma is an interesting and refreshing take on the classic Scooby-Doo universe. The show is funny, with sharp humor and moments of good jokes that stand out. The modernized take on the characters is bold and mostly enjoyable, but one significant change didn't sit well for me: Shaggy's. While the new interpretation of his character might resonate with some, I missed his silly hungry personality and iconic visual design.nnAnother major letdown was the absence of Scooby-Doo. His presence has always been central to the charm of the series, and not having him felt like an omission. The rest of the cast was handled well, and the story was engaging enough to hold my attention. While I appreciate the effort to bring something new, retaining more of the original essence, especially with Shaggy and Scooby, would have elevated the score.

The movie tells the story of L√°szl√≥ T√≥th, a Hungarian-Jewish survivor of the Holocaust, played by Adrian Brody. He moves to America and struggles to deal with his past and build a new life. The film's story is beautifully woven together with stunning architectural designs, which represent the main character's journey and the idea of legacy.nnPeople who have seen the movie are praising the actors, especially Adrian Brody, who gives a complicated and nuanced performance. The supporting actors, including Guy Pearce and Felicity Jones, are also doing a great job.nnThe movie's cinematography, music, and direction are also getting a lot of attention. Brady Corbet's vision is both personal and grand, making The Brutalist a must-see on the biggest screen possible.nnOverall, The Brutalist is an amazing film that will keep you thinking long after it's over. With its important themes, beautiful visuals, and great performances, it's no wonder this movie is being called one of the best of 2024.nnThe movie's ability to balance big themes and personal stories is also worth mentioning. It's a film that will make you feel and think, and it's definitely worth watching. If you're looking for a movie that will challenge your thoughts and emotions, then The Brutalist is the perfect choice.

I was 6 years old when I was watching it on my VHS! It was in a time that life and family situation were not so pleasant. Because I was watching The Lion King at least 6-7 times every day I was somehow able to manage through the rough times! This is my ultimate favourite movie! Because of the depth and wisdom, because of the songs and characters, because of the way that was drawn! I really miss that with the animations nowadays! Kids don't need live-animation they would understand the normal animation better and it would look to them more appropriate as they are kids! Lion King have it all!!!!

First of all, producing AI robots on a large scale with such shoddy programming and lack of security, that a user can mess it up accidentally-by pushing the fricking power button, no less!? Facepalm. The laws of robotics, anyone?...nnSecondly, a domestic/nanny robot with long nails, lush lashes, pouty lips and a sexy li'l maid's uniform? Was this movie written by horny teenage guys? Well, at least they gave it sensible shoes, right?...nnAnd as for cyber security, plugging a malfunctioning data core into a mainframe with internet access? Seriously?? Ever heard of a sandbox?nnThe plot, such as there was, was thin, messy and full of gaping holes. This could have been done so much better.

Synopsis of this review - While the overall movie is visually stunning and seems promising in the beginning with a lot of scientific jargon thrown in good measure, you have a feeling at the end of the movie that many of the scenes are forced and the script writers are found lacking in terms of the premises they chose (the movie would have still made sense without the OCD part), the way they force scenes onto you just to make their job easier and a lack of logic throughout.nnSome of the questions I was left pondering over at the end of the movie:nn1) Why OCD?nnHaving watched films like 'North 24 Kaatham' and 'Hey Jude' just to mention a couple of them in Malayalam, this movie really doesn't require that premise to carry the story forward. It was probably used to confuse the viewers, but at the end of the day an air marshal would find it difficult to operate if he had OCD. It is very likely that the rigorous screening to get into such a job would filter out such people, whether you like it or not. You don't need to have OCD to be a good sketch artist or an air marshal. On the contrary, you would expect people with OCD have a tough time concentrating, among many other shortcomings, for doing such a job. Being a perfectionist is different from having OCD. If this was done to get the viewers to sympathise with Haran, I would say he didn't need.nn2) Writers resort to a form of 'deus ex machina' or a form of 'plot convenience'?nnA) The antagonist randomly gets to live in the same building as the antagonist and the protagonist then gets assigned for no obvious reason to sketch in a police investigation in front of the antagonist. Would have made a lot more sense if this was all planned by either one of them.nnB) How was it that all the witnesses were on the same flight without neither the police nor the army knowing?nnC) How could the antagonist be sure that the plane would crash for sure, and even if it did, that all the witnesses would die especially on the ground? Blackmailing one of the pilots would have made more sense.nnD) Mentioning during one of the most important scenes that the projected super villain is not the real one in just one dialogue.nnE) This is a sensitive topic, and even the supervillain had doubts with this. Would the threat of posting explicit videos of a family member drive people to commit to such extreme obedience? This seems like it is from the 80s 90s era. It can still happen now, but you can't be sure.nnF) Alisha being hit by a truck randomly?nnG) Hard drive corrupted because Allen was in the XRay room? Too convenient?nn3) Logical failures?nnA) Why did Alisha think that Haran was trying to kill her? She clearly saw the molester blackmailing the ATCO before Haran burnt down the warehouse.nnB) Why did Haran draw his own portrait the first time? Allen was smoking in a corner and not looking at the sketch. Haran could have easily modified the sketch to look like someone else. I understand that it was a revelation to himself that Alisha was a witness, but still could have managed to pull this off being as smart as he is.nnC) After Haran manages to run Allen off the road into a cliff during the car chase, he seems to be not looking at the road and then when he looks back holds his arm covering his head as if to suggest an impending collision. But later it is shown that he walks out of his car to check on Allen and he gets shot right in his chest which looks lethal with blood splattering. A couple of scenes/days later Haran is shown perfectly alright.nnD) If it was that easy for Allen to adopt a new identity and vanish into thin air, why go to all this trouble?nnE) Haran being such a great sketch artist should have got Alisha to describe the face of the ATCO and sketched it himself and let someone else match it with the passengers rather than letting her figure it out knowing that she has problems with just that.nn4) Random musings/Loose threads?nnA) What was Haran planning to do by picking the lock of the apartment Alisha was living in? Does not show any clear motive.nnB) I'm not entirely sure about this and I'll give the benefit of doubt to the writers. But if Allen spoke to Alisha when he came to pick her up assuming she would think he is Haran because he was disguised as Haran, I'm sure Alisha should have been able to differentiate them with their voice. If this scene is not in the movie it could have been used to elevate the movie by portraying that she is in doubt.nnC) What was the chain that Allen handed over to Mandira Bedi and what was their relationship?nnD) Why the fascination with r*pe videos used as tools to control people?nnE) Why cut short the narrative of Alisha having mistaken Allen for Haran (which would have made the film's title 'Identity' a lot more sensible) so easily in a few scenes? Starting the movie with mistaken identities and then finally setting them right would have made the movie superlative.nnConclusion - I only went to the trouble of writing this long review because I saw potential. I would like to end by quoting Ranga Annan - 'Shradhikkanam Ambane!'.

It's a gritty; raw; street-smarts' movie/biopic on the most formidable hip-hop powerhouse unit of all-time; Niggas With Attitude or NWA!nnThere is exceptional casting where the actors actually resemble the people they are playing. They can actually deliver lines and spit and it's authentic and street-worthy and it's so incredibly real. It's really hard to make these authentic and this is about as close as they can do it.nnProduction-wise it's on-point and I LOVE the vinyl/label pressing plant. That's some seriously nice vibes. There is the usual excess and debauchery. It's also paying homage to the timeline and I loved the fact that Tower Records is included (rip)!nnIt's an incredibly hard job to do a biopic and if you want to see a bad one see the CBGB's one. This is just a great film. Of course it's never going to be perfect but I enjoyed this as much as the Elvis one as it was just sheer entertainment and fun!nnA street-worthy biopic with atttitude and charisma which punches hard. 8/10. Corey Hawkins really personified Dr Dre. What a deliverance.

"Requiem for a Dream" is a harrowing and unflinching descent into addiction. Aronofsky masterfully crafts a portrait of despair, showcasing the devastating impact of drug abuse on four interconnected lives. Jared Leto, Jennifer Connelly, and Ellen Burstyn deliver career-defining performances, their raw vulnerability and physical deterioration both horrifying and mesmerizing. The film's visual style, with its jarring cuts and distorted imagery, perfectly mirrors the characters' fractured psyches. While undeniably disturbing, "Requiem for a Dream" is a powerful and unforgettable cautionary tale about the destructive nature of addiction and the importance of hope in the face of despair.

Great movie from start to finish. Highlights the emotions and sensitivities of sexual assault from perspective of both victim and perpetrator in the most convincing manner with stellar script, acting & direction.nnFiona Palomo was amazing and Alfonso Dosal was also brilliant. There were many points in this film where I forgot these two were acting altogether, even though they were both playing actors in the film.nnThis film is high impact, including sensitive moments with tears to unexpected twists in a plot that came together seamlessly.nnBest Mexican film since Roma and better in my opinion.

Yeah - don't get it. With an 8.2 score on iMDB you'd think this would have more on offer than cinematic goose fat. The beginning is unbelievably unengaging, you never buy Russel Crowe's character, until he's aged suitably old enough where his crumminess becomes naturally organic. Maybe it's because they let Crowe speak in his native Australian pipes, that's where the issue comes in, as it sounds dissonant when every other actor doesn't have this offputting mumble to their line deliveries. It does pick up a good swing to itself in the latter half, where his schizophrenic condition takes centre stage and Jennifer Connelly has to put on the nanny act as the wife, every time Ed Harris shows up it becomes fun and even comedic to imagine how this all looked on set. Maybe I'm just too unmoved to have any expressed sympathies for the real story of John Nash, an esteemed mathematician who lived and died in esteem, because everything I took out of A Beautiful Mind is likely the wrong message.nnI will say, even if this does spell out little I cared for the actual content of the film itself, that I like the poster they use for it, where Crowe takes up half the image and you see a small shadowy of Ed Harris, blurred into oblivion, only identifiable by his black fedora. It gives a nice touch to the subplot of John Nash wrestling with his debilitating schizophrenia condition, like phantoms are always entrapping him, keeping him stuck in his own mind that isn't actually all that beautiful. Even in the supposedly triumphant ending, when his longtime friend at Princeton University haggles John's wife along with him to watch the man - in his seventies mind you - talking to a table of students still in that mumble mumble voice, and since he's talking to them openly and without death daggers you're supposed to have tummy flutters. Except he's still conversing and explaining as though he's the most shaken-up, neurotic teacher in the world, a mathematical genius who presents himself as though there's no correct solution to anything.

This is my first Bones review! Hubs and I watch Bones every night as our comfort show to fall asleep.nnThe bachelorette party in this episode is super fun! The girls wearing their bright colored country outfits in contrast to the bikers dark colors and leather was a striking choice.nnDaisy's one liners are hilarious in this episode: "We're homies!" "I've been called a skank!"nAnd I laugh every time at drunk Bones admiring how soft her furniture is and Booth telling her if they did "those things" in the tub she would drown, üòÇ and when she says "I thought it was Moose's motorcycle." I die. Every time.nnAnd of course, as always, Angela helps us see Bones' personality.nnPS I am loving the Bones Booth.

I am not one to usually write reviews, but this is one of the best dramas I've ever seen in a long time since CLOY! Although it had a lot of great competition with other 2024 KDramas; it still surpassed them all! LOVED the chemistry between the leads, which is often rare to find, to the point that it seems so real just like CLOY!! The cliffhangers at the end of each episodes left me wanting more and couldn't wait for Fri&Sat to come around. My only wish was that the episodes were longer, either 16 or 20; but they did their best in fitting everything in their final episode. Most kdramas have always had this issue of having a strong ending, but I loved how they tied up everything neatly. Still can't move on from this one! Def at the top of my list with CLOY and Boys over flowers.

It's not every day you see a cartoon that exceeds your expectations as much as this one does. Jentry Chau is one of the best shows I've seen in a while, and it deserves more attention. Everything about it is excellent, from the killer soundtrack to the stylistic animation to the engaging characters to the extremely well-developed lore. And although it's aimed toward teens, it's a show people of all ages can enjoy.nnJentry Chau is a teen girl who has to deal with the drama of high school while fighting off demons trying to kill her for her powers. She's helped by her great-aunt, a powerful Daoist priestess, and a shape-shifting demon. But the coolness of the premise doesn't stop there. Jentry not only defeats ghosts and demons, but she also uncovers the mystery of her parents' deaths and explores stunning yet terrifying new realms. The show does an amazing job at balancing the plot with the world-building, introducing new conflicts and new settings with each episode.nnPlease give Jentry Chau a chance. Netflix has a nasty habit of cancelling great shows before they have a chance to reach their full potential, and the only way to keep that from happening is showing your support for the show. If you're a fan of fantasy, coming-of-age stories, or Chinese mythology, Jentry Chau vs. The Underworld is definitely worth your time.

The director has put in a lot of effort in making this movie. The storyline is unique. The first half is about story development and character build up whilst the second half is about emotional aspects.nnThe film's emotional resonance was palpable, with moments of joy and sadness. Its a testament to the filmmaker's skill that they could evoke such strong emotions in the audience.nnThe movie explored complex themes with thought provoking insight, encouraging viewers to reflect on thei own values and beliefs.nnBGM and music also gives the best support throughout the film. The technical aspects of the movie were simply brilliant. The cast delivers powerful performance that brought depth, nuance and authenticity to their characters.

This kdrama deserves a standing ovation! The actors are phenomenal, with Yoo Yeon Seok delivering the ultimate dream husband and Chae Soo Bin shining brilliantly in her role. Their chemistry is off the charts, making every scene a delight to watch. The story is incredibly engaging, keeping you on the edge of your seat as you try to predict what will happen next. It's a masterpiece that has me rewatching episodes while eagerly awaiting the next one. The excitement and anticipation are unmatched. This drama is a must-watch! üòçüíó If you haven't seen it yet, you're in for a treat. Highly recommended!

A soaring, emotional and cinematic experience that will certainly have you captivated, especially if you are a history buff or a fan of world war 2 history and the post war era. It's raw, bringing in so many elements of that turbulent period, while also giving an empathetic view of the experience of the Jews who had to start a new life as immigrants in an America where antisemitism was still alive and well. I was worried about the run time being a little long, but I didn't feel it at all. This one will definitely stay in my mind for a while. Recommending it to all my history buff friends. So relevant for our time.

This drama is a masterpiece that keeps you emotionally invested from start to finish. The tension in each scene is palpable, and the actors' performances are nothing short of extraordinary. They bring their characters to life with such authenticity and presence that it's easy to forget they are acting. The chemistry among the cast is electric, making their interactions feel incredibly genuine and adding depth to the story. Every scene is meticulously crafted, showcasing the dedication of the entire team. The lead actors truly shine, carrying the show with their exceptional talent. Their performances left a lasting impression on me, and I'm already on my second watch. This drama is a must-watch, and I highly recommend it! üòçüíó

Among all the dramas accessible in 2024, I think this is the greatest.nnGenerally, there will be no dull episodes. At first, I was intrigued by the drama's title.nnI am a picky viewer, and I became easily bored when the drama's first episode was dull and uninteresting and also when the actors delivered cringe-worthy performances, I dropped the show and did not continue watching. But this drama kept me interested from start to finish and I looked forward to viewing every Friday and Saturday on Netflix.nnThe lead actors, Yoo Yoon-Seok and Chae Soo-Bin, have excellent chemistry as well as the second lead.nnAll the cast deliver convincing portrayals.

I absolutely love this drama! It had me hooked from the very first episode, right till end. The waiting for more episodes was torturous but so very worth it. Every single episode kept me wanting to see more. And the FL and ML, what can I say - both their performances were chef's kiss! There were so well suited to one another, and so believable too. Their on/off camera chemistry was off the roof. And the ending was soooooooo SATISFYING!! This drama has left a lasting impression on me. I give it a 100/10.nnA few more episodes would have been so appreciated. But this girl right here is very much satisfied:))

Ooh, boy, do I have a lot to say about Chicken Little.nnWhat's the story?nnChicken Little is a pariah among the townspeople of Oakey Oaks because of how he mistook an acorn for a piece of the sky and caused mass hysteria. After one year of being tormented by the extremely petty townspeople, he suddenly wins their affections after winning a baseball game. After this, aliens land on Earth and leave their child behind. Chicken Little, his friends, and his dad (who believe me, we WILL get to later) have to return the alien child to his parents before the town can be destroyed.nnThat's the first issue with the movie. The story is so disjointed and lazy. First, it's about an outcast kid trying to prove himself to everyone around him. He accomplishes that in the first 20 minutes. Then, all of a sudden, it's about an alien invasion. Seriously, were the writers just picking story ideas out of a hat?nnThen there's the animation. For Disney's first fully CG film, this is not a good start. The character designs look very unappealing, and the backgrounds look like something out of an early 2000's morning/afternoon cartoon (think Veggietales or Jimmy Neutron) While those were good for the budget they had, Chicken Little is a theatrical film from a huge animation studio. Surely they could do better than this!nnThe very worst thing about this movie, though, is the characters and the overall mood. Chicken Little has very little in the way of personality, to the point that, even though the entire world was in danger of being destroyed, I didn't feel any tension about it. His pig friend is extremely annoying. Many times when he opened his mouth, I found myself facepalming and begging him to shut up. Unfortunately, he provides most of the film's "humor" (which is made up of nothing but pop culture references and jokes related to bodily functions). Then there's Buck Cluck. Yeah, there's a reason he's one of the most hated Disney characters. He's a cowardly loser who cares more about his own reputation than he does about his own son. He discourages his son from trying new activities, he constantly treats him as a disappointment, and he doesn't even bother to stand up for him when the entire town mocks him and treats him as an outcast. Seriously, why am I supposed to sympathize with this guy? Sure, he apologizes to his son near the end, but that hardly makes up for his awful treatment of him throughout the first two acts. Really, the only supporting characters I found somewhat amusing were Abby and the fish.nnThere's also the mood of the movie. My gosh, this has got to be the most cynical and depressing movie Disney has ever made. Essentially, a bunch of people relentlessly torment a literal child for one small mistake. They even make a whole movie-within-a-movie about it. Seriously, how cruel and petty do you have to be to think that's okay? Then, they suddenly worship Chicken Little when he wins a baseball game, only to turn their backs on him when he tries to warn them about the sky falling again. What is the message of this movie supposed to be? If you suspect something bad is happening, don't bother telling anyone because nobody will believe you? That is NOT a good message to be teaching children. Also, the movie fails as an underdog story. Sure, Disney has done stories where the main characters were outcasts (take Dumbo or the Hunchback of Notre Dame, for example), but even those characters had kind and compassionate people by their side who provided hope to them and showed them that they are inherently worthy of respect just by being themselves. Chicken Little has to actively risk his life against a bunch of aliens in order for anyone to respect him again. Overall, this story is way too cruel, especially for Disney.nnNeedless to say, I won't be watching this one again. If you want to see a good Chicken Little adaptation from Disney, their 1943 short film of the same name does a much better job of translating the original story to animation.

Some dramas capture your heart and never let go, and for me, When The Phone Rings was exactly that. It became my ultimate comfort drama, delivering an emotional rollercoaster that left me feral and overwhelmed in the best way possible. Every episode was a masterpiece that had me eagerly awaiting the next, and during the weeks of delayed broadcast, I found myself rewatching the first four episodes so many times that I could recite them word for word. The wait only deepened my obsession, prompting endless theories about what might happen next.nnStellar Acting and Captivating CharactersnThe lead actors brought their A-game, but it was the male lead who truly stole the show. His nuanced portrayal of a complex character moved me deeply. The chemistry between the leads was electric, making every interaction feel genuine and heart-wrenching. Their performances elevated the story, making it impossible not to root for them despite the challenges they faced.nnA Story That Hooks YounThe drama's plot, while sometimes labeled as "Wattpad-coded," was undeniably addictive. It struck a perfect balance between heart-fluttering romance, tension, and moments of introspection. Yes, the themes may have leaned into familiar tropes, but they were handled with such charm and sincerity that it felt fresh and deeply personal.nnThe Ending: A Near-Perfect ClosurenWhile I loved the finale, I couldn't help but wish for an added layer of emotional depth. A scene where their son mirrored the stoic demeanor of Baek Yoo Yeon during his birthday photoshoot would have been a beautiful touch, adding a poignant callback to his father's character arc. Including this moment during the housewarming party would have tied the narrative together seamlessly, offering a more satisfying resolution.nnUnfair CriticismnIt's disheartening that the drama has faced criticism for its supposed "wattpad-coded theme" and mistranslations during its finale. These detractors overlook the emotional impact, the stellar acting, and the incredible storytelling that made this drama resonate with so many fans. The themes may not be groundbreaking, but their execution was heartfelt, making it a memorable experience for viewers like me.nnFinal ThoughtsnIt isn't just a drama-it's an experience. It's the kind of show that keeps you thinking long after the credits roll, that makes you laugh, cry, and fall in love all over again. While no drama is perfect, this one came close for me. It's a comfort drama I'll cherish, and one I'll happily revisit whenever I need to be reminded of the magic of K-dramas.

I have the encouragement because of the two of them. They both make today a good day.

Similar vibe to The English (2022). Very well made. Great to have a quality production that's a Netflix original series amongst the mass of mediocre content they pour out so generously.
