The show's attention to detail, from the design of the masked man's costume to the realistic portrayal of injuries and struggles, adds to its authenticity and immersive quality.nnDespite occasional dips in quality, such as the slower pacing in parts of Season 5, The Masked Man remains a strong and compelling series overall. It has moments of brilliance that showcase its ability to surprise, scare, and move its audience. Its strongest episodes, like "Try Me," "What It's Like Without Him," and "The End?," demonstrate the show's emotional and narrative prowess.nnIn conclusion, The Masked Man is a good show because it combines gripping storytelling, complex characters, emotional depth, and intense action to create an unforgettable viewing experience. It challenges its audience to confront their own notions of morality and survival while delivering a thrilling and emotionally charged narrative. It is a testament to the power of great storytelling and remains a standout series in its genre.

Tonight I watched Queer in cinema as part of a monthly Pride Evening. The movie theatre was loaded. I didn't know anything about the movie, except that Daniel Graig was the lead in a gay character. To be honest it was not an easy watch. Daniel's alcohol and drug use is enormous. He looks dishevelled, his fingers and nails brown from smoking. The silent young man he falls in love with is truly gorgeous and athletic. As the story slowly progresses, I lost interest in the main character. I wished he would shoot himself up to death with heroin, and were done with it.nnAs for the acclaimed styling, it is a shame the backgrounds are often digital computer images. People walk like puppets, and cars drive like toys. The sea is digital, even as the too slow flying planes in the sky. I dont understand why the director wanted to film this story without having the funds to pull it off? In that regard -and many others- Call Me By Your Name was way better. Most scenes are inside dark hotelrooms and poor rooms. Everything is worn out, colorless. Daniels decay was already undigestible, and together with this artificial gloom, it made feel distant from whats happening.nnDaniel is impressive but the young man made me watch untill the end. If it wasn't for him I'd left the movie after half an our.

I thought Avatar 1 was the best sci fi adventure-epic since the original Star Wars trilogy, but Avatar 2 was at best somewhat vaguely interesting. I was hoping for an Empire Strikes Back experience -- an original, thrilling sequel with the same epic storyline, music, and visual effects as the first film in the series. Instead, I was massively, epically disappointed. Avatar 2 features a completely forgettable soundtrack, as James Horner died after making the music for Avatar 1. The film is 3 hours long, and while the first half is intriguing, the second half is lackluster, and the final act is dull and repetitive, with some major plot events copied almost verbatim from the first film. The story effectively expands the lore of the Avatar universe by focusing on Jakes children and the reincarnated Colonel, which I thought was cool, but not sufficient to redeem the movie completely. The visual effects are as groundbreaking as Avatar 1, but without a soundtrack and story to go along with it the movie falls flat. Only diehard fans of Avatar 1 will appreciate this movie. The bottom line is that with all the resources James Cameron has access to, this should have been a much better sequel, especially after so many of us waited for it for 13 years.

Heretic" begins with all the makings of a truly compelling thriller-sharp tension, a compelling mystery, and a protagonist whose journey feels equal parts dangerous and captivating.nnThe first act pulls you in like a courtroom argument you can't look away from. The twists are intriguing, the stakes are high, and the atmosphere is saturated with dread. It's the kind of film that makes you lean forward, eagerly awaiting each reveal.nnBut as the plot thickens, the narrative begins to lose its edge. By the third act, the once-thrilling ride begins to slow, leaving you wishing it had held onto the same level of intensity it so expertly delivered in the beginning.nnIt's like the infamous U. S. Supreme Court ruling when they defined pornography; it aint easy to explain it, but you know it when you see it.nnStill, "Heretic" isn't without its merits. The direction is confident, the performances are compelling, and the cinematography adds layers to the film's dark undertone.nnThe story may stumble toward the end, but the initial momentum makes it worth the journey. If you're the type to savor a thriller for its mood and characters rather than a perfectly wrapped-up finale, "Heretic" might just be your next favorite thriller-drama.

I will admit, I have not seen F. W. Murnau's 1922 "Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror" or Werner Herzog's 1979 "Nosferatu the Vampyre," but I've watched a few youtube videos, so that obviously give me plenty of ethos here. Robert Eggers is one of my favorite current directors, for someone with a catalogue of 3 films prior to this, he is an absolutely baffling talent who puts so much artistic drive and direction into every film. It's no surprise that such a prolific master of so many different kinds of horror would go on to tackle his life-long dream of adapting Nosferatu this early on into his career, and I am absolutely here for it.nnEggers' adaptation of Nosferatu is probably the most visually stunning horror film to come out in 2024. The gothic architecture, the night scenes that somehow manage to be nearly daylight bright, but also pitch dark at the same time, and let's not forget what I think is the second most impactful shot in the film, Count Orlok's gnarled, ugly, decrepit hand stretched out as far as the eye can see over Wisborg as pained screams from the victims of his plague echo hauntingly.nnNearly every performance on display here is one for the history books, in my humble opinion. Aaron-Taylor Johnson as Friedrich Harding is an absolute dick and Emma Corrin as Anna Harding is a true friend to Ellen (I also got major queer vibes from her and Ellen in the scene before Orlok comes to her at the window, that may just be me). Simon McBurney as Herr Knock is absolutely insane, he fell straight into this psychotic role, Willem Dafoe as Albin Eberhart von Franz is definitely NOT Van Helsing, but what he is is an absolutely obsessed genius who will go every length to stop Orlok, there's nothing i can say about Dafoe that hasn't already been said a billion times. And of course, who can forget our main trio of absolutely stellar performances? Nicholas Hoult as Thomas Hutter, our sweet, loyal, naive every man through whom we see the true, abject horror of Count Orlok, Lily-Rose Depp proves that good acting does run in the family as she plays the tortured, noble heroine Ellen Hutter, haunted from a young age by a purely evil darkness because of circumstances she did not deserve, who makes the ultimate sacrifice at the end of the film to save the people of Wisborg. Depp certainly has the strongest emotional performance, you can really see her absolute torment as she hopes like hell to escape Orlok's grasp and the sheer conflict in her as she makes the ultimate act of true love to save her dear Thomas from the absolute monster that is Count Orlok. And of course, how could I possibly forget, Bill Skarsg√•rd as the absolutely pure evil villain that is count Orlok, putting on the strongest overall performance. Seriously, if you told me that was Bill Skarsg√•rd and I didn't already know, i would call you a liar. Orlok's booming, deep, raspy voice strikes fear into all who hear it (the addition of him only breathing to speak magnifies the fear factor by a solid 1000%), he truly falls deep into a role of pure horror, an villain with absolutely no comprehension of the word "mercy."nnHowever, for as stunning as the performances are (which elevate some admittedly static characters to a much higher quality), I believe the biggest thing that makes this movie an instant classic, setting it apart from its contemporaries, is the heightened sexuality of it all. The way that Orlok preys on Ellen in the original, the way that he feeds, everything about the original film is inherently sexual, so the decision from Eggers to bring that sexual to a higher, more explicit forefront was an absolutely brilliant idea. Going into the film, i knew that there was some sexual content in it, but i had no idea how dripping with sexuality this movie would be. The way that Orlok drains blood from Thomas at the beginning of the film feels almost like an act of fellatio, straddled on top of him and drinking the blood from him with absolutely disgusting and appalling gulps feels like an act of violation. And of course, the central conflict of the movie, Orlok's pure, carnal desire for Ellen Hutter, is just as gross as it sounds. Ellen and Thomas having rough, aggressive sex while she calls out to Orlok in an act of hopeless defiance against him, and of course, the way that Orlok sleeps with her at the end of the film is strangely beautiful in a purely disgusting way. The final shot of the film, Orlok's withered corpse of a body laying dead atop Ellen, wreathed in flowers as the early morning sun pours in through the windows, is a hauntingly gorgeous shot. It was absolutely uncomfortable to watch and i loved every second of it. The exploration of Ellen's sexual shame, manifested as Count Orlok, and the way that said shame kills her in the end, is a tale as old as time, but one that is explored beautifully in this film.nnOverall, Nosferatu is a dramatic, gorgeous, disgusting, sexual tragedy of a film, and one that i think fits very well into Eggers' filmography. I wouldn't say that it's better than the Lighthouse, as that film is more cinematically beautiful, thematically unique, and superiorly performed, Nosferatu still falls in place as one of the best horror films of the 2020s thus far and certainly as one of the best adaptations of Bram Stoker's Dracula.

This game holds A special place in my heart, such a beatiful adventure. Ys is a series that follow the Story of its main character Adol Christen. Without going into many details, you don't need to play the others to understand this as for each game is a self contained history. I'll make this short because who the hell uses imdb for videogames, specially JRPGsnThe good:n-Excellent history. It is full of misteries and intrigue that will keep your attention from the start to the nedn-Amazing Cast, from playable characters of the main group to the castaways survivorsn-DANAn-Memorable soundtrack. If you don't believe me look for: Next Step Toward The Unknown, sunshine coastline, Gens D'Armes, Inclucian dance etc. I still listen the whole soundtrack years later.nn-Fun gameplay, althought simplennThe bad:n-It is game originally released for PS vita and it shows (get the steam version)n-the rock, paper scissor combat sytem kinda force you 3 party membres that fit every class (and you don't get to bypass this till lategame for no reason)n-There are so many different maps at hand in different menus that confuse the hell out of you with the directions.nnPretty much that is. As I said above get the steam version as it has a solo Dana mode that is very important to the plot and is fun as hell, it is also very cheap. Give this game a chance and you won't regret it.

As a long-time fan, I was excited for the new series - the cast is great, and I really wanted to love it. But honestly, this just doesn't feel like Doctor Who anymore.nnThe stories are shallow, the pacing is all over the place, and the whole thing feels more like a chaotic kids' show than the fun, clever sci-fi adventure it used to be. Doctor Who has always been family-friendly, but this series feels like it's aimed at a much younger audience - and not in a good way.nnThe cast does their best, but the writing lets them down. There are glimpses of potential, but it's buried under manic energy and weak scripts. I know the show evolves, but this feels like a step in the wrong direction.nnI'll stick with the classics for now - they remind me why I fell in love with the show in the first place.

This thing is not a documentary, and I can't believe the director credit himself as the writer because there is NO script at all !nnThis is a huge disappointment, a really huge one.nnI truly believe that the other comments are from "rookie fans" of the movie, beginner or with small knowledge about it, because if you're a real diehard one you will learn nearly nothing at all. For myself I learn four things, that's all. Pretty expensive (140$.. sic) for so few new information.nnThe problem is, they sell this project as the ultimate Aliens companions, please pay extreme attention to these words. They say that it will be about absolutely everything, scene by scene, all the behind-the-scenes, all the secrets, about everything. On the paper, it's truly the dream for a fan, but the reality is the total opposite. It's just a +4hrs non-stop interviews of the 60% of the cast, who speak about things we already know or are already well-known, there is no off-voice to explain anything, you just deal with screen changing and interviews with sample of the movie and sometimes a rare making of footage.nn- They didn't pay any tribute to Trevor Steedman and barely spoke about Tip Tipping, no tribute to Paul Maxwelln- No tribute to Jay Benedict too, I didn't recall it was even mentioned in this "doc"n- Very small tribute to Al Matthews, the same for James Horner (they overshadow his difficult work and didn't mention that he used old stuff like Star Trek sample for Aliens OST)n- There is no interview of the cast of the director's cut such as Christopher Henn, Mac McDonald and Holly de Jong.nn- There is no interview of the small cast such as Barbara Coles (they even didn't know that her name is Mary, they refer to her as the cocooned colonist...), Valerie Colgan, Alibe Parsons, Alan Polonsky or even Carl Toop and Eddie Powell (who were inside the xenemorph costumes)n- Do you know the name of the guy who pull out his mask on the very first scene and say the first "real" sentence? No, and you will not because they didn't tell a word about it.nn- There is no interview of Walter Hill (only one alive of Brandywine) BUT there is an interview of the director himself Ian Nathan!!! But no one care!nn- They interview a very very very small part of the crew, they even didn't interview people who were there when Cameron kicks the tea trolley, they didn't show the infamous t-shirt of the crew against Cameron.nn- They say they will talk about the comics... It must be a joke! The interview of Mark Verheiden is a shame, he nearly didn't talk about Dark Horse. Worst of all ; they didn't interview Mark Richardson, who found Dark Horse and write the adaptation of Aliens in comics.nn- They completely overshadow all the novels and the video games, they interview V. Castro who recently wrote Vasquez. Who cares? Why haven't they interview Steve Perry and his daughter Stephani ? They wrote dozen of Aliens novels. Or also Alex White, his Cold Forge is considerate to be one the best Alien novel ever written.nn- They absolutely not talk a single line about the TV cut of 1989 !nnYou can't imagine how many example of failure I can count and how high is my anger against that so-called "ultimate documentary" about Aliens. This is a complete disaster and a huge waste of money.nnI will never, ever, support another of their pitiful low-quality project, never!

The Curious Case of Natalia Grace had the potential to be a thoughtful exploration of a unique and tragic story, but instead, it devolves into a sensationalized and manipulative spectacle. What could have been a balanced and respectful documentary instead relies heavily on dramatization, questionable editing, and forced narrative twists.nnFrom the beginning, the series locks viewers into a false dichotomy: either Natalia was an innocent six-year-old child or a sociopathic adult pretending to be one. Both extremes lack nuance, and the truth, as the series suggests, likely lies somewhere in the middle. However, instead of exploring this complexity, the show leans on overblown claims and fabricated suspense.nnScenes that should be raw and spontaneous, like Natalia's emotional reaction to seeing a childhood photo or her interactions with key figures from her past, are marred by overly edited sequences. Multiple angles and dramatic cuts make it clear that these moments have been staged, turning reality into a poorly constructed drama. This approach not only undermines the credibility of the series but also strips away the humanity of Natalia herself, reducing her to a character in a fictionalized narrative.nnLater seasons spiral further into sensationalism, introducing dramatic shifts in how Natalia's second adoptive family is portrayed. Initially depicted as loving and supportive, they are later accused of exploitation and abuse with little substantiated evidence. These forced narrative twists feel contrived, designed only to keep viewers engaged rather than to honor the complexity of the case.nnEven more troubling is how the creators try to emulate groundbreaking documentaries like The Jinx. Manufactured moments-such as dramatic phone calls conveniently received during production-attempt to replicate the impact of real revelations but lack the authenticity that made those moments in The Jinx memorable.nnWhat is most disappointing, however, is the exploitation of Natalia herself. After enduring years of hardship, she is now subjected to further manipulation by being portrayed as a volatile character whose story shifts to suit the producers' needs. This is not a documentary about understanding the truth-it's about stretching a narrative for as many seasons and viewers as possible.

The latest entry in Charlie Brooker's Cunk On... universe, Cunk on Life is certainly not Diane Morgan's funniest outing as the fantastically oblivious documentarian Philomena Cunk, but she retains all the brainless charm we would want. As usual, she offers up her own understanding of the subjects in-between a series of interviews where we yet again must ask just how "in on it" the interviewees were.nnThis time around, she explores life itself and the many different explanations for how life exists, not to mention the greatest of all questions: why.nnIt doesn't take too long before she starts interviewing those who believe that the greatest riddle of all time isn't actually a riddle at all (and yet will project arrogance onto those who simply try to explain that NOBODY truly knows the answer and/or ask that people would PROVE these things before taking them as definitively factual), namely the religious. The first exchange with "spiritual author" and parapsychology scholar Rupert Sheldrake perfectly distills what I'm referring to: "Is there a God?" "Yes." "Oh, that was quick."nnLater, Cunk tries to wrap her head around science, death, the philosophies that concern death, and the role that science seems to have assumed following the proverbial death of God, but more and more of the jokes end up rather lame. Cunk on Life is not as consistently or constantly hilarious as 2023's Cunk on Earth, and some of the less successful gags are in the form of skits, an element that Cunk on Earth did not use. It's also markedly more juvenile than before. The best parts are still the narrations and interviews, which make perfect use of the bewildering stupidity of this character.nnWhen people say she's Borat-ing, they don't just mean the simple fact that she's doing a docu-comedy where a character interacts with real people who do not know that it is a character. Just as Borat speaks with people who are racist enough to believe that a caricature like Borat could be a real person (validating them to a point where they reveal even uglier things about themselves), Cunk often seems to come across scholars who are sufficiently full of themselves to believe that Cunk/Diane Morgan really is just that dumb (not discerning that they're the ones being taken for a ride).

Watched a gangster stuff in a long time. What a messed up series showing human emotions of love, ambition, being no one and drove. Loved the pace and intensity. Oz and Sofia are just phenomenal but the kid did his part. Ox role, the vulnerability, the heartless killing the zeal to prove to mum and the overall mess about it is so beautifully choreographed.nnThe beautiful thing is the moving between intense fights and love of mum and son and of Sofia with her cousin daughter.nnEveryone showing their vulnerability and intensity when needed.nnThen at the end the message that there is not everything about power as it is about love.

I watched Dagon (2001) without any big expectations, driven by the curiosity of recently visiting Combarro, the coastal village where it was filmed. Honestly, I was expecting a weak production, maybe even something trashy and amateur, but I ended up pleasantly surprised. Despite some flaws, especially the visual effects that aged very poorly, Dagon turned out to be an engaging experience, particularly for fans of Lovecraftian horror.nnThe story follows a group of tourists who, after a storm damages their yacht, end up stranded in a village called Imboca. From the very beginning, the atmosphere is dark and unsettling, with the villagers exuding a disturbing and eerie vibe. While the narrative doesn't break new ground, it keeps you hooked with its constant tension and air of mystery. The characterization of the villagers is especially creepy and bizarre, reminding me of the Ganados from Resident Evil 4. I wouldn't be surprised if the creators of the game drew inspiration from this film, given the visual similarities and the unsettling nature of the Imboca inhabitants.nnOne of Dagon's greatest strengths is its atmosphere. It's the kind of movie best enjoyed on a stormy night, with the darkness and the sound of the wind enhancing the experience. The suspense is well-crafted and, in that regard, surpasses many more recent horror films. Although it's not consistently violent, the moments of gore are strikingly effective. One scene, in particular, stuck with me: near the end, there's a character being skinned alive in a graphic and brutal sequence, rivaling some of the more shocking moments from the Terrifier series.nnHowever, not everything works perfectly. The film's biggest drawback is its visual effects, which suffer from the limited budget and outdated technology. Some scenes that could have been truly memorable lose their impact due to these technical shortcomings. In my opinion, this movie deserves a remaster with updated effects or even a reboot that preserves its weirdness and darker elements.nnI'm honestly thankful I didn't watch this movie as a child, as I'm sure I would've been both terrified and traumatized by the villagers' grotesque appearances and the violent scene near the end. It's a curious and flawed film, but one that deserves to be rediscovered by anyone who enjoys solid horror with a touch of mystery.

Beast Games plunges viewers into a harrowing dystopia, a grim spectacle of desperation where the impoverished compete for a chance at salvation, only to be crushed by the weight of others' failures. Early team games force impossible choices: strive for glory or sacrifice yourself for the group, individual ambition versus collective survival. Beneath its highnbudget production, it's Jr. Squid Game show, how the wealthy exploit the struggles of the less fortunate for entertainment. Despite its intensity, it struggles to find originality.nnI particularly hate the 2nd event, where people in a line need to self scarifies themselves to save the group and for that group to advance. Which is so STUPID.

Congrats to the whole When the phone rings cast!nnIt was well executed drama. Right actor and actress was chosen. The chemistry was oozing and they really complimented each other. O dont think there is another actor or actress can portray the role aside from Chae Soo Bin and Yoo Yeon-seok. This kdrama makes me wanna go back to kdramaland.nnPlot were well executed there's no boring episode and you will thrilled as well as anticipate the next episodes.nnFrom main leads to the villain and supporting actors everyone where superb.nnTo more projects together with the main leads.nnPraying they will have more project we can watch.

This was quite the challenge to get through. If you are like me and just wanna see the disaster stuff, skip the first 3 episodes and just watch the 4th one, you really won't be missing anything other than pointless filler content and some of the dumbest characters you most likely won't be rooting for at all, I know I didn't.nnI really expected this show to be something great. If you are familiar with the Norwegian disaster films The Wave, it's sequel The Quick and The Burning Sea you'll know they do this sort of thing impressively well. Unfortunately this series itself was a disaster. I will however give props to the visual effects team who did a solid job. The little amount of destruction there is looked amazing, but as my headline suggests there is very little of it unfortunately, which is a bummer for someone like myself who enjoys the chaos mother nature unleashes. That is on screen of course, not in real life, I'm not a monster :/.

The excessive reliance on CGI in Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga feels like a major misstep. Instead of embracing the raw, visceral authenticity that made the earlier films iconic, the over-polished, obviously computer-generated visuals dilute the impact. With an entire continent at their disposal for filming, it's baffling that they chose artificial backdrops over real landscapes. The result is a film that looks sterile and lacks the gritty, tactile quality that defined the Mad Max aesthetic. This CGI overkill undermines the sense of danger and realism, making it harder to connect with the world and its characters.

This review is based on my personal evaluation.nnTo summarize, I love the whole series.nnThe cast that skillfully well-matched.nnThen "cast" delivered their role perfectly well. The emotions that they portray to me, it feels like it comes out naturally and not staged. That means they really are a good actor/ actresses. It was well written and well delivered. It doesn't matter how many times you watched the series, the intense emotion will still the same.nnThe chemistry of the main characters are top. Even the small details of the series are top-notch.nnI'm happy that the series won a lot of awards. After this one, it's going to be hard for me to look for a new one to watch.nnCongratulations to all the casts and staff that produce this amazing series!

column3: Eiga Kono subarashii sekai ni shukufuku o!: Kurenai densetsu (2019)
column4: It's more konosuba and story of works perfectly for movie length. So we are having a good time tonight.nnThe comedy is still some of the strongest is anime and hits the nail on the head every time to make me laugh, so I would very heavily recommended on that.nnIt's insane how well they combine story and comedy, and how the main character kazuma is so funny in every place to put him. He worked so well as the perverted HeronnThe new characters in the movie the Crimson demons are so fun and over the top. They have that over the top protagonist vibe and it is so funny. If the dub or sub it doesn't matter, it's so fun.nnThe biggest place you can see the movie budget is the background they look so nice in the movie. Most of the movie it looks the same as the show, but then in the second half you can really feel the movie budget.nnThe main villain is funny beautiful sexy with lots of attitude and react perfectly to the insanity around her.nnThe movie is extremely funny it is entertaining and it works perfectly . If you like konosuba there's no excuse not to watch it.

column3: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)
column4: Inspired by the true events of the attack of one of the two whales of notoriety that inspired the American classic Moby Dick, this seafaring suspense/peril filled drama hits all the right marks of a well told maritime tale, albeit cold-shouldering some amazing cast members, which may prove to be the only downside to an otherwise excellent movie.nnChris Hemsworth joins his MCU co-star Tom Holland as perhaps the two main characters of focus in this story, Brendan Gleeson playing our narrator of this harrowing survival tale as the older version of Tom's character. These three actors did a marvelous job as one would expect, with a roster of other Hollywood A-listers being basically underutilized to tragic effect.nnSharing the big screen with his co-star Gleeson from 28 Days Later, Cillian Murphy gets a surprisingly small amount of screentime as Mr Joy, 1st mate Chase's closest friend. Cillian Freaking Murphy with surprisingly little time in front of a camera! Adjacent his legendary talent is co-star Paul Anderson of Peaky Blinders with only a few lines of dialogue in the movie. But, we're not done yet. Add Michelle Fairley, Joseph Mawle and Donald Sumpter (probably more) from Game of Thrones, Jordi Molla, Ben Whishaw, Charlotte Riley, I mean...the list goes on and on. All top notch actors being given a minimal presence in the script kind of makes you feel cheated by the time the credits role.nnThat being said, barring the misuse of such a phenomenal cast, the movie was still very well written and vastly entertaining. Still recommend the watch.

When the Phone Rings is a story that unfolds when a Show Window couple, who have been living without speaking to each other for three years in an arranged marriage, receive a threatening phone call from a kidnapper. With When the Phone Rings' cast led by Yoo Yeon-seok and Chae Soo-bin, the series follows a married couple whose lives change after one of them is kidnapped.nnDont get why are mad for this unique kdrama. Did not expect the chemistry between YYS and CSB. For me it's brilliantly portrayed and execution of all their emotions in every scene is just soooo perfect!!! No wondered why they got several. Kodus to all directors, casts, crew and the whole production team for giving us a healing kdrama in the worldddd.

If you like your 80's action movies and if you like it with a bit of gore and violence then this will be right up your street. Not only that had me laughing out loud for the entire movie. The over the top violence top level comedy and all happening at a relentless pace left me wanting more. When everyone had had enough of the Christmas pish with James bloody cordon on every channel this is the perfect antidote and exactly what I needed. What a laugh!! Nazi Ninjas I'm bought in.nnThe characters were brilliant (Tam the Bam my favourite) with some outstanding cameos. Not to mention the music was incredible.nnWhat next for dick dynamite and his crew......I'm intrigued.

63 years of watching every movie genre, I have never walked out of a theater during the film. Without some clue as to how a man and women have had an ape as a child and taught it to talk made no sense and I couldn't get passed the bewildered feeling I had. No human even mentioned or recognized that it was a chimpanzee. I was hoping Charlton Heston shows up would yell "This is MAAADNESS!"nI enjoy all kinds of music including pop, but that wasn't the issue. I just kept asking myself why is he an ape? I saw Heston kiss one in Planet of the Apes but that wasn't a true story. This is a true story. I left the theater disturbed after a human gave the ape a hummer.nnGoogled "is Robbie Williams a gay monkey" , Yes and he lives next to Jimmy Page.

I would even say it's now one of my favourite films of all time. The Menu gave me one of the most strangest viewing experience. It was one of the most unique movies I have ever watched and left me thinking about it for days after. It was the perfect mix of thriller, comedy, and absurdity. I went into this movie expecting it to be a little odd, maybe a little scary and slightly boring. I thought it was going to be a typical failure but no it was actually the opposite ,it's one of those movies you don't take yours off of it. The story was engaging, well-paced and full of unexpected twists. I would watch it over and over.

column3: "The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power" (2022)
column4: Honestly, I thought I'd reviewed this before now - but I think it must have been the shock.nnI'm a HUGE Tolkien fan and I was initially really looking forward to going back to Middle Earth again, and I think that's why I hate this so much.nnSo what's wrong with it? I hear you ask.nnOverall, its not representative of Tolkien's writing and I find that too jarring to get over. Examples:nThe Orcs are presented as a somewhat misunderstood race, but they are evil creatures created by corruption.nnGaladriel at this point in the books has a husband and child, but no acknowledgement of that and her character is not someone that has been through thousands of years, from the age of the trees to the second age, she behaves like a 20-something year old.nnSauron (yes, its obvious) is one of the Maiar, but Galadriel (on her ridiculous hunt for) doesn't recognise that and just sees him as human, behave.nnThe Harfoots and Dwarves alike, I find buffoonish, and that annoys me - they're meant to be a race of people (well, the dwarves are) and they are just a caricature.nnWith all the free roam for the second age and they created something that in reality challenges canon. A lot of people will say so what, but the problem with that isnthat we will never get a Silmarillion adaptation, which would have been brilliant to see in cinema as a TWO part film.nnI gave it 4 stars because some of the visuals, especially Numenor, did look amazing.nnNot the costumes though, they looked quite cheap, can't believe the budget was more than Peter Jackson's adaptation of the Lord of the Rings (only - not the Hobbit films - they also looked terrible).

When the phone rings is one of those few korean dramas i did not skip an episodes or fast forward. The storyline is not cliche, it is refreshing. I love all the characters, and they potrayed their roles very well. It's nice to watch something where you can exchange ideas with other people of who the killer was. This drama test my patience because i almost cheat by reading the webtoon, so glad i did not! I just wishes they would have made it to 16 episodes because story like this deserves more recognition and longer running time. By the way, the lead actors have a great chemistry. Hoping for the 2nd season though i know it's not possible.

Loved it, from start to finish. The story is captivating, with a few plot twists along the way. Choice of soundtrack is also thoughtful, hooking you up even more. While I agree the last episode could've been stretched more to provide a solid background, it was still enjoyable enough.nnI have not read the source material, but from the snippets here and there that other users provide, the changes made in the adaptation make a lot of sense, catering to a more realistic approach.nnOne thing I would've enjoyed more would be secondary characters - we got a lot of main leads, while others were strictly background. I guess by keeping the episodes with only 12 not usual 16, this was the sacrifice.

Everyone definitely has their opinion on the ending of this kdrama but it definitely gave me everything I wanted. There was some stuff not needed which has angered a lot of people. But it doesn't take away how good the drama was. The script, cinematography, OST and chemistry was 10/10. The ending was definitely perfect for me a so don't think you need details all the time to understand the plot of a drama. Leave some to your imagination. I'll be rewatching until I'm tired of it. It definitely was the best romance thriller kdrama in a long while. Love to YYS, CSB and other characters. They definitely slayed and performed their role well.

First off, I'm not a fan of the book and I have no intention of reading it. So what I think of this movie isn't colored by some slavish devotion to a book that should have had its gold sticker used to seal it shut so that no one would ever have to suffer again. This could have been a nice, marshamallow fluff Cinderella story, even with the music. The problem is that the fairy who cursed Ella, Lucinda, is just pure rage bait. I think it's because the explanation or excuse that she gives to Ella does not make sense. She blames Ella for everything and claims that she always had a choice when we have seen with our own eyes that this is not the case. Nothing happens to this fairy and I think she just flies off- she doesn't even get her dress dirty. The worst part is that the writers expect the viewer to hand-wave this poorly written drivel and continue on. Lucinda ruins everything, both for the characters and the movie itself. Skip it.

Gotta give some credit here. The framing narrative for this anthology, that of a random bloke surfing an extreme porn site on the deep web, is a very interesting idea. Unfortunately, it is also very boring to watch a guy as he is watching porn on the internet. An idea more interesting in concept than execution, I think.nnWell this sure lives up to the XXX in that title. There is straight up some pornography in this. Fully visible anal fisting and masturbation. Definitely not a film to watch with your parents.nnThere are some decently shocking bits and pieces here towards the end I suppose, but there is even more pretentious torture porn nonsense that spends more time showing people scream and squirm than actually anything shocking. If the videos showcased on that dude's favorite porn site are indeed the grimmest stuff to be found on the deep web, then I suppose the deep web is a bit more tame than I thought. If the most shocking content to be found there is truly just a bunch of gay men fisting each other, then I can probably handle it.nnEh... A bit dull. I suppose if you're into the whole shock horror thing this may be one for your completionist list.. But general audiences will find little reason to seek this one out, even for the sake of intentionally upsetting themselves.

If you're looking for a cookie cutter film that engages in the detective style discovery process in the typical ways, you'll be disappointed. This film is great because of its DIY nature that reflects the lived realities of Black women attempting write themselves into history. Its a great example of the genuine failures and flunders that come with doing archival work as a Black woman for the sake of preserving a Black woman's legacy. It's meant to display that struggle, thats what made it a 10 star watch to me.nnThe ending is uneventful but its meant to be. Its meant to show what happens when Black women want to commemorate a Black women that doesn't want to be visible because of what's happend to he when she was visible.nnThe film feels close to my feet as a Black women on social media and grew up on the internet. Its beautifully through tout and feels so so organic. Also the soundtrack is fire.

Just watched this, I'd already seen reviews but figured I'd still give it a shot. Wishing I hadn't, despite being less than 90 mins it felt torturously long! Found myself frequently checking to see how much was left.nnAs I said in the title, this film is offensively bad. If it was simply badly written or poorly acted, but with a decent heart or message then I could forgive the rest, but it isn't. This film is actively harmful, I despair for any parent or child who suffered due to the terrible messages this film pushes onto people.nnAs others have said, the main character is a teenage boy supposedly 'addicted' to internet porn, yet he never ever masturbates. Maybe he wouldn't be tossing & turning unable to sleep at night if he occasionally relieved the tension? But no, he watches fully clothed women on websites yet thinks he's watching porn, he is obviously meant to be turned on by this, yet never thinks of touching himself. He is picked on by the stereotype jock bullies, who think he's a freak because one time he looked at yet more fully dressed people but this time wearing rubber/latex. Teenage boys do not get appalled by porn like this.nnThis film was clearly written, directed, and produced, by people with no understanding of computers, porn, or what teenage boys do, or how they speak. How they had the self confidence to make a film without these basic understandings is beyond me.nnAwful movie, please don't waste 1.5hrs discovering that for yourself. It's irredeemable, it isn't a funny bad movie like The Room. It's simply bad.

One of the most iconic films in history, it is top 2 on IMDb and many people consider it to be the best film ever made.nnIt is without a doubt a great Drama and Crime film. The way the film shows the mafia from within the mafia is brilliant, instead of the protagonists being the good guys, and it works very well, because of the script and direction.nnThe film shows Don Corleone, a great Italian mobster in New York, and shows very well how, in addition to ordering crimes and being influential in politics and in several other sectors, he is respected, they call him the godfather because of the respect they have for him, in addition to the film showing a lot of how he takes care of and worries a lot about his family. He is undoubtedly one of the most iconic characters of all. The film shows that he was attacked and while he was injured his son, Michael Corleone, took over the family business. This was the son who went to college, served in the war and didn't care about the family business, and yet he was the one who took his father's place. He is a character who is always trying to hide his feelings, but is very impulsive at times. The film also focuses a lot on other members of the Corleone family, such as Dom's daughter and other children, and also on the gang war taking place.nnThe film is almost three hours long, and although it is very focused on dialogue, it is not a boring film. In some parts of the gang war I felt a little confused watching it, I think it is because the film shows and mentions so many characters, but the film's script is phenomenal.nnFrancis Ford Coppola's direction is incredible, combined with the wonderful performances of Marlon Brando and Al Pacino in particular, some scenes are incredibly tense, for example the scene where Michael is going to kill the police officers and the noise of a train appears, it's incredible how it shows the confusion in his mind with this and with Al Pacino's performance without saying a single word, among other incredible and iconic scenes in the film. The film's photography is beautiful, the soundtrack is iconic, the setting and costumes are also incredible.nnOverall, I really think the film is a masterpiece as they say, but personally I found the film a little confusing.

This "movie" is genuinely unwatchable. And I put the word movie in quotes because this barely qualifies as a movie. It's more like a middle school art project that the students gave up on after the first 10 seconds. It's literally laughably bad, but it takes itself seriously. I have no idea how this got made, because everyone involved should have walked off the set the moment the first scene was filmed and these "actors" opened their mouth. There's is absolutely nothing redeeming about this film. It seems like it's the porn version of an equally pathetic movie, and the lead actress' acting is so atrocious you will honestly be shocked when you realize it's NOT a porn parody. No one should watch this film. It will make you a dumber person, and will ruin your week.

Dazed and confused is a 1993 movie that is based on adventures of several teenagers in high school and junior on the last day of school. The students indulge themselves in illicit behaviours such sex, doing drungs and drinking of alcohol on the last day of their high school. Due to several characters in the movie it's makes it an endless and memorable movie that is worthy re-watching thus it's a classic movie. The movie relates and exposes how teenagers can exposed to drugs and the dangers if supervision by parents and guardians don't pay attention to their children while they are in high school.

The books I loved as a child were Laura Ingalls Wilder's "House on the Prairie" series. I read every single one. I cried when her dog Jack died, and I shivered along with her in the middle of summer during the winter of blizzards on the prairie. I also liked Anne of Green Gables, but there was something about the pioneers that set them apart. The next year I read the entire Narnia series. The year after that I read The Hobbit. I spent more time reading than watching tv as a kid, but I did manage to stumble onto a few horror movies during the free HBO week or month we would get occasionally.nn"It" was not among the free HBO horror flicks. I only happened to watch this one bc my friend Irene invited us over for a slumber party in the summer of 1990. She must have taped the series when it aired on tv that year. (Hopefully, this aired before the summer, bc otherwise it would count as part of the pirated collection.) This Pennywise was the creepiest? I did have honest nightmares for a few nights after the slumber party, but I didn't really think much more about the killer clown. Clowns aren't that common.nnNot until 2019 did I make connection to my actual life. I happened to see an ad for the latest "It" release back in 2017 when it aired on tv in 2019. I set my DVR and watched the movie, but this one wasn't as scary as that one in 1990. There was something scarier about the pre-internet pre-cellular world. I read the wikipedia summary for the movie. I counted the interval between the years I first saw a clown at a school, my 1983 kindergarten graduation ceremony, and the year I saw a clown in a local library, the 2010 Oak Lodge Library clown. They were the exact number of years apart as specified in the book! What? I wasn't a believer until the numbers added up.nnMagically, that October 2019 a person impersonating a woman who was impersonating my brother walked up behind me at a local Wendy's (Cin-Dayton Rd.) and made a very insulting gesture. He was with a woman who looked like someone I ate lunch with my junior year of high school at Lakota. I didn't know that group that well. I just happened to eat lunch with them. Anyways, I think he was a very bad man whoever he was? It didn't help that the Wendy's staff told me that I almost got "it" that day if that man hadn't done that behind my back in line. The clerk with the beard told me that she was a "witch." He was shaking his head yes. She's a witch. He had dark hair and was heavyset just like my brother. He was sick. Did I see "it" or did I see someone trying to save me from hitmen at Wendy's? Either way, I apologized on his behalf bc I was afraid of a race war.nnAll of that was much scarier than the1990 "It" series. The basic premise of "It" is that a little boy dies in a sewer. Supposedly, this Pennywise rips off the little boy's arm while he's chasing a paper boat that floats away down the sewer drain. Now, if my brother had died in similar circumstances then I would have been much more negatively affected by the fictional account.nnMy brain never picked up on the clues bc my brain always made Mark the same person. My brain absolutely can tell the difference between identical twins and most doppelg√§ngers, but I couldn't tell that someone wasn't there anymore. Denial? My brain not exploding? Someone standing behind my back in 2020-2021 was pointing to a local toy store, but I don't know what happened there in the 1980s. In my multiverse, we visited only one time and my mother was complaining about the prices. We didn't buy anything and left. That's all I remember from the 1980s. If my brother was sent back to Pittsburgh, it was bc my father must have found out that he wasn't his biological son.nnIn February 2020, I found out that I had been kidnapped in the city of Pittsburgh, PA in either 1978 or 1979 at the age of 18 months. After 10 DNA tests at five different companies I am no closer to finding out the identity of my ethnicity or biological parents as they were before the test. The DNA companies published fake DNA relatives for me bc someone told them that my father was an overseas asset. I won't ever know the truth. The two options were a cousin who was French/Slovenian who was from the same neighborhood as my mother or a woman who was part Turkish and part French or Norwegian or Finnish. No one in my family had ever met her. It sounds like she committed suicide in 1978 due to the ballet troupe, and the kidnapper kidnapped me from a babysitter's thinking I was his. The only thing Todd ever said to me was that I looked like the matron of a girls boarding school.nnIt sounds like the young lady who lived in the Boston area in the 1990s could have had the same biological mother? We did look alike in the photos. We never met. Is it possible that her Dad was French Dad with the wider set eyes, and my Dad was the Italian Swiss Turkish man from Istanbul? She was trying to find Oz, but she never met him. Anyways, there was something disturbing about that British movie, "My Beautiful Launderette." I just saw that one last year. I have to caution that it could have been that two Turkish woman looked alike?nnPennywise wasn't as scary after all that and the pandemic. To this date, I haven't actually ever seen a dead body, except for the times at University Hospital Cincinnati between 2000-2002 when I would be working near a window and they would wheel a draped body to the morgue across the hall.nn**** I am NOT the cat from Fairfield. My only sexual partner was an old man who used the name of Michael who lived at 4692 SE Derry Lane Milwaukie, OR 97267 between 2007-2010. I haven't seen him since 2010. I don't want to know if he was "it." I just don't want to know. He doesn't deserve a visit from me in jail if he's been in jail.nn**** Is there a social media account with my name on it? Deniz E. Osman? Why am I getting confused with someone else? Did she try to murder someone and move into a new house in Liberty Township?nnBy Sue KiesewetternUpdated Jan. 6, 2025nJournal dash news dot comn(This paper used to be called the "Pulse Journal." Then, it became "Today's Pulse." Now it's called "Journal News")nnFairfield family's lost cat went to Kentucky before they got it back 3 weeks laternnLona McClain got her family's Christmas miracle.nnIt was in the form of a Facebook message found in the last few minutes of Christmas night. That's when she found a message with a picture of a cat with a Christmas bow - the Fairfield family's beloved cat Leo that had been missing for three weeks.nnLeo was in the Fort Mitchell, Ky. Home of Alex Johnston and Paul Finn more than 30 miles away.nn"We've been loving a sweet boy for little over a week now and I think you might be his mom!" began Johnston message. "If it's him, know that he's been very loved and spoiled rotten."nThe message from Johnston came after McClain had put up laminated missing cat posters and after unsuccessful searches by friends, family, neighbors, strangers and a professional search firm.nn"She (Alex) reached out to me at midnight Christmas night. My 8-year-old daughter Addy cried all Christmas day that Santa didn't bring her cat back. She had asked Santa for her cat to come back,'' McClain said.nn"We're big on our faith. We had kept praying and I told the kids to have faith, God would work it out. But we had about given up hope."nnAlex Finn said she knew the cat the family had been caring for must have a family who was missing it. Every day she had been combing Facebook groups trying to find its owner, with no luck.nnOn Christmas day she was determined to find the cat's owner, so she spent hours combing Facebook groups looking for a post about a missing cat that matched the description of the cat her family was caring for.nn"I knew somebody was missing this cat. His behavior was so loving. He was a cat who acted like a dog. He was declawed. Everybody loved this cat. He was cuddled up next to me,'' Finn said.nn"On Christmas day it was really bothering me. This cat let my 3-year-old carry him around like he was a stuffed animal - he tolerated it. I said 'I know this cat has kids.' It was so heavy on my heart."nSo she spent two hours combing through missing cat posts until she found a listing about a cat with unique markings that matched those of the cat her family was caring for.nn"Once that happened...I reached out to her (McClain), wrote a long message. I woke up on Dec. 26 and had all these messages from her."nThe two women and their children met in a downtown Cincinnati parking lot to verify it was the right cat and then return Leo.nnThat's when both families unraveled the mystery of how Leo ended up in with the Johnston-Finn home.nnAfter getting out of the family's garage unbeknownst to the McClains as they were leaving for work and school, Leo made his way to the Jeff Wyler Honda dealership on Colerain Avenue - a distance of six miles - where Paul Finn was a salesman.nnAfter two days of the cat - then dirty and emaciated - trying to get inside the dealership or sleeping under cars, Paul Finn took it home to Fort Mitchell. The family already had two cats, a dog, and a button quail.nnEveryday Johnston combed Facebook postings trying to find out who Leo belonged to as he was becoming a part of their family - loved by her 3- and 6-year-old sons, Rory and Knox.nn"My kids were heartbroken - absolutely devastated - when we thought we found the owners," Johnston said.nn"But we kept reminding them if it were their cat would they want somebody to keep it. Doing the right thing even when you know doing the wrong thing has no consequences is the right thing to do."nThe two moms didn't tell their children in advance that Leo might be returning to him home when they met in the parking lot of the Frisch's near the Cincinnati Museum Center.nn"I felt sad when I lost him," Addy said. "I felt happy and excited when I found him. I didn't give up hope because Jesus would find him."

Turner Classic Movies did fans of musicals a huge favor on New Year's Day this year when they ran "That's Entertainment" numbers I, II, and III in succession. For this second entry however, I'm in agreement with a whole host of reviewers here on IMDb who feel that this one wasn't as focused as the first release from 1974. Whereas the original was entirely committed to MGM musicals from roughly 1929 through much of the Fifties, this one thought it would be a good idea to insert drama and comedy clips among the musical sequences, and it just came off as a random collection of clips with no relationship to each other. Gene Kelly and Fred Astaire share hosting duties and even at their advanced age (Astaire 77, Kelly 63), manage to tap and dance their way through a few intricate numbers. A neat highlight was a scene from "It's Always Fair Weather" from 1955 in which Kelly does an entire sequence on roller skates. Although a number of comedians are billed for this program, you'll miss Laurel and Hardy and W. C. Fields in still shots if you blink, however there's an Abbott and Costello routine involving earplugs I'd never seen before. Marx Brothers fans will thoroughly enjoy the stateroom scene from "A Night at the Opera", enough so you'll want to catch the whole picture. Judy Garland shows up a lot in scenes with Astaire and Kelly, again, randomly placed, while a retrospective of films featuring Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn takes up a fair amount of screen time. If you're not familiar with their careers, a few scenes will surprise, with folks like Frank Sinatra and Greta Garbo shown dancing, and a couple of Roberts, that would be Montgomery and Taylor, actually singing. Not very well, but that's what MGM pushed some of their stars to do while under contract. One downside, and it happened frequently enough in both I and II, is that some of the movie clips aren't identified by title, so if you wanted to check them out, it would be difficult to do. For example, my summary line above didn't even mention who said it and where; it was Franchot Tone speaking to Jean Harlow in the 1933 film "Bombshell". The full quote, if I may, was actually "Your hair is like a field of silver daisies. I'd like to run barefoot through your hair".

The production quality of this movie is truly commendable. All the cinematographic expertise of malayalam cinema, especially when it comes to capturing the vast landscape as an element of this arduous run for life, shows an excellent quality. Capturing the characters is also great with impressive coverage and camera handling, and it really pays off in the screen and storytelling. The lead character succeeds in not imitating, but in capturing the essence of the character, as the story proceeds forward. A R Rahman killed it, with really emotional bgm. The scenes are structured, but is not really noticed as we are lost in the landscape and an ever continous timescape. Day-night-day-night and you really don't know that three years have passed. Without a lot of characters, the scenes really make you feel home. The film also has a solid flashback or backstory that tells how much home means to the main character.nnThough the movie becomes prolonged due to a few repeated scenes, the overall structuring of the plot is amazing.

L can't stop watching a good story all know Nolan swings for the fences of what's possible and pushes the realms of normality. This film for whatever reason just doesn't mesh together the way most of his films do even with complex suspension of disbelief aspects. It's often scattered and juxtaposed to a near outrageous level. The visuals are spectacular at times but also seem way too extravagant to take seriously other times. Robert Pattinson is flawless and probably the standout of the film with his vigorous performance. The same cannot be said about John David Washington's barren and emotionless lack of effort. I can't believe he was given the starring role. He brings the interest level down to almost unwatchable levels. Overall this is one of Nolan's rare misfires which he is capable of once in awhile.

I really admire the artful assembly of the 22 short movies to narrate the stories of people in Gaza. Each story is a unique window to the soul of a human being and his/her daily struggle and allows audiences to connect with the characters despite the surreal environment they are living in. This assembly has been done with the full awareness to not overwhelm the audience to the scale that they feel completely helpless.nnA question came up with the friends, after we all watched the documentary. Question of "having choice". We asked how much choices do people of Gaza have? We debated and agreed and disagreed. I understand having "choice" for Palestinians is a very politically charged debate. I think this documentary really portrays people struggle with this question. And that's why I think everyone should watch it.

The cast delivered outstanding performances, bringing depth and nuance to their characters. The storytelling was engaging, with a narrative that flowed seamlessly. The pacing was well-balanced, allowing the audience to absorb the emotions and themes.nnWhat resonated with me most was the film's ability to tackle complex issues with sensitivity and wit. With its talented cast, clever writing, and memorable moments, this film is sure to stay with you long after the credits roll. Highly recommend!"

Megan Park certainly knows how to catapult young actresses into stardom. The Fallout launched Jenna Ortega into the stratosphere, and now it's Maisy Stella's turn. Stella excels as Elliot with her impeccable comedic timing, line reads, and emotions. Even when acting among experienced actresses like Aubrey Plaza, Stella shines with immensely. I don't know if it's Stella's vibe or Elliot's, but she carries herself like Renee Rapp (confident, charismatic, and gay as hell). In her first leading role, she carries the film with ease and leaves you wanting more. Good movie best graphics and good sound tracks.

Every single episode of this show was thrilling in its own way. The story-line, animation, quotes, direction, everything was detailed to the point of magnificence. I think what really made this show different from other shows is its way of describing reality of deep human human nature that lies beyond human conscience. Show also manifests the way people hold their beliefs and how they turn on the people very people they loved and, even die just because of the beliefs they hold. Since the trailer came out I loved the idea of Florence and Andrew together in a romance film, and they don't disappoint me, a great pair of actors who where capable of make you feel those emotions of infinite love and expectations in this life.nnI really loved how they character where made, as part of the lgbtq+ community I think that the little look at Almunt's sexuality was accurate, It is not the theme of the movie, it actually can be unnoticed, but the way she acts and say things to Tobias like in the proposal, I think that was well done and interesting as a visibility.nnAbout the soundtrack I felt it nostalgic and at the same time, full of love. Is all about the movie, more about the fellings and not so much about the things that happened, how happend and when does.nnThis leaves me to the order of the scenes, at first I doesn't feel right, like, I wanted to see more of them at first meet, but then I was like, wait, this is the thing of the movie, the time and how we are living in it.nnFor me, we where seeing they memories in the time they have together, I thought that the director was gonna be more directly and then in the end it would be like Almunt in her lasts moments smiling, but It wasn't and Im grateful for that. She is now living in our memories like she wanted to be; happy, funny, successful, a great women, great partner and of course great momnn(Sorry about my english, not my first language)

There's something sinister and exploitative about Beast Games and I love it. People across America are gathered to compete for five million dollars. They engage in various games, many of which involve betrayal and temptation to engage in venal acts of self-interest. The games are run by mega-rich Youtuber, Mr. Beast, who has amassed a huge online following. Him and his friends bring a removed and apathetic quality to the hosting/ongoings that is complimentary to the depraved nature of the games themselves. A contestant will be eliminated through no fault of their own, crying about their kids and future, only to be dropped through a trapdoor seconds later. Unintentional bathos? Hilarious regardless.nnSo, it's cheap entertainment, does it really deserve a 10? No, not really, but it deserves higher than than a 5. The most interesting aspect of Beast Games is how common the contestants are and the micro-anthropology on display. Reality shows have increasingly moved away from "reality". Were they ever real? No, of course not. Reality TV has always been produced in a way to present curated narratives and characters. But early on there was an authenticity to reality show contestants that has since been lost. Now, reality shows seem to pull from a small pool of already semi-famous people or people who already look like they belong on television. Beast Games feels like it really did grab 1000 random Americans.nnThe preacher, who can't say a single sentence without invoking Jesus, congregating a flock of followers. The villainous Egyptian brothers who bully a girl to eliminate herself. A homosexual White guy in a room with two Black people refusing to eliminate himself after legitimately losing a game where they all agreed the loser would self-eliminate. The complete disregard for considering diversity when contestants are faced with choosing who will join them on a helicopter to continue the game on a private island (of course you'd choose your friends, and surprise, a lot of people link up with their same race and gender). All these little moments serve as a salve to the regular phoniness you see in Hollywood and "prestige" TV.nnA lot of people will find Beast Games distasteful, because it is. That's what I find great about it. There's more verisimilitude in this twisted reality game show than most fictional TV today. Welcome to the coliseum. Get the popcorn.

A Hilarious and Heartwarming Exploration of Age, Identity, and Self-Discovery*nn"My Old Ass" is a sidesplitting and poignant comedy that delves into the complexities of aging, identity, and self-discovery. The film follows the story of Jay, a man in his 60s who finds himself at a crossroads in life. With a talented cast, witty dialogue, and a narrative that balances humor and heart, "My Old Ass" is a must-see for anyone looking for a movie that will make them laugh, cry, and reflect on their own life journey.nn*A Relatable Protagonist*nnJay, played by a talented actor, is a relatable and endearing protagonist. His struggles to come to terms with his aging body, his sense of purpose, and his place in the world are deeply relatable. As he navigates the challenges of growing older, Jay's story is both universally relatable and uniquely personal. The film's portrayal of his inner turmoil, his relationships, and his quirks makes him a lovable and authentic character that audiences will root for from start to finish.nn*A Talented Cast*nnThe cast of "My Old Ass" is a talented ensemble of actors who bring depth, nuance, and humor to their respective roles. The chemistry between the leads is undeniable, and their interactions are filled with warmth, wit, and a deep sense of camaraderie. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with standout performances that add to the film's humor, heart, and emotional resonance.nn*A Narrative that Balances Humor and Heart*nnThe narrative of "My Old Ass" is a masterful balance of humor and heart. The film's tone is consistently funny, with a witty script that is full of clever one-liners, humorous observations, and comedic set pieces. At the same time, the movie tackles serious themes like aging, identity, and mortality with sensitivity, nuance, and depth. The film's ability to balance humor and heart is a testament to the skill of the filmmakers, who have crafted a narrative that is both entertaining and emotionally resonant.nn*Themes and Messages*nnAt its core, "My Old Ass" is a movie about self-discovery, identity, and the search for meaning in life. The film explores themes that are relevant to audiences of all ages, from the challenges of growing older to the importance of relationships, community, and personal growth. The movie's messages about embracing one's true self, finding purpose and passion, and living life to the fullest are inspiring and uplifting, making "My Old Ass" a film that will leave audiences feeling hopeful, energized, and motivated.nn*A Visual Feast*nnThe cinematography of "My Old Ass" is a visual feast, with a vibrant color palette, stunning landscapes, and a keen eye for detail. The film's use of lighting, camera angles, and composition is highly effective, creating a visual narrative that is both beautiful and evocative. The movie's production design is equally impressive, with a keen sense of period and place that adds to the film's authenticity and charm.nn*Conclusion*nn"My Old Ass" is a hilarious and heartwarming movie that explores the complexities of aging, identity, and self-discovery. With a talented cast, witty dialogue, and a narrative that balances humor and heart, this film is a must-see for anyone looking for a movie that will make them laugh, cry, and reflect on their own life journey. The film's themes and messages are inspiring and uplifting, making "My Old Ass" a movie that will leave audiences feeling hopeful, energized, and motivated. If you're looking for a film that will make you feel good, look no further than "My Old Ass" - it's a cinematic treasure that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

column3: "Dark Side of the '90s" (2021) {Internet 1.0: Don't Believe the Hype (#1.10)}

Was getting headaches listening to it and ended up FF to the end, where they were STILL talking about PETS.nnNO, Amazon was not worth that much money back then. They were still trying to launch their kindle you lying sack of crap, which wouldn't come about until after 2000.nnThey spent 30 minutes talking about sock puppets. How pathetic is this series? What depths can they not stoop to?nnThis is the absolute worst depiction of the 90's i've ever seen.nnAnyone who wants to know what it was really like, I've got all your answers. This is absolute trash and lies. Just because they throw something in your face, doesb't mean that's what.... oh, right, when people look back in 20 years at today they'll only remember the stuff that was thrown in out face, like every single agenda, all the propaganda.nnThank God the 90's didn't have social media to ruin everything.
