I devoured the HBO Max series 'Hacks' and was blown away by its sharp wit, clever writing, and outstanding performances. This show is a love letter to female friendship, exploring the complexities and joys of relationships between women.nnI loved how 'Hacks' seamlessly balances humor and heart, tackling topics like aging, identity, and trauma with sensitivity and nuance. The chemistry between Jean Smart and Hannah Einbinder is undeniable, and their characters' unlikely friendship is both authentic and aspirational.nnJean Smart's performance as Deborah Vance is a masterclass in comedic acting, bringing depth and vulnerability to a character that could have easily been a caricature. Hannah Einbinder's Ava, on the other hand, is a brilliant and relatable millennial foil to Deborah's old-school humor.nnHacks' is a must-watch for anyone who loves comedy, drama, or just great storytelling. With its talented cast, clever writing, and authentic portrayal of female friendship, this show is a true gem. Don't miss it!

Suits is an haighly praised, high-drama legal series with flat characters, it's not without its flaws. Here's why I'm giving it 3 starsnn1. Donna - She's the reason I stuck with the show through Season 5. Donna is incredibly skilled, witty, and sharp, and while she has no boundaries and doesn't always respect others', she's undeniably a force to be reckoned with. Her strength and charisma make her an unforgettable character, and her presence on screen elevates the entire series.nn2. Jessica - A refreshing contrast in a sea of cis straight white male characters, Jessica brings power and elegance to the table. Her performance is top-notch, and her role as a formidable boss is both empowering and captivating. She adds a layer of depth and complexity that makes her a standout amidst the chaos. And Gina Torres was great for the roll.nn3. Drama - If you're in the mood for something that doesn't require too much thought, Suits delivers. The drama is engaging, perfect for zoning out or letting it run in the background. The show's characters are easy to recognize by both voice and actions, and it's simple to pick up if you missed a bit of the plot, they'll explain things again.nnConsnnThat being said, there are some significant drawbacks that really affected my enjoyment:nnThe show often feels like a glorification of toxic masculinity. The men are consistently portrayed as self-centered, boundary-pushing individuals with little to no regard for others. They manipulate the system, defend morally questionable CEOs, and bend the law for the rich and powerful. Unfortunately, the characters don't grow or evolve; if anything, they become worse versions of themselves as the series progresses.nnThe characters rarely face any real consequences for their actions. This lack of accountability for the behavior of these entitled, often insufferable men becomes frustrating, especially when their bad actions are constantly praised by both the show's characters and its fanbase. The portrayal of these rich, arrogant figures left me feeling disillusioned, and honestly, it soured my view of the show.nnSuits can be incredibly engaging, but its depiction of toxic dynamics and the unrelenting praise of morally gray characters left me disenchanted. By the end, I couldn't help but feel like the show had inadvertently reinforced a lot of harmful stereotypes. The men in this show turned me gay for women. And Rachel made question if I was indeed gay for women.nnDespite the strong performances and clever writing, the lack of character growth and the show's problematic themes ultimately left me with mixed feelings.

Good TV Show. Love Kevin Costner. While Kayce doesnt want anything to do with the ranch and Beth only comes home if she feels like it. And they insult him all the time. He then makes ONE mistake,which is 100% understandable after a lifetime of bullying and telling him hes worthless, despite he dedicated his whole life to his family, and they want to kill him. Beth the brat especially, who did nothing but run away from home and comes back every few years...And in general, every character has issues and conflicts with everybody. Nobody talks to anyone and resolves matter. All they do is scheme and fight. Or stupid things that the writers forget or think the viewers are too stupid to notice. Like when John says goodbye, writers the letter and even says to his family "this is gonna be the end of us" and how hes not coming back. What happens? Nothing. They just put that in for drama, the cheapest possible plot point. Or how they ride in into a compound defended by PROFESSIONAL militia and ex soldiers with vests, nightvision/thermal vision etc... And Rip just rides in on his horse and with a shotgun in the middle of it with John on his side and NOB.nn7/10.

The 1-sentence review: „Ä∞This is a pre-packaged, off-the-shelf, watchable romance that has some nice seasoning & truly bright moments for romance fans„Ä∞nnIs it in the top 20 that I would show to a viewer new to Asian programming? Nope, but for a romfan it will pass the time very nicely. I'll stick some toes over the edge of the cliff & say it's worth watching for Song Ha Yoon's performance alone. She EATS her role up. PMY is always worth watching. NIW isn't bad to look at, either.nnThis drama is actually an advice column. There's plenty of useful truths to be gleaned, such as:nnüë†Shoes your friends wisely - eh, 'Choose,' I mean.nnüë†We accept the love we think we deserve (from The Perks Of Being A Wallflower).nnüë†Keep your friends close & your enemies closer (until the battle is over)nnüë†Statements don't grow up to be cliches b/c they're mostly false.nnüë†Some people just get used to losing. Some losers don't realize what (big picture) losers they are & will do anything to avoid (small picture) losing. Losing once in awhile is not a bad thing, as pride is always the biggest problem. Humility is good for the soul. Being a doormat, though, will rob your life's essence.nnOuch. Ep1 HURTS. Kang "Ji" Won has led a painful life & now she's close to death: Stage 4 cancer. "I never knew happiness," she says. Horrible husband. Horrible family. Horrible friends. Her husband & bff cause her death & now they will enjoy the life insurance payout. The End.nnBut wait! There's more! After the end, Ji gets a reset. She wakes up back in time, year 2013... Meltdown! Is this a dream? If so, is 2023 the dream or 2013.2? Let the Chippies fall where they may... & Ji has a couple snagging Chippies in her life.nnTo go along w/ MMH one has to be accepting, as there's no acceptable reasoning for the time slip. It's connected to the FL's father, but that's all we know. Our FL learns that fated consequences are FATED and must occur. In her prior life she had a crescent-shaped scar on her arm from a coffee pot burn. She manages to avoid getting burned the 2nd time, but, instead, our ML gets burned w/ a scar /exactly/ like Ji's. Therefore, she proceeds slowly. Methodically. Carefully. She won't break up w/ her bf & future killer until she's certain she's transferred her bad fate w/ him onto her frenemy/her killer's aider-and-abetter, her lifetime friend, Soo-Min. They lay down a satisfactory (enough) premise.nnIt's also illogical at times. It's constructed in a way that's easy to ride along with as everything is attributable to fate. Fates can be transferred to others, but not avoided. They use physical objects, like shoes & candy, to reset the scene & channel ill fates to those who deserve it. After a person opens a door s/he never would/should have in ep15, & allows another party to barge in - it just wouldn't happen - I then had to stop, reflect, & admit that the whole show is built on an arguably silly premise. But I'd been enjoying it w/o a care-to-logic until then, which is indicative of skill & good execution. Just take the ride & don't think too much. If you can do that, the show is good.nnOtikay?nnIt's 2013. Again. What does Ji do?nnüç¨Break up w/ the jerk.nnüç¨Buy stocks.nnüç¨Stop being a doormat.nnBeing a doormat is not an easy habit to quit, though. Ji gets help. She's made new friends at work & she, unbeknownst to her, has an angel watching over her. 19 hours of programming gives the show ample time to methodically stroll through the plot. It takes our leads awhile to pair up. They have legitimate concerns: The prior timeline was brutal to Ji. After the break-up, the coffee pot/scar incident occurs, so she decides to soften her stance on her status w/ ex, Min Hwan - just until she leverages the potential outcome.nnPark Min Young, a truly special talent, is the FL, Kang "Ji" Won. I've seen her in What's Wrong with Secretary Kim-6.8 (apologies, it's cute, but overrated IMHO) Forecasting Love & Weather-6.8, When the Weather Is Fine-9 (it's brilliant) & Her Private Life-8 (This one deserves the accolades that Sec-Kim gets. It's adorabs)nnNa In Woo (Spark-6.4) plays Yoo Ji Hyuk. He's a tad geeky & wears ill fitting suits that look like tents. That's by design, as his character gets a needed upgrade after exposure to our FL. Purely observationally, this actor looks like a giant next to the ladies, & he also has the largest Adam's apple I've ever seen. He's an impressive looking man.nnLee Yi Kyung (Eulachacha Waikiki) portrays the weasel bf, Park Min Hwan. Song Ha Yoon (Intimate Strangers) portrays Jung Soo Min, Ji"s frenemy, & she does It marvelously. The character is yicky-icky, but the actress has a tough job, acting as a near split-personality who does drama better than ElizabethTaylor, & she sticks the landing. In fact, by ep10, I was most impressed w/ her: She's amazing. Other than guest appearances, Choi Gyu-Ri's only other role is in Behind Every Star. In MMH she plays Ji's new work friend, Yoo Hee-Yeon & she's darling. I hope to see more of her. Director, Park Won Gook also brought us Special Labor Inspector Jo, & Screenwriter Shin Yoo Dam wrote the high IQ show, Awaken. The worst criticism of MMH is that it's boilerplate stuff, but the execution is above average. It also has worthy themes.nn1st of all, some people don't know when to stop. "Gosh, I can just never win against you!", exclaims 1 conniving mean girl after losing at chess. "Well, I could predict your moves b/c you tried to take it all," is the reply. "A good leader should know how to let go of what is not theirs," is the follow-up pearl of wisdom.nn2ndly, messed up parents leave a massive pile of refuse on top of their kids' heads. I'm not trying to beat up on anyone. I doubt there is such a thing as parenting w/ zero regrets. The perfect parent has yet to be discovered. We need to try & keep the baggage to a minimum & the üíò at a maximum. Many kids can't dig out from underneath the mess & go through life at a disadvantage. Ji's mother ran off with another man - in a town so small everyone knows how many 'spoons are in each house'. The vicious gossip piled pressure on Ji to not be like her Oma. She has to look perfect. Act perfect. Cast no shadows. That's why she accepted the love she could "get". She accepted the scraps that Soo Min & Min Hwan threw at her. There was no real love there. They only used her to bolster their own egos. She was a disposable ladder for them.nn3rdly, we have another theme that is 1 of the harshest & cruelest truths that I know: Weakness is not OK. Weakness invites aggression, & enables evil: In the end, it's not much different than evil. It's easy to have compassion for somebody who's in a weak state, & we're all liable to be weakened at 1 point or another. That's just part of being human. Perhaps people who are weak enjoy the compassion & the attention tossed their way. But, in the long run, it's only going to allow in a bunch of trash. Evil must be opposed. It's like weeds. If you don't stamp them out they'll take over. I know this is brutal, but it happens to be 100% true. Sometimes, running away is the best opposition, sometimes fighting back is. Lying around to be someone else's doormat is never the right course. Never, ever, ever, EVER. And: Wallowing in self-pity is not only pathetic, it's contemptible.nnThe writer dropped more pearls of wisdom for us. Min Hwan is jealous of the boss b/c of the way Ji's been looking at him & visa-versa. He pulls her aside & unwittingly lets his character show: MH: " I told you that jerk likes you." JW: "He has a girlfriend." MH: "You are so naive. Do you really think that matters to a guy? Do you know what? Every single man is a cheater. So he has a girlfriend? A guy could be married & still like someone else. You know what a man's dream girl is? An unfamiliar lady that he doesn't know yet. That's just how men are..." By the time Ji has this following exchange with Soo-Min she's grown significantly: S: "Why do you hate me?" J: "You're self-centered. Some people have a way of eroding those around them, & you are exactly that type of person...You don't trust easily. And it's only b/c you can't be trusted. You think that everyone is like you, & so you can't trust them." When people tell you who they are, please believe them & protect yourself accordingly. Protect yourself, don't /project/ yourself.nnActing ‚úî. Writing ‚úî. Directing ‚úî - all are good. The artistry is also smashing. The wardrobe is outstanding. Both of our leads dress in DRAB, until they decide to do better - to BE better. Then they go from drab to fab. "People are already treating me differently b/c of my outfit." Ji just gave herself a makeover. She's experiencing 1st-hand how important appearances are in public life. It may not be right, but it is so. Turns out, once Ji Hyuk's in a suit that fits right, all the ladies in the office are checking him out, too. By the beginning of ep6 they look like a matched Ken & Barbie in ‚ö´ & ‚ö™ chic. There's a gorgeous wedding dress in one ep. The music is quite good, too, such as The Journey, by Kelley McRae & Wounds of Time, by Kim So Yeon. Half of ep 16 is a well executed wrap-up - what has been lacking from too many Kdramas in the past. As long as you enjoy Kromcoms, this one has its savory appeal.nnIn parting, I'll quote one k!ck@$$, self-actualized woman, Sarah Connor: "There is no fate but what we make." „Ä∞From The Terminator movies„Ä∞nnQUOTEüì¢nnThe mother of success is failure.nnYou're right. I'm a pushover. That's how I'm most comfortable.nnBeing considerate has its limits. Bad people don't recognize it when you're being considerate to them.nn„Ä∞üñç IMHOnnüì£7.6 üìù7.4 üé≠8.3 üíì7 ü¶ã5 üé®7 üéµ/üîä7.3 üîö7.6 ü§ó4.5 ‚ñ™ üåû4.5 ‚ö°5 üòÖ2 üò≠6.5 üò±4.3 üòØ4 ü§¢3 ü§î4.9 üí§0nnAge 15+nLimited but present language: $h!+ Füí£nnRated TV-15nnRe-üì∫? NeutralnnRecs:nCrazy Love-7.8,nTouch your heart 8.2,nRomance is a bonus book-7.9,nHer Private Life 8,nLove to Hate You 8.9,nOh My Ghost 10,nBe Melodramatic-8.7,nHospital Playlist 9.

RWBY has been an amazing journey so far, from its classic beginnings (Seasons 1-3), through to the mixed received middle era (Seasons 4-6). Now, I have reached the final seasons... well as of yet, many are still to come. From what I am able to gather, 7-9 seems to be the least talked about era compared to the others, and I'm not quite sure the reason.nnThe only explanation I could maybe come up with is that people either find these last few seasons forgettable, or that there's not so much to talk about... but man do I have a lot to talk about when it comes to Volume 7. Seeing as I knew I was reaching RWBY's 3rd era, I wasn't sure what to expect.nnI barley have found many reviews when it comes to Volume 7, let alone many people even talking about it in general. In fact, as unpopular Volumes 8-9 are to the fandom, they're at least talked about for a variety of different reasons, whereas Volume 7 sort of just... exists. And after giving it a watch... I have to say that this is probably the definitive example of the term "slow burn".nnQuickly, I must get one thing out of the way which is somewhat upsetting... this is probably the worst soundtrack in RWBY... and yet its still incredible! By no means is it anywhere near the level of Volume 4 or 1's soundtrack, but it's so worth the listen. The first half of the lyrical songs are very... strange, and are mainly jazz-like or upbeat music you wouldn't expect from something as angry and metal as RWBY.nnWith that said, the second half carries a lot of that Volume 6 energy, where everything feels so passive aggressive, where all the characters are tired of playing games! It stands out the most in fight scenes as well, I couldn't help but notice the strange shift in instruments and tone in the second half of the soundtrack compared to the first...nnAnd that's the best way I can explain its volume... having a pretty standard and middle-ground first half, yet having a second half so incredible that the entire thing is worth it... but that's also not exactly a great thing. The second half of this Volume absolutely blew my mind and took my breath away... but its such a shame that the first 6 episodes aren't at that same level.nnRight away, I must bring up the fact that the main problem I have with this Volume in its first few episodes is that it doesn't know where it wants to go. It almost feels as though they knew where to take the last few episodes, but lost track with how pacing and character development should work. What I find so fun about RWBY is its ability to cleanly switch from one scene to another so smoothly while connecting the dots all together whilst doing so... that wasn't what was happening during the first few episodes.nnThe episodes struggled to find which characters it wanted to focus on, what the intentions were, which unfortunately, lead to a lot of filler. The reasoning behind having this con may be due to the addition of several new characters. Without spoiling, brand new characters as well as surprising guests from previous seasons make a comeback, which only has the story anxiously put pieces together to hopefully form a story.nnIt doesn't come off too horribly, and I would be lying if I said it was downright terrible, but I won't lie when I say the first half of Volume 7 was probably some of the most dull episodes of RWBY... which kind of hurts. These episodes weren't bad, but I would struggle to sit through all of them again if I were to rewatch this season... which as shocking as this may sound due to my rant, I probably will do.nnThis is because these last episodes of the Volume carry some of the greatest episodes I have ever seen in not only RWBY, but in any show I have seen in my life. The episode titled "Gravity" still stands as the third best episode I have ever seen in the show (with the first two best being the last 2 episodes of Volume 3). Even the next episode after, "With Friends like these" is a potential Top 10 episode of the show, that's how amazing this second half was.nnThe fights during this half felt so ferocious, like everyone hated each other and wanted nothing more than to slit each other's throats. And best of all, the pacing didn't feel anywhere close to boring now that the new and returning characters finally added something to the plots structure. The whole time while watching, I knew that these new characters were definitely important, it was just hard to tell when they would really shine, which eventually takes awhile to happen.nnAgain, no spoilers at all, bit some of the plot twists also had me in shock and experience similar emotions the whole cast of characters felt in these scenarios. These situations finally meant something; this second half should probably go down as the most important part of the Pre-Volume 3 period.nnWith all this in mind, it should be clear that this is so far RWBY's... strangest Volume. The first hour or so sadly feels like a chore, which is something I have never felt before when watching RWBY, and heck, there's only 2 episodes in this whole Volume that surpass the 8/10 mark on IMDb (arguably, Gravity being an 8.7).nnBut I can't promise enough that every second is entirely worth it, because I don't know if I can speak for many RWBY fans, but the final 3 episodes will be some of the most groundbreaking, cinematic, and astonishing episodes of RWBY you will ever watch, which is insane considering this is much past the classic era (that era featuring some of the greatest episodes of all time).nnIt was a super tough decision, but I think I would go as far as to rank this slightly above Volume 1. Sure, I understand that Volume is iconic and brings some of the most snappy and well-known dialogue in the whole show, but I'm still so taken aback by how the last few episodes decided to slap me in the face with bewilderment at first, I still cant believe how much I enjoyed those episodes.nnEveryone is right when it comes to this Volume being forgetful, I can completely see that. The first half struggles so much on what it wants to be and has trouble finding its identity... but after slowly piecing the puzzle together, it ends up producing some of the most magical episodes I have ever watched in any show in my life. And for that, I could never find myself to find it truly unmemorable.

I really loved their chemistry. Every episode hooked me to find or puzzled every scenes that I have watched. If you consistently watch the episode until the end you'll understand the flow of the drama. I hope there's season 2 for it. I want to see more of their chemistry and impressive acting between both actors. They portrayed their character well.nnSoobin and Yoonseok did a great job. Thanks for this drama I was able to watch a Korean drama again for the longest time hahaha!nnI hope that they will have another project again with any genre because I know that whatever character they can do their job well.

As I am certain many others have pointed out in the almost 200 reviews on this series, it is the best (and worst even though I mean that in a very good way) emotional rollercoaster ride possible. It starts out fairly mildly with evoking compassion for Charles (Ted Danson) as he seeks purpose and meaning in his life. The walls are closing in after his wife's death and his retirement. He has a 'decent' but not close relationship with his daughter that has devolved into clipping printed newspaper articles and mailing them to her rather than calling or in person visits even thought hey live 2 hours apart. Charles' background and personality make it difficult for him to fully recognize and 'fix' his problem - lack of purpose and loneliness. But the series is not overly heavy handed with this in the beginning, just a constant reminder like water on stone, slowly eroding away and marking Charles' personality.nnThe (improbable but believable) twists and turns that set Charles on a track to try to stay relevant offers a rich field for Ted Danson's ability to play interesting and somewhat quirky characters with humor. Not over the top, begging for laughs, but much like Charles' sartorial choices in the show, feel like a comfortable, well worn set of clothes. Natural.nnAll is good until towards the end of episode 5 (at least that's where I finally woke up to the impending blows of the incoming sledgehammer) when we are pummeled by a number situations that penetrate deeply to those of us who are of an older generation, who have lost parents and grandparents (or younger friends and family as well), or have had family members suffer from Alzheimer's and dementia. The vibe (for me at least) sharply turned from a comedic story of one person's journey to find fulfillment in their later life into a repetitive bitch slap of reality that seniors and their friends and family go through. Loss, pain and helplessness in the face of recognizing that we cannot 'fix' all problems. And ultimately, Memento Mori.nnThe redeeming portion of this story arc is that Charles, who is never portrayed as a selfish or callus person, becomes much more socially and self-aware. Recognizing the needs of others, and the special awareness from Charles' own personal history with his late wife, Charles demonstrates compassion, kindness, and, most importantly, action to try to help where he can. All while accomplishing the objective of his new (and temporary) job.nnWe are left with an upbeat ending, not ignoring the combined losses suffered during Season 1, but rather regaining and focusing on the relationships created and restored. New energy in Charles' life - and for others due in part to Charles' interactions and interventions, subtly underscore the fact that life is worth living and seeking to live our best possible lives with whatever time we have.nnA Man on the Inside hits hard at times but balances things out - just as in real life, it is how we focus on living and taking joy where we can while still mourning those we have lost. Well balanced, with laughter and tears - I am looking forward to Season 2 already and cannot wait to find out what Charles' next 'job' (and continued journey of self-awareness) is.

"My Old Ass" is a 2024 coming-of-age comedy-drama directed by Megan Park. The film stars Maisy Stella as Elliott, an 18-year-old on the brink of college, who, after consuming psychedelic mushrooms, encounters her 39-year-old future self, portrayed by Aubrey Plaza. This unexpected meeting leads Elliott to reassess her relationships and life choices.nnThe film has been praised for its unique premise and strong performances. Critics highlight the chemistry between Stella and Plaza, noting that their interactions bring both humor and depth to the narrative. The picturesque setting of Muskoka Lakes, Ontario, adds a nostalgic and romantic backdrop to the story. However, some reviewers feel that while the film introduces modern elements, it ultimately follows a conventional storyline.nnOverall, "My Old Ass" offers a fresh twist on the coming-of-age genre, blending humor with introspection. It's a thoughtful exploration of self-discovery and the complexities of growing up, making it a worthwhile watch for those interested in heartfelt narratives.

Boys Don't Cry (1999), directed by Kimberly Peirce, is a powerful and harrowing portrayal of a young transgender man named Brandon Teena (Hilary Swank), who navigates the complexities of love, identity, and survival while trying to live as a man in rural Nebraska. Based on a true story, the film shines a spotlight on the emotional and physical toll of societal rejection, gender identity struggles, and the extreme violence faced by transgender individuals.nnHilary Swank delivers a career-defining performance as Brandon, capturing the vulnerability, strength, and determination of a young man trying to find acceptance in a world that refuses to see him for who he truly is. Swank's portrayal is both sensitive and raw, drawing the audience deeply into Brandon's world. Chlo√´ Sevigny, as Brandon's girlfriend, provides a tender and equally compelling performance, while Peter Sarsgaard offers a chilling portrayal of one of the film's antagonists, embodying the toxic masculinity and violence that fuels the story's tragic turn.nnThe film's direction is deliberate and gritty, with a documentary-like realism that emphasizes the isolation and hardship faced by Brandon and his loved ones. The cinematography is often unpolished, reflecting the rawness of the characters' experiences, while the film's pacing keeps the tension palpable, building up to the devastating conclusion. The film doesn't shy away from showing the brutal reality of Brandon's life, confronting issues of gender violence and the dangers of trying to live authentically in an unforgiving society.nnWhile the film's unflinching portrayal of violence and discrimination may be difficult for some viewers, it's an essential narrative that opens a dialogue about the struggles faced by the transgender community. However, its heavy subject matter, combined with some pacing issues in the middle, may detract from its overall impact for some viewers.nnBoys Don't Cry is a poignant and heartbreaking film that challenges perceptions of identity and acceptance while delivering standout performances from its cast. It's a painful yet necessary watch that raises awareness of transgender issues and the brutal consequences of ignorance and hatred.nnRating: 6/10. A raw and powerful film that explores identity and survival, with strong performances but a difficult, often painful, subject matter.

The Other Side of Hope (2017), directed and written by Aki Kaurism√§ki, is a beautifully crafted film that blends humor, drama, and social commentary with Kaurism√§ki's signature minimalist style. The story follows a poker-playing restaurateur, played by Sakari Kuosmanen, who befriends a group of refugees newly arrived in Finland. As the characters navigate the complexities of their new lives, the film explores themes of friendship, survival, and the quest for belonging.nnThe performances are understated but deeply affecting, with Sherwan Haji giving a moving portrayal of a Syrian refugee trying to find his place in an unfamiliar world. Kuosmanen's portrayal of the restaurateur is equally compelling, embodying a character who, though initially detached, becomes a source of quiet support and solidarity for the refugees. The chemistry between the characters feels authentic, and their growing friendship is the heart of the film.nnKaurism√§ki's direction is simple yet profound, with sparse dialogue and a deliberate pace that allows the film's themes to unfold naturally. The cinematography complements the story's mood, using muted colors and still frames to reflect the emotional restraint of the characters while emphasizing the quiet beauty of their interactions. The soundtrack, which features folk and traditional music, further enhances the film's sense of warmth and humanity.nnThe Other Side of Hope is a film about kindness in the face of adversity, highlighting the humanity that connects us all regardless of background or circumstance. While the film's pace may be slow for some, its emotional impact and thoughtful commentary on the refugee crisis make it a poignant and rewarding experience.nnRating: 8/10. A quietly powerful film that explores the themes of hope and human connection with subtlety and grace.

I never leave User Reviews on IMDB. No one will read them. But this series is so incredibly good and it has given me so much that I feel obliged to write about it although no one will ever read this or care.nnSince BoB aired I must have watched it over 40 times (at least twice a year). With some episodes like "Day of Days", "Carentan" and the Battle of the Bulge episodes getting more airtime than others.nnWhat amazes me is the timelessness of the series. This could have been made in 2011, 2021 or even in 2031. It never ever gets old. I feel a connection to the characters I have never felt in any other movie or series before and probably never will again.nnThe story, the acting, the effects, the authenticity, the music....everything about this series I just beyond excellent. It is hard for me to imagine that this level of quality will ever be surpassed.nnAnd now almost 25 years later when we know that not all things portrayed in the series were accurate, I still regularly return to the series.nnHere's to another 25 years of watching BoB, because that is exactly what I'm going to do.nnCurrahee!

Contains spoilers up to Season 6, so only read, if you watched all of it.nnAltogether: Very good acting, directing, and storytelling.nnThings I liked:nnThere are 3 main themes, which you will see throughout the series:nnFirst, there is the "badass" theme which Johnny Lawrence represents. 80's rock and roll, "be a man, don't be a pussy", that kind of stuff. Every time Johnny gives a Cobra Kai (later Eagle Fang) lesson, there is some cool 80's hard rock music happening with amazing cutscenes representing the attitude, and the challenges are often absurd. Obviously, the filmmakers deliberately overdid this, but in a really humorous way, which often ends in a disastrous way or at least not the way he intended. You shouldn't take this too seriously, because it is intended to be like this to emphasize the attitude. If you see this as a source of humour, then you will have a great time. At first this theme is also the bad theme, as Johnny sticks to the Cobra Kai motto "Strike first, strike hard, no mercy", and that is what he teaches, but soon he realizes that this was a mistake, and you can be badass without being evil. Johnny's character development is shown excellently both story wise, and in representation.nnThen, there is the second theme, the "good guy theme" which Daniel LaRusso is trying to represent. Trying to keep the teachings of his former Karate teacher, Miyagi Sensei, he wants to show kids the "right" way of Karate, which is balance, kindness, and defence only. While he thinks he always acts like what Miyagi Sensei taught him, that is often not the case, as he is very stubborn because of his childhood traumas. He is clearly not over the past where he suffered from Johnny's bullying, but nor is Johnny suffering from Kreese's misguidance and the defeat that Daniel did to him at the All-Valley tournament. This often causes Daniel to escalate situations to the worse, instead of letting go, and finding balance. This is also not to be taken too seriously as this is also a source of great humour that both Daniel and Johnny are acting like child rivals all the time, even though they are grown up adults now. It is very funny, but sometimes though-provoking, that their young students seem to be more mature when their Senseis are having a debate. Lots of the conflict solving between Johnny and Daniel relies on their students, or a third person, like Amanda, Daniel's wife.nnAnd then there is the "evil theme" which is represented first by John Kreese, and later by Terry Silver. Kreese takes over Cobra Kai and manipulates students to be heartless, unforgiving, and ruthless to other people. They teach that the real world is cruel and you should also be, if you want to survive. This causes the young students to commit violent acts, and give innocent kids immense bullying. The series involves a number of flashback memories of Kreese and Silver being in the battlefield of the Vietnam war, which somewhat explains where their cruelty is coming from. It is a very good move in filmmaking, showing that they are not born evil, but also suffered from traumas that made them like this, and how they had come to the conclusion that you have to give no mercy, because the world doesn't show you mercy. Diving into Kreese's and Terry's past and giving us an explanation as to what events led to their psychological state is what I consider a great step forward from the original Karate Kid movie.nnThe main plot is that although at first Johnny and Daniel thought they are enemies of each other, they soon realize they need to rise above their childish rivalry and unite in order to beat the greater evil, which is John Kreese's/Terry Silver's Cobra Kai. This is represented beautifully and has a slow burn to it with lot's of conflicts, reactions, events and character development.nnThere is also non-karate related teen drama involved, like the love between Robby, Tory, Miguel, and Samantha in every configuration, and adult and family drama with Daniel and his wife, their children, and Johnny and his ex-wife and their kid Robby, and Miguel's family which adds a great deal to the story. Then, as the story progresses these 3 main families are tied in more than one way.nnThe only other families that we can get a little peak is Tory's "family" which involves a dying mother, and an aunt who wants to inherit everything they had. And Kenny's family who has a father on a military quest, and a brother in juvie, and a mother.nnThings I missed or didn't like:nnI wish the story involved more of the families of main characters, like Hawk, Demitri, Devon and see how their parents reacted on the whole Karate drama, and how they try to interact and make contact with other parents to solve the problems their kids are having.nnOne other thing I'm missing is more side characters in the dojos. There are like 4-5 side characters altogether, but I think it really narrows down the plot. I would've loved to see more of the new members of Cobra Kai, and Miyagi Do have at least some screen time. There is Berth, Mitch, Chris, Stingray which are not that important in the story, but I really wanted to see more students introduced, and give them some meaning to the story. There is a couple of scenes where you can see random people in both Cobra Kai and Miyagi/Eagle Fang dojos, but we don't even know their names.nnAlso, there could have been at least one, but preferably two or more dojos in the Valley that competes with the main two Dojos, with two or more students with important role. But there are none. Any other dojos we see is only at the tournament, with nearly zero screen time, and that blue dojo, which Silver buys after Miyagi/Eagle fang finishes second in the second All-Valley and has to quit.nnOne thing I felt really unjustified is that at season 6, Demitri is going to the Sekkai Tekkai and fights like a pro, while the whole Demitri character is portrayed about being afraid of fighting, and hard work, and not wanting the whole Karate thing in his life. Even after he lands a successful kick at Hawk at the school fighting in season 2, Demitri is portrayed like he doesn't want hard training and Karate in his life, and there is no sign that he trains hard. So how did he do this good in the Sekkai Tekkai? They should've shown Demitri becoming a hard-training Karate student that can fight good, but there weren't any signs of this.nnAlso, I miss more female characters. The whole story involves only 3 main female characters, Sam, Tory, and at the end Devon. There could have been more.nnConclusion:nnAltogether, I love this series, and even though some people say it's corny or cheesy, it's meant to be this way, and that makes the beauty of it. It's funny, exciting, emotional and badass at the same time, and I'm glad this series exists, and I had an amazing time watching it.

I'm probably in extreme minority of people who survived watching Every Single Episode of this show.nnAnd I started watching it still with an open mind.nnIt was really dumb and disrespectful towards the Scooby Doo franchise, but I am still the type who loves watching traiwrecks in slow motion and have fun watching something bad.nnThat was the case for majority of season 1.nnIt was terrible, dumb and... unpredictable, because you can't predict such stupidity.nnBut season 2... They tried to top themselves with how ridiculous everything was.nnBrains in Jars, being popular girls, they even get piercings.nnIt got to the point where it wasn't even funny how bad it was. It was tiring. And some dialogues made straight up no sense, like the writers used ChatGPT to write it for them, or they had some thought and decided to not go with it but nobody erased the leftovers of that thought from the script...nnI give it 2/10, I'll be generous, because I had few laughs in season 1.

When I ask friends, family, and acquaintances if they like horror movies, the most common response is no, they don't like horror movies that are solely about torture and gore. The terrifier series is exactly the type of movie they're referencing.nnI believe your enjoyment of terrifier will come down to a simple yes or no equation. Do you like torture porn? If yes, you will enjoy this series. If not, you won't.nnThere's no doubt that terrifier 2 is a significantly better movie than it's predecessor, terrifier 1. The production is better, the soundtrack is better, the acting is better, the writing is better. And yet, the core of the movies remains the same. People die slowly in horrifically gory set pieces.nnArt the clown never talks and he mimes grand amusement at the disgusting misery of his victims. He's a killer I noted as unique and interesting in terrifier 1 but honestly the originality is starting to wear thin. I can only watch Art laugh and point at a disfigured victim so often before it grows old. Miming amusement might be very different from other slasher killers but it's still a one-note range of reactions.nnI often think about movies in terms of the emotions they invoke in the viewer. Horror movies should, in an ideal world, invoke horror which is a combination of fear and repugnance. I never felt scared watching this movie. The primary emotion at play in terrifier is disgust so the repugnance is covered but I don't think suspense and fear are handled well at all in these films. This is why I would categorize terrifier in the same genre as movies like hostel, the human centipede, and other torture porn flicks.nnUltimately, it comes down to what you expect and want out of horror films. I want suspense and fear interlaced with horrific elements. Terrifier focuses mostly on horrific gore and torture but lacks in suspense and fear.nnI also want to say that obviously my review is subjective. There's nothing wrong with appreciating gore and torture in a film, it's just not for me. In terms of gore and torture porn, terrifier is exceptional. My low rating is simply because I do not appreciate those elements and found the film lacking in elements I cherish like suspense and terror. Which is mildly ironic given the film's title.

"Damsel" is a refreshingly original and delightfully quirky film that turns the traditional princess fairy tale on its head. Directed by Edward Burns and starring Millie Bobby Brown, the movie follows the story of Elodie, a princess who is anything but the typical damsel in distress.nnThe film begins with Elodie being kidnapped by a dragon and taken to its lair. But instead of waiting to be rescued, Elodie takes matters into her own hands and sets out to escape. Along the way, she meets a bumbling knight named Sir Edward, who is tasked with rescuing her.nnAs the story unfolds, it becomes clear that Elodie is no ordinary princess. She's smart, resourceful, and determined to take control of her own destiny. Millie Bobby Brown shines in the role, bringing a perfect blend of humor, wit, and vulnerability to the character.nnThe film's script is clever and engaging, with plenty of witty one-liners and humorous moments. The pacing is quick and energetic, with a narrative that's full of unexpected twists and turns.nnOne of the standout aspects of "Damsel" is its feminist themes. The movie cleverly subverts traditional fairy tale tropes, presenting a strong and independent female protagonist who doesn't need a man to rescue her. Elodie is a true heroine, and her story is a powerful celebration of female empowerment.nnThe film's visuals are also noteworthy, with a vibrant color palette and impressive production design. The dragon's lair is a particular highlight, with its intricate stone carvings and fiery torches.nnIf you're looking for a fun and original take on the traditional fairy tale, "Damsel" is a must-see. With its clever script, engaging characters, and feminist themes, it's a movie that will delight audiences of all ages.nnIn short, "Damsel" is a damsel-in-distress story that's anything but distressing. It's a fun, feisty, and feminist fairy tale that will leave you smiling and feeling empowered.nnRating: 4.5/5 starsnnRecommendation: "Damsel" is a great choice for anyone who loves fairy tales, adventure movies, or strong female protagonists. It's suitable for audiences of all ages, although some scenes may be too intense for very young children.

Title: A Cinematic MasterpiecennRating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (10/10)nnReview:nnFrom the very first frame to the closing credits, this film is an absolute triumph of storytelling, direction, and performance. The director's vision is brought to life with such precision and artistry that it leaves you spellbound. The cinematography is breathtaking, capturing every emotion and nuance with stunning clarity. The screenplay is a perfect blend of drama, humor, and heart, keeping you engaged and invested in the characters' journeys.nnThe cast delivers performances that are nothing short of extraordinary. Each actor brings depth and authenticity to their roles, making you feel every joy, sorrow, and triumph alongside them. The chemistry between the leads is palpable, adding an extra layer of magic to the film.nnThe soundtrack is a beautiful accompaniment to the visuals, enhancing every scene and elevating the emotional impact. The attention to detail in the production design, costumes, and special effects is impeccable, creating a world that feels both real and fantastical.nnIn summary, this movie is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates the art of cinema. It is a testament to the power of storytelling and a reminder of why we love movies. A true masterpiece that will be remembered for years to come.

The cinematography is vibrant, especially during the surreal trip scenes, and the soundtrack perfectly captures the bittersweet, nostalgic vibe of a transformative summer. While the pacing occasionally drags, the witty script and strong performances keep you engaged. The older Elliott's advice isn't preachy but comes with the weight of lived experience, making her warnings feel both relatable and slightly heartbreakingnOverall, My Old Ass is a hilarious, touching, and surprisingly profound film that reminds us how messy but beautiful growing up-and growing older-can be. It's a must-watch for anyone who's ever wondered what their younger or older self might have to say.

Possibly my all time favourite film.nnI will make no reference to plot points. There are other places to go for film synopsis.nn'A Scanner Darkly' is a fraught, thought provoking, surprising, suspenseful, paranoid and uniquely funny ride from start to finish. The first feature length narrative driven film to employ the astonishingly beautiful rotoscoping animation technique, it is unique in so many ways.nnPhilip K Dick's writing is done justice by a formidable ensemble of actors, with Keanu Reeves, Winona Ryder, Robert Downey Jr, Woody Harrelson and Rory Cochrane providing perfect performances throughout, and Richard Linklater's direction cementing 'A Scanner Darkly' as an enduring cinematic classic. It really is that powerfully good.nnThe prescient nature of the story being told is at once amazing and slightly disturbing, with Philip K Dick's work, yet again, unfolding across the decades in to a virtually clairvoyant commentary of the state of today's society.nnIf you enjoy challenging, complex, character driven narrative film making that is simply breathtaking in its scope and beauty while providing scathing social commentary in an utterly captivating and entertaining manner, you will surely love the cinematic masterpiece that is 'A Scanner Darkly.

Movie from Canadian director Megan Park starts very well; it is an apparent body-swap adventure with plenty of promised laughs featuring Aubrey Plaza, and her billed presence alone made it one of the autumn's most attractive-seeming films. But mystifyingly, dismayingly, My Old Ass morphs into a gloopy, droopy, soupy young adult fantasy romance which finally fails to deliver its own ending, and we are denied the actual big finish, without which the entire story has been a pointless waste of time. (I suspect an earlier script-draft had that ending but Park had second thoughts. If you are looking for a funny and entertaining movie I recommend it.

The portrayal of Mexico is a caricature, riddled with lazy stereotypes - other than the mum saying her son teacher was missing - so it covers a couple of violent headline news, but far from a full critic of why it happens. The fact that not a single Mexican actor graces the screen, a slap in the face to a rich culture and talented performers dealing with difficult themes.nnThe music? An offensive assault on the ears. It's as if the composers Googled "Mexican music" and slapped together the first five results. No soul, no nuance, just a jarring cacophony. Sorry but "hasta mi pinche vulva te extra√±a" is so cringey in spanish!nnAnd the trans representation? The film reduces a complex and nuanced identity to a cheap plot device, lacking any genuine depth or respect into a couple of poorly written songs about "de pene a vagina".nn"Emilia P√©rez" is not just a bad movie, it's an insult.

column3: "Skeleton Crew" (2024) {We're Gonna Be in So Much Trouble (#1.7)}
column4: We watched an episode that provided above average viewing pleasure. I think if there are no surprises in the last episode, Skeleton Crew will probably close its IMDB score at 7.2-7.4. It's a pretty good score for a Disney production.nnWith the crazy Captain Silvo killing Brutus without hesitation, we saw once again that this series does not appeal to children. This scene in particular reminded me of the moment when Han Solo killed Greedo.nnThe ones seen in the hologram were most likely KB's parents, which shows that KB's parents are homosexual. Although it doesn't pose a problem for me, it doesn't make sense for Disney to introduce this classic visibility method into every project, whether relevant or not.nnAlthough SM 33's knockout of Captain Silvo made me laugh and I admired SM 33 again, it felt very forced that he was defeated with a lightsaber just a few minutes later. The biggest thing I will criticize about this series is that SM 33 is defeated in almost every episode, it is not nice at all.nnAs for the At Attin issue, the scene where we see this mysterious planet inside the Barrier was very special in terms of both image quality and spiritual feelings. However, if the only mystery of At Attin is that it is the Mint of the Old Republic, I think the series will fail very badly because especially in the 3rd episode, what it made us feel about this planet was much more.nnI hope we will see a completely different side of it in the finale.nnWe heard the inspector's voice for the first time, even if it was for a second. Captain Silvo said to the droid, "Bring the inspector. It's better than talking to a droid." and I'm sure we will see the Inspector as a droid in the finale.nnAnd another scene ending with a lightsaber... No matter what, I don't think Captain Silvo is bad enough to do this to the children's family.

Pushpa: The Rule - Part 2 (2024) attempts to build on the high-octane drama of its predecessor, diving deeper into the turbulent life of Pushpa (Allu Arjun) as he battles relentless opposition to sustain his sandalwood smuggling empire. Directed by Sukumar, the film promises an epic continuation of the saga but struggles under the weight of its sprawling narrative and excessive runtime.nnAllu Arjun once again delivers a charismatic performance, embodying Pushpa with grit and determination. His on-screen presence remains a major draw, and his dynamic with Rashmika Mandanna provides occasional emotional grounding. Fahadh Faasil, as the ruthless police officer, brings a menacing intensity, but his character's development feels sidelined in favor of overextended action sequences and melodramatic subplots.nnVisually, the film is a spectacle, with vibrant cinematography and high-energy set pieces that capture the rugged allure of its forest setting. However, the storytelling is bogged down by uneven pacing, with a bloated runtime of over three hours that stretches the plot thin. Key moments of tension and drama are diluted by unnecessary digressions, making the film feel disjointed.nnWhile the film attempts to delve into themes of power, loyalty, and survival, these elements are often overshadowed by style-over-substance filmmaking. The music and choreography, while energetic, occasionally feel excessive, detracting from the narrative's impact.nnPushpa: The Rule - Part 2 is a mixed bag, offering moments of cinematic flair and compelling performances but ultimately succumbing to an overambitious scope. Fans of the first installment may appreciate the continuation, but the sequel lacks the sharp focus and intensity that made the original stand out.nnRating: 5/10. A visually arresting but narratively bloated sequel that struggles to recapture the magic of its predecessor.

My old ass is a very interesting movie, I highly recommend. I can watch it everyday without getting tired üëå. The romantic storyline is sweet and unfolds naturally without being rushed or inauthentic. Elliott's exploration of queer identity feels real and fits into her larger exploration of identity itself, adding some nuance to coming of age. The beautiful natural setting and seeming simplicity of the plot lend a sense of profundity to the larger questions at hand -- who we are, why we are, and what's worth it in this life. Overall, the movie is well-written, decently paced, and earns its sentiment without ever being sentimental. It evokes true emotion, a testament to its substance in a cluttered field. If you've ever been in a situation where pain was anticipated, even guaranteed, but the experience was worth it anyway -- this movie will feel bittersweet, and, overall, familiar.

In Loser is Winner, each defeat is a stepping stone to something greater. The protagonist's journey is riddled with mishaps, but the humor and heart keep the story alive. It's a joyous exploration of what it means to embrace imperfection and keep moving forward. Loser is Winner delivers a rollercoaster of emotions, capturing the humor and heartbreak of failure. The characters are unforgettable, their struggles relatable, and their triumphs heartwarming. It's a bold, comedic take on the idea that losing is just another path to winning. With a mix of sharp humor and heartfelt storytelling, Loser is Winner captures the resilience of the human spirit. Each setback feels like a victory in disguise, making this a story that's as empowering as it is entertaining.

This does not feel like a Scorsese movie... except, yes it does when you've got the F word every 5 seconds in a 3-hour movie.nnThe Wolf of Wall Street is a wild ride. I've never had so much fun in the cinema before. The audience was unanimously in stitches, and the editing was so amazing that it felt like a 2-hour movie, not 3 hours.nnFrom the get-go the crazy and addictive momentum of the narrative is spearheaded by Matthew McConaughey's monologue about the necessity of masturbating multiple times a day, drinking several martinis, and snorting coke frequently in order to function and survive as a quotidian Wall Street stock broker. At first we witness DiCaprio's adorable naivety awkwardly exposed amidst a pool of sharks, but once the influence of the daily hustle and grind sinks in, he transforms into what could be among his best onscreen performances.nnThe Wolf of Wall Street is dazzling in all respects, and incorporates a very witty and crackling screenplay to boot. Jonah Hill almost steals the show as Leo's chubby and jovial sidekick (watch for the qualuude OD sequence), while Margot Robbie hits it out of the ballpark as Leo's terrifyingly sizzling Jersey wife.nnThis is perhaps one of Scorsese's most accessible and watchable outings. I've been sold.

Watched almost the entire first episode, but couldn't finish it as it was so so average.nnFrom the below average looking women and above average looking men, there wasn't any true acting or true writing for that matter.nnThe action starts 70 years after the end of the Butlerian Jihad, basically the end of a century old war against thinking machines and the complete removal of this technology from millions of planets.nnThat conflict forced humans to specialize in functions the machine usually had. And it forced humanity to mutate and adapt to win the war, with a return to feudalism and with the start of different philosophies.nnBene Gesserit origins and there pharmaceutical interests, their training, their studies of the human body... is non-existent.nnThe source material was so rich and developed, you would need to really be ignorant to just put this bland and uninspiring exposition.nnAnyways, I will not continue to watch it, as it has nothing for me ... just another Rings of Power or Wheel of Time.

The story's humor and grit are intoxicating, drawing viewers into a world where the underdog thrives in the chaos of defeat. It's quirky, uplifting, and unflinchingly honest. With sharp writing and memorable characters, Loser is Winner flips the script on conventional success stories. The protagonist's failures are both comical and painfully relatable, offering a fresh perspective on perseverance. It's a celebration of imperfection with a surprising depth of emotion. The Rise of the Underdog: A Bizarrely Inspiring Journey.

I absolutely loved this drama! Everyone did an amazing job. Having read the webtoon, I can confidently say the drama's characters lived up to their names. The webtoon's Sa Eon had a darker persona, but I really liked the drama version too-he was such a gentleman!nnSoobin, aka Hejoo, also did an amazing job. Huge props to her for learning sign language-it added so much depth to her character and the story.nnFor those saying the last part didn't make sense, I suggest rewatching it and paying close attention. It's easy to miss some details when you're engrossed in the mystery and the love story's progression.nnHowever, I did notice some translation issues that led to misunderstandings. It's unfair to rate the drama 1 star because of this. So much effort went into it! Giving it 1 out of 10? That's just too harsh.

This is billed as a docudrama though anyone with even a cursory knowledge of Roman history will take offense to any part of this series being labeled as a documentary. Taking creative liberties in dramatizing a subject matter for television audiences is one thing; rewriting history while presenting it as historical fact is something else altogether and crosses into unethical territory.nnPresenting Carthage as freedom fighting barbarians led by a black Hannibal waging war against the slave-master Rome is so historically off base that it's insulting. Carthage was the dominant Mediterranean power well before Rome was even a republic and like all empires at the time they were well-known for having a large slave population, even more so than Rome. They were Phoenician people from Tyre in present-day Lebanon and have absolutely no relation to Sub-Saharan Africa, which is the equivalent of an ocean away, so presenting Hannibal and his family as black Africans was obviously a decision made in order to push a particular agenda despite knowing it's a flat out lie. That's fine for a fictional series but don't present it as history. The best thing I can say about this series is that it's a real challenge seeing how far you can make it before reflexively shutting it off.

My Old Ass is a coming of age story that merges elements of a stoner comedy with some low tech time travel to great effect. It's so funny and easy to like but its greatest strength comes from the emotional core and the beautiful messages which come from it. It's a winning argument about how life is messy, scary and full of extremely painful heartbreak however, that only makes it all the more important to take the risks and enjoy the best moments.nnThe authentic connections between Elliott, Chad (Percy Hynes White), and her friends (Maddie Ziegler, Kerrice Brooks), and family moments solidly hit home - poignant scenes with brother Max (Seth Isaac Johnson) as a social conscience, whimsical Spencer (Carter Trozollo) , and with her mom (Maria Dizzia) and dad (Alain Goulem), bring surprising emotional depths on a vehicle of relatable, and well delivered comedy. We came in for a short trip, and wound up wishing we could hang out longer inside this unexpected cinematic, treat.

The Series Three Woman positions itself as an unflinching exploration of womanhood and sex but stumbles into something far more shallow and frustrating. The characters are flat, offering no emotional depth or reason to evolve. Instead, they remain consumed by their own vapid hatred of their lives and obsessed with what "others" are supposedly saying about them.nnThe irony, however, is glaring: when you pull back the curtain to see who's really voicing these awful sentiments about women, it's the show itself. The supposed critique of societal expectations turns into a self-loathing caricature that tears women down while pretending to lift them up.nnIt's a painful watch, not because it's raw or real, but because it's so devoid of heart or genuine understanding. Without growth, humanity, or meaningful insight, the series feels like a cynical exercise in judgment rather than an exploration of womanhood.

Years and years have gone by without seeing popular media and queer identities mix, ESPECIALLY lesbians. This is the first time I've felt truly represented in an animated show without being censored. The lesbian characters got the same treatment and sex scene a "normal" straight couple might get. This is an extremely big step forward for lesbian representation. This is what REAL rep looks like, a normal couple, that happens to be 2 women. The episode was a long time build up of 2 complex and interesting characters that, since they graced the screen together, had chemistry. It felt real, it felt like a proper build up, and a good climax to their relationship on screen before an intense fight for their lives. I can only wish to see more shows rep queer women like this in my life time. This was a GREAT episode beyond just the enjoyment, writing, and animation. This is arguably historical.

Rewatched the original trilogy as a refresher before watching Resurrections and realized I'd forgotten just how dull the second and particularly the third movies actually were. Did not have high hopes for this film because of the low IMDB rating, but actually LOVED it! Really enjoyed the continuation of the story and finding out what happened in the real world and in the matrix after the war ended. The many self-references and easter eggs were spot-on and the video footage homages to the original Morpheus and Agent Smith were perfect. The fight scenes weren't the boring, blown-out CGI of the third film, but were character-focused and emotionally meaningful. Jonathan Gross and Neil Patrick Harris were both excellent in their respective roles and as a Sense8 fan, I also loved seeing all the Sense8 cast roles and cameos. If a fifth movie is made, I look forward to see more character development with this new cast. Overall, really really good. Hugely exceeded my expectations and was a delight to watch. Thank you for this new chapter, Lana!

My older brother introduced me to The Little Rascals back in, like, 2010, when he was 10, and he's roughly 3 years older than me. Not long after we checked the first DVD of Our Gang by Hal Roach out of the library, we eventually watched the movie together, and I really enjoyed it. In fact, I have ever since!nnBasically, this movie is a setting update of Our Gang, but with many of the same characters, and its plot consists of re-interpretations of a couple of the original shorts. The central plot thread is this: young mischief-maker Spanky MacFarland (played by Travis Tedford) is the president of an anti-girl club called the He-Man Womun Haters Club (his words, not mine), and picks his best friend, Alfalfa Switzer (Bug Hall) to represent the club in a very important go-cart derby. However, the boys soon discover Alfalfa in a romance with a girl from school, Darla (Brittany Ashton Holmes), and hatch a scheme to break them apart, which leads to Darla turning her attention to snobby rich boy Waldo Johnston (Blake McIver Ewing), who just moved to town. However, while Spanky and his gang are busy meddling in Alfalfa's love life, their prized, undefeated racer, The Blur, is stolen by local bullies Butch (Sam Saletta) and Woim (Blake Jeremy Collins).nnNow, let me just start by addressing the acting. Of course, having kids be the stars of your movie is bound to be a drawback, especially when most of them have little-to-no acting experience. It probably doesn't help that several of them, especially Travis Tedford as Spanky, Ross Bagley as Buckwheat and Zach Mabry as Porky, are simply trying to copy the style of the young actors who's shoes they're filling from the 1940's shorts, instead of trying to make the roles their own, and it really makes it come off as inauthentic. But nonetheless, the kids' acting isn't without a surprising amount of charm. Particular highlights include Bug Hall, who shows some surprising professionalism as Alfalfa, especially for what little acting experience he had at the time, as well as Brittany Ashton Holmes, who brings some realistic girliness to Darla, and the same can even be said for Juliette Brewer (who, at the time, had only voiced Rosy in Balto) and Heather Karasek (who had NO acting experience at all, at the time) as her friends, Mary Ann and Jane, which is especially impressive. In addition, Blake McIver Ewing brings some terrific smarminess to Waldo, and Sam Saletta and Blake Jeremy Collins are the quintessential schoolyard bullies as Butch and Woim. The movie also guest-stars a remarkable group of celebs you would recognize right away as an adult, including Reba McEntire as famous racer AJ Ferguson, Whoopi Goldberg as Buckwheat's mother ("Whoopee."), comedy legend Mel Brooks as a stingy bank teller, and even the fat, orange man himself, soon-to-be-President McDonald Trump, who's PERFECTLY cast as Waldo's dad ("Waldo, you're the best son money can buy.").nnThen, of course, there's the writing. Of course, the movie does have the inherent silliness that comes from trying to take the 1940's comedy shorts and translate them into the 1990's. Still, however, there are a number of great, on-point gags to be found in this movie. There's the pranks that Spanky and the guys play to sabotage Alfalfa's picnic lunch with Darla, such as pouring the grape soda through what Darla thinks is an old boot. To quote Froggy (Jordan Warkol; voice dubbed by Elizabeth Daily), "Actually, it's a sneaker!" HAHAHAHA! The scenes of Butch and Woim chasing Alfalfa are pretty funny, too. In addition, the movie is even heartwarming in places.nnAnd lastly, the music. William Ross scored the movie terrifically. His rearrangement of the Our Gang theme, "Good Old Days" by Leroy Shield is stellar, and sounds very faithful to the original version. The rest of his incidental music blends with the tone of every scene, ranging from cheerful, to tender, to whimsical. In addition, the movie makes terrific use of songs, especially the late, great Dr. John's rendition of "You Must Have Been a Beautiful Baby" in the end credits.nnAll things considered, The Little Rascals is a very charming and nostalgic movie, though it is very flawed, and undoubtedly silly. Honestly, it's quite a guilty pleasure for me. But those of you who like Our Gang are bound to like this movie!!!!!

American History X is a gripping exploration of hate, redemption, and the influences that shape our beliefs. Edward Norton's portrayal of Derek Vinyard is raw and compelling, capturing the emotional struggle of a man trying to break free from a deeply ingrained ideology. The film's structure, switching between black-and-white flashbacks and present-day scenes, effectively highlights the roots of Derek's hatred and his efforts to change.nnA key turning point comes when Derek helps Danny remove neo-Nazi paraphernalia from his room. This act symbolizes Derek's rejection of his former beliefs and his determination to steer his brother away from the same destructive path. It's a powerful moment that visually underscores the film's central message of breaking the cycle of hate.nnThe flashback to their father at the dinner table reveals how these racist ideologies were instilled early on, showing how easily prejudice can take root when passed down by a trusted authority figure. This insight is later contrasted with the montage of Derek washing away his hate, which visually captures his commitment to change and his desire for a better future.nnHowever, the film's ending is harsh and abrupt, driving home the message that the cycle of hate only leads to more pain and loss. While impactful, it feels like it undermines the hopeful message of Derek's redemption and the possibility of breaking free from hatred. Despite this, American History X remains a deeply thought-provoking and emotional film, earning a 9/10 for its bold storytelling, powerful performances, and its unflinching exploration of difficult themes.

Ghost" holds a special place in my heart as one of my favorite films. Its romantic and poignant storyline beautifully portrays a love that transcends even the boundaries of death. The on-screen chemistry between Demi Moore and Patrick Swayze is truly remarkable, with their subtle gestures and glances conveying more passion and intimacy than any overtly graphic love scenes could achieve. Their connection feels genuine and deeply romantic, portrayed through their meaningful gazes and interactions.nnBeyond the captivating leads, "Ghost" features a cast of endearing characters such as Sam Wheat, Molly Jensen, and Oda Mae Brown, each adding depth and charm to the narrative. The plot unfolds seamlessly, keeping viewers engaged and invested in the characters' journey throughout the film.nnAdding to the film's allure is its enchanting score, with standout tracks like the theme song "Ghost" composed by Maurice Jarre specifically for the movie. The timeless classic "Unchained Melody" further enhances the magical atmosphere of the film, leaving a lasting impact on the audience.nnIn essence, "Ghost" is a cinematic gem that weaves together romance, mystery, and supernatural elements with finesse. Its ability to evoke emotions and captivate audiences through its heartfelt storytelling, memorable characters, and enchanting music solidifies its status as a truly magical and enduring film.

I'm not necessarily a religious person, but the least I've learned about religions is that they have a logical foundation, despite being a faith. The end of the world, or apocalypse, if it ever happens, will depend on something more complex than the decision of a gay couple in some cabin isolated from the world. Important ethical questions were completely disregarded in this pathetic movie. The main question: If saving the world requires me to become a murderer, then should I become a murderer? No, a sensible person would never do that. This is the kind of irresponsible psychosis propagated by movies like this, it's something very serious. You can't propagate the idea that killing an innocent person is a "sacrifice" to save the world, that's not a sacrifice and it doesn't save the world, it's just murder. Unfortunately, in today's world, where people are increasingly distant from reflection on morality and ethics, it is easy to convince ordinary people that "sacrifices" of this kind may be necessary for the "greater good." It turns out that the greatest good that human beings possess is their ability to decide not to kill. Cain killed Abel, and this brought great shame to humanity. Mr. Shyamalan now says that, in order to redeem humanity, a new Cain had to act. No, if there is any salvation for humanity, it is its ability to refuse to kill one another, but this unfortunate director puts the opposite in a ridiculous and hateful fable. Shame on M. N. Shyamalan.

The problem with Ridley Scott is he is great at originals but desperately poor at sequels. This is a movie which should never have been made. As for the sharks I mean credibility adds to believability and filling the coliseum which had chambers under the arena floor with seawater is just one step too far and completely idiotic. It lost me at that point. As for the Emporers really. This had a weak ending and really there was nothing left to feel good about out. Ok so Maximus died in the original but the audience had a satisfactory ending with a few tears and a belief the empire would endure under a republic. Please don't make Gladiator III.

This show took me on an emotional journey, where every moment touched my heart in such a profound way.nnYoo Yeon Seok is absolutely captivating in this role.
