Bilbo Baggins (Orson Bean's original voice) is swept into a quest to reclaim the lost Dwarf Kingdom of Erebor from the fearsome dragon Smaug (Richard Boone's voice). Approached out of the blue by the wizard Gandalf the Grey (John Huston's voice), Bilbo finds himself joining a company of thirteen dwarves led by the legendary warrior, Thorin Oakenshield (voice by Hans Conried). Their journey will take them into the Wild; through treacherous lands swarming with Goblins and Orcs, deadly Wargs and Giant Spiders, Shapeshifters and Sorcerers. Although their goal lies to the East and the wastelands of the Lonely Mountain first they must escape the goblin tunnels, where Bilbo meets the creature that will change his life forever ... Gollum. Here, alone with Gollum, on the shores of an underground lake, the unassuming Bilbo Baggins not only discovers depths of guile and courage that surprise even him, he also gains possession of Gollum's "precious" ring that holds unexpected and useful qualities ... A simple, gold ring that is tied to the fate of all Middle-earth in ways Bilbo cannot begin to know.nnAn early adaptation of Tolkien's classic with the usual ingredients, magic, supernatural events, and dramatic impressions staged through primitive but enjoyable drawings. This sensational animated epic adventure is plenty of action , attractive roles, impressive battles , enjoyable drama, gorgeous frames and being pretty entertaining , in spite of only 77 min , while still managing to keep a quick enough pace for those unfamilar with the lengthy literary work . The movie packs a real sense of wonder and stimulating action set pieces illuminating the full-blown feats of the various protagonists and winding up in overlong battles and a stunning finale. The Hobbit contains incredible array of technical visual effects, being animated by Topcraft in Tokyo, a now-defunct Japanese animation studio whose animation team re-formed as Studio Ghibli under Hayao Miyazaki. Sensational and colorful cinematography and long-standing as well as sensitive musical score, including catching songs. Beautifully realized set design with phenomenal production values and lavishly produced by Harvey and Bob Weinstein . The film provides amusement enough during the seventy minutes and stays closer to the novel than any of the former adaptations -mostly animated and in low budget- such as the mediocre effort by Ralph Baski who directed an animated version of ¬®The Lord of the Rings¬®. The motion picture will appeal to Tolkien followers as the neophyte who didn't have seen the previous and subsequent cinematic adapted works. Stunning direction by Jules Bass and Arthur Rankin Jr, bringing competently the fantastic world and mythology of the great British author to life. Bass and Rankin, produced and directed 'The Hobbit (1977)(TV)' and 'The Return of the King (1980)(TV)', both of which were later remade as live-action films by Peter Jackson. Both films also feature some casting similarities. Rankin and Bass hired Orson Bean to be the voice of Bilbo, and later Frodo as well. The older Bilbo in Jackson's film is played by Ian Holm, largely on account of his having played Frodo in the BBC Radio version. The three trolls in The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey (2012) are all voiced by actors who also play one of the dwarves. Rankin and Bass's version did the same, although the actors do not play the same dwarves in both versions.nnThis is the second film version of the Hobbit, the original was a 1966 12-minute animated short produced by Gene Deitch. There are various roles in The Hobbit are related to characters in The Lord of the Rings. Bilbo is of course Frodo's uncle. He is also a Took on his mother's side, making him a cousin to Peregrin Took (Pippin). Elrond is actually a great-uncle to Aragorn (several generations removed). Gloin is the father of Gimli, while the Elven King (named Thranduil) is the father of Legolas. The Hobbit(1977) is well worth watching it, along with Peter Jackson's trilogy : The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey (2012) , The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013) and The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014) and another Jackson trilogy: ¬®The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)¬® ¬®The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers¬® (2002) and ¬®The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King¬® (2003) , all of them magnificently directed by Peter Jackson .

I love horror, but not gore. You can have horrifying movies without the gore. Having said that, The Green Inferno is one of those incredibly gory movies that I did like. I've seen many gory movies and just don't care for them. It's not scary, it's just gross. BUT this movie was the first ever to make me sick to my stomach from that very first cannibalistic scene. Good googly moogly! I guess it disturbed me because it was very realistic. This wasn't like some supernatural strength inbred or masked psycho cutting someone's guts out in a very unfathomable way, but very damn close to how you'd roast a pig at the next party. They seasoned him, made a pit to cook him, slow roasted him, and there ya go. Gag! Now, so I think it realistic that some "good doers" just happened to crash land amongst a land of indigenous cannibals? Yes. That is not beyond the realm of being real. So they season them up like a roasted pig, well, I do not know, but I don't really want to know. I did find some of the movie quite silly, but in a funny way if there can be fun in a movie where people are disgustingly being held captive and cooked.nnThis is one of those movies that I can watch more than once, so I gave it a 7. Disgusting, but very entertaining and the colors were beautiful, and frightening.

Green Book (2018), directed by Peter Farrelly, is an uplifting drama-comedy based on the true story of an unlikely friendship that transcends racial and social divides. Set in 1962, against the backdrop of the racially segregated American South, the film tells the story of African-American pianist Dr. Don Shirley and his Italian-American chauffeur, Tony "Lip" Vallelonga. With its poignant narrative, memorable performances, and touching exploration of cultural and personal differences, Green Book stands out as an engaging and heartfelt film.nnThe Story: An Unlikely PartnershipnThe film begins in New York City, where Tony Vallelonga (Viggo Mortensen), a tough, brash bouncer, is temporarily out of work after the nightclub he works at closes for renovations. Desperate for a job, Tony stumbles upon an opportunity to drive Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali), a world-class pianist, on an eight-week concert tour through the Deep South.nnAt first, the two men couldn't be more different. Tony is loud, unsophisticated, and prejudiced, while Dr. Shirley is reserved, highly cultured, and deeply aware of the discrimination he faces as a Black man. Despite their differences, they embark on the tour, using the "Green Book"-a guide for African-American travelers to find safe accommodations and restaurants in a segregated America.nnAs the journey progresses, the duo faces a range of challenges, from casual racism to violent confrontations, while also discovering common ground and fostering mutual respect. The film follows their evolving relationship, as Tony learns to confront his own biases and Dr. Shirley begins to break down his emotional barriers.nnOutstanding PerformancesnThe chemistry between Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali is the heart of the film. Mortensen delivers a transformative performance as Tony, fully embodying the character's rough-edged humor and underlying decency. His physicality and mannerisms bring authenticity to the role, making Tony both flawed and endearing.nnMahershala Ali, in a role that earned him an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor, is equally compelling as Dr. Don Shirley. Ali portrays Shirley with grace, depth, and quiet strength, balancing his character's dignity with moments of vulnerability. The nuanced portrayal captures Shirley's internal struggle as a man caught between two worlds-too refined for the working-class Black community and too Black for the white elite.nnTogether, Mortensen and Ali create a dynamic that is both humorous and deeply emotional. Their growing friendship feels genuine, and their banter is often as entertaining as it is revealing.nnA Tale of Friendship and GrowthnAt its core, Green Book is a story about breaking down barriers and confronting prejudices. Tony's journey from a man with ingrained racial biases to someone who genuinely respects and admires Dr. Shirley is both moving and thought-provoking. Similarly, Dr. Shirley's willingness to open up and trust Tony adds depth to his character arc.nnThe film strikes a balance between humor and drama, using moments of levity to offset the heavy themes of racism and inequality. From scenes of Tony teaching Shirley how to eat fried chicken to their debates about music and culture, the film captures the complexities of their relationship with warmth and wit.nnCriticisms and ControversiesnWhile Green Book was critically acclaimed and won several awards, including the Academy Award for Best Picture, it faced criticism for its portrayal of race relations. Some critics argued that the film simplifies the complexities of racism in America, presenting a "white savior" narrative that centers Tony's perspective over Shirley's. Others pointed out that the film glosses over Shirley's personal struggles and largely omits his family's input, which led to disputes about its historical accuracy.nnDespite these criticisms, the film's universal themes of friendship, acceptance, and personal growth resonate with audiences. Its focus on small, human moments rather than grand political statements allows it to connect emotionally, even if it doesn't delve deeply into the broader context of racial injustice.nnFinal ThoughtsnGreen Book is a heartfelt and entertaining film that showcases the transformative power of friendship. While it may not fully explore the deeper complexities of its historical backdrop, it succeeds as a character-driven story with outstanding performances from its lead actors. Mortensen and Ali's chemistry carries the film, creating a poignant and memorable journey that will leave audiences laughing, reflecting, and ultimately moved.

Many of viewers from South America really love this drama and we want another project with them. Thanks to all cast for this special project that we really enjoy it.

Jimmy Stewart didn't make 6.0-on-the-IMDb movies. This is better than that, and belongs in a collection including Mr. Hobbs Takes A Vacation and even Harvey. Featuring No less than the then-well-known Billy Mumy (Danger, Will Robinson! "Anthony" on the Twilight Zone, and many others) as a mathematical child savant, the movie might start out feeling like a typical family television sitcom in 1965, but about midway through you feel it picking up steam and the writing starts to get quite clever. With a supporting name-brand character-actor cast all the way though I found it was one of those movies that you are sorry when it's over. Definitely watch this if you get a chance to see it.nnP. S. At the time I write this review, the cast list on the IMDb is unaccountably missing the movie's prominent fourth-wall narration character, played by Ed Wynn, and also fails to mention the uncredited (apparently, that was her requirement) appearance of the legendary Brigitte Bardot, whose role in the story inspired the title. I tried to edit these conspicuous omissions and we'll just have to see whether the admins here do their duty accordingly.

Man this is one heck of a movie. The acting is phenomenal. The story, gripping. It makes you want to cry, shout, laugh, all of it.nnPros- all the characters were great. FromnBottles to shotgun even the Beast. All of them made you think of a gang. Not overly brutal or intense. Overall just a good movie. Love that his son forgave him.nnCons- the first prison scene with the black dude getting gang raped. Idk there. I find that really hard to believe that would happen in gen pop in this day and age. Maybe some shock and awe Hollywood insertion idk. But 1 guard on watch up and leaves for 10 min and that happens and that's the ONLY thing that happens at that time? No murders or anything else? Maybe he was a pedo and we just didn't know. There is some more ehh idk stuff about the prison life but most is small like that. Towards the end when money tells the Mexican boss about the 2nd trailer, then gives it the cops. I'm not sure I get the reason for that. Seems like he made an enemy with him. Finally, at the end of the movie, he seems to not even want to explain himself to his family at all. Sure keep away and contact minimum but why not even explain himself a bit? Why he avoided them. I can't give this a 10 For that alone. It just doesn't make sense like the parole officer said. Wait. What happened to bottles?nnLike i said earlier, not a 10 but a solid 8.5-9. Well done.

If you get annoyed that most streaming services only include cartoons and not actual shows you can watch as a family that are entertaining to both parents and kids. I would classify this show with 'The Middle' and 'Malcom in the Middle' that i would consider classics. The first 3 or 4 seasons is very well written. Very funny and light hearted. The series seems to take a darker, more serious turn around season 5 that doesn't really target children any more. The subjects turn to teen pregnancy, sex, affairs, etc around season 5. Im not sure if they pulled in a new Hollywood writer or what. But the entertainment value drops significantly with Sheldon himself remaining the most entertaining character. The portrayal of marriage problems was well done - slowly developing over years. But a little out of place for this target market.

Remarkably entertaining and in today's TV productions that is special. I love how they manage to deal with some of the most absurd people, places, pronouns and things in a very manageable un-woke way. The interpersonal relationships get snarled up, stretched out to the point of screaming but snap back to the usual "only in small doses" behavior. My only gripe (I subtracted 1 starüò¨) is the atrocious fashion some of those people have going on and I am Not speaking of Will's suits. Ugly Sweater Vest wearing season it seems year round and that is hard to believe in Atlanta heat....maybe they cool off with the jenko imitating lounge wear looking way up over the ankles pants slacks or bottoms?? I dunno but I look forward to the next episode üòé

Started watching the show because of the name of course, also Queen is playing the series so that definitely got my attention. I'm writing this in hopes to get more seasons. It's a good show to watch. Yeah, it's cliche when it comes to the procedural drama part. (Ex: csi Miami, NY, Criminal Minds etc) but other than that it's definitely a feel good show. It's a good quality show. You can tell budget wasn't cheap went it came to production. I like how the daughter asked the mom to teach her, instead of being spoiled about it considering her upbringing. I also like how the show focuses on modern global issues.

The acting is top notch from all the cast members. Great chemistry from the main leads.nnYYS and CSB definitely deserve the 3 awards this drama received a.k.a best couple, best actor and best actress at the MBC awards 2024.nnEP 1-10, 10/10 easilynEP 1-12, 8.5/10nEP 11-12, 4/10 (4 being generous And we all know it wasn't the cast cause they delivered especially the villain in these 2 episodes)nnThe cast and acting was really good, and i ended up loving the kidnapper. I've beef with the writers and director and producers for messing up Ep 12 and going the book way. I hated the book end, it was so messy. But WTPR is definitely going to be an OG for me and will probably be rewatching it monthly.

Kathryn Hunter is one of the best actors on the planet earth. Though this movie is ultimately unworthy of her talent, it's all in good fun. I wish I could see her on stage. What a legend!nnBut yeah, about this movie. It made me laugh a few times, mostly at its sheer audacity. There's a lot of flatulent and bodily excrement involved. It's quite literally a shitty movie. And there's gross breast feeding, obviously. How could there not be?nnOh, and Brandy is in it.nnAs filmmakers, the Egger Brothers have a long way to go before they catch up with their older brother, Robert. They may have something to offer down the road, but cinema this is not.nnDid I mention what an amazing actor Kathryn Hunter is?

I love this show! They have such a clever way to spin their conversations and make a funny pun or joke. These guys are geniuses!nnThe show is in Spanish and it's 3 Argentinians and 1 Venezuelan. It's pure gold!nnIt's usually a casual conversation between the 4 hosts about any relevant topic from news, movies, series or anything current. They chat about the topic while making fun and creating comedy, including roasting each other.nnIt may contain mature content like sexuality, slangs, strong jokes about Venezuela's political situation, religion, ethnicity, etc. However, it's always comedy intended.nnThanks for all the laughs!

Many platitudes and tropes made this film a bit of a slog; there really wasn't enough meat on the bone for me to sink my teeth into. It felt like a trip to Nostalgia for millennials, and really, it seems like most films and series (and ads and products and music and websites and styles and trends etc etc ) are being created BY the 40-and-younger FOR the same demographic, in part because they're the most vocal/active group(s) on social media; easy access to desires and expectations as well as free promotion means this, of course, makes sense.nnHowever, the rest of us are out here too, and although it's always nice to find another watchable Swedish film, it's becoming harder and harder to locate one with that sweet spot; something that spans generations, goes deep but can still evoke a genuine glow, doesn't signal when and where and how to feel, and doesn't lean too far into the box-ticking.nnThere are, of course the ubiquitous non-white characters and the gay arc, (which honestly feels forced given the main character's history-as far as we see) regardless of region or era, because it's a Swedish film. You'd be hard-pressed to find anything produced post-2010 without such organic-feeling "diversity". Ahem. It gets a bit tiresome living in an Instaworld where everyone is a tattooed, pierced, rainbow-haired, misgendered ASD-and-chronic-illness-sufferer who hates their whiteness and "beige" choices as to which genitalia goes where and with whom in their huge clown glasses and fillered-faces. I have big ol' tattoos and had multiple painful piercings for twice as long as many of the hive-minds out there have been around, so it's not that I'm too buttoned up, I suppose I miss subcultures when they actually were subversive. Then again I'm simply an old gal yelling at clouds here.nnThis film wasn't really made for me...but I'm getting really tired of stating this!nnThere's a recent Swedish film via Netflix called "Thank You, I'm Sorry", and although sadly rare, it really is an absolute gem; I dare you to watch this without falling I'm love with the sisters. See my review of it if interested; THIS is how to make a light film dealing with heavy subject matter.nnOne More Time is obviously meant to land on the lighter-side of things by dragging us through the many costume changes as well as trying in earnest to get us to laugh with them regarding this newly-40 year-old's life choices. The problem is that it's too meta to proffer much if any insight, and too hyper-focused on the character's selfishness and vanity for us to care about her at all.nnAlso, she's a 40 year-old woman, and regardless of her 18 year-old body, her lack of worldliness or emotional maturity, she has lived long enough, and apparently hard enough, to know whether or not she's a) gay and b) has feelings for her estranged best friend. The moment she sees her in her present timeline she should feel something-anything, but she doesn't. No, she'd rather play dress-up and party than search for more meaning in this opportunity. Deep.nnNot nearly as deep as they were trying to be.nnAnd speaking of dress-up; who the hell dresses like a stripper sex worker in high school?? I mean, I know that the film was set during the burgeoning (and awful) boy-band / Brittany years, and even I, in 2002 in my mid-30s was horrified at the prospects of the over-sexualising of very young girls (and I myself had lived through the Madonna years as a teen, so was no stranger to the experience). The male students would be tortured, and even if a young girl wasn't quite ready emotionally to engage in sex, the signals she was sending stated otherwise. And loudly. I also know that Sweden is rather fond of flying its open-mindedness flag at every opportunity, but puh-leeze! The objectification of women has become so common due to this "attitude of acceptance" ever present in film for the last 60+ years, that it's cheap and frankly lazy, while totallly lacking in a scrap of ingenuity or imagination. Issues aside, there's also no way a small-town teen would have access to, much less the money for, a wardrobe, consisting of mostly high-cost labels, of this variety and volume in 2002, and no small-town high school would look like a staging of High School Musical. Who had the energy to even bother accessorising to this extent five days a week at the crack of dawn? The apparent absence of nightlife in this town begs the question whether it would be worth the time, effort and budget to posses even half of her closet's contents. And look, I wouldn't be focusing on this aspect of the film, if they hadn't done so, which made it all the more empty an experience.nnAll of this posing revolves around a somewhat ham-fisted redemption tale that ultimately begs us to feel deeply for the main character by the time we get to the all-too predictable conclusion. This whole shallow world-building was too tropey and entirely implausible; I can't imagine many, if any women fitting perfectly into her high school clothes at 40. We don't all gain, but bodies do change shape, and these implausible details serve merely as distractions that take the viewer right out of the narrative over and over again.nnIf they really wanted to sort of piggyback onto Groundhog Day, she would've worn the same clothes she'd "died" in; this would've added a bit more depth, fish-out-of-water feel and plausibility.nnBut time-travel is also implausible, yet so is this woman's inability to see that her once-closest friend is absolutely pining for her in their youth. She was practically drooling, and her "drama" friends seemed to be hovering in the background constantly every time they spoke to each other, on a knife's edge of rushing to comfort her with such urgency and transparency, that she had obviously shared her heartfelt feelings with them. Fiona was so enamoured, in fact, that she-an obstensively successful singer-has remained single at 40, because NO ONE comes close to her friend who ditched her in high school...? A friend who's so obtuse and unaware, she doesn't "realise" that she has the same feelings until she reads a note, written by Fiona at 12, and squirreled away in a "time-capsule" no less (no tropes there), or that she's even a lesbian..? Now everything makes sense, and her life is complete.nnHuh?

Enjoyed this. Only lasted one season.nnI read the synopsis and thought it was a comedy, but it is mainly drama, with some comedy thrown in. So, a few laughs to be had.nnIt is listed in IMDB as a drama, so it was my error.nnGood cast do a nice job.nnFew 'soapy' style story lines along the way, probably a bit too many for my liking, but I suppose it kept things moving along.nnThe show mainly focuses on the characters lives outside the selling of the "Ann Summers" products.nnBit ironic that the show is about female empowerment, but the "Ann Summers" concept was created by a man. He used his then Secretary's name (with slightly different spelling) as the company name.

It feels like they hired a 4th grader to write a sappy, overwrought victim fantasy - or at least that is my explanation for how they confusingly dreamed up this utterly unbelievable story line. They were so desperate to retcon Randall's birth mother (as they were seemingly determined at this point in the series to ensure Randall remain as unlikeable and unsympathetic as humanly possible) that they wrote an embarrassingly bad dime store romance novel. It was an hour of cringing and laughing out loud at contrived, ham fisted, dramatic misfires and backstory assassination. I really wish I had accidentally skipped this one so that my perception of the generally well written show would not have been irreparably damaged. Whatever - TV is allowed to have a bad day.

For me, Christian adaptation movies can be well or poorly executed. Remember the movie The Ark (2007)? Well, it had good animation, but it was bad because it relied on sexual jokes and had no good character development. Now, when this movie comes out, it will definitely have my expectations.nnThe animation is beautiful, you can tell they put a lot of effort into the animal designs, the backgrounds and the setting, it could look like Pixar movies.nnThe script is good, they take Noah's Ark as a story, the character development is good and the jokes are good too.nnI heard there is a sequel, hopefully it will be a saga.

I already got the feeling this was going to be bad by the opening scene. But then, the editor in me saw something unforgivable. After the opening scene it cuts to black and then the words "40 years later" appear and then it goes into an extremely long title and credit sequence with stock After Effects graphics from Envato Elements or something.nnHere's what should have happened:nOpening scenenCut to blacknDo your awful and extremely long title and credit sequencenCut to black "40 years later"nFade in to a scene with actors who are the people we are expecting to see 40 years later.nnThey broke up the flow by putting the title sequence in the wrong place. 40 years later a title sequence? No 40 years later people doing stuff... like a ridiculous sex scene.

This kept my interest throughoutnthe series. It had drama, tenderness and suspense that kept me riveted to the screen from beginning to end! An excellent series.nnThe acting was outstanding. It revolves around the murders of a young boy and elderly woman that were stabbed to death. It took 16 years to solve the case which involved the latest DNA research. This research went against the Swedish police and their la s against the rights of privacy.nnThis is the first time that I have rated and written a review for IMDB.nnIf you want to be completely entertained andnkept on the edge of your seat watch this limited series.

No real plot. Sex scenes without any depth. The lines between reality and truth were blurred. A change in the marital relationship happened throughout the story. I guess that was the point of the couple's relationship with inevitable exploration at the end. The movie was too long and so boring a fellow movie attendee was snoring loudly throughout. Even with some explicit scenes. Thendominant younger man overtakes the obedient middle aged wife turning her into her supposedly untapped desire. Then her female assistant uses her obtained knowledge of the affair to gain advancement. Too many holes in the storyline. A complete disappointment and a waste of money.

This is one of the worst shows I've ever seen. The worst part is that the first episode tricks you into thinking it's something else- something that may have a laugh here or there- with some great characters.nnIt is not that at all. By episode 2 you see a definite change but keep hoping for more "episode 1" energy to return- it won't. And not only that, you then get to walk thru some of the darkest, most depressing, debauchery I've ever seen.nnThey want you to think this is about overcoming rape and finding oneself, but it is far from that. It is a story of self-loathing and hatred- which Hollyweird seems to love (hence the awards it just won). If you take a subpar character, who makes a LOT of bad choices, and who isn't very compelling to start with- that's your male lead. The female lead did a wonderful job acting, and i would've rather followed her storyline even though she is insane. The male just hates himself, and there's no redemption at the end. You aren't rooting for either of them, or relating to either of them. It is just a cringe-inducing, hate-fest.nnThis was painful, disturbing (to say the least), and not entertaining. I couldn't have disliked it more.

I usually like dark comedies but this one just didn't do it for me. Maggie Gyllenhaal plays Lee who has just gotten out of a psych ward and gets her first job working for a lawyer played by James Spader. Things get weird in the office with some S&M stuff and Lee discovers she enjoys the submissive role. When I read pretty much that description of this movie it sounded like something I'd like. But as I said, this one just didn't click for me. I never found it very funny or stimulating.nnOh well, they can't all be golden. 4 out of 10 stars from me on this one.nnI usually like dark comedies but this one just didn't do it for me. Maggie Gyllenhaal plays Lee who has just gotten out of a psych ward and gets her first job working for a lawyer played by James Spader. Things get weird in the office with some S&M stuff and Lee discovers she enjoys the submissive role. When I read pretty much that description of this movie it sounded like something I'd like. But as I said, this one just didn't click for me. I never found it very funny or stimulating.nnOh well, they can't all be golden. 4 out of 10 stars from me on this one.

This is a pretty good series. I've always loved a thriller that combines ancient rituals that, after recent devastation, turn into pathological cultish events. Like Texas chainsaw massacre, or midsummer. I like the premise. Jude Law is great. The first three episodes were fantastic. But then episode 4 happened where this mother and her two daughters show up for some "birthday fun" on the island for one of her young girls. EVERYTHING, I mean EVERYTHING pointed to get off the island. But no, mom makes bad decision after bad decision , even the daughters are like "WTF?! Mom! Why are we here?!" So guess what..mom makes them hike to an abandoned resort to "see if they have a room". Now They are stuck on the island too'. How fun! A freezing cold, creepy island with weird people all telling you to go home, weird signs of what looks like huge bloody vaginas everywhere. Yaaaay. Happy birthday darling!

A complete failure. No rhythm, no right atmosphere. Please do not waste your precious time in it. A original and true crime story completly wasted on this film. Erasable.of your mind. I'm still yawning. I don't know what else to say about a film that, despite its pretensions, fails to arouse any interest in the plot. Photography uses black and white and color without any justifiable criteria. The acting of the actors, with some exceptions, is quite poor. The soundtrack is terrible and doesn't add anything to the narrative, rather it hinders it. As I said before a good story absolutely wasted. You will feel scammed.

In my opinion, people say that this game is really stupid. That's not true. It takes skill and smarts to play. I play a lot like every day. This game is so good. It should deserve more updates.nnOddly, this game has a lot of character characters that you can play as. My personal favorite is Baymax. Yes I'm talking about the Disney Baymax. If you don't know him, maybe this will jog your mind. "Ba la la la la la la."nnIf you're wondering it is a gun game. Probably meant for people 11 and up. What's even cool about the game is that instead of using a plane to get to the battle Island they use a flying bus called The Battle Bus.nnThe last thing I gotta say is that it's a really good game and that it should deserve more respect.

I watched all the way to the end hoping for redemption... instead it got worse right up to the last scene. I sometimes sincerely don't understand how movies get 7 star average... did I see a different movie than you weirdo's? Super slow paced, lacked any redemptive story. They could have shaved about an hour off of this train-wreck and achieved the same outcome.. and it would have wasted one less hour of my life... that I can never get back I might add. If you are into super long drawn out scenes, ridiculous stories about weird cult like people, with a splash of gore and sex, this is for you. If it is just the gore and sex you are after. Go watch dead pool... at least there is some entertaining dialogue in that...

This is a bleak, dark and depressing series and although the detective work is admirable, and I would like to watch to the end, I don't think I can go on. First criticism is the colour tones of regulation grey, light grey, dark grey, and black that make faces difficult to register. Secondly there is a tendency to place scenes in look-alike locations, so that confusion sets in as to where and why our detective is there at all. Then, all the people and their lives are without even the slightest glimmer of joy or normality, even the houses are as dreadfully grim as their occupants. Everyone wears ill-fitting track-suit tops, filthy trainers, has either greasy or unkempt hair, is permanently dishevelled and also deeply unhappy.nnThe whole thing has an air of hopelessness and despair. However....as the number of murders became incredulous, and the small local police unit seem unable to handle the enormity of the bloodcurdling slaughter, we are presented with the story line of the ruptured relationship between the detective and his daughter. Both use drugs, the father confesses he had pedophile inclinations towards his daughter when she was a four-year-old child, the ensuing scene in the dreary motel bedroom was very disturbing.nnIt was this final darkness that marked the point at which I yearned for some release from the unrelenting awfulness of it all and decided to switch stations.nnI truly believe most viewers recoil from entertaining such depictions in their living rooms, and prefer to follow a taut tale of detective work minus the unwelcome introduction of a journey through the incestuous thoughts of the father.

Oh look another anti-Catholic movie brought to you by the usual Hollywood non-Catholic suspects; what a surprise. Sure it's based on a recent book but this crowd isn't going to be selecting books based on degrading any other religion any time soon, are they? For Catholics and being Italian, I am one myself; the plot reveals complete ignorance about the very foundation of Catholicism and the betterment of one's spiritual self throughout life so as to align with the teachings of Christ. The Church's teachings focus not on the physical but on the spiritual. Everyone is accepted particularly those with crosses to bear whether they are physical, hormonal, developmental or psychological or all of the above as it is through suffering, through broken bones and through resulting self-examination that we emerge more polished, humbled and closer to understanding the ultimate sacrifice of Jesus Christ on behalf of humanity. The ultimate sacrifice endured for the forgiveness of sins of humanity and the opening of the gates of Heaven for all those who choose to follow his path.nnWe all know the devil works through agents and weak, spineless individuals to divide humanity as do the producers of this movie. This is the polar opposite of what Catholicism is all about; it is all encompassing, accessible to all of humanity, it is about our souls and not about our physical appearances or worldly desires. It is a means of attaining love for others, for self and ultimately achieving unrelenting love for God and all of his creation. Dark forces delight in introducing falsehoods about the Church that feed on ignorance to weaken faith and undermine credibility in the Church. This is nothing more than the work of the weak who have chosen another path; a dark, materialistic, self-centered, empty path.nnThe movie's misrepresentation of the papal selection process is laughable; reduced to a high school presidential race full of silly gossip, narcissistic political maneuvering borrowed from American politics and nonsensical drama that drives Hollywood in a sad attempt to sneer at the true spirit that guides the election of a new Pope by the College of Cardinals - that being the Holy Ghost. The Church is immune to worldly human weakness and is a vessel of truth that beholds the entirety of Divine Revelation.nnThe film laughingly attempts to turn the clergy and leadership into Hollywood-like caricatures riddled with scandals and power struggles. The producers must have been salivating when they read a book they could exploit to smear and continue to denigrate the Church with and hope the sheeple take the bait. As with all institutions and humanity, people are not immune to sin. In particular, the Church in the past was an easy target for malicious infiltration by those who wished to take advantage of a culture of silence, shame and inability to effectively punish perpetrators. That is changing today institutionally more so than in Hollywood and society in general where child molestation occurs about 80% of the time in the family by a parent or direct guardian - hard fact. This is a convenient movie to use so as to distract from reality and delude gullible masses. The whole point of this movie is to undermine faith in clergy and the Church. This is an injustice to the majority of priests and bishops who serve faithfully and provide spiritual guidance.nnLastly, in a desperate attempt to strike at an immovable tenet of the Church - that according to Catholic doctrine the Pope is a bishop and the priesthood is reserved for men. This is not an opinion but a core teaching of the Church that the all-male priesthood is rooted in Divine Revelation. This is the will of God which no human has any say in particularly Hollywood anti-Catholic propagandists. Flawed incrementalism is used in a paltry attempt to introduce a cardinal, an individual inflicted by 46 XX DSD (CAH), to become Pope. According to the film the individual has a uterus so normal female structures with masculanized external genitalia. The film uses the unfortunate condition of a DSD in an attempt to blur the Church's teaching on the papacy. The Church embraces all, regardless of inflictions, intersex conditions that are obviously no fault of the inflicted individuals and accepts and acknowledges all forms of DSD whether the three most common; congenital adrenal hyperplasia, complete androgen insensitivity and Turner syndrome or any variety of conditions with atypical development of chromosomal, gonadal, or anatomic sex. However, attempting to exploit this condition in a flawed logical framework to continue to place wedges between society and the Church is the real injustice. It seems like we are in a world where people are beginning to wake up to the falsehoods perpetrated by Hollywood and the like. Real degenerates scheming to bring the world towards darkness; hopefully it's curtains for them soon enough.

Epic but best in color and Elsa's hair should have been red.nnSaw in black and white and then immediately after in color. I was skeptical about it going in for black and white in the first place but it was a genuinely good watch. Just... better in color. Character development, writing and acting is solid throughout. The cinematography was awesome throughout.nnHadn't seen a new marvel movie in a while because they were losing me with some of the lamer shows. And Disney as a whole has just been disappointing with how they ruin classic characters and stuff. But this was a fresh, fun watch. I'm definitely exploring the comics with these guys later. Just wish they made Elsa's hair red. Real bummer.

I didn't want to write this review, but I felt I had to. As a Mexican and a film student, I can't stay silent about Emilia P√©rez. This movie isn't just poorly written - it feels like an episode ripped straight from a badly made narco soap opera. The melodrama is so clumsy it borders on the absurd.nnIt feels as if the director skimmed through one or two articles about drug trafficking in Mexico and thought that made him an expert. The result is a shallow story that neither understands nor respects the gravity of the subject. And when the topic involves the desaparecidos - one of Mexico's deepest wounds - that ignorance isn't just noticeable, it's offensive. In its lack of understanding, I'd go as far as to say the script even veers into racist territory.nnIs there anything redeemable? Maybe the cinematography. But even the songs don't work - they aren't songs, they're just rhythmic dialogue. I've seen a lot of criticism regarding the casting, and while I don't entirely disagree, I believe that's the least of the film's problems.nnTo the festivals that awarded Emilia P√©rez, I extend an invitation: watch I'm No Longer Here or El Infierno. Both are powerful examples of what can be achieved with proper research, sensitivity, and a genuine understanding of Mexico's social issues. In comparison, Emilia P√©rez is exposed for what it truly is - a mix of pretension and ignorance.nnThe one redeeming element, in my opinion, is Karla Sof√≠a's performance. She delivers a worthy effort in a film that otherwise falls short of the story it claims to tell.

Odd Thomas (2013).nnAt first Odd Thomas says he doesn't want to be a celebrity but ends up being one in the end, that's the American dream.nnHe doesn't care about his mother who is his blood, who is locked up in a psychiatric hospital, but he surrounds himself with strangers, this is American propaganda from his TV series.nnOdd Thomas is like Peter Parker mixed with John Constantine, his girlfriend Stormy would be like Mary Jane Watson, William Dafoe's character is like Commissioner James Gordon. The plot is like in Columbine, mass murder.nnThere are four attractive women in the film: Addison Timlin, Gugu Mbatha-Raw, Laurel Harris, Melissa Ordway.nnMy favorite scene in the film is the escape scene with the truck full of explosives and the villain Varner shoots and the bullet grazes Odd's face.nnIt seems that the budget was inflated, is it money laundering?, without proof.nnRobert "Bob" Robertson was the pseudonym used by Sergio Leone.nnIs it a message that the guy with the yarmulke-like hair is plotting a massacre with policemen and a teacher? His ghost vandalizes the church.nnLevana is a witch's name. Yelchin was good in the action scenes but was lacking when he cried for Stormy.

column3: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)
column4: This completely exceeded my expectations. Going into it, I wasn't sure what to expect from a movie based on the true events that inspired Moby-Dick, but I was genuinely impressed by both the plot and the performances.nnThe story, which follows the harrowing tale of the Essex ship's encounter with a massive whale, is more engaging than I anticipated. It blends survival drama with a rich emotional core, delving into the characters' fears, desperation, and the overwhelming power of nature. The pacing keeps the tension high, and there's a sense of dread that builds as the crew's situation becomes more dire.nnWhat really took me by surprise, though, was the acting. Chris Hemsworth, as the ship's first mate, delivers a performance that goes well beyond his usual action-star persona. His emotional depth here is impressive, especially in the film's quieter, more introspective moments. Cillian Murphy also stands out, bringing a nuanced portrayal of a character struggling with guilt and trauma. Even smaller roles, like those from Ben Whishaw and Tom Holland, contribute to making the ensemble cast feel grounded and real.nnOverall, it was far more compelling than I expected. It's a gripping survival tale with excellent performances and a surprisingly complex emotional layer. If you're looking for a movie that balances action with depth, this one is worth a watch.

After two viewings is not difficult to understand, the are four persons, the man with the mustache and hat belongs to the high class and resents every one except the dame (he turns out to be only an impostor having achieved his status by the same means), she also is only an object of attraction for the other men. She is at the same time consumer oriented but in reality unsatisfied sexually. The mechanic knows that whiteout him noting works and is intellectually curious but his curiosity is censored by the higher class and he turn his interest to the dame. The vendor representing the middle class is completely subservient to the higher. The priest has no direct contact with any of them. The lower class is represented by the concierge and cleaning woman. At the end is the boy that doesn't understand or is influenced by the economic system at the moment.

The problem with this series is that it's a roller coaster of script quality. The main character, Karppi, has a skull of steel. She can take hits with pipes, gun butts, shovels and even shots to the head, her hair is always in perfect shape and she recovers within minutes. It is Supergirl in Finland. The characters react half an hour later, they leave loose threads in the plot, there are inconsistencies in the events and they betray the police genre by not respecting some of its own conventions. It gives the impression that the Finnish police are stupid. They are very good actors, but neither some of the scripts nor the direction are of much help. And I think that Finnish justice system is not fairly portrayed in this series.

As a premise, a murder mystery thriller set in the Star Wars universe is perhaps one of the more interesting ideas to have come out of the Disney era. Executing such a premise requires great action sequences, compelling characters, and dialogue worthy of intriguing the audience. While the first (and unfortunately, only) season of The Acolyte hits the first of these three categories quite well with coordinated action sequences which have not been seen in Star Wars since The Clone Wars, it falls short on the latter two. As such The Acolyte can show flashes of what could have been but fails to make a truly compelling storyline, which can have the effect of making some scenes and episodes downright boring. That said, the highs of the show's action scenes and some of the more intriguing story elements still make for a decent show that is worthy of a watch if you can slog through some of the more questionable parts.

I rolled into this hoping to learn more about the Epstein saga. I've followed numerous podcasts and other docuseries. I applaud the series allowing the victims to tell their tale. I wish they had touched on more of the Epstein saga.nnThe Trump undertones were horrid. Every few minutes is a Trump pic or video insert. I counted 1 photo of Clinton. Clinton was on his plane, on his island, visited him nonstop. But someone they make it about attacking Trump? Just truly pathetic. So many other involved, criminal power players you could have used. But you chose to attack Trump. Can you at least put your political biases away long enough to do a good documentary?nnFrom the opening scenes you make sure to attach Epstein as a neighbor to Trump. Countless cuts to the same pics of Trump and Melania with Jeff and Ghislaine. Where are all the pics of Clinton and Jeff. There's countless ones that can be found in a simple google search.nnWhere are the countless references to Bill's trips to the island, his 27 rides on the plane, the multiple phone numbers for Bill? What about Jeff's connections to Donald and William Barr? You leave out that his firs teaching job was working for William Barr's dad. What about a true history of who Maxwell is and his well known ties to arms dealing? When talking about the case in Florida. You reference Mar-a-Lago multiple times but leave out that Trump kicked him off of there. You leave out the US Attorney publicly stating Epstein belongs to intelligence. So many things you leave out, but at least we get clips of Trump every few minutes.nnTruly a sad disservice to these women. You had a chance to give their story a bullhorn from a mountain top and instead you wasted time with political opportunities. You probably should have tried to uncover more of what allowed this to happen to them. The failures of the government and Law Enforcement agencies that should have helped and protected them.

Ok. So... I cried at the end of the movie. Not from sadness or horror, but from laughing so hard. The overall movie is supposed to be a drama? Right. üòÇnBoth Demi and Margaret Qualley are beautiful and amazing and neither are ashamed to be naked on screen.nnI would consider about 80% of the movie to be drama. Definitely symbolic of the media and the pursuit of perfection. The movie had more than one place to end if it was meant to remain a drama. HOWEVER, things took a turn and the blood, oh my, the blood. Evil Dead or Kill Bill spurting style blood. And a boob the falls on the ground. Hilarity ensues. The very end was like starfish crawling to water.

"From Ground Zero" is an emotionally gripping and profoundly essential film that demands the attention of audiences worldwide. Through its vivid and unflinching portrayal of life amidst devastation, it sheds light on the untold stories of resilience, despair, and unwavering hope. This powerful cinematic work immerses viewers in the raw realities of systemic injustice and human suffering, compelling us to confront the devastating cost inflicted by a war mongering entity on these innocent lives. The film is more than a documentary; it is a stirring call to action, urging us to reflect on our shared humanity and the pressing need for compassion and change.nnWith poignant storytelling and an unfiltered lens, it presents a brutally honest account of the lived experiences of those too often overlooked by the world or the reality on the ground that is hidden and discredited by bad actors around the world. It challenges viewers to see beyond headlines and statistics, to recognize the faces, dreams, and struggles of people who endure unimaginable hardships at the hands of a cruel force. As a testament to the enduring human spirit and a condemnation of apathy, From Ground Zero: Stories from Gaza is a wake-up call to confront the greatest injustice in our time and to advocate for a world built on dignity, empathy, and justice. This film is not just a viewing experience; it is a profound and necessary reckoning.

Stunning is the word. For plot, for directing, for acting, for chemistry, for everything that Bad Sisters is actually. I haven't been this amazed by a TV show (or a movie) in years. Just wow! A big applause to all the actors and actresses here.nnDespite loving it so much, I just hope they don't go all Hollywood on it and make another season. The series feels complete, and let's not spoil it like Hollywood crews usually do with TV series they make - ruin it for the sake of money. Stay put and enjoy the masterpiece as it is.nnI will "follow my fanny" and gladly rewatch it soon for fantastic humour, language, elegance and stunning acting. Bravo!

Plot (25%) The plot is highly intriguing and surprising, but the inclusion of child abuse is unsettling. Score: 23%nCharacters (20%) The characters feel bland, with potential for development through plotlines and conflicts. Score: 9%nDirection (15%) The pacing and tone were fantastic, perfectly fitting the show's sad and gloomy atmosphere. Score: 15nVisuals (15%) The visuals were impressive, though not particularly groundbreaking. Score: 14%nMusic (10%) The minimal use of music leaves little impact. Score: 3%nTheme (10%) The theme is grounded and well-executed, pushing boundaries outside my comfort zone but leaving an impression. Score: 8%nEntertainment Value (5%) Not highly entertaining for me, but likely appeals to its target audience. Score: 3%nOverall: 75% The first episode was surprising; looking forward to the next one tomorrow.

"Watching Baby John is like sitting through a poorly stitched imitation of a blockbuster like Theri but without the soul, logic, or emotional depth that made Vijay's movie iconic. Varun Dhawan tries his best, but his performance feels hollow, as if he's unsure whether he's playing a cop, a father, or just a generic Bollywood hero.nnThe story lacks originality, with a predictable plot that's neither gripping nor engaging. The emotional scenes, which were the backbone of Theri, come across as forced and melodramatic here. The action sequences are over-the-top yet uninspiring, leaving you wondering if the director was more focused on slow-motion shots than actual storytelling.nnThe supporting cast doesn't help either. The villains are caricatures, and the child actor, while talented, is let down by a lackluster screenplay. The music, far from elevating the film, feels repetitive and forgettable.nnUltimately, Baby John is a forgettable attempt at recreating the magic of Theri. It's a clear example of how simply copying a successful formula without understanding its essence results in a shallow, unremarkable film. Save yourself the time and skip this one."

Everyone says great show, but why the ex and daughter.nnThree reasons:n1. Sex appeal is very similar to comedy relief. The son is too serious, death all around, it just lightens up the mood.nn2. Main protagonist has strengths as a land man. But he also has his flaws and his hurdles. He's an alcoholic; he lives like a teenage male; he's divorced and he's jumpy at his wife; and the last one is he's got a wife who has a love/hate relationship with him AND a daughter who is growing up too fast (and the positive is she loves him, as opposed to despising him).nn3. The ex and daughter has a counterweight to the additional hurdle of having a son who's so smart that he may take his father down sooner rather than later.nnAnd I love Becca. I'm male and cheering for the oil guys cuz I believe in capitalism. And she's a pitbull. It's like there is a 12 year surgeon who's born with brain to do open heart surgery-she's young, maybe too young, but she points out all the flaws that men have in this business, and she puts them to shame. She hunts down everyone and everything. And she will sooner than later be BBT greatest opponent. Cartels, no problem. Accidents, it happens. Lawsuits, pay em off. But Becca may be BBT biggest fight. And she's very very easy on the eyes. Canadian women are something else, no offense to ex and daughter! LOLnnGreat show all around!!!

Season one= messy, with some clean spots every so often; along with a stupid cliff-hanger for no reason. Grayson is the main attraction, everything else is meh.nnSeason 2- an improvement, but still suffers from silly writing and contrived decisions; Deathstroke was awesome though!! Blackfire storyline was a wet fart. Hated Dick's decisions After Jericho. Rose was boring.nnSeason 3- A regressive downgrade with so much wasted potential, Scarecrow wasn't really Scarecrow, Red Hood was a disappointment, and the show felt more like a Bat Family show than a Teen Titan's one. Don't get me started on Tim Drake also, Good lord what a miscast to add to the miscast list in this show.nnSeason 4- Started off quite promising, then like the rest of the seasons in this show it fell off it's feet and became a drag once more. Brother Blood's final battle against the Titan's is laughable, why would you fist fight Night-Wing when you can fire energy beams at him!!!? Or anyone for that matter!? Trigon's return is a massive disappointment and then even worse; he's killed!? Trigon is IMMORTAL by the way.nnAs you can see the mains flaws of this show are it's contrived writing and direction, its actor's are a mixed bunch.nnBrentan Thwaites is a great Dick Grayson, his portrayal may be too dark for some and I would've liked some more comedy from his Grayson but he captures the character quite well.nnCurran Walters is a great Jason Todd, his Red Hood isn't any different unfortunately but if you just view him as Jason he does well.nnRyan Potter is a good Beast Boy, however his character is underdeveloped and by the last season it's too late to care when they finally try to do so.nnSuper Boy is also excellent, along with Krypto.nnI like Donna Troy and Dawn, mostly Dawn cause eye candy but both actresses do well; Hawk is also fine but contrived writing also hurts his character. Sucks when they leave the show.nnRaven, Starfire, and Tim Drake are all terrible, I especially hate Tim; apart from some intellectual scenes his actor is terrible at portraying him. Plus the progressive Bisexual messaging with him, (I'm assuming because they made him Bi recently in the comics) was really nauseating.

column3: Sally Leapt out of a Window Last Night (2023)
column4: I love a good Sapphic period drama like any old red blooded lesbian but have to say there's an untrue fact in this one. The story is heroic, I had just watched a very similar short however also in the Iris Prize series. Period drama with a ward and a family member in the house eloping, maybe this was a premise in a contest? The story builds up from a young ward in 1778s Ireland but it was unclear who Eleanor was, is she also a ward, or a niece? Or just living there like a roommate. This wasn't really cleared up, I just understood she had to go to a convent and she didn't want to. The intimate scene was clearly trying to avoid actually showing anything, not sure why. Was it rated for kids? I won't spoil it, it's a full rounded story with a good ending.nnHowever, I was very shocked to then read the blatant lie that ireland was the first country in the world to legalize gay marriage in 2015! This is not true, as a Dutch person very proud to say it was the Netherlands in 2001.nn"21 December: Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands signs into law the first same-sex marriage bill in the world. It had previously cleared the country's Senate on 19 December in a 49-26 vote and the House of Representatives on 12 September in a 109-33 vote. The law came into effect on 1 April 2001."nnSo this was dissapointing to read, a simple google search would have cleared that up.

I give it a 10/10 literally because it's the best book adaptation I have ever seen ( and I say as a fan of the Peter Jackson LoTR ). One of my favorite books and it is so well done interpret. I had my fears when starting the show as I didn't even come close to imagine how good it would turn out to be. Everything, every detail is captured perfectly and I was able to relive the book once again but this time through the directors view, the amazing shots, montage, pace, and last but not least the tremendously great acting of all of the cast. Increible!!!nnP. S. I Advise you watch it in Spanish with English subs as it would really blend in with the whole experience.

The main characters in Wild Coast Warriors, Nonhle Mbuthuma and Sinegugu Zukulu won the Goldman Environmental Prizes for 2024, nicknamed the "Green Environmental Nobel Prizes." They both were also awarded the Burning Planet Heroes of the Year accolade from the Daily Maverick newspaper in South Africa on Christmas day, 2024.nnWild Coast Warriors was selected as the Best Feature in the Environmental & Cultural category at the Pakistan International Mountain Film Festival 2024. Wild Coast Warriors, has also been awarded the Best Feature Documentary award at the Hill Film Festival in Bangladesh. This film had its World Premiere at the 26th Encounters International Documentary Film Festival and the first two screenings were sold out. It was nominated "Best of the Fest." Wild Coast Warriors has been judged an Award Winner (Best Documentary Feature, November season) at the International Guadalajara Film Awards in Mexico and nominated for the Best Feature Doc at Madrid Indie Film Festival Awards in Spain, it has been selected as a winner of the IMDb qualifying seasonal competition of Montreal Independent Film Festival, as the Best Environmental Film, given an honorable mention at the Lookout Wild Film Festival in Chattanooga, Tennessee, USA.nnPippa Ehrlich, director of "My Octopus Teacher," said "Wild Coast Warriors was a critical story about the power of community advocacy, and a warning to big corporations that there is strength in the voices of vulnerable people who are connected to and dependent on their land."

This was a film that I got the chance to see thanks to Justin Cook who sent over a screener. What I knew coming in was that this was a horror film that was from 2024. Since I like to include independent films when I can, I decided to check this out. Other than that, I did come into it blind with just the information I've given here.nnSynopsis: when a troubled assistant bank manager's baby daughter goes missing, he must follow the instructions of a mysterious voice on the other end of a baby monitor to save her before she disappears forever.nnWe start this with a guy running away from a group of hooded individuals at night. He is Andy (Ryan Barton-Grimley). What is interesting here is that they're also wearing masks which look like creepy babies. One of them catches Andy.nnThis turns out to be a nightmare. He wakes up at work. The building's janitor, Thomas (Richard Gayler), checks in on him and we learn that Andy was recently promoted to the title in the synopsis. His boss is George Jansen (Patrick Pankhurst), who is going away on vacation. This puts pressure on Andy since he must oversee responsibilities while he is gone. It doesn't help that he has a newborn at home that they're sleep training. A box comes for him and it is a new baby monitor that is an owl.nnHe goes home to his wife, Allie (Simone Barton-Grimley). She gets ready to go out for a girl's night. This will leave Andy at home, since he doesn't believe they can afford a babysitter. Things seem to be going well. Andy keeps falling asleep and being woken up by the monitor. One of the times that he goes into the baby's room, he opens the window. There is another time he goes in there to find that his daughter is gone. That's when a strange voice, done by Ari Schneider, talks to him over the monitor. He needs Andy to steal money from ATMs with this special, unmarked card that he has. To complicate things, there is another person calling from a fraud detection company. He usually speaks with George, but with him gone, this falls on Andy. It is a race against the clock to get the infant back, but things aren't as they seem either.nnThat is where I'll leave my recap and introduction to the characters. Where I want to start is with the fact that this is a film that I could connect with. My wife and I, at the time of writing this, have a two-year-old and another child on the way. I remember those sleepless nights until we figured out sleep training. I can appreciate that this is using how parents become sleep deprived and it is a struggle. This does use a troupe that I'm not the biggest fan of since it cheapens things for me. What I will say is that this made me anxious with the knowledge that a baby could be in peril.nnNow since this is a newer film, I'm not going to spoil it. The main conflict here is that Andy must steal 250 thousand dollars in a set timeframe or he will never see his daughter again. It seems like he's able to rob ATMs with this unmarked card that he has. I didn't realize what I was seeing at first, but I believe that he uses this in the beginning. I just thought it was a keycard for work. This card allows him to confuse the ATM system and take money. He must hit a bunch of machines to collect enough, especially since it doesn't allow him to take out the max amounts. There are little things that happen along the way, like dropping money and someone taking it. There's also a police officer, played by David Rickabaugh, who finds Andy suspicious. I'd do whatever it takes to get my daughter back so I connect there.nnLet me then shift to an issue that I have. This uses dream sequences as a major aspect. I am slightly forgiving just remembering when I wasn't sleeping due to our daughter not. I get that it will drive you insane and make you feel like you're losing your mind. That's something that I can work with. This is also playing with the idea that him feeling guilty is playing into what is happening. Also, he might not be fully ready to be a father. It takes this ordeal for him to figure it out. We even get that Allie might leave him due to their daughter. How this concept is used was solid, but through dreams is something that is overused to me.nnI then want to shift over to talk about the acting performances. I'll preface by saying that this is a low budget effort so no one is great. Ryan Barton-Grimley did write, direct and stars in this. It makes me think that he must have raised a small child since he's spot on there. There were a couple moments here and there where I don't know if he nailed what he needed. He fits this role though so credit there. Schneider has a good voice to be the one that we hear over the monitor. There are eerie things that happen there. Simone Barton-Grimley doesn't have much time on screen. She's more of that character though that is looming. Ryan needs to have the baby home before she gets back so it helps with the tension. Other than that, Rickabaugh and Gayler work as these two who we don't know if we can fully trust. Pankhurst works in his limited role as well.nnAll that is left then is filmmaking. The best part here is the sound design. Hearing the baby over the monitor is regularly so there is that nagging feeling with it. That helps with the idea that Ryan might not be cut out to be a father. I also like what they do with these voices that are haunting him over the machines as well. I'd say that the cinematography and framing were solid. They do well with blurring the lines of reality and the nightmares, so despite my feelings on using that, they capture it well. There are also limited effects, but the blood we see and the masks were creepy.nnIn conclusion, this is one that I think is exploring an interesting idea. I'd say that Ryan Barton-Grimley does well as our lead with Schneider there to push him to where he ends up. This is also well made with the sound design along with the cinematography and framing to capture the nightmare logic. Not one that I think everyone will enjoy or connect with like I did. I still thought that this was a solid enough film. Borders on horror in general but goes enough into that realm.nnMy Rating: 6 out of 10.

I would have given it 10 stars if Disney would have let abela die of a stroke or heart attack. Or maybe even butthole cancer. Maybe even get trapped in the house when it collapsed and she was crushed or smothered to death. But hey it was good none the less. What ever happened to the good ole days when b*tchy old grandmas that treated their grandkids like garbage would die a horrible death? I think it would have been fitting. Or maybe while she was trapped in the collapsed house Bruno's rats could have slowly eaten away at her while she contemplated how horrible she treated the one granddaughter that loved their family the most.

I do love me a good WW2 movie and I have seen quite a few of them. It's nice seeing one that is inspired by events I've never heard of before. When I say inspired, I mean it. They really take liberties with the facts for the full entertainment effect which makes it come off looking a little like Inglourious Basterds or even Overlord. I also like Guy Ritchie's stuff. He's an auteur who puts his own quirky touch on everything he directs, this movie included.nnA rag-tag team of out misfit soldiers lead by Gus March-Phillips (Henry Cavill) get commissioned (more like forced) to blow up a ship in a port of Africa that the Nazis control. Operation Postmaster is one of the many pivotal operations in the war, that if not successful may have caused a domino effect that could be devastating. There's more to the plot, but as I said it isn't the most accurate. I hope it will inspire you to look up one of the many interesting events of WW2.nnOne of the big things they took liberties with was the violence. I don't believe anyone actually died, but in the movie a ridiculous amount of people get shot. There are also a ton of over-the-top fight sequences, mostly from Alan Ritchson who plays Lassen. He bull-dozes himself through a gang load of Nazi's. Somehow even with all the violence they manage to keep the movie lighthearted and even silly at times. Cavil and Ritchie play off each other very charmingly.nnMost of the actors of this "Scooby Gang" do a satisfactory job with the material that they were given, which really isn't much. They are not really the most fleshed out characters, but this is not really that type of movie. Henry Cavill and (built like a brick house) Alan Ritchson are really the only ones who stand out. Even the blindingly attractive woman is forgettable. I always like seeing Til Sweiger in any movie. I have been following his career for a long time. For someone who is supposed to be an incredibly brutal heartless person, he comes off more like a bungling smitten fool, which diminishes the feeling of danger for our heroes. I mean he dies so easily and embarrassingly. All the Nazis are inept. I also wasn't impressed with the portrayal of Wonston Churchill. Danny Sapan had a small but memorable roll as a tribal leader of the African community there. He delivers my favorite line of the movie about hating Nazis not because they are evil, but because they are gauche.nnThe set, costumes, cinematography and especially the musical score are impressive. It clearly has a generous budget and some talented people on the technical side of it.nnApparently, Ian Fleming who wrote the James Bond books was a young officer at that time because he's in a few small scenes. I'm not sure if it was necessary to throw that tad-bit in, but there you go.

Fighter (2024), directed by Siddharth Anand, showcases spectacular action sequences that solidify Anand's reputation as one of India's finest action directors. However, beyond the action, the movie struggles with a dull story and a lack of emotional depth, making it an average watch overall.nnThe concept of the movie had potential, but the execution falters. The first half starts off decently, but the second half drags and becomes boring. The pacing issues, coupled with weak editing (the film could've easily been trimmed by 30 minutes), make the runtime feel exhausting at points.nnHrithik Roshan, as usual, looks dashing, but his performance doesn't bring anything new. Deepika Padukone, while visually stunning, fails to deliver a memorable performance. Her acting feels recycled from Pathaan.nnAnil Kapoor delivers his typical performance.nnThe dialogues are painfully cringe-worthy and fail to create any impact.nnOn the positive side, the movie excels in technical aspects. The aerial action sequences are brilliantly shot, the cinematography captures the stunning beauty of Jammu and Kashmir, and the background score heightens the thrill during action scenes. The VFX is impressive in parts but falters, especially during the climax.nnThe songs, however, are a big letdown. Apart from being visually appealing, particularly the track Ishq Jaisa, the music doesn't leave a lasting impression. Deepika's semi-nude monokini moments may excite some viewers.nnVerdict: Fighter is a visually pleasing action flick that doesn't live up to its potential. Watch it for the action and cinematography, but keep your expectations very low.

This show hooked me from the beginning. The actors were amazing. I see some gave it a bad rating for the ending but the show as a whole was well done. The ending was rushed but still a great watch. It was a romantic thriller which is exactly what is was supposed to be. Loved the music and the escape. It's not a serious drama but a fun one. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a romance like a romance novel. The characters are beautiful and sexy. The plot is creative and not your typical kdrama which I like. It's not my favorite kdrama but certainly a very entertaining one. It's worth the watch if you are into that genre.

I'm gonna be honest. The writers built an entire fantasy world, spent many seasons and years on Aravos and his plans but... that's it? Like his story is done after 10 minutes?nnThe finale started so good with Karim suddenly turning to Aravos' side and unexpectetly getting crushed without a comment. Rex Igneous - killed. Callum's dilemma of being killed to imprison Aravos. So many "Oh damn"- moments.nnIt feels like the creators got tired of their own show and just wanted to rush to an end. So many stories which have been created over all the last YEARS were just thrown away. But hey, at least we can save the world by friendship, love and jokes, am I right?

What a disappointing slow, plodding waste of time.nnWhile the cast is top notch, with Fiennes, Tucci, Rossellini (in a very small role), and Lithgow, the "right" vs. "left" politics slaps the viewer in the face. There's supposed to be intrigue and behind the scenes views of what it takes to pick another pope. The intrigue is as feeble as the octogenarians playing the part of cardinals. The tension was over dramaticized, the tension that's supposed to keep us on the edge of our seat instead pulled one to their ever present phone to start scrolling.nnWas the purpose of the movie to cast further shade onto the Catholic church and belittle it further? The overt characterizations were poorly written.nnOn the plus side, the cinematography and DP were top notch. It's a shame it had to end with Dil (re: The Crying Game) being outed as a transsexual Pope. Oops, it wasn't Dil, it was Cardinal Vincent Benitez, a last minute appointee.nnThere are more producers and executive producers of this movie, than there are real life cardinals at the vatican conclave. Apparently it took a big push to get this botched homunculus made.nnWhile the visuals, lighting and in some parts music were exceptional, the cast couldn't save the.lacking story, the pitiful western politics, and the laughable trans DEI based twist.

What a gorgeous retelling of the Cain and Abel story, adapted from the Steinbeck novel East of Eden.nnThis miniseries apparently was impossible to get; Oprah couldn't get it for her favorite book show. I'm glad it's on DVD now, and I hope a lot of people watch it.nnThe James Dean film East of Eden only covers the last third of the book. The miniseries takes us back to the beginning, of the rivalry between brothers Charles (Bruce Boxleitner), Adam (Timothy Bottoms), and the woman that changes their lives, Kate (Jane Seymour).nnThe miniseries moves on to the twins (who are either Charles' or Adam's), Cal and Aaron (Sam Bottoms and Hart Bochner), and shows us Kate as an older woman, still ruining lives either directly or indirectly.nnThe production is magnificent, it's brilliantly photographed and directed.nnThe star of the miniseries is Jane Seymour, in an absolutely staggering performance as the sociopathic Kate, first as a young girl who burns down her parents' house, and later as am arthritic woman who runs a whorehouse.nnThe amazing thing about the performance is how Seymour ages - her walk, her bearing, her gnarled hands, everything about her says she's aged.nnThe acting is uniformly good with one caveat, and that's the acting of Timothy Bottoms. As the younger Adam, he comes off as mentally unstable; as the adult Adam, he gives a very external performance.nnSadly, the important role of Sam (Soon Tek-Oh) was eliminated in the James Dean film. Sam is the one who translates the important word in the Bible story of Cain and Abel, "Timshel." In the end, God blesses Cain with free will, leaving the choice of good and evil to him ("Thou mayest rule over him").nnVery powerful, and totally missing from the film. This is a shame, because the story centers around choice. In this version, it's fantastic, and with it, the miniseries has the same ending as the book.nnI highly recommend this to everyone. It's a shame we don't have miniseries like this any longer. The Dean film is beautifully done, but it's not the whole story. You will be swept away by the full experience.

Life And Other Problems tells a story of a man named Max who wants to find the meaning of life by interviewing mostly various scientists and asking them questions like: "Why does life exist?", "What is the purpose of life?", "What is the difference between a man and an animal?", etc. This storyline is somewhat frustrating, because the questions are vague and the answers are vague, meaningless, factually dubious or any combination of the above. But along the way, Max drops subtle clues that eventually tell another, completely different story, perhaps the one he wanted to tell in the first place but didn't find the courage to. This story appears if you follow Max's off-hand remarks about his personal life scattered throughout the movie. If you want to piece it together by yourself, stop reading now.nn--- SPOILER ALERT!!! THE REST IS ALL SPOILERS!!! ---nnThe hidden story is this: Max is a middle-aged man and his eldest daughter is about to move out of his house. Max is incredible sad about it. It's a natural event but the loss of his daughter's company is crushing to him. To make things worse, Max is unable to express his emotions, because he has learned not to have any emotions in the first place. This runs in his family since his grandfather starved to death, probably in a concentration camp, during World War II. Since then, everyone in his family had to be strong, no emotions were allowed, because they could be devastating.nnBut this time, Max's grief is so great it threatens to break out and wreak havoc on his perfectly controlled, emotionless world. So Max starts looking for ways to suppress his emotions once again. His preferred method is rationalization of the sort: "It makes no sense to be sad, because... (insert a comforting intellectual explanation here)."nnHe turns to biologists, hoping they could explain to him that grief makes no sense First, he tries to learn from a zoo employee who decides to kill a healthy giraffe. This man's resistance to emotions is remarkable. People are crying in his face, begging him to sell the giraffe to them for a million dollars, yet he always finds a rational-sounding explanation why he won't do it. It seems like he's perfectly mastered the skill of ignoring emotions but Max isn't satisfied (perhaps because the zoo man only ignores the grief of others and actually seems to kill the giraffe for his own pleasure).nnSo Max tries other biologists and digs up an esoteric book from about 200 years ago. Then he uses the scientists vague answers to his vague questions and the material from the book to create an esoteric religion that explains to him that everything in the universe is connected, so he can never be away from his daughter, and God may actually exists, because some scientists believe he does. And that's it.
