How about becoming vegetarian? How about taxing David Walsh's ill-gotten gambling revenue that his wife spends on dresses and carnivorous, celebrity, dinner-parties? How about calling-out Kirsha's Cruella campaign for cruelty against felines, and females?nnIf you want actual science go to the Australian Pet Welfare Foundation reports and peer-reviewed articles in international 'Animals'. A 'One Welfare' approach, optimises the well-being of people, animals and their environment. Community Cat Programs intensive de-sexing is effective, low-cost and saves many lives - animals, humans and wild.nnBut hey, the government-funded ABC think it is 'electorally popular' to push 24-hr cat curfews - expensive failures which hurt renters, target the elderly, and the disabled, and effectively criminalise cat-carers. Couldn't we Eat the Rich, instead of punishing the poor? 'The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are treated' - Mahatma Gandhi. Australia - where are you?

You can watch this "film" on archive.org - but I would not recommend it.nnIt is badly made (just images and texts thrown together) - very low production value, void of any critical thinking. Boring to watch, really has no place at all.nnTo call Quisling a Humanitarian is nauseating - he is personally responsible for the deaths of many of his own countrymen and -women.nnThe correct title would be Vidkun Quisling: Traitor, Murderer, Disgraced.nnThe Einsatzgruppen, including units like Quisling's, were responsible for the mass murder of over a million people, primarily Jews, but also including Roma, Soviet POWs, and others deemed "undesirable" by the Nazi regime.nnIt's important to note that:nnQuisling was a collaborator: He led the puppet government of Norway during the German occupation and actively aided the Nazis in their persecution of the Norwegian population.nnIndividual responsibility: While it's difficult to pinpoint the exact number of killings directly attributable to Quisling himself, he bears significant responsibility for the atrocities committed in Norway under his rule.nnThe Holocaust was a horrific event, and it's crucial to remember the victims and learn from this dark period in history.

A strange experience is all I can sayn'Mainstream' was a very strange experience for me. It's one of the more unique films I've ever seen, however unique certainly doesn't always equal good. The main problem I found with the film were the characters. The type of people being portrayed - fame-seeking, do anything for money, selfish, entitled scum - aren't a lot of fun to watch, even when they are being portrayed by Andrew Garfield giving everything he has to a role.nnGarfield is probably the one redeeming factor this movie has going for it. It was a strange performance to watch because I could tell he was putting it all out there and doing a great job of it, but his character was so strange and unlikeable that it almost all went to waste. Maya Hawke (daughter of Uma Thurman and Ethan Hawke) on the other hand didn't have to do a whole lot for her role, but because she was the one mildly likeable character her performance came across quite well. It was a weird dynamic.nnI don't think I can recommend this one. There's a world where I could see people enjoying this here and there, but for the most part people just aren't going to have a good time with this one. If you like unique and bizarre movies though then this one could be right up your alley. Otherwise stay away.

While not considered a classic in the traditional sense, this film comes remarkably close to achieving that status due to its abundance of standout scenes. The narrative centers around Sam, a man who cherishes his fulfilling life, a stark contrast to the premise of the film "Click." Instead of fast-forwarding through his days, Sam's idyllic existence is abruptly cut short when he is tragically killed, only to return as a ghost. This aspect of the story, where Sam retains the ability to interact with the physical world while other departed souls cannot, may be viewed as a minor flaw. However, the strength of the characters and plot is so compelling that this inconsistency hardly detracts from the overall enjoyment of the film.nnSam's discovery that he can communicate with a counterfeit spiritualist, portrayed by Whoopi Goldberg in a role executed with remarkable skill, may seem somewhat cliche. Yet, the film's engaging narrative and character development easily overshadow this familiarity. Without revealing spoilers, it's worth noting that the movie delivers a satisfying experience, blending elements of romance, humor, logic, adventure, suspense, and memorable scenes that captivate the audience.nnNumerous standout moments contribute to the film's allure. Whether it's Sam trailing his friend to the killer's hideout, interactions with his friend that are nothing short of iconic, or the sequences involving Whoopi Goldberg's character navigating the bank, each scene adds to the film's charm. Noteworthy scenes also include Sam's encounters with enigmatic dark figures, particularly the emotional depth displayed when Sam shows compassion towards a malefactor in a poignant and heroic moment, despite the wrongs committed against him.nnThe film's ability to evoke such a range of emotions and its adept portrayal of character dynamics make it a truly enjoyable watch. It seamlessly weaves together elements of humor, suspense, and genuine human connection, culminating in a movie that resonates with audiences on a profound level. With its mix of engaging storytelling, memorable scenes, and emotional depth, this film emerges as a classic in its own right-a cinematic gem that is sure to captivate viewers and leave a lasting impression.

I found Nosferatu to be a short film stretched out over 2 1/4 hours. I understood the historical basis but the dialogue and acting felt like a Shakespeare play performed by first year graduates. Although the actors put their hearts into it the dialogue was two dimensional, acting wooden and the performance like a stage play. There were no subtle emotional nuances or segways. They were happy, they were sad, they were miserable, they were crazy. Ive suffered from these visions all my life and if you go to the castle you will die, aaaaarrrrggggg. That night. I'm over it now, you can go.nnThey also spent an hour for the guy to get to the castle. When he went into the Gypsy camp, they warned him, then left, I had no sense of, "better not go there". That could have been cut. The gypsies killed a vampire while parading a virgin, he witnessed it, then woke up. What relevance did that have to the story.nnI also don't think the plague narrative was developed enough. In the original film Nosferatu was made to look like a Jew and he immigrated to the country bringing rats which spread the bubonic plague. Jews were persecuted in Europe for bringing the plague.nn"The physical appearance of Count Orlok, with his hooked nose, long claw-like fingernails, and large bald head, has been compared to stereotypical caricatures of Jewish people from the time in which Nosferatu was produced (Wikipedia)". To see how Europeans saw Jews watch Al Pacinos The Merchant of Venice. So adapt the story for people who don't know this history.nnI could go on for hours. The cinematography was great but this movie reminded me of a BBC play on roids back when TV was black and white.nnThe ending scene was the only good part of the movie.

In my opinion, this Speak No Evil was 10000000000 times better than the original.nnWithout giving spoilers, no forget it I have to give spoilers to make my point. So the first one was infuriating and so disturbing that I thought about it for like a week. Now the director might think that's awesome but I did not. The ending of the original is horrific. The ending of this remake is a hell yeah! Fist pump on the air the Americans won! They beat your crazy asses and saved the children.nnI enjoyed that much more because A) I'm American. And B) I like that the villains were taken out by the couple that were made to look weak the whole movie. The wife wasn't that weak now was she? That actress I've seen in other movies, I really like her. I saw her in that one movie the Turning, she's good. And she's pretty, but anyway. James McAvoy was awesome as usual. He plays crazy so good you have to wonder.

It could have been a great serie and ended up being something that tasted like nothing. The first 3 episodes are exactly the same, it could have been 1 and even after those 3 episodes it was not clear what the series was about, whether it was horror, science fiction, a drama or a police series. At some point it started to become clearer and more or less you could see where it was going until the chapter that was dedicated entirely to the gang rape, did it added something to the story by dedicating 1 hour to that entire scene ? Absolutely NOTHING because it was irrelevant to the hole story (with 10 minutes was enough) I guess it was a simply to force the viewers for some empathy and deep emotions. The lasts episodes were already becoming a bit heavy for me, the protagonist spent his time crying every 5 minutes, then incredible scenes like someone coming to kill you who is 200 meters away and the only thing they could think of was to sit and wait exaggerating screams and cries without even wanting to run. It was also not clear what was the role they wanted to give to the mother who acted as a psychic but in the end she was just a murderer. The serie ended up being repetitive, exaggerated and with implausible situations.

Ghost is one of my favorite films. It is romantic and touching. Ghost shows the love that transcends even death. The chemistry between Demi Moore and Patrick Swayze is incredible. The way they look at one another is sexier than any of those very graphic "love scenes". They make a real romantic connection just through their eyes. Ghost not only has wonderful, likeable characters in Sam Wheat, Molly Jensen, and Oda Mae Brown, but it has an engrossing plot that moves right along. Entwined in all this is a beautiful score. The theme song "Ghost", written by Maurice Jarre specifically for the movie, is enchanting, and, of course, an oldie, "Unchained Melody", adds another magical touch to a magical film.

column3: "Found a Homeless Billionaire Husband for Christmas" (2024)
column4: OH MY (REDACTED) GOD, I just paid to watch this movie, and dear lord, I have never experienced such a wild ride with any film <3! The semblance of a plotline-requiring an archaeology team and National Geographic to decipher-keeps you on a constant roller coaster that ends with the weakest, limp resolution ever.nnThe main character never asks questions and behaves like an autistic kid who just gained the ability to see into all seven realms while on the verge of death at the Astroworld concert. I don't know if this actor is actually paid or also on the brink of death with a gun to her head because the way she speaks her lines without reacting to the mess in her script is incredible. The actor is amazing but is juxtaposed by the brain-dead storytelling depriving her of any common sense and thus relatability. What was the film even about? Any real message is cloudy, and it makes it feel like, even though the production value was high for this film, the director must have also been at Astroworld with the autistic kid. He had to have been SO high to make the astronomical leaps in logic that only someone with an IQ level of a cheeseburger could make to extract any semblance of relatability and suspense from the movie.nnThough every single event in this film feels like it's supposed to be the climax, the screenwriting ensures that any kind of reveal is delayed by subverting the audience's expectations through PULLING SOMETHING STRAIGHT FROM THEIR (REDACTED) to elongate arcs. This formatting keeps you interested just long enough to watch the next Instagram reel ad they make.nnThe biggest problem with this movie is the formatting. This was not meant to be a feature-length film but rather a series of TikToks played together in sequence to (hopefully) add up to a movie. However, the plotline revolves around this and astronomically hurts the film. Oh my god, the rising action feels infinite, as every major and minor conflict introduced in one segment is immediately resolved-or, even worse, seemingly postponed to a later reel. The action and suspense are instantly dropped, and any buildup to the climax is sabotaged. These segments begin repeating and harassing the viewer with enticing and sexy promises of a quick and logical resolution to the arc you were just hooked by-only for that arc to be extinguished within seconds. Scenes completely invalidate and retcon each other with barely any acknowledgment by any character.nnThough the story arc is most comparable to the erratic plotlines of dreams, the setting, camera work, and overall visuals of the movie are stunning, as are the actors themselves. While the characters seem to have dementia and forget which timeline they are in, the actors are amazing and play their parts effectively, even making the audience want to like this movie. The film had all the ingredients for greatness, which is why the story is such a letdown.nnThe company that produced this film has clearly tailored its storytelling to fit the format of an accompanying TikTok/Instagram-like app. It's very scary to see this dark and twisted path that movies-and entertainment in general-are taking to profit off the popularity of short-form platforms. This leaves a grim outlook for future generations. However, its sheer atrocity has also made me crave a real feature film that breaks the norm and challenges the status quo-movies that dare to stray from stereotypes, overused tropes, and mimicry.nnI hope that, through this type of content, we will eventually move past reusing the same tired molds for stories and be able to tell narratives that relate to us on a much deeper level-beyond the reach of cash grabs and HD revisions of old movies. My hope is for incredible films that use creativity to surpass what has been shown purely to generate profit. Either that, or we'll finally grow sick of all movie remakes, sequels, and spin-offs that completely stifle art.nnDid I also mention this movie was filmed ONLY in vertical 2160x3840 resolution?"

It's a comedy as it suggests. Overall its a fairly executed movie. The time travelling part is amazing as it helps her understand her way of life in a better perspective, also she gets to understand her sexuality more. The movie is engaging as it keeps you hooked up to see what the end is.nnShe gets to view life in a different way by understanding what family means not just that but also what it means to have friends most of all having a boyfriend she loves.nnElliot as she celebrates her birthday with friends, she finds her self in need of seeking advice about her future. Her older self advises her to strengthen bonds with her family .

This was ten times the movie I expected. I'm not a horror or gore fan, but in an era when social commentary is branded as "woke" by those who tend not to pick up on it, I'll lend my ears to a filmmaker with something to say through horror.nn"The Substance" doesn't pretend to be "for everyone". I can hardly stomach needles onscreen, but it's the SOUND palette of this movie that might be the most disgusting sound design I've ever experienced in a movie, yet it's cartoonish at the same time. Kind of like the dessert wafer scene in Monty Python's "The Meaning Of Life" on acid. You'll know the basics of the plot by now, but the execution is centered in a feminist Cronenberg social critique and then skips numerous opportunities to just quit at any convenient ending point to take a detour from David Lynch's Mulholland Drive to his Elephant Man with John Waters' and Divine's middle fingers to society's relegating women to window dressing for the enjoyment of others, and still refusing to let up without a full on Gwar show finale (just as messy and just as silly) that generously delivers the gross-out spectacle while mocking our collective refusal to deal with seeing ourselves age.nnDon't see it on a full stomach.nn[PS: Props also to the dark techno angle of the film score. I'm sure the music supervisor(s) were aware of the track "Substance (Felix Da Housecat Remix)" by Dot Allison. While not as dark and heavy as the film's score, it seems a missed opportunity not to include it somewhere, even over the end credits. I recommend looking the song up wherever you get your music.]

Making a movie a cultural icon takes many coincidences, and Terminator 2 is doomed to be one. It has every feature to be remembered. When I was a little boy and hadn't seen much film, the Terminator series was the one that I remember to this day. The story of human rebellion fighting against the killing robots produced by the uncontrolled AI network Skynet is simply stunning and stuttering. In 2025, as we look at T2, it is surprising that this movie, though made in 1991, is not outdated.nnThe 15 minutes of the opening T2 is almost identical to the first one, so it's natural for the audience to take the same mindset that T-800 is evil and T-1000, shaped like a police officer, is a good guy. Then, all the scenes imply that T-800 returns to hunt John Corner again this time, and T-1000 is here to protect him. The confusion, tension, and fright burst when T-800 commanded coldly, "Get down." The stark contrast between an evil-looking good guy and a kind-looking bad guy gets maximized, leaving everyone shocked and awed. This design in the plot gives T2 its flavor while keeping the link with T1. Sadly, many sequels of this time have neither fun to watch nor the creative spark that made the original films memorable. Most of them are only monotonic repetitions.nnThe transformation of the T-800 is another reason why people love this film. How would anyone refuse to see an intellectually 3-year-old robot imitate a handsome teenager and become more like a human? Terminator learning has recently been similar to AI learning, making T2 more special in 1991.nnAnother thing worth mentioning is the completion of our heroine, Sarah Corner. After her trauma in the first Terminator, she went through several phases to restore trust in the T-800. We can see more of Sarah's side as a mother. Her urgency in protecting her son is mixed with the responsibility of saving the hope for the future leader of human rebellion. Therefore, Sarah Corner, a character from the last part, still has a complete growing curve. This strong and independent woman, who held a SPAS-12 fighting against the Terminator, became part of American pop culture.nnEven though it's a textbook commercial movie, James Camer still instills much of his owning in it. It vaguely shows some social phenomena at that time, including juvenile delinquency, harsh environments in mental hospitals, and magnates controlling society. Though not explained in detail, these details add more dimensions to interest, and this is the proper standard of a masterpiece: Whenever it is watched, there is always something new to dig out.nnLooking back on my childhood, I feel blessed to have watched the Terminator series. Being exposed to films of such high quality at a young age undoubtedly helped me develop a better taste in motion pictures. At least whenever I want to indulge in a movie marathon, I find myself drawn to gems like "Terminator" or "The Lord of The Rings," confident that they will continue to inspire and entertain.

Have you ever looked up at the stars of night and wondered if there was anything out there? What if we discovered that all those beautiful and magnificent stars have no life on them? There is no love or hate, no light or dark. It is just us. This is the brutal story Ad Astra tells us.nnFor many Sci-Fi lovers, one of the greatest pleasures of watching Sci-Fi movies is to see those hardcore settings and get bombarded by all those special effects, and that is a significant reason why, in recent years, films like Interstellar and Gravity have received such high praise. However, as one of those Sci-Fi movies that promoted itself as "hardcore" and "realistic," Ad Astra has the biggest critics/audience divide on Rotten Tomatoes for a Brad Pitt movie. For me, Ad Astra is even more excellent than Interstellar and deserves more credit.nnAd Astra tells the story of Major Roy McBride (Pitt), an astronaut who is informed that the mysterious power surges that threaten to destabilize human civilization have been traced to the Lima Project. This space station in orbit around Neptune was sent 29 years earlier to search for intelligent life, and Roy's father, H. Clifford McBride (Tommy Lee Jones), was the project's leader. Roy agrees to cross the solar system to uncover the truth about the Lima Project, the power surges, and his father's disappearance.nnOne of the most beautiful things about Ad Astra is its characterization and foreshadowing of emotions.nnIn this movie, our protagonist is no longer someone who would "panic" or do something stupid that makes himself regretful. This time, our "hero," Roy, is a man with a closed heart and who is slightly autistic. When he meets other colleagues, he uses a smile as a disguise, but there's no emotion inside him. He can fall from 36000 kilometers and land safely on the ground, but his heart rate is kept under 80. This man is dead inside. He grew up as a hero son while his father ditched him and his mother for a space journey. This Roy, somehow still a boy, needs love. But when someone indeed loves him, he feels uneasy and deliberately keeps a distance just not to scare himself. You have to acknowledge that this kind of character is more complex and more difficult to predict. But it doesn't mean our Roy is hollow; His heart is filled with solitude, and nothing can penetrate it. This father-searching journey is destined to be one of self-searching. This is why the audience can't feel much intense in the first few conflict scenes. Because the director purposely sets the audience aside to match Roy's indifference. This kind of alienation is throughout the film. Personally speaking, this is where the subtlety lies. The whole movie, including the visuals, audio, and even the monologue, is designed to convey the solitude overwhelming Roy through the journey.nnPeople often forget how much they are like their parents, and that is why tragedy is passed down from generation to generation. Unavoidably, Roy didn't realize he inherited his father's solitude.nnClifford McBride has only one goal-finding life in outer space. This idea possessed him so much that he left his life on Earth behind and lived on the spaceship Lima for 30 years. Clifford refuses to take the truth of failure and insists on the other crew following him, causing an irreparable tragedy. Blinded by this obsession, he is stuck in the quagmire of loneliness, refusing to face his son. When Roy finds him, crossing the whole solar system. He instinctively shuns the touch of his son. That move out of consciousness reshows that they are the SAME. Nonetheless, Roy slowly realizes his difference from his father on the way and turns to human society in the end, and his father abandons himself to nil space after seeing the emptiness of the universe. At the movie's end, Roy makes up his mind to cut off the rope connecting his father and sends him drifting into the dark space. That wrinkled and winding rope is like an umbilical cord. It represents both the reborn of Roy and the death of Clifford. Cutting that rope, Roy not only killed his father physically but also spiritually. At that moment, he finally figures out that he's not going to be his father but to be himself. Although there was nothing out there, Roy still had people. He accepts the solitude and decides to create pleasure from sharing bonds with others.nnNot every Sci-Fi movie needs to be perfectly logical or live the physical book. The unrestrained imagination can also be the plain white canvas where people's beautiful and touching story is painted. Sometimes, it is easy to enjoy a film when you stop thinking and let the movie flow through it. Feel it rather than think. Then, after viewing one of them, you may look up in the sky and ask, is there anything out there?

I hadn't read the book, and I found this often hard to follow. When I got home, I read the IMDB plot synopsis, which allowed me to check if I'd interpreted things right. If you're someone who doesn't like having to work hard to piece together a story, I recommend you read the synopsis before watching the film.nnOn the positive side, the acting is excellent. Aunjanue Ellis-Taylor created a wonderful character as the grandmother - her facial expressions convey so much. The overall theme - how those who are supposed to protect us will often abuse that power, and then crush anyone who points this out - remains an important one to this day. I saw parallels with the Irish institution depicted in Small Things Like These. It was particularly poignant seeing the confidence that Elwood had in the civil rights movement get comprehensively destroyed as he realised that the rights are worth nothing if powerful people ignore them.nnThe three things I disliked most were (a) the extent to which you had to infer what had happened - obviously, you don't always want everything spelled out in detail, but it was hard to fit the pieces together, especially as at times things moved very fast; (b) the "point of view" camera shots did not work for me - occasionally they led to a beautiful and unusual perspective on something, but a lot of the time I found the camera movement jarring. (c) I'm afraid that I (white British person) would have liked subtitles - some of the dialogue was hard to follow - and this, put together with the other challenging aspects of the film, just added to the frustration.nnI know people who loved this film, and it got great reviews in some of the UK press, so I think for many people the experimental approach to storytelling and camera shots was exciting and refreshing. For me, it just was too much - especially for a film coming in at just under 2.5 hr. I was relieved when it ended!

By the time you get to the "one man war" the summary talks about, the movie is quite literally more than half way over. It's 49 minutes in before the girl gets kidnapped. The entire movie runtime is 1 hour 30 minutes. That's over half the movie just setting up the relationship between between the unrelated grown man and the girl. Man on Fire managed the same thing in what felt like a 10th of the time. And then when it's finally at a point you think it's going to get some traction, they knock him out and you have to watch a 2 minute flashback of two grown men waxing poetic about family in a gym complete with majestic lighting through the windows violins.nnAnd then there's a lot more talking. This is not an action movie, it just has a couple of action scenes sprinkled towards the end. Disappointing.

**Movie Review: *12th Fail* (2023)**nn*12th Fail* (2023), directed by *Vijay Maurya* and based on the best-selling novel by *Anurag Pathak*, is an inspiring yet heart-wrenching drama that strikes at the core of the pressures, struggles, and ambitions faced by today's youth. Set in the backdrop of the cut-throat education system in India, the film tells the story of a young man's journey from failure to success, portraying the trials and tribulations of students who find themselves trapped in a system that values results over personal growth and well-being. With a message of resilience, empathy, and perseverance, *12th Fail* is more than just a story about academic struggles-it's a reflection on the human spirit.nn**Plot and Themes:**nnThe film centers on the life of *Abhilash (played by Vikrant Massey)*, a small-town student who, despite his best efforts, fails his 12th-grade exams. This seemingly devastating moment becomes the catalyst for his personal and emotional journey, as he confronts the immense pressure to succeed in a society that defines a person's worth by their academic achievements. Abhilash's initial failure leads him to question his self-worth and identity, but it also prompts him to seek out a different path-one that prioritizes his own happiness and sense of purpose rather than adhering to the conventional societal standards.nnThe central theme of the movie revolves around the idea that failure is not the end but rather a stepping stone to a more meaningful and authentic life. Abhilash's story is one that resonates deeply with many students in India, where the stress to perform academically is overwhelming, leading to immense mental health issues. The film takes on these serious topics with sensitivity and compassion, offering an alternative perspective on success that doesn't rely solely on grades or career achievements.nn**Performance:**nnVikrant Massey's portrayal of Abhilash is nothing short of brilliant. He captures the nuances of a young man's internal struggle with remarkable depth. Massey's performance is subtle yet powerful, effortlessly transitioning from vulnerability to strength. His character's journey is both emotional and inspiring, making him the perfect fit for a role that requires both sensitivity and strength.nnThe supporting cast also deserves commendation. *Medha Shankar* as Abhilash's supportive yet realistic girlfriend brings warmth to the film, offering a voice of reason when the protagonist is lost in self-doubt. The character of Abhilash's mentor, played by *Sandeep Kulkarni*, adds another layer of emotional depth, representing the rare but crucial role of educators who genuinely care about their students' well-being and growth.nn**Direction and Cinematography:**nnDirector Vijay Maurya, known for his previous works in the industry, does an exceptional job of bringing the sensitive subject matter to life. His direction ensures that the film never loses its emotional weight, while maintaining a relatable tone throughout. The pacing of the film is steady, allowing the narrative to unfold organically and giving the audience the space to connect with Abhilash's journey.nnThe cinematography, handled by *Saurabh M. Pandey*, captures the essence of small-town life in India with authenticity and simplicity. The film's visual aesthetic is clean and grounded, mirroring the raw, unfiltered nature of the story. The backdrop of schools, bustling marketplaces, and quiet family homes creates a familiar atmosphere that draws the audience closer to the protagonist's world.nn**Music and Soundtrack:**nnThe music in *12th Fail* is evocative and complements the narrative beautifully. The soundtrack, composed by *Amjad Nadeem Aamir*, features songs that resonate with the emotional undertones of the film, without overwhelming the storytelling. The tracks are well-placed, subtly elevating the mood of the film and enhancing the emotional moments. One standout song is "Zindagi Se," which encapsulates the central theme of the movie: facing life's challenges with courage and dignity.nn**Final Thoughts:**nn*12th Fail* is not just another film about academic struggles. It is a poignant reminder of how societal expectations can sometimes overshadow personal dreams and aspirations. With its strong performances, realistic portrayal of student life, and powerful message, the film strikes a chord with anyone who has ever felt the weight of failure or the pressure to conform.nnThe film's message is clear: failure is not the end; it is a chance to redefine success on one's own terms. In a world where success is often measured by numbers, *12th Fail* reminds us that true success lies in self-discovery, resilience, and staying true to one's dreams.nnIn a time when student mental health is a growing concern, *12th Fail* is a much-needed conversation starter. It's a film that inspires, comforts, and challenges its audience, urging them to redefine what it truly means to succeed.

"My Old Ass" is a hilarious and heartwarming coming-of-age comedy. On her 18th birthday, Elliott embarks on a psychedelic journey that unexpectedly introduces her to her 39-year-old self. This older, world-weary version of Elliott offers a unique perspective on life, love, and the importance of embracing the present moment.nnAubrey Plaza delivers a masterclass in comedic timing as the cynical older self, perfectly balancing wit and wisdom. Maisy Stella shines as the younger Elliott, capturing the anxieties and excitement of youth with remarkable authenticity. Their on-screen chemistry is undeniable, creating a dynamic and entertaining duo.nnThe film masterfully blends humor and heart, exploring themes of self-discovery, family dynamics, and the bittersweet nature of growing up. "My Old Ass" is a delightful and thought-provoking cinematic experience that will resonate with audiences of all ages.

column3: "One Piece: Wan p√Æsu" (1999) {Luffy Tatsu! Uragirareta Yakusoku no Ketsumatsu! (#1.37)}
column4: "One Piece" Episode 37,"Luffy Rises! Result of the Broken Promise!", is a pivotal moment in the series, marking a significant turning point for both the Straw Hat Pirates and the show as a whole. This episode is widely regarded as one of the best in the series, and for good reason.nnThe episode delves into Nami's tragic backstory, revealing her enslavement under Arlong and her desperate attempts to save her village. Her despair and vulnerability are heartbreaking, and the scene where she pleads with Luffy for help is incredibly powerful. Luffy's response, placing his hat on Nami's head as a sign of trust and support, is a defining moment in his character development, showcasing his unwavering determination to protect his friends.nnThe confrontation with Arlong and his fishmen crew is intense and action-packed. The fight scenes are well-choreographed and visually stunning, but the focus remains on the emotional stakes. Nami's rage and desperation fuel her fight against Arlong, while Luffy's determination to protect her is unwavering. The scene where Luffy finally defeats Arlong is a cathartic moment, marking a victory for both Nami and the Straw Hat Pirates.nnThis episode not only solidifies the bond between Luffy and Nami but also establishes the Straw Hat Pirates as a force to be reckoned with. It demonstrates the crew's willingness to fight for their friends and their unwavering belief in each other. This episode also marks a shift in the tone of the series, moving from light-hearted adventures to more serious and emotional storylines.nnThis episode is a turning point in the series, elevating it to new heights and cementing its place as one of the greatest anime of all time.

Begins with excellent stock footage of air combat, but drags on very slowly after that. Definitely turn it off when he gets medical help. The plot is very hard to follow because of actors playing multiple roles and so many of the uniforms and the equipment that do not have clear insignias. Dubbing does not help because it is all with the same accent. Probably better with just subtitles, but they are also not well done. Perhaps the original version made more sense to native Russian speakers. It is nice to see an actress who looks like an actual real woman, but the viewers who are accustomed to the images of naked women in American films will be disappointed by the nudity. I would have deleted it. Overall, an embarrassingly amateur, low budget melodrama that was clearly made as propaganda. For much of the film I thought that it might have been a film that was at least partly made during the war, because that would have explained the poor quality of film-making.

"The Ministry of Ungentlemanly Warfare," directed by Guy Ritchie and released in April 2024, is an action-comedy film that delves into a lesser-known chapter of World War II history. The movie draws inspiration from Damien Lewis's 2014 book, "Churchill's Secret Warriors," and presents a dramatized account of Operation Postmaster-a covert mission executed by British forces to disrupt Nazi operations.nnPlot OverviewnnSet in late 1941, the film portrays the United Kingdom's struggle against Nazi Germany's advances in Europe. With London enduring relentless bombings and supply lines threatened by German U-boats, Prime Minister Winston Churchill (portrayed by an uncredited actor) authorizes Brigadier Colin Gubbins (Cary Elwes) to initiate Operation Postmaster. This clandestine mission aims to sabotage the Nazis' U-boat resupply operations on the Spanish-controlled island of Fernando Po.nnGubbins assembles a diverse team led by Major Gus March-Phillips (Henry Cavill), including operatives such as Marjorie Stewart (Eiza Gonz√°lez), Richard Heron (Henry Golding), and Anders Lassen (Alex Pettyfer). The narrative follows their perilous journey aboard the Swedish fishing trawler "Maid of Honor," their strategic maneuvers to infiltrate enemy territory, and the ensuing high-stakes operation to neutralize the Italian supply ship "Duchessa d'Aosta" and its accompanying vessels.nnCritical ReceptionnnThe film has garnered mixed reviews from critics and audiences alike. Some reviewers commend the ensemble cast's performances, particularly Henry Cavill's portrayal of Major Gus March-Phillips, noting his charismatic and commanding presence. Eiza Gonz√°lez's role as Marjorie Stewart is also highlighted for adding depth and intrigue to the narrative. The film's action sequences, characterized by Guy Ritchie's signature dynamic style, are praised for their intensity and choreography. However, some critics argue that the film's pacing is uneven, with certain segments feeling rushed while others linger unnecessarily. Additionally, the blend of historical events with comedic elements has been a point of contention, with opinions divided on its effectiveness.nnHistorical AccuracynnWhile the film is inspired by true events, it takes creative liberties for dramatic effect. Operation Postmaster, as depicted, is a heavily fictionalized version of the actual mission. The real operation, conducted in January 1942, involved the seizure of three Axis ships from the Spanish island of Fernando Po and was relatively bloodless with minimal strategic impact. Key historical figures, such as Ian Fleming and Winston Churchill, had limited involvement in the actual events, contrary to their prominent roles in the film. The film's portrayal of the operatives and their fates also diverges from historical records, opting for a more glamorous depiction.nnTHE TIMESnnConclusionnn"The Ministry of Ungentlemanly Warfare" offers a stylized and action-packed interpretation of a World War II covert operation, blending historical inspiration with cinematic flair. While it may not serve as a precise historical account, the film provides entertainment through its engaging performances and high-octane sequences. Viewers seeking a factual retelling may find discrepancies, but those open to a dramatized war film with elements of humor and action are likely to appreciate Guy Ritchie's latest venture.

Elizabeth Gillies is too talented to be here, in the beginning of the movie she got a few real laughs out of me, her delivery is on point as always but even she couldn't save this movie in the long run. On a real level she is the reason I watched this, I've recognized her talent ever since Victorious aired on nickelodeon, I always thought she was the best actor and singer on that show and was so excited to see her grow in both fields. Sadly most projects she is attached to don't tend to be all that good, this is no exception. This movie is degenerate for degeneracys sake, if this movie came out when I was in or fresh out of high school I probably would have fooled myself into liking it more, but I'm 27 and this movie is too Juvenile for how explicit it is. The characters are cartoonishly over the top, and the plot is predictable. Not to get too graphic but this is not an accurate portrayal of the porn industry, and I get its a comedy and dosen't have to be, but all the sex positive feminism in porn is vastly overstated. The industry is rampant with addiction, disease, abuse, and SA along with a ton of other problems that feminists as well as all decent people could easily identify as moral evils. This isn't the worst thing ive seen Liz in I can't say I enjoyed "Animal" more than this movie but I really hope she gets some better roles in the future.

I don't really understand why it's so low rated.nnI have seen couple dozen cdramas and a whole lot of kdramas. And among cdramas this is right in the top 5 for me.nnOn the outset, this may look similar to several other cdramas we have seen,like You are my hero, My dear guardian(also starting Johnny), Flaming Heart, Fireworks of my heart, etc.nnBut trust me it isn't. I mean apart from leads being in love and then reconciling after years, yes that part sounds similar to Fireworks of my Heart. But rest is quite different.nn******SPOILERS AHEAD*******nnWhy I loved it ? Because it has an actual plot, that revolves around the leads, why they separated and things that keep happening around them. This isn't just another doctor-special forces love story. We have seen plenty of those. This is story of two people meeting in college, falling in love and some really evil people making their love life like hell, every time they try to get together.nnThe chemistry between the leads work. Johnny Huang is by no means a great actor, but still such roles suit him, especially I loved his character here, always calm, composed, even in the worst of situations, he never loses his temper and calm head. Absolutely loved his green flag character. Swet, gentle yet intimidating in subtle ways.nnFL is the best part and highlight of the show. I haven't seen this actress in any other drama. But here she absolutely nails her character and emotions. She has a very captivating expressions that will keep your eyes enaged on her. Her expressions timings were on point and so were her dialogue delivery. It was amazing how nicely she portrayed the shades of her character, like when she's single and not with ML anymore, there's a gloomy depressed vibe around her face, but whenever she's with ML she is able to suddenly switch on and brighten up. Even the difference in her smiles is brilliant, like her smiling when she's single and her smiling when she's close to ML. Her smile, facial expressions and EYES, she's good , really good. I hope she gets recognised for her acting and gets more lead roles.nnOne particular scene I wanna mention, where the obsessed antagonist, comes too hard on FL, hugs and molests her. Her expressions after that are so bang on. Like you can feel that she's shocked, angry, scared, emotional crying, like every emotion in those few seconds were so brilliantly done by the FL actress.nnAlso special mention to whoever was the makeup artist of the FL, there was very subtle makeup done on her throughout the show, which is what female doctors on duty actually look like, her hair is mostly just open and dishelved, a very simple look given to her, which is easy for me to resonate with a real hard working on duty female doctor. In most medical dramas, I don't remember seeing such details, like most female doctors will have full nicely done hair, full makeup on all the time on duty. But I love how they preferred real and subtlety in this show. Same for her wardrobe. Very real and genuine.nnNow lastly the plot, it'll keep you engaged for most of the show. Even though it's mostly predictable, especially for people who have watched enough shows and movies. But still it'll keep you hooked up, as they reveal one connection after another and connect the dots.nnI absolutely loved this show and would definitely recommend it.

Plotn"My Old Ass" is a bold and hilariously self-aware comedy that dives into the complexities of aging, self-reflection, and finding joy in unexpected moments. The movie follows the life of a quirky protagonist who, after a lifetime of putting others first, decides it's finally time to embrace their quirks and live unapologetically. Along the way, they encounter colorful characters, awkward situations, and heartfelt revelations that redefine their outlook on life.nnThis film is a charming mix of humor and heart, blending laugh-out-loud moments with touching reflections on aging and self-acceptance. The writing is sharp, with witty one-liners and an overarching message that life only gets better when you stop taking it too seriously.nnThe lead performance is outstanding, perfectly balancing comedic timing with moments of emotional depth. The supporting cast adds a layer of chaos and warmth, making the story feel both personal and universal.nn"My Old Ass" succeeds in delivering a poignant reminder that it's never too late to rewrite your narrative. The pacing occasionally lags, and a few jokes might miss the mark for some, but its overall charm keeps the audience engaged.

Throughly enjoyed watching this fast-paced historical fantasy show that feels unique to anything else I have watched within the historical fiction realm. Emily Bader is fantastic as Jane Grey and all the other character are extremely strong and extremely like able or hate able, especially Edward Bluemel as Guilford Dudley and Kate O'Flynn as Mary. If you are on the fence about watching give this show a chance I was hooked from episode one. I really hope Amazon gives this show another chance and reverses their decision to cancel it or My Lady Jane can be revived on another network or platform. I think this is story should continue to be told!

On the surface, this is a homecoming story, but there is another dimension present, hidden in the character Benji.nnDescendants (cousins) of a Jewish holocaust survivor (their Grandmother) visit Poland, joining a holocaust tour with other tourists, there for similar reasons.nnThe movie seems to be about this tour, through various historical landmarks in Poland, famous towns, the oldest cemetery, a concentration camp, etc.nnIt is a rather mundane backdrop, almost black and white, mostly still cinema, like walking through a photo album. The characters are also deliberately mediocre, middle class, retired, boring.nnBenji is the exception. As the movie gently rolls by it becomes clearer and clearer this movie is about him. His emotional reactions to the mundane and sometimes even grim backgrounds passing around him become the foreground of the story.nnHis presence becomes like the girl in the red dress from Schindler's List. A vivid point of dramatic focus in the gray world. Like the girl in the red dress we are instinctively prepared for something to happen, something to explain what we are seeing.nnIt becomes clear Benji is like an orphan in the world, extremely alone. We find out he lives in his mother's basement where he already tried to commit suicide when his grandmother (his closest friend) passed away.nnHis emotional state is that of a person saying goodbye, seeing things for the last time. Everything becomes important, the smallest details are belabored. Right up to the point where he says goodbye to his cousin.nnHis cousin goes back to his family and his job and his life in the City. Benji remains at the Airport, surrounded by people but poignantly alone. Like the girl in the red dress, discarded on a pile of faceless strangers.nnThe closing scene of Benji at the Airport is almost unbearably sad. He is there because he knows all that awaits him is a life of pain in a dark basement that is not a home, only adjacent to it.nnWe never find out he roots of his pain, just the symptoms - loneliness contrasted by manic social behavior. He is looking at the word through a barred window, unable to be at home in it.nnBut there is a feeling of impending dread, a gnawing worry about Benji's fate as we leave him homeless at the Airport. What will happen to Benji?

I like to watch animations occasionally and I had watched and enjoyed the previous Moana before watching this second installment. It's a nice animation franchise to watch with the family, having meaningful messages about family, friendships, self-confidence, love and respect for nature etc. Which can emotionally resonate with almost everyone, having a beautiful exotic scenery and telling of old legends of Hawaii. But...nMoana 2 lacked "a lot" as not having much of a story and a "good enough" musical quality. As it was like the same thing once again(?), with insignificant characters like the Bat Lady Matangi or the old farmer Keke and situations that looked like stretch for the feeling of an adventure like the monster clam thing...nUnfortunately most of the songs seemed weaker than the first. Honestly I liked the melody and the structure of the new Moana song "Beyond" however the lyrics were like "A. I. generated", sucking the the soul and meaning from the original "How Far I'll Go".nnThere weren't many memorable and well written songs in this one I must say. "Can I Get a Chee Hoo" was horrible... Just like "Get Lost" which was also quite irrelevant with the general tone, sounded more like an adult-related theme(?)... The singing and voice-acting performances were quite good though but without much meaning or emotion, they fell flat.nnThe artistic quality of the visuals were top-nocth as it is a Disney brand but Moana 2 didn't introduce anything new or appealing visually either. Knowing that it was planned for TV series earlier and turned into a theatrical release, I guess it was a little bit rushed and not well-prepared for the movie theatre screening. The story about Moana becoming a demi-goddess could have been told much better if the creative team had given more time to finesse their work.nnMoana 2 has a very predictable ending as expected but it also does not evoke such strong emotions, well because Moana doesn't do anything that she hasn't done before (sail, swim, sing and drown) literally (!). She definitely goes beyond but how and why she comes back is a mystery... "because it's her destiny so shut up!", one would say I presume.nnThe message was confusing either: "Risky your life for your impossible dreams, dont worry, even if you die, you will be rewarded / resurrected...?" Doesn't it feel dangerous to anyone?...nAnyway, children will still enjoy Moana 2 because of the theme of sisterhood, funny and awkward situations, Moana's pets, the Kakamoras etc. But it's very unlikely that children will enjoy the songs in this one better than the first... Final words for Moana 2 is that it could have been much better with a meaningful epic adventure. And I hope they don't make a third.

Book title: The Call of the WildnnFunny enough, Jack London books and their movie adaptations are usually adjusted to children's versions, although the originals are quite vicious. Not a Disney movie but still got disneyed, which is not a bad thing per se; I didn't want to see the violent acts in full color.nnAdaptationn- General story: Loyal.nn- Small aspects: Almost all the book's events are present but are considerably less brutal.nnActing: All actors did a really good job. Their effort is exhibited and much appreciated.nn- Best portrayal: John Thornton. Somehow Harrison Ford always delivers. Maybe this character was natural to his actual age but still, he infuses the film with true emotions.nn- Not the best portrayal: Buck. Maybe it is for the best not to use any more real animals as actors anymore, understandable. The CGI is decent, but it breaks the atmosphere, and above all the dog does not look like a St. Bernard. This aspect alone ruins the story. They should have digitalized a real one or put a little more effort into its appearance.nnMusic and Score: Adequate. It's not spectacular but it contributes to the atmosphere.nnCinematography: The film sets are pretty obvious but can't say they look bad.nnEditing: Excellent pace. Not an easy task to have an animal as the protagonist, but this film nails it.nnFinal decision: Respectable adaptation and extraordinary PG movie. A child movie but not stingy in any way. Any adult can enjoy it.nnWinner: Book by unanimous decision, nonetheless it was a fair fight.

There's almost nothing about this that I enjoyed. The cinematography is well done, the actors did well with what they were given, but that's where it ends.nnI don't know whose reality or even fantasy this plays out. It's just sadism porn centred around a horrible musician who has no idea how to have normal human interactions, and a kid who wants to be the greatest in spite of absolutely no one telling him he can or should be.nnThe subtleties of the drumming tempo are only noticeable to a trained ear, which I don't know maybe trained drummers get a kick out of guessing if it's right or wrong? Because I sure didn't. Fletcher's teaching techniques wouldn't even suit the military let alone a stage band. He provides absolutely no proper feedback and doesn't build up anyone's confidence. The entire time I was waiting for his character arc to find an "aha" moment where he suddenly makes the student realise his potential and shows him that he respects him, but there was none of that. It's just a movie about a guy we're supposed to hate and a kid we have no reason to believe in.nnNot only is he so unlikable that we can't find a reason to respect his methods, but his character gets fired for his prolific bullying. So then what, we're supposed to feel sorry for him that he's a hardass who people didn't understand?nnNo, he's just a bad person.nnHe then goes on to tell the kid that he needs a drummer for a show coming up, and he needs someone who "really knows the parts". After we just watched him talk trash about him the entire movie so far telling him he's a terrible drummer? Nothing about his backstory commands the respect required to give us a reason to believe this change of heart. If any person treated you this way and then asked you to play in their band you'd tell them to get stuffed.nnWhich culminates in a moment of terror inducing confrontation right as they're about to play on stage that Fletcher knew the kid was the reason he was fired, because he was the one who spoke out at the behest of his father. The entire show Fletcher gives him the eyes just to further terrorise him. For what? To what end? He's a proud guy, he knows a band member screwing up on stage only makes him look worse. I'm left astounded and confused as to the entire reason this all happens. The kid walks off.nnBut no, he has to show him he's the best so he goes back out and plays. Taking over the show without Fletcher's conduction.nnAgain, for a guy we have no reason to believe is the musical great he claims to be.nnThen they suddenly just decide to respect each other right there on stage over the love of music, even though one of them starts the show with psychological warfare and the other tries to prove a point with an upstaging performance that in real life as an audience member I I can only imagine I'd be cringing out of my seat.nnNot to mention how pissed the rest of the band would be at a ring-in suddenly calling the shots on the kit.nnIt's nonsense.nnThis movie made me feel emotions, but none of them were good. There was no moment of realisation or proper conclusion. It just ends with utter confusion.nnI'm left bewildered why so many people rate this with a perfect 10/10, to the point that this sits firmly in the top 250 without budging. I would have been content never knowing this movie existed if it didn't sit so highly in the ratings.

Jett Klyne plays "Max" a 12 year old boy who manages to escape a Nazi loading operation that takes his mother (Katherine Fogler (Faigie) and little sister off to be executed and mass buried in their hometown in Poland. He doesn't realize that until much later. He manages to find his way to a farm for awhile then out to the forest where he manages to survive off mushrooms, fish, berries and the occasional rabbit all the while doing his best to avoid Nazi colluders who are all searching for hidden Jews to get the reward. (Goes to show the depravity of mankind during this historic period) Nothing questionable, no violence but it is implied, no nudity. Lots of murder and dead bodies lying about rotting. It amazes me that this kind of thing is still going on now. Hopefully soon this will all stop for good. A fine watch and historical as well, the last bit has a piece with Max today visiting those who survived with him. Enjoy!

The movie resonated well with the struggle of those confused by their own feelings. It brilliantly captures the complexity and nuances of fluidity. Furthermore it have come to my attention, every subtle details, music, and cinematography that conveys the deepest message of today's world problem, that everyone doesn't have to conform to a label in order to be normal. In Nate father's word: focus on what you love and go from that point. I share the same feelings for Nate, for questioning the sexuality of oneselves is still considered weird in some parts of the world. It was one of many films that made me cry.

I put off seeing this for a pretty good while because of some apparently unusually-sensitive IMDB reviewers complaining about how explicit it is and even referring to it as p**n. Others complained about the language.nnFolks, I'm pretty conservative in my personal life, but one thing I do understand and value is the need for storytellers to be able to reflect certain fundamental realities of life in unashamed ways.nnDid you know that underneath our clothes all of us have naked bodies? It's true. Naked bodies are a real thing in real life. Some of you out there seem to be in denial about this, or to equate nakedness with only you-know-what. Boy, I bet you're all a party to walk around a sculpture garden with.nnThere is nothing sexually explicit in this film. Your ability to watch it and enjoy it without getting all uncomfortable and feeling a need to cleanse your conscience with a review here on IMDB will depend entirely on maturity.nnTo tell this particular story - which is outstanding by the way, and deals with real issues involving the real human condition, particularly from a female perspective in certain industries, but for men in certain industries also - everything that made it into the final cut of this film is necessary. That means the nudity, the cussing, the everything. Take those things out, the story loses all weight and significance. Furthermore, this is a story that can ONLY be told with these very specific types of characters - otherwise, again, it loses all weight and significance.nnEven Dennis Quaid's character - who many I'm sure will find abrasive, off putting, and frankly, disgusting - perfectly reflects real people walking around out there in the real world who truly are of this type! His character really does exist out here in the real world. Quaid plays the character to perfection to create just the right amount of nausea.nnHonestly, the artistic skill that went into just about every decision involved with this movie is impressive - from the opening shot and throughout. The pacing is amazing, the camera work is amazing, the actors are amazing, the story is amazing, the details in how the whole fictional premise for this story works is well thought out and amazing.nnYes, Demi Moore deserves every bit of praise she is getting right now for her part in this. What a bold (and brave) decision. A better actress could not have been cast here considering the stage of life she's in, and her career. The fact that she's so well known, and so many of us have followed her life and have watched her aging in the real world compliments and gives weight to the fictional character in the mind of the audience.nnWill absolutely be remembered as one of the best movies of the year.

My expectations were low after watching the trailer, as it looked really dull (idc what other fans say the trailer sucked), and especially after just finishing the disgraceful canon-breaking show the Acolyte. Therefore, this show seemed like it was gonna be absolutely awful. However, because I am a MAJOR fan of SW, I still decided to give the show a shot hoping to be wrong. After reaching the halfway mark, here is what I have found:n1) Better than the Acolyte, but tbh thats not even hard to do as the Acolyte is simply the WORST. I'd say this show is slightly better than BoBF and slightly worse than Obi-Wan.nn2) Episodes 1 and 2 are the only interesting episodes I've encountered so far. Episode 3 was meh and episode 4 was stupid.nn3) There is no sense of mystery, adventure, and there is only slight action. No detailed plot or anything. Story is very boring and the whole plot behind the show is very bland, but maybe the last two episodes will prove me wrong (unlikely though)n4) This show is apparently a part of Filoni's Mandoverse, which is supposedly Disney's last hope for making good SW contentnOkay I get it everyone, this show is supposed to be for children but that doesn't mean it has to be boring for older audiences. Take Rebels for instance, which is very much a kids show but it is still fun to watch when your older also.nnIdk, it just really seems to me that disney puts a lack of effort into anything they come up with now. It is very depressing, seeing my favorite franchise of all time die. The last hope for star wars is Andor season 2. If that flops, than star wars might be officially dead. Also, if Andor season 2 flops than Kathleen Kennedy had better get fired along with Bob Iger etc.nnThis Show: 5/10nFuture of SW: Very Uncertain.

In the 1970s child abuse was a taboo subject. No level of abuse by parents or schools was deemed excessive. Indeed, only 3 years after this film was made, the US Supreme Court ruled that it was perfectly acceptable to beat a child with the equivalent of a baseball bat to the point of requiring medical treatment and 3 days of bed rest. That boy was about the same age as character Paul Harris in this teleplay. Many people have complained the plot is too transparent but I was fooled on first viewing and enjoyed the twists. Malden gets to show his softer side in this episode while Douglas gets to show his indigation over pursing terrified child. But the screenwriter missed an opportunity to show the real terror of a child who feels abandoned by everyone in his life. But perhaps that was just too strong for the broadcast standards of the time. Unfortunately, David Gruner, who was 17 at the time of filming, isn't convincing as a 13-year-old, but that's a minor complaint. Marietta Hartley took a break from selling Polaroid cameras to guest star in this episode. Her performance is a bit uneven but that may be due to the script or direction. We should have more foreshadowing of how her character is resolved. Marge Redmond, who plays the foster mother, always raises the bar in these cameo roles. There are a couple of problems with the logic in the script. For one thing, a child who shows visible abuse should have been immediately removed from the home. And I rather doubt foster children can be adopted the first week they're in their new home. Well, maybe Lt. Mike Stone pulled a few strings downtown?

I recommend the film for lovers of criminal thrillers, investigations and realistic heroes (they try to get closer to reality),n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------nThe Batman tells the story of our beloved Batman in an extremely immersive and "down to earth" (realistic) way, with a wonderful villain (enigma), Batman (Bruce) in a terrible mental state, wonderful Gotham, Incredible soundtrack, Batman Acting as a detective throughout the film, the only negative point in my opinion is that Alfred has very little participation. 3 hours of film that goes by quickly.nn10/10.

Short, interesting shows with interviews of psychopaths. Professionals offer their perspectives of the behavior of the killer during their interviews, typically soon after the crime.nnAnd then, season 7 hits and, of course, there are two episodes with transgender individuals. Whatever. HOWEVER. The professionals use the preferred pronouns of these individuals which is ridiculous. You are DOCTORS and know that he is not a she and shame on you for supporting that. The second that you did that, you lost all credibility. Bring in real doctors, real professionals that live in reality. You are part of the problem.

"When Gotham is ashes, you have my permission to die."nnThe Dark Knight Rises will forever be known as one of the greatest finale's in film history. Up there with Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter. Here is my review for the final Christopher Nolan, Batman installment.nnActing: I'm gonna start with Tom Hardy as Bane. For me, he was the highlight of the entire movie. He had a very strong pressence and unlike the typical cliche villains, Bane was actually a frightening in the film. He couldn't use his face to express emotion because of the mask but Tom's performance was so brillaint I was legit terrified of this man, and I haven't been scared of anything in a movie since I was eight! Now, Anne Hathaway also blew me away. I liked her as an actress but I really couldn't see her as Catwoman. The previews with her in it just wasn't impressing me and convincing me that she is Selina Kyle. I was proven wrong. She was absolutely AMAZING as the character. I personally still prefer Michelle Pfeiffer as Catwoman but Anne is close second. Joseph Gordon Levitt, I didn't expect nothing less from him. I've always liked Joseph Gordon Levitt ever since I saw him in G. I Joe (I actually liked that movie and felt he was a highlight) and him playing John Blake was great.nnChristian Bale gave probably his best performance in any film he's done. He was just great as a broken Bruce Wayne. Michael Caine, I felt was a little weak in this movie. When he cried both times in the movie, I just wasn't buying it. I don't mean I didn't like him in it, I just don't think he was better in this than the others. Marrion Cotillard, I have never liked her. She was weak in Inception and I think she was slightly better in this film. I did like the twist involving her though. Morgan Freeman was good as always, I mean he is Morgan Freeman. He isn't a bad actor. But, this trilogy didn't showcase his acting abilities a whole light. Although, I felt he was the heart of the entire trilogy.nnWriting: I felt the writing was also the best out of the entire trilogy. It had me on the edge of my seat literally in every exciting part of the film. It wasn't as clever as The Dark Knight but it definitely does what a movie like this is suppose to do.nnDirection: Christopher Nolan, his vision for the Batman franchise not only brought new life in the franchise but also showed that not all comicbook movies and characters are as light hearted and fun as a character like Spider-Man. This film IS his masterpiece. Anyone (in my opinion) who feels that The Dark Knight is his masterpiece, especially talking the trilogy alone is probably still mezmerised (sorry if I spelled that wrong) by Heath Ledger's Joker, believe me I am too.nnEditing: The editing is wonderful in this film. It keeps the story flowing as it should. No confusing fights, nothing dragging.nnFight Choreography: The fight choreography is great. The fights in Batman Begins were a little weak and there was hardly any fighting in The Dark Knight. The fights that were there were hardly better than Batman Begins. I think the fighting here is brutal as it should be, on the edge of your seat, scary fighting. Especially the first encounter between Batman and Bane. *spoiler for those who have yet to see it* I was actually a little bit surprised when Bane broke the bat. Believe me, deep inside I was all excited but at the same time I was in shock and a little saddened for Batman. *spoiler end*nnEnd results: The Dark Knight Rises is without doubt, the best of the trilogy and perfectly ends what I feel is the greatest trilogy I have ever seen. Powerfuly performances, strong script and a director who knows what he is doing. The Dark Knight Rises left me with happiness in my heart in the end despite my fear through out the movie. I feel this is like The Avengers, in the sense that this is a MUST SEE in the theater. I am awarding The Dark Knight Rises a 10/10nnP.s: The bank heist/chase was my favorite scene in the entire movie. Watch for my review of The Amazing Spider-Man later in the week. Comment below and be respectful.

This review is for the English dubbed version from 2000.nnThe Bondage Master is an expert with rope. He uses his skills both for photo shoots and live performances at an S&M club. He saves a woman who was being attacked and learns she is searching for her sister who has been working as bondage model. He agrees to help search.nnThis is a modern Pink Eiga. There is limited nudity. There are some sex scenes. And there is a lot of bondage along with limited discipline. S&M is a definite theme for this film. The Bondage and S&M elements were handled without being truly mean or degrading. In fact at times it was with a slight sense of humor and always with being consensual.nnThis is one story with several sub-stories tied in. This kept the entire film interesting. A bit of crime drama, drama with some comedy. The characters are very interesting too.nnThe biggest problem is with the English dubbing. I will need to see the original Japanese version but I didn't like some of the English voices & performances. Most sound like what you'd hear in a bad B movie from the 1980's. Played way over the top for comic relief. One character is the single totally stupid character often in B movies. He ruined almost every scene he was in.nnThis had the potential to be a truly excellent movie. A couple of abrupt scene changes that I had to rewind to understand. Plus that one stupid character that needn't been written that way. Still this was actually an entertaining movie.

I am only just over half way through the film and therefore I may be writing this review a might early. Just once, I wish a filmmaker had the balls to write a movie based on the truth. "Heretics", or nonbelievers, don't spread hate or violence... That would be the "People of faith" that are responsible for every war, genocide, colonization, witch trials, burning of scientists, the Dark Ages, slavery, and even one Holocaust (Yes, that was Straight White X-tian Nationalists)... If there is a surprise twist ending then I will update my review but so far I am disappointed. Hugh Grant is good though ...

I liked this show because it's interesting, but truth is, it's not a very satisfying program. Great acting, of course, it's got great actors. The story is entirely intriguing and for the most part keeps you hooked in the 'what's gonna happen next?' loop because it does move at a nice pace. With 7 episodes it's not too long of a series and allows for each section of the story to have it's full time up front.nnBut none of the characters are likable. Seriously. They're all pretty self-absorbed, shallow people. I know lots of real folks are like that but basically 6 out of 10 people will have SOME kind of redeeming quality in their personality. The only character I got happy seeing was the cat. He's a cat so he always makes me go AWEEE...but everyone else, it's pretty hard to really care if things go right for them. Even in the scenes of her in her office, her co-workers weren't overly good folks either. Was it in the water? They seemed shallow, fake, even the lines stated were about how the Jr editing assistant (or whatever) was only being how she was (faking sincerity) to get something out of the bad guy to one-up Cate Blanchette's character. I mean, if even the lines are serving up this thought because it's how they are then....nnBut then the last episode reminds you that in a way it's always BEEN a set up. When we finally are getting the truth of what happened that day and night of the original interaction before he drowned (he raped her..for hours) we're made to understand that, now that we know, we're supposed to feel horror and sympathy for her. Gee, don't we feel bad we kinda despise her?nnAnd no, I couldn't. Why? Because logically speaking she could have prevented the ENTIRE drama by coming out with her truth in the beginning. Her son wouldn't have been victimized, almost dead then. Her husband wouldn't have had to realize his wife was a liar, which she STILL was even after she told him she was raped instead. By letting him think the worst, she set him up to LOOK bad in his anger at her. She set him up with that! What was he SUPPOSED to do?nnThen after the truth came out, she decided she couldn't forgive him for being angry at her for a fake affair because as soon as he knew it was actually a rape he had different feelings and reactions? How DARE she!nnHe wasn't happy she had an affair because that is about CHOICE! Of course he won't like it. Might even want to punish her for it.nnRAPE is a whole different reaction ballpark. But she took that AWAY from him! Because SHE didn't want him to have to deal with it in the beginning, then decided she didn't like how he reacted once he knew the truth?nnYah..I still don't like HER. But him, the husband? I'm coming around on.nnInteresting show because it brings out some very interesting points, obviously. For me, tell the truth or deal with the consequences.

'Apostle' follows a man who is on a mission to rescue his sister, who has been captured by a sect demanding ransom over its declining society. It is learned that the community lives on a separate island offshore England, after the founding fathers fled from the mainland fearing persecution by the King.nnAs time goes by, the community grows larger, welcoming immigrants who have a special ticket to enter Eridens. All people who board this settlement must devote themselves, including offering their blood to the Queen of the land.nnThomas's journey as the protagonist is far from easy, as he must blend in with the community's customs and practices, essentially becoming a new resident. Thanks to the King's envoy, who is instructed to assassinate the cult leader, Prophet Malcolm, Thomas accidentally gains Malcolm's respect by stopping the envoy's attempt, even though he injures him in the process.nnThe plot progresses slowly, digging deeper and deeper into the island's darkest secret until Thomas eventually discovers the Queen, who had kept the island fertile in the past but is now in a dying state. The Queen is embedded with the plantation's tendrils creeping inside her body. She is covered with roots and in an almost vegetative state, consuming only blood as the source of the island's fertility.nnHowever, while the plot is well-written, I feel the movie is somewhat flat and bland. Despite the revelation of the gory Queen, the atmosphere the creators aimed to convey does not reach the audience well. The fact that Malcolm is slowly losing his popularity, adding to the 'spiraling' effect of the movie, does not help much in creating a dreadful atmosphere. The lack of 'uncanny' acting may be a factor in this result. If such acting were executed correctly, it would be a decisive element in this film to evoke a terrifying feeling. I always compare one film to another in my IMDB reviews, so putting this work alongside some of A24's pictures is not over the top.nnA24, with the likes of Midsommar and The Killing of a Sacred Deer, has been successful in delivering an uneasy feeling to spectators. The cast is instructed to show flat emotions, making us wonder what the characters actually feel. The unfolding mystery before our eyes ultimately provides an eerie feeling, which is vital to such a work.nnOverall, Apostle displays some solid performances with a few flaws. I would recommend this film if someone asked me: "What is a well-written cult-themed movie I can ENJOY?"

My wife and I were excited to watch this, as it came up on a "definite noir to see" list.nnBoy, were we bamboozled.nnWe were extremely sorry to have wasted our time to watch this turkey. As other reviews have stated, it was far too long, with far too many plot holes. Besides the fact that Joan is far too old to pull off the role she is in. Jack Palance, in one of his earlier roles, looks almost TOO wooden -- and his acting certainly is. Gloria Grahame doesn't come out of this unscathed. Although she attempts her chops as the femme fatale, you can't buy it, because she looks like a duck.nnNot to try to spoil it (as it is already horrible, not too much chance of that) -- but she has ample opportunities to bring someone else in to quash the baddies plot. WAY too many chances. Yet she followed her ridiculously inept plan to it's anticlimactic -- and extremely disappointing finish.nnDo yourself a favor and AVOID this. Even Joan Crawford fans would cringe at this one. Worse, it might even "de-fan" you. Real talk. You have been warned.
