column3: Volshebnik Izumrudnogo goroda. Doroga iz zhyoltogo kirpicha (2025)
column4: "The Wizard of the Emerald City" (2025): A Disappointing Journey into FantasynThe film The Wizard of the Emerald City, which premiered in January 2025, sparked a wave of discontent among viewers. Expectations were high for this ambitious project, supported by the Russian Cinema Fund, but reality fell short, leaving audiences disappointed. Let's analyze what went wrong.nnBudget and ExecutionnOne of the primary complaints from viewers is the film's visual component. Despite claims of a significant budget, the movie's graphics feel outdated and fail to meet modern standards. At times, the special effects resemble those seen in early 2000s films, when visual effects technology was still in its infancy.nnPlot StructurenThe script feels fragmented and underdeveloped. The narrative unfolds superficially, lacking deep character development or emotional engagement. The most glaring issue is that the film ends halfway through the story, leaving audiences without a complete narrative arc. This abrupt cutoff is especially frustrating for viewers expecting a cohesive story.nnNegative Role Model for Children: The Case of EllienThe portrayal of the main character, Ellie, deserves special attention. Instead of showcasing her as a strong and determined figure growing through her journey, the film presents her as a capricious and self-centered girl overly reliant on others' help. This approach risks promoting a negative behavioral model, especially for young viewers who might look to Ellie as a role model.nnEllie frequently acts like an immature character, seeking validation and direction from others rather than developing her own skills and decisions. Unlike the original story, where Ellie is portrayed as more independent and resolute, this adaptation undermines essential qualities such as self-reliance and responsibility.nnFurthermore, the film endorses a troubling pattern of behavior in which betraying friends remains unpunished if it serves Ellie's goals. She makes choices that undermine trust and violate moral principles, but these actions are ultimately forgiven with mere weak apologies. This sends a dangerous message: that betraying trust and prioritizing personal goals over friendships carries no serious consequences. For a young audience, this is a deeply concerning takeaway.nnUnexpected Ending and Marketing MisstepsnOne of the most contentious aspects is the lack of prior disclosure that the film is only the first part of a larger story. The abrupt plot cutoff provoked widespread discontent since viewers were not informed about this format. Advertising materials and the film's description led audiences to expect a complete, standalone work, which some see as misleading.nnEthical and Legal ConcernsnFrom a legal perspective, the creators' actions could be interpreted as a violation of consumer rights. Russian law requires full and accurate disclosure of product or service information. If the omission of the film's sequel was intentional, it could be classified as unfair practice.nnPositive AspectsnIt is worth noting that the film does have some strengths. The musical score effectively enhances the atmosphere, and certain visual elements are commendable. Additionally, despite its flaws, the project managed to draw attention to Russian cinema-albeit with a negative undertone.nnConclusionnThe Wizard of the Emerald City turned out to be a disappointing project that failed to meet audience expectations despite significant investments. Outdated visuals, inefficient budget use, an underwhelming script, and the lack of transparency regarding its format as "part one" all contribute to the overall sense of frustration. Negative elements, such as poor character portrayal and the promotion of selfish behavior, further exacerbate the film's shortcomings. The movie leaves viewers with a sense of incompleteness, and unless the creators address these issues moving forward, the project risks not only failure but also losing the audience's trust.

IMO, Black Mass is a great crime docu-drama/biopic that's tense, thrilling and holds your attention to the end. This was a great, quality movie and one I enjoyed beginning to end--including the credits! Johnny Depp was outstanding as James 'Whitey' Bulger, and maybe one of his best acting performances of his career-- the other actors Joel Edgerton, Benedict Cumberbatch, Kevin Bacon and Corey Still did a superb job as well. Also, Scott Cooper did an amazing job directing this film.nnBottomline, Black Mass has all the elements you need in a crime thriller including his childhood friend turned FBI agent James Connolly (Joel Edgerton) who ended-up in jail for his FBI role protecting Whitey Bulger by diverting attention away from the FBI by getting Bulger's "informant information" on the Mafi.nnWell done.

I loved When Harry Met Sally growing up and now I have a queer version. This is instantly one of my favorite films. It makes me so happy. Especially as someone who hates holidays, but am cool with others loving them, and they are so cute.nnI bought the film on tellofilms to support a queer platform :) I'm so glad I came across it! It's so well made too, definitely has rewatchability value. I immediately told my friends about it and added it to my movie recommendation spreadsheet.nnKudos to Alexandra and all involved. This is such a beautiful sapphic love story and so so relatable! I hate the holidays (but will watch this film over and over and enjoy every minute!) I sense a new holiday tradition. Maybe i'll start my own Holiday Club!

The first two seasons were by far the most watchable and what the show should have stayed like. Some episodes were boring but some were good and entertaining.nnAround season 3 the show is still good but the amount of s3x scenes got ridiculous it might aswell be put in the p0rn genre.nnIn season 4 is where it started to go down hill and also where it started to become more "w0ke" which is the ultimate destroyer of most shows and movies.nnSeason 5 is just boring, w0ke and not entertaining. At this point I'm only half way through season 5 but I don't know if I want to watch 6. Either way I doubt my star rating or review would change having seen season 6 considering what others are saying.nnOverall the show looks great apart from some crappy CGI the few times it's used. Most of the characters are not that interesting apart from a couple which get killed off contributing to the show becoming more and more boring. The historical accuracy is very bad in the later seasons and there's only some moments here and there that make the show interesting but overall I do not recommend.nnThis show does not deserve to have such a high IMDB rating which I believe it only got due to the first 2 seasons. This show is one of a kind and had good potential but overall is a bit boring, repetitive and historically inaccurate.

I have to assume that plot holes were an intentional goal here. Becky introduces us to her super-religious foster parents... that are never part of the story or mentioned again. Proud Boys (Noble Men here) are planning a bit of terrorism but Becky shows up to get her dog back and so they go after her... one at a time. Guy #1 falls in a hole... and lets Becky put a hand grenade in his mouth, wrap him in duct tape, and tie the pin to the front door of the house. Banjo guy with years of experience in violence goes after Becky... panics immediately at the sight of a smoke canister, fires aimlessly, crawls out, and lays there waiting for her to kill him.nnAnd so on...

"Always stay with me darling. Never leave me. Please I need you I need you so much, please... Please find my belt!"n..... Ladies and gentlemen I present you a simi biopic of Woody Allen!!! Life imitates art!nn(NOTE: this is my first review ever, I don't have any experience in writing one, and English isn't my native, so i hope you'll be patient reading my long review, and many thanks).nnWe sometimes come across a rare film that it seems nobody have seen before, hoping it to be a gem, a buried treasure, that we can feel proud we're among the only few who came across such film.nnUnfortunately, this is not the case with this one. It seems nobody has seen this one, as both IMDb and Letterboxd shows no one has reviewed it or rated it yet.nnFor I, I had the pleasure (although it wasn't?!) to come across this very rare one!!! And I tell you this film is horrid and twisted.nnNow to the plot, you can read the first half in the plot description and up to this point, all is typical melodrama, nothing to write home about, man in love with woman, another woman friend of the man dies (in a very horrible way), she leaves a child behind, asking the man to take care of her, he pass himself as her father or adopt her, all the same.nnBut wait for the second half, where it will get messed up!nn(Spoiler ahead)nThe first half takes place around 1917/1918, at this point, Mitzi (the now adopted daughter) is 6 years old (as it's confirmed in the closing credits). Years jump to 1931! Mitzi now must be 18 or 19?! Why is it important to point that out?! Well, as I was afraid, the film went exactly the direction I was expecting, (with a little twist than usual?) (one would expect such a twist if he had seen Abel Gance's La Roue, Frank Borzage's Lazybones, and Lon Chaney's Laugh, Clown, Laugh)nFor now SHE IS IN LOVE WITH HER ADOPTING FATHER!!! When Michael Morda rejoins with his old flame, she gets extremely jealous of her "DADDY" (as she calls him!).nnShe confesses to Jerry (Charles Ruggles) about her emotions, and HE'S ALRIGHT WITH IT AND HAPPY ABOUT IT, not only that, HE TEACH HER SEX UP HERSELF FOR HER "DADDY" to notice her.nnShe then hints at Michael, he spanks her (on her rear of course), she runs crying, he tries to comfort her, she gives him a kiss on the mouth to give him a hint about her love, but when he senses it, he tries to put her away in another apartment... The separation won't last long.nnThey rejoin then, dance a little, they share A VERYYY LOOONG KISS (MORE THAN THE NOTORIOUS 3 SECONDS, I measured it, it was a whole 9 SECONDS, as far as I remember, it's the longest I seen for a pre-Code film, I'm not exaggerating, I tell you it's madness). Then he confesses to Jerry that he's MADLY IN LOVE WITH HER! Excuse meeee?!! She was literally a baby in your hand, you raised her since she was 6 and watched her grow up... I tell you it's creepy... it's messed up... It's f****d up!!!nnI mentioned that that was the case in many silent films I mentioned before, but at least the girlies didn't end up with the adopting father! While here, no, they reconcile at the end and share another long kiss, curtains down.nnPhew, that was pretty exhausting. As you have read the theme here was actually common in the that (and the silent) era, I can't really figure it out WHY?! Did the audience of the past really enjoyed such twisted stories?! It seems yes (Evidence is the contemporary reviews didn't mind it, photoplay called it pleasant and celebrated Michael "winning" Mitzi!, so did new york times) I that's the past, but today this film would be controversial and considered "ped*phelia", as it should be. (So was Woody Allen inspired by this film to have his notorious affair?! Life does imitate art!)nnIt is such a shame this rare film had such a frustrating theme, because it's told in style and talent, the cast are excellent, the directing is smooth, but those won't redeem the heinous affair.nnThe closing line of the film (I wrote it up first in this review) has traumatized me... It seems it will haunt me for a long time!

I rarely, if ever, write reviews, but I felt compelled to share my thoughts on this movie. It's disheartening to see the current state of film when a movie like this manages to secure a seven rating on IMDb. Frankly, that score feels far too generous. Everything about this film-from the plot to the performances-was painfully average and forgettable. The characters were so underdeveloped and lifeless that I couldn't bring myself to care about a single one of them, not even in the slightest. If you're considering watching this, I urge you to save your time and energy. Instead, revisit a true masterpiece like Heat-a film that delivers intensity, depth, and emotion. Watching Heat a hundred times over would still be a better use of your time than sitting through this uninspired mediocrity.

Dutch writer/director Halina Reijn's new feature 'Babygirl' is an exercise in boldness. The film is a fresh take on the age old story of self-discovery and self-destruction.nnIn the movie Nicole Kidman plays Romy, a highly successful CEO of a robotics company by day and sexual submissive by night. Despite having a picture-perfect home life with a loving husband and two daughters, Romy remains unseen and sexually unsatisfied until she meets an intern (Samuel) at her company who sees a side of her that's she's been hiding - her sexual identity.nnTwo older films come to mind when watching 'Babygirl' - Stanley Kubrick's 'Eyes Wide Shut' and Adrian Lyne's 'Unfaithful'. All three deal with infidelity and the razor's edge one walks when engaging in it. What stands out in 'Babygirl' is the feral, masochistic nature of Romy and Samuel's illicit encounters which leave Romy in equal parts exhilarated, scared, embarrassed and liberated.nnReijn's film presents an unvarnished view into shifting power differentials. The CEO has power over an intern just as much as a dom has power over a sub. Romy the titan gives in to the commands of Samuel the peon. Their initial encounters are awkward and uncomfortable both for them and the audience. It's like watching two porcupines mate. The fact that Romy is cheating on her husband, theater director Jacob (played admirably by Antonio Banderas) is intriguing, but what she needs for sexual fulfillment is even more so.nnThe performances are strong all around, but the film belongs to Kidman whose brilliant portrayal is both brave and vulnerable. At 57, Kidman is doing the best work of her career on TV and the big screen.nnReijn's direction is intimate, raw and unyielding. She pulls no punches and lets scenes breathe until they become difficult to watch. The cinematography is harsh and unfiltered, making the film feel more realistic. I did have a problem with the bombastic score which, at times, threatened to overwhelm the visuals.nnAll in all 'Babygirl' is a fascinatingly frank and thought-provoking exploration of human sexuality that also turns the tables on workplace sexual politics. Be prepared as this film earns its R rating, but it's well worth the watch.
