There was no need to change the original book story.nnEnough of the ideology blah blah blah.nnIt would have been a good movie otherwise.nnThe original story with the characters or beautifully drawn and the execution of the neighborhood is well implemented.nnThe introduction of ideology into the story is extremely forceful and disrespectful to the original intent of the writer in the book.nnThe acting is, otherwise, well done and the storyline between present and past feels clear as it builds our understanding of the main characters history and personal conflicts.nnThe conclusion is successful in transmitting a good life lesson.

I got really excited watching this movie because both the art direction and acting were incredible so I got really anxious to see the final scene where they are supposed to go kill Dracula (Count Orlok) but instead I was rewarded with a disgusting 30 minute sex scene of the woman getting bit and raped by Dracula who looks absolutely disgusting by the way.nnReally awful ending, I wish I did not give them my money despite how good the first part was. Why would you follow the book until the last scene? How is the director so narcisitic to think that he should change the final scene? It's disrespectful to the fans and the author of the book.nnSo much ruined potential, could've been the first good Dracula/Vampire movie of the 21st Century.

It took a season for Ncuti Gatwa and the writers to figure out The Doctor in his new guise, as it does every time we get a new Doctor. But I really enjoy this take on a lifelong favourite. We see a Doctor who shares his vigor and zest for life, who isn't afraid to shed a tear (okay, maybe a few less tears would be nice), and who shows he is smiling to hide the pain of a lost world.nnSpecial effects are getting better and better. I like and hate the new interior of the TARDIS control room, but it seems to suit the Doctor. I hope we keep this Doctor for several years to come, I felt Whittaker left too soon and would like to see someone stay with the role.

I hate movies where the antagonist gets the upper hand simply because the protagonist is an idiot. This is one such movie.nnClueless rich girl is the new girl at school and decides to cosplay being poor to "feel normal". Rich girl is shocked when she is mercilessly bullied. She even has a knife pulled on her ....WHAT? How is a student even able to have a knife at school? The daughter of rich girl's maid has decided to seize the opportunity to pretend to be said rich girl, her and her two followers proceed to be cartoonishly evil to rich girl. Early on, rich girl decides to confess (sans any proof) that she is the true heiress, of course nobody believes her. Rich girl later has plenty of opportunities to provide proof of her identity, but doesn't because....reasons.nnPlot was silly and full of holes (wouldn't teachers and administrators have both girls' full names?), sound was hollow in one scene, acting ranged from decent to cringey. The protagonist is bland, the antagonist is one- dimensional as are several of the supporting characters.nnEven though she is bullied, given detention repeatedly, accused of being a liar and a thief, rich girl keeps up the facade because it's so important to her to be a normal teen, even though most of what she goes through is not a normal teen experience. 3/10.

Watched> Sunday and Monday, 5th & 6th January, 2025 @ Edge Water Studios. Rated 4 * * * * Very Good < Cert. Would be 15 > This 4-part TV mini series on The ITV Channel. The only negative is with the commercial TV channel showing the advertising breaks, in each of the four episodes. The Positive for me, is the drama itself. PLAYING NICE, was well acted, especially from James Norton (also Executive Producer), Niamh Algar, James McArdle and Jessica Brown Findlay. Well written by Grace Ofori-Attah and based on the book by J. P. Delaney (also Ex Producer) and well directed by Kate Hewill. Which is good to see more female directors getting involved, as they usually do great directing. A great example of that is Kathryn Bigelow, who directed the award winning for director, The Hurt Locker. Throughout this hard gripping drama about two pairs of parents getting each others baby mixed up at the births by mistake. Apart from death or serious illness, this must be a parents worst ever nightmare. The drama keeps you on edge, wondering what is going to happen next, what next can go wrong for one of the parents, how are we going to get through this, all the time, they are thinking why is this happening to us, are we going to be strong for each other? And how can we keep calm throughout this nightmare which seems to be getting worse, instead of getting better. All of this is going through the parents mind, which is also a continuation of upset, worry and trauma. HOW ON EARTH, IS THIS GOING TO BE SORTED OUT BETWEEN THESE TWO FAMILIES? AND TO WHAT CONCLUSION!! (ps)

The second major film made by the director Steve McQueen is one of the best films made in the 2010's, that is greatly underrated.nnThe movie follows a relatively successful businessman named Brandon living in New York, who harbours a dark and shameful addiction. Brandon, played by Michael Fassbender, is addicted to sex. He constantly needs to satisfy his need to orgasm, he hires prostitutes, picks up random women on bars or on the street, and when he's unsuccessful or isn't able to do that, he masturbates watching pornography or using his imagination. His addiction is so intense that he can't control it even while working, his mind wonders off when he sees an attractive coworker, constantly picturing having sex with them, he watches pornography in his shared office, even having his computer confiscated because he caught a virus downloading enormous quantities of porn, and to top all of that, he uses the office bathroom to masturbate.nnBrandon's shameful secret is surfacing and impacting his life, and he knows it's a matter of time until it brings him down. In the beginning of the film, Brandon stares down a beautiful woman on the train who seems interested and eye-flirts back. She then gets visibly uncomfortable and gets up showing her wedding ring, clearly feeling ashamed for engaging with another man that way, thus leaving the train in a hurry. Brandon follows her and loses her on the train station. He gets bothered because his lustful quest to fulfil his needs must continue.nnWhile his condition worsens, Brandon's sister Sissy shows up at his apartment, played by Carey Mulligan, the only person close to him, someone he constantly pushes away because he is incapable of having any other type of intimacy with people. Their relationship is truly dysfunctional, both having severe social and phycological problems in their own way. While Brandon managed to organize his life and having some financial success, Sissy doesn't have a home, money or a stable job. Sissy, while also having problems with relationships, is the antithesis of her brother, him being completely apathetic and Sissy needing a lot of emotional reassurance and support, clearly on the verge of a breakdown and dealing with a lot of loneliness. Brandon shut his emotions down completely, and Sissy is a slave to hers.nnWith his sister now living in his apartment, Brandon has another obstacle, not having the privacy to do what he needs to do, leading him to spiral downwards at a faster pace and to search for orgasms more destructively. Sissy has sex with Brandon's boss, a married man, she then proceeds to get attached to the point that she calls and texts him, showing how easily Sissy also has sex with other people, but differently to Brandon. She gets a look at his brother hidden facete, accidentally entering the bathroom while he¬¥s masturbating and finding a cam girl website active on his computer. This leads him to try to take some initiative and get rid of his porn and sex toys collection.nnAfter a fight with his sister and Brandon showing his resentment towards her, he goes out. This is the most uncontrollable we've seen him, actively looking to cause problems and is in complete shackles to his addiction. Sissy calls Brandon all night pleading for him to return home, but he doesn't care. Brandon goes lower than he's ever been, having sex with multiple women and being so desperate that he even has oral sex with a man in a shady club. While he is on this rampage, we can hear the voice messages left by his sister, and that's when she says a vague sentence that completely explains them both without giving any type of concrete information on why that is, "We're not bad people, we just come from a bad place".nnAfter a night of a sex binge, Brandon returns home when his train is evacuated due to a police investigation. This triggers something in him, suddenly remembering his sister who has a history of self-harm, and rushes home. He gets there only to find that Sissy had tried to end her life.nnThis is when we see Brandon's shame to its max. His addiction almost cost his sister's life, causing him to break down and recognizing how broken and troubled he truly is. The movie ends with Brandon returning home and meeting the same woman he saw on the metro in the beginning of the film, eying him down. This time we don't see lust in Brandon's eyes, we see shame.nnMichael Fassbender and Carey Mulligan gave an outstanding performance, giving these two characters their all. Steve McQueen's crude and uncensored approach took this film to its full potential, not being afraid to show nudity. This plus Fassbender's performance allowed the audience to delve into Brandon's psyche, see what was going on in his mind every minute of the day and while engaging in sexual intercourse/activities, and truly put us in his shoes. We can feel his anhedonia and lack of emotion, his inability to have a connection to other human beings. We can also feel how uncomfortable he felt around his sister and understand why he pushed her away even though she was the only person he truly cared for.nnHarry's Escott soundtrack emphasized Brandon's Spiral, the calm but unsettling track "Brandon" gradually strengthens dramatically, with a ticking noise always playing, hinting to his urge to orgasm gradually getting bigger. The track also gives off a feeling of "impending doom", something Brandon must've been feeling with his masquerade falling apart and his problem surfacing. When the track reaches its peak, it comes down in a similar pattern to the previous part, being slower but still dramatic. The track is constructed like Sisyphus curse, he pushes the boulder up the side of the mountain towards the peak, expecting and end, but the boulder falls of the other side and the cycle endures, exactly like Brandon's sex addiction. It¬¥s never ending and it only gets worse.

Few films in recent memory have left audiences as bewildered and disappointed as Nosferatu (2024). Billed as a bold reimagining of the classic 1922 horror masterpiece, the movie instead descends into a mire of poor creative choices, lackluster performances, and an utter disregard for its source material's legacy. While remakes often tread a fine line between homage and innovation, this film tragically fails to honor either, making it, in my opinion, one of the worst cinematic experiences in recent history.nnA Directionless VisionnnThe first glaring flaw lies in the film's direction. Helmed by a director who seemed more interested in imposing their artistic pretensions than crafting a coherent story, Nosferatu (2024) meanders without purpose. Gone is the haunting atmosphere of F. W. Murnau's silent original or even the eerie gravitas of Werner Herzog's 1979 reinterpretation. Instead, we are subjected to a visually incoherent and tonally inconsistent film that doesn't know whether it wants to be a psychological drama, a gothic horror, or a satirical commentary on modern anxieties. This indecisiveness creates a jarring viewing experience, leaving the audience more confused than captivated.nnSubpar PerformancesnnMuch of the blame for the film's failure must also be attributed to its cast. The titular Nosferatu, played by a prominent actor known for their roles in arthouse cinema, delivers a performance that is neither menacing nor tragic. Instead, the character feels like a caricature, devoid of the mystique or menace that made Max Schreck's original portrayal iconic. The supporting cast fares no better, with performances ranging from wooden to over-the-top. The lack of chemistry between the leads only compounds the problem, undermining any emotional stakes the film tries to establish.nnA Script That Betrays Its RootsnnThe screenplay is arguably the film's weakest element. Instead of crafting a compelling narrative, the script opts for a disjointed structure filled with pretentious dialogue and unnecessary subplots. The decision to modernize the story results in a loss of the timeless quality that defined the original. Moreover, the attempts at social commentary-whether on capitalism, technology, or the environment-feel ham-fisted and out of place, detracting from the core horror narrative. By trying to do too much, the script accomplishes nothing, leaving audiences alienated and uninvested.nnA Visual and Auditory MisfirennIf there's one aspect of Nosferatu that should have been its saving grace, it's the visual presentation. Unfortunately, the cinematography is a chaotic mess. The excessive use of CGI robs the film of any authentic atmosphere, making the gothic settings feel artificial and lifeless. The over-reliance on dim lighting and shaky camera work further detracts from the viewing experience, often making scenes difficult to follow.nnThe soundtrack, too, is a major disappointment. While the original Nosferatu used silence and an evocative score to heighten tension, this remake bombards viewers with a jarring mix of discordant orchestral pieces and inappropriate modern tracks. The result is a film that is not only visually unappealing but aurally grating as well.nnA Disservice to HorrornnPerhaps the most unforgivable sin of Nosferatu (2024) is its failure to be frightening. The original Nosferatu is remembered not just for its innovative filmmaking but for its ability to instill genuine dread. By contrast, this remake relies on cheap jump scares and predictable horror tropes, failing to create any sense of suspense or unease. The lack of originality in its scares makes it feel like a generic horror movie dressed in gothic trappings rather than a worthy successor to a genre-defining classic.nnConclusionnnIn its ambition to reinvent a cinematic legend, Nosferatu (2024) manages to accomplish the opposite: it diminishes its source material while failing to stand on its own merits. From its muddled direction and uninspired performances to its lackluster script and shoddy production values, every element of this film feels like a missed opportunity. While remakes always carry the risk of falling short of their predecessors, this film's failure is particularly egregious, given the rich material it had to draw from. For those seeking a memorable horror experience, Nosferatu (2024) is best avoided. Instead, revisit the classics that remind us why this tale of terror has endured for over a century.

Being Dutch, like the director Halina, I was very sceptical. A lot of movies coming from Dutch directors revolve around sex and often portrayed in a very explicit manner that doesn't always help the story.nnBabygirl is different. It is provocative and explicit, in a good way because it actually serves the storyline. There is a suspense to it, platfullness and eroticism that is quite unique for contemporary movies. It dares to be uncomfortable and challenge your beliefs on relationships, sex, power dynamics.nnI read a lot of people having a hard time with the fact that both characters don't have to face a lot of consequences from their 'bad' behaviour. I see this differently. At the end of the day they are both grownups and the movie is not about exploring the me-too theme at all, it is not ment to be moralistic and judge these characters. It's about exploring female desire.nnAnd I have to say both lead actors give stellar performances. That also helps!nnGood job Halina!

This is such a great documentary. Despite being queer I've never really resonated with drag and have never been a regular watcher of RuPaul's Drag Race, so I didn't come into this with preexisting context. That didn't matter, though -- the story is great, Lady Camden is so charismatic, and I was so moved by her journey. Luke Willis did an excellent job. I looked him up and saw that he's a former ballet dancer so it's really cool to see his transition to filmmaking. I was so sad to miss a live screening of this when it came to the Bay Area and I'm so glad it's now available to stream. I'm so glad this movie exists!

It's a superbly-directed film by Clint Eastwood featuring the excellent cinematography work of Tom Stern and editing sequences by Joel Cox and Gary Roach with the inspirational book called 'Playing the Enemy: Mandela and the Game that Made a Nation by John Carlin'.nnThat narrative is so important as Mandela has to fuse the country together and uses its biggest weapon to unify the country. Sport.nnNo bigger occasion than the South African World Cup in 1995. It really bridged communities together and showed people that blacks and whites can play together and win and succeed. It's a tragedy that there was only one black player in the starting line-up but what an achievement he made.nnI love the narrative. Matt Demon is superb as a relatively short version of Francois Pienaar! The funny quote from the bodyguard claiming that he's much shorter in real life than on the TV amplifies this.nnThere is a great 'Presidential Seal' by Morgan Freeman who just oozes absolute class and engraces the Nelson Mendella ethos so perfectly-well!nnI got goosebumps watching it as I remember hearing on the news how important Mandela's release was and how important Rugby was for him to secure a sense of release in his country which was previously impossible.nnSport is so important and this movie should be an educational film for all to see at schools. It's so important that people bridge differences and idealogies and racial segregation through the powerful medium of sports.nnClint Eastwood does an incredible job in amplifying this message and it's so very near perfect. It's also really hard to do sports' movies and many suck but this does not. Absolutely awesome movie! 9/10!

Is the plot predictable? Of course it is, it's a romantic comedy. But I enjoyed the humor and the jokes, they don't make them like this anymore.nnThe male lead is a definition of a playboy and quite cruel while doing that. But that's why we're here for aren't we? For the character development. As a psychologist I value the tricky part in human relations. For example in this movie there is a lot of room for speculation they don't spell it out for you.nnThe question we're all asking ourselves is who is going to be able to seduce our playboy? It turns out it will be a sick young girl. First thing about her is very obvious she is striking his ego because she's "much younger". The second thing is that he knew her mother, but he wasn't quite interested in her mother was he? Did he fumble her mother so now he gets a second chance with her daughter ? Maybe. But the thing that really seals the deal is that she's terminally sick. He tries to get rid of her but she tell him about his illness, he feel bad for her and practically stays with her because of compassion. That's the main reason he fell in love only with her, she's the only one with whom he has enough time for falling in love. AKA he wasn't able to scare her away. She had nothing else to be scared of in life.nnBut the important detail you're all missing is why would her grandmother allow this course of events? (My first that was "omg what a progressive grandma") And also many of you could ask yourselfs why even get in a relationship with this emotionally crippled jerk? And why did grandma allow that when she knows him well? The answer to that question is would it really be better to spend her last couple of months alone? ;( while going through a heartbreak? Grandma wanted her to have an adventurous and emotionally fulfilling last year. So would anyone in that situation. We don't have enough time to search for a perfection of a man.nnAt the end the surgery doesn't miraculously save her which I liked, it's not a typical fairy tale end.nnAnd for you guys who don't know how does he save a relationship with his daughter. The answer is also quite simple, she always wanted to have a relationship with her father and he had a trauma bond with her. She was there for him and helped him when his lover died. At this point his character is also "developed" he moves on from him surface level lifestyle and starts to appreciate life and accepts more of traditional values.

The movie was great. I liked the plot, the characters, the comedy, and some lines were beautiful. The actors did a great job and I loved the romance between Jacob and Hana. All in all, it was almost gonna be one of my top romantic comedy movies but!nnDON'T forgive the cheater. The male lead tries to persue the wife who cheated, the movie displays her as a good person, and it's all romantic?? It ruined the movie for me. Cheaters deserve nothing of that sort.nnAlso, a high school girl sending her nudes to a 40 yo grown man? That's like child porn. And then giving them to a 13 year old boy?? Girl chill!nnOverall, except these two points and the clich√© graduation speech (where the male lead suddenly starts making it about glorifying his cheating wife), the movie was great.

I'm watching all the Alien films in order. I feel this needs to be stated as normally I'd not be up for watching Alien vs. Predator, but I'm going in with an open mind. To be honest the Alien franchise already lost its way before this sidebar, so what's the harm in getting two classic 80s film monsters on the screen together. A team of archeologists are assembled in Antarctica by Charles Bishop Weyland (Lance Henriksen). He's the only holdover from what's gone before, the rest are brand new. We have Alexa (Sanaa Lathan), the guide on this expedition, Sebastian (Raoul Bova) the charismatic digger, Mark (Tommy Flanagan) the miserable muscle and Graeme (Ewan Bremner), the scientist goofball. Deep below the ice, they think they've found an ancient pyramid... possibly the first built, but by whom, or what. The set up is riddled with clunky cliched dialogue and it doesn't improve, but you're not watching this for its writing are you. Weyland is of course the company name from previous films and therefore assumed the bad guy, but not so. Here he's mostly just a rich old man, sick and looking for one last adventure to be remembered by. The pyramid when they reach it is like something from Indiana Jones, except instead of hieroglyphs of sphinx, there's Predator statues. Plus there's a defrosting caged Alien in the basement. A Queen! It's seems the Predators have woken the structure, as a team of them arrive from space. They gut the surplus cast and follow the human explorers into the icy depths. It's all a bit nuts, but I don't hate it. It's far-fetched, but not dumb, certainly not in terms of Alien films. It's a playful twist on the question of how the Egyptians built the pyramids conspiracy, it was aliens... according to this it was. The pyramid is a rights of passage colosseum for coming of age Predators, pitting themselves against the Aliens. It helps if you're familiar with Alien to follow this, it expects you to know that face-huggers are bad, although I guess there's little doubt of that. They get the Matrix bullet-time treatment here, which is pretty cool. Adele (Agathe de la Boulaye) gets the first honour of incubation, but doesn't do it nearly as well as John Hurt. I won't lie, the pyramid setting is a masterstroke. It reconfigures every ten minutes, with the walls grinding and shifting in ever twisting puzzles, separating those still alive into prey. Bang on the hour, the two species come face to face in a bonkers battle of brutal bloodlust. It's what you'd expect, but quite entertaining and it provides distraction for the few remaining humans to run for it. Shy on action it is not. A great film it is not, but compared to some other Alien films, it fairs better than you might think. It actually makes sense in a way and doesn't pretend to be anything but an action romp. This is my first time watching this spin off and I'm pleasantly surprised. My expectations were low and easily met, but freed of the weight of the standalone alone Alien films, this is quite good.

Dutch writer/director Halina Reijn's new feature 'Babygirl' is an exercise in boldness. The film is a fresh take on the age old story of self-discovery and self-destruction.nnIn the movie Nicole Kidman plays Romy, a highly successful CEO of a robotics company by day and sexual submissive by night. Despite having a picture-perfect home life with a loving husband and two daughters, Romy remains unseen and sexually unsatisfied until she meets an intern (Samuel) at her company who sees a side of her that's she's been hiding - her sexual identity.nnTwo older films come to mind when watching 'Babygirl' - Stanley Kubrick's 'Eyes Wide Shut' and Adrian Lyne's 'Unfaithful'. All three deal with infidelity and the razor's edge one walks when engaging in it. What stands out in 'Babygirl' is the feral, masochistic nature of Romy and Samuel's illicit encounters which leave Romy in equal parts exhilarated, scared, embarrassed and liberated.nnReijn's film presents an unvarnished view into shifting power differentials. The CEO has power over an intern just as much as a dom has power over a sub. Romy the titan gives in to the commands of Samuel the peon. Their initial encounters are awkward and uncomfortable both for them and the audience. It's like watching two porcupines mate. The fact that Romy is cheating on her husband, theater director Jacob (played admirably by Antonio Banderas) is intriguing, but what she needs for sexual fulfillment is even more so.nnThe performances are strong all around, but the film belongs to Kidman whose brilliant portrayal is both brave and vulnerable. At 57, Kidman is doing the best work of her career on TV and the big screen.nnReijn's direction is intimate, raw and unyielding. She pulls no punches and lets scenes breathe until they become difficult to watch. The cinematography is harsh and unfiltered, making the film feel more realistic. I did have a problem with the bombastic score which, at times, threatened to overwhelm the visuals.nnAll in all 'Babygirl' is a fascinatingly frank and thought-provoking exploration of human sexuality that also turns the tables on workplace sexual politics. Be prepared as this film earns its R rating, but it's well worth the watch.

I didn't find this movie sexy or thrilling at all. I found it more scary and uncomfortable. There wasn't sexual tension between Nicole and Harrison. She just eventually gives into the idea of this guy having control over her after a few scenes of them being awkward and uncomfortable with each other. And that's mostly where I have a problem with this movie because it's supposedly liberating the sexual fantasies of women but instead it portrays abuse as kinky. It wasn't consensual and it wasn't spicy. It was just gross. She didn't want to take her clothes off at several points throughout the movie and to me that's a big fat no. I get that that can be a fantasy but it wasn't portrayed that way either. It was portrayed as a creep emotionally and sexually manipulating a middle aged woman. There wasn't even a power dynamic. He as the lesser person had more power than her and she was the CEO! It was like reading a wattpad novel with random and outlandish things occurring just to move the plot along. If the roles were reversed we would've gotten a hotass Bossman with power over his much younger female intern who's career could be ruined by the scandal but in this case the man still had the power to ruin her career and she was in a higher position than him. If that's how a woman's world works I don't want it.nnThankfully Nicole Kidman is such an amazing actress that it made up for most of the movie but it still ended so anti-climatically. This woman was scared to end a sexual relationship with her intern because he was blackmailing her, only for her to send him to Japan and finally get a backbone within the last 10 minutes of the movie. Like wtf is going on?! It had all the right elements but it was put together so poorly. I get she wanted to be told what to do like a dog and "couldn't" tell her husband but it seemed more like she was scared the whole time and that she wanted to be an actual dog while having sex.nnThis had abuse-me-while-I'm-super-uncomfortable-about-it vibes instead of a liberating sexual fantasy.

Most of the world is populated by dumb people. You can be certain while reading some of the reviews that fail to understand what Eggers did here. Light, shadows, every scene is a piece of art. Caravaggio, Van Gogh, you can see them while watching this movie. Should we talk about how Eggers deals from a psychological standpoint the thematic of rape? Or what about the women condition, repressed beings and thus lean to cultivate an evil inside that hollows them? An evil that drains them of their lives. Should we talk about the religious thematic? A redemption for women, given the fact that Ellen dies to redeem humanity of its sins.nnBut this is just peanuts comparing to the magnificence of Eggers movie. Watch it more than once and enjoy every detail that contains. This is our Nosferatu, this is our legacy.

If you have read the original books, then it's a bit disappointing as it's nothing like them, (and Enid Blyton would turn in her grave regarding the amount of things they have changed to accommodate the snowflakes - am amazed Aunt Fanny kept her name lol)nnBut to be fair, overall I thought it was alright..nnA good mystery programme for kids (and for adults too, as long as you don't think about the original books).nnGeorgina (sorry, George - just using up some characters here lol), and Aunt Fanny were awful actors, didn't believe or engage with them.nnThe wee boy who played Dick was brilliant; , hope he does well in his acting career.

You hate, you love, you hate again, you're surprised, you say, what the hell, the world is so infested with shitty people.nnThen there's Marla. God, who's born with that ambition? You start thinking about your loved ones when they get older, What happens with them?nnYou are constantly thinking about it. It depends on your values and what you believe is good and evil. Then the ending is so sweet and beautiful; it's what I had wished for from the beginning. It was worth it!nnYou decide if being a Marla is the right thing to do in this world. It's your decision.nnI LOVE happy ending so much!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I typically don't write reviews about movies I initially watched as a child. But I have done so recently for some TV series I have watched, & I wrote a review for Disney's 'Hercules' elsewhere two summers ago. So, I thought I would share it here with IMDb.nnI've always had a good memory for remembering details of movies many years later. But seeing this one again, as with my past experiences of revisiting childhood movies & such, I again notice new things & see things differently. I enjoy the adult humour hidden in plain sight. The part where Herc peeks around to glance at Nessus' genitals had me pause it to stop laughing! The part where Pain & Panic play kids under the boulder had an interesting line: "Somebody call I. X. I. I.!" It took me a bit to figure out that reference!nnIt's not all comedy though - it's also epic. The integration of CGI into the traditional animation, although it hasn't aged as well, is still kind of awesome, namely during the Hydra scene. I still get a tingle down my back at the bit where Hercules, mounted atop Pegasus, looks in horror upon the multi-headed beast appearing out of the darkness.nnEven though I knew how the ending goes, I was about ready to bawl at the part where Meg dies. Surprising that that scene strikes me at age 32, but had no effect on me at age 8. Not surprising, however, is how much I like Meg's hairstyle & her armpit-blended bosoms.nnOverall, my favourite character is still Hades. His persona as an overcaffeinated salesman caught between an anger management problem & a suppressed desire to pursue a career in stand-up comedy is inimitable & unforgettable. Disney could have dedicated an entire TV spinoff to just Hades' life after quitting the Underworld.nnOther things I also notice now include how much resemblance Panic's persona bears to that of Harold Green on [link=tt0101177], the facial resemblance of the giant snake Herc wrangles to Joanna in [link=tt0100477], & how you could feed a village of starving children with Zeus' pecs.nnEven at the age of eight or nine, I was aware though that this movie was less a depiction of Greek mythology than it was a parody of American life in the 90s. For a rather refreshed, even contemporary (at the time) take on what was intended to be another Disney classic, it hasn't aged too badly & still has a great feel to it.

This is bad, just bad. It's easy to see that things are so bad in Hollyweird that top notch actors are having to just take whatever comes along. There isn't anything redeeming about this film. This could have been a decent film with the correct military consultant and director. For the military historian this is a nightmare. The uniforms are wrong, the weapons are wrong, even the boonie slang and radio talk are incorrect. This one should have been left on the shelf until it could have had the right budget. There are many other Vietnam era films that are MUCH better. Do yourself a favor and go watch one of them instead.

So I didn't think it could get worse that The Exorcist: Believer..... and I was wrong. In the 5 minutes that I watched, it seemed so rushed and casual that I thought this must be a snuff film or something along the lines of making fun of this specific genre. Luckily, I checked out the IMDB score and reviews.... It saved me a ton of time and disappointment. The storyline seems completely lacking and there is no character or story development at all.nnApparently, I have to write more. This movie just isn't worth the amount of characters for the minimum review size. Comparing all exorcism movies to the OG, is ridiculous. But movies like Exorcism of Emily Rose and even The Last Exorcism seem to hit the point.

column3: "The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power" (2022)
column4: Firstly, don't read the negative reviews filed before 2024...they are irrelevant. No, this is not Lord of the Rings. The Silmarrilion and other divergent works serve as the source material for this rather unwieldy show. BUT, don't be deterred by the first season's efforts to bring the characters and plotlines into focus... it's quite a task. The visuals are breathtaking throughout, but the show really takes off in season 2, after all the setup is in place. The stories begin to weave together, the characters deepen and you are inexorably drawn in. Be prepared for the addiction that is inevitable. Like me, you will be waiting eagerly for season 3.

Both me and my wife are big fans of previous work by Taylor Sheridan. The Yellowstone series and Lioness being our favorites. Landman was really disappointing (we quit after 3 episodes). Billy Bob was a ridiculously tough old man in every scene and the portrayal of his daughter and ex-wife are sexist and shallow. The father-daughter relationship feels creepy. The series display a very odd view of women which surprises us because all other Sheridan shows have had strong, independent female characters. It's impressive how many series Taylor Sheridan has produced in just a few years, but this show may be the evidence that he should slow down and focus on quality rather than quantity.

Zombie (1979).nnWhen the boat arrives it's like Dracula's Demeter.nnThe ending of this film was plagiarized in Battle Royale (2000).nnTisa was too much of woman. There were four attractive females in the film Tisa Farrow, Olga Karlatos, Auretta Gay, Stefania D'Amario.nnThe protagonist Peter West is like Clark Kent from Metropolis daly.nnI like Lucio Fulci's directing style. The movie has good music.nnIt's silly how she tricks the policeman on the boat, but this Peter West ends up laying hands on Anne two minutes after meeting her.nnStake in the eye. It's supposed to be about judging others Matthew 7:1-6, Luke 6:37-42.

Film:nFuher and the seducer. Or goebbels and the fuher.nnInteresting film from the perspective of Joseph Goebbels who is the main propagandist and spin member of the nazi party.nnIt talks about how shaping hitlers image took effort and a lot of mass manipulation.nnThey talk about it in a jovial, fun way as if it is a game to them.nnThe fanaticism around Hitler is apparent, humanising a lot of these people, and showing their delusions at the forefront.nnWhat is fascinating to see is the meticulous planning into fanning the flames of the German people and of the Jews by promoting protests against the nazi party as well as increasing tensions between the groups.nnNot a bad film, but not revelatory either. Most likely a 6/10.

I loved this one, a slowly moving film made for adult audience, great dialogue and acting. Love del Toro, Timberlake is also surprisingly good. Characters are liberatingly far away from the normal ¬´all good¬ª or ¬´all evil¬ª stereotypes. Plot is sufficiently complex to require your full attention, and if you are like me you will feel the suspense and not move much from your chair. Also void of endless unrealistic fighting scenes and car chases, which is a big plus. When I saw that the movie had only 6.8 on Imdb I was really surprised, as I think it deserves an 8 or 9 and I consider myself to be really picky and demanding. All in all a great thriller.

I think this is a nice film. I rarely write reviews, i usually ciick other's people comments as helpful or not, but i decided to write a review mainly for two reasons: a) there is only one review (!) and b) the rating is unfairly low in my opinion. The story begins with a family of four, a loving couple with two kids. One day the wife (Mariel) returns early at home and finds her husband with woman's clothing. After the initial shock she tries to understand what is happening, The children finding out react badly, very negatively. After some time firstly the son and later the girl accept the situation (their father wants to change sex with surgury), but not his fathet , neither the sister of Mariel. Mariel is very supporting albeit the many problems/challenges that she understans she will face (socially, emotionaly, sexuaslly, fiancially as the husband is fired from his work, etc). A delicate matter that is described decently in the film. Directing is good, so is the acting.

I saw the previews and this looked like a movie I would have zero interest in, but then word of mouth was good and it was nominated for awards, so I decided to see it and it turned out I was right in my initial judgement. I heard words like suspense and thriller, but the movie is over and I'm still waiting for it. Older woman cheats on her husband with a younger man, how original! And there's zero suspense to the husband finding out, and coworkers finding out, that's inevitable in any movie. And in the end they all live happily ever after with zero repercussions. Such a thriller! What a disappointment. The only reason it's up for awards and people like it is Nicole Kidman's star power. Sorry, I need more than that.

True story about Gunnar S√∏nsteby, whom was an important figure in the Norwegian resistance - located in Oslo - during the Nazi occupation of Norway.nnA combination of the old "Gunnar S√∏nsteby" (an actor) and the WW2 Gunnar, it is a back-and-forth between the two of them. Fortunately, this back-and-forth isn't too disturbing. I would have preferred a more chronological movie, whereby only attention is put to the WW2 period.nnThe acting is very good. Superb however are the scenes! All looks exactly as you would expect things to look like during WW2.nnThe storyline - apart from being fragmented - would have benefitted greatly from a clear antagonist, "the bad guy". This to give the viewer a better idea on how the Nazi's were trying to identify and locate the resistance members. Because that was something that clearly happened.nnTaking into account all of the above, I think that this movie deserves a score of 7.3/10, making it a 7-star IMDb movie.nnI personally think that this movie is best watched after you first see the movie "Max Manus - Man of War" (2008), which features the same resistance group. That movie gives a better view on the functioning - and people - in that resistance group. Whereby Gunnar S√∏nsteby seems to be a leader of the group, it was actually Max Manus - and his close friends - that committed the operational side of the sabotages. In the Max Manus movie, you will see several of the famous sabotages like e.g. The sinking of the Donau war-ship.nnAs a final remark, I want to comment on the original movie description that accompanies "Nr. 24". It reads that S√∏nsteby is the greatest war hero of Norway. To say this, does injustice to all people that died during work for the army, the resistance or from Nazi torture or execution. This whilst fighting for Norway's freedom. It would be more fair to name all the people that risked, or even gave their life, a hero. It should not be about whom is able to survive the war - and live the longest - to be able to claim a title like "greatest hero".

How anyone rates this movie any higher is a fact beyond my comprehension. The plot is so thin and contrived. Alex gets shot, beaten and even has a pair of garden shears stuck in to him yet still he awakes from that only to be fully agile, flexible, alert and able to fight once more! Inevitably he got shot again. I was expecting to see him awaken from that too.nnThis is just one example of incredulous plot lines. There were so many others. I won't recount them here.nnBottom line, this film is not worth the effort. If you've seen and appreciate films that genuinely warrant an IMDB rating of 7 or more you won't be satisfied by this one.

Penelope's Story helped me healed. I was able to see forgiveness from another perspective and it gave me hope.nnThis is a movie that brings up light to the world and I want to see more about these type of movies.nnI had the amazing opportunity to see this movie at the Latin American film festival in Ottawa and I was glad that it has Spanish subtitles. Me and my friends were blessed by it and I can't wait for it to be available to the public so I can share it with my family and some friends who had gone through a form of abuse.nnIn the Q&A with the director and actors I had the opportunity to know why this movie is so closed to the Director's heart and felt empowered by her journey to overcome mental abuse. I'm hopeful that this movie will touch many lives as it did with mine. So Watch It! I 100% recommend it!

Critique on capital punishment.nnHow much simpler could it get? Go to the drawing board yourself and try come up with a plot for this topic.nnHave a young man kill a man that is shown to be a douche bag (only reason he ever gets so much screen time) and then have him get executed in a cold way. Oh, and also humanise the living crap out of the killer for the second half of the movie, have him talk about his family.nnI liked the part where he killed the man because he was partly responsible for the murder of his sister some time ago. But here is the catch: why? This correlation is never explained so I'm just supposed to give the movie a benefit of the doubt that there was some smart psychological explanation behind this.nnAlso for a topic like this, the movie never 'argues' its ideas, it just sets up the plot so 'meticulously' to make us feel for the character. What if the cab driver was a real kind man, like we saw him work some hard hours to feed his family, and then he gets killed, now that would be a harder pill to swallow AND a more convincing one. Because in retrospect this movie is so obvious. I don't even have some strong opinion on the topic of capital punishment so I'm not biased to dislike this movie, but it's approach feels so 'first draft' that I can't really appreciate this movie.nnCinematography: somehow the movie was very atmospheric from the get go, but God. I felt like I was watching the movie through a peephole the entire duration because the amounts of vignettes and shadow gradients added in the post production.nnThe positive note for this film is how the scenes are directed, yes, I'd agree those murders were impactful and the coldness of both murders got through very well. It was fantastic. The acting from everyone is superb.nnThe movie was paced well and was fun to watch as well, the intensity was well maintained through the first half of the movie. I just felt like it was a let down in such a basic attempt to prove its point and I can imagine that it could've been done in a much more thought provoking way.

This production did a really good job on a remake of a classic and very controversial horror film. Casting was quite appropriate, and the variations of the new version were frozen unpredictable and definitely pushing it to the line. There were a couple of parts that dragged a little, but nothing too serious to deter my high rating of this phone. The tough call is whether this is better than the original? The sequels after their so I don't care for at all, but this remake of the original version is the exception to that rule. I would certainly recommend this movie but not to the people that are easily distracted by graphics or extreme nudity or controversial rape scenes.

We just finished season one of this terrific series from Australia. The acting and writing are super, with real life storylines. Just love City Homicide. Thanks to Amazon Prime for airing this great series. American series sadly cannot compete with our Brit/Australian friends. If Hollywood wants to learn how good series are made, they need to look at our Brit & Australian friends. The actors in it are all terrific. The series shows the realistic interactions between police colleagues and shows their personal sides as well in a real light. If you like police dramas like we do and can find this series on a platform, don't miss it.

The LANDMAN story is list to the hyper sexualized daughter and the drunk crazy obnoxious X wife. It's cringe worthy and adds nothing to the story. It would be nice to more Jon Hamm, but he seems more like a background character at this point. Meanwhile the Xwife's trips to an old age home are taking up too much of the show. The son's story line is interesting. If a bit unbelievable at times. They also started out with the Mexican cartel threatening & beating Billy Bob's character Tommy Norris , along with stealing oil company assets, but that story line has fallen flat. After reading several of the other reviews seems clear the Xwife idea was a bad one.

Get the Gringo (2012) is an action thriller written and starring Mel Gibson and it was a lot of fun from start to finish.nnPositives for Get the Gringo (2012):nThis was an action thriller movie with a simple premise that is done perfectly well. Mel Gibson is awesome as the grizzled badass we all know and love since the Lethal Weapon franchise. I likes the family he has to care for here and becomes a part of by the end of the movie. The action sequences are bloody and awesome. And finally, this is a movie that wants to entertain the audience for 90-minutes.nnNegatives for Get the Gringo (2012):nMy only issue with the movie is that the villains weren't a threat at all and they were boring.nnOverall, Get the Gringo (2012) is a good old fashion mid budget action thriller movie that I would like to see more nowadays.

After the build up & performance from Pushpa 1, this one really lacks logic and really undigestable at times.nnSome scenes are really unnecessary for e.g. The opening one in Japan.nnMusic is not as soothing as it was in part one.nnWriting was very poor.nnOne can find something good in it in bits and pieces only.nnAllu Arjun's acting was unbearable at times. He wanted to carry on from part one where he left but the storyline didn't support him enough.nnFafa should have just left the franchise after part one only.nnRashmika's character could have been given more legit dialogues and space seeing the aura she carried from part one.

It starts off with a well portrayal of anora being a sex worker, and gradually moves on to a romantic fantasy and then into a rollercoaster ride of chaos and conflicts. Mikey Madison absolutely nails the character with a performance being so natural to our eyes. Anoras life turns instantly into a fantasy as she meets a Russian spoiled boy and gets married to him. The main topic/content of the story is set up on the aftermath of this crazy situation. They are joined by other characters who engages into their life inorder to get the marriage annulled. Literally every character in the movie absolutely nails it with their natural performance. Moreover the story dives into the emotions of anora , her emotions being exploited and how her life was just a mere toy for rich and spoiled people. In the final minutes of the film, anora's actions in the car clearly explains the emotions she goes through and sets the standard for what the point of the movie is. Having many comedic situations and moments with absolute chaos, the movie does not fail to entertain all while displaying the point of the movie through the character of anora as well as pointing out instances of such experiences which still occur in this world to this day. Overall it was a well made movie that does not disappoint.

If you're looking for a Midsommar level horror lol this is not it. This movie made me laugh more times than it scared me; felt like an unhinged SNL short. This is a movie you watch while baked out of your mind because it's easy enough to follow and will keep your attention. The mother in law, Solange, is wacky and over the top - she carries the film. Unsure of how Brandy and Andrew Burnap were able to stay in character with Kathryn Hunter pretending to be a klansman and farting in their faces.nnOther reviewers are correct in their claims that this movie is full of excrement, as it relies on pee pee poo poo humor to fill gaps in its underwhelming writing. I was intrigued by how this slop was ever picked up by HBO and found out that directors Sam and Max Eggers are related to Robert Eggers - the director of Nosferatu and The Witch. I'm assuming nepotism is how they got the HBO gig. Anyway save your time and watch a movie from Robert Eggers catalog if you're actually looking for quality, however if you're in the mood for a hate watch, this may be the film for you!

Where do i even start with this masterpiece of online media. First of all, the toilets are so funny when they say "skibidi dop dop"! It brings a tear to my eye knowing all the people who burst out in laughter will have a better day thanks to skibidi toilet. Furthermore, i enjoy how the camera men, the good guys, take down the evil toilets with style and skill, unlike other hero characters in the media, the camera men are simply the best in all areas. Lastly, i enjoy how the characters grow over the episode's, with the series growing more serous over time. Its great to see the show going down this path as I JUST LOVE SKIBIDI TOILET. I simply wish everyone the pleasure of watching this peak example of media.

I thought this was a really good series and couldn't believe the low 6.5 rating in IMDb. I am a fan of police/crime/thriller/mystery dramas, however so many are mundane, formulaic, and predictable. So I welcomed this series which was a refreshing break from the formulaic stuff being churned out nowadays. I thought it fast-paced and believable with clever and moving interwoven plotlines.nnI did have a problem understanding the Jamaican dialect which I'm not accustomed to and wished subtitles had been provided (not available with my edition). Yet one still cares about the main protagonists and what will happen to them. I did lose a sense of plot twists occasionally but that didn't affect my overall enjoyment of the series. I'm already on the lookout for Season 2.

This episode of "Boy Meets World" is extremely important and memorable. The message in the episode "Teacher's Bet" is extremely powerful. I wish the lesson was not still necessary. Unfortunately, the lesson in the episode is still very relevant in today's world. Antisemitism still exists thirty-two years after the episode originally aired and eighty years after the end of the Holocaust. It is my favorite because of the important message and the line, "Obviously, this is one of those Mr. Feeny lesson things." I learned to look for the lesson in each subsequent episode of this excellent television series.

My Old Ass is nearly all about the way we navigate that feeling of nostalgia or that fear of what is to come. If you don't fit into one of the two groups presented by Elliott, then I don't know how well the movie will play with you. Also, the film never really explains the rules that it is working with, which I am sure will frustrate a lot of people. They tip-toe around the future being quite dark, and I would have liked a little more clarity there. Finally, there is a sort of fractured/vignette feeling to the film rather than a whole, which I didn't mind because it hit those emotional beats for me, but if that is not happening for you, then this will likely distance you further from the narrative.

Here's a possible positive review for the movie "My Old Ass":nn*A Heartwarming and Hilarious Masterpiece!*nn"My Old Ass" is a sidesplitting and poignant film that will leave you laughing, crying, and reflecting on life. The movie's unique blend of humor, wit, and emotional depth makes it a must-watch for audiences of all ages.nnThe cast delivers outstanding performances, bringing to life relatable characters that will capture your heart. The script is clever, insightful, and authentic, tackling themes that resonate deeply.nnWhat sets "My Old Ass" apart is its ability to balance lighthearted moments with more serious, thought-provoking commentary. The result is a film that's both entertaining and enriching.nnOverall, "My Old Ass" is a triumphant achievement in storytelling. Don't miss this opportunity to experience a movie that will make you smile, nod your head in recognition, and maybe even inspire you to live life to the fullest.

Maybe if is not the best Christmas movie, but I liked it.nnIt is funny, maybe predictable, maybe sometimes stupid, but for me it is a modern good adaptation of the classic "A Christmas Carol". I enjoyed it, and the movie put me in Christmas spirit.nnI absolutely liked the "Karen" gags.nnSubstituting the usual Scrooge with a Karen worked for me and made the movie worth to view.nnI liked also the diversity in the characters: the gay brother and his husband, the African-American neighbours and the other different characters: in the movie.nnMaybe the plot is not very original, but for me it is a good Christmas movie.

What was the real life couple Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman thinking before signing a movie about cheating on each other!nnNow I know this movie is supposedly filled with a lot of symbolism and hidden details and themes like secret pedophile clubs, but I believe it is not possible to figure all that out in the first watch; it will take at least 3-4 rewatches. So we will not talk about that stuff. But even if you are making a detailed movie like that, I believe it is important that the movie in its first watch itself is enjoyable enough. I am not saying that it should be like a Michael Bay movie (not a fan of that stuff personally). I like slow burners, but this movie, in its first watch at least, gives you only a tan rather than a burn, in all its slowness.nnAs was the scenario with Kubrick's previous movie Full Metal Jacket, the first 40 minutes are brilliant and very entertaining. Your eyes remain glued to the screen but then a new thread in the story opens and is not able to maintain the same tension. It was Vietnam war in FMJ and the secret society in this one. Every emotion till the prostitute scene was highly palpable but the story goes on a different tangent when Tom goes to the orgy. It somewhat deviates from what I thought would be the central theme. Then the ending was always predictable.nnThe cinematography, music and detailing were top notch as you expect from a Kubrick movie. He is a true master of cinema. The editing was also nice except the overuse of the transition in which one shot fades into another. Kubrick wants his actors to be over-expressive and I agree with him that it makes the movie more interesting, until, it doesn't, which was the case with the acting of Nicole Kidman and Marie Richardson. Nicole Kidman was especially painful to watch. She utters the dialogue so slowly that you feel like sleeping. Tom Cruise did a pretty good job.nnScript also had its flaws; for example, Tom tries to find Nick's address and the first girl she stumbles across, knows it; the receptionist of the hotel doesn't even remember Amanda's name which is weird because I don't think people dying in your hotel is a daily affair; and above all, Tom Cruise throwing his medical license as an FBI badge to get access to any place possible. The lead characters also needed some more depth for a 2hr39min movie.nnIt will probably grow over me when I watch it again, but for now it feels one of the weaker ones of Kubrick.

This 69 year old straight white male absolutely loved this film. It has been years since I have been so moved by a film. I have never been a huge Aubrey Plaza fan. She has a lot of people that really love her. I just like her and she was very good in this, but the two young leads Maisy Stella and Percy Hynes White were just terrific.. I have always loved coming of age stories. There are going to be a lot of haters that give this a one cause they thought they were going to the Reagan movie in the theater next door, but I call this maybe the best Romantic Dramedy that I have ever seen . Truth be told I was grappling between a 9 and a 10 but decided to add the star tot counteract the haters. Sometimes with reviews I.worry that I am going to give spoilers. Let me just say that if you have a good heart you will love this film. I did not think much of Megan Park's first film.

We like this programe ,ive had experiances myself ,but this barrie bloke with stupid multi tool vest, he wears ??? Panics ,doesnt seem to know what he is doing , sumons spirit responce then goes panic running away, redicullouse ,just looks the worst member of team.make him driver thats all. I have myself several experiances through my life so far ,so i believe in spirit world, the spirit spoken words placed on screen are TOO SMALL NOT ON SCREEN LONG ENOUGH .nnIve had spirit large orbe enter my room in scotland when i was young tank soldier ,armoured commander, it moved with intellegence, observed me then moved to my feet passed through my feet knees hips shoulders giveing me small shocks like electrical, then left my body speeded up left through window.

Does Ivo beat his students for bad marks, I wonder?nnJoking, joking.nnAnyway, this story cries "danger" all through and every party involved.nn(mild spoilers alert)nnFor if you see someone is promiscuous, don't expect them to be faithful to you and do not try to beat fidelity out and into them.nnAnd if you see someone is dark and moody, don't expect them to be tolerant to your ways.nnCertainly, don't "steal" your brother's partner if you know of your brother's quick temper %-)nnDon't play with the fire, don't test someone's patience, don't break their trust, don't manipulate them into giving into your demands only to throw them away as you get what you want.nnDon't be violent, on the other hand, as it only makes people fear and loathe you.nnAnd still, people are ready to take risks and chances as their hearts tell them to, because feelings and logic don't always match.nnJust to be close to someone even if for a short time.nnI loved this little dark fantasy.nnLoved actors and characters, the mood, the music, the scenery, the photography.nnThe only character that makes me wonder is Isabel.nnOr, rather, the actress Michaela Jay (?)nnWhat's that in her?nnShe is more of a snow queen.nnI don't feel the connection between her and Tim for some reason.nnThere is more tension, fire and flame between her, her brother and her wandering husband.nnThose three got quite a story to tell!nnIt's a nice 00s drama, albeit not flawless - but then, who or what, is?nnIt is coloured blue, green, white and grey. With the sparks of yellow.nnDon't watch it if you are easily upset or offended, if you see politics everywhere, if you don't believe that bisexual people exist, if you are triggered by scenes of violence, etc.nnDon't watch it if you are not ready to go with the flow and immerse yourself into the fantasy world where mystery is intertwined with reality.nnWatch it if you like something melancholic and melodramatic, but not overly so.nnWatch it if you like stories about human relationships, psychological drama, suspense, moody blues, wry humour and the like.

It is without a doubt the heaviest film I have ever seen, It apparently serves as a kind of criticism against violence, but the film is incredibly disturbing.nnIt shows a young man (Alex) who hangs out with a gang of friends in the future. The film shows them doing very violent and heavy things (even explicitly), After he is arrested, he undergoes an experiment to rehabilitate himself. The story and narration focus completely on him and everything he does. At the same time that the film is violent, it seems to be criticizing everything it shows.nnThe film has a very closed script in the plot itself. Technically, the story of the film is very good.nnThe film has a "futuristic" aesthetic that is similar to current modern times. This, plus Stanley Kubrick's photography, makes the film one with a lot of the author's signature. However, it shows a lot of things that I don't even like to write about. The violence is explicit. The film was even banned in some countries, and with good reason. But in the end, even with all this violence, technically it is a great Kubrick film.

365 Days is a terrible movie, and I regret watching it. The book was slightly better than the movie, but still bad overall, and honestly, I regret both reading the book and watching the film.nnI have nothing against sex scenes, but there needs to be an actual plot. In this story, the solution to every problem was sex, which is just ridiculous. I had hoped it would improve in the later parts, but it didn't. It's completely unrealistic and feels more like straight-up adult content (if you know what I mean). Watching Massimo was so awkward, and the fact that she gave in to him (in the first part) is absurd.nnAlso, he just wins her heart with money, which makes no sense. Why would you laugh and seem happy within 24 hours of being kidnapped? It's completely absurd. The 2/10 rating I'm giving comes solely from the book because, while still bad, it was much slower-paced and felt more natural.nnThe entire movie was uncomfortable to watch, and I wouldn't sit through it again. Honestly, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

It feels like Ferry 2 is a copy of the earlier movie and serie. The makers lack new ideas. Nothing original.nnFrank Lammers is a great actor as usual, he does a great job.nnThe problem is the story. Another drugs related conflict in which Ferry promises to deliver a certain amount of pills, but has problems making and delivering them.nnAnd what also annoys me is the very bad acting of Jonas Smulders, who plays Lex. Just awful acting. He ruins the whole movie (even if the story was good, his acting would still ruin it).nnSuch a pity.nnJes (played by Aiko) is a good actress, although her boring attitude and boring facial expressions in this movie sometimes is a pain in the ass to watch.

### Black Money: The Most Disappointing Work I've Seen from Raihan RafinnI had high hopes when I started watching *Black Money*, directed by Raihan Rafi. As someone who thoroughly enjoyed his previous works, especially the commercial hit *Toofan*, I was expecting another remarkable project. Unfortunately, what I experienced was nothing short of disappointing. Throughout the series, I felt let down by almost every aspect - from the overacting to the poor technical quality and a storyline that failed to captivate.nn#### A Story That Goes NowherennThe biggest flaw of *Black Money* is its weak and uninspired story. The premise had potential, but it felt as though no effort was put into fleshing it out. Instead of a gripping narrative, the series meandered aimlessly with predictable twists and clich√©d moments. I kept waiting for something engaging to happen, but it never did. The lack of depth in the story made it hard to care about the characters or their struggles.nn#### Overacting from Talented ActorsnnOne of the most frustrating aspects of this series was the performances. I've seen the cast excel in their past roles, which made it even more disappointing to watch them overact to the point where it became unbearable. The dialogue delivery felt forced, and the characters were exaggerated to the extent that they seemed cartoonish. I couldn't connect with any of them because their performances lacked the authenticity and subtlety needed to make them believable.nn#### Technical FailuresnnThe technical quality of *Black Money* was shockingly bad. From the very first episode, the poor cinematography was evident. The lighting was flat, and the camera work lacked creativity, making the visuals look dull and lifeless. The editing choices were equally questionable, with abrupt transitions that disrupted the flow of the story. Even the sound design was underwhelming, failing to add the tension or atmosphere that a series like this desperately needed.nn#### Direction That Lacked PassionnnWhat puzzled me the most was Raihan Rafi's direction. In *Toofan*, he proved his ability to craft engaging stories and bring out the best in his cast and crew. But in *Black Money*, it felt like he wasn't fully invested in the project. The direction was inconsistent, and the series lacked a clear vision. The pacing was all over the place, and there was no sense of cohesion between the scenes. It's hard to believe this is the same director who delivered such brilliant work in the past.nn#### Wasted PotentialnnWhat makes *Black Money* even more disappointing is the fact that it had so much potential. A story centered around corruption and crime involving money could have been gripping and thought-provoking. But instead of diving deep into these themes, the series scratched the surface and ended up being a shallow, poorly executed mess.nn#### Final ThoughtsnnWatching *Black Money* felt like a chore. The overacting, weak story, poor technical quality, and uninspired direction made it one of the worst viewing experiences I've had in a long time. As a fan of Raihan Rafi, I hope this is just a temporary misstep and not an indication of his future work.nnIf you're considering watching *Black Money*, I'd recommend saving your time and revisiting Rafi's earlier works instead. This series is a reminder that even the best directors can sometimes falter, but I'm hopeful that Raihan Rafi will bounce back stronger in his next project.

Horimiya" is the ultimate portrayal of youthful love, capturing the beauty of unexpected connections and the complexities of personal growth. The story follows Kyoko Hori, a popular high school girl, and Izumi Miyamura, a quiet and seemingly aloof boy. Beneath their seemingly ordinary appearances, both harbor deep insecurities and hidden sides that only each other can see.nnWhat makes Horimiya truly special is its genuine and realistic portrayal of love. The chemistry between Hori and Miyamura is undeniable, with their bond evolving naturally from friendship to a sweet, endearing romance. It's a love story where both characters grow, support each other, and become better versions of themselves.nnThe show also shines through its incredible character development and a diverse cast, each bringing something unique to the table. The lighthearted humor mixed with tender moments and heartfelt confessions will make you laugh, cry, and ultimately believe in the power of love.nnA perfect blend of romance, friendship, and self-discovery, Horimiya is an anime that will stay in your heart long after the final episode.

Never read the books and never heard anything about this story before I saw the show. I don't know how close it comes to the books but as a show is absolutely fantastic.nnEverything was done right , actors , costumes, music and the scotsmen in kilts are so sexy . I am in love.nnWe have beautiful landscapes , music to match , time travel , an intelligent mature woman as a lead character and two attractive men that love her . I like the romance part and the history part. I like everything about this show.nnI wish they add some subtitles . I watched this movie on the plane because of the cast. Michael Keaton and Mila Kunis were both great in this movie, but the writing was very cringe and left me with a very uncomfortable and almost angry feeling about the demonization of the title character.nnFirst of all, the whole movie is centered around what a deadbeat father and husband he is, attributed to his love of art and his art gallery small business he had owned for decades. The breakup of his first marriage is not explained much but he and his ex maintain a civil relationship and an almost friendship. His relationship with his 36 year old daughter to me is quite strong. In fact I have known many friends in the same situation as having a father who starts over with a younger wife and has young children in their late forties and in real life the relationship with the older children is rarely this caring. He has meaningful conversations with her and is quite involved in her pregnancy. He is truly ecstatic about being a grandfather. However the movie simply trashes him because he often calls the older daughter by the youngest daughter's name, and for being more involved in the younger children's lives than he was with the older daughter. Firstly, most parents mix up their kids names. My mom would sometimes shout all four of our names before she got it right. It's not grounds for bad parenting. It's just a thing overworked parents do. Secondly, he was most certainly NOT more involved with the younger children's lives, and only started attending parent teacher conferences when his wife abandoned the family without notice leaving him no choice. So the daughters angry perceptions of him seemed were more reflections of her inability to appreciate her father than of his failings. She became extremely angry at him when he failed to drive her to a doctor appointment. This anger was justified however at the current state his life was in (wife left him, business about to shut, parenting 2 young kids alone) I believe he deserved more grace than he was given. Also she was in a stronger place in her life than he was so it was foolish of her to rely on him. She had no kids, was 36, no job, and was married to a successful doctor. Taking uber to a doctor appointment isn't the end of the world. She also didn't seem to call or text. Odd communication.nnNow for the wife. The new younger wife is placed on a ridiculous pedestal she does not deserve. Without warning she leaves her two kids alone with a workaholic father because she is a junkie addicted to pills (apparently uppers and downers). At no moment is she held accountable for her own addiction, and in fact, her husband is blamed because he works too much. He is criticized hard for not recognizing she had a problem, however on all accounts she is an amazing super mom who cooks expert gluten free meals and never takes the kids late to school. She is celebrated for leaving the family because she is "getting help." I found the way she left to be truly cruel and the dad would have an excellent case for custody of the kids vs the selfish drug addicted abandoner. When she shows up unannounced and demands to talk about why she is divorcing him, she is taking time away from when he is supposed to be taking his adult daughter to the doctor. She has no respect for his time, doesn't ask if it's a good time and just barges in unannounced. Also I am not sure why his working so much was such a problem for her, since she doesn't eat an income. The division of labor in the household seemednlike the common American trad wife set up and there was no indication she had expressed desire to find a job or do other things.nnIn summary- this movie was a major bummer with a really strange perspective and I wish I hadn't seen it.

"Kick-Ass" is an unapologetically fun and bold superhero movie that flips the genre on its head. With its dark humor, over-the-top action, and quirky characters, it delivers a wild ride that's as entertaining as it is outrageous. Aaron Taylor-Johnson is great as the awkward, well-meaning Dave, but it's Chloe Grace Moretz as the foul-mouthed, fearless Hit-Girl who steals the show with her incredible fight scenes and sharp wit. The movie balances its satirical tone with genuinely heartfelt moments, making it more than just a parody. While it's definitely not for the faint of heart, "Kick-Ass" is a refreshingly unique take on the superhero story that's both chaotic and oddly charming.

The movies magnificent writing and outstanding casts makes for a truly unforgettable viewing experience I highly rrecommend it for fun and entertaining watch especially for someone trying to find a place in the world .The main characters journey is both poignant and hilarious , and I found myself nodding in recognition more than once!

Aubrey Plaza brings her signature wit and charm to the role, providing a humorous yet poignant perspective on the challenges of growing up. Critics have noted that Plaza's performance adds depth to the film, making her character's insights both entertaining and relatable. The film's exploration of themes such as living in the present and appreciating youth resonates well with audiences, particularly teenagers who often take their time for granted.

I was intrigued first by the idea of some group visiting Poland to just see it all. I thought it would be a real comedy and a really enjoyable movie.nnBut, unfortunately it was a complete disaster. The behavior of Benji wasn't funny. Hell no, he was really boring and pissing me off. Especially with his constant critique of everyone but he himself just acts like some great guy. His attitude towards everyone is really rude and when they entered the Majdanek I was a little stressed not by the place but by the thought that Benji will comment again. Of course instead of making a scene in concentration camp they decided for a CEMETERY as a perfect place for that. Walking over the graves, just arguing around it. I felt bad for the tour guide then as he was literally preserving the history of those who were laid there to rest, and Benji jumped at him saying "THEY were people not some numbers". Like isn't talking about their life truly remembering them? Not as a stone? Like yeah sure put the rock on his grave, but don't you want to know something more about him?nnMoreover, the visual aspects were appalling. What do you mean there are no cars on the streets and the whole city is empty?nnThe only redeeming part was the moment where both cousins put the stones in front of the doors and a Polish elderly man yelled at them to clear off the mess, cause someone lives behind these doors and they might trip.nnFinally, stop with the constant Chopin. The music doesn't connect with the theme of the movie. I understand the only polish music the American people know is Chopin. But, shouldn't klezmer music be more appropriate for this theme?nnI don't know what people see in this movie that makes it so entertaining. For me it was really painful and I wanted to leave the theatre numerous times.

That summer before college can be strange, a moment suspended between life stages, and Elliott (Maisy Stella) is right in the thick of it. She's turning 18 in the tiny picturesque community in Muskoka, Ontario, where her family has farmed cranberries for generations. She has a janky little motorboat, two best friends and a massive crush on the girl behind the counter at the local coffee shop. And she's looking forward to heading to Toronto in a few short weeks to start the next chapter of her life. Sounds familiar. You might even relate. But "My Old Ass," written and directed by Megan Park, does not go in expected coming-of-age directions. It's as much about reframing middle-aged regrets as it is a story about youth, love and possibility - and thus the emotional heft it wields is two-pronged.nnElliott belongs to a newish and very welcome variety of teen girl movie protagonist. For decades, these characters were mostly siloed into vapid types, the better for us, I guess, to "understand" them: Goths, cheerleaders, ditzes, bookish wallflowers, cool girls, bullies. Elliott, on the other hand, is funny, capable and comfortable in her own skin. She can drive a tractor and steer a boat, and also forgets to show up for her own birthday dinner with her family. She is very thoroughly 18, with as strong a sense of self as you can really have at that age, while also being kind of a jerk at times to her parents and brothers. She loves them. She just finds them kind of annoying, though she's not above apologizing for her behavior.

Wow.... good movie therenComedy,drama, romance,full of emotion,had me sobbing and laughing at the same time......and the storyline is great..... imagine meeting with your older self telling you stuff, what to do and what not to do...before any mistakes are made...,..that would be awesomennAnd I loventhat she had to re-think everything......and make things right before it was too late and before she hurt her loved onesnnMy old ass manages to show that the decisions you make as a teenager really needS one to be careful cause once you're older there's so much regret like you'll be asking yourself why did I ever do that.......

Story- PredictablenThe story follows a love triangle between a musician, a lawyer boys & a confused girl.nnThe story was predictable right from the first scene.
