Some scenes the writer had gone too dramatic which made emotional scenes look forced. The best part of screenplay was the chemistry between nandani & sam which was very good. The screenplay was too long for this shallow story thus many scenes make you feel bored.nnCharacters- AveragenSameer "Sam" Rossellini- He was student of nandani's father, learned music from him. He was shown very fun loving person, you will love his character initially in love story but after some time you will expect some amount of seriousness in his character. Even in emotional scenes his character didn't showed seriousness.nnNandani- She was daughter of teacher of sam. She was confused between her husband and lover. At some point you will either find her character illogical or you will hate her.nnVanraj- He was husband of nandani. He was shown very simple who can't sing but was very honest & a responsible husband. His character needed more attention especially his scenes with nandani.nnPundit darbar- He was father of nandani & a talented singer but was bounded by conservative thoughts & ideologies although he loved his daughter a lot.nnRest all characters just supported the story, not much focus was paid on them.nnPerformances- Above averagenSalman khan- He did a fabulous work as a lover. But lack of seriousness was a major drawback of his performance. Even in emotional scenes didn't worked.nnAishwary rai- Her performance was inconsistent, she aced in romantic scenes but in emotional scene her performance & dialogue delivery seemed too dramatic & forced emotional. But she looked extremely gorgeous.nnAjay devgan- His performance was good but was not satisfying due to his shallow character. But you will like his performance especially in emotional scenes.nnVikram gokhale- He did a good job in limited screen time.nnRest all performances were good as they did their respective parts well.nnDirection- Above averagenIn some scenes the director successfully conveyed what he wanted but in some parts he exaggerated which made certain parts too dramatic.nnEditing- NegligiblennDialogues- Nothing specialnnCinematography- GoodnnProduction value- Next levelnThe sets & costumes were excellent. All costumes were placed well researched.nnMusic and BGM- RemarkablenThe blend of traditional classical and modern music was superb. All songs were excellent.nnBGM was also good.nnIdeology- The main ideology writer wanted to convey was that it is easy to love, but it's more difficult as well as important to fulfill love. The character of vanraj taught us that you can win love even by remaining simple & grounded. Whole film revolved around this simple one line message.nnFinal verdict- The film had a shallow story along with above average performances. If you have lot of time then you can see this simple predictable love story of exceptional songs & lavish vintage sets. The film is contradictory to it's title where the girl gives her heart another time inspite giving before to another man. Average screenplay, predictable story along with rushed climax & good songs make this film a simple one time watch time pass film.nn1- Songsn1- Production value, sets & costumesn0.5- Directionn0.5- Cinematographyn0.5- Performancesn0.25- Screenplayn0.25- Ideology.

My Old Ass is a genre-bending coming-of-age story with a wild twist, directed by Megan Park. The film follows free-spirited Elliott (Maisy Stella), a teenager whose life takes an unexpected turn during her 18th birthday when a mushroom trip introduces her to a time-traveling version of herself-her 39-year-old "old ass" (played by Aubrey Plaza). What begins as a surreal encounter quickly turns into a hilarious and heartfelt journey as Elliott's older self starts dishing out unsolicited advice on love, family, and life choices, forcing young Elliott to rethink everything she thought she knew.nnPark, following up on her strong debut The Fallout, dives into absurdity with this sophomore film, blending stoner comedy, sci-fi, and emotional drama with just the right touch of Hallmark-style sentimentality. The small-town lake setting of Muskoka, Ontario, adds a postcard-perfect charm to the otherwise wacky narrative, creating a warm contrast to the film's offbeat humor and time-bending antics.nnMaisy Stella's portrayal of young Elliott captures the essence of teenage uncertainty and angst, while Aubrey Plaza's older Elliott injects the story with her signature dry wit and offbeat energy. Plaza's performance, which could have easily overshadowed the film, instead complements Elliott's more earnest journey, striking a balance between humor and heartfelt moments. Together, the two create a compelling dynamic that elevates the film beyond its quirky premise.nnWhile the film's surreal elements could have derailed into chaos, Park masterfully keeps things grounded, using the bizarre premise to enhance the emotional stakes. Elliott's internal struggles about growing up, love, and identity hit hard, and even though the film dips into melodrama, it maintains a level of authenticity that resonates.nnThe supporting cast adds depth to the film, though some characters feel underutilized. Elliott's best friend Ro (Kerrice Brooks) is unfortunately relegated to the role of a sounding board, and her story arc feels a bit underdeveloped. Percy Hynes White's charming portrayal of Chad, Elliott's summer love interest, brings added tension as Elliott's older self warns her against pursuing him, creating a tug-of-war between her past and future desires.nnDespite a few familiar tropes, My Old Ass delivers a delightful mix of laughs, emotional beats, and chaotic energy. The film's exploration of identity, time, and the messy transition into adulthood strikes a chord, and Park's playful mixing of genres keeps the ride enjoyable, even if not every element perfectly lands.nnWith its mix of sci-fi weirdness, heartfelt moments, and stoner comedy, My Old Ass will appeal to those looking for something unconventional but relatable. It's a sweet, funny, and sometimes nostalgic trip that punches with emotional force, often without you even realizing it. Though the film wraps up a little too quickly, it leaves a lasting impression-a fun, surprising, and emotional journey into the complicated world of growing up.l like it.

All four episodes are unrelated but have a common futuristic atmosphere, which means you may love one and hate another. At least I do.nnFirst episode: I loved it. The writers wanted a bit too much in one episode, but the romance was very sweet.nnSecond episode: Disliked, was I watching porn? Plus it came with a bad plot.nnThird: Religion and AI, very interesting philosophy.nnFourth: Best of the four. I loved a conversation between the two young girls. That Pang couldn't have sang her song, if Mook wouldn't have supported her and showed her strength. It seems we all have a purpose, some of us in the spotlight, and some of us are strongest behind the decor.nnAnd I was very pleased by this idea of a futuristic environmental crisis, not because it is nice, but it is creative.nnSince childhood I've been bombarded with either American or European movies, I love to get to know the Eastern influences. Yes, some aspects are unfamiliar to me, like acting style, but the more I watch it, the more I understand it, the more I enjoy its influence.

First Love Monster is a quirky romantic comedy about Kaho Nikaido, a high school girl who falls for Kanade Takahashi, a handsome boy who saves her life. She soon discovers Kanade is actually a 5th grader, despite his mature appearance. The series delivers absurd humor, comedic misunderstandings, and eccentric characters, but its premise and age gap dynamic can feel uncomfortable for some. With colorful visuals and over-the-top jokes, it's best suited for fans of unconventional and silly rom-coms. BUT, in my opinion it's very very very very not fits for meee. I like ((popcorn)) but an elementary childd?!

I'm a sucker for any horror film with a quirky angle, and at first Game of Death seems to fit squarely into that category.nnThinking it would be along the same lines as 2006's Stay Alive, 2022's GATLOPP or The Blackening (all mediocre movies themselves) I gave it a try... it wasn't.nnThe concept of all those films are largely the same, a game (be it board or video) seems innocent enough but actually has real life brutal consequences. Jumanji but with the horror turned all the way up.nnWhat Game of Death fails to do where they succeeded though, is to make the GAME an actual GAME.nnIn the others characters die because they get killed off in the game, or they refuse to bow to the very varied and interesting whims of the game they are playing, which gives them tailored 'missions' relating to their personalities and connections to other players.nnHere the game is a glorified countdown timer that takes a bit of their blood at the beginning.nnThat's it, the game is just 'kill people or your head will explode' which isn't really a game at all when you think about it.nnAnyway, outside of the main plot device being a bust, the characters are all terminally unlikable, there is a weird and unnecessary incest subplot, and it feels like the director has just picked up a copy of 'Babies first Camera Shots' and wants to try ALL of them.nnGame of Death's biggest sin though, is that it's just boring. Boring characters, boring use of a good concept, boring kills, boring conclusion and a boring post-scene that completely rips off Jumanji to set up a sequel that will never EVER be made.nnOh, and the WORST speech I think I've ever heard in all of recorded cinematography, where the final girl goes on for a good 3 minutes about how she's choosing life and all this nonsense, mere moments after deciding her life wasn't more important than other innocent people's lives.nnYou can tell the writer really thought they'd hit a home run with this hokey, bloated diatribe, but it just comes across an cringey and... you guessed it; boring.nnThe gore effects on the head explosions ARE good, but then there's a scene where a guy has been cut in two and the effects there look like a primary school painting. Sadly it is one of the best parts of the movie.nnMy advice would be to watch one of the other films I mentioned, you might have a moderately better time.

There are way more better ways to execute an artist biopic movie than this one. I cannot take this movie seriously and I can't even take the positive 10/10 reviews seriously because they really seem AI generated, which further raises my suspicion on the rating of this movie.nnI get the innovative idea of putting a CGI monkey as a main character and expecting the audience to develop a connection with it but in this case it seems it just doesn't work. (It was more laughable and most parts I couldn't really take seriously). The humour is really stale and way more sexually oriented than I expected. It was unfunny and in some parts just plain weird, considering the main character is a monkey.nnThis movie doesn't seem genuine and I see it as a way for Robbie Williams to further feed his ego. His hungry ego is clearly the main template for this movie. It is so selfish to the point where I don't believe some of these things ever happened and he just made it up to seem as the bigger man. The movie is solely focused on him being the victim and choosing extreme self-destructive behavior, which is shown way too often, despite getting everything he ever wanted. In some scenes this is just too obvious and it starts to get obnoxious really quickly, at moments even tiring considering that this movie has a runtime of 2 hours and 15 minutes. Some scenes really got me scratching my head and I couldn't understand how you even come up with that and be satisfied with the outcome (Knebworth performance), and some scenes really seem added additionally to complete the plot.nnThe ending, although I found it okay, left some things to be desired and it felt a little bit worn out and boring.nnThe only reason I'm not giving this movie a 1* review is because of the animation team, which did a great job, especially in certain scene transitions.nnAs mentioned, the movie just serves as an ego boost for Robbie and lacks depth, which is the reason why I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone who wants to take it seriously.

I've actually created my IMDB account only for this review. I thought that this series must have at least a bit of quality, which of course, it did. Like already written in the description, this TV Show change my life in a short period of time. I binged all four seasons and it was a blast. Finally i found a TV show that I could really connect to. Action, story, quality, it has it all in this 25 minute SFM animation. A very tense and engaging experience from start to finish, this episode is the greatest in the series. The fact that this was all made in an older generation free animation software is insane, the visuals look spectaculare and the animations smooth. All the world-building built-up to this episode makes this feel like a finale. All the sudden plot-twists make many things you think you know about the series and destroy it. The cliffhanger ending is perfect and keeps you engaged for the next episode to release. In conclusion, this is a masterpiece of animation filled with plot-twists, action, and story that is executed perfectly.

The acting was very good. Rosalind Eleazer is compelling, that's why it got 7* from me. I didn't want to take my eyes off her character. Ashley Walters, Mary Malone, Jessica Plumber and others were all very good too. The mysteries in Kat's personal life did keep me interested enough to keep "turning the page." And I was not correct about my guess as to what happened in her very messy past, which is good. That part was interesting. But somehow the central police mystery fell totally flat. The evil people were a bit chilling but the investigation wasn't. They were smart to limit it to 5 episodes, it was the right length. Honestly, it's fine, a good quick binge for mystery fans.

'Into the Spiderverse' (2018) caused a paradigm shift in animation, best described in Arcane's context as a 'Glorious Evolution'nn2010 and forward, animation geared toward more realism, making selling points out of realistic hair, clothing and even water and sand physics. Meanwhile, 2D animation adhered mostly to it's tried and tested aesthetic, with CGI being used to enhance instead of making it 3D. This holds true for other forms of animation - like stop motion.nnThe Spiderverse films broke tradition and combined these elements. The goal is to make it look like hand drawn pages of a comic book come to life. The outcome was distinct. The 2D and CGI elements blended seamlessly and created its own style. It proved that 'visually stunning' is not how close you can get to mimic reality, but how beautiful the outcome despite mixing mediums.nnTo be fair, Some Spiderverse scenes also look like real skylines and streets. Proving that realism can still be conjured even if it isn't entirely 3D. The industry followed and this 'style' popped more often.nnArcane essentially perfected this. It's 3D but everything is made to look like a painting - because they are ACTUALLY painted in production. Special effects, explosions and gases, more often than not, take a 2D-cartoon form, juxtaposing the 3D characters. The show is one of the best-looking animated series to date - with every frame literally a painting.nnFortiche Production, the French studio responsible for animating the series is a frequent collaborator of Riot - the game company. If it was not yet known, Arcane is based on 'League of Legends', one of the most popular video games, which is also a world-renowned E-Sport. While Austin is more familiar with League's main rival, Dota 2, there is no denying League's reach and popularity. Their World Championships are as big as sports events, and Fortiche are usually commissioned to make music videos for promotion. This is also why each episode of Arcane itself contains at least one dialogue-less sequence that flows like a music video. Musicians featured are not to be taken lightly as well, because Grammy-winning bands abound the soundtrack - namely Linkin Park, Imagine Dragons and Twenty One Pilots.nnFast forward to 2024 - Arcane's overwhelming success translated to it becoming the new canon lore instead of being a spin-off game companion. While this move gained mixed reception from the actual gamers, it is further proof that the series is just on another level. It drew a global audience, with some having no idea that it's based on a game.nnArcane's success is not only from its beautiful animation, or billboard nominated OSTs. Its narrative goes far beyond what is expected of a video game tie-in. The initial set up of pitting the rich city of Piltover and the oppressed undercity of Zaun has already enough allegorical power to draw audiences, but the main focus on tragic characters from both sides and the details surrounding their motivations, permits them to stay till the very end.nnArcane circulates its main themes on love and connection, parenthood and family, violence and vengeance, transformation and forgiveness. The series boasts accolades such as a 100% critic score for Rotten Tomatoes and the second season being the only tv series in IMDB with each episode scoring 9 and above as of this writing. It's also a recipient of a Primetime Emmy Award and dominated the Annie Awards for television series for its first season in 2022.nnHowever, despite season two having a better overall rating than season one, there's a fair share of criticisms thrown upon it that started when claims circulated online that it's 5-season plan was shortened due to the costs bloating to 250 million dollars - prompting writers and artists to shorten sequences and plotlines. This remains unproven, and can be a premature miscommunication of the actual announcement that the series will expand into other regions and stories.nnEven then, for us, everything set in the first season all fell into place as intended. Maybe people just wanted more of Arcane and we could not blame them. Nevertheless "there is beauty in imperfections" clich√© as it may be, it more or less applies to Arcane whether or not season two did have its issues.nnThe character Victor further expresses through dialogue that "there is no price to perfection...only an end to pursuit" Whatever it's circumstances, Arcane currently has no equal. A true triumph of a show.

My Old Ass is a coming of age story that merges elements of a stoner comedy with some low tech time travel to great effect. It's so funny and easy to like but its greatest strength comes from the emotional core and the beautiful messages which come from it. It's a winning argument about how life is messy, scary and full of extremely painful heartbreak however, that only makes it all the more important to take the risks and enjoy the best moments. I felt belonging especially when I was leaving my home town Harare Zimbabwe üáøüáº to go for college in Bulawayo. The feeling of leaving my teenage friends loved ones and even my family members.

The movie is amazing. Megan has an amazinga taste when she writes. Beautiful filmnMy Old Ass is a coming of age story that merges elements of a stoner comedy with some low tech time travel to great effect. It's so funny and easy to like but its greatest strength comes from the emotional core and the beautiful messages which come from it. It's a winning argument about how life is messy, scary and full of extremely painful heartbreak however, that only makes it all the more important to take the risks and enjoy the best moments.nnMaisy Stella gives an amazing lead performance, starting off unaware of what she's about to leave behind which allows her to grow over the course of the film and her internal struggles as she discovers new things about herself unfold in a really earnest fashion. Aubrey Plaza is only on screen for two scenes and it's so impressive how funny she is in the first one and how much emotion she brings to the second. Percy Hynes White nails his part as someone who is supposed to be a red flag but his actions only confirm the opposite.nnAs writer & director Megan Park delivers a breezily entertaining film that consistently looks nice thanks to its scenic locations and ability to hone in on the smaller details that mean everything before delivering a well earned emotional gut punch at the end. All the dialogue feels authentic without ever coming across as unintentionally awkward and there's a lot of fun to be had in catching the small details Aubrey Plaza lets slip about this version of the future.

As a Canadian who saw this all unfold on the news and the documentaries that followed, and a true horror movie fan of 30+ years, I can't say anything good about this movie! Let me be blunt, there was NO 'comedy' in the real-life story of Robert 'Willie' Pickton, or his 20-some known victims (or.49 according to Pickton's confessions). I'm sure the victim's families would agree with that statement and I hope they never see this movie. This movie makes a farce out of the murders and how they were carried out. In my opinion, I find Jake Busey to be a mediocre actor at best, not to mention he looks nothing like Picton, so I did not like him in this role at all. If your lead actor falls short, the rest of the cast is simply there to pick up the pieces.nnThere were no 'pretty people' in Picton's life or among his victim's, everything was a depraved, filthy, slimy, drug and alcohol fueled nightmare, from his pig farm, to Hastings street in Vancouver and the prostitutes he murdered. Picton lived his life on the dark seedy underside of the actual dark seedy underside. You can't use the term 'based on true events' and miss ALL the true events, or downplay the most horrid of them. If properly told, depicted and acted, Picton's story would make Leatherface look like an overgrown man-child running amuck with an electric carving knife. Picton picked up prostitutes, drifters and junkies, he had sex with them, drugged them, tortured some of them, enslaved some of them, killed, bled out, skinned and dismembered them and fed almost all of them to his pigs to cover up his crimes. Somebody should have fed the film/footage of this movie to pigs, to cover up how awful it is.

Crimson Echo is one of the most powerful experiences of film that I've had in a long while. This comes from both the force of its message and from the tension with the constraints of its chosen medium. The execution as a generative work using extremely optimized visual media makes every minute gesture resound. The use of a decentralized blockchain (a censorship-resistant infrastructure) also lends force to the subversion of censorship -- a central theme for this film's topic, which has been widely censored and suppressed by mainstream media as well as social media algorithms and public discourse in general.nnIndeed, Chainleft makes every element of the film's medium speak -- the technical, the aesthetic, the conceptual, the social, the aural. It interconnects all of these through its execution like a fractal seed.nnThis is a film that illuminates not only a dire humanitarian issue, but also offers structures that can serve to change the underlying conditions that have allowed it to unfold. In its release mechanism, it wields the financialized nature of blockchains to accrue donations for Gazan relief. It connects with a broad group of people who would otherwise be ambivalent or even resistant to supporting this cause by using its mastery of a technology they are engaged/invested in to capture their interest and respect, and it then channels this toward its activist aim.nnThis execution, however, would not matter unless it communicates its message experientaly in film, and it does this with a poetic and resoundingly heartfelt force.

This is absolutely amazing, me and my friend sat and watched the whole thing in our sixth form common room during our frees. The story line is so beautiful yet leaves on on edge with the bone shaking plot twists. Absolute cinematic masterpiece from reelshorts and i haven't been blessed with such cinema in years. I need this injected into my bloodstream and then i'll die happy.nnLucas is sexy, the tension between him and emma is just riveting. I felt it in my toes.nnOverall: no work done -> but my life has been changed and no amount of revision could do what that show did to me.nnI blame you ben armstrong.

Taylor Sheridan writes cookie cutter shows - once again here he is pandering to a certain segment that like toxic masculinity and believes women are here to serve men. The eye candy is nice but like other viewers I was creeped out about the daughter. Shades of pedophilia here? Portraying her as a 17 year old. The ONLY reason I watched after that episode was when I saw the actor was actually 28 years old. Then there's the recycled characters, the son with a heart of gold getting involved with and 'saving' the poor but beautiful and tough indigenous (Yellowstone), or here Mexican, girl. Where have I seen this before? However Billy Bob is entertaining and it feels like he's in on the joke. I expect him to wink at the camera at any moment. I want to hate Taylor Sheridan shows but they are addictive.nnYellowstone was unnecessarily violent and as unrealistic as a show can be. What 5 or 6 ranch hands for thousands of acres and how many animals? We have two horses and it's all two of us can handle with 7 acres. They couldn't even portray mucking stalls accurately. Now we have oil workers who can't operate a pipe wrench. SMH.nnI won't watch Tulsa King because I hate Stallone. 1883 was ok. I couldn't handle 1923 after the first episode. I did just (barely) make it through Lioness season 1 thanks to Zoe Salda√±a but the level in of violence in that makes me wonder if Mr Sheridan knows his audience or if there's really something wrong with him. And again with the absurdity on the shootout at the last episode of season 1. 1970's era security team that couldn't hit the side of a barn.nnBut yes here I am, still watching. Though not as bad as Suits with the most lazy writing I've ever seen in my life, I was able to say the lines before the characters they were repeated so often.

Sometimes I try to imagine a show's creators meeting with a network to discuss their pitch ideas. This is what I figure Evil went like.nnNETWORK: We are big fans of your previous work. The Good Wife, The Good Fight. What do you have for us today?nnCREATORS: Well, get this, we are thinking... X Files but ...with a Catholic and Supernatural twist.nnNETWORK: Wow... We're liking it, we're liking it. Right everybody? Go on.nnCREATORS: Well, we're thinking an African American priest, a POC tech guy and a female psychologist.nnNETWORK: Yep, that should work in today's climate. Our peers will like that. And with X Files, there seemed to be a kind of monster of the week. Same idea here, we're guessing.nnCREATORS: Yep. But the thing is, there will be no explanation or follow-through on any of the monsters or events. They are assessors, these three and they assess and then the next assessment comes and... like you know, poof, goldfish memory... onto the next.nnNETWORK: Okay... so to get this straight, they, the monsters, the creepy stuff... just appear and go away and nothing much changes?nnCREATORS: Exactly.nnNETWORK: Well, you have to give the audience something. Something. You know, with the X Files there was a feeling of ... what's the word... (snapping their fingers, pointing to an intern. The Intern cautiously says 'closure') Yes, that's it! Thanks, Chloe. Closure! (The intern reminds them her name is Madison. They wave her off.)nnCREATORS: Nope. We'll just leave some episode endings hanging. Nothing... no closure or really any sense of moral. There will be one episode with a jinn and his head is on fire and Kristen will be playing with the idea of having a one-night stand and then the next episode, reset. Like, The Simpsons. And plot threads as well, we'll abandon a few of those, too.nnNETWORK EXEC (holding an overview): It says here you plan one episode where a wife turns to salt. To salt? Like in the Bible. Oh, Catholic thingie... got it! And her husband. What happens to him after this?nnCREATORS shrug: Who knows? Nothing?nnNETWORK EXECS (sharing looks): Well, that might be... okay...um tell us about these characters.nnCREATORS: You know how in some shows where a character can be honest and foster communcation and solve their problems and resolve misunderstandings but they don't and it annoys the audience and it just goes on and on. We're going to do that a lot. We mean, a lot, a lot.nnNETWORK: Frustrating the audience for the sake of drama, okay, good for binge watching should it get streamed. It worked for Downton Abbey.nnCREATORS: For instance, the female character, her name is Kristen and her mother is single and dating Kristen's arch enemy. This arch enemy is like Hannibal Lector but if he looked like a nerd. Well, he threatens Kristen and her family and the mother starts dating him. All Kristen has to do is tell her mother: this man has threatened your granddaughters' lives but nope... she doesn't and it goes on, unrealistically for a long time. That's the basic idea.nnNETWORK: And these granddaughters? What's their deal?nnCREATORS: Four of them. They will be adorable but constantly talking over each other, screaming and it will be really annoying but we won't do anything about it. Because, you know...nnNETWORK: And Kristen, what's her background?nnCREATORS: She was a mountain climber and a doctor. And she is in her early thirties. Maybe forties. She is slim and pretty. That's important and she's intelligent. And she's not a man.nnNETWORK: Okay, well... a mountain climber, now a doctor. When did she get time to climb mountains, become a doctor and have four kids?nnCREATORS (blinking, silence).nnNETWORK: And the other two characters. This POC tech guy.nnCREATORS: He will be the skeptic and comic relief, a non-believer and then he will believe. Like Kristen, a demon will visit him. Oh yeah, Kristen has this demon named George that appears in her dreams.nnNETWORK: Does she talk to the priest about this demon?nnCREATORS: They don't really talk about much stuff that is supernatural in their lives. Again, no one is honest with each other. Like, Kristen, this one bad guy - a non-POC - is threatening her family and the police, of course, are on the bad guy's side... because... plot says so and Kristen, instead of getting help, she unalives him.nnNETWORK: I am sure you can say the 'k' word here.nnCREATORS: Anyway... and then she has this dark side.nnNETWORK: Where did that come from?nnCREATORS: Unclear. Maybe it's the arch nemesis. We're still trying to figure stuff out. The nerd has power and maybe he doesn't. We'll keep audiences guessing. Again, drama. Another example: the one associate points out she has blood on her leg and instead of saying, 'oh I cut myself shaing', which most normal and careful people hiding a crime would do,but nope, Kristen gives him enough to suspect her... because... you know... plot.nnNETWORK: For a woman who climbed mountains, you think she would be more careful. Okay, and this priest? Tell us about him.nnCREATORS: We're going to make sure his stories involve politically correct subjects.nnNETWORK: Great, we need that. We need to divide our viewership even more.nnCREATOR: And he is super attractive. Like an American Idris Alba.nnNETWORK: As long as the non-POC and straight men look less intelligent, all the better. And with the police, make sure the detectives are women and the one male detective is incompetent and shown sleeping on the job. We need that.nnCREATORS: We got you covered. But all this won't be so on the nose like in our show The Good Fight. We will make it subtle so certain people don't turn it off.nnNETWORK: As long as a certain bunch of people not on our political side feel uncomfortable, we're happy. Anything else?nnCREATORS: Did we mention the granddaughters are annoying and we won't do anything about it?nnNETWORK: Yep. And that characters refuse to be honest with each other for the sake of drama. And with our casting, Rotten Tomatoes will sure give us a Fresh Score. Let's get thing going. Green light it!

"My Old Ass" explores themes of aging, love, and the human condition, as Stella embarks on a journey of self-discovery and redemption. Through a series of poignant and often humorous moments, the film examines the complexities of life and the importance of living with purpose and passion, even in the face of adversity.nnOverall, "My Old Ass" is a heartwarming and thought-provoking film that offers a fresh and insightful perspective on the challenges and joys of growing older. With its strong performances and nuanced storytelling, the film is sure to leave a lasting impression on audiences of all ages.

Ubisoft finally learned to make good games. The plot is very breathtaking, it doesn't even feel like you're playing a video game because of how much it pulls you into it's world. The classic characters return and Mayro goes on yet another unforgettable adventure, which is something professional writers can't even do these days anymore. Really, really, really, really, really, really solid game! And the music, it's literal perfection, been vibin' to the music all day and all night because it's so majestic. Thank you Koji Kondom, you worked hard on contributing to this masterpiece of a modern video game.

I'm surprised no other has seen nine queens is actually a spin-off, or, better, a parody of "House of Games". The analysis of the differences between the two movies is a very interesting subject i submit to all imdb addicts and con-movies experts. I have to admit that, following Mamet's plot, i fell in bielinsky's trap exactly as i suspect he expected me to_"Nine Queens: A Twisty, Turning Argentinean Heist Movie"_nn"Nine Queens" (2000) is a critically acclaimed Argentinean heist movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Directed by Fabi√°n Bielinsky, this film is a masterclass in storytelling, with a complex web of twists and turns that will keep you guessing until the very end.nnThe movie follows two small-time con artists, Juan (Gast√≥n Pauls) and Marcos (Ricardo Dar√≠n), who team up to sell a set of rare stamps, known as the "Nine Queens," to a wealthy collector. However, things quickly become complicated as the two men find themselves caught up in a complex scheme involving forgery, theft, and deception.nnThe film's strength lies in its clever script, which is full of unexpected twists and turns. Just when you think you know what's going on, the story takes a sudden turn, keeping you on your toes. The film's pacing is also expertly handled, with a slow-burning tension that builds to a thrilling climax.nnThe cast is also excellent, with standout performances from Pauls and Dar√≠n. The chemistry between the two leads is palpable, and their banter adds a welcome layer of humor to the film.nnOverall, "Nine Queens" is a must-see for fans of heist movies and crime thrillers. With its clever script, expert pacing, and strong performances, this film is a true gem of Argentinean cinema.nnIf you enjoy movies like "The Usual Suspects," "Ocean's Eleven," or "The Sting," you'll love "Nine Queens." So, grab some popcorn, sit back, and get ready for a wild ride!

"My Old Ass" is a gentle, moving, and light sci-fi coming-of-age story that will leave you breathless. The film follows Elliot, a sarcastic Canadian teen lesbian, who meets her 39-year-old self, and it's a game-changer. With a perfect blend of heartwarming and heart-wrenching moments, this movie will take you on an emotional rollercoaster ¬π.nnMaisy Stella shines as Elliot, bringing to life a character that's both relatable and authentic. Her performance is supported by an incredible cast, including Aubrey Plaza, who plays Older Elliot with her signature wit and charm. Maisy Stella's performance is captivating, conveying a mix of emotions - curiosity, fear, and wonder - as she confronts her older self.

Actor Lee Min-ho, what kind of person are you?? How perfectionist you are! OMG, I'm so proud of you, how from time to time you always choose amazing projects. After falling in love with the super excellent "Pachinko", I can't help myself from two timing this feeling because I'm falling in love like crazy with this new one.. the feeling of "Je t'aime passionnement a la folie".nnJust like "Pachinko" that has unique opening, I also like the fresh opening of "When the Stars Gossip".nnIt's a rare series that we can't blink our eyes while watching it or we want to repeat some scenes we might not watch carefully because each scene is so well made.nnIt's the combination of delicate artistic surprises.. so beautiful like we were in an art exhibition feeling, and the promising intriguing story in which each character has their own sides of lives to understand and psychological layers to study. It's promising because I like to study the psychological layers of the characters while connecting them to the thread of their life backgrounds.nnI believe it's gonna be a rich experience following this series to the end. I have a positive feeling it's a masterpiece.

Forrest Gump is my 4th favorite movie.nnI'll start with the bad part. The screenwriting. It is pretty corny. Especially the John Lennon part or the KKK part.nnOnto the good stuff. The whole thing is beautifully shot. The shot where Jennay' and Forrest are walking past the Lincoln Memorial or when Forrest is running across Americuh'.nnSecondly, Eric Roth (screenwriter) gives us a huge reason to root for Forrest. He doesn't just shove the fact that he is disadvantaged at every given moment. Instead, we are shown a man with infinite determination to achieve his purpose in life, end up with Jennay'.nnThirdly, the stories that Forrest has to tell are extremely captivating. From Vietnam to ping pong to meeting Elvis as a child (Forrest is the child) to literally reporting the break-in at Watergate. I was not on the edge of my seat, I could've fallen off.nnFinally, and most importantly, the characters. Bubba is a great friend but Lieutenant Dan is the star of the show. He is extremely entertaining and even goes through a character arc which I will not spoil.nn8/10. Amazing movie.

This is yet another movie that tries to give metaphorical meaning to turning into an animal. I mean, it probably was that all along, but in this day and age, when you see there is a movie about someone turning into an animal and tagged horror and body horror you expect some were-action. But no, other than some slightly nauseating scenes of body hair, which are still less horrible than the birth scene at the end, this film is all about motherhood.nnAnd I liked that it portrayed the good and the bad, the frustrations of and the unfairness towards women and pregnant women in particular, but also how their whining sometimes crosses the mark into self-absorption an bitchy preaching. Meanwhile the working dad, "mansplaining" (god, I hate this word, it's so dumb) and having a much better time without realizing it, yet still complaining, comes off as out of touch and insensitive, only to be shown to regret being blind to things and having his own feelings and frustrations to overcome. The interaction with "the other moms" was also nicely done, switching from a general dislike and lack of empathy to realizing they were probably feeling the same way themselves.nnThe dog thing... I don't know what to say. Apparently Amy Adams is cute even in dog form, but other than that it felt just a little bit gimmicky. It's true that I wouldn't have watched the film without Amy Adams in it and the promise of some fantastic elements, but I still feel cheated. Same applies to the sweaty dirty sexy Adams on the posters, when she is an overweight mommy throughout the film. BTW, her transformation in the film is dramatic. I don't know if she gained weight for this or it was more on the prosthetics side, but she embodied postpartum mom.nnBottom line: I have not read the book this is based on, so I don't know how good of an adaption it is, but it felt like a serious film, done with care and carried really well by all actors involved. I didn't love it, but also I can see how this is good. I will rate it average, though, because of the gimmick and poster bait and switch thing. People should not be lured to see a film they did not intend to watch.

"I'm Still Here" tells a tragic story that took place during the Brazilian military dictatorship in an engaging way. Alongside the protagonist, Eunice Paiva, played in an exemplary manner by Fernanda Torres, we see the emotions, anguish and violence of the regime, in the daily life of a family that lives with the absence of Rubens Paiva, who was arrested and killed by the dictatorship. The work is a journey through time, which made me reflect in the cinema after the film, while crying pitifully. For its exemplary direction, for the emotions represented and for the plot, which recalls democracy as a project that resists violence, this film is a rare gem, which deserves to be seen by everyone, especially Brazilians.

This is the best series of this franchise , well I guess Yellowstone is #1 but this is def #2 a million times better than the other run off show they did. It def doesn't compare to this one. Was really disappointed that they didn't continue with it, I mean I guess cause the girl died ? But still would have loved to see more of this one :( it was SO GOOD. Everything about it, especially the actors that they casted for this series. All around good show. It's always the good ones that don't get more seasons. Or don't care to make it more than one season. As a "limited series" which is poop if you ask me. 10/10 recommend.

We truly don't understand the general rating of 8. The acting felt mediocre, more suited to a B-movie. The storyline (or the acting) was totally not at the same level as the movies with Tom Cruise and packed with clich√©s, making it hard to enjoy it. However, since most of the other comments are overwhelmingly positive, we have to conclude that this just wasn't our thing. That said, we rely on IMDb reviews to choose what to watch, so hopefully, this kind of disappointment won't happen again. Surprised that the bodyguard received the same rating as totally another league of acting and story. Bizarre rating.

Outlander is a time-traveling romance series that has captivated audiences worldwide. The show follows Claire Randall, a nurse during World War II, who finds herself transported back to 1743 Scotland. There, she becomes entangled in the Jacobite uprising and falls in love with the charming Jamie Fraser.nn*The Verdict*nnOutlander has received widespread critical acclaim for its unique blend of romance, drama, and historical fiction. The show boasts a 90% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with praise for its lush scenery, engaging storyline, and strong performances from the cast, particularly Caitriona Balfe and Sam Heughan ¬π.nn*What Works*nn- _Timeless romance_: The chemistry between Claire and Jamie is undeniable, making their love story a compelling centerpiece of the show.nn- _Historical accuracy_: Outlander meticulously recreates 18th-century Scotland, immersing viewers in the sights, sounds, and politics of the time.nn- _Strong female lead_: Claire is a smart, resourceful, and independent protagonist who drives the story forward with her courage and determination.nn*What Doesn't*nn- _Graphic content_: Some viewers may find the show's depiction of violence, rape, and other mature themes disturbing or off-putting.nn- _Pacing issues_: A few episodes can feel slow or unevenly paced, particularly in the early seasons.nnOverall, Outlander is a must-watch for fans of historical fiction, romance, and drama. With its captivating storyline, memorable characters, and stunning scenery, it's no wonder the show has become a global phenomenon ¬≤.

This film is so sexist. There are tons of misandrist "jokes", which have the energy of those people who say something offensive that they clearly believe, and then try to justify it with "it was just a joke" when challenged. Mulan's community at the start of the film seem more concerned about her getting married and having babies than being happy. I thought this would change when it became clear that Mulan didn't fit in, or at least when she returned home as a war hero at the end, but nope. It's never really challenged. We're meant to forgive Shang for being angry at Mulan and leaving her behind for being a woman, even though he never really does anything to redeem himself. There are some visually impressive moments and one good song, and it does seem like they *tried* to give it a satisfying ending, but this film mostly just made me angry. I also hear that it's racist, but I don't know enough about Chinese culture or history to confirm or deny that.

"My Old Ass" (2024) is a cinematic masterpiece that will leave audiences in stitches and introspection. This film is a beautifully crafted exploration of life, love, and self-discovery.nnThe film's narrative is expertly woven, seamlessly balancing humor and poignancy. The protagonist's journey is relatable, endearing, and hilarious, making it easy to become fully invested in their story.nnThe acting performances in "My Old Ass" are phenomenal. The cast delivers nuanced, authentic portrayals that bring depth and complexity to the film. Their chemistry on screen is undeniable, making every interaction feel genuine and engaging.nnOne of the standout aspects of "My Old Ass" is its thoughtful and realistic portrayal of relationships. The film tackles themes of family, friendship, and romance with sensitivity and humor, avoiding clich√©s and stereotypes.nnThe movie's tone is impeccably balanced, shifting effortlessly between laugh-out-loud moments and poignant introspection. The pacing is well-balanced, with a narrative that flows smoothly and keeps viewers engaged.nnThe cinematography and production design are also noteworthy, adding to the film's overall charm and character. The visuals are stunning, with a keen attention to detail that immerses viewers in the world of the story.nnOverall, "My Old Ass" (2024) is a triumph. With its talented cast, clever writing, and thoughtful direction, this film is sure to resonate with audiences. If you're.

This movie could've been really good, but it spends a lot of its (already short) runtime showing off the designs of the ghosts and sets, and as a result the plot, pacing and characterization really suffer. We never really find out why Adam and Barbara, or even Lydia, dislike Lydia's family so much. We as the audience are meant to dislike them because they're rich and entitled, but do the other characters have the same reasoning? Who knows! Lydia clearly feels different from other people and at points seems to genuinely want to die, but we never find out why beyond her being goth (or something similar) and considering herself "strange and unusual". Then at the end she suddenly seems happy and to fit in with other teenagers, despite not much in her life really having changed. I have no idea if she was meant to have being going through a 'not like the other girls' phase and the ending shows her growing out of it, if the film thinks it's cool to be 'not like the other girls', or if the filmmakers genuinely believed that every goth and/or teenager is suicidal and socially isolated. Because they never tell us! This leaves Lydia feeling very undeveloped, which is a big problem with the other characters too. Adam and Barbara aren't developed beyond 'nice couple who feel protective of Lydia', Lydia's parents are never developed beyond 'rich entitled people', and Beetlejuice is never developed beyond 'perverted ghost'. The film is paced messily too. Adam and Barbara dying and Lydia moving in is rushed over, the ghosts trying to scare the humans away is dragged out, and the characters preventing the wedding near the end is rushed, and it's not even clarified how Barbara was able to control the sandworm and get it back to the house to defeat Beetlejuice. Adam and Barbara's relationship with Lydia is sweet, but like the characters it's underdeveloped.nnI guess this film is loved because of its creative character design for the ghosts and set design for the afterlife, and because people find it funny (the humour isn't to my taste personally) but I was disappointed that such a beloved film didn't have stronger plot and characterization.

A Small Light (2023) is a poignant American series that recounts the harrowing tale of the Frank family during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands. The series shines a spotlight on Miep Gies, the brave and compassionate woman who risked her life to shelter the Frank family and other Jews in a hidden annex. Through its deeply emotional narrative, the series portrays the resilience of those facing unimaginable oppression and the humanity of those who sought to help them.nnThe series effectively conveys the plight of the Jewish people during the Holocaust, drawing viewers into the raw, heartbreaking reality of their hidden existence. It evokes powerful emotions, making it difficult not to feel the weight of their suffering and the courage of those like Miep who stood against tyranny.nnWhile A Small Light serves as a reminder of the atrocities faced by Jews during World War II, it also invites reflection on how historical narratives can shape perceptions. In the context of modern conflicts like Gaza and Israel, the series raises questions about how the legacy of victimhood and resilience can be overshadowed by actions that diverge from those values.nnThe series succeeds in highlighting the universal themes of compassion, courage, and the fight against injustice, while subtly urging viewers to consider how historical narratives and contemporary realities intersect.

Super dumb story with awful actors performance.nnEvery scene is like a something that is played without any motivation. Just told they lines and that's it.nnOnly the two artists is actually played (the sick villain and the villains in the gallery) The scenario of the whole story is without any clever path.nnThe "Aqua" character is absolutely unnecessary.nnThe color combinations for the scenes are super cool looking but this will not help to the limited series to become a masterpiece.nnDetective without gun chasing a van with villains... guys this is ridiqulous. I prefer not watch any other movie from that screen play writer.

I have never seen a film as relentlessly uncompromising about the allure, power, and banality of the con game as I have seen in the Argentine 'Nine Queens.' From the opening sequence where small-time grifter Juan pulls a $20 switch at a convenience store to the final scam that looks like 'House of Cards' and 'The Sting' welded onto 'Hard Eight,' nothing is as it seems and no one can be trusted.nnMore recently think of 'Sexy Beast,' 'The Heist,' and 'The Score.' However this is David Mamet territory, where buddies keep one eye on the target and the other on the buddy.nnIn the current 'Enron' environment, no surprise at the allegorical suggestion of this film that trust is a rare commodity these days, banks are vulnerable (consider the Argentinean economy), and lame goddess Nemesis may never catch up with some of business's most egregious con artists, from CEO's to salespeople.nnThe film's pace is quick, like the hands of 3-card Monte; emotional involvement either on the screen or in the audience is minimal; everyone has a moment of triumph and defeat. Even beauty has its deceptive moment when Leticia Bredice, as the sister of other con artist Ricardo Darin, struts her stuff in the hotel lobby.

A delightful twist on a classic trope-where an older self meets their younger counterpart and dispenses advice-unexpectedly turned out to be a film I thoroughly enjoyed. In "My Old Ass," we meet Elliot, an eighteen-year-old gay girl eager to escape her family's cranberry farm. One night, after tripping on mushrooms, she encounters her future self, a relaxed thirty-nine-year-old woman. Elliot is left bewildered: is she hallucinating? Can this easy-going woman really be her two decades ahead? As the older version shares details about her college life and future relationships, she warns Elliot about a guy she should steer clear of.nnThe film balances humor and heart, combining silly moments with poignant ones. Young Elliot, played beautifully by Maisy Stella, spends time with friends, shares sweet yet innocent moments with her boyfriend, connects with her family, and faces the arrival of The New Boy in Town (portrayed by the talented Percy Hynes White), which disrupts her final carefree weeks before college. Some scenes will bring smiles, while others may bring tears; a particularly touching moment occurs between Elliot and her mother, who already feels the ache of missing her.nnStarting as a light-hearted comedy, "My Old Ass" evolves into a sensitive exploration of a young woman at a pivotal point in her life. By the end, it becomes one of the most insightful and impactful films I've seen this year. Aubrey Plaza delivers her usual subtly expressive performance as the older Elliot, and the stunning Canadian landscape almost feels like a character itself. This film is definitely worth watching.

column3: "Quiet on Set: The Dark Side of Kids TV" (2024)
column4: These children went through fire and decided to stand up and say enough. No child should endure horrendous sa or horrendous racial abuse. The courage, the strength, it made me cry, and it gives me hope that the future will be better. As truth bubbles to the surface, creating ripples of change that turn into waves of change.nnTrauma incorporates into every aspect of life. I know that pain, how it affects family, friends, life and it changes everything. I had to face my own monster and it took 5 years in court, multiple restraining orders, defamation lawsuit, and no matter how many people I warned that he wouldn't stop at one victim they didn't listen until the wake up call was another victim. It breaks my heart thinking of others going through this too, because no one should have to go through this.nnDrake you are brave, those people are fools on the wrong side just like you said, it is okay to break down/to cry/to not want to feel, trauma is incredibly difficult to process. Yet you have so much life left, and no one can steal your joy; don't let them. Never fall for the trap of becoming what you hate to understand why. Instead face what you hate and say You can't live here any more, I won't allow you to steal my life, my happiness, my joy, my future. Thank you for speaking up. I know it is so so difficult, but Thank you.

I watched this again yesterday for the first time in a long time. I had vague memories of great set pieces and loads of action.nnThis was clearly a series of 6 or 7 action sequences that were strung together with a 'story'. These action sequences are amazing, over the top, from shot outs on the highway to chased through flavellas, all bonkers, all ridiculously enjoyable.nnWhat I had not considered was the totally irresponsible filmmaking; almost soft core porn set ups in nightclubs showing how sexy it is to take ecstasy. Beautiful looking people French kissing their E's from one mouth to another, mmm.nnSmith and Lawrence are great reprising their original roles, their natural rapport comes across. However so many scenes are just pointless and don't serve a purpose, giving a young man abuse and threatening him with a gun for daring to take out Marcus' daughter, the scene in the tv store that they discuss the injury to Marcus' backside which blatantly plays up to homosexuality.nnAll in all a very confusing movie which could and should have been managed by adults rather than just letting Bay go daft.

From episode one I should have stopped watching. The whole thing is nonsense. Since when do a crime unit go to crime and decide to take the IT guy with on his first day, lol. I am sure the book is much and way better. The idea is good, acting is okay too. But the way it is put together on film makes me laugh. If this was a comedy it would be more fun. The kid in the van, his mom telling him to run and he keeps going to the van. The dog with the stick haha... The lady with the axe, its all so stupid.. If I am the bad guy the first thing i do is grab the axe away, not pull the phone from the wall. Its so distracting when every scene is done so badly.

I enjoyed watching the film, but I literally lost the plot and could not wait to jump onto IDMB and see if anyone else could explain it. We were left to work out too many things by ourselves. The moment when things fall into place should come within the film, not after discussion with others.nnThe number of beers theory was one explanation, and thanks to wolfstar_imdb for spotting that. There were four in the fridge, then one was opened by Ocho before another two were consumed by him and Javier when they have a moment in the Airbnb. That left one, but in the final sequence there were three. Ocho had been alone all of the time, meaning all the sequences with Javier were imagined. And that, thankfully, poor Sonia never died in New York.nnI would have personally liked the lad in the park to have had a bigger part (so to speak), and question if we were really that fearful of HIV in 1999. In 1989, yes. Things had moved on a decade later. And if Ocho had had so much sex that he'd forgotten that night with Javier, he certainly wasn't as fearful as is suggested. The sex scenes were devoid of affection, as is so often the way in porn, on TV and in films.nnI was left wondering what might have been had some of my own encounters worked out differently. 'What Might Have Been' would have been a better title for the film and would have pointed viewers in the right direction from the outset.

A Hilarious and Relatable Look at Getting Older: My Old Ass ReviewnnAs we age, our bodies start to feel the effects of time. Our joints creak, our energy levels decline, and our memories start to fade. But despite all these changes, one thing remains constant: our sense of humor. And that's exactly what "My Old Ass" is all about - embracing the absurdities of aging and laughing at the challenges that come with it.nnA Universal ExperiencenLet's face it, getting older is a universal experience. We've all been there, or we'll all get there eventually. And that's what makes "My Old Ass" so relatable. It's a lighthearted and humorous take on the aging process, with all its aches, pains, and indignities. Whether you're in your 30s, 40s, 50s, or beyond, you'll find something to laugh about in this review.nnA Healthy Dose of SarcasmnOne of the things that sets "My Old Ass" apart is its healthy dose of sarcasm. The author isn't afraid to poke fun at themselves and the absurdities of aging. From creaky joints to memory loss, no topic is off-limits. And that's what makes this review so funny - it's a no-holds-barred look at the challenges of getting older, with a healthy dose of humor and sarcasm.nnEmbracing the Absurdities of AgingnBut "My Old Ass" is more than just a funny review - it's also a celebration of the absurdities of aging. The author embraces the quirks and challenges of getting older, and finds the humor in them. Whether it's struggling to get out of bed in the morning, or trying to remember where you put your keys, "My Old Ass" finds the funny side of things.nnA Lighthearted Take on a Serious TopicnAging can be a serious topic, but "My Old Ass" approaches it with a lighthearted touch. The author doesn't shy away from the challenges of getting older, but instead finds the humor in them. And that's what makes this review so refreshing - it's a lighthearted take on a serious topic, with a healthy dose of humor and sarcasm.nnConclusionnIn conclusion, "My Old Ass" is a hilarious and relatable review that's all about embracing the absurdities of aging. With its healthy dose of sarcasm and humor, it's a must-read for anyone who's getting older (and let's face it, that's all of us). So if you're looking for a lighthearted take on a serious topic, look no further than "My Old Ass". It's a funny, relatable, and refreshing review that's sure to leave you laughing.nnRating: 5/5 starsnnRecommendation: If you're looking for a funny and relatable review about getting older, "My Old Ass" is a must-read. It's a lighthearted take on a serious topic, with a healthy dose of humor and sarcasm. So if you're feeling old and creaky, or just want to laugh at the absurdities of aging, "My Old Ass" is the perfect review for you.

Conflict by Aku Louhiniemi is a truly gripping series that kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The storytelling is top-notch, and the characters are deep and complex, making every episode feel fresh and unpredictable. The cinematography is also stunning, perfectly capturing the tension and atmosphere of the show. Louhiniemi's direction brings a unique energy to the series, blending suspense with real emotional depth. I can say that I went through all the emotions while whatching this :')nA must-watch for anyone who loves intense, thought-provoking drama. 10/10!nn*****************

This is movie isüî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•"This film is a masterclass in storytelling, blending timeless themes of love, loss, and redemption with an authenticity rarely seen in modern cinema. It doesn't rely on flashy effects or gimmicks but instead leans into the raw power of its characters and their journeys. "Nueve Reinas," directed by Fabi√°n Bielinsky, is a captivating Argentine film that masterfully intertwines elements of crime, drama, and dark comedy. Released in 2000, this clever heist film has garnered critical acclaim and a dedicated following, solidifying its status as a modern classic in Latin American cinema. With its intricate plot, sharp dialogue, and outstanding performances, "Nueve Reinas" is a thrilling ride that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats.nnAt the heart of the film are two con artists, Marcos (Germ√°n Palacios) and Juan (Ricardo Dar√≠n), whose paths cross in a bustling Buenos Aires. Marcos is a seasoned grifter with a wealth of experience, while Juan is a younger, less experienced hustler looking to make his mark. Their chemistry is palpable, and the dynamic between the two characters drives the film forward. Dar√≠n's portrayal of Juan is particularly noteworthy; he captures the character's vulnerability and ambition with finesse, making him relatable even as he navigates the morally ambiguous world of con artistry.nnThe plot revolves around a high-stakes con involving a rare set of stamps known as the "Nueve Reinas" (Nine Queens). As Marcos and Juan attempt to pull off this elaborate scheme, the film delves into themes of trust, betrayal, and the blurred lines between reality and deception. The screenplay is tightly woven, filled with unexpected twists and turns that keep the audience guessing. Just when you think you have figured out the characters' motivations, the story takes another sharp turn, showcasing Bielinsky's skillful storytelling.nnOne of the film's greatest strengths is its ability to balance humor with tension. The witty dialogue and comedic moments provide levity amidst the high-stakes con, creating a unique viewing experience that engages both the mind and the heart. The banter between Marcos and Juan is sharp and often hilarious, highlighting their contrasting personalities while deepening their relationship. This blend of comedy and drama ensures that "Nueve Reinas" remains entertaining from start to finish.nnVisually, "Nueve Reinas" is a treat. The cinematography captures the vibrant streets of Buenos Aires, giving viewers a taste of the city's culture and energy. The film's pacing is expertly crafted, with each scene building upon the last to create an escalating sense of urgency. Bielinsky's direction is both confident and subtle; he allows the characters' actions to speak for themselves while maintaining a tight grip on the narrative.nnThe supporting cast also deserves recognition for their contributions to the film's success. Each character adds depth to the story, from the enigmatic figures they encounter to those who complicate their schemes. The interactions between characters reveal layers of complexity in their motivations and desires, enriching the overall narrative.nn"Nueve Reinas" is not just a heist film; it is a commentary on human nature and the lengths people will go to achieve their goals. The film raises questions about morality, loyalty, and the consequences of deceit. As Marcos and Juan navigate their way through a world built on lies, viewers are left to ponder what it truly means to be honest in a dishonest world.nnThe film's ending is particularly noteworthy, leaving audiences with a sense of ambiguity that lingers long after the credits roll. It challenges viewers to reflect on what they have witnessed and consider the implications of the characters' choices. This thought-provoking conclusion elevates "Nueve Reinas" beyond mere entertainment, inviting deeper analysis and discussion.

Well I wasn't sure what to expect from this short 'Minisode' but it basically acts as an extended end scene to the nowhere line or a post credit scene and boy does it work well! The music for one fits extremely well and the line delivery is good! They obviously do what the description says and what the cover suggests in this, which is talk about that mysterious letter from Amon Peterson AKA Jacobs father. I was already invested in that arc from episode 2 and was a tad worried when it wasn't mentioned at all in episode 3 as that was basically all a dream. Yes there was that one scene in one of the dreams where Jacob wanted to stay in the dream because his parents were alive which i thought was a great scene but it didn't add to the arc or anything. Well this has been put so it takes place between episode 2 and 3 and it works nicely!

I like movies that start with the question "What ifüòÅ...?" Those simple but profound plots at the same time. Those stories that develop in a peaceful context, that encourages the audience's thinking. I like them because these are the instances where you can get to know yourself a little better if you do the exercise that the movie poses to you. The script of My Old Ass is precisely that, simple but that invites you to think about yourself, to put yourself in the place of the protagonist and ask yourself "What would you do?".nnThe leading performances help everything flow well, despite the secondary performances, which do not all work as efficient support for the main roles. The locations are wonderful. The direction is on point, focused on the story rather than boasting with daring shots. Perhaps the soundtrack is a bit austere, especially with the small plot twist in the last act. Even so, it contributes its grain of sand.nnThe most sensitive moviegoers will receive this film like a tear-gas bomb to the chest, but will end up feeling good. It's my consolation to convince them not to miss this warm tale.

"Follow the Leader" begins with Corporal Muggs McGinnis being discharged from the army...even though WWII isn't finished. This is because Muggs cheated on the eye exam...and his vision was so bad they Army rejected him. But Muggs' determination to make America a safe place for democracy, apple pie, and the Kardashians make him want to serve his country. So when a new member of the old gang, Spider (Billy Benedict), is murdered, Muggs smells a rat and investigates. Additionally, a long-time member of the gang, Danny, has been jailed...and Muggs is determined to free him as well. And, to do so, he works undercover as a member of a gang he thinks might be behind all this.nnThis is clearly a WWII positive propaganda film meant to drum up support for the country at war. As such, it's pretty good stuff and is pretty entertaining...especially for an East Side Kids film. Overall, a bit more intelligent than usual for the franchise...with Huntz Hall and Leo Gorcey playing it more seriously and less for dopey laughs.nnBy the way, although Billy Benedict played Spider, he soon became Whitey...a DIFFERENT member of the gang. And, Bernard Gorcey is in this one but he's not playing Louie...the malt shop owner in nearly all the remaining East Side Kid/Bowery Boys films.

If only for the cave with the sliding door, I remember this mildly entertaining fantasy adventure from my childhood. It all follows the usual path of a hero who falls in love with the princess to the chagrin of his boss who also has designs on her! In this case it's the princess "Zafir" (Helen Gilbert) who is the object of everyone's desir; "Amdar" (Paul Henreid) the man she loves and "Khalid" (John Sutton) the malevolent usurper who would have her father's kingdom and his daughter. Fortunately for them, and us, she has the assistance of the wily "Sheherazade" (Jeff Donnell) and there's the occupier of the magic cave, too. He is, of course, "Ali Baba" (Philip Van Zandt) and he might just be persuaded to help out. Oh, right, and there's also "Sinbad" (Lon Chaney Jr.) just to keep the "Arabian Nights" theme fully exploited throughout. With a public execution looming, it is going to fall to the heroic men to save the sultan and his daughter from the scimitar, but will they manage to overcome the city walls and the overwhelming number of royal guards in time? Nothing remotely original, no, but I did quite enjoy this theatrically delivered costume romp, especially the lively effort from Donnell who clearly thinks she's more than a match for any man (character or actor). There's plenty of action to stop the romance getting too cheesy and though Henreid is as wooden as a cedar tree, his talents mix well with the rest of the mediocrity on offer here to present us with a perfectly watchable adventure film.

In the beginning the series was almost training people on autism, especially when Sam had the incident with the police was a revelation for many people who haven't thought about autism before.nnBut by the final season Sam was like 10% of the story and the show focused on everyone else.nnMore than 50% of the series becomes about Casey and her sexual orientation questioning, the next 30% is the parents and only a tiny portion is kept for the main characternnIts even hard to think of enough characters to complete the review because of what I mentioned abovennIts a pity as it could be a great show to remember.

Amazing Graphics and EditsnHaving discovered Gabalton's novels only recently (generally reserving my limited reading time to the likes of Bernard Cornwell and Patrick O'Brien, more swords;less romance),I was pleased with the quality of the production, casting, pace and overall presentation of this complex story. Romantic? Yes. However, if the mini-series story line continues in keeping with the books (as seems likely)it will likely unfold into dovetailing themes of sacrifice,duty,honor,jealousies and complex loyalties that even many of the male viewers will relate wholeheartedly to. Not since PeterJackson's close to the novel(s) rendition of the Lord of the Rings saga have I been as pleased (at least with the initial installment) with a book-to-screen version of a great story. Thanks STARZ!

Graphic imagery without a purpose. I figured this would be the case, but decided to watch it to get it off of my watchlist. My existing impression was on the money. The narrative takes a backseat in favor of showing as much shocking visual pieces as could fit into the run time with barely enough story to string along the scenes. I usually try to put myself in the shoes of an audience that would enjoy the movie, but I really can't find much to highlight here. I'm not a person who gets squeamish over grotesque imagery so I am confident that I wasn't taken out of the plot by some sort of knee-jerk reaction to what I was seeing. Overall I'd say it's not even worth watching even if you just want to be able to say you've seen it. I doubt I'll ever return for a re-watch.

"I just watched 'My Old Ass' and I'm still reeling from the experience! This film is a masterclass in storytelling, with a unique premise that's both hilarious and heartwarming.nnThe cast delivers outstanding performances, with Maisy Stella shining as the lead. Her chemistry with Aubrey Plaza is undeniable, and their scenes together are some of the film's highlights.nnThe direction is superb, with a keen eye for detail and a deep understanding of the characters. The cinematography is stunning, capturing the beauty of the film's settings and adding to the overall atmosphere.nnWhat I loved most about 'My Old Ass' is its thoughtful exploration of identity, love, and self-discovery. The film tackles complex themes with sensitivity and humor, making it a truly unforgettable watch.nnOverall, 'My Old Ass' is a must-see film that will leave you smiling, laughing, and maybe even shedding a tear or two. Don't miss out on this gem - go watch it as soon as you can!"

"My Old Ass" is a mesmerizing, poignant, and expertly crafted coming-of-age tale that delves into the complexities of love, family, and self-discovery. Aubrey Plaza shines as the older Elliott, guiding her younger self through a transformative journey.nnThe film masterfully weaves together elements of drama, romance, and magical realism, creating a unique narrative that's both captivating and emotionally resonant. Maisy Stella delivers a standout performance as the younger Elliott, navigating her character's vulnerabilities and growth with remarkable depth.nnThe supporting cast adds richness to the story, particularly the chemistry between Elliott and Chad, which is authentic and tender. The film's exploration of themes such as identity, love, loss, and the consequences of choice will linger with viewers long after the credits roll.nnOverall, "My Old Ass" is a triumph of storytelling, boasting impressive performances, thoughtful direction, and a narrative that will resonate with audiences of all ages. Don't miss this unforgettable cinematic experience!nnRating: 10/10 stars.

"My Old Ass" is a delightfully quirky and surprisingly heartwarming coming-of-age story. The premise, an 18-year-old encountering her 39-year-old self on a psychedelic journey, is inherently intriguing. The film masterfully walks the line between laugh-out-loud humor and genuine emotional depth.nnThe performances are stellar, particularly the actress playing both the younger and older versions of Elliott. Their chemistry is undeniable, creating a dynamic that's both comedic and touching. The film's exploration of self-discovery, regret, and the passage of time feels authentic and relatable.nn"My Old Ass" is a refreshing and unique cinematic experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll. It's a reminder to embrace the present, cherish the journey, and never stop growing.nnRating: 4.5 out of 5 stars.

"My Old Ass" is a heartwarming and humorous coming-of-age film that explores themes of identity, family, love, and self-discovery. The movie follows Elliott, an 18-year-old girl who meets her 39-year-old self during a mushroom trip, leading to a series of unexpected events and life lessons ¬π.nnThe film features a talented cast, including Maisy Stella in her film debut, Aubrey Plaza, Percy Hynes White, Maddie Ziegler, and Kerrice Brooks. With its unique blend of comedy, drama, and fantasy elements, "My Old Ass" has received widespread critical acclaim for its authentic storytelling, witty dialogue, and outstanding performances.

I found this entertaining but there are so many flaws such as the main character is a detective but seems to be extremely naive to everything that has gone on. Everyone seems to be extremely well off. James Nesbit plays a very camp gangster, which is almost comical. Lisa Faulkner's son continues to walk towards the van even though she is telling him to run. The operation is not the most sophisticated as they should know that banks will report unusual activity, but somehow they have managed to get away with it on numerous occasions as insinuated. Even Kat finding out her Dad was gay, is totally predictable. This series does feel like a tickbox exercise.
