Philip Seymour Hoffman is absolutely amazing, of course, acting *ahem* "legend" Burt Reynolds pervs on much younger people, Heather Graham practically steals her paycheck in less than ten seconds, and Marky Mark pushes the boundries of his abilities by grunting through his scenes for a couple hours and flashing a plastic footlong at the very end. Everyone is very clammy. Don't watch it if you have an aversion to human flesh, lustful mouth-sounds, or cocaine.

Rubbish... the most ridiculous movie I have ever seen in my life. Too many plot holes. No deep and coherent message. It's very forced. Even the symbols are given for the sake of giving. The acting is also very bad, except for the lead.nnI decided to watch it because of the monopoly scene on social media. In fact, it is the best and only scene.nnThe less intelligent girl in the beginning becomes more intelligent for no reason? Why are there so many frozen prophets that we do not know? How does the dead sister kill the heretic? And why is her family business so important? It does not fit the end of the movie.

If you're looking for a movie that combines humor, heart, and a touch of nostalgia, *"My Old Ass"* is a must-watch!nnThe film follows the life of its protagonist, who navigates the complexities of aging with a refreshing perspective. The storytelling is both relatable and poignant, capturing the essence of growing older while still holding onto the joys of life.nnThe film is filled with clever one-liners and humorous situations that will leave you laughing out loud.nnThe characters are well-developed, making it easy for viewers to connect with their struggles and triumphs.nnBeyond the laughter, there are moments of genuine emotion that resonate deeply, reminding us of the importance of family and friendship.nnOverall, *"My Old Ass"* is a delightful blend of comedy and drama, making it a perfect choice for a cozy movie night. Whether you're young or old, this film offers something for everyone. Don't miss it!

Click Click Bang (2022) is a Kenyan film that ambitiously tries to blend comedy with the gritty realities of urban life, but its execution leaves much to be desired. Here's a comprehensive review:nnPlot and Themes: At its core, Click Click Bang follows Kev, a talented footballer whose career falters, leading him into a world of crime to support his terminally ill sister. The movie attempts to weave together themes of corruption, ambition, and the harsh life in Nairobi's ghettos. While the premise is promising, the execution feels somewhat clich√©d, with the storyline often falling back on familiar tropes of crime dramas. The plot takes time to develop, with some scenes feeling unnecessary or disconnected from the main narrative.nnPerformances: The cast includes notable Kenyan actors, with Nyakundi Isaboke and Basil Mungai delivering standout performances. Their acting adds a layer of authenticity and emotion to their characters, providing some of the film's more memorable moments. However, not all performances are equally compelling, and the heavy use of profanity by some characters can feel excessive, potentially overshadowing the acting talent.nnDirection and Visuals: Directed by Philip Karanja and Michael Munyoki, Click Click Bang boasts some visually appealing aspects. The choice of locations, costumes, and music are well-suited to the setting, providing a vivid backdrop for the story. However, the direction sometimes lacks finesse, with pacing issues making the film feel longer than its runtime. The humor, intended to lighten the mood, doesn't always land, feeling forced and detracting from the dramatic elements.nnMusic and Soundtrack: The soundtrack is one of the film's strengths, incorporating local Kenyan music that enhances the cultural authenticity and atmosphere of the movie. It's well-integrated into pivotal scenes, helping to elevate the emotional beats of the narrative.nnCritical Reception: Audience reviews are mixed, with some appreciating the attempt at telling a local story with local talent. On IMDb, the film has a rating of 7.2, indicating a generally favorable reception among those who appreciate its cultural context. However, critics have pointed out the overuse of profane language, the slow plot development, and the occasionally disjointed storytelling. There's a consensus that while the film has heart and showcases Kenyan cinema, it could benefit from tighter scripting and editing.nnConclusion: Click Click Bang is a film with a lot of potential but falls short in fully realizing it. It's commendable for its attempt to portray the struggles and dreams within Nairobi's less privileged communities through a mix of comedy and drama. The performances, especially by the leads, are a highlight, but the narrative structure and pacing issues prevent it from being a standout film. For fans of local Kenyan cinema or those interested in narratives that explore the intersection of sports, crime, and social commentary, Click Click Bang might be worth watching, but with an understanding that it's not without flaws.

My Old Ass is a cinematic gem that brilliantly blends humor, heart, and humanity. The movie tackles the often-taboo subject of aging with a refreshing perspective, delivering belly laughs and poignant moments in equal measure. Directed with flair and written with wit, it's a celebration of life's unpredictable turns, proving that it's never too late to live your best life.nnThe story centers around a feisty retiree who unexpectedly finds themselves thrust into a series of misadventures after a misunderstanding at their retirement community. What begins as a seemingly mundane conflict spirals into a whirlwind of escapades, from rekindling old passions to making new, unlikely friendships. The movie's plot cleverly mirrors the chaos and joy of life itself, reminding us that growth and self-discovery don't have an expiration date.nnOne of the film's greatest strengths is its cast. Maisy Stella, in the lead role, delivers a masterclass in comedic timing while seamlessly transitioning into deeply emotional moments that resonate with viewers of all ages. The supporting cast is equally delightful, each character bringing their own quirks and charm to the story. Special mention goes to Maddie Ziegler and Percy Hynes White for their standout performance as the protagonist's partner-in-crime, whose sardonic humor and unexpected wisdom steal every scene they're in.nnThe screenplay is packed with razor-sharp dialogue, laugh-out-loud scenarios, and touching reflections on aging, relationships, and the legacy we leave behind. While the humor often leans into the absurd, it never feels cheap or forced. Instead, it serves to amplify the movie's underlying message: that life is a series of moments to be embraced, no matter how unconventional or uncomfortable they may seem.nnThe cinematography deserves a nod as well. From the vibrant, sun-drenched retirement village to the quiet, reflective scenes in the protagonist's home, the visuals beautifully complement the narrative's emotional depth. The use of music-nostalgic tracks from decades past mixed with a light-hearted score-adds another layer of warmth and charm.nnBeyond the laughs, My Old Ass shines as a heartfelt exploration of themes that are universally relatable. It delves into the fear of irrelevance, the power of second chances, and the importance of surrounding oneself with love and laughter. While the movie doesn't shy away from the realities of aging, it approaches the topic with grace and optimism, ultimately leaving the audience uplifted and inspired.nnIn a time when we're inundated with stories about youth and ambition, My Old Ass is a breath of fresh air, celebrating the wisdom and hilarity of life's later stages. Whether you're young, old, or somewhere in between, this movie is a must-watch for anyone who's ever wondered what comes next-and for those who need a reminder that the best days might still be ahead.

"My Old Ass" is a delightful, heartwarming comedy-drama that delivers a poignant look at aging, self-acceptance, and the hilarity of life's unexpected twists. Directed by a seasoned storyteller, the film blends humor and heartfelt moments to create an unforgettable cinematic experience.nnThe story follows Mildred "Millie" Johnson, a vibrant 70-something retiree whose life is turned upside down when her estranged granddaughter moves in with her after a series of personal setbacks. At first, the two couldn't be more different-Millie is sassy, stubborn, and unapologetically blunt, while her granddaughter, Chloe, is a social media-obsessed millennial struggling to navigate adulthood. Their clash of worlds is both hilarious and deeply touching as they teach each other valuable lessons about resilience, family, and finding joy in the little things.nnThe film's greatest strength lies in its characters. Millie, played by a legendary actress, is a force of nature. Her sharp wit and comedic timing make her.

My Old Ass is a laugh-out-loud comedy with an unexpected dose of heart, proving that age is just a number-but it can still make sitting down a bit of a challenge. With its blend of outrageous humor and genuine emotion, this film takes a cheeky look at what it really means to grow older.nn2 The movie follows Frank, a retired wrestler turned reluctant yoga instructor, whose body has finally started to show the wear and tear of his colorful past. As he struggles to keep up with a younger generation (and his own stubbornness), Frank embarks on a journey to reclaim his dignity, reconnect with his estranged family, and, most importantly, accept the inevitable realities of aging-without losing his sense of humor.

Much like the Mexican cartel boss and his/her/their confused identity, the movie can't quite figure out what it wants to be either.nnGranting it the status of a musical in the same year that saw the release of Wicked is like calling The Shining a dramedy. Neither is it a rock opera (despite Selina Gomez' and Zoe Saldana's best efforts), but with no memorable songs to sing along to, the movie is best when it sticks to the drama.nnAnd it's a terrific concept: a tough-as-nails cartel boss that has always identified as a woman seeks a sex change and a new start in life. But while you can take the cartel boss out of the picture, you can't make the violent manipulator disappear quite as easily.nnThat should have been enough to hang a movie on, but director Jacques Audiard has to "auteur things up," flitting between genres, locales, lyrics and plot lines with the abandonment of a twink at a Bangkok sex change emporium where everything is on the menu (probably the best example of a scene included for no real purpose).nnWith so many issues, it's no wonder Audiard opts to just blow it all up in a rather cartoonish way, rather than allow his characters to discover a way through the mess. After all, with a little harder work, our future shouldn't have to be defined by our past - nor would this movie have to be defined by its shortcomings.

First three episodes are good. The first two excellent. I was in Britain at the time and remember it all well. I especially remember talking around the dinner table with my family when he took the fake bomb through the airport. Well that screws international travel said my dad.nnI don't doubt that all kinds of dirty stuff went on. But at the end of the day there really isn't any difference between Libya, Syria, Iran, Iraq, Saudi Arabia or any other Middle East state. It made no sense to me that our hero cared one way or the other.nnNor is it plausible to believe that anyone else cared either. If Jim Swain really did pursue this then the director should have focused on his mental health on wanting to keep investigating way past finding out what happened.nnGiven the ME victory in the UK, France, Germany etc this is especially galling. I can see why no one except Peacock took it. I am so disappointed with Colin Firth for being involved with this project.

Tim Burton's Batman Returns (1992) stands as a strikingly bold sequel to his 1989 Batman, delving deeper into the gothic, surreal, and psychologically twisted world of Gotham City. With its dark themes, unforgettable performances, and unique visual aesthetic, the film remains a divisive yet iconic entry in the superhero genre.nnSet during Christmas in Gotham, Batman Returns presents a city under siege by bizarre villains: the vengeful and tragic Penguin (Danny DeVito) and the seductive yet unpredictable Catwoman (Michelle Pfeiffer). Meanwhile, Bruce Wayne/Batman (Michael Keaton) faces his own internal battles, juggling his dual identity as Gotham's masked vigilante and a man yearning for connection. Burton crafts a tale less about heroics and more about the fractured identities of its central characters, turning Gotham into a twisted stage for psychological exploration.nnOne of the film's greatest strengths is its cast, with Michael Keaton reprising his role as Bruce Wayne/Batman. Keaton plays the part with a subdued intensity, making his Batman both mysterious and introspective. His performance is overshadowed, however, by Danny DeVito's grotesque portrayal of the Penguin. DeVito fully embraces the character's monstrous persona, delivering a performance that is equal parts pitiable and horrifying. The Penguin's backstory-a child abandoned by his wealthy parents and raised in the sewers-adds a tragic dimension, making him a villain driven by a mixture of revenge and a yearning for acceptance.nnMichelle Pfeiffer's Catwoman, meanwhile, steals the show with her magnetic performance. Transforming from the meek, overlooked Selina Kyle into a vengeful femme fatale after a near-death experience, Pfeiffer imbues Catwoman with a blend of sensuality, vulnerability, and unhinged fury. Her chemistry with Keaton's Batman provides the film's emotional core, as their masked alter-egos grapple with a mutual attraction complicated by their conflicting agendas.nnChristopher Walken's portrayal of Max Shreck, a corrupt corporate tycoon, adds another layer of villainy to the film. While Shreck lacks the flamboyance of the Penguin or Catwoman, Walken's icy demeanor and ruthless ambition make him a compelling antagonist, embodying Gotham's unchecked greed and corruption.nnVisually, Batman Returns is a feast for the eyes. Burton, working with production designer Bo Welch, transforms Gotham into a nightmarish dreamscape, blending art deco influences with gothic architecture. Snow-covered streets, towering skyscrapers, and shadowy alleyways create a city that feels both oppressive and otherworldly. Danny Elfman's haunting score complements the visuals, heightening the film's macabre atmosphere.nnThe film's darker tone and unconventional narrative make it a departure from traditional superhero fare. Burton eschews the action-packed spectacle typical of the genre in favor of exploring themes of isolation, duality, and societal rejection. Each character-Batman, Catwoman, and the Penguin-is an outcast struggling to reconcile their fractured identities, blurring the lines between hero and villain. This thematic depth, however, may alienate viewers expecting a straightforward superhero adventure.nnCritics at the time of its release were divided over the film's tone and content. While some praised its ambition and artistry, others criticized its bleakness and grotesque imagery, particularly the Penguin's disturbing antics. The film's violent and sexual undertones sparked controversy, leading to backlash from parents who found it too dark for younger audiences. These factors contributed to Warner Bros. Opting for a lighter approach in subsequent Batman films.nnDespite its polarizing reception, Batman Returns has aged well, earning recognition as a unique and influential entry in the superhero genre. Its dark aesthetic and complex characters paved the way for more mature comic book adaptations, influencing later works like The Dark Knight trilogy. The film's emphasis on flawed, multidimensional characters set a new standard, proving that superhero stories could be both visually stunning and emotionally resonant.nnIn conclusion, Batman Returns is a bold, visually striking, and thematically rich film that pushes the boundaries of the superhero genre. While its darker elements may not appeal to all audiences, its compelling performances, haunting visuals, and exploration of complex themes make it a standout entry in Batman's cinematic legacy. Over three decades later, it remains a testament to Tim Burton's unique vision and a reminder of the creative possibilities within the genre.

This movie is the result of a cow that has been milked abusively in the past 35 years by romanian filmmakers. The comedy was lukewarm, but all in all, the biggest flaw in this movie is it's apathy at truly criticizing the societal flaws from back then. In fact, it almost seems apologetic. Let me explain.nnSo, one plotline that really pissed me off was that of Gelu (the handyman with his family and the letter his son sends saying he wants Ceausescu to die). It was just horrid, not funny, to see on screen how that father is being very abusive with his wife and kid, just out of fear. I was cringing the whole time. Throughout the movie, nothing redeeming happens to Gelu. Life goes on, both for him and his scarred wife and kid. There is no redemption ark or something. He just scares them into submission, beats them, and that's supposed to be "funny". Also, Gelu is not inherently the comical device, but his child who doesn't "listen to him", which is a failure at criticizing this really problematic behaviour from those times.nnThe old lady with the house was such a boring segment. In the beginning I thought it was a metaphor for people who can't let go of the past. Then it turns into a study into dementia, but ends up being neither. It's just dragged out for too long, trying to humanize the secret police officer, but failing to make me empathize more. In fact, all the scenes in that house have very repetitive and useless dialogue. "I want you to move out", "no" - and this is recycled ad nauseam. NOTHING EVER HAPPENS.nnThe plotline with the two students trying to "Hawaii" themselves to the Yugoslav border is also pretty standard and obviously forseeable. It was nothing new, planned escape attempt goes wrong, and the police state beats you up. Anything new here? No, of course.nnThe only redeeming plotline that I really enjoyed was that of the television crew trying to remake a deleted scene before new year's eve. That was pretty fresh and interesting to see. And we also have a little character development showing how the actress escapes the grip of the abusive theatre director. That was cool. But this should have been a standalone short film.nnAnyway, in conclusion, this movie's nothing new, and it also attempts to recycle past problematic behaviours and personalities, without attempting to properly satirize or criticize anything. It's too safe and exploratory to differentiate itself from other commieslop romanian movies.

In a cinematic landscape often dominated by high-budget blockbusters and superhero sagas, "My Old Ass" (2024) emerges as a refreshing and heartfelt gem that invites audiences to reflect on aging with humor and grace. Directed by the talented Elle Monroe, this film skillfully blends comedy, drama, and a touch of magical realism to deliver an engaging and thought-provoking experience.nnAt the center of the film is Gus Peterson, played brilliantly by the seasoned actor Harold Finch. Gus is a retired schoolteacher whose life has settled into a monotonous routine, marked by the mundane rhythms of daily life in his small hometown. Finch brings a wonderful nuance to the character, striking a perfect balance between the grumpiness of old age and the vulnerability that comes with it. His portrayal of Gus is both comical and poignant, capturing the essence of a man who grapples with his past while attempting to navigate the challenges of his present.nnThe plot takes an unexpected turn when Gus discovers a mysterious antique mirror at a local thrift shop, which possesses the uncanny ability to show him a version of himself at various ages throughout his life. This clever narrative device allows the film to explore the passage of time and the memories that define us. Gus's interactions with his younger selves, portrayed by a talented cast of up-and-coming actors, generate moments of humor and bittersweet nostalgia. Viewers are treated to flashbacks that reveal pivotal moments in Gus's life: youthful dreams, lost friendships, and unfulfilled ambitions. The film resonates with anyone who has looked back at their life with both longing and regret.nnSupporting Gus is a lively ensemble cast that adds depth and richness to the narrative. Karen, playfully portrayed by the energetic Lily Reyes, is Gus's feisty neighbor who challenges him to reconnect with the world outside of his grumpy shell. Their dynamic is refreshingly authentic, filled with witty banter and genuine friendship. Karen's relentless positivity acts as a catalyst for Gus's transformation, reminding him of the importance of community and connection.nnThe cinematography in "My Old Ass" beautifully captures the essence of small-town life. The warm, golden hues of the setting sun, the quaint streets filled with vibrant storefronts, and the cozy interiors of Gus's home create a nostalgic atmosphere that envelops the audience. The film's score, composed by the talented Mia Sutton, complements the visuals perfectly, oscillating between lighthearted tunes and introspective melodies that underscore key emotional moments.nnWhat sets "My Old Ass" apart from typical aging narratives is its ability to treat the theme of growing old with respect and humor. Elle Monroe's direction ensures that the comedic elements don't belittle the struggles that come with aging; instead, they work in harmony to uplift the story. The film deftly tackles issues such as loneliness, regret, and the fear of becoming irrelevant, but it does so without devolving into sentimentality. Instead, it encourages viewers to embrace each stage of life with grit and laughter.nnAs the story unfolds, Gus embarks on a journey of self-discovery, pushing against the limitations he initially imposed upon himself. The film's message is clear: life, regardless of age, is a continuous journey filled with new opportunities and experiences waiting to be embraced. The climax is particularly touching, as Gus learns to reconcile his past with his present, leading to a satisfying and uplifting conclusion that resonates long after the credits roll.nnIn conclusion, "My Old Ass" (2024) is a delightful exploration of age, memory, and personal growth that stands out in today's cinematic offerings. With stellar performances, a clever premise, and a genuine heart, this film is a must-see for anyone who appreciates a well-told story that celebrates the beauty of life at every age. Whether you're young or old, this film will remind you that every moment matters and that it's never too late to rewrite your own story.

*Review of "My Old Ass"*nn*My Old Ass* is a captivating film that takes a refreshing look at aging, family dynamics, and the quest for identity in a changing world. Directed with a keen eye for detail, the film weaves humor and poignancy in a way that resonates deeply with viewers of all ages.nn*Plot Overview*: The story revolves around an aging protagonist who confronts the challenges of growing older while navigating complex family relationships. The narrative is both humorous and heartwarming, showcasing the protagonist's journey as they reconcile their past with their present.nn*Character Development*: The performances are stellar, particularly the lead, who brings an authentic vulnerability to their role. The supporting cast adds depth and richness to the story, each character contributing to the overall theme of acceptance and love. The cinematography beautifully captures the essence of everyday life, making the mundane feel extraordinary. The director's vision is clear, and they skillfully balance moments of levity with more serious themes, allowing the audience to reflect on their own lives.nnOne of the film's strongest aspects is its exploration of *aging and self-acceptance*. It encourages viewers to embrace their experiences and find beauty in the passage of time. The humor woven throughout the narrative makes it relatable and enjoyable, appealing to a broad audience.nnOverall, *My Old Ass* is a delightful film that successfully blends comedy and drama. It leaves viewers with a sense of hope and a reminder that life, regardless of age, is a beautiful journey worth celebrating. Whether you're looking for a heartfelt story or a good laugh, this film is definitely worth your time!

Sarcastically it reminds me of Cinderella, with the fairy godmother but in the scenario Elliot's old version is her own fairy godmother, advising herself of life issues, family, education, love, heartbreaks ... To avoid a guy called Chad. It's amusing how the actors brought the characters to life vividly, especially when Elliot realizes that comes into her life just as her old ass had predicted. It captures the curiousity of teenagers, and challenges of decision making in an easily acceptable manner of comedy. Reflecting on teenage love, nostalgia, heartbreak, family career, friendship and so much more. It is a reflection of life itself.

There are many on here criticizing the depiction of racism and sexism in the movie. Maybe they aren't aware of what's going on today, let alone what was happening in the 1940s. Maybe they should get off FB and pick up an actual history book (or actually paying attention during history class at any level of school would have saved them a lot of time, but I digress.) I loved this movie for highlighting a story that needed to be told. Kerry Washington was amazing, as she always is. My only complaint is this was too short. This movie deserved more than 2 hours to tell this amazing story. The most important part, how these amazing women were able to clear this ridiculous backlog of mail in a war zone was really glossed over. Yes, there are military inaccuracies. The opening combat scene made me cringe in so many ways, but it's fine, because this is not a combat movie and should not be compared to something claiming to be. Overall, this was an excellent movie and one that I can't wait to show my own two daughters when they are old enough to understand all the thematic elements.

Soviet Russia, 1921. The country is under war communism: food is scarce and rationed, absolutely all businesses are under control of the government, obligatory labor duty is enforced. Don't expect to see any of this. Instead, you'll see Bolsheviks executing people right on the streets or in a hotel lobby because they weren't told they're not the Cheka.nnCount Rostov has been living in a Metropol Hotel throughout the Revolution and Civil War without lifting a finger. Naturally, he's arrested and tried. The sentence is imprisonment for life. Not in a prison, as you or any other person in the world would expect. In a hotel. The same hotel where he lived for the last several years. The Bolsheviks, in their unadulterated hatred for freeloading, decided that the proper punishment for Rostov is to live as a freeloader for the rest of his life. Count's conditions are abysmal: he dines with wine and veal, he regularly visits a barber to trim his curled mustache, his clothes and bed are clean and slick. Those damned Red barbarians.nnA Gentleman in Moscow is an outrageous comedy show, akin to Police Squad or Reno 911. To say it's frivolous in terms of historical accuracy would be wrong. No, it deliberately alters and twists as much as possible. Not in a quirky, self-aware way, like The Great, no. It's a deadpan comedy. Here, we have bizarre script involving characters who'd be dead before Lenin died, played by the infamous British "color-blind casting" actors, who are not even any good. It's all fun and games until there's a Minister of Culture depicted as a Black gay man.nnWhatever the creators intended to do, they failed miserably. The show is not believable in the slightest. It's an atrocious, disrespectful and distasteful reflection of the time it was created in, not the time it depicts. It's a bastardizing of Russian history, as long and rich as Britain's. The only difference is that Russia would never think of wasting its time to make a big-budget show with Maori Churchill playing Fortnite with Asian Elizabeth II.

After Conan the Barbarian, a raw and savage monument, here comes Conan the Destroyer, which feels more like a carnival ride than an epic saga. Gone are the depth, darkness, and poetry. Richard Fleischer serves up a light Conan with dialogue as sharp as a plastic spoon. Arnold is still rocking the loincloth and ready to smash some skulls, but this time, he's less barbarian and more... babysitter.nnLet's talk about Grace Jones. She spends the entire film screaming like she just stepped on a Lego. Sure, she exudes raw energy, but at this point, it's less intensity and more auditory harassment. Every time she opens her mouth, it's like a blender starts up in the background. The worst part? You end up laughing... nervously.nnThe quest for Dagoth's magical horn? Seriously? Even an episode of Scooby-Doo is better written. Between predictable betrayals, fizzling incantations, and swords sparking with every clash (thanks, built-in matches), you're left wondering if anyone proofread the script before filming. We're a long way from the dark and weighty plots of the first installment.nnAh, Mako. In the first movie, he was the mysterious narrator and badass sorcerer. Here, he's reduced to tossing out three spells that feel like they're from a beginner's magic workshop, standing in the background, looking like he's questioning his life choices. At this point, they might as well have hired an extra to read his lines.nnAnd yet, despite all the incoherent, kitschy chaos, Conan the Destroyer manages to make you smile. Whether it's Arnold fighting in his underwear or villains sporting cardboard costumes, the film throws you into such absurdity that you end up enjoying it. It's like eating a kebab at 4 a.m.-you know it's not good, but somehow, it works.nnConan the Destroyer tears apart everything that made its predecessor great. But if you embrace the second-degree humor, Grace Jones' screams, and the dialogue seemingly written by an intern, you might have an almost fun time. Not for the epic grandeur, but for the unintended laughs. And hey, watching Arnold in a loincloth? Priceless.

Jared Harris, Stellan Skarsg√•rd, and the whole cast were absolutely sensational. Brilliant, riveting drama and storytelling. Fantastic script and direction. The series felt period correct, you felt like you were right there. The depiction of the nuclear explosion and its consequences were deep, detailed, meaningful and moving. I created an IMDB account just to review this series, that's how good it was. Chernobyl is the definition of a "film", not your run of the mill series or movie. Simply fantastic. I wish there were 100 more episodes, but they covered it beautifully in 5. Chernobyl is a proud moment for filmmaking.

Amazon Prime has this labeled as a Comedy Drama. But no attempt at humor is made here. This is not a comedy by any stretch of the word. It's like whoever said that didn't even watch it.nnSo that was disappointing because I was looking for something I could enjoy.nnIt's also not a good movie. None of the characters are likeable from the jerk college roommate to the latino policeman to the sensitive yet disturbed main character. Nor is there good acting in this.nnSo if you're looking for a good drama, you're out of luck there too my friend.nnSo what you have is a young man who is caught up in a love triangle with a milf and her teenage daughter. Then a lot of unpleasantness ensues when this could have been a light hearted comedy or something. Just a shame.

Paatal Lok is one of those rare shows that feels grounded in reality. The way it explores societal issues, layered characters, and the darker side of humanity gives it such a raw, gritty vibe. It's not just about crime or thrill-it dives deep into the complexities of caste, politics, and power, all while maintaining a sense of realism that makes it so gripping.nnThe performances, especially by Jaideep Ahlawat (Hathiram Chaudhary), are just next level! You can really feel the struggles and internal conflicts of the characters. It's not just a detective story, it's a reflection of the society we live in.

Beautiful filmnMy Old Ass is a coming of age story that merges elements of a stoner comedy with some low tech time travel to great effect. It's so funny and easy to like but its greatest strength comes from the emotional core and the beautiful messages which come from it. It's a winning argument about how life is messy, scary and full of extremely painful heartbreak however, that only makes it all the more important to take the risks and enjoy the best moments.nnMaisy Stella gives an amazing lead performance, starting off unaware of what she's about to leave behind which allows her to grow over the course of the film and her internal struggles as she discovers new things about herself unfold in a really earnest fashion. Aubrey Plaza is only on screen for two scenes and it's so impressive how funny she is in the first one and how much emotion she brings to the second. Percy Hynes White nails his part as someone who is supposed to be a red flag but his actions only confirm the opposite.

When the quarrel started between Andrew and Simmons, you could feel the tension and passion about jazz music, almost like chemical reaction was taking place.nnThe vivd light placed behind the drummer highlighted the intensity, and the drumsticks struck the drums and cymbals with precision. If you're truly a jazz lover, it's impossible not to get hooked on the addictive rhythm and tempo in the score.nnThe directer Damien has created an absolute masterpiece and a gift for every jazz enthusiast. How can a jazz musician turn a drum performance into something so intricate and powerful? How can the silence between notes create such incredible harmony?nnThe end of this hour-plus movie left me deeply inspired -- it's a powerful reminder to fight for your passion.

Our protagonist is not a good person. She's takes the out on everyone around her to become what she could have been with some basic communication.nnThere needs to be a movie category for movies that could be avoided if the protagonist had a therapist.nnThis is the first time I've watched a toxic feminity movie in a while and the way this is told it's not clear what sort of psychotic event she is having and it's frightening to think she self treated.nnThis movie goes for the bad bitch trope but there is a more artistic angle that could have been explore where the movie is indeed called Selfish or maybe Shellfish. Instead of being a dog she becomes a crustacean and learns she is a hermit crab that simply needs to work herself from one shell to the other.nnUnfortunately it went with bitch equals dog equals wild animal equals freedom and it doesn't do anything with any of it. The idea just hangs there and feels shallow, like clickbait.

column3: The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh (1977)
column4: This is a bit of a return to the episodic ones that kind of seem to end with the new Renaissance. A lot is done to help make up for that by how this truly embraces being the silver screen version of a bedtime story. This is far from the only of these two open on the image of a book to underline the fact that it's an adaptation since that's what the studio was doing until fairly recently. But it is the first and possibly only to play with that. The narrator can talk directly to the people a non-zero amount of times, someone almost goes flying off the page until they turn to the next one, etc. In addition a lot of the humor comes from verbal comedy, imagine g rated Blackadder, so there's rhyming, double meaning and more. This delivers everything that we at the time expected from it's ilk; it's fun funny cute exciting communicates its positive messages well the animation is smooth, they had really gotten the hang of making humans look right by this point much better than the otherwise excellent but occasionally awkward Snow White, everything moves exactly as is supposed to unless that's the gag.nnI believe it is accurate to the source material so I can't credit this with inventing it; rather I'll acknowledge how great it is that it's stays true to how different the personalities of the characters are, and often the ones you would expect to be anxious based on the animal they are, also are here. For example the rabbit and the piglet who's so nervous that even when he writes his name he stutters. In today's vernacular Tigger has ADHD. He's easily distracted and has a one-track mind, wants to do the thing he likes all the time even when it gets him in trouble, others sometimes find him annoying on account of all this. We have to learn to live with each other's quirks rather than try to fix each other we have to operate from a place of empathy. In closing when Winnie the Pooh himself is stuck in the hole that leads into the bunny's home, we get the most concentrated instance of something that appeared in all of the other features from The Corporation leading up to it, and that is of course butt centric jokes. I swear someone's always falling on their behind, it's sticking out, they're getting hit in it and so forth. 8/10.

Really enjoyed this drama, I finished the book over the weekend knowing the drama was about to start. I enjoyed the drama very much, although there were dramatic changes such as Maddies profession whitch was different to the book it pretty much stuck to the same basic storyline and a lot of the events were similar. I watched the whole thing in one sitting and would highly recommend. The cast was a fantastic cast and I thought they fit the rolls really well. It was especially grate to see Sanetra Saka from Casualty feature as she's an actriss i really like. The plot was very suspensful and contained a lot of grate twist. I am alwyas glad when a drama that is based on a book remains close to the drama.

I really enjoyed this movie. I liked the young leads and Hallmark using some new young faces. I liked the realistic portrayal of young people pursuing acting or theater as a career and how often they need other jobs to make ends meet. I liked that she was taller than him. I liked that the movie wasn't condensed into a one-week romance. I enjoyed it so much that I was surprised by the low IMDb rating on this one. I read many of the other reviews and I can understand some of the criticism, but overall I thought it was a darling movie. I don't understand anyone claiming Katie Findlay was bad because she was fantastic and such a breath of fresh air for Hallmark.

I'm assuming most of the reviews here were written by men based on their ratings, their review titles, the complaints about audio and their reviews. A 13 year old girl. Multiple 15,16 year olds. All doing the exact same thing I did in college - party and cut loose with my new found freedom. In retrospect, I'm lucky nothing really awful ever happened to me and so glad I never went to a big spring break location. If a girl is underaged, consumed alcohol and can't walk or speak on her own - she cannot give consent. Period. This guy rivals our new president in his narcissism, truly shocking. Multiple audio and video tapes of his abuse, so many lawsuits in the US and other countries that I lost track. The author of the article/main interviewer/narrator is so incredibly well spoken and so clearly did her due diligence. I hope Joe Francis rots alone in a tiny apartment after he's extradited and prosecuted. This film is about a sexual predator who is well educated, rich, entitled and well spoken - all a man needs to succeed in any business. Men who justify his behavior - imagine your daughter or your sister or your niece or your granddaughter being put in this position. And believe me it could absolutely happen to the sweetest, nicest, naive, sheltered young girls. 13 years old.

Over 50 minutes of the movie is watching the main character get violated. Over 50 minutes. I genuinely can't understand how this has so many high ratings and good words. Who the hell enjoys watching a girl get sadistically played with for fifty minutes? And this isn't supposed to be porn while the camera does slow pans over her breasts, crotch and other areas? You people are sick. I don't get it. I love horror movies, thriller, revenge stories- all of it. But this is just porn for people who like watching women suffer. FIFTY MINUTES. Can't believe I watched this garbage when all the reviews were saying good things. I was expecting brutality and awful things to happen to her, but not for half of the movie with her being unable to do literally anything, and us just watching a woman get toyed with like she's a ragdoll. And these reviews sure fooled me. Can't believe yall think the rest of the movie was worth it. You people are genuinely sick.

Herald for Darkseid, Stephenwolf, arrives on Earth searching for the mysterious mother boxes. Wonder Woman and Batman must recruit more members to their alliance if they wish to stand a chance of stopping Steppenwolf and his army of Para-demons.nnI was one of the few who somewhat enjoyed this film when it came out. Its not the best don't get me wrong and suffers from cheesiness but the action is often fun enough. The CGI is mostly alright but there are times when it looks pretty average or in the case of Henry Cavells moustache removal, downright horrible. There's also some questionable camera angles and physical humour, particularly involving Woman Woman, that could be considered sexist. I'm not as concerned about that stuff but it is noticeable when it happens. Compared to Zack Snyders Justice League Cut, this version does have a couple things going for it - runtime and colour. The 2017 Justice League is a more manageable 2hrs in length (which is still 2hrs 20 minutes shorter than Snyders!) and the colour theme is brighter, whereas Snyders was quite dull and brown a lot of the time.nnFinal Verdict: It's a okay film. You can tell it was chopped and changed and cellotaped backed together from whatever it was originally going to be and it kind of feels like a try-hard Avengers film but you know what, it was fun for what it was.

column3: We're All Going to the World's Fair (2021)
column4: This movie is a waste of time, producers might have thought they're being metaphorical but the reality is they had no story, bad acting, the timeliness is very unclear, also it did not discuss an issue nor gave a closure (they thought they did).nnSo I am not trying to be really harsh but it is like watching a c grade film for someone's first attempt at college.nnMost importantly, the ending of the movie was kinda cut fast.nnIt was bad enough that I created an Imdb account although I am sleepy just to leave a review.nnDo not watch it unless you really have too much positive energy and trying to force yourself to get bored and confused.

I know this season it not finished will come up part 2. My point is why this season 3 not same canon and messed up with plot also missed information and feel like it skipped information. And wasted my excited for season 3 and not what I expected itnnI was looking forward about Yahya meet gosha after 36 years and same time this manga not there in tv show that where make me piss off don't make me remind me of dragon ball super when manga not related to tv show called "NO PLOT" and what make waiting for 4 years and result not match from manga!! Since this tv show makes me already disappointed.nnWhen coming out part 2 ?

My first review ever, and one of the worst movies ever. Thought it would be a serious and fascinating whodunit mystery. Thought it would be a cool period piece with a diverse cast. Instead, absolutely nothing happens more than an hour in. I don't care about any of these characters, don't care who the killer is. The only thing killed was 2+ hours of my time. BORING!! The ratings and feedback totally tricked me into thinking this was a hidden gem. Instead it was hidden for good reason.nnIf you like mysteries and whodunits there are lots of good ones, just not here. I couldn't find one redeeming quality about this movie. Shouldn't have given this a chance. IMDb ratings failed me here.nnWho did it? Who cares!

The Fallout series sounds like it aimed for a lot and missed almost everything, especially what makes post-apocalyptic worlds resonate: emotional depth, connection, and genuine stakes.nn. It is painfully SLOW.nn. Surface-Level Writing and Lack of Depth.nn. Clich√©d Tropes Over Substance.nn. Shallow Unlikeable Characters.nn. Missed Opportunities with Humor.nn. Poor World-Building.nn. Lack of Emotional Connection.nn. Hollow and Pretentious.nn. The 50s music is repetitive/ awkwardly timed and not suitable for every single scene.nn. It is full of scenes we have seen it before in other series.nn. In this world, body parts work like LEGOS.nnThe series tries to dress up as profound with theatrical sets and pretentious storytelling but quickly reveals itself as yet another post-apocalyptic slog. It drags you through predictable plotlines, lifeless characters, and cardboard conversations. The pacing is so slow it puts you to sleep, only to jar you awake with gratuitous gore and bad monster designs.nnThe production design is well crafted but ends up looking like a stage play.nnWhat was with the body part roulette! It felt more like a "we failed biology class but went ahead and wrote a script anyway" way. Normal people were walking after losing or smashing their feet! Fingers were reattached and working instantly!nnFallout isn't just violent and gory-it's violently boring and gory. For a series that supposedly thrives on survival, it sure kills the viewer's interest. Maybe those who play the game enjoyed it!nnPS: A second after my review was posted i checked to see if there was any error in writing and saw instant 30 Dislike! Obviously this people didn't have time to read my review, then noticed that the same has happened to all those reviews who have criticized the show! Whatever is happening, is not the right way to defend something so flawed, Honestly this is sad.

I loved this movie. It was more than a 10/10 for me. The characters are written so well and the casting was damn near PERFECT, EVERY CHARACTER WAS PLAYED EXCEPTIONALLY WELL.nnI have this movie downloaded on all my devics coz i rewatch it sooo much. (and i do not rewatch moves soo...)nShout out Alex Meyers for recommending it, thats how i got to hear about it and meet the love of my life, Ayo Edebiri.nnThe storyline was rather personal because im a lesbian :0, and mostly we get very deep storylines and its nice to have a coming of age, humorous movie that shows queerness from a teen perspective and explores the journey (in a more accepting society)nThis movie will always be a favorite and very close to my heart. So yeah WATCH IT!!!

After viewing 20+ seasons, it is disappointing and disheartening to witness the tainting of this show's writing and production by western Hollywood-esque standards.nnThe stereotypical tropes of portraying several its Black cast of characters in negative roles is unfortunate. Too many of them have either been snuffed early in a story, (framing a Black man by way of a suicide by lynching), troubled, criminal, addicted, abused or in subordinate demeaning and undignified roles.nnFor what began as an incredible series is deteriorating making it now difficult to view.nnGuess I'll have to wait for the final season of Vera.

I like two types of reality tv: feel-good shows like Queer Eye, Biggest Loser, etc., and the more guilty-pleasure type shows where you know there's going to be drama, but that's why you're there, like The Circle, or any of the many, many dating shows out there. This show is just garbage.nnI was hoping to see luxury real estate in New York. That's about 5 minutes of the show. The rest is ridiculous drama that is cringy and had me rolling my eyes and saying "grow up". We never really find out if the people buy the apartments they're shown, but we definitely learn that these women still act like they are in high school. There are two guys in the show that seem to just be eye candy, from the slow closeup going up and down the shirtless body of the one guy, to the preview of the two of them playing basketball shirtless (I barely made it through the first episode and refuse to watch the rest).

A fantastic cast of characters and a story with many twists and turns. This film gets better and better as it goes on with so many unexpected moments. The dialogue and storyline move quickly with a very unexpected twist and turns. You'll be on the edge of your seat with this mystery meets comedy film. Everything gets resolved by the end for a highly satisfying and entertaining film.nnI loved the drug scenes with some really great comedic acting. The hilarity of sex with a corpse was also really funny. The house it's filmed in is gorgeous and everything is super polished and well done. Highly recommend!

The show is very disappointing, especially considering its title. A show called "Selling" should deliver on its promise of showcasing sales, but instead, it falls flat. It's baffling how a concept centered around selling, whether it's luxury real estate or high-stakes business deals, barely includes any of the selling process at all. There's no real insight into how deals are closed, no behind-the-scenes look at negotiations, and no strategies revealed that could captivate viewers. The title misleads the audience into expecting a focus on the actual art of selling, yet what we're given is something entirely different.nnInstead of focusing on selling, the show leans heavily into drama-far too much drama. While drama can add a layer of entertainment to a reality series, in this case, it completely overshadows the premise. Audiences tune in to see aspirational lifestyles, entrepreneurial skills, and success stories, but what they get is petty squabbles and overproduced conflict. The balance is entirely off, and it feels like the producers prioritized creating sensational moments over showcasing substance. If drama was meant to enhance the narrative, it should have been used sparingly to complement the selling aspect, not dominate the show entirely.nnMoreover, the lack of diversity is glaring and deeply problematic, especially given the city the show is set in. The cast does not adequately represent the multicultural vibrancy of one of the most diverse cities in the world. This missed opportunity is not just disappointing-it's a disservice to the audience and to the city itself. A diverse cast would have brought fresh perspectives, richer stories, and a more authentic reflection of the city's demographic makeup. Instead, the cast feels homogeneous, making the show feel disconnected from the real-world community it's supposed to portray.nnRepresentation matters, and in a time when audiences are calling for more inclusivity, the show's lack of diversity feels like a step backward. It's not just about ticking boxes; it's about capturing the essence of a diverse city and showing the different ways people navigate their professional and personal lives. A show set in a global, multicultural city should reflect that reality, and this one falls short in a way that feels tone-deaf and uninspired.nnTo improve, the show needs to reassess its priorities. First and foremost, it should deliver on its promise of focusing on selling. Viewers are drawn to shows like this to gain insights into the hustle, the negotiation skills, and the innovative ways professionals close deals. Including more scenes that explore the intricacies of the selling process-client interactions, marketing strategies, and challenges faced-would make the show far more engaging and informative. Audiences don't want a superficial glimpse; they want to feel inspired by the effort and creativity that goes into high-stakes sales.nnSecondly, the drama needs to be dialed down and used as a seasoning rather than the main dish. Conflict can be engaging, but it should not overshadow the core theme of the show. Producers need to strike a balance, allowing viewers to connect with the cast on a professional level while still enjoying occasional glimpses into their personal lives.nnFinally, the cast desperately needs an overhaul to include individuals from a variety of backgrounds, cultures, and experiences. This would not only make the show more relatable to a broader audience but also enhance the narrative with new and compelling perspectives. A more inclusive approach would elevate the show, making it more authentic and representative of the community it aims to showcase.nnIn its current form, the show feels like a missed opportunity on multiple levels. The misleading title, excessive drama, and lack of diversity are significant flaws that prevent it from resonating with viewers. With some thoughtful changes, it could transform into a show that not only entertains but also informs and inspires. For now, however, it remains a disappointment that fails to live up to its potential.

Newman's Luke escapes for the whole second half of the movie! It's also kind of bittersweet that the filmmakers decide not to show how Newman gets captured, but leaves it at first on the prisoners- who after getting beaten up by Oscar winning George Kennedy's rily character, and getting them to fix a road like its some competition- and then just suddenly he's caught again. At one point this even leads to the now classic line, once sampled in a Guns n Roses song, "what we've got here is failure to communicate" by the always great character actor Strother Martin. Though if you're not really looking for message or allegory, it's also just a really neat 'guy' movie, in the best sense of the word, with scenes like the torturous girl-washes-car-in-front-of-chain-gang scene, and of course ones that just show them acting like real guys. It's populated by a plethora of acting talent, with Kennedy, Dennis Hopper, Luke Askew,

After 40 minutes of yelling at the main character we finally rage quit. We don't know the ending but we hope he dies. He's such an idiot. His girlfriend Nora is too good for him. His in-utero child would be better off without him.nnOk. That's a bit much, but our whole family was so frustrated by this move.nnOf course this whole thing is the writer's fault. They wrote a character who constantly makes frustratingly idiotic decisions showing zero common sense. We ended up hating the character. On top of that, the plot relies on impossible turns.nnIf you are somebody who likes things to make a modicum of sense, stay away from this movie. Seriously.

Unfortunately, this movie wasn't very good, but not because of the racism. The overall storyline was good but should've dug deeper. He also started a lot of good side stories but didn't finish them. It seemed like a movie full of side stories. It also dragged a little towards the middle and there was so much meaningless dialogue. There were meaningless flashbacks, dancing and music that didn't add to the movie and took time away from the story he could've been telling. Overall the movie felt very disjointed. The cinematography was good though. Like I said, style over content.nnNow about the racism. What's really funny is all the reviews mad about the film showing the racism that existed, but not at the fact that racism actually existed during wartime! LOL. That was the best and most consistent part of the story. It showed how ridiculous and unnecessary racism is and how all it does is compound whatever problem you're going through. McQueen wasn't making a "statement" or trying to "add" to the movie by showing this, he was simply explaining what life would have been for a mixed race little boy during that time. Being mad at that really says more about the audience than McQueen. One review said he couldn't "leave it alone". Newsflash, there's no way to "leave alone" something that exists for you every single day because of the color of your skin. Regardless of this though, the movie still wasn't good and that sucks because I really wanted it to be.

This was a really good mini series. There was a lot of mystery which kept you glued so you wanted to keep watching. The relationship between the friends was very interesting and believable. They were a good mix. The Love story and the way it was told was so good that even if you couldn't get into the series you also couldn't stop watching to see how it would turn out. The dog farmer and the murders were well written and so engrossing even when feeling so bad for the circumstances of the lives taken. There were many twists and turns with the storylines and the reason for her father's death and the people involved were great.

So no one has seen "Empire Strikes Back", "Lord of the Rings", or "The Bourne Trilogy"? Do you guys not understand how trilogies and three-part stories are supposed to work?nnWe were already told that there would be three seaons total, and that BOTH seasons would be out at various times. And the director already made a public announcement far before Season 2 was released that Season 2 and 3 were a two-part narrative of the series.nnThe ending of Season 2 was not only designed to add more suspense and desire for Season 3, but also because it takes a long, long time to prepare two seasons of a show within a 1 year time frame.nnThe fact that all the vast majority of "bad" reviews are focused on something that was already talked about and discussed is absolutely ridiculous.nnAnd go ahead and talk about bad writing and cheap plots all you want after you make a show better reviewed and received than this!

Linda didn't have a choice. All the bathrooms were locked up. What was she supposed to do.nnAa long as she cleaned it up. Right. And what was the cop doing right there to busy her.nnAnd the lady cop was so rude and not giving her a break. And officer Bosco was a real jerk.nnAnd why does Louise always mess up the belchers credit cards. I thought she was the smart one.nnAnd why didn't Bob go to another ATM. There has to be other ATMs in this town.nnAlso, Linda should of just been given a ticket to show up at court, nor held. It's just a misdemeanor to poop outside.nnThis entire episode doesn't make sense.

"Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" is an emotionally resonant and visually stunning take on modern-day relationships, identity, and the impact of technology on human connections. Directed with sensitivity and nuance, the film beautifully captures the struggles of a generation caught between the virtual and real worlds.nnThe story revolves around three friends navigating love, ambition, and the loneliness that often accompanies hyper-connectivity. The chemistry between the lead actors feels authentic, and their performances are heartfelt. The dialogues are sharp yet relatable, reflecting the lives of young urbanites today.nnWhat stands out most is the film's unique narrative style. It doesn't preach or moralize; instead, it lets the audience feel the void created by an overly digital lifestyle. The cinematography deserves special mention-Mumbai has rarely been shown with such intimacy and charm. The background score subtly enhances the emotional beats of the story without overpowering it.nnThat said, the film does have a few moments where the pace dips, and some subplots feel underexplored. But these minor shortcomings don't take away from its overall impact. "Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" is a refreshing, thought-provoking watch that lingers long after the credits roll.nnIt's a must-watch for anyone seeking a film that mirrors the complexities of our digital age while reminding us of the importance of real connections.

I have never written a review on IMDB in my life but felt compelled to make an account just to write a review for this show.nnWhat a waste of time. Story looks promising at first but goes absolutely nowhere. Characters are all so strange, make nonsensical decisions all the time and their motivations are just mental.nnMain characters dad goes nuts because he's about to be found out as gay and how convenient her fiancee turns up and accidentally stabs him right in the heart. Who decided this was worth making a program out of. Somehow the main character is so important that everyone around her decides to live some mad conspiracy just to try and keep her happy. Bizarre.

The parts that stood out to me the most were Shoji and Spinners polar opposite views on Heteromorph Racism, and Rock Lock's interaction with one of the Heteromorphs, saying a Colored person wouldn't know what its like to be oppressed, showing that Colorism in MHA is more of a forgotten type of racism, and its changed to how your body looks, instead on how it is colored.nnSpinner never really shone as a villain to me personally, he struck me as a follower more than a leader, and that's shown brightly here because has struggling to take leadership of the army he and his commanders amassed, Combining that with Shoji, who's the person in the right in the situation, being a sufficient leader and trying to guide the heteromorphs in the right direction, using their malice for good instead of bad.

I have never walked out of a movie before until I watched this!!! I am a Christian but I still enjoy some horror movies. (Halloween, nightmare on elm street, scream) . But The amount of demonic and sexual undertones was overwhelming. Way too much unnecessary nudity. I went to watch this with my bf and we were uncomfortable until we decided to leave. I also didn't appreciate the fact that there is pretty blatant evidence for pedophilia coming from Nosveratu. Please trust me and don't watch this movie if you are a proclaiming Christian. Or really any person that doesn't like demonic or spiritual movies or ideas.

Anyone with half a brain could figure out where the story was going to go about a quarter of the way through the movie. As a Hallmark movie, there are tropes that need to be followed. Most important - no kiss until the last moment before "roll credits!" Well, this movie violated that rule not once, but TWICE! (There are no epilogues in a Hallmark movie - stop that!)nnThe story did have its moments, and I will always tear up at a reunion of long-separated family members or a moving goodbye scene. So Hallmark still did a good job of tugging at heartstrings. But I have to complain about the IMDb listing - only the three primary actors listed? Is that because the woman playing the grandmother looked younger than the woman who was supposed to be her daughter? I do hope that is fixed once the movie has been released on all platforms...nnThere were major plot holes and continuity issues that disrupted the viewing experience for me. (What happened to the tulips? Why didn't the women buy a beverage in the pub? Why did repairing the garden table transform it into something so ugly when they were both supposed to be historic heirloom preservers? I HAVE QUESTIONS!!!)nnProps to the main characters for actually looking like you cared about each other. That's rare in a Hallmark movie.

"The Way to Eden" (Feb. 21, 1969) Old TV Guide synopsis: 'The Enterprise captures six spaceship-snatching rebels who are led by a long-robed fanatic determined to reach the mystical planet Eden.' A wrong headed attempt to do 'space hippies' that offers a more substantial role for Skip Homeier ("Patterns of Force") as a maniacal guru carrying a disease that could kill all his followers. Imagine viewers dismissing this episode mere months before Charles Manson became front page news with the brutal slayings of actress Sharon Tate and all of her houseguests, the utopian ideal held by the hippie movement turned on its head in distasteful fashion. These rebels insist on deriding Kirk as 'Herbert' (don't ask), and find a kindred spirit in Spock, essentially a half human outcast who has already found his own Eden aboard the Enterprise, finally rejecting the undisciplined methods involved in their journey. The climactic revelation that it's not the paradise they believed it would be is another cruel reminder that "You Can't Always Get What You Want" (the upcoming B-side of The Rolling Stones #1 hit "Honky Tonk Women").

Have you ever seen a movie that you heard was so great and then wandered out of the theater wondering why? That was my feeling in 1981 and the people I was with thought the same leaving us all baffled at the acclaim. All these years later, my opinion hasn't changed. I give this a fairly high rating because the acting is very good as is the excellent cinematography and of course, there is that very famous musical score, which was beautiful until so overplayed on sports shows, commercials, events, etc, it became an eye roller after a while. I've rated this low because this story of two runners aiming for and eventually participating in the Olympics of 1924 where one is running for God and the other because he's an angry Jew trying to prove himself is boring much of the time despite being a quality piece of filmmaking. I read here that 40 minutes were cut due to studio insistence, a fact I've never heard before. I usually balk at such news, but not in this case. This won an Oscar for best film over Raiders of the Lost Ark, Reds, Atlantic City and On Golden Pond, all better movies and one of the very rare films to win best picture without nominating the man who created it, the director. Perhaps those who are more religious than I just appreciate this more.

I don't understand why so many people give it a bad rating. I'll give it a 9 because it was very entertaining and, just like in Coben's novels, there are plot twists until the final minute but everything makes sense. Good acting and tension always at its maximum. I'm a writer and I envy Coben's ability to constantly generate "cliffhangers". It's not easy to achieve it but Coben manages it. Someone said that it seems like a script created by artificial intelligence, I don't think this is possible, this story is without a doubt pure creation of an intelligent and creative human. I look forward to Coben's next series. Many thanks Mr. Coben!!

As someone who has binge-watched every season of Queer Eye the moment it drops, I've always been enamored with the show's heartfelt concept. The Fab Five's genuine care, humor, and expertise have turned each episode into an inspiring journey of transformation-not just for the heroes they help, but for viewers like me.nnThat said, Season 9 feels like a departure from the magic that made Queer Eye so special in its earlier seasons. While it's important to acknowledge the incredible talent and dedication of the Fab Five (and to emphasize that my critique has nothing to do with the new team dynamic), the way the season is shot leaves much to be desired.nnThe production choices this time feel overly polished, as though the focus has shifted from the authenticity of their interactions to a strange emphasis on manicured poses or random staged activities. The result feels forced, almost bordering on the kind of overly scripted vibe we associate with shows like Selling Sunset. This is disappointing for a show that has always thrived on its genuine, natural energy.nnI miss the raw, unscripted charm that made the first eight seasons so impactful. While the transformations are still meaningful, and the Fab Five's expertise shines through, the shift in tone detracts from the emotional depth and humor that once felt so effortless.nnQueer Eye is at its best when it feels real, when we see the humanity in the Fab Five and the people they're helping. I hope future seasons return to that sweet spot-because that's what made me (and so many others) fall in love with the show in the first place.

This was a really good show, and I would recommend this for teens, adults, or anyone over 13 who just needs a comfort show to watch. This show was not just entertaining but helped me learn about being bisexual, gay, trans, a romantic and many more, and the importance of it. Heartstopper gave me an important message in every single episode and helped me learn more about myself then I did before. Furthermore, I have watched this show twice and am on my 3rd time because I'm watching this with my mom and she loves it. If this review doesn't make you want to watch one of my favorite shows ever I don't know what will, but I really hope you watch this show because it helped me in many ways! Ps, this show helped me get through hard times in my life.

Nothing too new or insightful here. Very over-produced and sensationalized. There's a lot of repetition throughout and choppiness switching from "expert" to "expert." It's hard to watch more than one or two in a row for how repetitive it is.nnThere are some very real flaws/oversights in this show. One example is the Aileen Wuornos episode, where men just sat around calling her evil and soulless, speculating that "maybe" her rough upbringing contributed to her behavior. Wow. Earth-shattering revelation. The producers of this show didn't think it might be important to interview a female expert? It just feels icky when a female victim of a lifetime of abuse is on TV getting blasted by a bunch of men.nnI guess Donnie Wahlberg did a good job reading from cue cards?

S2 story line is wafer thin. Juliette's storyline is creeping to somewhere unknown and pointless. Ps: as a scuba diver, that scene pissed me off!nnPlease start killing off some of the characters. Let's start with Walk & Juliette!nnAll the characters are unlikeable, except for Solo.nnI have to write 600 words to be able to post this review. So I'll repeat what I said above ....nnS2 story line is wafer thin. Juliette's storyline is creeping to somewhere unknown and pointless. Ps: as a scuba diver, that scene pissed me off!nnPlease start killing off some of the characters. Let's start with Walk & Juliette!nnAll the characters are unlikeable, except for Solo.

I created an IMDb account just to leave a review because I feel compelled to warn others about how excruciatingly frustrating this show is. I went in with high hopes, but after investing four hours of my time, I found it to be an absolute waste. It was a painful experience, What made it even worse was how unrealistic the events were, especially as they led to a disaster. The selfishness of the daughter and the selflessness of the father were both exaggerated to the point of absurdity, making their actions seem contrived and unconvincing. It was frustrating to watch such unbelievable character choices unfold, and it only added to the overall disappointment.

The plot to this movie isn't anything crazy out or out of this world. Its core conflict starts early in the movie, centering around family and whether family should drive one's own future or be able to find one's own future through passion and skill. The idea of being generational trauma (a parent abandoning a family, whether intentional or not, for a music career) plays heavily into the movie and how that unfolds over generations. The movie as a whole pulls at the heartstrings when a family pulls together and loves each other despite being mad at each other. I definitely felt like this movie did a good job of handling tough topics and bringing both joy and sadness in equal measure.nnSurrounding the plot of the movie involves a lot of folklore and tradition, pulling in good music, animation and storytelling. The animation was spectacular, as are most Pixar movies in my opinion, as it pulls in a lot of culture themes such as the Day of the Dead and includes a lot of color without overdoing it. The movie's concept of the Land of the Dead is novel and gave a concept of a city beyond ours where the dead lived, worked and partied. The music was amazing, centering around the guitar, and the singing was amazing by all actors.

Okay, hear me out...this story felt like the character of Samuel was a sort of version of Mary Poppins, but sexual. He came into this woman's life when he was needed and left when he was no longer needed. Doesn't that sound like Mary Poppins to you?nnThe story, as we know, is about a bored wife that hasn't gotten an orgasm from her husband and we see that she can only climax watching porn and masturbating on her own. She has fantasies that have yet to be explored because her wants and needs have been kept silent in fear of being judged as being "abnormal" by her husband.nnSo, in comes at the most opportune time a man named Samuel that seems to have the qualities she is needing most and he has also fully picked up on. Perhaps he is an empath and is fully aware of the situation but it seems as two consenting adults go forth and explore this unknown territory together it brings out the version of Romy (Nicole Kidman) that she has been needing to set free. It's all about communication and consent folks. The big issue is that he is an intern and she is an executive so it makes it into a power struggle...but not for long.nnWhen things get too dangerous for her in keeping her job and her family together, she wants to back off. In fear of Samuel asking to be transferred and an investigation ensuing, she lets it continue to run its course. The sub and dom elements in this film were slight but okay, I can see how intriguing that can be but the control over a dog aspect between Samuel in the beginning and the end when Jacob (Antonio Banderas) and Romy were exploring each other in new ways because of how Samuel opened up a new world for them both, why keep showing Samuel and the dog while Romy is climaxing? Does she feel like she is the dog because, if so, that feels just so wrong.nnAnyways, Samuel ended up being transferred to a new company in Hong Kong or Tokyo or wherever I can't remember but he left as easily as he came into their lives...much like Mary Poppins. They have a happier marriage now and everyone lives happily ever after. That about sums it up.nnNicole Kidman was stellar as Romy and I loved how she opened herself up and had shown a side of her that she hasn't shown before. The vulnerability was beautiful and I appreciate her ability to take on such a role.nnThe soundtrack was fantastic. I quite enjoyed the 80's mixed into the synth pop and enveloping the storyline to help the characters along the way.nnI loved it. It probably was the best idea going to see it with my dad (he wanted to see it and my mom didn't want to go so I volunteered.) The most uncomfortable I felt was hearing George Michael's "Father Figure" during their sexy time haha! My dad right beside me, I had to just pretend I wasn't really there anymore xD.

I'm not expert by any means at all. This show has been highly predictable for each character. We don't like how sexualized the entire show is. It's nonsense & garbage writing. The attorney and his fantasies about a minor teen girl are disgusting. After the first episode we finished the season watching through Vidangel to take all that out. But you can still clearly see how trashy the daughter & her Mom, Angela behave. Angela could be a really in depth character too if they would give her better material. The son could as well be a very good character to add depth to the show. The guy is likable. Overall it's simply just okay to a normal, tv watcher.

Just a ridiculous unfunny show. Apparently I have to put more effort into my review than they put into this show. I'm sure mouthbreathers might find this funny, but anyone who lives in the real world wouldn't. I actually like Dennis Leary as an actor and a comedian, but he must be running out of money. I have no idea how he could have possibly read the premise of the show and went "This will be a masterpiece! They will remember me until the end of time!" He has to be doing this for the quick buck. I imagine in private he hates himself for doing this show. He can't possibly find any of this funny.

One of the worse movies I have ever seen. I walked out of the movie theater. Story line, corny. Seemed like an excuse to see Kidman naked every 5 minutes. I am sorry someone convinced her this was a good role to play. I know she will look back very soon and regret this decision. And the young was not attractive physically and had zero charm. Atleast pick a better story line for the male actor. He seemed ignorant. I just understand the need for all the sex scenes we get it, leave that to the privacy of your own home. One lady next to me fell asleep. It was boring and cheap. Sorry I wasted 50 minutes of my time.

Ryan Eggold is by far above the other actors. Really poor casting, from unrealistic soap actors to an ill fitting cap on an unconvicing police liutenant. Unessesary naked love scene, with yet another female actor going naked. It would be refreshing to find a female actor that hasn't gone topless once in a while. Unconvincing plot with the cops turning up just too late every single time. Good to see some new black actors, but there must be better out there. To be captive in a cupboard until the tradesman finish the job before shouting lol. Shoot someone and they fall over a 4 feet fence into a river ???. Hopscotch suddenly changes numbers... too much.

This episode is amazing, the tension and development of the episode is fantastic, the animation was also very well done, and the direction was surprising throughout the episode,Levi is also explored very carefully, and his relationship with Erwin is incredible, the impact of this episode is very good and the emotion caused by it too, in the end it was a special episode For the work, being a milestone in the entire anime, the end of the episode was exciting and surprising, causing a conflict with the viewer when watching the episode.nnAn episode that I consider perfect overallnnI hope a lot for the future of the characters.

A truly powerful and moving depiction of the Lockerbie bombing and all that transpired thereafter.nnThe series follows the story of Jim Swire, whose daughter was killed in the bombing and who spends the rest of his life fighting for justice (he continues to this day).nnThe series sends you on a rollercoaster of emotions and leaves you thinking about cover-ups, miscarriage of justice and of course, all those who lost their lives in the bombing.nnColin Firth is incredible...as ever, and portrays Jim Swire's painful search for justice, so unbelievably well.nnThoughts and prayers go to all those who lost their lives in the bombing and to the families who continue to fight for the truth.

Sleepaway Camp (1983).nnAt the beginning of the credits you can see the consequences of the ending with so many murders that they finally got the camp closed.nnThe atmosphere at the camp is nicer than in the Friday The 13th part VI movie.nnSome like Ricky, Mozart have fun at the Camp, others are mean and deserve their punishments like Artie, Billy, Mel, Judy, Meg, Kenny, Paul.nnThe good guys were Ronnie, Sussie, Gene, Jeff, Eddie and the lifeguard.nnIt's the homophobic movie. The best characters are Ricky and his crazy mother Martha straight out of a sitcom, the crazy mother has nice physical features.nnAngela who is a man stares at Judy out of physical attraction.
