Angela/Peter is bisexual then she feels a crush on Paul the lascivious.nnIt's a good movie, but Angel/Peter exaggerated almost at the end killing almost anyone who sees him as ugly.

The only thing that's crafty and supreme about this series is that it manages so well to keep you on the edge of your seat. And for the last 2 days, I felt compelled to watch it and finish it.nnBut I felt like I was chewing ashes in my mouth after it was done. And realized I was taken on a journey where I felt like I had to participate, but the journey was unconvincing and I didn't like how it ended.nnI felt like I was rooting for the main character as much as I was getting convinced about his not being guilty. At times it even felt like there was logic, what felt like strong logic to the story.nnPlenty of scenes throughout the series try to paint a picture of people being imperfect or making poor life choices and at the same time trying to convince you those choices are truly bad but then it feels like these characters aren't really paying any price for those choices.nnTake the lead character for instance. He's transgressed big time, cheated on his wife and his children, yet they stay by him unflinchingly, only ever so slightly asking fearful questions about his potential guilt or not really provoking him. That guy has the support any cheating man can ever wish for. For his family to be so epically gaslit, it's just difficult to believe.nnAnd the problem with the entire series is that there are plenty of situations or cases where it's difficult to believe what happens. And because there's an illogical lack of real-life consequences (despite the Stockholm syndrome portrayed by the family plus almost anyone otherwise close to the main character), it just doesn't add up and at some point you realize you're being taken on a sequence of unexpected illogical turns just so that you second-guess or assign guilt to virtually any other character.nnTo also then end in such an epic way for the family given the huge amount of stress portrayed by the ending, and then their final scene showing some utter family bliss is just outright not acceptable. Any such big unfairness comes out in spades via ways the family members pay for somehow in the future.nnWhat's more, for the victim in the series that's portrayed several times as this gentle with kids prosecutor but then completely spit out the fact that she was pregnant in front of the child of the main character which felt diabolical to say the least... that's sheer character inconsistency. Plus, if you took so many steps to hide, why become so outright disrespectful with the guy's family? Just because she was suddenly confronted? It doesn't make any logical sense.nnThis series is a ride that keeps you glued to the screen, but that's everything it does. The character inconsistencies and the frivolity of the turn of events make it effective, but certainly not realistic of high writing quality. You'd end up feeling highly cheated, perhaps in many ways much more so than the characters' family was by his transgressions in the script.

I chose to watch this mainly because of the cast, but also because it had a promising story line.nnI regretted it almost immediately, but stuck with it until episode 3, after which I take no more.nnIt's a cross between a James Bond spoof, and an LBTGQ soft porno / romance.nnPlot holes are huge, writing is in the 'wing it' style, and believability is practically zero. It completely failed to interest me, or to engage me in any way. At one point I actually checked it's classification on IMDB, just to see if was indeed meant to be a comedy; it isn't.nnIt tries to be a 'Slow Horses', but gets absolutely nowhere near, just a clich√©d, boring, empty, crass pile of unbelievable, accidental comedy.nnI gave it two stars rather than one as the cast is excellent and the acting is good. But why Sarah Lancashire or Kiera Knightley would of taken parts in this script is beyond me. I can't imagine they are stuck for work!nnDon't waste your time.

It's difficult to review this movie.nnEither because it's linearly the direct sequel of Gladiator (one of the most beloved and rightly praised epics of the last 30 years), but also because the movie seems to anchor itself too much to the first one to create a real emotional connection.nnOn the other hand there are too many positive aspects on the movie to say it's not a good entertaining action flick, especially the acting (Denzel and Joseph Quinn are really the best ones) but also the exquisite costume design and the whole Rome/Colosseum environment is visually stunning and historically enlarged in a very epic way.nnI felt that perhaps Ridley Scott really had a strong personal motivation, even somehow postponed or asleep since Gladiator, to be able to drive the Roman Empire background storyline to a next level. It is clearly showing a lot more of the political and social background, now with up to date CGI technology and additional resources (and I dare to say budget and production decision making), at his disposal to do it.nnI believe he could have pitched this as an entirely independent story from Gladiator and from the initial storyline, but I also agree the sequel was hard to resist given some of the open family fragments coming from the original (especially the bastard son Lucius next steps) that perhaps he wanted to try to explore.nnDoes it work? Not entirely.nnI still think the best aspects of the movie are when flashbacks and dialogue connect to the first movie and ironically enough when some of the Hans Zimmer musical score from the first is played in the background (sorry Harry Gregson Williams, you are one of the greatest composers, but I didn't find this score very appealing).nnIn sum, I really think that if this movie was a an entirely separate one, with no direct/indirect connection to Gladiator, it could be perceived as more solid however the somehow convoluted story in the last 30 mins. And some rushed plot elements to make it emotionally tied with the original make it somehow fragile.nnThe Colosseum battle scenes are nice but I expected a lot more and much better after almost 25 years from the original, especially the CGI that was used, which given the risky choices of introducing baboons and sharks, clearly don't seem to have been the most effective ones.nnTo conclude, I felt entertained but as a direct sequel to Gladiator it's far from a genuine epic action movie. It has really good ideas (especially stretching the historical visual context) and even great characters ( with good acting) but I honestly felt that although Paul Mescal is indeed no Russel Crowe it is the Lucius/Hanno character that seems a little bit lost when compared with Maximus drive/ energy/ motivation and presence in the first one.nnLike I said, in a vacuum this could have worked better but with such a high legacy to cope with, it was almost doomed to be short to deliver.

This Wrestlemania was really one of the greatest. It had the best match card in all of the Wrestlemania's of that time. The Rivalry between Ricky "The Dragon" Steamboat and Randy "Macho Man" Savage and Hulk Hogan and Andre The Giant was very good.nnIt had good tag team matches but some ending's we're bad like Jake "The Snake" Roberts and Honky Tonk Man but the rest was just beautiful it had great guest's and it reached a new indoor record in the Silverdome of 93,173 people so this was the most watched event of that time.nnMany records were broken in that night and i found this Wrestlemania very entartaining and i hope Wrestlemania IV is gonna be better.

No spoilers/short review-This movie was a good watch as a horror fan. However, it's terribly overhyped. If you like horror then it's worth making a movie night out of it but it's not something that left my jaw on the floor or something that I believe to be a masterpiece-Just a typical body horror movie, but a decent one. My only criticism is the prolonged shots of butts, twerking, etc., it was super uncomfortable watching, even by myself. I found myself fast forwarding a lot of the first hour due to this. The amount of exposure wasn't needed to get the point across. It's almost like they are doing exactly what the movie portrayed and it definitely got uncomfortable and stigmatizing for women. Other than that, it's okay-if you like horror then it's worth your time.

The best advice for writers is write what you know. As a person from the south of the US, I find this very offensive. Barely does anyone run around with the confederate flags anymore and believe it or not, we do not go around killing African Americans. Look at the statistics if you don't believe me. There is more black on black crime than anything else.nnI loved this show until now. I'm not saying there is no racism but now we have equal opportunity racism. There is racism from every group which really sad but thinking this is the norm in the American South shows how ignorant the writers are and that is even more sad. Shame on y'all, your ignorance is showing.

I love cheesy Christmas movies, so I had high hopes for this one. Sadly, although cheesy, it's also a bit of a mess.nnAs a gay remake of The Holiday (Kate Winslet & Cameron Diaz) it could have been great. But it seems that the "star's" ego of writer and main character, Taylor Frey got in the way. His character is completely unlikable and his turnaround for the ending too sudden to make sense. Additionally, while Taylor can be a likable actor, this role was simply too big and required too much from his abilities.nnThe secondary characters don't fare much better. Rick Cosnett as Oliver comes across as that sighing princess stuck in her tower waiting to be saved rather than a sharp, successful attorney. Samer Salem is wasted in his role and also has too quick a turnaround for his character. Worst though is Daniel Garcia as Henry, who experiences "love at first sight" with a toxic and negative Wilde who gives him no indication that his feelings might ever be reciprocated or acknowledged. He ignores rudeness and disdain and chases after Wilde when most would have taken the first hint.nnI get that it's supposed to be a romantic holiday movie, and I really wanted to like it more. But in its current for it's too short and the character's growth just doesn't make sense .

This movie is a boring and senseless toy of a rich man, who has and takes an opportunity to show his twisted sexual fantasies on a big screen.nnIt's so problematic in many ways, that I'm genuinely terrified by the hype it gets. It's not even scary, just repulsive.nnYou can look for the deep sense in a cesspit as long as you like, but in the end - it's still just waste. And the sense itself is on the surface, being shoved in your face every 10 minutes of the narration.nnI was so excited to see the movie and I was in pure shock after. I just hope that more people will speak about it and won't follow the crowd.

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim (2024)
column4: I saw this movie in the cinema on Boxing Day, just as I had the original movie many years ago. Whereas the cinema was packed out for The Fellowship of the Ring, there were only three other people in the cinema with me for this, which is a pity.nnThe story, which is a retelling of an earlier siege of Helm's Deep by the forces of the rebellious prince Wulf, centres around Hera, Helm Hammerhand's daughter who is forced to rally the defences when her father becomes incapacitated. Unlike other stories in this universe, however, there's no quest to go on, no dragons or dark sorcerers to slay, no dwarevs or elves to deal with. It's just a conflict between Men.nnAnd to be fair, it works. Wulf is the villain of the story, but you can understand his anger. Helm Hammerhand is supposedly the hero of the siege at Helm's Deep, but his pride, temper and arrogance provoked the war in the first place and almost brought his people to ruin. It's almost Shakespearean in the way that the two main (male) antagonists are driven by their vices, their passions and their flaws to their own self-destruction ... which leads, of course, to Hera having to save the day.nnWhich leads to the only real false note in the film. Now, the character of Hera is brave, clever, loyal, likeable ... and yet, the opening narration (Miranda Otto, reprising her role of Eowyn) laments that there are no songs celebrating Hera's great deeds. Why wouldn't there be? Her side wins, and history is written by the victors, so the idea that the true hero of Helm's Deep would just pass half-forgotten in her people's folklore doesn't make a great deal of sense to me.nnBut that hardly spoils a genuinely enjoyable movie. It's not up there with Peter Jackson's trilogy but I rank it ahead of the TV adaptation and far, far ahead of those Hobbit travesties.nnAnd best of all, it inspired me to pick up the Lord of the Rings book for the first time in a couple of decades, so I'm very glad to have watched it.

I know it's very difficult to be original and make a good movie at this point, when it comes to this character, but putting a mustache on the count, I think it was the worst idea.nnI'll be very honest. As a lover of the genre, I liked the movie. Especially at the beginning, although they could have explored and developed the real estate agent's journey to the castle a little more, his arrival and his acting performance when he meets Nosferatu are outstanding and perhaps the best or one of the best of all film adaptations.nnNosferatu promised a lot and had s few good disturbing scenes worthy of a truly bastard and which will remain for the Dracula filmography but the mustache put him in the category of I already know this guy...he looks like an uncle of mine or I see him a lot somewhere, maybe he looks like the baker or the hairdresser in my neighborhood. In addition, they made him too visible on more occasions than indicated, too obvious in contrast to the use of his own shadow.nnHer scenes reminded me of the Exorcist and I found them excessive. Removing some of the intensity from her role, removing the jump scares that didn't work at all and nobody needed, focusing good old Wilem Dafoe in a different way in which he would have shined at least 20 percent of what Anthony Hopkins shined in Bram Stoker's Dracula, and removing Count Orlock's mustache would have given the film a 10 and it wouldn't have seemed so long to me; the two and a half hours were very noticeable and they shouldn't have.

Attempting to adapt one of Marvel's most iconic storylines, Dark Phoenix falls under the weight of its ambition, delivering a lackluster conclusion to the Fox X-Men era. Unlike most others in this franchise, this installment barely had anything to offer and I found it pretty boring despite the glaring flaws the film provided some fine performances but nothing too special from James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender given the material they were provided. Certain sequences such as the space mission and the final train battle had some cool elements letting each X-Men shine in their own moments and the action sequences for a brief time elevated the film. This almost feels like two movies squeezed into one leaving no room for the plot points to be explored. It is written very poorly as if the writers had not seen or read anything about the X-Men before with characters (particularly Charles Xavier) acting out of character. Jessica Chastain's character and her alien army offered no motivation and presence in the film leaving them to be very forgettable. The pacing is uneven with long stretches of nothing happening straight into rushed action. The CGI in some moments is fine but particularly in the climatic moments of the film looks horrible and outdated seeming like they were just trying to rush this one out (which they were). In a film where the emotional weight should feel very heavy, it fails to capture you emotionally and will leave you disengaged from what's going on. There is also some horrible dialogue in here and the writing fails to deliver on the narrative and emotional potential of the source material. Arriving at the end of Fox's X-Men era the film is handled with little care or passion when they should have taken time to have a grander sendoff to these characters. Overall Dark Phoenix struggles to deliver a satisfying conclusion to Fox's X-Men saga weighed down by a lackluster script, underwhelming villains, and missed opportunities to do justice to the iconic storyline it is trying to adapt.

This film is literally great! Some burning scenes & visual effects are really unimaginable! This film didn't did well in the theaters just because of another police film (singham) was released & this film is a remake of already known film! But still so many things, scenes are visually new & great in this one!! This is a wholesome grand level cinema!nnAnother negative point is Varun looking very young & the story is south based! People would've loved if this movie was made upon not oriented city or story! All though it's a visually great entertaining & hear touching movie! Well invested product!

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim (2024)
column4: I expected something entertaining like Netflix Castlevania animation series and with good animation.nnI am gonna be brutally honest - this movie felt like "lotr checklist" the movie. Its like a committee sat down, watched lotr movies together and based on that compiled a looooong checklist of things that have to be crammed into this movie. This movie wink wink nudge nudges slowly along. "Remember this bit from lotr movies? Well, heres it again except different, awkward/hollow/meaningless or unintentionally(?) comical with anime surface".nnHelms deep? Check.nnGiant elephants? Check.nnHorns blown? Several. Check.nn"Motivating" speeches of army commander in front of line of men? Check.nnGiant eagles? Check.nnOrcs? Check somehow, even if this is war between humans.nnSlowmotion "dramatic" death of a character? Check.nn"Meaningful" and "motivational", "deep" conversations? Unfortunately... Check, I guess. More on this one later.nnHijacking then killing giant elephant? Check.nnLegolas slide down the trunk of a giant elephant? Strangely, no. There was an opportunity though. I think they almost did it but decided otherwise.nn... and on and on checklist goes.nnYou get the point.nnI felt nothing when any of the characters died. I did not care for any of them. Animation was most of the time OK. Some times it was good. My favourite bit was when gramps went full JoJo on cave troll. That was my favourite bit, alongside with his whole rising to avenge his sons bit. Its just that they really didnt go anywhere with it, except yet another death I didnt care for.nnLastly... dialogue. Dear god, the dialogue. So many "profound" conversations between characters - I am sorry if this is not the case - but some of it felt like written by AI, especially those ones that were supposed to be "profound and meaningful" for the characters. If not AI, at very least written by writers who were out of their depth here.nnI several times checked clock for it to end. If this movie were 3 hours long, I'd have walked out.

Brilliant premise, and started reasonably well given they are the most unprofessional police department in the history of TV (even Police Squad lol) but season 2 is truly awful, sorry to say.nnJaime Murray/Lila ruined it for me not sure if it's the English accent sticking out like a sore thumb, or that she's constantly barely dressed or that it was so obvious she'd end up bedding Dexter but the character is annoying such as turning up at his work unannounced, manipulating the break up with Rita and just the phony breathy nature of her made me want to smash up the TV tbh.nnWay too predictable and far fetched, the amount of near misses Dexter wangles his way out of, add other unlikeable characters such as Doakes and Maria just made me switch off.

This set of short films highlight the fact that not only that art is necessary, but required even during a live stream destruction on life.nnIt shows that Gaza has a culture of art and filmmaking that continues and adapts with the on going wars they have had to endure.nnThe fact that as a world we have allowed this continue is not addressed but watching this begs to ask what is wrong with us? Why do we allow this to continue?nnEvery single short film builds on the beauty of the people, shows they skills they continue to cultivate and surfaces the resilience of the Palestinian people in a way that no other film could do.

I Saw the TV Glow (2024).nnIt is the allegory of Plato's cave. The best thing about the film would be Brigette Lundy-Paine.nnIt is a mockery since to be a director, a screenwriter they must have money to go to expensive universities. What do they know about minimum wage jobs?nnAnd be sensitive like the protagonists. In college there are fraternities and sorority houses. It is how these directors and screenwriters see people with miserable jobs.nnThis is a woman trapped in the body of a man, who is a coward who is afraid to search for her Identity, created to evade the emptiness of her mediocre reality.nnThis useless coward of a protagonist rejects it several times out of fear, he is not even curious to know if it is real or not.nnHe reaches his midlife crisis in a miserable job singing "happy birthday to you!"nnThat Pink opaque series was like Buffy the Vampire Slayer (dull which I couldn't stand, it was like a female Spider-Man who bullied men, it was stupid).nnThe visually silly villains were like something out of Sailor Moon (the anime was silly, I liked it better as Hentai) and The Power Rangers' villains.nnThe movie was like three long episode of Do you afraid the dark?

I didn't understand the story of the film itself between the characters of Nosferaiu and Ellen HutternnI liked the atmosphere, lighting, acting, image and design of Count Dracula himself.nnI liked and was surprised by the moment with the children and the course of the scene in the film was very unexpected for our time.nnI didn't like the plot between the characters of EllennHutter and Naosferatu. There are too many hints of sex and not only hints in the film. In my opinion, this is a very big minus of the film.nnAnd the second point is that the story is very drawn out, some moments could have been cut.

Shawn Levy's *Deadpool & Wolverine* delivers the expected mix of irreverent humor, over-the-top action, and fourth-wall-breaking antics. Ryan Reynolds reprises his role as the foul-mouthed antihero Deadpool, this time teaming up with Hugh Jackman's Wolverine, who's brought back to life in true comic book fashion. Together, they take on a multiverse-threatening mission while trading barbs and punches along the way.nnReynolds is as sharp and self-aware as ever, infusing Deadpool with his signature blend of sarcasm and charm. Hugh Jackman brings a gruff, world-weary edge to Wolverine, seamlessly stepping back into a role that fans have missed. Their chemistry is undeniable, providing some of the film's most entertaining moments.nnHowever, the film's frenetic pacing and reliance on multiverse tropes can feel exhausting, with the plot often taking a backseat to gags and spectacle. While fans of the characters will enjoy the callbacks and meta-jokes, newcomers might struggle to find a cohesive narrative amidst the chaos. Emma Corrin shines in a supporting role as the enigmatic antagonist, though her character deserves more depth.nnVisually, the film is polished, with action sequences that deliver plenty of thrills, albeit with a sense of d√©j√† vu. The script leans heavily on Deadpool's trademark humor, which, while effective, risks overshadowing the emotional stakes of the story.nn*Deadpool & Wolverine* is a film for die-hard Marvel fans and those who enjoy irreverent superhero antics. It's best watched with a crowd, where the humor and spectacle can be shared and amplified.nnRating: 6/10 - An entertaining but uneven ride that leans on fan service over substance.

For me this film was like watching an educational film for teenagers who hadn't learned about the holocaust before. It was a film made by Jesse Eisenberg for people that Jesse Eisenberg wanted to educate. Perhaps he had met enough people in their 20's and 30's who hadn't had the same educational experience as Woody Allen and his contemporaries had had, so this film had to be made. The impact of the holocaust on jews born in America was portrayed vividly but it was rather plastered on. As if we were made to watch a movie from a filmmaker who himself was trying to learn how to portray deep experiences in spite of being a shallow person. It's somewhat saddening that these types of films get to be made, they get the funding and the advertisement, when in fact they're made by somewhat shallow and immature people as Jesse Eisenberg who, don't get me wrong, wants to do the best tribute possible, and succeeds moderately in depicting how important it is for new generations to understand history and the horrors of holocaust, but who are just not up to anywhere near the level of filmmakers of the past. Now Woody Allen could make a film about holocaust and joke about it a lot because he lived in a world where history was taught and understood, as the filmwatchers themselves had a real connection to the holocaust, through their family experience or through school education. Unfortunately Jesse is destined to make a film about the same theme but has to inundate it with a pointless story about two cousins, which said relationship doesn't really evolve anywhere but satisfies the contemporary audience with a spectrum-set/weed-smoking/internely-disturbed character played by Kieran McCulkin, only so that it would keep the spectator involved. I hope this film be remembered as an early point on the rising learning curve of Jesse Eisenberg's films, because the intentions are perfect, the technics are great (he really knows how to drive forward a story in a hotel room without words) but the output is mediocre because what lacks is the fire, the unrelentless vigor of telling the truth, the "I don't give a peep" mode of life that he is already alluding to in Kieran's character. If he had made this film with the same burn of Kieran's character, this could have been a masterpiece. As it stands, it is merely a generational film teaching youngsters about the importance of understanding history.

A masterpiece for the eyes. Beautiful and at the same time full of very authentic details (like the depiction of Romanian people, local gipsies, old ladies at the church, etc. I am from the Balkans and I admire this part).nnSuper scary, I think I will be afraid of the darkness for quite so many days after seeing it.nnAn amazing depiction of a haunted woman by the main actress. Although she was not so impressive in the "normal" scenes, she was absolutely amazing when she was playing the posseessed or sleepwalking parts.nnThe bridge she did! (Even if it was stunted or animated, it was just mind blowing.)nBut the best part of it all was the philosophical second plan idea of the movie, which spoke of the power and darkness of the female sexuality and how it was treated and is still being treated as something animalistic, evil, a disease. Also, the internal struggle for women who try to supress it, the battle to stay faithful to your husband and the inevitability of it overwhelming the love, even when you know that it will bring a fatal end.nnAnd last but not least - the movie theater was full of people, some of them very young. Everybody watched the movie in silence and left the salon in silence. I rarely see so many people from different background being shocked and thoughtful simultaneously because of a movie.

I went into this wanting to like this series but it was ridiculously far-fetched with way too many coincidences to make the story believable.nnThe plot jumps all over the place and non of the characters are particularly likeable. There is a unfulfilling conclusion and things wrap up very quickly and somewhat strangely at the end (after Kat has forgiven her ex very very quickly).nnThe main character is particularly bad at her job and is completely fine with a stranger breaking into her home.nnThe hooks at the end of each episode keep you watching but in the end it's not worth it.nnI really wouldn't waste your time, you won't be missing much at all.....

The movies does not follow up with the line of the last movie besides that there now 2 emperors and no story behind them who are they and why did we not get a small brief on them. Besides that in the real life the character denzel plays was actually emperor so its kind of bizzare that we end up in a movie like this and he gets killed. Its very wierd the turn the film makers took with this one but then again it was not the best movie ever either the worst one the story was cool it just needed a little bit more explanation on who is everybody because we felt a little out of zone in this one.nnCheers.

Luca Guadagnino's Queer attempts to translate William S. Burroughs' semi-autobiographical novel into cinema, but it stumbles along the way. The film boasts a visually stunning backdrop and a heartfelt performance by Daniel Craig, yet the disjointed narrative and indulgent pacing hold it back from greatness.nnCraig imbues William Lee with vulnerability, but the obsessive fixation on Eugene Allerton, portrayed by Drew Starkey, lacks the depth needed for genuine emotional resonance. The chemistry between the leads is insufficient to spark the tension that the story hinges upon.nnGuadagnino's signature aesthetic is unmistakable, with lush cinematography and a thoughtfully curated soundtrack. However, these elements cannot overcome a narrative weighed down by uneven pacing and heavy symbolism. The episodic structure struggles to maintain momentum, making certain scenes feel repetitive and aimless.nnFor fans of Guadagnino or experimental storytelling, Queer offers moments of visual and auditory delight, but it falls short of delivering an emotionally profound or memorable cinematic journey.nnRating: 7/10 - A visually rich yet emotionally distant adaptation.

I was very entertained by this movie, good performances all around. Initially I found it by going throught Alicia SIlverstones filmography - she is such a cutie pie, and cool at the same time, I just really like her personality. I like the "bad movie genre" as it is called by some, but obviously it is not actually bad, it is just lower budget and doesn't take itself too seriously ? Sort of like I don't like to do in my own life. And as an amateur movie maker myself, I would love to make something like this, or be part of it in some creative capacity. The ending is actually kinda emotional, and I feel it is being well underrated by the people of imdb - not unusual, but that's ok, we can leave these less mainstream gems for the connosoirs.

This has to be one of if not the worst found footage film I have ever seen and I have seen some bad ones in my time.nnThe film is just boring from the get go, hardly any story, hardly any acting and what acting you see is awful and I mean truly awful.nnThe only good thing is the main actress looked good and that was it.nnNo nudity, barely any blood, no language. In fact there is hardly any talking in the film, so if you need to fall asleep, put this film on low volume, turn the lights out and try to watch it.nnThis is the type of film that IMDb needs negative stars for, yes it is truly the at bad.nnNever ever watch this film, it is one of the worst found footage movies out there.

This slow going, almost boring at times, family drama, was a big let down. I had hopes seeing two great actors together but the movie failed to make their bond feeling real and deep, and sometimes it even falls into good guy - troubled guy trope.nnKieran is the light of the movie and, truthfully, the only reason to watch it. His character should have also get more background to his story.nnSight-seeing the concentration camp was totally out of place and I can't figure out what was the intention behind it, didn't fit into the atmosphere or narrative.nnIn conclusion the movie had a potential but seems like they couldn't successfully blend comedy and drama like other films of this genre. Not once I smiled, not once weep .

Plot: Where do I even begin, this was the worst movie I have seen in theatres so far. First hour in the movie i was waiting for a plot to build. The villains were childish and no real threat. It wasn't interesting because pushpa was clearly going to win whatever somehow. It got boring because I knew that pushpa was going to come and solve the problem and we as the audience were going to get zero explanation or logic behind it. The "main villain" was a joke. And the last minute "kidnapping" was almost laughable because this was clearly just added in last minute without any proper context. Pushpas older brother didn't care when they were touching his daughter inappropriately and was just mad that pushpa interfered but then when his daughter gets kidnapped all of a suddden he loves his daughter and is crying. Like make it make sense. Ugh so annoying.nnHero Centric: OH MY GOD WE GET IT!!! HES GREAT! I DO NOT NEED EVERYONE HYPING HIM UP EVERY SECOND. He's the strongest, smartest, coolest and all of the above. THIS DOES NOT MAKE A GOOD MAIN CHARACTER. How can we root for a main character that no one can compete with. Everytime this man came onto screen, there was slow motions, music score change, and corny dialogue to make him look cool. And yes it works, BUT NOT FOR EVERY SCENE. They do this everytime and I honestly couldn't care for it. They keep trying to show how pushpa is so smart and he outwits the police but they never show us how. It just works out for pushpa like he's some sort of god. So boring and made him corny.nnLength: Every scene could have been shortened down. The fight scenes were too long. I've seen movies that have exaggerated fight scenes but nothing to this extent. He's taking down people with only his mouth... i'm not three years old, I would like some use of physics in this. That man was flying. And everyone coming at him one by one... like i've seen that in other movies but what makes it work is that the hero does get hurt and it's never that long. This scene went on for twenty minutes of everyone just coming at him individually. I was so bored. And it wasn't just this fight scene. Every scene possible. If we took out how much glazing pushpa was getting than we'd get a hour long film.nnOverall: I was so disappointed and will not be seeing the third movie. I like to appreciate when a story is well thought out even if it's not executed correctly. This story was garbage. I would've been able to create a better plot line in my sleep. A.

I saw a viral TikTok about this show so I decided to give it a try. All in all it wasn't terrible but it's one of those shows where the credits start rolling on the final episode and you ask yourself "did I just waste 5 hours of my life?"nnIn my opinion it was a lot easier to watch that 'Fool Me Once.' Which is another show on Netflix based on a Harlan Coben book. I only made it through 2 episodes of that series and I did watch the entirety of 'Missing You.'nnOverall, I could have overlooked it's many flaws if the conclusion was brilliant (which I was really hoping for) but in the end it felt lackluster.

Went into the movie just knowing that its good. When Orlok appeared during the 1st half of the movie I was amazed. I loved his character, and I couldnt really pinpoint the actor playing him. Then the infamous mustache appeared and my hopes of Orlok being Charles Dance ( which I was very excited that it could have been him ) or Bill Nighy, waned.nnDon't get me wrong Bill Skarsg√•rd did an amazing job, but I just cant get myself behind that mustache.nnThe amazing atmosphere during the 1st half of the movie, disappeared entering the 2nd half.nnA couple of jump scares and a couple really memorable scenes and the lovely "cock" pronunciation from Willem Dafoe, were the most memorable things from the 2nd part.nnAll in all a solid 7/10.

As a whole, the show is pretty good with the majority of the main cast doing their very best to carry some iffy writing. However, I was very glad to see the inclusion of a sparky new character in the form of Moira Mayfair, played by the incomparable Alyssa Jirrels. Although she isn't present in the novels, she brings an energy that the show was calling out for! Brilliantly acted and not to mention, she's super hot. More of her! Love that they filmed the Scotland scenes in Ireland as Ireland is a way cooler place than Scotland (no shade). I wonder if the cast had fun filming there! I'm sure they did!

Satoshi Kon's *Tokyo Godfathers* is a profoundly moving and unconventional holiday story that masterfully blends comedy, drama, and heartfelt emotion. Set against the vibrant yet cold streets of Tokyo, the film explores themes of redemption, family, and the unexpected ways lives intertwine.nnThe story follows three unlikely protagonists: Gin, a disgraced father; Hana, a kind-hearted transgender woman; and Miyuki, a runaway teenager. Their discovery of an abandoned baby on Christmas Eve sets off a series of adventures filled with twists, humor, and moments of raw humanity. The chemistry between these characters is electric, and their individual backstories add depth and emotional resonance to the narrative.nnSatoshi Kon's direction shines with meticulous attention to detail, capturing Tokyo's urban landscape in all its grit and beauty. The animation is fluid and expressive, perfectly complementing the film's poignant moments and comedic beats. Keiko Nobumoto's screenplay is sharp and heartfelt, balancing the darker realities of homelessness and loss with an underlying message of hope and redemption.nn*Tokyo Godfathers* is more than just a holiday film; it's a timeless story about human connection and the small miracles that can change lives. Its ability to find warmth and humor amidst hardship makes it a standout in both Satoshi Kon's filmography and the world of animated cinema.nnRating: 9/10 - A beautifully crafted and deeply emotional journey that captures the magic of humanity.

This movie is not for everyone, but man did I enjoy it. I would say this movie is better with a little smoke beforehand. This movie has a really fun cast they all fill their role perfectly Eduardo Franco as Jermey, who I feel is the same role in every movie, but I find him hilarious. His twin sister Becky is played by the beautiful Geraldine Viswanathan. We also have Sadie Calvano, Daniel Dohenny, Luke Spencer Roberts to fill out the rest of the main friend group, Sarah, Sean, and Donnie.nnAfter Sean comes back home from Germany, him and his bros Jermey and Donnie plan a camping trip. After Jermey's twin sister has a breakup with her vape god boyfriend Chad, her and Sarah kind of last minute hop on the camping trip. You know exactly what they're doing with the Chad character. He is played by Alexander Calvert who did a great job at the douche character. I will say I really enjoyed the movie but I think the first 2/3 are the best. I love the chemistry between the cast they do really seem like friends. Jermey getting a fake ID, saying he's a solider is great I love how they use it later, when trying to find Jermey in the hospital. I know the cast don't look like high schoolers but whatever, they're close they look more like college kids, but that's exactly what they were. I don't really care though the movie is funny and they don't look like they're in the 30's so that's fine. I love the car trip up there it's pretty short but Sean folding with Becky and Donnie's cutting edge commentary on the situation.nnAfter getting to the camp they all start drinking and acting like high schoolers. Sean is trying to get with Becky who has only been broken up for 17 hours. So we have the classic will they won't they. I really enjoy the akward acting from Daniel and the kind of opposite approach from Geraldine who is more confident and quick witted I enjoy the contrast and she made me laugh multiple times from her quick wit. Sean had a chance to get with her before at a party but dungoofed and denied a request to smoke with her on the roof. The dialogue and writing isn't the most complex premise but the writing for the characters I find so well done, it just makes it feel more like friends like when Sean and Donnie are insulting each other when they first see each other again. Or when Donnie makes fun of Sean for denying the smoke with Becky when they smoke all the time. Or Donnie sending snap chats while Sean is flopping with trying to riz up Becky. As well as Becky's quick witted remarks to make it less awkward when Sean drops the condom in front of her at the hospital.nnAfter spending the night partying Sean is about to score with Becky when it's interrupted again, by Jermey cutting his weiner off and yes that's the main premise the group of friends trying to get their friends penis back to him after giving the wrong cooler to the evac crew. It's silly it's obsurd, but that's why I love these movies. Same with Game Over Man. I love these types of movies and I should mention this movie was made by the Workaolics crew, so if you're not into that type of comedy this prolly isn't your cup of tea. A penis is cut off in Game over man too, geez these guys got thing for cutting of male parts I guess. The funniest parts for me are them trying to get the penis. Like Sean trying to suck the venom out of the wiener after thinking a snake left poison in it after biting it. Them returning to the gas station and the guy running it cleaning it and making it beautiful after thinking a vet lost his penis. He also said this wasn't his first time doing this. Micheal Eklund did a phenomenal job in this role, he really killed it. Drinking the pop while cleaning it or shooting bows at the gang after finding out the truth and hitting Donnie. One random trait about Jermey I found hillarious was him trying to get Sean to bang his sister it's dumb af, but has some good moments like Jermey giving him the King condom and then Sean dropping it later at the hospital while talking to Becky. Also Sean random boners whenever Becky touches but honestly even if she's near him he has a boner. I love the scene when they're still in the woods and steal a boat from a dad his son but not before scarring the innocence away from an 11 year old kid, by interrogating the kid pretty much into giving them their dads sports boat key. Also love part when it like turns into like a drama for a second when Sean sacrifices one for the team to you know suck the venom out, that's not there.nnSome things I didn't care for, it's little but they kept going to the wrong hospital I get it like once but they did it like 3 times. I liked how they tied in Jermey's fake ID with finding him at the right hospital. Of couse they have a part where the crew kind of have a falling out, and it doesn't last long and the ending is pretty cliche and obvious. The falling out occurs because back at the camp when Jermey initially cut his crouch off. Sean took all the phones to try to get reception and call help and I guess the liquor had some influence on the situation but he didn't seem that messed up. He ends up texting Chad and calling him a taint and a few other things, acting like he's Becky, when Chad wants her back and says he's sorry. Yea that guy wasn't gonna change. A little later a voicemail is heard and it's Chad calling Becky a taint the whole car hears it, and at the time Becky think it's just Chad being a douche, which he is. Towards the end of the movie Donnie is mad at Sean and lets it slip that he sent the text that instigated the voicemail and she's mad at him obviously. They kind of go all their separate ways after going through all the work and accidentally give Jemreys penis to another biker dude who lost his junk from a crazy junkie. After a little motivation speech to the biker dude he has a change of heart and let's them take his penis that was just flushed out from the sewers. Yes she cut it off and flushed it down the toilet. The junkie shows up and cuts it off again, which I wasn't a huge fan of felt a little forced. The biker is also Blake from workaholics played by Blake Anderson, it was great to see him again. After the crazy mishap at the hospital Sean and Donnie run into Sarah and Becky who has just called Chad and was gonna go with him. Sean has his end of movie speech to win over girl and I do like how didn't nail it he was awkward. It's just cliche you know. But I do like how she said it was not a good speech. But I did think he nailed the part of not being with a cheater and being with someone who respects like he does. It's cheesy but it was effective. She leaves Chad and they go deliver their friends and brothers jewels.nnThis is my favorite part of the ending where it turns into like an action movie and they get to the hospital and rush through the hospital knocking over hospital personnel, security guards, and anyone in their way. Sean delivers it just in time before Jermey was gonna have to do some crazy surgery. I like part where Sean and Becky are about to kiss but she can't because he sucked her bothers kingdom come earlier. I love the last shot of the I'm guessing drone shot of Becky and Sean finally kissing before taking him back to the airport to go back to Germany. Jermey returning in the wheelchair and trying to see Sean and Becky kiss. Also forgot to mention this whole movie Jermey swore he was talking to a girl named Kendall Jenners who everyone swore was a catfish but she was actually real and hot. I also didn't mention but Donnie and Sarah have been in some hot water, I think partially because Donnie might have started something saying they were together when they weren't, while Sarah actually liked him. He's known for doing this by admitting to making the rumor of Sean not in Germany actually in rehab for bath salts. But by the end you know some movie magic they have a moment and they are together by the end too. It's a happy ending. I love the dialogue as well as the drone shot is going. This movie is fun, and I highly enjoyed it watching it with my brother. I had never seen the whole thing only clips. So it was nice to actually see it. Not for everyone but I know this is gonna be a guilty pleasure one for me just like Game Over Man.

"Captain Blood" was such a worldwide success in the mid thirties that it made overnight stars of Eroll Flynn and Olivia de Haviland and created a demand for action-adventure films that produced some of the best films ever in the genre. For the first half of the thirties the swashbuckling film was seen as something left behind in the twenties, with Douglas Fairbanks. There was also a problem with early, cumbersome sound equipment being unable to work well with fast action and outdoor locations. But the success of "Treasure Island" and "The Count of Monte Cristo" in 1934 showed the film audience still had an appetite for these kinds of films.nnSo Warner Brothers took a gamble, and what a gamble it turned out to be. Although the studio had allotted a really big budget for the film, most of the other important aspects seemed to be left to chance. It was given to director Michael Curtiz who up to then had directed mostly minor films with a few exceptions like "Cabin In the Cotton" and "The Kennel Murder Case". He would receive the first of five Best Director nominations from the Academy for this film. It ended up starring two virtual unknowns. Errol Flynn had filmed a flop in Australia and in Hollywood had had only small parts in three minor films. Olivia de Haviland had appeared in only three previous films. Writer Casey Robinson had written titles in the silent era but had only begun writing screenplays two years before.nnThough putting a film like this in the hands of a bunch of unknowns would seem totally mad, somehow it worked and in the biggest way possible. All of these principals went on to big careers for the next decade and more. Curtiz's fluid camera technique using movement and unusual camera angles was ideal for the genre. Flynn instantly became one of Hollywood's biggest stars, especially in adventure films. He and Olivia de Haviland had such chemistry that they appeared in eight films together. She was a fine dramatic actress in future films and won Academy Awards for "To Each His Own" and "The Heiress". Curtiz would go on to direct "The Adventures of Robin Hood", "Casablanca", "Mildred Pierce" and "Yankee Doodle Dandy". Robinson went on to write some of the biggest films of Flynn and Bette Davis. This is reminiscent of "Laura", which also had a cast and crew of unknowns who went on to big careers.nn"Captain Blood" falls into two parts of almost equal length. The first part involves the unfair enslavement of Dr. Peter Blood - it's his name not a pirate moniker as the title might suggest. - The attraction that grows between him and Arabella Bishop is forbidden because of his status and creates complications. Part two is the pirate story, a story of a rare pirate of noble character with a strict code of ethics, which makes his pirating suitable for a hero's story. And is Flynn ever a hero. His natural charisma and ability to inspire and lead men practically jumps out of the screen. He's also intelligent, well spoken and as gentlemanly as Ronald Colman but highly athletic as well.nnThe love story ties the two parts together. And Olivia de Havilland is as perfect in her role as Flynn is in his. She's not just beautiful and complemented by the period costumes, but self assured, playful and feisty as well. The actress always brought great intelligence to her roles when she could, though the studio often gave her one dimensional sweet and innocent ingenue parts that required very little.nnThey are supported by a fine cast. In Blood's crew there's the gunner, Hagthorpe, played by Guy Kibbee, who had been a regular in Warner's Busby Berkeley musicals but who handles this part really well. Ross Alexander plays young Jeremy Pitt, in a winning way, a choice role for this up and coming actor. There are two villains here, a recurring element in Flynn's action films. The first is Colonel Bishop (Arabella's uncle), played by Lionel Atwill, who is entirely despicable. He has one funny moment when he thinks his money has been saved from a Spanish warship but is basically a one dimensional character. More nuanced is French pirate Levasseur, played with great charm overlying his villainy by Basil Rathbone. It would have been nice to bring him on sooner as he's a complex and potentially interesting character. Rathbone would be one of films' great villains three years later in "The Adventures of Robin Hood." Henry Stephenson is a paternal Royal Envoy bringing good tidings, and Vernon Steele is a rather nasty King James II.nnThere's lots of English history going on here in the period of the Restoration. The film begins with the Monmouth Rebellion, an attempt to depose James II and put his older brother's (Charles II) illegitimate son, James Scott, First Duke of Monmouth on the throne and ends with the Glorious Revolution which sent James II to France and put William and Mary on the throne. In the thirties more people knew about these events as English history was a school staple. Fortunately you don't need to know anything at all about it, as the film telegraphs how one should feel and is not trying to teach history.nnThis is a splendid action film in the grandest style and the mix of special effects would have looked pretty incredible in the thirties. The ships and sea battles are still impressive despite moments of knowing some segments are models. High points are an invasion of Port Royal by Spanish pirates and a battle between Flynn's ship and two French frigates, both spectacularly realized. But the film, for all its action, is held together by the presence of Flynn and de Havilland. Also supporting the film with great verve is the gloriously heroic score by Erich Wolfgang Korngold. This stirring music is the other thread that holds the film together and surprisingly was the first time background music was used in this way. It's something to say, but this 85 year old film holds up just as well now as it was when it was new.

column3: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
column4: Horrible script with the most unrealistic and absurd absurdist dialogue. It was just bad.nnWhether or not you are a fan of Greek mythology, this movie is trash.nnTerrible acting and zero character development. Nicole should be embarrassed for taking this role. Colin was even worse.nnThere is no "suspense" except for: when is this drivel over? It was painstakingly slow, pretentious, and faux art house. This is the kind of crap people in flyover states hate coastal elites for. Except I am hard pressed to find even a fellow New Yorker who found this excrement worthy of any compliment. 1/10 (one of the few 1 stars in two and half decades of an IMDB account).

column3: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo (1966)
column4: It's one of the greatest classic Westerns. I hadn't seen it yet, but I heard a lot of people say it's a great movie, and it's also a top 10 movie on IMDb. I really liked the movie, but it has some flaws.nnAs a Western, it's incredible. It has several really good action scenes. If I'm not mistaken, it's set during the Civil War or something like that, and the war scenes are also really good.nnThe story tells of three men: the good, the bad, and the ugly. The synopsis shows that it's focused on a treasure hidden in a cemetery. But the movie has trouble focusing on that. Even though the title of the movie seems to focus on three characters, the bad character barely appears in the movie, and in the final scene he appears in a very casual way. The plot focuses much more on the good and the ugly, initially as friends, then enemies, and then they help each other again. But their relationship seems good and is well developed.nnThe film is almost three hours long, and the part I mentioned about the main objective only starts after an hour. When I saw how long the film was, I was a little apprehensive, but the film is not completely boring, obviously it could have been shorter, but it develops well. The film's script is very good, it doesn't leave any loose ends or introduce characters with too much screen time who are useless, as is the case in other Clint Eastwood films, and it doesn't leave any obvious loose ends (I didn't notice after watching it only once).nnThe film's photography is very good, the action scenes, both shooting and explosions in the war, are very good and really intriguing, the main actors are good, but in terms of audiovisual, the main highlight is the soundtracks, which are very iconic and very good indeed. In general, I didn't like the film very much at first, but in the end I liked it a lot.

From starting from a weak story line to finishing in even more disappointment than I could imagine,no chemistry between the actors,feels rushed,very predictable,glad when it was finally over,5 episodes has never felt like more of a chore in my life.nnThe main character kat was always focused on one task (her ex) for 5 episodes that could of been tackled in 2,leaving time to explore other avenues and making a deeper connection with the leading character.nnWith many strong actors casted it's disappointing they couldn't of been used to there full potential.nnCurrently writing this with 12 minutes left on last episode I just couldn't hold my frustration in any longer.nnP. S don't waste your time With this garbage.

Firstly to the four 'real' ratings that gave this movie a 7, 8, 9 and 10 star rating really?nnYou are really giving the game away that you have something to do with this movie and this how you get views.nnI am surprised at IMDB, are they really that thick that they can't see the evidence that's in front of them, oh well into the movie itself.nnWe str off with a mother and daughter talking and this goes on for awhile, which was fine and the tension built up slowly when the daughter's lights went out, more taking goes on and bang we see her get killed, which was fine and I thought if they had stuck to that format then the movie could have been a lot better, but alas they didn't carry in with the way that worked.nnWell what happened? Weak storyline, very weak cliched characters, different languages which without subtitles didn't work, overall a boring movie that had a great start.nnDon't waste your time.

Was interesting the CIA and UK special operation mentioned, as both had teams waiting of the coast of Scotland, on its flight route. But this will never come out to the general public. This was meant to crash into the sea, with both land and sea teams close to many locations. This is why you had government teams on the ground so quickly after the crash, looking among the wreckage and planting fake evidence to be found at a later date during in investigation. Documents locked away, will stay locked away for many years. Both US,and UK intelligence will make sure , none of this information will ever see the light of day.

I decided to give this show a chance, mostly because Abbott Elementary doesn't come back for a few weeks.nnPositives:nGreat soundtrack of 80s classics. It isn't set in the 80s so that doesn't line up, but still a good choice.nnSupporting cast seems to be strong and the "issues" the kids bring up are pretty on brand for today's environment ex Tourette's syndrome variation named after a student who won't let people talk about it.nnLove that they have out gay charactersnnNegatives:nnEvan. I get that he is supposed to be neurotic and scattered but that doesn't make him funny....nHe interrupts people constantly, spazzes out and runs away over nothing, and in general is just doing too much. He is so effing annoying that I had to jump off after three epsnnThis show has a lot of wasted potential. Maybe they'll refine it in the future if it's picked up again. (Doubtful imo)

Outstanding series sharing the truth behind what really went down. I loved how much real evidence and footage was used, exposing the lies, greed and corruption world wide.nnColin Firth plays Jim Swire incredibly well and gives the audience a deep insight into what Dr Swire and his family went through.nnAs someone who was born a few years after this event, I had never heard of this event until watching the series and think it is disgusting how justice was not served for this case, but of course that is the world we live in today.nnThe director did an incredible job at capturing the story and revealing for us what really went down.

Moments of excellence:n1. Cooper revealing his master plan to become a real player in the oil businessn2. Succession planning with the end nearing for the Jon Hamm character.nn3. Philosophical discussion on family by non other than Jerry Jonesn4. Billy Bob breaking down the relationship status he has with his wife and her need for validation.nn5. The intersection of big business, government, military and the drug cartels. Each flexing, each showing the power it has and its ability to inflict damage on the other. All realizing they need to somehow work together.nnCringen1. Daughter using bible study as code for bad behaviorn2. Mum endorsing daughter having sex with star QB at home with everyone there. Extremely disturbing that daughter is 17n3. Trying to trade sex for a favor where the QB will play the role of a strippern4. Arranging for "old people" to visit the syrup club at 11am as a field tripnnA little less cringe and and a bit more story development would go a long way into turning this show from an entertaining but forgetful series into a must watch for several seasons to come.

This official release is a collection of excellently restored and video transferred film footage of Led Zeppelin's live performances. The video is excellently clear and sharp and cleaned up despite some of it having been filmed on 16mm film. The audio is impeccable and I really enjoyed the DTS 5.1 surround sound track over the LPCM stereo track. Some of the songs are repeated several times at different performances. At over 5 hours it is difficult to even binge watch in it's entirety and the first disk alone is around 3 hours length. The 2 DVD set is best enjoyed in segments, maybe as you're reading up on it's background and writing a review on iMDB.

This show is written so bad. Everything is so ridiculous. Nothing is even remotely realistic, plausible or logical. The whole story and so called backstory is full of plot holes and doesnt make any sense.nnThe badguy is a terrorist because he hates the West and says they killed his parents. We got some flashbacks which must show us how this motive originates. What we see is how the badguy flees as a kid with his parents and how his parents get killed by a Taliban like militia. The only thing we see Western forces do is saving an Afghan child which is also shot by that same Afghan militia. So this should tie the whole story together about how this kid wants to take revenge, but on the killers of his parents, but on the West?nnBut the utmost outrageous part is the guantanamo bay like situation the Dutch national security agency (AIVD) has going on where they abuse and torture an innocent child and lady. In reality, the AIVD cant even listen in on a phone without having written permission of the minister.nnOn top of that, an AIVD agent attacks an innocnet woman and shoots an unarmed man in the middle of the street, in front of a crowd of people and a lot of police agents.nnEven a kid can create a more logical and realistic story.

From the completely unnecessary explicitness to the weird acting... I insisted on it hoping that something would change the feeling of wasted time. Nothing did.nnI don't know in which planet this director lives but the scenes that were meant to be sexy were boring and cringy.nnThe whole "internal monologue narration" from multiple characters explaining what is going on is just the cherry on top. If the acting, the direction, and the screenwriting cannot convey the idea... why not add explanations out loud?nnKate Blanchett and Sacha Baron Cohen did just fine but they were unable to save the series. Wasted time.

Funny, bold, irreverent, nostalgic, sad, inventive, political, the feature-length documentary Flashback manages to pack a lot into its 90-minute running time. The bar, which began in the late 70s as a queer haven in dangerously homophobic Edmonton, Alberta, soon developed into a thriving and gloriously salacious mecca for queers from all over the continent. For me the true joy of the film was seeing and hearing witnesses who were there during the 10-odd years that marked the club's apogee: the owner, staff, customers, costumers, hairdressers and make-up artists for the legendary drag shows, all of whom are articulate, brazen and defiant in the face of community hostility, oppressive police and, eventually, devastating AIDS. As LGBTQ bars now are disappearing all over North America, Flashback shows how essential and supportive they could be in a time of grave crisis. Since we seem to be entering into another one of those, Flashback point up the need for a safe locus for expressions of resistance and solidarity at a time when many people's sense of a queer community begins and ends in their phones.

La Maschera del Demonio, The Mask of Satan, Black Sunday (1960).nnI saw it as a kid and as an adult I rediscovered it through a documentary about Mario Bava's filmography. I have seen it many times.nnBarbara Steele in gorgeous black and white adorns this gothic story.nnTim Burton plagiarising Mario Bava many times, as in Sleepy Hollow (1999).nnBarbara Steele is Princess Asa Vajda the Satanist Witch and vampire and also plays her opposite counterpart Princess Katia.nnThe film Viy (1967) the adaptation of a story by Nikolai Gogol what was inspired Mario Bava's The Mask of Satan, in that plot a monk must spend three nights with demons and a beautiful dead witch in a chapel.nnDr. Kruvajan was an idiot, he is like an inept Dr. Val Helsing mixed with Renfield. The closest to Van Helsing was the village priest. Dr. Andrej Gorobec had it all figured out in his life by the end of the film, he would have Princess Katia Vajda, the castle and maybe take a young mistress from the village that he could impregnate. The younger brother Constantine was gay and clearly physically attracted to Adrej.nnThe coachman Javutich in the middle of the night towards the castle is straight out of Dracula.

After that I cringed so hard I couldn't even watch it. I had so much vicarious shame for both the Dutch and the Danish couple. Just grabbed my phone to get my attention of off the movie.nnWhats wrong with this movie you would ask? The Dannish couple is trying to be so polite its painful to watch. When they go out for dinner a weird man is babysitting their kid and they just agree with it. Then at the "restaurant" the dutch man tries to have some sort of political discussion about that fish is the same thing as meat. Its unbearable to watch.nnThey find their daughter in the bed of the Dutch couple and they decide to leave. But they forgot their daughters doll and decide to go back. I couldn't..... It's such bad writing...nnThey deicde to STAY..... Together with some nice child abuse the cringe goes on for another hour or so.nnThe ending is both predictable and disgusting. Cutting of the tongue of a kid and stoning naked people to death. Its not even scary. Its just trying to be disturbing and it utterly fails to deliver.nn- Cringen- Disturbing ( not in a good way )n- Nothing happens until the last 5 minutes of the movien- Child abusen- Really bad Dutch musicn- Ugly house.

With the news that a prequel / sequel to this groundbreaking film is currently in the works in the form of [link=tt27351074], perhaps it is time to revisit the greatest "clash of the titans" ever committed to film. [link=nm0000520]'s 1995 Los Angeles crime saga clocks in at just over three hours, and stars two of America's greatest acting talents: [link=nm0000199] and [link=nm0000134] (who will not be returning for the next installment). But one only need watch approximately half of that time in order to understand why [link=tt0113277] sets the standard by which any and all future pairings of these two cinematic giants will be rated. And it is not just the infamous Coffee Shop scene which provides an excuse to love this film; though said scene is certainly well worth waiting for. (More on this in a moment.) No, the secret to this film creeps into frame at the very moment that the L. A. metro train glides effortlessly toward the viewer - surrounded by smoke and creaking slowly along - carrying inside a silent, brooding and patient master thief, Neil McCauley (masterfully played by DeNiro). And the secret to loving this film is just that... patience.nnOne would expect a crime drama starring [link=nm0000134] and [link=nm0000199] (in their first "real" pairing in film history as most agree that [link=tt0071562] does not really count since the two mega-stars never actually share the screen) to begin with a bang. And therein lies Mann's genius. Does Mann choose to open this much anticipated cops-n-robbers action flick with a Hollywood-style, big box office bonanza of explosions and shrapnel? Nope. Instead Mann eases us into the environment that these two alpha-males will inhabit by way of a train ride. The doors slide open and out into the night steps McCauley. There is no evidence of the carnage to come as McCauley appears, only a hint of his expertise as he silently scans his surroundings, searching for a sign of anything out of order.nnFast forward to a bedroom. Morning brings with it the promise of lovemaking, as we are introduced in a vastly different way to the man who will become McCauley's adversary, Detective Lieutenant Vincent Hanna (who we will come to realize is an over the top manic played brilliantly by Pacino). Hanna and his wife Justine, (played with seductive aplomb by [link=nm0893204]) are having a moment... one neither wants interrupted. Lucky for everyone involved - characters and viewers alike - no interruption presents itself, and both are allowed to finish. Little do either know that this will be their last such moment together. For on the horizon lie several days of complicated cat and mouse antics, punctuated by the smell of cordite and the sight of death.nnAnd then comes the big bang. With an expertly planned and craftily executed tractor-trailer-rig-into armored-car smash-up, McCauley and his crew (portrayed by a world weary [link=nm0000174] in what many consider his finest performance, a still high in real life [link=nm0001744] and a gritty faced [link=nm0001803]) are off to the races. And what follows is the stuff of legend. Only not all of what is presented is legend... much of it is true to life.nn[link=tt0113277] was born out of a 1989 television pilot also penned by Mann, entitled [link=tt0097700], and most if not all of TAKEDOWN appears in the script for [link=tt0113277] . (Unfortunately, TAKEDOWN is only available on DVD in Region 2 countries, but is well worth viewing if you can grab a copy.) TAKEDOWN itself was based in part on stories Mann was told by his good friend and [link=tt0090410] collaborator [link=nm0011477]. Adamson (along with STORY's [link=nm0001199]) worked as a Detective in the Chicago Police Department's Major Crimes Unit in the late 60's, and was responsible for taking down the real life Neil McCauley. In fact, the two actually had a face to face in a local coffee shop... just as DeNiro and Pacino do in [link=tt0113277]. And the outcome was much the same.nnWhen the fateful scene finally comes... boy is it worth the wait. Having tracked McCauley's scent for several days through cold-blooded murders to successful and aborted heists, Hanna decides to up the ante and confront the man himself. He suggest a cup of joe and the two sit down for a chat. What transpires is by far the meatiest mano-y-mano ever committed to film. As the two cautiously attempt to relate to one another, they each discover that they share a common principle: They are each unflinchingly committed to one thing and one thing only. For McCauley that one thing is remaining true to his instincts and guarding himself against becoming attached to, as he puts it, "anything you are not willing to walk out on in thirty seconds flat if you spot the heat around the corner." For Hanna, that commitment is to tracking the scent of his prey and holding onto his angst, which, according to Hanna, is the thing that "keeps me sharp... on the edge... where I gotta be." And it is within this discussion of their two intersecting lives, punctuated by dark words and veiled threats, that the most observant of viewers will glean a probing glimpse into the psyche of both actors. And Mann knew it when he wrote the dialogue.nnDeNiro: "It is what it is. Its either that or we better both go do something else, pal."nPacino: "I don't know how to do anything else."nDeNiro: "Neither do I."nPacino: "I don't much want to either."nDeNiro: "Neither do I."nnThen both men smile.... barely. Want to know why? Because at this very moment, both men are exposing their true feelings about acting, NOT (as some may think) discussing their character's feelings about their chosen profession. DeNiro and Pacino have let their guard down ever so briefly, and shown the world why they are the best of the best.nnBut this film is not all about De Niro and Pacino chewing up the scenery and each other. Costars Kilmer and Sizemore (in their roles as McCauley's right-hand men Chris Shirherlis and Michael Cheritto respectively), [link=nm0000685] (as McCauley's wounded and dogged fence Nate), [link=nm0000204] (as Hanna's tortured step-daughter Lauren Gustafson), [link=nm0932112], [link=nm0836071] and [link=nm0505971] (as Hanna's fellow Detectives in the Robbery Homicide Division Drucker, Casals and Bosko respectively), [link=nm0000171] (as Shirherlis' caught between love and the right path wife Charlene) and [link=nm0000312] (as McCauley's lied to and frail girlfriend Eady) add so much depth to this film that it takes several viewings to fully digest the three course meal that Mann serves up. The interlocking stories of each character's life, filled with despair, pain and - at times - hope, move [link=tt0113277]nfrom the genre of "yet another cops-n-robbers flick" into the realm of "cinema masterpiece."nnAnd as for Mann's directing... Mann is THE MAN. His use of light and shadow, along with his bold and signature over-the-shoulder camera angels create a visual canvass that places the viewer squarely in mid '90's Los Angeles. Showing off the seamy underbelly of late night L. A., Mann uses this film to expose locations and scents only hinted at in former films such as [link=tt0090180]. (Mann would eventually expose more of this environment while producing the television series [link=tt0315686] - a show sadly lacking a Blu-ray / DVD release - and while directing the [link=nm0000129] / [link=nm0004937] show down film [link=tt0369339].)nnMann is one of the cinemas most daring and detailed Directors, and this film is a high water mark in his ever expanding career. It is no wonder that fans of both [link=tt0113277] and [link=tt0097700] feel strongly that the former expands and betters the latter by leaps and bounds. [link=tt0113277] is the once and for all standard by which any and all future pairings of De Niro and Pacino will be rated. And none will match up. None could. (If you require proof, just have a look at the sorely disappointing [link=tt1034331]). Give this film a little patience and you will surely be rewarded. Because it is the slow build that really pays off.nnWhile stalking the crime scene that follows the previously mentioned armored car heist, Hanna offers this observation to describe McCauley's crew:nn"The M. O. is that they're good."nnIt's not just McCauley's crew that are good. They ALL are. And so is this film. It will leave you itching for the next chapter... coming soon... I hope.
