I watched this film based upon the 7.1 IMDB rating and was thoroughly disappointed. Normally a 7.1 rating would mean a great film.nnMaybe I am missing something but the film is shot like a 1980's straight to TV film. The plot is thin, the characters are one dimensional and it was overly long. The whole story was unnecessarily drawn out. The story line jumps back and forwards for no apparent reason. I had no empathy for any of the characters. There were some random scenes with naked men in locker rooms and saunas that had me laughing out loud.nnOverall I think they were trying too hard to tell a simple story and failed. My time would have been better spent elsewhere.

I love the two first episodes! The scenery is so spectacular! I love actor Lee Minho as the devoted doctor and as the astronaut against his wishes!nnThe commander Eve is so loveable! The scenes are all intense and yet give a lot of information that makes you wonder about the final plot. I like it when you have to wonder how the plot will be! That makes the watch more interesting!nnThe story is full of fun with a serous theme! On many scenes you can choose to take it serous or hilarious! Nicely done by the director.nnIt is long ago that I have seen a show where there is so much effort to give us viewers a treat to the eyes. The launching, the sky, the earth, the teams on earth and in space! So greatly done!nnThe space station is made so realistic as is the acting in this space station. What a great cast!nnI am so looking forward to next week!

Really enjoyed this mini series. At first for me was a slowish start but you need to keep with it. It all ties in together by the end and leaves you with a warm nice feeling!nnJack O'Connell as Roy Goode is exceptionally as is Jeff Daniel's as Frank Griffin. What a pair! They have a real connection that follows throughout the series kind of sad really. Michelle Dockery as Alice Fletcher really surprised me. Iv seen her in Downton Abbey of course but her character in this couldn't be any more different.nnI can't forget Thomas Brodie -Sangster as Whitey Winn. His acting and his American accent really impressed me. In fact seeings as most the leading actors are in fact British I applaud each and every one of them with their portrayal of their western country characters!nnDefinitely one to watch!

Life Is Beautiful, directed by and starring Roberto Benigni, is a poignant blend of comedy and tragedy that explores the horrors of the Holocaust through the eyes of a loving father determined to shield his son from the grim realities of their situation. Balancing lighthearted humor with heartbreaking drama, the film crafts a unique narrative that celebrates the human spirit even in the darkest of times.nnBenigni's performance as Guido is magnetic, effortlessly transitioning between moments of joy, wit, and profound emotional depth. His chemistry with Nicoletta Braschi, who plays his wife Dora, is tender and endearing, grounding the film's early, whimsical scenes in genuine warmth. Giorgio Cantarini as the young Giosu√® delivers a performance filled with innocence and charm, embodying the hope that drives Guido's protective actions.nnThe film's first half unfolds as a romantic comedy, filled with Benigni's signature physical humor and exuberant charm. However, the shift to the harrowing backdrop of a Nazi concentration camp in the second half introduces a tonal complexity that underscores the resilience of the human spirit. Benigni's ability to infuse moments of levity into an overwhelmingly bleak setting highlights the power of imagination and love as tools for survival.nnWhile the film's sentimentality and use of humor in a Holocaust narrative have sparked debate, its message of hope and the lengths to which a parent will go to protect their child's innocence resonate deeply. The cinematography and Nicola Piovani's Oscar-winning score further enhance the emotional weight of the story.nnLife Is Beautiful is a bold and unconventional film that, despite its polarizing approach, leaves an indelible mark. It's a testament to the enduring power of love and the human capacity for hope, even in the face of unimaginable adversity.nnRating: 7/10 - A deeply moving and uniquely crafted story of love and survival.

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)
column4: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, directed by Peter Jackson, is a triumphant conclusion to one of cinema's most ambitious trilogies. With its breathtaking scale, emotional depth, and masterful storytelling, the film delivers a finale that feels both monumental and intimate, cementing the trilogy's place as a landmark in fantasy filmmaking.nnElijah Wood and Sean Astin anchor the narrative with their moving portrayals of Frodo and Sam, whose journey to destroy the One Ring reaches its grueling climax. Astin, in particular, shines as Sam, embodying unyielding loyalty and quiet heroism. Viggo Mortensen's Aragorn comes into his own as the reluctant king, delivering a performance that balances nobility and vulnerability. Ian McKellen's Gandalf and Andy Serkis's Gollum continue to captivate, while the ensemble cast, including Miranda Otto and Bernard Hill, adds richness to the sprawling narrative.nnJackson's direction is nothing short of visionary. The epic battles, particularly the Siege of Minas Tirith, are stunningly choreographed, blending practical effects and CGI to create awe-inspiring set pieces. The film's quieter moments, such as Frodo and Sam's final push to Mount Doom, are equally compelling, driven by Howard Shore's evocative score that heightens both grandeur and poignancy.nnWhile the film's extended runtime allows for a comprehensive conclusion, its multiple endings may test the patience of some viewers. However, these moments provide closure to the story's many arcs, making the journey feel complete.nnThe Return of the King is a towering achievement that brings Tolkien's epic tale to life with unparalleled artistry and emotional resonance. It's a celebration of friendship, sacrifice, and the enduring power of hope, leaving a legacy that will inspire generations to come.nnRating: 8/10 - A breathtaking and emotionally satisfying finale that crowns an extraordinary trilogy.

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)
column4: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers, directed by Peter Jackson, is a visually spectacular continuation of Tolkien's legendary saga. Expanding the narrative across multiple storylines, the film dives deeper into the conflicts and alliances shaping the fate of Middle-earth. While ambitious in scope and stunning in execution, it occasionally falters under the weight of its sprawling narrative.nnElijah Wood continues to deliver a compelling performance as Frodo, whose journey grows darker with the increasing burden of the One Ring. Sean Astin as Sam provides heartfelt support, while Andy Serkis's groundbreaking portrayal of Gollum is a highlight, capturing the character's internal struggle with remarkable nuance. Viggo Mortensen, Ian McKellen, and Orlando Bloom excel in their respective roles, though the divided storylines leave some characters underdeveloped.nnJackson's visual direction remains exceptional, with breathtaking battles like Helm's Deep showcasing his mastery of large-scale action. The detailed world-building immerses viewers in the grandeur and peril of Middle-earth, with CGI and practical effects seamlessly blending to create iconic moments. Howard Shore's score once again enriches the emotional and dramatic weight of the story.nnHowever, the film's narrative suffers from pacing issues, with certain segments feeling overly drawn out while others seem rushed. The constant shift between storylines, though necessary, sometimes dilutes the emotional intensity and momentum. While the themes of loyalty, courage, and the corrupting influence of power remain strong, the film feels like a bridge between the more focused first installment and the climactic finale.nnThe Two Towers is an ambitious middle chapter that expands the world and stakes of the trilogy but struggles to balance its intricate plotlines. It's a visually stunning epic that sets the stage for a grand conclusion but lacks the narrative cohesion of its predecessor.nnRating: 6/10 - A visually impressive but uneven continuation of the saga.

Positively the worst movie ever made about a public librarian. Goofy characters, ghastly story, cold and manipulative women, moronic men, sex without any kind of excitement. PALMETTO and WILD THINGS came out in the Nineties, and at the time people said those movies were bad rip-offs of classic film noir.nnBut those two movies were DOUBLE INDEMNITY compared to this mess.nnI like Diane Kruger. She was brilliant in INGLOURIOUS BASTERDS. She was lovely in TROY. Why on earth would she ever agree to this? Her character is so lifeless, boring, empty, and at the same time needy and cruel. Was this some lost clause in the Treaty of Versaille?nnARTICLE 15: Once every 50 years a stunning German actress must come to American and be humiliated by a no-name director and make a movie where she is stupid and evil and does all the stupid things people laugh at Germans for doing. Except for eating sauerkraut and drinking beer!

column3: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
column4: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring, directed by Peter Jackson, is a cinematic masterpiece that brought J. R. R. Tolkien's rich world of Middle-earth to life with stunning detail and emotional depth. As the first installment of the epic trilogy, the film sets a high standard for storytelling, blending breathtaking visuals, compelling characters, and a powerful narrative.nnElijah Wood delivers a heartfelt performance as Frodo Baggins, the reluctant hero burdened with the fate of the world. Ian McKellen shines as Gandalf, embodying wisdom and strength, while Viggo Mortensen, Orlando Bloom, and Sean Bean add gravitas to their roles as members of the Fellowship. The ensemble cast, including Cate Blanchett as the ethereal Galadriel, enhances the film's emotional resonance and brings Tolkien's iconic characters to life.nnPeter Jackson's direction is visionary, seamlessly combining practical effects with groundbreaking CGI to create a fully realized world. The sweeping landscapes of New Zealand serve as a stunning backdrop, while Howard Shore's unforgettable score amplifies the film's epic scale and emotional beats. From the idyllic Shire to the perilous Mines of Moria, every frame is meticulously crafted, immersing viewers in the grandeur of Middle-earth.nnThe screenplay, adapted by Fran Walsh, Philippa Boyens, and Jackson, skillfully condenses Tolkien's dense prose without losing its essence. Themes of friendship, courage, and the corrupting influence of power are woven throughout, resonating deeply with audiences. However, the film's pacing can occasionally feel uneven, with moments of exposition slowing the momentum.nnDespite minor flaws, The Fellowship of the Ring is a landmark achievement in fantasy cinema, setting the stage for an unforgettable trilogy. It's a testament to the power of storytelling and the enduring appeal of Tolkien's world.nnRating: 8/10 - A visually stunning and emotionally engaging start to a legendary journey.

The story is fine. A good wrap up to the initial season. Has all the usual tropes and character behaviors one would expect from an 80s era style horror/comedy/suspense. The kids are the stars still as they are with the entire season... Now let's get to the problem..nnHas anyone ever seen a Michael Bay film? Transformers? Bad boys? There's this action production sequence where they just randomly flash between stuff at 1k mph. Easier to ignore in those films. However here it's with darkness and flickering lights for multiple sequences (it also rears it's ugly head in season 2 as well). Not only is it but not good action, you can't just flicker lights to give me the appearance of great action... But it is seizure inducing and the lack of epilepsy warning at the star of the episode should illicit grounds for lawsuit. It really is that bad. So much so that this is a re-watch for me because I had to stop watching at the end of season 2 because of this.

The film Maria, directed by Pablo Larra√≠n, defies the expectations it creates in its audience. Contrary to what one might anticipate, it is not a biographical film about an opera singer but rather a psychological exploration of the loneliness of a woman who happens to be an opera singer and has turned to a kind of emotional masochism and self-destruction.nnIf you approach Maria expecting a biographical film that narrates the life story of an opera singer, you will likely be disappointed. By the end of the film, not only do you not truly know Maria, but the film deliberately leaves you with ambiguities. Questions arise about why she enters a relationship with a wealthy man, why she has a child with him, why she loses weight, and even about her relationships with her two servants. This intentional lack of clarity led me to turn to Wikipedia after watching the film, hoping to find answers about Maria's life.nnThe film begins with Maria's death and ends with her death, creating a closed cycle in which we accompany her during her final days. Through two distinct layers-black-and-white imagery depicting scenes from her past, and low-quality color footage showing fragments of her life-we witness a woman in the throes of a midlife crisis at fifty-three, succumbing to self-destruction. While the film intentionally leaves gaps in Maria's story, there are subtle hints that contribute to understanding the characters. For instance, Onassis's reference to Hermes from Greek mythology, and his claim that he himself is Hermes, helps the viewer grasp his character. Hermes, after all, was a trickster and a mediator between mortals and the gods of Olympus.nnOverall, Maria excels in direction, atmosphere, and lighting, effectively conveying the sense of loneliness experienced by its protagonist. However, if your goal is to learn about Maria the opera singer through this film, it is unlikely to offer much insight.

This film is just awful. The lead actors act with sentiments, which are hopelessly unrealistic. The remainder of the cast a superfluous add-on. The scenery is bland, the emotions do not match the action, there is no real depth to the plot. Indeed the train from Warsaw is the only real Polish entity that is shown in any depth,nnThe "buddies" are like oil and water with little sign that they even know much about each other. Their main interaction is smoking marijuana in a country where it is quite illegal.nnThe "Jewish" scenery is minimal and almost irrelevant.nnThe cousins talk about their holocaust survivor grandmother, Dory, but provide no real emotion or detail about her. Eighty-five years after the Nazi invasion of Poland the fact that grandma's old home still stands is surprising. However, the fact that the residence has no discernible Jewish elements is unremarkable.nnGo see a better movie, like Ishtar. This one a bigger turkey than a float in a Thanksgiving day parade.

Worst movie I've ever seen. If I could give negative a thousand stars I would. I'd rather re-watch The Human Centipede than ever watch this crap again. A wholesome story about an aging woman who risks her marriage and career for an affair with a fumbling idiot who isn't even very hot and then she ultimately has zero consequences at the end. I'm sure it was aiming for artsy and edgy (maybe even empowering?) but missed completely.nnNicole Kidman has an amazing plastic surgeon for her body, not so much for her face (which we spend half of the movie staring directly into while she fakes oragams). The actor who plays the idiot she has an affair with annoyed the crap out of me because he's wishy washy with his dominance; one minute he seems confident the next confused and angry. Ok, she wants something dangerous and exciting, but why this semi attractive, semi assertive reject? He's not so much sexy as he is creepy, so much so I was expecting some sort of Fatal Attraction twist (which would have, maybe, made the movie interesting, but alas another disappointment). Antonio Banderas was amazing in this movie. He is the only believable character.nnThe sex scenes were more odd than hot to me. Before you get upset and say, "You just don't like kinky stuff or dom/sub stuff," let me assure you that you are wrong. I just like good acting, a good story line, and believable dominance portrayal. I think they were trying to push boundaries but the actual sex scenes were lack luster and repetitive. If you like being sightly treated like a dog or cat before mediocre sex, this movie is for you.

High quality production, with space for the viewer, to actually receive a deeper message. Grand directing work. And a story that has never been less or more up-to-date then to now. More and more corruption world wide revealed, this series talks to the audience giving the chance to oberseve the world wide mechanisms of enabling corruption starting within ones own family home. The film does not give directive to what is right or wrong but again gives masterfully space to come to ones own realisations and conclusion. No sex money making lame blockbuster as let's face it so many are. Grand acting and video editing and cut as well. More please.
